column1: DOMESTIC AFFAIRS
I. THE ECONOMIC OUTLOOK

Prophets of doom predicted that the United States could not escape a runaway inflation during the war and an economic collapse after the war. These predictions have not been borne out. On the contrary
column2: the record of economic stabilization during the war and during the period of reconversion has been an outstanding accomplishment.

column1: We know
column2: however
column3: that nothing is as dangerous as overconfidence
column4: in war or in peace. We have had to fight hard to hold the line. We have made strenuous efforts to speed reconversion. But neither the danger of a postwar inflation nor of a subsequent collapse in production and employment is yet overcome. We must base our policies not on unreasoning optimism or pessimism but upon a candid recognition of our objectives and upon a careful analysis of foreseeable trends.

column1: Any precise appraisal of the economic outlook at this time is particularly difficult. The period of demobilization and reconversion is fraught with uncertainties. There are also serious gaps in our statistical information. Certain tendencies are
column2: however
column3: fairly clear and recognition of them should serve as background for the consideration of next year's Federal Program. In general
column4: the outlook for business is good
column5: and it is likely to continue to be good--provided we control inflation and achieve peace in management- labor relations.

column1: Civilian production and employment can be expected to increase throughout the next year. This does not mean
column2: however
column3: that continuing full employment is assured. It is probable that demobilization of the armed forces will proceed faster than the increase in civilian employment opportunities. Even if substantial further withdrawals from the labor market occur
column4: unemployment will increase temporarily. The extent to which this unemployment will persist depends largely on the speed of industrial expansion and the effectiveness of the policies of the Federal Government.

column1: Along with extraordinary demand there are still at this time many critical shortages resulting from the war. These extraordinary demands and shortages may lead to a speculative boom
column2: especially in the price of securities
column3: real estate
column4: and inventories.

column1: Therefore
column2: our chief worry still is inflation.

column1: While we control this inflationary pressure we must look forward to the time when this extraordinary demand will subside. It will be years before we catch up with the demand for housing. The extraordinary demand for other durable goods
column2: for the replenishment of inventories
column3: and for exports may be satisfied earlier. No backlog of demand can exist very long in the face of our tremendous productive capacity. We must expect again to face the problem of shrinking demand and consequent slackening in sales
column4: production
column5: and employment. This possibility of a deflationary spiral in the future will exist unless we now plan and adopt an effective full employment program.

column1: 2. GENERAL POLICIES--IMMEDIATE AND LONG-RANGE
During the war
column2: production for civilian use was limited by war needs and available manpower. Economic stabilization required measures to spread limited supplies equitably by rationing
column3: price controls
column4: increased taxes
column5: savings bond campaigns
column6: and credit controls. Now
column7: with the surrender of our enemies
column8: economic stabilization requires that policies be directed toward promoting an increase in supplies at low unit prices.

column1: We must encourage the development of resources and enterprises in all parts of the country
column2: particularly in underdeveloped areas. For example
column3: the establishment of new peacetime industries in the Western States and in the South would
column4: in my judgment
column5: add to existing production and markets rather than merely bring about a shifting of production. I am asking the Secretaries of Agriculture
column6: Commerce
column7: and Labor to explore jointly methods for stimulating new industries
column8: particularly in areas with surplus agricultural labor.

column1: We must also aid small businessmen and particularly veterans who are competent to start their own businesses. The establishment and development of efficient small business ventures
column2: I believe
column3: will not take away from
column4: but rather will add to
column5: the total business of all enterprises.

column1: Even with maximum encouragement of production
column2: we cannot hope to remove scarcities within a short time. The most serious deficiencies will persist in the fields of residential housing
column3: building materials
column4: and consumers' durable goods. The critical situation makes continued rent control
column5: price control
column6: and priorities
column7: allocations
column8: and inventory controls absolutely essential. Continued control of consumer credit will help to reduce the pressure on prices of durable goods and will also prolong the period during which the backlog demand will be effective.

column1: While we are meeting these immediate needs we must look forward to a long-range program of security and increased standard of living.
The best protection of purchasing power is a policy of full production and full employment opportunities. Obviously
column2: an employed worker is a better customer than an unemployed worker. There always will be
column3: however
column4: some frictional unemployment. In the present period of transition we must deal with such temporary unemployment as results from the fact that demobilization will proceed faster than reconversion or industrial expansion. Such temporary unemployment is probably unavoidable in a period of rapid change. The unemployed worker is a victim of conditions beyond his control. He should be enabled to maintain a reasonable standard of living for himself and his family.

column1: The most serious difficulty in the path of reconversion and expansion is the establishment of a fair wage structure.
The ability of labor and management to work together
column2: and the wage and price policies which they develop
column3: are social and economic issues of first importance.

column1: Both labor and management have a special interest. Labor's interest is very direct and personal because working conditions
column2: wages
column3: and prices affect the very life and happiness of the worker and his family.

column1: Management has a no less direct interest because on management rests the responsibility for conducting a growing and prosperous business.

But management and labor have identical interests in the long run. Good wages mean good markets. Good business means more jobs and better wages. In this age of cooperation and in our highly organized economy the problems of one very soon become the problems of all.
Better human relationships are an urgent need to which organized labor and management should address themselves. No government policy can make men understand each other
column2: agree
column3: and get along unless they conduct themselves in a way to foster mutual respect and good will.

column1: The Government can
column2: however
column3: help to develop machinery which
column4: with the backing of public opinion
column5: will assist labor and management to resolve their disagreements in a peaceful manner and reduce the number and duration of strikes.

column1: All of us realize that productivity--increased output per man--is in the long run the basis of our standard of living. Management especially must realize that if labor is to work wholeheartedly for an increase in production
column2: workers must be given a just share of increased output in higher wages.

column1: Most industries and most companies have adequate leeway within which to grant substantial wage increases. These increases will have a direct effect in increasing consumer demand to the high levels needed. Substantial wage increases are good business for business because they assure a large market for their products; substantial wage increases are good business for labor because they increase labor's standard of living; substantial wage increases are good business for the country as a whole because capacity production means an active
column2: healthy
column3: friendly citizenry enjoying the benefits of democracy under our free enterprise system.

column1: Labor and management in many industries have been operating successfully under the Government's wage-price policy. Upward revisions of wage scales have been made in thousands of establishments throughout the Nation since VJ-day. It is estimated that about 6 million workers
column2: or more than 20 percent of all employees in nonagricultural and nongovernmental establishments
column3: have received wage increases since August 18
column4: 1945. The amounts of increases given by individual employers concentrate between 10 and 15 percent
column5: but range from less than 5 percent to over 30 percent.

column1: The United States Conciliation Service since VJ-day has settled over 3
column2: 000 disputes affecting over 1
column4: 000 workers without a strike threat and has assisted in settling about 1
column5: 300 disputes where strikes were threatened which involved about 500
column6: 000 workers. Only workers directly involved
column7: and not those in related industries who might have been indirectly affected
column8: are included in these estimates.

column1: Many of these adjustments have occurred in key industries and would have seemed to us major crises if they had not been settled peaceably.
Within the framework of the wage-price policy there has been definite success
column2: and it is to be expected that this success will continue in a vast majority of the cases arising in the months ahead.

column1: However
column2: everyone who realizes the extreme need for a swift and orderly reconversion must feel a deep concern about the number of major strikes now in progress. If long continued
column3: these strikes could put a heavy brake on our program.

column1: I have already made recommendations to the Congress as to the procedure best adapted to meeting the threat of work stoppages in Nation-wide industries without sacrificing the fundamental rights of labor to bargain collectively and ultimately to strike in support of their position.
If we manage our economy properly
column2: the future will see us on a level of production half again as high as anything we have ever accomplished in peacetime. Business can in the future pay higher wages and sell for lower prices than ever before. This is not true now for all companies
column3: nor will it ever be true for all
column4: but for business generally it is true.

column1: We are relying on all concerned to develop
column2: through collective bargaining
column3: wage structures that are fair to labor
column4: allow for necessary business incentives
column5: and conform with a policy designed to "hold the line" on prices.

column1: Production and more production was the byword during the war and still is during the transition from war to peace. However
column2: when deferred demand slackens
column3: we shall once again face the deflationary dangers which beset this and other countries during the 1930's. Prosperity can be assured only by a high level of demand supported by high current income; it cannot be sustained by deferred needs and use of accumulated savings.

column1: If we take the right steps in time we can certainly avoid the disastrous excesses of runaway booms and headlong depressions. We must not let a year or two of prosperity lull us into a false feeling of security and a repetition of the mistakes of the 1920's that culminated in the crash of 1929.

During the year ahead the Government will be called upon to act in many important fields of economic policy from taxation and foreign trade to social security and housing. In every case there will be alternatives. We must choose the alternatives which will best measure up to our need for maintaining production and employment in the future. We must never lose sight of our long-term objectives: the broadening of markets--the maintenance of steadily rising demand. This demand can come from only three sources: consumers
column2: businesses
column3: or government.

column1: In this country the job of production and distribution is in the hands of businessmen
column2: farmers
column3: workers
column4: and professional people -- in the hands of our citizens. We want to keep it that way. However
column5: it is the Government's responsibility to help business
column6: labor
column7: and farmers do their jobs.

column1: There is no question in my mind that the Government
column2: acting on behalf of all the people
column3: must assume the ultimate responsibility for the economic health of the Nation. There is no other agency that can. No other organization has the scope or the authority
column4: nor is any other agency accountable
column5: to all the people. This does not mean that the Government has the sole responsibility
column6: nor that it can do the job alone
column7: nor that it can do the job directly.

column1: All of the policies of the Federal Government must be geared to the objective of sustained full production and full employment--to raise consumer purchasing power and to encourage business investment. The programs we adopt this year and from now on will determine our ability to achieve our objectives. We must continue to pay particular attention to our fiscal
column2: monetary
column3: and tax policy
column4: programs to aid business--especially small business--and transportation
column5: labor-management relations and wage-price policy
column6: social security and health
column7: education
column8: the farm program
column9: public works
column10: housing and resource development
column11: and economic foreign policy.

column1: For example
column2: the kinds of tax measures we have at different times--whether we raise our revenue in a way to encourage consumer spending and business investment or to discourage it--have a vital bearing on this question. It is affected also by regular notions on consumer credit and by the money market
column3: which is strongly influenced by the rate of interest on Government securities. It is affected by almost every step we take.

column1: In short
column2: the way we handle the proper functions of government
column3: the way we time the exercise of our traditional and legitimate governmental functions
column4: has a vital bearing on the economic health of the Nation.

column1: These policies are discussed in greater detail in the accompanying Fifth Quarterly Report of the Director of War Mobilization and Reconversion.
3. LEGISLATION HERETOFORE RECOMMENDED AND STILL PENDING
To attain some of these objectives and to meet the other needs of the United States in the reconversion and postwar period
column2: I have from time to time made various recommendations to the Congress.

column1: In making these recommendations I have indicated the reasons why I deemed them essential for progress at home and abroad. A few--a very few--of these recommendations have been enacted into law by the Congress. Most of them have not. I here reiterate some of them
column2: and discuss others later in this Message. I urge upon the Congress early consideration of them. Some are more urgent than others
column3: but all are necessary.

column1: (1) Legislation to authorize the President to create fact-finding boards for the prevention of stoppages of work in Nationwide industries after collective bargaining and conciliation and voluntary arbitration have failed--as recommended by me on December 3
(2) Enactment of a satisfactory full employment bill such as the Senate bill now in conference between the Senate and the House--as recommended by me on September 6
(3) Legislation to supplement the unemployment insurance benefits for unemployed workers now provided by the different States--as recommended by me on May 28
(4) Adoption of a permanent Fair Employment Practice Act--as recommended by me on September 6
(5) Legislation substantially raising the amount of minimum wages now provided by law--as recommended by me on September 6
(6) Legislation providing for a comprehensive program for scientific research--as recommended by me on September 6
(7) Legislation enacting a health and medical care program--as recommended by me on November 19
(8) Legislation adopting the program of universal training--as recommended by me on October 23
(9) Legislation providing an adequate salary scale for all Government employees in all branches of the Government--as recommended by me on September 6
(10) Legislation making provision for succession to the Presidency in the event of the death or incapacity or disqualification of the President and Vice President--as recommended by me on June 19
(11) Legislation for the unification of the armed services--as recommended by me on December 19
(12) Legislation for the domestic use and control of atomic energy--as recommended by me on October 3
(13) Retention of the United States Employment Service in the Federal Government for a period at least up to June 30
column2: 1947--as recommended by me on September 6

column1: (14) Legislation to increase unemployment allowances for veterans in line with increases for civilians--as recommended by me on September 6
(15) Social security coverage for veterans for their period of military service--as recommended by me on September 6
(16) Extension of crop insurance--as recommended by me on September 6
(17) Legislation permitting the sale of ships by the Maritime Commission at home and abroad--as recommended by me on September 6
column2: 1945. I further recommend that this legislation include adequate authority for chartering vessels both here and abroad.

column1: (18) Legislation to take care of the stock piling of materials in which the United States is naturally deficient--as recommended by me on September 6
(19) Enactment of Federal airport legislation--as recommended by me on September 6
(20) Legislation repealing the Johnson Act on foreign loans--as recommended by me on September 6
(21) Legislation for the development of the Great Lakes-St. Lawrence River Basin--as recommended by me on October 3
4. POLICIES IN SPECIFIC FIELDS
(a) Extension of Price Control Act.
Today inflation is our greatest immediate domestic problem. So far the fight against inflation has been waged successfully. Since May 1943
column2: following President Roosevelt's "hold the line" order and in the face of the greatest pressures which this country has ever seen
column3: the cost of living index has risen only three percent. Wholesale prices in this same period have been held to an increase of two and one-half percent.

column1: This record has been made possible by the vigorous efforts of the agencies responsible for this program. But their efforts would have been fruitless if they had not had the solid support of the great masses of our people. The Congress is to be congratulated for its role in providing the legislation under which this work has been carried out.

On VJ-day it was clear to all thinking people that the danger of inflation was by no means over. Many of us can remember vividly our disastrous experience following World War I. Then the very restricted wartime controls were lifted too quickly
column2: and as a result prices and rents moved more rapidly upward. In the year and a half following the armistice
column3: rents
column4: food
column5: and clothing shot to higher and still higher levels.

column1: When the inevitable crash occurred less than two years after the end of the war
column2: business bankruptcies were widespread. Profits were wiped out. Inventory losses amounted to billions of dollars. Farm income dropped by one-half. Factory pay rolls dropped 40 percent
column3: and nearly one fifth of all our industrial workers were walking the streets in search of jobs. This was a grim greeting
column4: indeed
column5: to offer our veterans who had just returned from overseas.

column1: When I addressed the Congress in September
column2: I emphasized that we must continue to hold the price line until the production of goods caught up with the tremendous demands. Since then we have seen demonstrated the strength of the inflationary pressures which we have to face.

column1: Retail sales in the closing months of 1945 ran 12 percent above the previous peak for that season
column2: which came in 1944. Prices throughout the entire economy have been pressing hard against the price ceilings. The prices of real estate
column3: which cannot now be controlled under the law
column4: are rising rapidly. Commercial rents are not included in the present price control law and
column5: where they are not controlled by State law
column6: have been increasing
column7: causing difficulties to many businessmen.

column1: It will be impossible to maintain a high purchasing power or an expanding production unless we can keep prices at levels which can be met by the vast majority of our people. Full production is the greatest weapon against inflation
column2: but until we can produce enough goods to meet the threat of inflation the Government will have to exercise its wartime control over prices.

column1: I am sure that the people of the United States are disturbed by the demands made by several business groups with regard to price and rent control.

I am particularly disturbed at the effect such thinking may have on production and employment. If manufacturers continue to hold back goods and decline to submit bids when invited--as I am informed some are doing--in anticipation of higher prices which would follow the end of price controls
column2: we shall inevitably slow down production and create needless unemployment. On the other hand
column3: there are the vast majority of American businessmen who are not holding back goods
column4: but who need certainty about the Government pricing policy in order to fix their own long-range pricing policies.

column1: Businessmen are entitled therefore to a clear statement of the policy of the Government on the subject. Tenants and housewives
column2: farmers and workers--consumers in general--have an equal right.

column1: We are all anxious to eliminate unnecessary controls just as rapidly as we can do so. The steps that we have already taken in many directions toward that end are a clear indication of our policy.
The present Price Control Act expires on June 30
column2: 1946. If we expect to maintain a steady economy we shall have to maintain price and rent control for many months to come. The inflationary pressures on prices and rents
column3: with relatively few exceptions
column4: are now at an all-time peak. Unless the Price Control Act is renewed there will be no limit to which our price levels would soar. Our country would face a national disaster.

column1: We cannot wait to renew the act until immediately before it expires. Inflation results from psychological as well as economic conditions. The country has a clear right to know where the Congress stands on this all-important problem. Any uncertainty now as to whether the act will be extended gives rise to price speculation
column2: to withholding of goods from the market in anticipation of rising prices
column3: and to delays in achieving maximum production.

column1: I do not doubt that the Congress will be beset by many groups who will urge that the legislation that I have proposed should either be eliminated or modified to the point where it is nearly useless. The Congress has a clear responsibility to meet this challenge with courage and determination. I have every confidence that it will do so.
I strongly urge that the Congress now resolve all doubts and as soon as possible adopt legislation continuing rent and price control in effect for a full year from June 30
(b) Food subsidies.
If the price line is to be held
column2: if our people are to be protected against the inflationary dangers which confront us
column3: we must do more than extend the Price Control Act. In September we were hopeful that the inflationary pressures would by this time have begun to diminish. We were particularly hopeful on food. Indeed
column4: it was estimated that food prices at retail would drop from 3 to 5 per cent in the first six months following the end of the war.

column1: In anticipation of this decline in food prices
column2: it was our belief that food subsidies could be removed gradually during the winter and spring months
column3: and eliminated almost completely by June 30 of this year. It was our feeling that the food subsidies could be dropped without an increase to the consumer in the present level of food prices or in the over-all cost of living.

column1: As matters stand today
column2: however
column3: food prices are pressing hard against the ceilings. The expected decline in food prices has not occurred
column4: nor is it likely to occur for many months to come. This brings me to the reluctant conclusion that food subsidies must be continued beyond June 30

column1: If we fail to take this necessary step
column2: meat prices on July 1 will be from 3 to 5 cents higher than their average present levels; butter will be at least 12 cents a pound higher
column3: in addition to the 5 cents a pound increase of last fall; milk will increase from 1 to 2 cents a quart; bread will increase about 1 cent a loaf; sugar will increase over 1 cent a pound; cheese
column4: in addition to the increase of 4 cents now planned for the latter part of this month
column5: will go up an additional 8 cents. In terms of percentages we may find the cost-of-living index for food increased by more than 8 percent
column6: which in turn would result in more than a 3-percent increase in the cost of living.

column1: If prices of food were allowed to increase by these amounts
column2: I must make it clear to the Congress that
column3: in my opinion
column4: it would become extremely difficult for us to control the forces of inflation.

column1: None of us likes subsidies. Our farmers
column2: in particular
column3: have always been opposed to them.

column1: But I believe our farmers are as deeply conscious as any group in the land of the havoc which inflation can create. Certainly in the past eighteen months there has been no group which has fought any harder in support of the Government's price control program. I am confident that
column2: if the facts are placed before them and if they see clearly the evils between which we are forced to choose
column3: they will understand the reasons why subsidies must be continued.

column1: The legislation continuing the use of food subsidies into the new fiscal year should be tied down specifically to certain standards. A very proper requirement
column2: in my opinion
column3: would be that subsidies be removed as soon as it is indicated that the cost of living will decline below the present levels.

column1: (c) Extension of War Powers Act.
The Second War Powers Act has recently been extended by the Congress for six months instead of for a year. It will now expire
column2: unless further extended
column3: on June 30
column4: 1946. This act is the basis for priority and inventory controls governing the use of scarce materials
column5: as well as for other powers essential to orderly reconversion.

column1: I think that this Administration has given adequate proof of the fact that it desires to eliminate wartime controls as quickly and as expeditiously as possible. However
column2: we know that there will continue to be shortages of certain materials caused by the war even after June 30
column3: 1946. It is important that businessmen know now that materials in short supply are going to be controlled and distributed fairly as long as these war-born shortages continue.

column1: I
column2: therefore
column3: urge the Congress soon to extend the Second War Powers Act. We cannot afford to wait until just before the act expires next June. To wait would cause the controls to break down in a short time
column4: and would hamper our production and employment program.

column1: (d) Small business and competition.
A rising birth rate for small business
column2: and a favorable environment for its growth
column3: are not only economic necessities but also important practical demonstrations of opportunity in a democratic free society. A great many veterans and workers with new skills and experience will want to start in for themselves. The opportunity must be afforded them to do so. They are the small businessmen of the future.

column1: Actually when we talk about small business we are talking about almost all of the Nation's individual businesses. Nine out of every ten concerns fall into this category
column2: and 45 percent of all workers are employed by them. Between 30 and 40 percent of the total value of all business transactions are handled by small business.

column1: It is obvious national policy to foster the sound development of small business. It helps to maintain high levels of employment and national income and consumption of the goods and services that the Nation can produce. It encourages the competition that keeps our free enterprise economy vigorous and expanding. Small business
column2: because of its flexibility
column3: assists in the rapid exploitation of scientific and technological discoveries. Investment in small business can absorb a large volume of savings that might otherwise not be tapped.

column1: The Government should encourage and is encouraging small-business initiative and originality to stimulate progress through competition.
During the war
column2: the Smaller War Plants Corporation assisted small concerns to make a maximum contribution to victory. The work of the Smaller War Plants Corporation is being carried on in peacetime by the Federal Loan Agency and the Department of Commerce. The fundamental approach to the job of encouraging small concerns must be based on:

column1: 1.Arrangements for making private and public financial resources available on reasonable terms.
2.Provision of technical advice and assistance to business as a whole on production
column2: research
column3: and management problems. This will help equalize competitive relationships between large and small companies
column4: for many of the small companies cannot afford expensive technical research
column5: accounting
column6: and tax advice.

column1: 3.Elimination of trade practices and agreements which reduce competition and discriminate against new or small enterprises.

We speak a great deal about the free enterprise economy of our country. It is competition that keeps it free. It is competition that keeps it growing and developing. The truth is that we need far more competition in the future than we have had in the immediate past.
By strangling competition
column2: monopolistic activity prevents or deters investment in new or expanded production facilities. This lessens the opportunity for employment and chokes off new outlets for idle savings. Monopoly maintains prices at artificially high levels and reduces consumption which
column3: with lower prices
column4: would rise and support larger production and higher employment. Monopoly
column5: not being subject to competitive pressure
column6: is slow to take advantage of technical advances which would lower prices or improve quality. All three of these monopolistic activities very directly lower the standard of living--through higher prices and lower quality of product--which free competition would improve.

column1: The Federal Government must protect legitimate business and consumers from predatory and monopolistic practices by the vigilant enforcement of regulatory legislation. The program will be designed to have a maximum impact upon monopolistic bottlenecks and unfair competitive practices hindering expansion in employment.
During the war
column2: enforcement of antimonopoly laws was suspended in a number of fields. The Government must now take major steps not only to maintain enforcement of antitrust laws but to encourage new and competing enterprises in every way. The deferred demand of the war years and the large accumulations of liquid assets pro- vide ample incentive for expansion. Equalizing of business opportunity
column3: under full and free competition
column4: must be a prime responsibility in the reconversion period and in the years that follow. Many leading businessmen have recognized the importance of such action both to themselves and to the economy as a whole.

column1: But we must do more than break up trusts and monopolies after they have begun to strangle competition. We must take positive action to foster new
column2: expanding enterprises. By legislation and by administration we must take specific steps to discourage the formation or the strengthening of competition-restricting business. We must have an over-all antimonopoly policy which can be applied by all agencies of the Government in exercising the functions assigned to them--a policy designed to encourage the formation and growth of new and freely competitive enterprises.

column1: Among the many departments and agencies which have parts in the program affecting business and competition
column2: the Department of Commerce has a particularly important role. That is why I have recommended a substantial increase in appropriations for the next fiscal year for this Department.

column1: In its assistance to industry
column2: the Department of Commerce will concentrate its efforts on these primary objectives: Promotion of a large and well-balanced foreign trade; provision of improved technical assistance and management aids
column3: especially for small enterprises; and strengthening of basic statistics on business operations
column4: both by industries and by regions. To make new inventions and discoveries available more promptly to all businesses
column5: small and large
column6: the Department proposes to expand its own research activities
column7: promote research by universities
column8: improve Patent Office procedures
column9: and develop a greatly expanded system of field offices readily accessible to the businesses they serve.

column1: Many gaps exist in the private financial mechanism
column2: especially in the provision of long-term funds for small and medium-sized enterprises. In the peacetime economy the Reconstruction Finance Corporation will take the leadership in assuring adequate financing for small enterprises which cannot secure funds from other sources. Most of the funds should and will be provided by private lenders; but the Reconstruction Finance Corporation will share any unusual risks through guarantees of private loans
column3: with direct loans only when private capital is unwilling to participate on a reasonable basis.

column1: (e) Minimum wage.

Full employment and full production may be achieved only by maintaining a level of consumer income far higher than that of the prewar period. A high level of consumer income will maintain the market for the output of our mills
column2: farms
column3: and factories
column4: which we have demonstrated during the war years that we can produce. One of the basic steps which the Congress can take to establish a high level of consumer income is to amend the Fair Labor Standards Act to raise substandard wages to a decent minimum and to extend similar protection to additional workers who are not covered by the present act.

column1: Substandard wages are bad for business and for the farmer. Substandard wages provide only a substandard market for the goods and services produced by American industry and agriculture.

At the present time the Fair Labor Standards Act prescribes a minimum wage of 40 cents an hour for those workers who are covered by the act. The present minimum wage represents an annual income of about $800 to those continuously employed for 50 weeks--clearly a wholly inadequate budget for an American family. I am in full accord with the proposal now pending in the Congress that the statutory minimum be raised immediately to 65 cents an hour
column2: with further increases to 70 cents after one year and to 75 cents after two years. I also favor the proposal that the industry committee procedure be used to set rates higher than 65 cents per hour during the two-year interval before the 75-cent basic wage would otherwise become applicable.

column1: The proposed minimum wage of 65 cents an hour would assure the worker an annual income of about $1
column2: 300 a year in steady employment. This amount is clearly a modest goal. After considering cost-of living increases in recent years
column3: it is little more than a 10-cent increase over the present legal minimum. In fact
column4: if any large number of workers earn less than this amount
column5: we will find it impossible to maintain the levels of purchasing power needed to sustain the stable prosperity which we desire. Raising the minimum to 75 cents an hour will provide the wage earner with an annual income of $1
column6: 500 if he is fully employed.

column1: The proposed higher minimum wage levels are feasible without involving serious price adjustments or serious geographic dislocations.
Today about 20 percent of our manufacturing wage earners--or about 2 million-- earn less than 65 cents an hour. Because wages in most industries have risen during the war
column2: this is about the same as the proportion--17 percent--who were earning less than 40 cents an hour in 1941.

column1: I also recommend that minimum wage protection be extended to several groups of workers not now covered. The need for a decent standard of living is by no means limited to those workers who happen to be covered by the act as it now stands. It is particularly vital at this period of readjustment in the national economy and readjustment in employment of labor to extend minimum wage protection as far as possible.
Lifting the basic minimum wage is necessary
column2: it is justified as a matter of simple equity to workers
column3: and it will prove not only feasible but also directly beneficial to the Nation's employers.

column1: (f) Agricultural programs.

The farmers of America generally are entering the crop year of 1946 in better financial condition than ever before. Farm mortgage debt is the lowest in 30 years. Farmers' savings are the largest in history. Our agricultural plant is in much better condition than after World War I. Farm machinery and supplies are expected to be available in larger volume
column2: and farm labor problems will be less acute.

column1: The demand for farm products will continue strong during the next year or two because domestic purchases will be supplemented by a high level of exports and foreign relief shipments. It is currently estimated that from 7 to 10 percent of the total United States food supply may be exported in the calendar year 1946.
Farm prices are expected to remain at least at their present levels in the immediate future
column2: and for at least the next 12 months they are expected to yield a net farm income double the 1935-39 average and higher than in any year prior to 1943.

column1: We can look to the future of agriculture with greater confidence than in many a year in the past. Agriculture itself is moving confidently ahead
column2: planning for another year of big production
column3: taking definite and positive steps to lead the way toward an economy of abundance.

column1: Agricultural production goals for 1946 call for somewhat greater acreage than actually was planted in 1945. Agriculture is prepared to demonstrate that it can make a peacetime contribution as great as its contribution toward the winning of the war.
In spite of supplying our armed forces and our allies during the war with a fifth to a fourth of our total food output
column2: farmers were still able to provide our civilians with 8 percent more food per capita than the average for the five years preceding the war. Since the surrender of Japan
column3: civilian food consumption has risen still further. By the end of 1945 the amount of the increase in food consumption was estimated to be as high as 15 percent over the prewar average. The record shows that the people of this country want and need more food and that they will buy more food if only they have the jobs and the purchasing power. The first essential therefore in providing fully for the welfare of agriculture is to maintain full employment and a high level of purchasing power throughout the Nation.

column1: For the period immediately ahead we shall still have the problem of supplying enough food. If we are to do our part in aiding the war-stricken and starving countries some of the food desires of our own people will not be completely satisfied
column2: at least until these nations have had an opportunity to harvest another crop. During the next few months the need for food in the world will be more serious than at any time during the war. And
column3: despite the large shipments we have already made
column4: and despite what we shall send
column5: there remain great needs abroad.

column1: Beyond the relief feeding period
column2: there will still be substantial foreign outlets for our farm commodities. The chief dependence of the farmer
column3: however
column4: as always
column5: must be upon the buying power of our own people.

column1: The first obligation of the Government to agriculture for the reconversion period is to make good on its price-support commitments. This we intend to do
column2: with realistic consideration for the sound patterns of production that will contribute most to the long-time welfare of agriculture and the whole Nation. The period during which prices are supported will provide an opportunity for farmers individually to strengthen their position in changing over from a wartime to a peacetime basis of production. It will provide an opportunity for the Congress to review the needs of agriculture and make changes in national legislation where experience has shown changes to be needed. In this connection
column3: the Congress will wish to consider legislation to take the place of the 1937 Sugar Act which expires at the end of this year. During this period we must do a thorough job of basic planning to the end that agriculture shall be able to contribute its full share toward a healthy national economy.

column1: Our long-range agricultural policies should have two main objectives: First
column2: to assure the people on the farms a fair share of the national income; and
column3: second
column4: to encourage an agricultural production pattern that is best fitted to the Nation's needs. To accomplish this second objective we shall have to take into consideration changes that have taken place and will continue to take place in the production of farm commodities--changes that affect costs and efficiency and volume.

column1: What we seek ultimately is a high level of food production and consumption that will provide good nutrition for everyone. This cannot be accomplished by agriculture alone. We can be certain of our capacity to produce food
column2: but we have often failed to distribute it as well as we should and to see that our people can afford to buy it. The way to get good nutrition for the whole Nation is to provide employment opportunities and purchasing power for all groups that will enable them to buy full diets at market prices.

column1: Wherever purchasing power fails to reach this level we should see that they have some means of getting adequate food at prices in line with their ability to buy. Therefore
column2: we should have available supplementary programs that will enable all our people to have enough of the right kind of food.

column1: For example
column2: one of the best possible contributions toward building a stronger
column3: healthier Nation would be a permanent school-lunch program on a scale adequate to assure every school child a good lunch at noon. The Congress
column4: of course
column5: has recognized this need for a continuing school-lunch program and legislation to that effect has been introduced and hearings held. The plan contemplates the attainment of this objective with a minimum of Federal expenditures. I hope that the legislation will be enacted in time for a permanent program to start with the beginning of the school year next fall.

column1: We have the technical knowledge and the productive capacity to provide plenty of good food for every man
column2: woman
column3: and child in the United States. It is time we made that possibility a reality.

column1: (g) Resource development.
The strength of our Nation and the welfare of the people rest upon the natural resources of the country. We have learned that proper conservation of our lands
column2: including our forests and minerals
column3: and wise management of our waters will add immensely to our national wealth.

column1: The first step in the Government's conservation program must be to find out just what are our basic resources
column2: and how they should be used. We need to take
column3: as soon as possible
column4: an inventory of the lands
column5: the minerals
column6: and the forests of the Nation.

column1: During the war it was necessary to curtail some of our long-range plans for development of our natural resources
column2: and to emphasize programs vital to the prosecution of the war. Work was suspended on a number of flood control and reclamation projects and on the development of our national forests and parks. This work must now be resumed
column3: and new projects must be undertaken to provide essential services and to assist in the process of economic development.

column1: The rivers of America offer a great opportunity to our generation in the management of the national wealth. By a wise use of Federal funds
column2: most of which will be repaid into the Treasury
column3: the scourge of floods and drought can be curbed
column4: water can be brought to arid lands
column5: navigation can be extended
column6: and cheap power can be brought alike to the farms and to the industries of our land.

column1: Through the use of the waters of the Columbia River
column2: for example
column3: we are creating a rich agricultural area as large as the State of Delaware. At the same time
column4: we are producing power at Grand Coulee and at Bonneville which played a mighty part in winning the war and which will found a great peacetime industry in the Northwest. The Tennessee Valley Authority will resume its peacetime program of promoting full use of the resources of the Valley. We shall continue our plans for the development of the Missouri Valley
column5: the Arkansas Valley
column6: and the Central Valley of California.

column1: The Congress has shown itself alive to the practical requirements for a beneficial use of our water resources by providing that preference in the sale of power be given to farmers' cooperatives and public agencies. The public power program thus authorized must continue to be made effective by building the necessary generating and transmission facilities to furnish the maximum of firm power needed at the wholesale markets
column2: which are often distant from the dam sites.

column1: These great developmental projects will open the frontiers of agriculture
column2: industry
column3: and commerce. The employment opportunities thus offered will also go far to ease the transition from war to peace.

column1: (h) Public works.
During the war even urgently needed Federal
column2: State
column3: and local construction projects were deferred in order to release resources for war production. In resuming public works construction
column4: it is desirable to proceed only at a moderate rate
column5: since demand for private construction will be abnormally high for some time. Our public works program should be timed to reach its peak after demand for private construction has begun to taper off. Meanwhile
column6: however
column7: plans should be prepared if we are to act promptly when the present extraordinary private demand begins to run out.

column1: The Congress made money available to Federal agencies for their public works planning in the fiscal year 1946. I strongly recommend that this policy be continued and extended in the fiscal year 1947.
State and local governments have an essential role to play in a national public works program. In my message of September 6
column3: I recommended that the Congress vote such grants to State and local governments as will insure that each level of government makes its proper contribution to a balanced public construction program. Specifically
column4: the Federal Government should aid State and local governments in planning their own public works programs
column5: in undertaking projects related to Federal programs of regional development
column6: and in constructing such public works as are necessary to carry out the various policies of the Federal Government.

column1: Early in 1945 the Congress made available advances to State and local governments for planning public works projects
column2: and recently made additional provision to continue these advances through the fiscal year 1946. I believe that further appropriations will be needed for the same purpose for the fiscal year 1947.

column1: The Congress has already made provision for highway programs. It is now considering legislation which would expand Federal grants and loans in several other fields
column2: including construction of airports
column3: hospital and health centers
column4: housing
column5: water pollution control facilities
column6: and educational plant facilities. I hope that early action will be taken to authorize these Federal programs.

column1: With respect to public works of strictly local importance
column2: State and local governments should proceed without Federal assistance except in planning. This rule should be subject to review when and if the prospect of highly adverse general economic developments warrants it.

column1: All loans and grants for public works should be planned and administered in such a way that they are brought into accord with the other elements of the Federal Program.

Our long-run objective is to achieve a program of direct Federal and Federally assisted public works which is planned in advance and synchronized with business conditions. In this way it can make its greatest contribution to general economic stability.
(i) National housing program.
Last September I stated in my message to the Congress that housing was high on the list of matters calling for decisive action.
Since then the housing shortage in countless communities
column2: affecting millions of families
column3: has magnified this call to action.

column1: Today we face both an immediate emergency and a major postwar problem.

Since VJ-day the wartime housing shortage has been growing steadily worse and pressure on real estate values has increased. Returning veterans often cannot find a satisfactory place for their families to live
column2: and many who buy have to pay exorbitant prices. Rapid demobilization inevitably means further overcrowding.

column1: A realistic and practical attack on the emergency will require aggressive action by local governments
column2: with Federal aid
column3: to exploit all opportunities and to give the veterans as far as possible first chance at vacancies. It will require continuation of rent control in shortage areas as well as legislation to permit control of sales prices. It will require maximum conversion of temporary war units for veterans' housing and their transportation to communities with the most pressing needs; the Congress has already appropriated funds for this purpose.

column1: The inflation in the price of housing is growing daily.
As a result of the housing shortage
column2: it is inevitable that the present dangers of inflation in home values will continue unless the Congress takes action in the immediate future.

column1: Legislation is now pending in the Congress which would provide for ceiling prices for old and new houses. The authority to fix such ceilings is essential. With such authority
column2: our veterans and other prospective home owners would be protected against a skyrocketing of home prices. The country would be protected from the extension of the present inflation in home values which
column3: if allowed to continue
column4: will threaten not only the stabilization program but our opportunities for attaining a sustained high level of home construction.

column1: Such measures are necessary stopgaps--but only stopgaps. This emergency action
column2: taken alone
column3: is good--but not enough. The housing shortage did not start with the war or with demobilization; it began years before that and has steadily accumulated. The speed with which the Congress establishes the foundation for a permanent
column4: long-range housing program will determine how effectively we grasp the immense opportunity to achieve our goal of decent housing and to make housing a major instrument of continuing prosperity and full employment in the years ahead. It will determine whether we move forward to a stable and healthy housing enterprise and toward providing a decent home for every American family.

column1: Production is the only fully effective answer. To get the wheels turning
column2: I have appointed an emergency housing expediter. I have approved establishment of priorities designed to assure an ample share of scarce materials to builders of houses for which veterans will have preference. Additional price and wage adjustments will be made where necessary
column3: and other steps will be taken to stimulate greater production of bottleneck items. I recommend consideration of every sound method for expansion in facilities for insurance of privately financed housing by the Federal Housing Administration and resumption of previously authorized low-rent public housing projects suspended during the war.

column1: In order to meet as many demands of the emergency situation as possible
column2: a program of emergency measures is now being formulated for action. These will include steps in addition to those already taken. As quickly as this program can be formulated
column3: announcement will be made.

column1: Last September I also outlined to the Congress the basic principles for the kind of decisive
column2: permanent legislation necessary for a long-range housing program.

column1: These principles place paramount the fact that housing construction and financing for the overwhelming majority of our citizens should be done by private enterprise. They contemplate also that we afford governmental encouragement to privately financed house construction for families of moderate income
column2: through extension of the successful system of insurance of housing investment; that research be undertaken to develop better and cheaper methods of building homes; that communities be assisted in appraising their housing needs; that we commence a program of Federal aid
column3: with fair local participation
column4: to stimulate and promote the rebuilding and redevelopment of slums and blighted areas--with maximum use of private capital. It is equally essential that we use public funds to assist families of low income who could not otherwise enjoy adequate housing
column5: and that we quicken our rate of progress in rural housing.

column1: Legislation now under consideration by the Congress provides for a comprehensive attack jointly by private enterprise
column2: State and local authorities
column3: and the Federal Government. This legislation would make permanent the National Housing Agency and give it authority and funds for much needed technical and economic research. It would provide additional stimulus for privately financed housing construction. This stimulus consists of establishing a new system of yield insurance to encourage large-scale investment in rental housing and broadening the insuring powers of the Federal Housing Administration and the lending powers of the Federal savings and loan associations.

column1: Where private industry cannot build
column2: the Government must step in to do the job. The bill would encourage expansion in housing available for the lowest income groups by continuing to provide direct subsidies for low-rent housing and rural housing. It would facilitate land assembly for urban redevelopment by loans and contributions to local public agencies where the localities do their share.

column1: Prompt enactment of permanent housing legislation along these lines will not interfere with the emergency action already under way. On the contrary
column2: it would lift us out of a potentially perpetual state of housing emergency. It would offer the best hope and prospect to millions of veterans and other American families that the American system can offer more to them than temporary makeshifts.

column1: I have said before that the people of the United States can be the best housed people in the world. I repeat that assertion
column2: and I welcome the cooperation of the Congress in achieving that goal.

column1: (j) Social security and health.

Our Social Security System has just celebrated its tenth anniversary. During the past decade this program has supported the welfare and morale of a large part of our people by removing some of the hazards and hardships of the aged
column2: the unemployed
column3: and widows and dependent children.

column1: But
column2: looking back over 10 years' experience and ahead to the future
column3: we cannot fail to see defects and serious inadequacies in our system as it now exists. Benefits are in many cases inadequate; a great many persons are excluded from coverage; and provision has not been made for social insurance to cover the cost of medical care and the earnings lost by the sick and the disabled.

column1: In the field of old-age security
column2: there seems to be no adequate reason for excluding such groups as the self-employed
column3: agricultural and domestic workers
column4: and employees of non-profit organizations. Since many of these groups earn wages too low to permit significant savings for old age
column5: they are in special need of the assured income that can be provided by old-age insurance.

column1: We must take urgent measures for the readjustment period ahead. The Congress for some time has been considering legislation designed to supplement at Federal expense
column2: during the immediate reconversion period
column3: compensation payments to the unemployed. Again I urge the Congress to enact legislation liberalizing unemployment compensation benefits and extending the coverage. Providing for the sustained consumption by the unemployed persons and their families is more than a welfare policy; it is sound economic policy. A sustained high level of consumer purchases is a basic ingredient of a prosperous economy.

column1: During the war
column2: nearly 5 million men were rejected for military service because of physical or mental defects which in many cases might have been prevented or corrected. This is shocking evidence that large sections of the population are at substandard levels of health. The need for a program that will give everyone opportunity for medical care is obvious. Nor can there be any serious doubt of the Government's responsibility for helping in this human and social problem.

column1: The comprehensive health program which I recommended on November 19
column3: will require substantial additions to the Social Security System and
column4: in conjunction with other changes that need to be made
column5: will require further consideration of the financial basis for social security. The system of prepaid medical care which I have recommended is expected eventually to require amounts equivalent to 4 percent of earnings up to $3
column6: 600 a year
column7: which is about the average of present expenditures by individuals for medical care. The pooling of medical costs
column8: under a plan which permits each individual to make a free choice of doctor and hospital
column9: would assure that individuals receive adequate treatment and hospitalization when they are faced with emergencies for which they cannot budget individually. In addition
column10: I recommended insurance benefits to replace part of the earnings lost through temporary sickness and permanent disability.

column1: Even without these proposed major additions
column2: it would now be time to undertake a thorough reconsideration of our social security laws. The structure should be expanded and liberalized. Provision should be made for extending coverage credit to veterans for the period of their service in the armed forces. In the financial provisions we must reconcile the actuarial needs of social security
column3: including health insurance
column4: with the requirements of a revenue system that is designed to promote a high level of consumption and full employment.

column1: (k) Education.
Although the major responsibility for financing education rests with the States
column2: some assistance has long been given by the Federal Government. Further assistance is desirable and essential. There are many areas and some whole States where good schools cannot be provided without imposing an undue local tax burden on the citizens. It is essential to provide adequate elementary and secondary schools everywhere
column3: and additional educational opportunities for large numbers of people beyond the secondary level. Accordingly
column4: I repeat the proposal of last year's Budget Message that the Federal Government provide financial aid to assist the States in assuring more nearly equal opportunities for a good education. The proposed Federal grants for current educational expenditures should be made for the purpose of improving the educational systern where improvement is most needed. They should not be used to replace existing non-Federal expenditures
column5: or even to restore merely the situation which existed before the war.

column1: In the future we expect incomes considerably higher than before the war. Higher incomes should make it possible for State and local governments and for individuals to support higher and more nearly adequate expenditures for education. But inequality among the States will still remain
column2: and Federal help will still be needed.

column1: As a part of our total public works program
column2: consideration should be given to the need for providing adequate buildings for schools and other educational institutions. In view of current arrears in the construction of educational facilities
column3: I believe that legislation to authorize grants for educational facilities
column4: to be matched by similar expenditures by State and local authorities
column5: should receive the favorable consideration of the Congress.

column1: The Federal Government has not sought
column2: and will not seek
column3: to dominate education in the States. It should continue its historic role of leadership and advice and
column4: for the purpose of equalizing educational opportunity
column5: it should extend further financial support to the cause of education in areas where this is desirable.

column1: (l) Federal Government personnel.

The rapid reconversion of the Federal Government from war to peace is reflected in the demobilization of its civilian personnel. The number of these employees in continental United States has been reduced by more than 500
column2: 000 from the total of approximately 2
column4: 000 employed in the final months of the war. I expect that by next June we shall have made a further reduction of equal magnitude and that there will be continuing reductions during the next fiscal year. Of the special wartime agencies now remaining
column5: only a few are expected to continue actively into the next fiscal year.

column1: At the same time that we have curtailed the number of employees
column2: we have shortened the workweek by one-sixth or more throughout the Government and have restored holidays. The process of readjustment has been complicated and costs have been increased by a heavy turn-over in the remaining personnel-particularly by the loss of some of our best administrators. Thousands of war veterans have been reinstated or newly employed in the civil service. Many civilians have been transferred from war agencies to their former peacetime agencies. Recruitment standards
column3: which had to be relaxed during the war
column4: are now being tightened.

column1: The elimination last autumn of overtime work for nearly all Federal employees meant a sharp cut in their incomes. For salaried workers
column2: the blow was softened but by no means offset by the increased rates of pay which had become effective July 1. Further adjustments to compensate for increased living costs are required. Moreover
column3: we have long needed a general upward revision of Federal Government salary scales at all levels in all branches-legislative
column4: judicial
column5: and executive. Too many in Government have had to sacrifice too much in economic advantage to serve the Nation.

column1: Adequate salaries will result in economies and improved efficiency in the conduct of Government business-gains that will far outweigh the immediate costs. I hope the Congress will expedite action on salary legislation for all Federal employees in all branches of the Government. The only exception I would make is in the case of workers whose pay rates are established by wage boards; a blanket adjustment would destroy the system by which their wages are kept aligned with prevailing rates in particular localities. The wage boards should he sensitive now
column2: as they were during the war
column3: to changes in local prevailing wage rates and should make adjustments

column1: I hope also that the Congress may see fit to enact legislation for the adequate protection of the health and safety of Federal employees
column2: for their coverage under a system of unemployment compensation
column3: and for their return at Government expense to their homes after separation from wartime service.

column1: (m) Territories
column2: insular possessions
column3: and the District of Columbia.

column1: The major governments of the world face few problems as important and as perplexing as those relating to dependent peoples. This Government is committed to the democratic principle that it is for the dependent peoples themselves to decide what their status shall be. To this end I asked the Congress last October to provide a means by which the people of Puerto Rico might choose their form of government and ultimate status with respect to the United States. I urge
column2: too
column3: that the Congress promptly accede to the wishes of the people of Hawaii that the Territory be admitted to statehood in our Union
column4: and that similar action be taken with respect to Alaska as soon as it is certain that this is the desire of the people of that great Territory. The people of the Virgin Islands should be given an increasing measure of self-government.

column1: We have already determined that the Philippine Islands are to be independent on July 4
column2: 1946. The ravages of war and enemy occupation
column3: however
column4: have placed a heavy responsibility upon the United States. I urge that the Congress complete
column5: as promptly and as generously as may be possible
column6: legislation which will aid economic rehabilitation for the Philippines. This will be not only a just acknowledgment of the loyalty of the people of the Philippines
column7: but it will help to avoid the economic chaos which otherwise will he their heritage from our common war. Perhaps no event in the long centuries of colonialism gives more hope for the pattern of the future than the independence of the Philippines.

column1: The District of Columbia
column2: because of its special relation to the Federal Government
column3: has been treated since 18oo as a dependent area. We should move toward a greater measure of local self-government consistent with the constitutional status of the District. We should take adequate steps to assure that citizens of the United States are not denied their franchise merely because they reside at the Nation's Capital.

column1: III. THE BUDGET FOR THE FEDERAL PROGRAM FOR THE FISCAL YEAR 1947 SUMMARY OF THE BUDGET For the first time since the fiscal year 1930 the Budget for the next fiscal year will require no increase in the national debt.
Expenditures of all kinds
column2: authorized and recommended
column3: in the next year are estimated at just above 35.8 billion dollars. Net receipts are estimated at 31.5 billion dollars. The estimated difference of 4.3 billion dollars will be met by a reduction in the very substantial balance which will be in the Treasury during the next fiscal year.

column1: A large part of the activities outside defense and war liquidation
column2: aftermath of war
column3: and international finance
column4: classified as "other activities in a following table
column5: is still due to repercussions of the war. These "other activities include more than 2 billion dollars for aids to agriculture and net outlays for the Commodity Credit Corporation--almost double the expenditures for the same purposes in prewar years. This increase is due mainly to expenditures for purposes of price stabilization and price support resulting from the war food production program. Other increases in this category are due to the fact that certain wartime agencies now in the process of liquidation are included in this group of activities. If all expenditures for those activities which are directly or indirectly related to the war are excluded
column6: the residual expenditures are below those for corresponding activities in prewar years. In making this comparison account should be taken of the fact that
column7: while prewar expenditures were affected by direct relief and work relief for the unemployed
column8: the postwar budgets are affected by the considerable increase in pay rates and other increases in costs and prices.

column1: To elaborate
column2: the Budget
column3: as I have remarked above
column4: reflects on both sides of the ledger the Government's program as recommended by the Executive. It includes estimates not only of expenditures and receipts for which legislative authority already exists
column5: but also of expenditures and receipts for which authorization is recommended.

column1: The Budget total for the next fiscal year
column2: the year that ends on June 30
column4: is estimated at just above 35.8 billion dollars--about a third of the budgets for global war
column5: although nearly four times the prewar budgets. This estimate is based on the assumption that a rapid liquidation of the war program will be associated with rapid reconversion and expansion of peacetime production. The total includes net outlays of Government corporations.

column1: The estimated expenditures in the next and current fiscal year compare as follows with those of a year of global war and a prewar year:
TOTAL BUDGET EXPENDITURES Fiscal year: (in millions)
Although allowances for occupation
column2: demobilization
column3: and defense are drastically reduced in the fiscal year 1947
column4: they will still amount to 42 percent of the total Budget. The so-called "aftermath of war" expenditures account for a further 30 percent of the total. The total of all other programs
column5: which was drastically cut during the war
column6: is increasing again as liquidation of the war program proceeds and renewed emphasis is placed on the peacetime objectives of the Government.

column1: On the other side of the ledger
column2: net receipts are estimated at 31.5 billion dollars. This estimate assumes that all existing taxes will continue all through the fiscal year 1947. Included are the extraordinary receipts from the disposal of surplus property.

column1: As a result
column2: estimated expenditures will exceed estimated receipts by 4.3 billion dollars. This amount can be provided by a reduction in the cash balance in the Treasury. Thus
column3: after a long period of increasing public debt resulting from depression budgets and war budgets
column4: it is anticipated that no increase in the Federal debt will he required next year.

column1: The current fiscal year
column3: is a year of transition. When the year opened
column4: in July 1945
column5: we were still fighting a major war
column6: and Federal expenditures were running at an annual rate of about 100 billion dollars. By June 1946 that rate will be more than cut in half. The Budget total for the current fiscal year is now estimated at 67.2 billion dollars
column7: of which more than two-thirds provides for war and war liquidation. Since net receipts are estimated at 38.6 billion dollars
column8: there will be an excess of expenditures of 28.6 billion dollars for the current fiscal year.

column1: For all programs discussed in this Message I estimate the total of Budget appropriations and authorizations (including reappropriations and permanent appropriations) at 30
column2: 982 million dollars for the fiscal year 1947. Of this amount
column3: present permanent appropriations are expected to provide 5
column4: 755 million dollars

column1: We have won a great war- we
column2: the nations of plain people who hate war. In the test of that war we found a strength of unity that brought us through - a strength that crushed the power of those who sought by force to deny our faith in the dignity of man.

column1: During this trial the voices of disunity among us were silent or were subdued to an occasional whine that warned us that they were still among us. Those voices are beginning to cry aloud again. We must learn constantly to turn deaf ears to them. They are voices which foster fear and suspicion and intolerance and hate. Thy seek to destroy our harmony
column2: our understanding of each other
column3: our American tradition of "live and let live." They have become busy again
column4: trying to set race against race
column5: creed against creed
column6: farmer against city dweller
column7: worker against employer
column8: people against their own governments. They seek only to do us mischief. They must not prevail.

column1: It should be impossible for any man to contemplate without a sense of personal humility the tremendous events of the 12 months since the last annual Message
column2: the great tasks that confront us
column3: the new and huge problems of the coming months and years. Yet these very things justify the deepest confidence in the future of this Nation of free men and women. The plain people of this country found the courage and the strength
column4: the self-discipline
column5: and the mutual respect to fight and to win
column6: with the help of our allies
column7: under God. I doubt if the tasks of the future are more difficult. But if they are
column8: then I say that our strength and our knowledge and our understanding will be equal to those tasks.@

column1: Harry S. Truman|Annual Message to the Congress on the State of the Union|1947-01-06|@Mr. President
column2: Mr. Speaker
column3: Members of the Congress of the United States: It looks like a good many of you have moved over to the left since I was here last.

column1: I come before you today to report on the State of the Union and
column2: in the words of the Constitution
column3: to recommend such measures as I judge necessary and expedient.

column1: I come also to welcome you as you take up your duties and to discuss with you the manner in which you and I should fulfill our obligations to the American people during the next 2 years.
The power to mold the future of this Nation lies in our hands-yours and mine
column2: and they are joined together by the Constitution.

column1: If in this year
column2: and in the next
column3: we can find the right course to take as each issue arises
column4: and if
column5: in spite of all difficulties
column6: we have the courage and the resolution to take that course
column7: then we shall achieve a state of well-being for our people without precedent in history. And if we continue to work with the other nations of the world earnestly
column8: patiently
column9: and wisely
column10: we can-granting a will for peace on the part of our neighbors make a lasting peace for the world.

column1: But
column2: if we are to realize these ends
column3: the Congress and the President
column4: during the next 2 years
column5: must work together. It is not unusual in our history that the majority of the Congress represents a party in opposition to the President's party. I am the twentieth President of the United States who
column6: at some time during his term of office
column7: has found his own party to be in the minority in one or both Houses of Congress. The first one was George Washington. Wilson was number eighteen
column8: and Hoover was number nineteen.

column1: I realize that on some matters the Congress and the President may have honest differences of opinion. Partisan differences
column2: however
column3: did not cause material disagreements as to the conduct of the war. Nor
column4: in the conduct of our international relations
column5: during and since the war
column6: have such partisan differences been material.

column1: On some domestic issues we may
column2: and probably shall
column3: disagree. That in itself is not to be feared. It is inherent in our form of Government. But there are ways of disagreeing; men who differ can still work together sincerely for the common good. We shall be risking the Nation's safety and destroying our opportunities for progress if we do not sett]e any disagreements in this spirit
column4: without thought of partisan advantage.

column1: As the year 1947 begins
column2: the state of our national economy presents great opportunities for all. We have virtually full employment
column3: our national production of goods and services is 50 percent higher than in any year prior to the war emergency. The national income in 1946 was higher than in any peace-time year. Our food production is greater than it has ever been. During the last 5 years our productive facilities have been expanded in almost every field. The American standard of living is higher now than ever before
column4: and when the housing shortage can be overcome it will be even higher.

column1: During the past few months we have removed at a rapid rate the emergency controls that the Federal Government had to exercise during the war. The remaining controls will be retained only as long as they are needed to protect the public. Private enterprise must be given the greatest possible freedom to continue the expansion of our economy.
In my proclamation of December 31
column3: I announced the termination of hostilities. This automatically ended certain temporary legislation and certain executive powers.

column1: Two groups of temporary laws still remain: the first are those which by Congressional mandate are to last during the "emergency"; the second are those which are to continue until the "termination of the war."
