A host of problems and projects in all 50 States, though not possible to include in this Message, deserves-and will receive--the attention of both the Congress and the Executive Branch. On most of these matters, Messages will be sent to the Congress within the next two weeks.

IV.

But all these problems pale when placed beside those which confront us around the world. No man entering upon this office, regardless of his party, regardless of his previous service in Washington, could fail to be staggered upon learning--even in this brief 10 day period--the harsh enormity of the trials through which we must pass in the next four years. Each day the crises multiply. Each day their solution grows more difficult. Each day we draw nearer the hour of maximum danger, as weapons spread and hostile forces grow stronger. I feel I must inform the Congress that our analyses over the last ten days make it clear that--in each of the principal areas of crisis--the tide of events has been running out and time has not been our friend.

In Asia, the relentless pressures of the Chinese Communists menace the security of the entire area--from the borders of India and South Viet Nam to the jungles of Laos, struggling to protect its newly-won independence. We seek in Laos what we seek in all Asia, and, indeed, in all of the world-freedom for the people and independence for the government. And this Nation shall persevere in our pursuit of these objectives. In Africa, the Congo has been brutally torn by civil strife, political unrest and public disorder. We shall continue to support the heroic efforts of the United Nations to restore peace and order--efforts which are now endangered by mounting tensions, unsolved problems, and decreasing support from many member states.

In Latin America, Communist agents seeking to exploit that region's peaceful revolution of hope have established a base on Cuba, only 90 miles from our shores. Our objection with Cuba is not over the people's drive for a better life. Our objection is to their domination by foreign and domestic tyrannies. Cuban social and economic reform should be encouraged. Questions of economic and trade policy can always be negotiated. But Communist domination in this Hemisphere can never be negotiated.

We are pledged to work with our sister republics to free the Americas of all such foreign domination and all tyranny, working toward the goal of a free hemisphere of free governments, extending from Cape Horn to the Arctic Circle.

In Europe our alliances are unfulfilled and in some disarray. The unity of NATO has been weakened by economic rivalry and partially eroded by national interest. It has not yet fully mobilized its resources nor fully achieved a common outlook. Yet no Atlantic power can meet on its own the mutual problems now facing us in defense, foreign aid, monetary reserves, and a host of other areas; and our close ties with those whose hopes and interests we share are among this Nation's most powerful assets.

Our greatest challenge is still the world that lies beyond the Cold War--but the first great obstacle is still our relations with the Soviet Union and Communist China. We must never be lulled into believing that either power has yielded its ambitions for world domination--ambitions which they forcefully restated only a short time ago. On the contrary, our task is to convince them that aggression and subversion will not be profitable routes to pursue these ends. Open and peaceful competition--for prestige, for markets, for scientific achievement, even for men's minds--is something else again. For if Freedom and Communism were to compete for man's allegiance in a world at peace, I would look to the future with ever increasing confidence.

To meet this array of challenges--to fulfill the role we cannot avoid on the world scene--we must reexamine and revise our whole arsenal of tools: military, economic and political.

One must not overshadow the other: On the Presidential Coat of Arms, the American eagle holds in his right talon the olive branch, while in his left he holds a bundle of arrows. We intend to give equal attention to both.

First, we must strengthen our military tools. We are moving into a period of uncertain risk and great commitment in which both the military and diplomatic possibilities require a Free World force so powerful as to make any aggression clearly futile. Yet in the past, lack of a consistent, coherent military strategy, the absence of basic assumptions about our national requirements and the faulty estimates and duplication arising from inter-service rivalries have all made it difficult to assess accurately how adequate--or inadequate--our defenses really are.

I have, therefore, instructed the Secretary of Defense to reappraise our entire defense strategy--our ability to fulfill our commitments-the effectiveness, vulnerability, and dispersal of our strategic bases, forces and warning systems--the efficiency and economy of our operation and organization-the elimination of obsolete bases and installations-and the adequacy, modernization and mobility of our present conventional and nuclear forces and weapons systems in the light of present and future dangers. I have asked for preliminary conclusions by the end of February--and I then shall recommend whatever legislative, budgetary or executive action is needed in the light of these conclusions.

In the meantime, I have asked the Defense Secretary to initiate immediately three new steps most clearly needed now:

First, l have directed prompt attention to increase our air-lift capacity. Obtaining additional air transport mobility--and obtaining it now--will better assure the ability of our conventional forces to respond, with discrimination and speed, to any problem at any spot on the globe at any moment's notice. In particular it will enable us to meet any deliberate effort to avoid or divert our forces by starting limited wars in widely scattered parts of the globe.

(b) I have directed prompt action to step up our Polaris submarine program. Using unobligated ship-building funds now (to let contracts originally scheduled for the next fiscal year) will build and place on station--at least nine months earlier than planned-substantially more units of a crucial deterrent--a fleet that will never attack first, but possess sufficient powers of retaliation, concealed beneath the seas, to discourage any aggressor from launching an attack upon our security.

(c) I have directed prompt action to accelerate our entire missile program. Until the Secretary of Defense's reappraisal is completed, the emphasis here will be largely on improved organization and decision making--on cutting down the wasteful duplications and the time-lag that have handicapped our whole family of missiles. If we are to keep the peace, we need an invulnerable missile force powerful enough to deter any aggressor from even threatening an attack that he would know could not destroy enough of our force to prevent his own destruction. For as I said upon taking the oath of office: Only when our arms are sufficient beyond doubt can we be certain beyond doubt that they will never be employed."

column4: will not make it so. There will be further setbacks before the tide is turned. But turn it we must. The hopes of all mankind rest upon us--not simply upon those of us in this chamber
column5: but upon the peasant in Laos
column6: the fisherman in Nigeria
column7: the exile from Cuba
column8: the spirit that moves every man and Nation who shares our hopes for freedom and the future. And in the final analysis
column9: they rest most of all upon the pride and perseverance of our fellow citizens of the great Republic.

column1: In the words of a great President
column2: whose birthday we honor today
column3: closing his final State of the Union Message sixteen years ago
column4: "We pray that we may be worthy of the unlimited opportunities that God has given us."@

column1: John F. Kennedy|Special Message to the Congress on Urgent National Needs|1961-05-25|@Mr. Speaker
column2: Mr. Vice President
column3: my copartners in Government
column4: gentlemen-and ladies:

column1: The Constitution imposes upon me the obligation to "from time to time give to the Congress information of the State of the Union." While this has traditionally been interpreted as an annual affair
column2: this tradition has been broken in extraordinary times.

column1: These are extraordinary times. And we face an extraordinary challenge. Our strength as well as our convictions have imposed upon this nation the role of leader in freedom's cause.
No role in history could be more difficult or more important. We stand for freedom.
That is our conviction for ourselves--that is our only commitment to others. No friend
column2: no neutral and no adversary should think otherwise. We are not against any man--or any nation--or any system--except as it is hostile to freedom. Nor am I here to present a new military doctrine
column3: bearing any one name or aimed at any one area. I am here to promote the freedom doctrine.

column1: I.
The great battleground for the defense and expansion of freedom today is the whole southern half of the globe--Asia
column2: Latin America
column3: Africa and the Middle East--the lands of the rising peoples. Their revolution is the greatest in human history. They seek an end to injustice
column4: tyranny
column5: and exploitation. More than an end
column6: they seek a beginning.

column1: And theirs is a revolution which we would support regardless of the Cold War
column2: and regardless of which political or economic route they should choose to freedom.

column1: For the adversaries of freedom did not create the revolution; nor did they create the conditions which compel it. But they are seeking to ride the crest of its wave--to capture it for themselves.
Yet their aggression is more often concealed than open. They have fired no missiles; and their troops are seldom seen. They send arms
column2: agitators
column3: aid
column4: technicians and propaganda to every troubled area. But where fighting is required
column5: it is usually done by others--by guerrillas striking at night
column6: by assassins striking alone--assassins who have taken the lives of four thousand civil officers in the last twelve months in Vietnam alone--by subversives and saboteurs and insurrectionists
column7: who in some cases control whole areas inside of independent nations.

column1: They possess a powerful intercontinental striking force
column2: large forces for conventional war
column3: a well-trained underground in nearly every country
column4: the power to conscript talent and manpower for any purpose
column5: the capacity for quick decisions
column6: a closed society without dissent or free information
column7: and long experience in the techniques of violence and subversion. They make the most of their scientific successes
column8: their economic progress and their pose as a foe of colonialism and friend of popular revolution. They prey on unstable or unpopular governments
column9: unsealed
column10: or unknown boundaries
column11: unfilled hopes
column12: convulsive change
column13: massive poverty
column14: illiteracy

column1: With these formidable weapons
column2: the adversaries of freedom plan to consolidate their territory--to exploit
column3: to control
column4: and finally to destroy the hopes of the world's newest nations; and they have ambition to do it before the end of this decade. It is a contest of will and purpose as well as force and violence--a battle for minds and souls as well as lives and territory. And in that contest
column5: we cannot stand aside.

column1: We stand
column2: as we have always stood from our earliest beginnings
column3: for the independence and equality of all nations. This nation was born of revolution and raised in freedom. And we do not intend to leave an open road for despotism.

column1: There is no single simple policy which meets this challenge. Experience has taught us that no one nation has the power or the wisdom to solve all the problems of the world or manage its revolutionary tides--that extending our commitments does not always increase our security--that any initiative carries with it the risk of a temporary defeat--that nuclear weapons cannot prevent subversion--that no free people can be kept free without will and energy of their own--and that no two nations or situations are exactly alike.

Yet there is much we can do--and must do. The proposals I bring before you are numerous and varied. They arise from the host of special opportunities and dangers which have become increasingly clear in recent months. Taken together
column2: I believe that they can mark another step forward in our effort as a people. I am here to ask the help of this Congress and the nation in approving these necessary measures.

column1: II. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL PROGRESS AT HOME
The first and basic task confronting this nation this year was to turn recession into recovery. An affirmative anti-recession program
column2: initiated with your cooperation
column3: supported the natural forces in the private sector; and our economy is now enjoying renewed confidence and energy. The recession has been halted. Recovery is under way.

column1: But the task of abating unemployment and achieving a full use of our resources does remain a serious challenge for us all. Large-scale unemployment during a recession is bad enough
column2: but large-scale unemployment during a period of prosperity would be intolerable.

column1: I am therefore transmitting to the Congress a new Manpower Development and Training program
column2: to train or retrain several hundred thousand workers
column3: particularly in those areas where we have seen chronic unemployment as a result of technological factors in new occupational skills over a four-year period
column4: in order to replace those skills made obsolete by automation and industrial change with the new skills which the new processes demand.

column1: It should be a satisfaction to us all that we have made great strides in restoring world confidence in the dollar
column2: halting the outflow of gold and improving our balance of payments. During the last two months
column3: our gold stocks actually increased by seventeen million dollars
column4: compared to a loss of 635 million dollars during the last two months of 1960. We must maintain this progress--and this will require the cooperation and restraint of everyone. As recovery progresses
column5: there will be temptations to seek unjustified price and wage increases. These we cannot afford. They will only handicap our efforts to compete abroad and to achieve full recovery here at home. Labor and management must--and I am confident that they will--pursue responsible wage and price policies in these critical times. I look to the President's Advisory Committee on Labor Management Policy to give a strong lead in this direction.

column1: Moreover
column2: if the budget deficit now increased by the needs of our security is to be held within manageable proportions
column3: it will be necessary to hold tightly to prudent fiscal standards; and I request the cooperation of the Congress in this regard--to refrain from adding funds or programs
column4: desirable as they may be
column5: to the Budget--to end the postal deficit
column6: as my predecessor also recommended
column7: through increased rates--a deficit incidentally
column8: this year
column9: which exceeds the fiscal 1962 cost of all the space and defense measures that I am submitting today--to provide full pay-as-you-go highway financing--and to close those tax loopholes earlier specified. Our security and progress cannot be cheaply purchased; and their price must be found in what we all forego as well as what we all must pay.

column1: III. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL PROGRESS ABROAD

I stress the strength of our economy because it is essential to the strength of our nation. And what is true in our case is true in the case of other countries. Their strength in the struggle for freedom depends on the strength of their economic and their social progress.

We would be badly mistaken to consider their problems in military terms alone. For no amount of arms and armies can help stabilize those governments which are unable or unwilling to achieve social and economic reform and development. Military pacts cannot help nations whose social injustice and economic chaos invite insurgency and penetration and subversion. The most skillful counter-guerrilla efforts cannot succeed where the local population is too caught up in its own misery to be concerned about the advance of communism.
But for those who share this view
column2: we stand ready now
column3: as we have in the past
column4: to provide generously of our skills
column5: and our capital
column6: and our food to assist the peoples of the less-developed nations to reach their goals in freedom--to help them before they are engulfed in crisis.

column1: This is also our great opportunity in 1961. If we grasp it
column2: then subversion to prevent its success is exposed as an unjustifiable attempt to keep these nations from either being free or equal. But if we do not pursue it
column3: and if they do not pursue it
column4: the bankruptcy of unstable governments
column5: one by one
column6: and of unfilled hopes will surely lead to a series of totalitarian receiverships.

column1: Earlier in the year
column2: I outlined to the Congress a new program for aiding emerging nations; and it is my intention to transmit shortly draft legislation to implement this program
column3: to establish a new Act for International Development
column4: and to add to the figures previously requested
column5: in view of the swift pace of critical events
column6: an additional 250 million dollars for a Presidential Contingency Fund
column7: to be used only upon a Presidential determination in each case
column8: with regular and complete reports to the Congress in each case
column9: when there is a sudden and extraordinary drain upon our regular funds which we cannot foresee--as illustrated by recent events in Southeast Asia--and it makes necessary the use of this emergency reserve. The total amount requested--now raised to 2..65 billion dollars--is both minimal and crucial. I do not see how anyone who is concerned--as we all are--about the growing threats to freedom around the globe--and who is asking what more we can do as a people--can weaken or oppose the single most important program available for building the frontiers of freedom.

column1: IV.
All that I have said makes it clear that we are engaged in a world-wide struggle in which we bear a heavy burden to preserve and promote the ideals that we share with all mankind
column2: or have alien ideals forced upon them. That struggle has highlighted the role of our Information Agency. It is essential that the funds previously requested for this effort be not only approved in full
column3: but increased by 2 million
column4: 400 thousand dollars
column5: to a total of 121 million dollars.

column1: This new request is for additional radio and television to Latin America and Southeast Asia. These tools are particularly effective and essential in the cities and villages of those great continents as a means of reaching millions of uncertain peoples to tell them of our interest in their fight for freedom. In Latin America
column2: we are proposing to increase our Spanish and Portuguese broadcasts to a total of 154 hours a week
column3: compared to 42 hours today
column4: none of which is in Portuguese
column5: the language of about one-third of the people of South America. The Soviets
column6: Red Chinese and satellites already broadcast into Latin America more than 134 hours a week in Spanish and Portuguese. Communist China alone does more public information broadcasting in our own hemisphere than we do. Moreover
column7: powerful propaganda broadcasts from Havana now are heard throughout Latin America
column8: encouraging new revolutions in several countries.

column1: Similarly
column2: in Laos
column3: Vietnam
column4: Cambodia
column5: and Thailand
column6: we must communicate our determination and support to those upon whom our hopes for resisting the communist tide in that continent ultimately depend. Our interest is in the truth.

column1: V. OUR PARTNERSHIP FOR SELF-DEFENSE
But while we talk of sharing and building and the competition of ideas
column2: others talk of arms and threaten war. So we have learned to keep our defenses strong--and to cooperate with others in a partnership of self-defense. The events of recent weeks have caused us to look anew at these efforts.

column1: The center of freedom's defense is our network of world alliances
column2: extending from NATO
column3: recommended by a Democratic President and approved by a Republican Congress
column4: to SEATO
column5: recommended by a Republican President and approved by a Democratic Congress. These alliances were constructed in the 1940's and 1950's--it is our task and responsibility in the 1960's to strengthen them.

column1: To meet the changing conditions of power--and power relationships have changed--we have endorsed an increased emphasis on NATO's conventional strength. At the same time we are affirming our conviction that the NATO nuclear deterrent must also be kept strong. I have made clear our intention to commit to the NATO command
column2: for this purpose
column3: the 5 Polaris submarines originally suggested by President Eisenhower
column4: with the possibility
column5: if needed
column6: of more to come.

column1: Second
column2: a major part of our partnership for self-defense is the Military Assistance Program. The main burden of local defense against local attack
column3: subversion
column4: insurrection or guerrilla warfare must of necessity rest with local forces. Where these forces have the necessary will and capacity to cope with such threats
column5: our intervention is rarely necessary or helpful. Where the will is present and only capacity is lacking
column6: our Military Assistance Program can be of help.

column1: But this program
column2: like economic assistance
column3: needs a new emphasis. It cannot be extended without regard to the social
column4: political and military reforms essential to internal respect and stability. The equipment and training provided must be tailored to legitimate local needs and to our own foreign and military policies
column5: not to our supply of military stocks or a local leader's desire for military display. And military assistance can
column6: in addition to its military purposes
column7: make a contribution to economic progress
column8: as do our own Army Engineers.

column1: In an earlier message
column2: I requested 1.6 billion dollars for Military Assistance
column3: stating that this would maintain existing force levels
column4: but that I could not foresee how much more might be required. It is now clear that this is not enough. The present crisis in Southeast Asia
column5: on which the Vice President has made a valuable report--the rising threat of communism in Latin America--the increased arms traffic in Africa--and all the new pressures on every nation found on the map by tracing your fingers along the borders of the Communist bloc in Asia and the Middle East--all make clear the dimension of our needs.

column1: I therefore request the Congress to provide a total of 1.885 billion dollars for Military Assistance in the coming fiscal year--an amount less than that requested a year ago--but a minimum which must be assured if we are to help those nations make secure their independence. This must be prudently and wisely spent--and that will be our common endeavor. Military and economic assistance has been a heavy burden on our citizens for a long time
column2: and I recognize the strong pressures against it; but this battle is far from over
column3: it is reaching a crucial stage
column4: and I believe we should participate in it. We cannot merely state our opposition to totalitarian advance without paying the price of helping those now under the greatest pressure.

column1: VI. OUR OWN MILITARY AND INTELLIGENCE SHIELD
In line with these developments
column2: I have directed a further reinforcement of our own capacity to deter or resist non-nuclear aggression. In the conventional field
column3: with one exception
column4: I find no present need for large new levies of men. What is needed is rather a change of position to give us still further increases in flexibility.

column1: Therefore
column2: I am directing the Secretary of Defense to undertake a reorganization and modernization of the Army's divisional structure
column3: to increase its non-nuclear firepower
column4: to improve its tactical mobility in any environment
column5: to insure its flexibility to meet any direct or indirect threat
column6: to facilitate its coordination with our major allies
column7: and to provide more modern mechanized divisions in Europe and bring their equipment up to date
column8: and new airborne brigades in both the Pacific and Europe.

column1: And secondly
column2: I am asking the Congress for an additional 100 million dollars to begin the procurement task necessary to re-equip this new Army structure with the most modern material. New helicopters
column3: new armored personnel carriers
column4: and new howitzers
column5: for example
column6: must be obtained now.

column1: Third
column2: I am directing the Secretary of Defense to expand rapidly and substantially
column3: in cooperation with our Allies
column4: the orientation of existing forces for the conduct of non-nuclear war
column5: paramilitary operations and sub-limited or unconventional wars.

column1: In addition our special forces and unconventional warfare units will be increased and reoriented. Throughout the services new emphasis must be placed on the special skills and languages which are required to work with local populations.
Fourth
column2: the Army is developing plans to make possible a much more rapid deployment of a major portion of its highly trained reserve forces. When these plans are completed and the reserve is strengthened
column3: two combat-equipped divisions
column4: plus their supporting forces
column5: a total of 89
column6: 000 men
column7: could be ready in an emergency for operations with but 3 weeks' notice--2 more divisions with but 5 weeks' notice--and six additional divisions and their supporting forces
column8: making a total of 10 divisions
column9: could be deployable with less than 8 weeks' notice. In short
column10: these new plans will allow us to almost double the combat power of the Army in less than two months
column11: compared to the nearly nine months heretofore required.

column1: Fifth
column2: to enhance the already formidable ability of the Marine Corps to respond to limited war emergencies
column3: I am asking the Congress for 60 million dollars to increase the Marine Corps strength to 190
column4: 000 men. This will increase the initial impact and staying power of our three Marine divisions and three air wings
column5: and provide a trained nucleus for further expansion
column6: if necessary for self-defense.

column1: Finally
column2: to cite one other area of activities that are both legitimate and necessary as a means of self-defense in an age of hidden perils
column3: our whole intelligence effort must be reviewed
column4: and its coordination with other elements of policy assured. The Congress and the American people are entitled to know that we will institute whatever new organization
column5: policies
column6: and control are necessary.

column1: VII. CIVIL DEFENSE

One major element of the national security program which this nation has never squarely faced up to is civil defense. This problem arises not from present trends but from national inaction in which most of us have participated. In the past decade we have intermittently considered a variety of programs
column2: but we have never adopted a consistent policy. Public considerations have been largely characterized by apathy
column3: indifference and skepticism; while
column4: at the same time
column5: many of the civil defense plans have been so far-reaching and unrealistic that they have not gained essential support.

column1: This Administration has been looking hard at exactly what civil defense can and cannot do. It cannot be obtained cheaply. It cannot give an assurance of blast protection that will be proof against surprise attack or guaranteed against obsolescence or destruction. And it cannot deter a nuclear attack.
We will deter an enemy from making a nuclear attack only if our retaliatory power is so strong and so invulnerable that he knows he would be destroyed by our response. If we have that strength
column2: civil defense is not needed to deter an attack. If we should ever lack it
column3: civil defense would not be an adequate substitute.

column1: But this deterrent concept assumes rational calculations by rational men. And the history of this planet
column2: and particularly the history of the 20th century
column3: is sufficient to remind us of the possibilities of an irrational attack
column4: a miscalculation
column5: an accidental war
column6: [or a war of escalation in which the stakes by each side gradually increase to the point of maximum danger] which cannot be either foreseen or deterred. It is on this basis that civil defense can be readily justifiable--as insurance for the civilian population in case of an enemy miscalculation. It is insurance we trust will never be needed--but insurance which we could never forgive ourselves for foregoing in the event of catastrophe.

column1: Once the validity of this concept is recognized
column2: there is no point in delaying the initiation of a nation-wide long-range program of identifying present fallout shelter capacity and providing shelter in new and existing structures. Such a program would protect millions of people against the hazards of radioactive fallout in the event of large-scale nuclear attack. Effective performance of the entire program not only requires new legislative authority and more funds
column3: but also sound organizational arrangements.

column1: Therefore
column2: under the authority vested in me by Reorganization Plan No. 1 of 1958
column3: I am assigning responsibility for this program to the top civilian authority already responsible for continental defense
column4: the Secretary of Defense. It is important that this function remain civilian
column5: in nature and leadership; and this feature will not be changed.

column1: The Office of Civil and Defense Mobilization will be reconstituted as a small staff agency to assist in the coordination of these functions. To more accurately describe its role
column2: its title should be changed to the Office of Emergency Planning.

column1: As soon as those newly charged with these responsibilities have prepared new authorization and appropriation requests
column2: such requests will be transmitted to the Congress for a much strengthened Federal-State civil defense program. Such a program will provide Federal funds for identifying fallout shelter capacity in existing
column3: structures
column4: and it will include
column5: where appropriate
column6: incorporation of shelter in Federal buildings
column7: new requirements for shelter in buildings constructed with Federal assistance
column8: and matching grants and other incentives for constructing shelter in State and local and private buildings.

column1: Federal appropriations for civil defense in fiscal 1962 under this program will in all likelihood be more than triple the pending budget requests; and they will increase sharply in subsequent years. Financial participation will also be required from State and local governments and from private citizens. But no insurance is cost-free; and every American citizen and his community must decide for themselves whether this form of survival insurance justifies the expenditure of effort
column2: time and money. For myself
column3: I am convinced that it does.

column1: VIII. DISARMAMENT

I cannot end this discussion of defense and armaments without emphasizing our strongest hope: the creation of an orderly world where disarmament will be possible. Our aims do not prepare for war--they are efforts to discourage and resist the adventures of others that could end in war.
That is why it is consistent with these efforts that we continue to press for properly safeguarded disarmament measures. At Geneva
column2: in cooperation with the United Kingdom
column3: we have put forward concrete proposals to make clear our wish to meet the Soviets half way in an effective nuclear test ban treaty--the first significant but essential step on the road towards disarmament. Up to now
column4: their response has not been what we hoped
column5: but Mr. Dean returned last night to Geneva
column6: and we intend to go the last mile in patience to secure this gain if we can.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: we are determined to keep disarmament high on our agenda--to make an intensified effort to develop acceptable political and technical alternatives to the present arms race. To this end I shall send to the Congress a measure to establish a strengthened and enlarged Disarmament Agency.

column1: IX. SPACE
Finally
column2: if we are to win the battle that is now going on around the world between freedom and tyranny
column3: the dramatic achievements in space which occurred in recent weeks should have made clear to us all
column4: as did the Sputnik in 1957
column5: the impact of this adventure on the minds of men everywhere
column6: who are attempting to make a determination of which road they should take. Since early in my term
column7: our efforts in space have been under review. With the advice of the Vice President
column8: who is Chairman of the National Space Council
column9: we have examined where we are strong and where we are not
column10: where we may succeed and where we may not. Now it is time to take longer strides--time for a great new American enterprise--time for this nation to take a clearly leading role in space achievement
column11: which in many ways may hold the key to our future on earth.

column1: I believe we possess all the resources and talents necessary. But the facts of the matter are that we have never made the national decisions or marshalled the national resources required for such leadership. We have never specified long-range goals on an urgent time schedule
column2: or managed our resources and our time so as to insure their fulfillment.

column1: Recognizing the head start obtained by the Soviets with their large rocket engines
column2: which gives them many months of leadtime
column3: and recognizing the likelihood that they will exploit this lead for some time to come in still more impressive successes
column4: we nevertheless are required to make new efforts on our own. For while we cannot guarantee that we shall one day be first
column5: we can guarantee that any failure to make this effort will make us last. We take an additional risk by making it in full view of the world
column6: but as shown by the feat of astronaut Shepard
column7: this very risk enhances our stature when we are successful. But this is not merely a race. Space is open to us now; and our eagerness to share its meaning is not governed by the efforts of others. We go into space because whatever mankind must undertake
column8: free men must fully share.

column1: I therefore ask the Congress
column2: above and beyond the increases I have earlier requested for space activities
column3: to provide the funds which are needed to meet the following national goals:

column1: First
column2: I believe that this nation should commit itself to achieving the goal
column3: before this decade is out
column4: of landing a man on the moon and returning him safely to the earth. No single space project in this period will be more impressive to mankind
column5: or more important for the long-range exploration of space; and none will be so difficult or expensive to accomplish. We propose to accelerate the development of the appropriate lunar space craft. We propose to develop alternate liquid and solid fuel boosters
column6: much larger than any now being developed
column7: until certain which is superior. We propose additional funds for other engine development and for unmanned explorations--explorations which are particularly important for one purpose which this nation will never overlook: the survival of the man who first makes this daring flight. But in a very real sense
column8: it will not be one man going to the moon--if we make this judgment affirmatively
column9: it will be an entire nation. For all of us must work to put him there.

column1: Secondly
column2: an additional 23 million dollars
column3: together with 7 million dollars already available
column4: will accelerate development of the Rover nuclear rocket. This gives promise of some day providing a means for even more exciting and ambitious exploration of space
column5: perhaps beyond the moon
column6: perhaps to the very end of the solar system itself.

column1: Third
column2: an additional 50 million dollars will make the most of our present leadership
column3: by accelerating the use of space satellites for world-wide communications.

column1: Fourth
column2: an additional 75 million dollars--of which 53 million dollars is for the Weather Bureau--will help give us at the earliest possible time a satellite system for world-wide weather observation.

column1: Let it be clear--and this is a judgment which the Members of the Congress must finally make--let it be clear that I am asking the Congress and the country to accept a firm commitment to a new course of action
column2: a course which will last for many years and carry very heavy costs: 531 million dollars in fiscal '62--an estimated seven to nine billion dollars additional over the next five years. If we are to go only half way
column3: or reduce our sights in the face of difficulty
column4: in my judgment it would be better not to go at all.

column1: Now this is a choice which this country must make
column2: and I am confident that under the leadership of the Space Committees of the Congress
column3: and the Appropriating Committees
column4: that you will consider the matter carefully.

column1: It is a most important decision that we make as a nation. But all of you have lived through the last four years and have seen the significance of space and the adventures in space
column2: and no one can predict with certainty what the ultimate meaning will be of mastery of space.

column1: I believe we should go to the moon. But I think every citizen of this country as well as the Members of the Congress should consider the matter carefully in making their judgment
column2: to which we have given attention over many weeks and months
column3: because it is a heavy burden
column4: and there is no sense in agreeing or desiring that the United States take an affirmative position in outer space
column5: unless we are prepared to do the work and bear the burdens to make it successful. If we are not
column6: we should decide today and this year.

column1: This decision demands a major national commitment of scientific and technical manpower
column2: materiel and facilities
column3: and the possibility of their diversion from other important activities where they are already thinly spread. It means a degree of dedication
column4: organization and discipline which have not always characterized our research and development efforts. It means we cannot afford undue work stoppages
column5: inflated costs of material or talent
column6: wasteful interagency rivalries
column7: or a high turnover of key personnel.

column1: New objectives and new money cannot solve these problems. They could in fact
column2: aggravate them further--unless every scientist
column3: every engineer
column4: every serviceman
column5: every technician
column6: contractor
column7: and civil servant gives his personal pledge that this nation will move forward
column8: with the full speed of freedom
column9: in the exciting adventure of space.

column1: X. CONCLUSION
In conclusion
column2: let me emphasize one point. It is not a pleasure for any President of the United States
column3: as I am sure it was not a pleasure for my predecessors
column4: to come before the Congress and ask for new appropriations which place burdens on our people. I came to this conclusion with some reluctance. But in my judgment
column5: this is a most serious time in the life of our country and in the life of freedom around the globe
column6: and it is the obligation
column7: I believe
column8: of the President of the United States to at least make his recommendations to the Members of the Congress
column9: so that they can reach their own conclusions with that judgment before them. You must decide yourselves
column10: as I have decided
column11: and I am confident that whether you finally decide in the way that I have decided or not
column12: that your judgment--as my judgment--is reached on what is in the best interests of our country.

column1: In conclusion
column2: let me emphasize one point: that we are determined
column3: as a nation in 1961 that freedom shall survive and succeed--and whatever the peril and set-backs
column4: we have some very large advantages.

column1: The first is the simple fact that we are on the side of liberty--and since the beginning of history
column2: and particularly since the end of the Second World War
column3: liberty has been winning out all over the globe.

column1: A second real asset is that we are not alone. We have friends and allies all over the world who share our devotion to freedom. May I cite as a symbol of traditional and effective friendship the great ally I am about to visit--France. I look forward to my visit to France
column2: and to my discussion with a great Captain of the Western World
column3: President de Gaulle
column4: as a meeting of particular significance
column5: permitting the kind of close and ranging consultation that will strengthen both our countries and serve the common purposes of world-wide peace and liberty. Such serious conversations do not require a pale unanimity--they are rather the instruments of trust and understanding over a long road.

column1: A third asset is our desire for peace. It is sincere
column2: and I believe the world knows it. We are proving it in our patience at the test ban table
column3: and we are proving it in the UN where our efforts have been directed to maintaining that organization's usefulness as a protector of the independence of small nations. In these and other instances
column4: the response of our opponents has not been encouraging.

column1: Yet it is important to know that our patience at the bargaining table is nearly inexhaustible
column2: though our credulity is limited that our hopes for peace are unfailing
column3: while our determination to protect our security is resolute. For these reasons I have long thought it wise to meet with the Soviet Premier for a personal exchange of views. A meeting in Vienna turned out to be convenient for us both; and the Austrian government has kindly made us welcome. No formal agenda is planned and no negotiations will be undertaken; but we will make clear America's enduring concern is for both peace and freedom--that we are anxious to live in harmony with the Russian people--that we seek no conquests
column4: no satellites
column5: no riches--that we seek only the day when "nation shall not lift up sword against nation
column6: neither shall they learn war any more."

column1: Finally
column2: our greatest asset in this struggle is the American people--their willingness to pay the price for these programs--to understand and accept a long struggle--to share their resources with other less fortunate people--to meet the tax levels and close the tax loopholes I have requested--to exercise self-restraint instead of pushing up wages or prices
column3: or over-producing certain crops
column4: or spreading military secrets
column5: or urging unessential expenditures or improper monopolies or harmful work stoppages--to serve in the Peace Corps or the Armed Services or the Federal Civil Service or the Congress--to strive for excellence in their schools
column6: in their cities and in their physical fitness and that of their children--to take part in Civil Defense--to pay higher postal rates
column7: and higher payroll taxes and higher teachers' salaries
column8: in order to strengthen our society--to show friendship to students and visitors from other lands who visit us and go back in many cases to be the future leaders
column9: with an image of America--and I want that image
column10: and I know you do
column11: to be affirmative and positive--and
column12: finally
column13: to practice democracy at home
column14: in all States
column16: to respect each other and to protect the Constitutional rights of all citizens.

column1: I have not asked for a single program which did not cause one or all Americans some inconvenience
column2: or some hardship
column3: or some sacrifice. But they have responded and you in the Congress have responded to your duty--and I feel confident in asking today for a similar response to these new and larger demands. It is heartening to know
column4: as I journey abroad
column5: that our country is united in its commitment to freedom and is ready to do its duty.@

column1: John F. Kennedy|Annual Address to a Joint Session of Congress on the State of the Union|1962-01-11|@Mr. Vice President
column2: my old colleague from Massachusetts and your new Speaker
column3: John McCormack
column4: Members of the 87th Congress
column5: ladies and gentlemen:

column1: This week we begin anew our joint and separate efforts to build the American future. But
column2: sadly
column3: we build without a man who linked a long past with the present and looked strongly to the future. "Mister Sam" Rayburn is gone. Neither this House nor the Nation is the same without him.

column1: Members of the Congress
column2: the Constitution makes us not rivals for power but partners for progress. We are all trustees for the American people
column3: custodians of the American heritage. It is my task to report the State of the Union - to improve it is the task of us all.

column1: In the past year
column2: I have travelled not only across our own land but to other lands - to the North and the South
column3: and across the seas. And I have found - as I am sure you have
column4: in your travels - that people everywhere
column5: in spite of occasional disappointments
column6: look to us - not to our wealth or power
column7: but to the splendor of our ideals. For our Nation is commissioned by history to be either an observer of freedom's failure or the cause of its success. Our overriding obligation in the months ahead is to fulfill the world's hopes by fulfilling our own faith.

column1: STRENGTHENING THE ECONOMY
That task must begin at home. For if we cannot fulfill our own ideals here
column2: we cannot expect others to accept them. And when the youngest child alive today has grown to the cares of manhood
column3: our position in the world will be determined first of all by what provisions we make today - for his education
column4: his health
column5: and his opportunities for a good home and a good job and a good life.

column1: At home
column2: we began the year in the valley of recession - we completed it on the high road of recovery and growth. With the help of new congressionally approved or administratively increased stimulants to our economy
column3: the number of major surplus labor areas has declined from 101 to 60; nonagricultural employment has increased by more than a million jobs; and the average factory work-week has risen to well over 40 hours. At year's end the economy which Mr. Khrushchev once called a "stumbling horse" was racing to new records in consumer spending
column4: labor income
column5: and industrial production.

column1: We are gratified - but we are not satisfied. Too many unemployed are still looking for the blessings of prosperity. As those who leave our schools and farms demand new jobs
column2: automation takes old jobs away. To expand our growth and job opportunities
column3: I urge on the Congress three measures:

column1: First
column2: the Manpower Training and Development Act
column3: to stop the waste of able-bodied men and women who want to work
column4: but whose only skill has been replaced by a machine
column5: or moved with a mill
column6: or shut down with a mine;

column1: Second
column2: the Youth Employment Opportunities Act
column3: to help train and place not only the one million young Americans who are both out of school and out of work
column4: but the twenty-six million young Americans entering the labor market in this decade; and

column1: Third
column2: the 8 percent tax credit for investment in machinery and equipment
column3: which
column4: combined with planned revisions of depreciation allowances
column5: will spur our modernization
column6: our growth
column7: and our ability to compete abroad.

column1: Moreover - pleasant as it may be to bask in the warmth of recovery - let us not forget that we have suffered three recessions in the last 7 years. The time to repair the roof is when the sun is shining - by filling three basic gaps in our anti-recession protection. We need:
First
column2: Presidential standby authority
column3: subject to congressional veto
column4: to adjust personal income tax rates downward within a specified range and time
column5: to slow down an economic decline before it has dragged us all down;

column1: Second
column2: Presidential standby authority
column3: upon a given rise in the rate of unemployment
column4: to accelerate Federal and federally-aided capital improvement programs; and

column1: Third
column2: a permanent strengthening of our unemployment compensation system - to maintain for our fellow citizens searching for a job who cannot find it
column3: their purchasing power and their living standards without constant resort - as we have seen in recent years by the Congress and the administrations - to temporary supplements.

column1: If we enact this six-part program
column2: we can show the whole world that a free economy need not be an unstable economy - that a free system need not leave men unemployed - and that a free society is not only the most productive but the most stable form of organization yet fashioned by man.

column1: FIGHTING INFLATION
But recession is only one enemy of a free economy - inflation is another. Last year
column3: despite rising production and demand
column4: consumer prices held almost steady - and wholesale prices declined. This is the best record of overall price stability of any comparable period of recovery since the end of World War II.

column1: Inflation too often follows in the shadow of growth - while price stability is made easy by stagnation or controls. But we mean to maintain both stability and growth in a climate of freedom.

Our first line of defense against inflation is the good sense and public spirit of business and labor - keeping their total increases in wages and profits in step with productivity. There is no single statistical test to guide each company and each union. But I strongly urge them - for their country's interest
column2: and for their own - to apply the test of the public interest to these transactions.

column1: Within this same framework of growth and wage-price stability:
This administration has helped keep our economy competitive by widening the access of small business to credit and Government contracts
column2: and by stepping up the drive against monopoly
column3: price-fixing
column4: and racketeering;

column1: We will submit a Federal Pay Reform bill aimed at giving our classified
column2: postal
column3: and other employees new pay scales more comparable to those of private industry;

column1: We are holding the fiscal 1962 budget deficit far below the level incurred after the last recession in 1958; and
column2: finally

column1: I am submitting for fiscal 1963 a balanced Federal Budget.
This is a joint responsibility
column2: requiring Congressional cooperation on appropriations
column3: and on three sources of income in particular:

column1: First
column2: an increase in postal rates
column3: to end the postal deficit;

column1: Secondly
column2: passage of the tax reforms previously urged
column3: to remove unwarranted tax preferences
column4: and to apply to dividends and to interest the same withholding requirements we have long applied to wages;

column1: Third
column2: extension of the present excise and corporation tax rates
column3: except for those changes - which will be recommended in a message - affecting transportation.

column1: GETTING AMERICA MOVING
But a stronger nation and economy require more than a balanced Budget. They require progress in those programs that spur our growth and fortify our strength.
CITIES
A strong America depends on its cities - America's glory
column2: and sometimes America's shame. To substitute sunlight for congestion and progress for decay
column3: we have stepped up existing urban renewal and housing programs
column4: and launched new ones - redoubled the attack on water pollution - speeded aid to airports
column5: hospitals
column6: highways
column7: and our declining mass transit systems - and secured new weapons to combat organized crime
column8: racketeering
column9: and youth delinquency
column10: assisted by the coordinated and hard-hitting efforts of our investigative services: the FBI
column11: the Internal Revenue
column12: the Bureau of Narcotics
column13: and many others. We shall need further anti-crime
column14: mass transit
column15: and transportation legislation - and new tools to fight air pollution. And with all this effort under way
column16: both equity and common sense require that our nation's urban areas - containing three-fourths of our population - sit as equals at the Cabinet table. I urge a new Department of Urban Affairs and Housing.

column1: AGRICULTURE AND RESOURCES

A strong America also depends on its farms and natural resources. American farmers took heart in 1961 - from a billion dollar rise in farm income - and from a hopeful start on reducing the farm surpluses. But we are still operating under a patchwork accumulation of old laws
column2: which cost us $1 billion a year in carrying charges alone
column3: yet fail to halt rural poverty or boost farm earnings.

column1: Our task is to master and turn to fully fruitful ends the magnificent productivity of our farms and farmers. The revolution on our own countryside stands in the sharpest contrast to the repeated farm failures of the Communist nations and is a source of pride to us all. Since 1950 our agricultural output per man-hour has actually doubled! Without new
column2: realistic measures
column3: it will someday swamp our farmers and our taxpayers in a national scandal or a farm depression.

column1: I will
column2: therefore
column3: submit to the Congress a new comprehensive farm program - tailored to fit the use of our land and the supplies of each crop to the long-range needs of the sixties - and designed to prevent chaos in the sixties with a program of common sense.

column1: We also need for the sixties - if we are to bequeath our full national estate to our heirs - a new long-range conservation and recreation program - expansion of our superb national parks and forests - preservation of our authentic wilderness areas - new starts on water and power projects as our population steadily increases - and expanded REA generation and transmission loans.
CIVIL RIGHTS
But America stands for progress in human rights as well as economic affairs
column2: and a strong America requires the assurance of full and equal rights to all its citizens
column3: of any race or of any color. This administration has shown as never before how much could be done through the full use of Executive powers - through the enforcement of laws already passed by the Congress - through persuasion
column4: negotiation
column5: and litigation
column6: to secure the constitutional rights of all: the right to vote
column7: the right to travel without hindrance across State lines
column8: and the right to free public education.

column1: I issued last March a comprehensive order to guarantee the right to equal employment opportunity in all Federal agencies and contractors. The Vice President's Committee thus created has done much
column2: including the voluntary "Plans for Progress" which
column3: in all sections of the country
column4: are achieving a quiet but striking success in opening up to all races new professional
column5: supervisory
column6: and other job opportunities.

column1: But there is much more to be done - by the Executive
column2: by the courts
column3: and by the Congress. Among the bills now pending before you
column4: on which the executive departments will comment in detail
column5: are appropriate methods of strengthening these basic rights which have our full support. The right to vote
column6: for example
column7: should no longer be denied through such arbitrary devices on a local level
column8: sometimes abused
column9: such as literacy tests and poll taxes. As we approach the 100th anniversary
column10: next January
column11: of the Emancipation Proclamation
column12: let the acts of every branch of the Government - and every citizen - portray that "righteousness does exalt a nation."

column1: HEALTH AND WELFARE
Finally
column2: a strong America cannot neglect the aspirations of its citizens - the welfare of the needy
column3: the health care of the elderly
column4: the education of the young. For we are not developing the Nation's wealth for its own sake. Wealth is the means - and people are the ends. All our material riches will avail us little if we do not use them to expand the opportunities of our people.

column1: Last year
column2: we improved the diet of needy people - provided more hot lunches and fresh milk to school children - built more college dormitories - and
column3: for the elderly
column4: expanded private housing
column5: nursing homes
column6: health services
column7: and social security. But we have just begun.

column1: To help those least fortunate of all
column2: I am recommending a new public welfare program
column3: stressing services instead of support
column4: rehabilitation instead of relief
column5: and training for useful work instead of prolonged dependency.

column1: To relieve the critical shortage of doctors and dentists - and this is a matter which should concern us all - and expand research
column2: I urge action to aid medical and dental colleges and scholarships and to establish new National Institutes of Health.

column1: To take advantage of modern vaccination achievements
column2: I am proposing a mass immunization program
column3: aimed at the virtual elimination of such ancient enemies of our children as polio
column4: diphtheria
column5: whooping cough
column6: and tetanus.

column1: To protect our consumers from the careless and the unscrupulous
column2: I shall recommend improvements in the Food and Drug laws - strengthening inspection and standards
column3: halting unsafe and worthless products
column4: preventing misleading labels
column5: and cracking down on the illicit sale of habit-forming drugs.

column1: But in matters of health
column2: no piece of unfinished business is more important or more urgent than the enactment under the social security system of health insurance for the aged.

column1: For our older citizens have longer and more frequent illnesses
column2: higher hospital and medical bills and too little income to pay them. Private health insurance helps very few - for its cost is high and its coverage limited. Public welfare cannot help those too proud to seek relief but hard-pressed to pay their own bills. Nor can their children or grandchildren always sacrifice their own health budgets to meet this constant drain.

column1: Social security has long helped to meet the hardships of retirement
column2: death
column3: and disability. I now urge that its coverage be extended without further delay to provide health insurance for the elderly.

column1: EDUCATION

Equally important to our strength is the quality of our education. Eight million adult Americans are classified as functionally illiterate. This is a disturbing figure - reflected in Selective Service rejection rates - reflected in welfare rolls and crime rates. And I shall recommend plans for a massive attack to end this adult illiteracy.
I shall also recommend bills to improve educational quality
column2: to stimulate the arts
column3: and
column4: at the college level
column5: to provide Federal loans for the construction of academic facilities and federally financed scholarships.

column1: If this Nation is to grow in wisdom and strength
column2: then every able high school graduate should have the opportunity to develop his talents. Yet nearly half lack either the funds or the facilities to attend college. Enrollments are going to double in our colleges in the short space of 10 years. The annual cost per student is skyrocketing to astronomical levels - now averaging $1
column3: 650 a year
column4: although almost half of our families earn less than $5
column5: 000. They cannot afford such costs - but this Nation cannot afford to maintain its military power and neglect its brainpower.

column1: But excellence in education must begin at the elementary level. I sent to the Congress last year a proposal for Federal aid to public school construction and teachers' salaries. I believe that bill
column2: which passed the Senate and received House Committee approval
column3: offered the minimum amount required by our needs and - in terms of across-the-board aid - the maximum scope permitted by our Constitution. I therefore see no reason to weaken or withdraw that bill: and I urge its passage at this session.

column1: Civilization, said H. G. Wells
column2: "is a race between education and catastrophe." It is up to you in this Congress to determine the winner of that race.

column1: These are not unrelated measures addressed to specific gaps or grievances in our national life. They are the pattern of our intentions and the foundation of our hopes. "I believe in democracy
column2: said Woodrow Wilson, because it releases the energy of every human being." The dynamic of democracy is the power and the purpose of the individual
column3: and the policy of this administration is to give to the individual the opportunity to realize his own highest possibilities.

column1: Our program is to open to all the opportunity for steady and productive employment
column2: to remove from all the handicap of arbitrary or irrational exclusion
column3: to offer to all the facilities for education and health and welfare
column4: to make society the servant of the individual and the individual the source of progress
column5: and thus to realize for all the full promise of American life.

column1: OUR GOALS ABROAD
All of these efforts at home give meaning to our efforts abroad. Since the close of the Second World War
column2: a global civil war has divided and tormented mankind. But it is not our military might
column3: or our higher standard of living
column4: that has most distinguished us from our adversaries. It is our belief that the state is the servant of the citizen and not his master.

column1: This basic clash of ideas and wills is but one of the forces reshaping our globe - swept as it is by the tides of hope and fear
column2: by crises in the headlines today that become mere footnotes tomorrow. Both the successes and the setbacks of the past year remain on our agenda of unfinished business. For every apparent blessing contains the seeds of danger - every area of trouble gives out a ray of hope - and the one unchangeable certainty is that nothing is certain or unchangeable.

column1: Yet our basic goal remains the same: a peaceful world community of free and independent states - free to choose their own future and their own system
column2: so long as it does not threaten the freedom of others.

column1: Some may choose forms and ways that we would not choose for ourselves - but it is not for us that they are choosing. We can welcome diversity - the Communists cannot. For we offer a world of choice - they offer the world of coercion. And the way of the past shows clearly that freedom
column2: not coercion
column3: is the wave of the future. At times our goal has been obscured by crisis or endangered by conflict - but it draws sustenance from five basic sources of strength:

column1: the moral and physical strength of the United States;
the united strength of the Atlantic Community;
the regional strength of our Hemispheric relations;
the creative strength of our efforts in the new and developing nations;
the peace-keeping strength of the United Nations.
OUR MILITARY STRENGTH
Our moral and physical strength begins at home as already discussed. But it includes our military strength as well. So long as fanaticism and fear brood over the affairs of men
column2: we must arm to deter others from aggression.

column1: In the past 12 months our military posture has steadily improved. We increased the previous defense budget by 15 percent - not in the expectation of war but for the preservation of peace. We more than doubled our acquisition rate of Polaris submarines - we doubled the production capacity for Minuteman missiles - and increased by 50 percent the number of manned bombers standing ready on a 15 minute alert. This year the combined force levels planned under our new Defense budget - including nearly three hundred additional Polaris and Minuteman missiles - have been precisely calculated to insure the continuing strength of our nuclear deterrent.
But our strength may be tested at many levels. We intend to have at all times the capacity to resist non-nuclear or limited attacks - as a complement to our nuclear capacity
column2: not as a substitute. We have rejected any all-or-nothing posture which would leave no choice but inglorious retreat or unlimited retaliation.

column1: Thus we have doubled the number of ready combat divisions in the Army's strategic reserve - increased our troops in Europe - built up the Marines - added new sealift and airlift capacity - modernized our weapons and ammunition - expanded our anti-guerrilla forces - and increased the active fleet by more than 70 vessels and our tactical air forces by nearly a dozen wings.
Because we needed to reach this higher long-term level of readiness more quickly
column3: 000 members of the Reserve and National Guard were activated under the Act of this Congress. Some disruptions and distress were inevitable. But the overwhelming majority bear their burdens - and their Nation's burdens - with admirable and traditional devotion.

column1: In the coming year
column2: our reserve programs will be revised - two Army Divisions will
column3: I hope
column4: replace those Guard Divisions on duty - and substantial other increases will boost our Air Force fighter units
column5: the procurement of equipment
column6: and our continental defense and warning efforts. The Nation's first serious civil defense shelter program is under way
column7: identifying
column8: marking
column9: and stocking 50 million spaces; and I urge your approval of Federal incentives for the construction of public fall-out shelters in schools and hospitals and similar centers.

column1: THE UNITED NATIONS

But arms alone are not enough to keep the peace - it must be kept by men. Our instrument and our hope is the United Nations - and I see little merit in the impatience of those who would abandon this imperfect world instrument because they dislike our imperfect world. For the troubles of a world organization merely reflect the troubles of the world itself. And if the organization is weakened
column2: these troubles can only increase. We may not always agree with every detailed action taken by every officer of the United Nations
column3: or with every voting majority. But as an institution
column4: it should have in the future
column5: as it has had in the past since its inception
column6: no stronger or more faithful member than the United States of America.

column1: In 1961 the peace-keeping strength of the United Nations was reinforced. And those who preferred or predicted its demise
column2: envisioning a troika in the seat of Hammarskjold - or Red China inside the Assembly - have seen instead a new vigor
column3: under a new Secretary General and a fully independent Secretariat. In making plans for a new forum and principles on disarmament - for peace-keeping in outer space - for a decade of development effort - the U.N. fulfilled its Charter's lofty aim.

column1: Eighteen months ago the tangled and turbulent Congo presented the U.N. with its gravest challenge. The prospect was one of chaos - or certain big-power confrontation
column2: with all of its hazards and all of its risks
column3: to us and to others. Today the hopes have improved for peaceful conciliation within a united Congo. This is the objective of our policy in this important area.

column1: No policeman is universally popular - particularly when he uses his stick to restore law and order on his beat. Those members who are willing to contribute their votes and their views - but very little else - have created a serious deficit by refusing to pay their share of special U.N. assessments. Yet they do pay their annual assessments to retain their votes - and a new U.N. Bond issue
column2: financing special operations for the next 18 months
column3: is to be repaid with interest from these regular assessments. This is clearly in our interest. It will not only keep the U.N. solvent
column4: but require all voting members to pay their fair share of its activities. Our share of special operations has long been much higher than our share of the annual assessment - and the bond issue will in effect reduce our disproportionate obligation
column5: and for these reasons
column6: I am urging Congress to approve our participation.

column1: With the approval of this Congress
column2: we have undertaken in the past year a great new effort in outer space. Our aim is not simply to be first on the moon
column3: any more than Charles Lindbergh's real aim was to be the first to Paris. His aim was to develop the techniques of our own country and other countries in the field of air and the atmosphere
column4: and our objective in making this effort
column5: which we hope will place one of our citizens on the moon
column6: is to develop in a new frontier of science
column7: commerce and cooperation
column8: the position of the United States and the Free World.

column1: This Nation belongs among the first to explore it
column2: and among the first - if not the first - we shall be. We are offering our know-how and our cooperation to the United Nations. Our satellites will soon be providing other nations with improved weather observations. And I shall soon send to the Congress a measure to govern the financing and operation of an International Communications Satellite system
column3: in a manner consistent with the public interest and our foreign policy.

column1: But peace in space will help us naught once peace on earth is gone. World order will be secured only when the whole world has laid down these weapons which seem to offer us present security but threaten the future survival of the human race. That armistice day seems very far away. The vast resources of this planet are being devoted more and more to the means of destroying
column2: instead of enriching
column3: human life.

column1: But the world was not meant to be a prison in which man awaits his execution. Nor has mankind survived the tests and trials of thousands of years to surrender everything - including its existence - now. This Nation has the will and the faith to make a supreme effort to break the log jam on disarmament and nuclear tests - and we will persist until we prevail
column2: until the rule of law has replaced the ever dangerous use of force.

column1: LATIN AMERICA

I turn now to a prospect of great promise: our Hemispheric relations. The Alliance for Progress is being rapidly transformed from proposal to program. Last month in Latin America I saw for myself the quickening of hope
column2: the revival of confidence
column3: the new trust in our country - among workers and farmers as well as diplomats. We have pledged our help in speeding their economic
column4: educational
column5: and social progress. The Latin American Republics have in turn pledged a new and strenuous effort of self-help and self-reform.

column1: To support this historic undertaking
column2: I am proposing - under the authority contained in the bills of the last session of the Congress - a special long-term Alliance for Progress fund of $3 billion. Combined with our Food for Peace
column3: Export-Import Bank
column4: and other resources
column5: this will provide more than $1 billion a year in new support for the Alliance. In addition
column6: we have increased twelvefold our Spanish and Portuguese-language broadcasting in Latin America
column7: and improved Hemispheric trade and defense. And while the blight of communism has been increasingly exposed and isolated in the Americas
column8: liberty has scored a gain. The people of the Dominican Republic
column9: with our firm encouragement and help
column10: and those of our sister Republics of this Hemisphere are safely passing through the treacherous course from dictatorship through disorder towards democracy.

column1: THE NEW AND DEVELOPING NATIONS
Our efforts to help other new or developing nations
column2: and to strengthen their stand for freedom
column3: have also made progress. A newly unified Agency for International Development is reorienting our foreign assistance to emphasize long-term development loans instead of grants
column4: more economic aid instead of military
column5: individual plans to meet the individual needs of the nations
column6: and new standards on what they must do to marshal their own resources.

column1: A newly conceived Peace Corps is winning friends and helping people in fourteen countries - supplying trained and dedicated young men and women
column2: to give these new nations a hand in building a society
column3: and a glimpse of the best that is in our country. If there is a problem here
column4: it is that we cannot supply the spontaneous and mounting demand.

column1: A newly expanded Food for Peace Program is feeding the hungry of many lands with the abundance of our productive farms - providing lunches for children in school
column2: wages for economic development
column3: relief for the victims of flood and famine
column4: and a better diet for millions whose daily bread is their chief concern.

column1: These programs help people; and
column2: by helping people
column3: they help freedom. The views of their governments may sometimes be very different from ours - but events in Africa
column4: the Middle East
column5: and Eastern Europe teach us never to write off any nation as lost to the Communists. That is the lesson of our time. We support the independence of those newer or weaker states whose history
column6: geography
column7: economy or lack of power impels them to remain outside "entangling alliances" - as we did for more than a century. For the independence of nations is a bar to the Communists' "grand design" - it is the basis of our own.

column1: In the past year
column2: for example
column3: we have urged a neutral and independent Laos - regained there a common policy with our major allies - and insisted that a cease-fire precede negotiations. While a workable formula for supervising its independence is still to be achieved
column4: both the spread of war - which might have involved this country also - and a Communist occupation have thus far been prevented.

column1: A satisfactory settlement in Laos would also help to achieve and safeguard the peace in Viet Nam - where the foe is increasing his tactics of terror - where our own efforts have been stepped up - and where the local government has initiated new programs and reforms to broaden the base of resistance. The systematic aggression now bleeding that country is not a "war of liberation" - for Viet Nam is already free. It is a war of attempted subjugation - and it will be resisted.
THE ATLANTIC COMMUNITY
Finally
column2: the united strength of the Atlantic Community has flourished in the last year under severe tests. NATO has increased both the number and the readiness of its air
column3: ground
column4: and naval units - both its nuclear and non-nuclear capabilities. Even greater efforts by all its members are still required. Nevertheless our unity of purpose and will has been
column5: I believe
column6: immeasurably strengthened.

column1: The threat to the brave city of Berlin remains. In these last 6 months the Allies have made it unmistakably clear that our presence in Berlin
column2: our free access thereto
column3: and the freedom of two million West Berliners would not be surrendered either to force or through appeasement - and to maintain those rights and obligations
column4: we are prepared to talk
column5: when appropriate
column6: and to fight
column7: if necessary. Every member of NATO stands with us in a common commitment to preserve this symbol of free man's will to remain free.

column1: I cannot now predict the course of future negotiations over Berlin. I can only say that we are sparing no honorable effort to find a peaceful and mutually acceptable resolution of this problem. I believe such a resolution can be found
column2: and with it an improvement in our relations with the Soviet Union
column3: if only the leaders in the Kremlin will recognize the basic rights and interests involved
column4: and the interest of all mankind in peace.

column1: But the Atlantic Community is no longer concerned with purely military aims. As its common undertakings grow at an ever-increasing pace
column2: we are
column3: and increasingly will be
column4: partners in aid
column5: trade
column6: defense
column7: diplomacy
column8: and monetary affairs.

column1: The emergence of the new Europe is being matched by the emergence of new ties across the Atlantic. It is a matter of undramatic daily cooperation in hundreds of workaday tasks: of currencies kept in effective relation
column2: of development loans meshed together
column3: of standardized weapons
column4: and concerted diplomatic positions. The Atlantic Community grows
column5: not like a volcanic mountain
column6: by one mighty explosion
column7: but like a coral reef
column8: from the accumulating activity of all.

column1: Thus
column2: we in the free world are moving steadily toward unity and cooperation

column1: OUR BALANCE OF PAYMENTS
On one special problem
column2: of great concern to our friends
column3: and to us
column4: I am proud to give the Congress an encouraging report. Our efforts to safeguard the dollar are progressing. In the 11 months preceding last February 1
