column7: defense
column8: foreign aid

column1: We did not - and could not - achieve these gains through import restrictions
column2: troop withdrawals
column3: exchange controls
column4: dollar devaluation or choking off domestic recovery. We acted not in panic but in perspective. But the problem is not yet solved. With the cooperation of the Congress
column5: business
column6: labor
column7: and our major allies

column1: We shall continue to attract foreign tourists and investments to our shores
column2: to seek increased military purchases here by our allies
column3: to maximize foreign aid procurement from American firms
column4: to urge increased aid from other fortunate nations to the less fortunate
column5: to seek tax laws which do not favor investment in other industrialized nations or tax havens
column6: and to urge coordination of allied fiscal and monetary policies so as to discourage large and disturbing capital movements.

column1: TRADE
Above all
column2: if we are to pay for our commitments abroad
column3: we must expand our exports. Our businessmen must be export-conscious and export competitive. Our tax policies must spur modernization of our plants - our wage and price gains must be consistent with productivity to hold the line on prices - our export credit and promotion campaigns for American industries must continue to expand.

column1: But the greatest challenge of all is posed by the growth of the European Common Market. Assuming the accession of the United Kingdom
column2: there will arise across the Atlantic a trading partner behind a single external tariff similar to ours with an economy which nearly equals our own. Will we in this country adapt our thinking to these new prospects and patterns - or will we wait until events have passed us by?

column1: This is the year to decide. The Reciprocal Trade Act is expiring. We need a new law - a wholly new approach - a bold new instrument of American trade policy. Our decision could well affect the unity of the West
column2: the course of the Cold War
column3: and the economic growth of our Nation for a generation to come.

column1: If we move decisively
column2: our factories and farms can increase their sales to their richest
column3: fastest-growing market. Our exports will increase. Our balance of payments position will improve. And we will have forged across the Atlantic a trading partnership with vast resources for freedom.

column1: If
column2: on the other hand
column3: we hang back in deference to local economic pressures
column4: we will find ourselves cut off from our major allies. Industries - and I believe this is most vital - industries will move their plants and jobs and capital inside the walls of the Common Market
column5: and jobs
column6: therefore
column7: will be lost here in the United States if they cannot otherwise compete for its consumers. Our farm surpluses - our balance of trade
column8: as you all know
column9: to Europe
column10: the Common Market
column11: in farm products
column12: is nearly three or four to one in our favor
column13: amounting to one of the best earners of dollars in our balance of payments structure
column14: and without entrance to this Market
column15: without the ability to enter it
column16: our farm surpluses will pile up in the Middle West
column19: which have gone through Western Europe for 15 years. Our balance of payments position will worsen. Our consumers will lack a wider choice of goods at lower prices. And millions of American workers - whose jobs depend on the sale or the transportation or the distribution of exports or imports
column20: or whose jobs will be endangered by the movement of our capital to Europe
column21: or whose jobs can be maintained only in an expanding economy - these millions of workers in your home States and mine will see their real interests sacrificed.

column1: Members of the Congress: The United States did not rise to greatness by waiting for others to lead. This Nation is the world's foremost manufacturer
column2: farmer
column3: banker
column4: consumer
column5: and exporter. The Common Market is moving ahead at an economic growth rate twice ours. The Communist economic offensive is under way. The opportunity is ours - the initiative is up to us - and I believe that 1962 is the time.

column1: To seize that initiative
column2: I shall shortly send to the Congress a new five-year Trade Expansion Action
column3: far-reaching in scope but designed with great care to make certain that its benefits to our people far outweigh any risks. The bill will permit the gradual elimination of tariffs here in the United States and in the Common Market on those items in which we together supply 80 percent of the world's trade - mostly items in which our own ability to compete is demonstrated by the fact that we sell abroad
column4: in these items
column5: substantially more than we import. This step will make it possible for our major industries to compete with their counterparts in Western Europe for access to European consumers.

column1: On other goods the bill will permit a gradual reduction of duties up to 50 percent - permitting bargaining by major categories - and provide for appropriate and tested forms of assistance to firms and employees adjusting to import competition. We are not neglecting the safeguards provided by peril points
column2: an escape clause
column3: or the National Security Amendment. Nor are we abandoning our non-European friends or our traditional "most-favored nation" principle. On the contrary
column4: the bill will provide new encouragement for their sale of tropical agricultural products
column5: so important to our friends in Latin America
column6: who have long depended upon the European market
column7: who now find themselves faced with new challenges which we must join with them in overcoming.

column1: Concessions
column2: in this bargaining
column3: must of course be reciprocal
column4: not unilateral. The Common Market will not fulfill its own high promise unless its outside tariff walls are low. The dangers of restriction or timidity in our own policy have counterparts for our friends in Europe. For together we face a common challenge: to enlarge the prosperity of free men everywhere - to build in partnership a new trading community in which all free nations may gain from the productive energy of free competitive effort.

column1: These various elements in our foreign policy lead
column2: as I have said
column3: to a single goal - the goal of a peaceful world of free and independent states. This is our guide for the present and our vision for the future - a free community of nations
column4: independent but interdependent
column5: uniting north and south
column6: east and west
column7: in one great family of man
column8: outgrowing and transcending the hates and fears that rend our age.

column1: We will not reach that goal today
column2: or tomorrow. We may not reach it in our own lifetime. But the quest is the greatest adventure of our century. We sometimes chafe at the burden of our obligations
column3: the complexity of our decisions
column4: the agony of our choices. But there is no comfort or security for us in evasion
column5: no solution in abdication
column6: no relief in irresponsibility.

column1: A year ago
column2: in assuming the tasks of the Presidency
column3: I said that few generations
column4: in all history
column5: had been granted the role of being the great defender of freedom in its hour of maximum danger. This is our good fortune; and I welcome it now as I did a year ago. For it is the fate of this generation - of you in the Congress and of me as President - to live with a struggle we did not start
column6: in a world we did not make. But the pressures of life are not always distributed by choice. And while no nation has ever faced such a challenge
column7: no nation has ever been so ready to seize the burden and the glory of freedom.

column1: And in this high endeavor
column2: may God watch over the United States of America.@

column1: John F. Kennedy|Annual Address to a Joint Session of Congress on the State of the Union|1963-01-14|@Mr. Vice President
column2: Mr. Speaker
column3: Members of the 88th Congress:

column1: I congratulate you all - not merely on your electoral victory but on your selected role in history. For you and I are privileged to serve the great Republic in what could be the most decisive decade in its long history. The choices we make
column2: for good or ill
column3: may well shape the state of the Union for generations yet to come.

column1: Little more than 100 weeks ago I assumed the office of President of the United States. In seeking the help of the Congress and our countrymen
column2: I pledged no easy answers. I pledged - and asked - only toil and dedication. These the Congress and the people have given in good measure. And today
column3: having witnessed in recent months a heightened respect for our national purpose and power - having seen the courageous calm of a united people in a perilous hour - and having observed a steady improvement in the opportunities and well-being of our citizens - I can report to you that the state of this old but youthful Union
column4: in the 175th year of its life
column5: is good.

column1: In the world beyond our borders
column2: steady progress has been made in building a world of order. The people of West Berlin remain both free and secure. A settlement
column3: though still precarious
column4: has been reached in Laos. The spear point of aggression has been blunted in Viet Nam. The end of agony may be in sight in the Congo. The doctrine of troika is dead. And
column5: while danger continues
column6: a deadly threat has been removed in Cuba.

column1: At home
column2: the recession is behind us. Well over a million more men and women are working today than were working 2 years ago. The average factory workweek is once again more than 40 hours; our industries are turning out more goods than ever before; and more than half of the manufacturing capacity that lay silent and wasted 100 weeks ago is humming with activity.

column1: In short
column2: both at home and abroad
column3: there may now be a temptation to relax. For the road has been long
column4: the burden heavy
column5: and the pace consistently urgent.

column1: But we cannot be satisfied to rest here. This is the side of the hill
column2: not the top. The mere absence of war is not peace. The mere absence of recession is not growth. We have made a beginning - but we have only begun.

column1: Now the time has come to make the most of our gains - to translate the renewal of our national strength into the achievement of our national purpose.
I.
America has enjoyed twenty-two months of uninterrupted economic recovery. But recovery is not enough. If we are to prevail in the long run
column2: we must expand the long-run strength of our economy. We must move along the path to a higher rate of growth and full employment.

column1: For this would mean tens of billions of dollars more each year in production
column2: profits
column3: wages
column4: and public revenues. It would mean an end to the persistent slack which has kept our unemployment at or above 5 percent for 61 out of the past 62 months - and an end to the growing pressures for such restrictive measures as the 35-hour week
column5: which alone could increase hourly labor costs by as much as 14 percent
column6: start a new wage-price spiral of inflation
column7: and undercut our efforts to compete with other nations.

column1: To achieve these greater gains
column2: one step
column3: above all
column4: is essential - the enactment this year of a substantial reduction and revision in Federal income taxes.

column1: For it is increasingly clear - to those in Government
column2: business
column3: and labor who are responsible for our economy's success - that our obsolete tax system exerts too heavy a drag on private purchasing power
column4: profits
column5: and employment. Designed to check inflation in earlier years
column6: it now checks growth instead. It discourages extra effort and risk. It distorts the use of resources. It invites recurrent recessions
column7: depresses our Federal revenues
column8: and causes chronic budget deficits.

column1: Now
column2: when the inflationary pressures of the war and the post-war years no longer threaten
column3: and the dollar commands new respect - now
column4: when no military crisis strains our resources - now is the time to act. We cannot afford to be timid or slow. For this is the most urgent task confronting the Congress in 1963.

column1: In an early message
column2: I shall propose a permanent reduction in tax rates which will lower liabilities by $13.5 billion. Of this
column3: $11 billion results from reducing individual tax rates
column4: which now range between 20 and 91 percent
column5: to a more sensible range of 14 to 65 percent
column6: with a split in the present first bracket. Two and one-half billion dollars results from reducing corporate tax rates
column7: from 52 percent - which gives the Government today a majority interest in profits - to the permanent pre-Korean level of 47 percent. This is in addition to the more than $2 billion cut in corporate tax liabilities resulting from last year's investment credit and depreciation reform.

column1: To achieve this reduction within the limits of a manageable budgetary deficit
column2: I urge: first
column3: that these cuts be phased over 3 calendar years
column4: beginning in 1963 with a cut of some $6 billion at annual rates; second
column5: that these reductions be coupled with selected structural changes
column6: beginning in 1964
column7: which will broaden the tax base
column8: end unfair or unnecessary preferences
column9: remove or lighten certain hardships
column10: and in the net offset some $3.5 billion of the revenue loss; and third
column11: that budgetary receipts at the outset be increased by $1.5 billion a year
column12: without any change in tax liabilities
column13: by gradually shifting the tax payments of large corporations to a more current time schedule. This combined program
column14: by increasing the amount of our national income
column15: will in time result in still higher Federal revenues. It is a fiscally responsible program - the surest and the soundest way of achieving in time a balanced budget in a balanced full employment economy.

column1: This net reduction in tax liabilities of $10 billion will increase the purchasing power of American families and business enterprises in every tax bracket
column2: with greatest increase going to our low-income consumers. It will
column3: in addition
column4: encourage the initiative and risk-taking on which our free system depends - induce more investment
column5: production
column6: and capacity use - help provide the 2 million new jobs we need every year - and reinforce the American principle of additional reward for additional effort.

column1: I do not say that a measure for tax reduction and reform is the only way to achieve these goals.
No doubt a massive increase in Federal spending could also create jobs and growth - but
column2: in today's setting
column3: private consumers
column4: employers
column5: and investors should be given a full opportunity first.

column1: No doubt a temporary tax cut could provide a spur to our economy - but a long-run problem compels a long-run solution.
No doubt a reduction in either individual or corporation taxes alone would be of great help - but corporations need customers and job seekers need jobs.

No doubt tax reduction without reform would sound simpler and more attractive to many - but our growth is also hampered by a host of tax inequities and special preferences which have distorted the flow of investment.
And
column2: finally
column3: there are no doubt some who would prefer to put off a tax cut in the hope that ultimately an end to the cold war would make possible an equivalent cut in expenditures - but that end is not in view and to wait for it would be costly and self-defeating.

column1: In submitting a tax program which will
column2: of course
column3: temporarily increase the deficit but can ultimately end it - and in recognition of the need to control expenditures - I will shortly submit a fiscal 1964 administrative budget which
column4: while allowing for needed rises in defense
column5: space
column6: and fixed interest charges
column7: holds total expenditures for all other purposes below this year's level.

column1: This requires the reduction or postponement of many desirable programs
column2: the absorption of a large part of last year's Federal pay raise through personnel and other economies
column3: the termination of certain installations and projects
column4: and the substitution in several programs of private for public credit. But I am convinced that the enactment this year of tax reduction and tax reform overshadows all other domestic problems in this Congress. For we cannot for long lead the cause of peace and freedom
column5: if we ever cease to set the pace here at home.

column1: II.
Tax reduction alone
column2: however
column3: is not enough to strengthen our society
column4: to provide opportunities for the four million Americans who are born every year
column5: to improve the lives of 32 million Americans who live on the outskirts of poverty.

column1: The quality of American life must keep pace with the quantity of American goods.
This country cannot afford to be materially rich and spiritually poor.
Therefore
column2: by holding down the budgetary cost of existing programs to keep within the limitations I have set
column3: it is both possible and imperative to adopt other new measures that we cannot afford to postpone.

column1: These measures are based on a series of fundamental premises
column2: grouped under four related headings:

column1: First
column2: we need to strengthen our Nation by investing in our youth:

column1: The future of any country which is dependent upon the will and wisdom of its citizens is damaged
column2: and irreparably damaged
column3: whenever any of its children is not educated to the full extent of his talent
column4: from grade school through graduate school. Today
column5: an estimated 4 out of every 10 students in the 5th grade will not even finish high school - and that is a waste we cannot afford.

column1: In addition
column2: there is no reason why one million young Americans
column3: out of school and out of work
column4: should all remain unwanted and often untrained on our city streets when their energies can be put to good use.

column1: Finally
column2: the overseas success of our Peace Corps volunteers
column3: most of them young men and women carrying skills and ideas to needy people
column4: suggests the merit of a similar corps serving our own community needs: in mental hospitals
column5: on Indian reservations
column6: in centers for the aged or for young delinquents
column7: in schools for the illiterate or the handicapped. As the idealism of our youth has served world peace
column8: so can it serve the domestic tranquility.

column1: Second
column2: we need to strengthen our Nation by safeguarding its health:

column1: Our working men and women
column2: instead of being forced to beg for help from public charity once they are old and ill
column3: should start contributing now to their own retirement health program through the Social Security System.

column1: Moreover
column2: all our miracles of medical research will count for little if we cannot reverse the growing nationwide shortage of doctors
column3: dentists
column4: and nurses
column5: and the widespread shortages of nursing homes and modern urban hospital facilities. Merely to keep the present ratio of doctors and dentists from declining any further
column6: we must over the next 10 years increase the capacity of our medical schools by 50 percent and our dental schools by 100 percent.

column1: Finally
column2: and of deep concern
column3: I believe that the abandonment of the mentally ill and the mentally retarded to the grim mercy of custodial institutions too often inflicts on them and on their families a needless cruelty which this Nation should not endure. The incidence of mental retardation in this country is three times as high as that of Sweden
column4: for example - and that figure can and must be reduced.

column1: Third
column2: we need to strengthen our Nation by protecting the basic rights of its citizens:

column1: The right to competent counsel must be assured to every man accused of crime in Federal court
column2: regardless of his means.

column1: And the most precious and powerful right in the world
column2: the right to vote in a free American election
column3: must not be denied to any citizen on grounds of his race or color. I wish that all qualified Americans permitted to vote were willing to vote
column4: but surely in this centennial year of Emancipation all those who are willing to vote should always be permitted.

column1: Fourth
column2: we need to strengthen our Nation by making the best and the most economical use of its resources and facilities:

column1: Our economic health depends on healthy transportation arteries; and I believe the way to a more modern
column2: economical choice of national transportation service is through increased competition and decreased regulation. Local mass transit
column3: faring even worse
column4: is as essential a community service as hospitals and highways. Nearly three-fourths of our citizens live in urban areas
column5: which occupy only 2 percent of our land - and if local transit is to survive and relieve the congestion of these cities
column6: it needs Federal stimulation and assistance.

column1: Next
column2: this Government is in the storage and stockpile business to the melancholy tune of more than $16 billion. We must continue to support farm income
column3: but we should not pile more farm surpluses on top of the $7.5 billion we already own. We must maintain a stockpile of strategic materials
column4: but the $8.5 billion we have acquired - for reasons both good and bad - is much more than we need; and we should be empowered to dispose of the excess in ways which will not cause market disruption.

column1: Finally
column2: our already overcrowded national parks and recreation areas will have twice as many visitors 10 years from now as they do today. If we do not plan today for the future growth of these and other great natural assets - not only parks and forests but wildlife and wilderness preserves
column3: and water projects of all kinds - our children and their children will be poorer in every sense of the word.

column1: These are not domestic concerns alone. For upon our achievement of greater vitality and strength here at home hang our fate and future in the world: our ability to sustain and supply the security of free men and nations
column2: our ability to command their respect for our leadership
column3: our ability to expand our trade without threat to our balance of payments
column4: and our ability to adjust to the changing demands of cold war competition and challenge.

column1: We shall be judged more by what we do at home than by what we preach abroad. Nothing we could do to help the developing countries would help them half as much as a booming U.S. economy. And nothing our opponents could do to encourage their own ambitions would encourage them half as much as a chronic lagging U.S. economy. These domestic tasks do not divert energy from our security - they provide the very foundation for freedom's survival and success.
III.
Turning to the world outside
column2: it was only a few years ago - in Southeast Asia
column3: Africa
column4: Eastern Europe
column5: Latin America
column6: even outer space - that communism sought to convey the image of a unified
column7: confident
column8: and expanding empire
column9: closing in on a sluggish America and a free world in disarray. But few people would hold to that picture today.

column1: In these past months we have reaffirmed the scientific and military superiority of freedom. We have doubled our efforts in space
column2: to assure us of being first in the future. We have undertaken the most far-reaching defense improvements in the peacetime history of this country. And we have maintained the frontiers of freedom from Viet Nam to West Berlin.

column1: But complacency or self-congratulation can imperil our security as much as the weapons of tyranny. A moment of pause is not a promise of peace. Dangerous problems remain from Cuba to the South China Sea. The world's prognosis prescribes
column2: in short
column3: not a year's vacation for us
column4: but a year of obligation and opportunity.

column1: Four special avenues of opportunity stand out: the Atlantic Alliance
column2: the developing nations
column3: the new Sino-Soviet difficulties
column4: and the search for worldwide peace.

column1: First
column2: how fares the grand alliance? Free Europe is entering into a new phase of its long and brilliant history. The era of colonial expansion has passed; the era of national rivalries is fading; and a new era of interdependence and unity is taking shape. Defying the old prophecies of Marx
column3: consenting to what no conqueror could ever compel
column4: the free nations of Europe are moving toward a unity of purpose and power and policy in every sphere of activity.

column1: For 17 years this movement has had our consistent support
column2: both political and economic. Far from resenting the new Europe
column3: we regard her as a welcome partner
column4: not a rival. For the road to world peace and freedom is still long
column5: and there are burdens which only full partners can share - in supporting the common defense
column6: in expanding world trade
column7: in aligning our balance of payments
column8: in aiding the emergent nations
column9: in concerting political and economic policies
column10: and in welcoming to our common effort other industrialized nations
column11: notably Japan
column12: whose remarkable economic and political development of the 1950's permits it now to play on the world scene a major constructive role.

column1: No doubt differences of opinion will continue to get more attention than agreements on action
column2: as Europe moves from independence to more formal interdependence. But these are honest differences among honorable associates - more real and frequent
column3: in fact
column4: among our Western European allies than between them and the United States. For the unity of freedom has never relied on uniformity of opinion. But the basic agreement of this alliance on fundamental issues continues.

column1: The first task of the alliance remains the common defense. Last month Prime Minister Macmillan and I laid plans for a new stage in our long cooperative effort
column2: one which aims to assist in the wider task of framing a common nuclear defense for the whole alliance.

column1: The Nassau agreement recognizes that the security of the West is indivisible
column2: and so must be our defense. But it also recognizes that this is an alliance of proud and sovereign nations
column3: and works best when we do not forget it. It recognizes further that the nuclear defense of the West is not a matter for the present nuclear powers alone - that France will be such a power in the future - and that ways must be found without increasing the hazards of nuclear diffusion
column4: to increase the role of our other partners in planning
column5: manning
column6: and directing a truly multilateral nuclear force within an increasingly intimate NATO alliance. Finally
column7: the Nassau agreement recognizes that nuclear defense is not enough
column8: that the agreed NATO levels of conventional strength must be met
column9: and that the alliance cannot afford to be in a position of having to answer every threat with nuclear weapons or nothing.

column1: We remain too near the Nassau decisions
column2: and too far from their full realization
column3: to know their place in history. But I believe that
column4: for the first time
column5: the door is open for the nuclear defense of the alliance to become a source of confidence
column6: instead of a cause of contention.

column1: The next most pressing concern of the alliance is our common economic goals of trade and growth. This Nation continues to be concerned about its balance-of-payments deficit
column2: which
column3: despite its decline
column4: remains a stubborn and troublesome problem. We believe
column5: moreover
column6: that closer economic ties among all free nations are essential to prosperity and peace. And neither we nor the members of the European Common Market are so affluent that we can long afford to shelter high cost farms or factories from the winds of foreign competition
column7: or to restrict the channels of trade with other nations of the free world. If the Common Market should move toward protectionism and restrictionism
column8: it would undermine its own basic principles. This Government means to use the authority conferred on it last year by the Congress to encourage trade expansion on both sides of the Atlantic and around the world.

column1: Second
column2: what of the developing and non-aligned nations? They were shocked by the Soviets' sudden and secret attempt to transform Cuba into a nuclear striking base - and by Communist China's arrogant invasion of India. They have been reassured by our prompt assistance to India
column3: by our support through the United Nations of the Congo's unification
column4: by our patient search for disarmament
column5: and by the improvement in our treatment of citizens and visitors whose skins do not happen to be white. And as the older colonialism recedes
column6: and the neo-colonialism of the Communist powers stands out more starkly than ever
column7: they realize more clearly that the issue in the world struggle is not communism versus capitalism
column8: but coercion versus free choice.

column1: They are beginning to realize that the longing for independence is the same the world over
column2: whether it is the independence of West Berlin or Viet Nam. They are beginning to realize that such independence runs athwart all Communist ambitions but is in keeping with our own - and that our approach to their diverse needs is resilient and resourceful
column3: while the Communists are still relying on ancient doctrines and dogmas.

column1: Nevertheless it is hard for any nation to focus on an external or subversive threat to its independence when its energies are drained in daily combat with the forces of poverty and despair. It makes little sense for us to assail
column2: in speeches and resolutions
column3: the horrors of communism
column4: to spend $50 billion a year to prevent its military advance - and then to begrudge spending
column5: largely on American products
column6: less than one-tenth of that amount to help other nations strengthen their independence and cure the social chaos in which communism always has thrived.

column1: I am proud - and I think most Americans are proud - of a mutual defense and assistance program
column2: evolved with bipartisan support in three administrations
column3: which has
column4: with all its recognized problems
column5: contributed to the fact that not a single one of the nearly fifty U.N. members to gain independence since the Second World War has succumbed to Communist control.

column1: I am proud of a program that has helped to arm and feed and clothe millions of people who live on the front lines of freedom.
I am especially proud that this country has put forward for the 60's a vast cooperative effort to achieve economic growth and social progress throughout the Americas - the Alliance for Progress.
I do not underestimate the difficulties that we face in this mutual effort among our close neighbors
column2: but the free states of this hemisphere
column3: working in close collaboration
column4: have begun to make this alliance a living reality. Today it is feeding one out of every four school age children in Latin America an extra food ration from our farm surplus. It has distributed 1.5 million school books and is building 17
column5: 000 classrooms. It has helped resettle tens of thousands of farm families on land they can call their own. It is stimulating our good neighbors to more self-help and self-reform - fiscal
column6: social
column7: institutional
column8: and land reforms. It is bringing new housing and hope
column9: new health and dignity
column10: to millions who were forgotten. The men and women of this hemisphere know that the alliance cannot succeed if it is only another name for United States handouts - that it can succeed only as the Latin American nations themselves devote their best effort to fulfilling its goals.

column1: This story is the same in Africa
column2: in the Middle East
column3: and in Asia. Wherever nations are willing to help themselves
column4: we stand ready to help them build new bulwarks of freedom. We are not purchasing votes for the cold war; we have gone to the aid of imperiled nations
column5: neutrals and allies alike. What we do ask - and all that we ask - is that our help be used to best advantage
column6: and that their own efforts not be diverted by needless quarrels with other independent nations.

column1: Despite all its past achievements
column2: the continued progress of the mutual assistance program requires a persistent discontent with present performance. We have been reorganizing this program to make it a more effective
column3: efficient instrument - and that process will continue this year.

column1: But free world development will still be an uphill struggle. Government aid can only supplement the role of private investment
column2: trade expansion
column3: commodity stabilization
column4: and
column5: above all
column6: internal self-improvement. The processes of growth are gradual - bearing fruit in a decade
column7: not a day. Our successes will be neither quick nor dramatic. But if these programs were ever to be ended
column8: our failures in a dozen countries would be sudden and certain.

column1: Neither money nor technical assistance
column2: however
column3: can be our only weapon against poverty. In the end
column4: the crucial effort is one of purpose
column5: requiring the fuel of finance but also a torch of idealism. And nothing carries the spirit of this American idealism more effectively to the far corners of the earth than the American Peace Corps.

column1: A year ago
column2: less than 900 Peace Corps volunteers were on the job. A year from now they will number more than 9
column3: 000 - men and women
column4: aged 18 to 79
column5: willing to give 2 years of their lives to helping people in other lands.

column1: There are
column2: in fact
column3: nearly a million Americans serving their country and the cause of freedom in overseas posts
column4: a record no other people can match. Surely those of us who stay at home should be glad to help indirectly; by supporting our aid programs; by opening our doors to foreign visitors and diplomats and students; and by proving
column5: day by day
column6: by deed as well as word
column7: that we are a just and generous people.

column1: Third
column2: what comfort can we take from the increasing strains and tensions within the Communist bloc? Here hope must be tempered with caution. For the Soviet-Chinese disagreement is over means
column3: not ends. A dispute over how best to bury the free world is no grounds for Western rejoicing.

column1: Nevertheless
column2: while a strain is not a fracture
column3: it is clear that the forces of diversity are at work inside the Communist camp
column4: despite all the iron disciplines of regimentation and all the iron dogmatisms of ideology. Marx is proven wrong once again: for it is the closed Communist societies
column5: not the free and open societies which carry within themselves the seeds of internal disintegration.

column1: The disarray of the Communist empire has been heightened by two other formidable forces. One is the historical force of nationalism - and the yearning of all men to be free. The other is the gross inefficiency of their economies. For a closed society is not open to ideas of progress - and a police state finds that it cannot command the grain to grow.
New nations asked to choose between two competing systems need only compare conditions in East and West Germany
column2: Eastern and Western Europe
column3: North and South Viet Nam. They need only compare the disillusionment of Communist Cuba with the promise of the Alliance for Progress. And all the world knows that no successful system builds a wall to keep its people in and freedom out - and the wall of shame dividing Berlin is a symbol of Communist failure.

column1: Finally
column2: what can we do to move from the present pause toward enduring peace? Again I would counsel caution. I foresee no spectacular reversal in Communist methods or goals. But if all these trends and developments can persuade the Soviet Union to walk the path of peace
column3: then let her know that all free nations will journey with her. But until that choice is made
column4: and until the world can develop a reliable system of international security
column5: the free peoples have no choice but to keep their arms nearby.

column1: This country
column2: therefore
column3: continues to require the best defense in the world - a defense which is suited to the sixties. This means
column4: unfortunately
column5: a rising defense budget - for there is no substitute for adequate defense
column6: and no "bargain basement" way of achieving it. It means the expenditure of more than $15 billion this year on nuclear weapons systems alone
column7: a sum which is about equal to the combined defense budgets of our European Allies.

column1: But it also means improved air and missile defenses
column2: improved civil defense
column3: a strengthened anti-guerrilla capacity and
column4: of prime importance
column5: more powerful and flexible non-nuclear forces. For threats of massive retaliation may not deter piecemeal aggression - and a line of destroyers in a quarantine
column6: or a division of well-equipped men on a border
column7: may be more useful to our real security than the multiplication of awesome weapons beyond all rational need.

column1: But our commitment to national safety is not a commitment to expand our military establishment indefinitely. We do not dismiss disarmament as merely an idle dream. For we believe that
column2: in the end
column3: it is the only way to assure the security of all without impairing the interests of any. Nor do we mistake honorable negotiation for appeasement. While we shall never weary in the defense of freedom
column4: neither shall we ever abandon the pursuit of peace.

column1: In this quest
column2: the United Nations requires our full and continued support. Its value in serving the cause of peace has been shown anew in its role in the West New Guinea settlement
column3: in its use as a forum for the Cuban crisis
column4: and in its task of unification in the Congo. Today the United Nations is primarily the protector of the small and the weak
column5: and a safety valve for the strong. Tomorrow it can form the framework for a world of law - a world in which no nation dictates the destiny of another
column6: and in which the vast resources now devoted to destructive means will serve constructive ends.

column1: In short
column2: let our adversaries choose. If they choose peaceful competition
column3: they shall have it. If they come to realize that their ambitions cannot succeed - if they see their "wars of liberation" and subversion will ultimately fail - if they recognize that there is more security in accepting inspection than in permitting new nations to master the black arts of nuclear war - and if they are willing to turn their energies
column4: as we are
column5: to the great unfinished tasks of our own peoples - then
column6: surely
column7: the areas of agreement can be very wide indeed: a clear understanding about Berlin
column8: stability in Southeast Asia
column9: an end to nuclear testing
column10: new checks on surprise or accidental attack
column11: and
column12: ultimately
column13: general and complete disarmament.

column1: For we seek not the worldwide victory of one nation or system but a worldwide victory of man. The modern globe is too small
column2: its weapons are too destructive
column3: and its disorders are too contagious to permit any other kind of victory.

column1: To achieve this end
column2: the United States will continue to spend a greater portion of its national production than any other people in the free world. For 15 years no other free nation has demanded so much of itself. Through hot wars and cold
column3: through recession and prosperity
column4: through the ages of the atom and outer space
column5: the American people have never faltered and their faith has never flagged. If at times our actions seem to make life difficult for others
column6: it is only because history has made life difficult for us all.

column1: But difficult days need not be dark. I think these are proud and memorable days in the cause of peace and freedom. We are proud
column2: for example
column3: of Major Rudolf Anderson who gave his life over the island of Cuba. We salute Specialist James Allen Johnson who died on the border of South Korea. We pay honor to Sergeant Gerald Pendell who was killed in Viet Nam. They are among the many who in this century
column4: far from home
column5: have died for our country. Our task now
column6: and the task of all Americans is to live up to their commitment.

column1: My friends: I close on a note of hope. We are not lulled by the momentary calm of the sea or the somewhat clearer skies above. We know the turbulence that lies below
column2: and the storms that are beyond the horizon this year. But now the winds of change appear to be blowing more strongly than ever
column3: in the world of communism as well as our own. For 175 years we have sailed with those winds at our back
column4: and with the tides of human freedom in our favor. We steer our ship with hope
column5: as Thomas Jefferson said
column6: "leaving Fear astern."

column1: Today we still welcome those winds of change - and we have every reason to believe that our tide is running strong. With thanks to Almighty God for seeing us through a perilous passage
column2: we ask His help anew in guiding the "Good Ship Union."@

column1: Lyndon B. Johnson|Annual Message to the Congress on the State of the Union|1963-11-27|@Mr. Speaker
column2: Mr. President
column3: Members of the House
column4: Members of the Senate
column5: my fellow Americans:

column1: All I have I would have given gladly not to be standing here today.

The greatest leader of our time has been struck down by the foulest deed of our time. Today John Fitzgerald Kennedy lives on in the immortal words and works that he left behind. He lives on in the mind and memories of mankind. He lives on in the hearts of his countrymen.
No words are sad enough to express our sense of loss. No words are strong enough to express our determination to continue the forward thrust of America that he began.

The dream of conquering the vastness of space--the dream of partnership across the Atlantic--and across the Pacific as well--the dream of a Peace Corps in less developed nations--the dream of education for all of our children--the dream of jobs for all who seek them and need them--the dream of care for our elderly--the dream of an all-out attack on mental illness--and above all
column2: the dream of equal rights for all Americans
column3: whatever their race or color--these and other American dreams have been vitalized by his drive and by his dedication.

column1: And now the ideas and the ideals which he so nobly represented must and will be translated into effective action.
Under John Kennedy's leadership
column2: this Nation has demonstrated that it has the courage to seek peace
column3: and it has the fortitude to risk war. We have proved that we are a good and reliable friend to those who seek peace and freedom. We have shown that we can also be a formidable foe to those who reject the path of peace and those who seek to impose upon us or our allies the yoke of tyranny.

column1: This Nation will keep its commitments from South Viet-Nam to West Berlin. We will be unceasing in the search for peace; resourceful in our pursuit of areas of agreement even with those with whom we differ; and generous and loyal to those who join with us in common cause.
In this age when there can be no losers in peace and no victors in war
column2: we must recognize the obligation to match national strength with national restraint. We must be prepared at one and the same time for both the confrontation of power and the limitation of power. We must be ready to defend the national interest and to negotiate the common interest. This is the path that we shall continue to pursue. Those who test our courage will find it strong
column3: and those who seek our friendship will find it honorable. We will demonstrate anew that the strong can be just in the use of strength; and the just can be strong in the defense of justice.

column1: And let all know we will extend no special privilege and impose no persecution. We will carry on the fight against poverty and misery
column2: and disease and ignorance
column3: in other lands and in our own.

column1: We will serve all the Nation
column2: not one section or one sector
column3: or one group
column4: but all Americans. These are the United States--a united people with a united purpose.

column1: Our American unity does not depend upon unanimity. We have differences; but now
column2: as in the past
column3: we can derive from those differences strength
column4: not weakness
column5: wisdom
column6: not despair. Both as a people and a government
column7: we can unite upon a program
column8: a program which is wise and just
column9: enlightened and constructive.

column1: For 32 years Capitol Hill has been my home. I have shared many moments of pride with you
column2: pride in the ability of the Congress of the United States to act
column3: to meet any crisis
column4: to distill from our differences strong programs of national action.

column1: An assassin's bullet has thrust upon me the awesome burden of the Presidency. I am here today to say I need your help; I cannot bear this burden alone. I need the help of all Americans
column2: and all America. This Nation has experienced a profound shock
column3: and in this critical moment
column4: it is our duty
column5: yours and mine
column6: as the Government of the United States
column7: to do away with uncertainty and doubt and delay
column8: and to show that we are capable of decisive action; that from the brutal loss of our leader we will derive not weakness
column9: but strength; that we can and will act and act now.

column1: From this chamber of representative government
column2: let all the world know and none misunderstand that I rededicate this Government to the unswerving support of the United Nations
column3: to the honorable and determined execution of our commitments to our allies
column4: to the maintenance of military strength second to none
column5: to the defense of the strength and the stability of the dollar
column6: to the expansion of our foreign trade
column7: to the reinforcement of our programs of mutual assistance and cooperation in Asia and Africa
column8: and to our Alliance for Progress in this hemisphere.

column1: On the 20th day of January
column3: John F. Kennedy told his countrymen that our national work would not be finished "in the first thousand days
column4: nor in the life of this administration
column5: nor even perhaps in our lifetime on this planet. But
column6: he said, let us begin."

column1: Today
column2: in this moment of new resolve
column3: I would say to all my fellow Americans
column4: let us continue.

column1: This is our challenge--not to hesitate
column2: not to pause
column3: not to turn about and linger over this evil moment
column4: but to continue on our course so that we may fulfill the destiny that history has set for us. Our most immediate tasks are here on this Hill.

column1: First
column2: no memorial oration or eulogy could more eloquently honor President Kennedy's memory than the earliest possible passage of the civil rights bill for which he fought so long. We have talked long enough in this country about equal rights. We have talked for one hundred years or more. It is time now to write the next chapter
column3: and to write it in the books of law.

column1: I urge you again
column2: as I did in 1957 and again in 1960
column3: to enact a civil rights law so that we can move forward to eliminate from this Nation every trace of discrimination and oppression that is based upon race or color. There could be no greater source of strength to this Nation both at home and abroad.

column1: And second
column2: no act of ours could more fittingly continue the work of President Kennedy than the early passage of the tax bill for which he fought all this long year. This is a bill designed to increase our national income and Federal revenues
column3: and to provide insurance against recession. That bill
column4: if passed without delay
column5: means more security for those now working
column6: more jobs for those now without them
column7: and more incentive for our economy.

column1: In short
column2: this is no time for delay. It is a time for action--strong
column3: forward-looking action on the pending education bills to help bring the light of learning to every home and hamlet in America--strong
column4: forward-looking action on youth employment opportunities; strong
column5: forward-looking action on the pending foreign aid bill
column6: making clear that we are not forfeiting our responsibilities to this hemisphere or to the world
column7: nor erasing Executive flexibility in the conduct of our foreign affairs--and strong
column8: prompt
column9: and forward-looking action on the remaining appropriation bills.

column1: In this new spirit of action
column2: the Congress can expect the full cooperation and support of the executive branch. And in particular
column3: I pledge that the expenditures of your Government will be administered with the utmost thrift and frugality. I will insist that the Government get a dollar's value for a dollar spent. The Government will set an example of prudence and economy. This does not mean that we will not meet our unfilled needs or that we will not honor our commitments. We will do both.

column1: As one who has long served in both Houses of the Congress
column2: I firmly believe in the independence and the integrity of the legislative branch. And I promise you that I shall always respect this. It is deep in the marrow of my bones. With equal firmness
column3: I believe in the capacity and I believe in the ability of the Congress
column4: despite the divisions of opinions which characterize our Nation
column5: to act--to act wisely
column6: to act vigorously
column7: to act speedily when the need arises.

column1: The need is here. The need is now. I ask your help.
We meet in grief
column2: but let us also meet in renewed dedication and renewed vigor. Let us meet in action
column3: in tolerance
column4: and in mutual understanding. John Kennedy's death commands what his life conveyed--that America must move forward. The time has come for Americans of all races and creeds and political beliefs to understand and to respect one another. So let us put an end to the teaching and the preaching of hate and evil and violence. Let us turn away from the fanatics of the far left and the far right
column5: from the apostles of bitterness and bigotry
column6: from those defiant of law
column7: and those who pour venom into our Nation's bloodstream.

column1: I profoundly hope that the tragedy and the torment of these terrible days will bind us together in new fellowship
column2: making us one people in our hour of sorrow. So let us here highly resolve that John Fitzgerald Kennedy did not live--or die--in vain. And on this Thanksgiving eve
column3: as we gather together to ask the Lord's blessing
column4: and give Him our thanks
column5: let us unite in those familiar and cherished words:

column1: America
column2: America

column1: God shed His grace on thee
And crown thy good With brotherhood
From sea to shining sea.@
Lyndon B. Johnson|Annual Message to the Congress on the State of the Union|1964-01-08|@Mr. Speaker
column2: Mr. President
column3: Members of the House and Senate
column4: my fellow Americans:

column1: I will be brief
column2: for our time is necessarily short and our agenda is already long.

column1: Last year's congressional session was the longest in peacetime history. With that foundation
column2: let us work together to make this year's session the best in the Nation's history.

column1: Let this session of Congress be known as the session which did more for civil rights than the last hundred sessions combined; as the session which enacted the most far-reaching tax cut of our time; as the session which declared all-out war on human poverty and unemployment in these United States; as the session which finally recognized the health needs of all our older citizens; as the session which reformed our tangled transportation and transit policies; as the session which achieved the most effective
column2: efficient foreign aid program ever; and as the session which helped to build more homes
column3: more schools
column4: more libraries
column5: and more hospitals than any single session of Congress in the history of our Republic.

column1: All this and more can and must be done. It can be done by this summer
column2: and it can be done without any increase in spending. In fact
column3: under the budget that I shall shortly submit
column4: it can be done with an actual reduction in Federal expenditures and Federal employment.

column1: We have in 1964 a unique opportunity and obligation--to prove the success of our system; to disprove those cynics and critics at home and abroad who question our purpose and our competence.
If we fail
column2: if we fritter and fumble away our opportunity in needless
column3: senseless quarrels between Democrats and Republicans
column4: or between the House and the Senate
column5: or between the South and North
column6: or between the Congress and the administration
column7: then history will rightfully judge us harshly. But if we succeed
column8: if we can achieve these goals by forging in this country a greater sense of union
column9: then
column10: and only then
column11: can we take full satisfaction in the State of the Union.

column1: II.
Here in the Congress you can demonstrate effective legislative leadership by discharging the public business with clarity and dispatch
column2: voting each important proposal up
column3: or voting it down
column4: but at least bringing it to a fair and a final vote.

column1: Let us carry forward the plans and programs of John Fitzgerald Kennedy--not because of our sorrow or sympathy
column2: but because they are right.

column1: In his memory today
column2: I especially ask all members of my own political faith
column3: in this election year
column4: to put your country ahead of your party
column5: and to always debate principles; never debate personalities.

column1: For my part
column2: I pledge a progressive administration which is efficient
column3: and honest and frugal. The budget to be submitted to the Congress shortly is in full accord with this pledge.

column1: It will cut our deficit in half--from $10 billion to $4
column2: 900 million. It will be
column3: in proportion to our national output
column4: the smallest budget since 1951.

column1: It will call for a substantial reduction in Federal employment
column2: a feat accomplished only once before in the last 10 years. While maintaining the full strength of our combat defenses
column3: it will call for the lowest number of civilian personnel in the Department of Defense since 1950.

column1: It will call for total expenditures of $97
column2: 900 million--compared to $98
column3: 400 million for the current year
column4: a reduction of more than $500 million. It will call for new obligational authority of $103
column5: 800 million--a reduction of more than $4 billion below last year's request of $107
column6: 900 million.

column1: But it is not a standstill budget
column2: for America cannot afford to stand still. Our population is growing. Our economy is more complex. Our people's needs are expanding.

column1: But by closing down obsolete installations
column2: by curtailing less urgent programs
column3: by cutting back where cutting back seems to be wise
column4: by insisting on a dollar's worth for a dollar spent
column5: I am able to recommend in this reduced budget the most Federal support in history for education
column6: for health
column7: for retraining the unemployed
column8: and for helping the economically and the physically handicapped.

column1: This budget
column2: and this year's legislative program
column3: are designed to help each and every American citizen fulfill his basic hopes--his hopes for a fair chance to make good; his hopes for fair play from the law; his hopes for a full-time job on full-time pay; his hopes for a decent home for his family in a decent community; his hopes for a good school for his children with good teachers; and his hopes for security when faced with sickness or unemployment or old age.

column1: III.
Unfortunately
column2: many Americans live on the outskirts of hope--some because of their poverty
column3: and some because of their color
column4: and all too many because of both. Our task is to help replace their despair with opportunity.

column1: This administration today
column2: here and now
column3: declares unconditional war on poverty in America. I urge this Congress and all Americans to join with me in that effort.

column1: It will not be a short or easy struggle
column2: no single weapon or strategy will suffice
column3: but we shall not rest until that war is won. The richest Nation on earth can afford to win it. We cannot afford to lose it. One thousand dollars invested in salvaging an unemployable youth today can return $40
column4: 000 or more in his lifetime.

column1: Poverty is a national problem
column2: requiring improved national organization and support. But this attack
column3: to be effective
column4: must also be organized at the State and the local level and must be supported and directed by State and local efforts.

column1: For the war against poverty will not be won here in Washington. It must be won in the field
column2: in every private home
column3: in every public office
column4: from the courthouse to the White House.

column1: The program I shall propose will emphasize this cooperative approach to help that one-fifth of all American families with incomes too small to even meet their basic needs.
Our chief weapons in a more pinpointed attack will be better schools
column2: and better health
column3: and better homes
column4: and better training
column5: and better job opportunities to help more Americans
column6: especially young Americans
column7: escape from squalor and misery and unemployment rolls where other citizens help to carry them.

column1: Very often a lack of jobs and money is not the cause of poverty
column2: but the symptom. The cause may lie deeper in our failure to give our fellow citizens a fair chance to develop their own capacities
column3: in a lack of education and training
column4: in a lack of medical care and housing
column5: in a lack of decent communities in which to live and bring up their children.

column1: But whatever the cause
column2: our joint Federal-local effort must pursue poverty
column3: pursue it wherever it exists--in city slums and small towns
column4: in sharecropper shacks or in migrant worker camps
column5: on Indian Reservations
column6: among whites as well as Negroes
column7: among the young as well as the aged
column8: in the boom towns and in the depressed areas.

column1: Our aim is not only to relieve the symptom of poverty
column2: but to cure it and
column3: above all
column4: to prevent it. No single piece of legislation
column5: however
column6: is going to suffice.

column1: We will launch a special effort in the chronically distressed areas of Appalachia.
We must expand our small but our successful area redevelopment program.
We must enact youth employment legislation to put jobless
column2: aimless
column3: hopeless youngsters to work on useful projects.

column1: We must distribute more food to the needy through a broader food stamp program.
We must create a National Service Corps to help the economically handicapped of our own country as the Peace Corps now helps those abroad.
We must modernize our unemployment insurance and establish a high-level commission on automation. If we have the brain power to invent these machines
column2: we have the brain power to make certain that they are a boon and not a bane to humanity.

column1: We must extend the coverage of our minimum wage laws to more than 2 million workers now lacking this basic protection of purchasing power.
We must
column2: by including special school aid funds as part of our education program
column3: improve the quality of teaching
column4: training
column5: and counseling in our hardest hit areas.

column1: We must build more libraries in every area and more hospitals and nursing homes under the Hill-Burton Act
column2: and train more nurses to staff them.

column1: We must provide hospital insurance for our older citizens financed by every worker and his employer under Social Security
column2: contributing no more than $1 a month during the employee's working career to protect him in his old age in a dignified manner without cost to the Treasury
column3: against the devastating hardship of prolonged or repeated illness.

column1: We must
column2: as a part of a revised housing and urban renewal program
column3: give more help to those displaced by slum clearance
column4: provide more housing for our poor and our elderly
column5: and seek as our ultimate goal in our free enterprise system a decent home for every American family.

column1: We must help obtain more modern mass transit within our communities as well as low-cost transportation between them.
Above all
column2: we must release $11 billion of tax reduction into the private spending stream to create new jobs and new markets in every area of this land.

column1: IV.

These programs are obviously not for the poor or the underprivileged alone. Every American will benefit by the extension of social security to cover the hospital costs of their aged parents. Every American community will benefit from the construction or modernization of schools
column2: libraries
column3: hospitals
column4: and nursing homes
column5: from the training of more nurses and from the improvement of urban renewal in public transit. And every individual American taxpayer and every corporate taxpayer will benefit from the earliest possible passage of the pending tax bill from both the new investment it will bring and the new jobs that it will create.

column1: That tax bill has been thoroughly discussed for a year. Now we need action. The new budget clearly allows it. Our taxpayers surely deserve it. Our economy strongly demands it. And every month of delay dilutes its benefits in 1964 for consumption
column2: for investment
column3: and for employment.

column1: For until the bill is signed
column2: its investment incentives cannot be deemed certain
column3: and the withholding rate cannot be reduced--and the most damaging and devastating thing you can do to any businessman in America is to keep him in doubt and to keep him guessing on what our tax policy is. And I say that we should now reduce to 14 percent instead of 15 percent our withholding rate.

column1: I therefore urge the Congress to take final action on this bill by the first of February
column2: if at all possible. For however proud we may be of the unprecedented progress of our free enterprise economy over the last 3 years
column3: we should not and we cannot permit it to pause.

column2: for the first time in history
column3: we crossed the 70 million job mark
column4: but we will soon need more than 75 million jobs. In 1963 our gross national product reached the $600 billion level--$100 billion higher than when we took office. But it easily could and it should be still $30 billion higher today than it is.

column1: Wages and profits and family income are also at their highest levels in history--but I would remind you that 4 million workers and 13 percent of our industrial capacity are still idle today.
We need a tax cut now to keep this country moving.
V.
For our goal is not merely to spread the work. Our goal is to create more jobs. I believe the enactment of a 35-hour week would sharply increase costs
column2: would invite inflation
column3: would impair our ability to compete
column4: and merely share instead of creating employment. But I am equally opposed to the 45- or 50-hour week in those industries where consistently excessive use of overtime causes increased unemployment.

column1: So
column2: therefore
column3: I recommend legislation authorizing the creation of a tripartite industry committee to determine on an industry-by-industry basis as to where a higher penalty rate for overtime would increase job openings without unduly increasing costs
column4: and authorizing the establishment of such higher rates.

column1: VI.
Let me make one principle of this administration abundantly clear: All of these increased opportunities--in employment
column2: in education
column3: in housing
column4: and in every field--must be open to Americans of every color. As far as the writ of Federal law will run
column5: we must abolish not some
column6: but all racial discrimination. For this is not merely an economic issue
column7: or a social
column8: political
column9: or international issue. It is a moral issue
column10: and it must be met by the passage this session of the bill now pending in the House.

column1: All members of the public should have equal access to facilities open to the public. All members of the public should be equally eligible for Federal benefits that are financed by the public. All members of the public should have an equal chance to vote for public officials and to send their children to good public schools and to contribute their talents to the public good.
Today
column2: Americans of all races stand side by side in Berlin and in Viet Nam. They died side by side in Korea. Surely they can work and eat and travel side by side in their own country.

column1: VII.
We must also lift by legislation the bars of discrimination against those who seek entry into our country
column2: particularly those who have much needed skills and those joining their families.

column1: In establishing preferences
column2: a nation that was built by the immigrants of all lands can ask those who now seek admission: "What can you do for our country?" But we should not be asking: "In what country were you born?"

column1: VIII.
For our ultimate goal is a world without war
column2: a world made safe for diversity
column3: in which all men
column4: goods
column5: and ideas can freely move across every border and every boundary.

column1: We must advance toward this goal in 1964 in at least 10 different ways
column2: not as partisans
column3: but as patriots.

column1: First
column2: wc must maintain--and our reduced defense budget will maintain--that margin of military safety and superiority obtained through 3 years of steadily increasing both the quality and the quantity of our strategic
column3: our conventional
column4: and our antiguerilla forces. In 1964 we will be better prepared than ever before to defend the cause of freedom
column5: whether it is threatened by outright aggression or by the infiltration practiced by those in Hanoi and Havana
column6: who ship arms and men across international borders to foment insurrection. And we must continue to use that strength as John Kennedy used it in the Cuban crisis and for the test ban treaty--to demonstrate both the futility of nuclear war and the possibilities of lasting peace.

column1: Second
column2: we must take new steps--and we shall make new proposals at Geneva--toward the control and the eventual abolition of arms. Even in the absence of agreement
column3: we must not stockpile arms beyond our needs or seek an excess of military power that could be provocative as well as wasteful.

column1: It is in this spirit that in this fiscal year we are cutting back our production of enriched uranium by 25 percent. We are shutting down four plutonium piles. We are closing many nonessential military installations. And it is in this spirit that we today call on our adversaries to do the same.
Third
column2: we must make increased use of our food as an instrument of peace--making it available by sale or trade or loan or donation-to hungry people in all nations which tell us of their needs and accept proper conditions of distribution.

column1: Fourth
column2: we must assure our pre-eminence in the peaceful exploration of outer space
column3: focusing on an expedition to the moon in this decade--in cooperation with other powers if possible
column4: alone if necessary.

column1: Fifth
column2: we must expand world trade. Having recognized in the Act of 1962 that we must buy as well as sell
column3: we now expect our trading partners to recognize that we must sell as well as buy. We are willing to give them competitive access to our market
column4: asking only that they do the same for us.

column1: Sixth
column2: we must continue
column3: through such measures as the interest equalization tax
column4: as well as the cooperation of other nations
column5: our recent progress toward balancing our international accounts.

column1: This administration must and will preserve the present gold value of the dollar.
Seventh
column2: we must become better neighbors with the free states of the Americas
column3: working with the councils of the OAS
column4: with a stronger Alliance for Progress
column5: and with all the men and women of this hemisphere who really believe in liberty and justice for all.

column1: Eighth
column2: we must strengthen the ability of free nations everywhere to develop their independence and raise their standard of living
column3: and thereby frustrate those who prey on poverty and chaos. To do this
column4: the rich must help the poor--and we must do our part. We must achieve a more rigorous administration of our development assistance
column5: with larger roles for private investors
column6: for other industrialized nations
column7: and for international agencies and for the recipient nations themselves.

column1: Ninth
column2: we must strengthen our Atlantic and Pacific partnerships
column3: maintain our alliances and make the United Nations a more effective instrument for national independence and international order.

column1: Tenth
column2: and finally
column3: we must develop with our allies new means of bridging the gap between the East and the West
column4: facing danger boldly wherever danger exists
column5: but being equally bold in our search for new agreements which can enlarge the hopes of all
column6: while violating the interests of none.

column1: In short
column2: I would say to the Congress that we must be constantly prepared for the worst
column3: and constantly acting for the best. We must be strong enough to win any war
column4: and we must be wise enough to prevent one.

column1: We shall neither act as aggressors nor tolerate acts of aggression. We intend to bury no one
column2: and we do not intend to be buried.

column1: We can fight
column2: if we must
column3: as we have fought before
column4: but we pray that we will never have to fight again.

column1: IX.
My good friends and my fellow Americans: In these last 7 sorrowful weeks
column2: we have learned anew that nothing is so enduring as faith
column3: and nothing is so degrading as hate.

column1: John Kennedy was a victim of hate
column2: but he was also a great builder of faith--faith in our fellow Americans
column3: whatever their creed or their color or their station in life; faith in the future of man
column4: whatever his divisions and differences.

column1: This faith was echoed in all parts of the world. On every continent and in every land to which Mrs. Johnson and I traveled
column2: we found faith and hope and love toward this land of America and toward our people.

column1: So I ask you now in the Congress and in the country to join with me in expressing and fulfilling that faith in working for a nation
column2: a nation that is free from want and a world that is free from hate--a world of peace and justice
column3: and freedom and abundance
column4: for our time and for all time to come.@

column1: Lyndon B. Johnson|Annual Message to the Congress on the State of the Union|1965-01-04|@Mr. Speaker
column2: Mr. President
column3: Members of the Congress
column4: my fellow Americans:

column1: On this Hill which was my home
column2: I am stirred by old friendships.

column1: Though total agreement between the Executive and the Congress is impossible
column2: total respect is important.

column1: I am proud to be among my colleagues of the Congress whose legacy to their trust is their loyalty to their Nation.
I am not unaware of the inner emotions of the new Members of this body tonight.
Twenty-eight years ago
column2: I felt as you do now. You will soon learn that you are among men whose first love is their country
column3: men who try each day to do as best they can what they believe is right.

column1: We are entering the third century of the pursuit of American union.
Two hundred years ago
column3: nine assembled colonies first joined together to demand freedom from arbitrary power.

column1: For the first century we struggled to hold together the first continental union of democracy in the history of man. One hundred years ago
column3: following a terrible test of blood and fire
column4: the compact of union was finally sealed.

column1: For a second century we labored to establish a unity of purpose and interest among the many groups which make up the American community.
That struggle has often brought pain and violence. It is not yet over. But we have achieved a unity of interest among our people that is unmatched in the history of freedom.
And so tonight
column2: now
column4: we begin a new quest for union. We seek the unity of man with the world that he has built--with the knowledge that can save or destroy him--with the cities which can stimulate or stifle him--with the wealth and the machines which can enrich or menace his spirit.

column1: We seek to establish a harmony between man and society which will allow each of us to enlarge the meaning of his life and all of us to elevate the quality of our civilization.
This is the search that we begin tonight.
STATE OF THE WORLD
But the unity we seek cannot realize its full promise in isolation. For today the state of the Union depends
column2: in large measure
column3: upon the state of the world.

column1: Our concern and interest
column2: compassion and vigilance
column3: extend to every corner of a dwindling planet.

column1: Yet
column2: it is not merely our concern but the concern of all free men. We will not
column3: and we should not
column4: assume that it is the task of Americans alone to settle all the conflicts of a torn and troubled world.

column1: Let the foes of freedom take no comfort from this. For in concert with other nations
column2: we shall help men defend their freedom.

column1: Our first aim remains the safety and the well-being of our own country.
We are prepared to live as good neighbors with all
column2: but we cannot be indifferent to acts designed to injure our interests
column3: or our citizens
column4: or our establishments abroad. The community of nations requires mutual respect. We shall extend it--and we shall expect it.

column1: In our relations with the world we shall follow the example of Andrew Jackson who said: "I intend to ask for nothing that is not clearly right and to submit to nothing that is wrong." And he promised
column2: that "the honor of my country shall never be stained by an apology from me for the statement of truth or for the performance of duty." That was this Nation's policy in the 1830's and that is this Nation's policy in the 1960's.

column1: Our own freedom and growth have never been the final goal of the American dream.

We were never meant to be an oasis of liberty and abundance in a worldwide desert of disappointed dreams. Our Nation was created to help strike away the chains of ignorance and misery and tyranny wherever they keep man less than God means him to be.
We are moving toward that destiny
column2: never more rapidly than we have moved in the last 4 years.

column1: In this period we have built a military power strong enough to meet any threat and destroy any adversary. And that superiority will continue to grow so long as this office is mine--and you sit on Capitol Hill.
In this period no new nation has become Communist
column2: and the unity of the Communist empire has begun to crumble.

column1: In this period we have resolved in friendship our disputes with our neighbors of the hemisphere
column2: and joined in an Alliance for Progress toward economic growth and political democracy.

column1: In this period we have taken more steps toward peace--including the test ban treaty--than at any time since the cold war began.
In this period we have relentlessly pursued our advances toward the conquest of space.
Most important of all
column2: in this period
column3: the United States has reemerged into the fullness of its self-confidence and purpose. No longer are we called upon to get America moving. We are moving. No longer do we doubt our strength or resolution. We are strong and we have proven our resolve.

column1: No longer can anyone wonder whether we are in the grip of historical decay. We know that history is ours to make. And if there is great danger
column2: there is now also the excitement of great expectations.

column1: AMERICA AND THE COMMUNIST NATIONS
Yet we still live in a troubled and perilous world. There is no longer a single threat. There are many. They differ in intensity and in danger. They require different attitudes and different answers.
With the Soviet Union we seek peaceful understandings that can lessen the danger to freedom.
Last fall I asked the American people to choose that course.
I will carry forward their command.
If we are to live together in peace
column2: we must come to know each other better.

column1: I am sure that the American people would welcome a chance to listen to the Soviet leaders on our television--as I would like the Soviet people to hear our leaders on theirs.
I hope the new Soviet leaders can visit America so they can learn about our country at firsthand.
