In Eastern Europe restless nations are slowly beginning to assert their identity. Your Government
column2: assisted by the leaders in American labor and business
column3: is now exploring ways to increase peaceful trade with these countries and with the Soviet Union. I will report our conclusions to the Congress.

column1: In Asia
column2: communism wears a more aggressive face.

column1: We see that in Viet-Nam.
Why are we there?
We are there
column2: first
column3: because a friendly nation has asked us for help against the Communist aggression. Ten years ago our President pledged our help. Three Presidents have supported that pledge. We will not break it now.

column1: Second
column2: our own security is tied to the peace of Asia. Twice in one generation we have had to fight against aggression in the Far East. To ignore aggression now would only increase the danger of a much larger war.

column1: Our goal is peace in southeast Asia. That will come only when aggressors leave their neighbors in peace.
What is at stake is the cause of freedom and in that cause America will never be found wanting.
THE NON-COMMUNIST WORLD
But communism is not the only source of trouble and unrest. There are older and deeper sources--in the misery of nations and in man's irrepressible ambition for liberty and a better life.

With the free Republics of Latin America I have always felt--and my country has always felt--very special ties of interest and affection. It will be the purpose of my administration to strengthen these ties. Together we share and shape the destiny of the new world. In the coming year I hope to pay a visit to Latin America. And I will steadily enlarge our commitment to the Alliance for Progress as the instrument of our war against poverty and injustice in this hemisphere.
In the Atlantic community we continue to pursue our goal of 20 years--a Europe that is growing in strength
column2: unity
column3: and cooperation with America. A great unfinished task is the reunification of Germany through self-determination.

column1: This European policy is not based on any abstract design. It is based on the realities of common interests and common values
column2: common dangers and common expectations. These realities will continue to have their way--especially
column3: I think
column4: in our expanding trade and especially in our common defense.

column1: Free Americans have shaped the policies of the United States. And because we know these realities
column2: those policies have been
column3: and will be
column4: in the interest of Europe.

column1: Free Europeans must shape the course of Europe. And
column2: for the same reasons
column3: that course has been
column4: and will be
column5: in our interest and in the interest of freedom.

column1: I found this truth confirmed in my talks with European leaders in the last year. I hope to repay these visits to some of our friends in Europe this year.
In Africa and Asia we are witnessing the turbulent unfolding of new nations and continents.
We welcome them to the society of nations.
We are committed to help those seeking to strengthen their own independence
column2: and to work most closely with those governments dedicated to the welfare of all of their people.

column1: We seek not fidelity to an iron faith
column2: but a diversity of belief as varied as man himself. We seek not to extend the power of America but the progress of humanity. We seek not to dominate others but to strengthen the freedom of all people.

column1: I will seek new ways to use our knowledge to help deal with the explosion in world population and the growing scarcity in world resources.
Finally
column2: we renew our commitment to the continued growth and the effectiveness of the United Nations. The frustrations of the United Nations are a product of the world that we live in
column3: and not of the institution which gives them voice. It is far better to throw these differences open to the assembly of nations than to permit them to fester in silent danger.

column1: These are some of the goals of the American Nation in the world in which we live.
For ourselves we seek neither praise nor blame
column2: neither gratitude nor obedience.

column1: We seek peace.
We seek freedom.
We seek to enrich the life of man.
For that is the world in which we will flourish and that is the world that we mean for all men to ultimately have.
TOWARD THE GREAT SOCIETY
World affairs will continue to call upon our energy and our courage.
But today we can turn increased attention to the character of American life.
We are in the midst of the greatest upward surge of economic well-being in the history of any nation.

Our flourishing progress has been marked by price stability that is unequalled in the world. Our balance of payments deficit has declined and the soundness of our dollar is unquestioned. I pledge to keep it that way and I urge business and labor to cooperate to that end.

We worked for two centuries to climb this peak of prosperity. But we are only at the beginning of the road to the Great Society. Ahead now is a summit where freedom from the wants of the body can help fulfill the needs of the spirit.
We built this Nation to serve its people.
We want to grow and build and create
column2: but we want progress to be the servant and not the master of man.

column1: We do not intend to live in the midst of abundance
column2: isolated from neighbors and nature
column3: confined by blighted cities and bleak suburbs
column4: stunted by a poverty of learning and an emptiness of leisure.

column1: The Great Society asks not how much
column2: but how good; not only how to create wealth but how to use it; not only how fast we are going
column3: but where we are headed.

column1: It proposes as the first test for a nation: the quality of its people.
This kind of society will not flower spontaneously from swelling riches and surging power.
It will not be the gift of government or the creation of presidents. It will require of every American
column2: for many generations
column3: both faith in the destination and the fortitude to make the journey.

column1: And like freedom itself
column2: it will always be challenge and not fulfillment.

column1: And tonight we accept that challenge.
A NATIONAL AGENDA
I propose that we begin a program in education to ensure every American child the fullest development of his mind and skills.
I propose that we begin a massive attack on crippling and killing diseases.
I propose that we launch a national effort to make the American city a better and a more stimulating place to live.
I propose that we increase the beauty of America and end the poisoning of our rivers and the air that we breathe.
I propose that we carry out a new program to develop regions of our country that are now suffering from distress and depression.
I propose that we make new efforts to control and prevent crime and delinquency.
I propose that we eliminate every remaining obstacle to the right and the opportunity to vote.
I propose that we honor and support the achievements of thought and the creations of art.
I propose that we make an all-out campaign against waste and inefficiency.
THE TASK
Our basic task is threefold:
First
column2: to keep our economy growing;

column1: --to open for all Americans the opportunity that is now enjoyed by most Americans;
--and to improve the quality of life for all.
In the next 6 weeks I will submit special messages with detailed proposals for national action in each of these areas.
Tonight I would like just briefly to explain some of my major recommendations in the three main areas of national need.
IV. A GROWING ECONOMY
BASIC POLICIES
First
column2: we must keep our Nation prosperous. We seek full employment opportunity for every American citizen. I will present a budget designed to move the economy forward. More money will be left in the hands of the consumer by a substantial cut in excise taxes. We will continue along the path toward a balanced budget in a balanced economy.

column1: I confidently predict--what every economic sign tells us tonight--the continued flourishing of the American economy.
But we must remember that fear of a recession can contribute to the fact of a recession. The knowledge that our Government will
column2: and can
column3: move swiftly will strengthen the confidence of investors and business.

column1: Congress can reinforce this confidence by insuring that its procedures permit rapid action on temporary income tax cuts. And special funds for job-creating public programs should be made available for immediate use if recession threatens.
Our continued prosperity demands continued price stability. Business
column2: labor
column3: and the consumer all have a high stake in keeping wages and prices within the framework of the guideposts that have already served the Nation so well.

column1: Finding new markets abroad for our goods depends on the initiative of American business. But we stand ready--with credit and other help--to assist the flow of trade which will benefit the entire Nation.
ON THE FARMS

Our economy owes much to the efficiency of our farmers. We must continue to assure them the opportunity to earn a fair reward. I have instructed the Secretary of Agriculture to lead a major effort to find new approaches to reduce the heavy cost of our farm programs and to direct more of our effort to the small farmer who needs the help the most.
INCREASED PROSPERITY
We can help insure continued prosperity through:
--a regional recovery program to assist the development of stricken areas left behind by our national progress;
--further efforts to provide our workers with the skills demanded by modern technology
column2: for the laboring-man is an indispensable force in the American system;

column1: --the extension of the minimum wage to more than 2 million unprotected workers;
--the improvement and the modernization of the unemployment compensation system.
And as pledged in our 1960 and 1964 Democratic platforms
column2: I will propose to Congress changes in the Taft-Hartley Act including section 14(b). I will do so hoping to reduce the conflicts that for several years have divided Americans in various States of our Union.

column1: In a country that spans a continent modern transportation is vital to continued growth.
TRANSPORTATION FOR GROWTH
I will recommend heavier reliance on competition in transportation and a new policy for our merchant marine.
I will ask for funds to study high-speed rail transportation between urban centers. We will begin with test projects between Washington and Boston. On high-speed trains
column2: passengers could travel this distance in less than 4 hours.

column1: II. OPPORTUNITY FOR ALL
Second
column2: we must open opportunity to all our people.

column1: Most Americans enjoy a good life. But far too many are still trapped in poverty and idleness and fear.
Let a just nation throw open to them the city of promise:
--to the elderly
column2: by providing hospital care under social security and by raising benefit payments to those struggling to maintain the dignity of their later years;

column1: --to the poor and the unfortunate
column2: through doubling the war against poverty this year;

column1: --to Negro Americans
column2: through enforcement of the civil rights law and elimination of barriers to the right to vote;

column1: --to those in other lands that are seeking the promise of America
column2: through an immigration law based on the work a man can do and not where he was born or how he spells his name.

column1: III. TO ENRICH THE LIFE OF ALL
Our third goal is to improve the quality of American life.
THROUGH EDUCATION
We begin with learning.
Every child must have the best education that this Nation can provide.
Thomas Jefferson said that no nation can be both ignorant and free. Today no nation can be both ignorant and great.
In addition to our existing programs
column2: I will recommend a new program for schools and students with a first year authorization of $1
column3: 500 million.

column1: It will help at every stage along the road to learning.
For the preschool years we will help needy children become aware of the excitement of learning.
For the primary and secondary school years we will aid public schools serving low-income families and assist students in both public and private schools.

For the college years we will provide scholarships to high school students of the greatest promise and the greatest need and we will guarantee low-interest loans to students continuing their college studies.

New laboratories and centers will help our schools--help them lift their standards of excellence and explore new methods of teaching. These centers will provide special training for those who need and those who deserve special treatment.
THROUGH BETTER HEALTH
Greatness requires not only an educated people but a healthy people.
Our goal is to match the achievements of our medicine to the afflictions of our people.
We already carry on a large program in this country. for research and health.
In addition
column2: regional medical centers can provide the most advanced diagnosis and treatment for heart disease and cancer and stroke and other major diseases.

column1: New support for medical and dental education will provide the trained people to apply our knowledge.
Community centers can help the mentally ill and improve health care for school-age children from poor families
column2: including services for the mentally retarded.

column1: THROUGH IMPROVING THE WORLD WE LIVE IN
The City
An educated and healthy people require surroundings in harmony with their hopes.
In our urban areas the central problem today is to protect and restore man's satisfaction in belonging to a community where he can find security and significance.

The first step is to break old patterns--to begin to think and work and plan for the development of the entire metropolitan areas. We will take this step with new programs of help for the basic community facilities and for neighborhood centers of health and recreation.
New and existing programs will be open to those cities which work together to develop unified long-range policies for metropolitan areas.
We must also make some very important changes in our housing programs if we are to pursue these same basic goals.
So a Department of Housing and Urban Development will be needed to spearhead this effort in our cities.
Every citizen has the right to feel secure in his home and on the streets of his community.
To help control crime
column2: we will recommend programs:

column1: --to train local law enforcement officers;
--to put the best techniques of modern science at their disposal;
--to discover the causes of crime and better ways to prevent it.
I will soon assemble a panel of outstanding experts of this Nation to search out answers to the national problem of crime and delinquency
column2: and I welcome the recommendations and the constructive efforts of the Congress.

column1: The Beauty of America

For over three centuries the beauty of America has sustained our spirit and has enlarged our vision. We must act now to protect this heritage. In a fruitful new partnership with the States and the cities the next decade should be a conservation milestone. We must make a massive effort to save the countryside and to establish--as a green legacy for tomorrow--more large and small parks
column2: more seashores and open spaces than have been created during any other period in our national history.

column1: A new and substantial effort must be made to landscape highways to provide places of relaxation and recreation wherever our roads run
Within our cities imaginative programs are needed to landscape streets and to transform open areas into places of beauty and recreation.
We will seek legal power to prevent pollution of our air and water before it happens. We will step up our effort to control harmful wastes
column2: giving first priority to the cleanup of our most contaminated rivers. We will increase research to learn much more about the control of pollution.

column1: We hope to make the Potomac a model of beauty here in the Capital
column2: and preserve unspoiled stretches of some of our waterways with a Wild Rivers bill.

column1: More ideas for a beautiful America will emerge from a White House Conference on Natural Beauty which I will soon call.
Art and Science
We must also recognize and encourage those who can be pathfinders for the Nation's imagination and understanding.
To help promote and honor creative achievements
column2: I will propose a National Foundation on the Arts.

column1: To develop knowledge which will enrich our lives and ensure our progress
column2: I will recommend programs to encourage basic science
column3: particularly in the universities--and to bring closer the day when the oceans will supply our growing need for fresh water.

column1: IV. THE GOVERNMENT
For government to serve these goals it must be modern in structure
column2: efficient in action
column3: and ready for any emergency.

column1: I am busy
column2: currently
column3: reviewing the structure of the entire executive branch of this Government. I hope to reshape it and to reorganize it to meet more effectively the tasks of the 20th century.

column1: Wherever waste is found
column2: I will eliminate it.

column1: Last year we saved almost $3
column2: 500 million by eliminating waste in the National Government.

column1: And I intend to do better this year.
And very soon I will report to you on our progress and on new economies that your Government plans to make.
Even the best of government is subject to the worst of hazards.
I will propose laws to insure the necessary continuity of leadership should the President become disabled or die.
In addition
column2: I will propose reforms in the electoral college--leaving undisturbed the vote by States--but making sure that no elector can substitute his will for that of the people.

column1: Last year
column2: in a sad moment
column3: I came here and I spoke to you after 33 years of public service
column4: practically all of them here on this Hill.

column1: This year I speak after 1 year as President of the United States.
Many of you in this Chamber are among my oldest friends. We have shared many happy moments and many hours of work
column2: and we have watched many Presidents together. Yet
column3: only in the White House can you finally know the full weight of this Office.

column1: The greatest burden is not running the huge operations of government--or meeting daily troubles
column2: large and small--or even working with the Congress.

column1: A President's hardest task is not to do what is right
column2: but to know what is right.

column1: Yet the Presidency brings no special gift of prophecy or foresight. You take an oath
column2: you step into an office
column3: and you must then help guide a great democracy.

column1: The answer was waiting for me in the land where I was born.

It was once barren land. The angular hills were covered with scrub cedar and a few large live oaks. Little would grow in that harsh caliche soil of my country. And each spring the Pedernales River would flood our valley.
But men came and they worked and they endured and they built.
And tonight that country is abundant; abundant with fruit and cattle and goats and sheep
column2: and there are pleasant homes and lakes and the floods are gone.

column1: Why did men come to that once forbidding land?
Well
column2: they were restless
column3: of course
column4: and they had to be moving on. But there was more than that. There was a dream--a dream of a place where a free man could build for himself
column5: and raise his children to a better life--a dream of a continent to be conquered
column6: a world to be won
column7: a nation to be made.

column1: Remembering this
column2: I knew the answer.

column1: A President does not shape a new and personal vision of America.
He collects it from the scattered hopes of the American past.
It existed when the first settlers saw the coast of a new world
column2: and when the first pioneers moved westward.

column1: It has guided us every step of the way.
It sustains every President. But it is also your inheritance and it belongs equally to all the people that we all serve.
It must be interpreted anew by each generation for its own needs; as I have tried
column2: in part
column3: to do tonight.

column1: It shall lead us as we enter the third century of the search for "a more perfect union."
This
column2: then
column3: is the state of the Union: Free and restless
column4: growing and full of hope.

column1: So it was in the beginning.
So it shall always be
column2: while God is willing
column3: and we are strong enough to keep the faith.@

column1: Lyndon B. Johnson|Special Message to the Congress: The American Promise|1965-03-15|@Mr. Speaker
column2: Mr. President
column3: Members of the Congress:

column1: I speak tonight for the dignity of man and the destiny of democracy.
I urge every member of both parties
column2: Americans of all religions and of all colors
column3: from every section of this country
column4: to join me in that cause.

column1: At times history and fate meet at a single time in a single place to shape a turning point in man's unending search for freedom. So it was at Lexington and Concord. So it was a century ago at Appomattox. So it was last week in Selma
column2: Alabama.

column1: There
column2: long-suffering men and women peacefully protested the denial of their rights as Americans. Many were brutally assaulted. One good man
column3: a man of God
column4: was killed.

column1: There is no cause for pride in what has happened in Selma. There is no cause for self-satisfaction in the long denial of equal rights of millions of Americans. But there is cause for hope and for faith in our democracy in what is happening here tonight.
For the cries of pain and the hymns and protests of oppressed people have summoned into convocation all the majesty of this great Government--the Government of the greatest Nation on earth.
Our mission is at once the oldest and the most basic of this country: to right wrong
column2: to do justice
column3: to serve man.

column1: In our time we have come to live with moments of great crisis. Our lives have been marked with debate about great issues; issues of war and peace
column2: issues of prosperity and depression. But rarely in any time does an issue lay bare the secret heart of America itself. Rarely are we met with a challenge
column3: not to our growth or abundance
column4: our welfare or our security
column5: but rather to the values and the purposes and the meaning of our beloved Nation.

column1: The issue of equal rights for American Negroes is such an issue. And should we defeat every enemy
column2: should we double our wealth and conquer the stars
column3: and still be unequal to this issue
column4: then we will have failed as a people and as a nation.

column1: For with a country as with a person
column2: "What is a man profited
column3: if he shall gain the whole world
column4: and lose his own soul ?"

column1: There is no Negro problem. There is no Southern problem. There is no Northern problem. There is only an American problem. And we are met here tonight as Americans--not as Democrats or Republicans-we are met here as Americans to solve that problem.
This was the first nation in the history of the world to be founded with a purpose. The great phrases of that purpose still sound in every American heart
column2: North and South: "All men are created equal"--"government by consent of the governed"--"give me liberty or give me death." Well
column3: those are not just clever words
column4: or those are not just empty theories. In their name Americans have fought and died for two centuries
column5: and tonight around the world they stand there as guardians of our liberty
column6: risking their lives.

column1: Those words are a promise to every citizen that he shall share in the dignity of man. This dignity cannot be found in a man's possessions; it cannot be found in his power
column2: or in his position. It really rests on his right to be treated as a man equal in opportunity to all others. It says that he shall share in freedom
column3: he shall choose his leaders
column4: educate his children
column5: and provide for his family according to his ability and his merits as a human being.

column1: To apply any other test--to deny a man his hopes because of his color or race
column2: his religion or the place of his birth--is not only to do injustice
column3: it is to deny America and to dishonor the dead who gave their lives for American freedom.

column1: THE RIGHT TO VOTE
Our fathers believed that if this noble view of the rights of man was to flourish
column2: it must be rooted in democracy. The most basic right of all was the right to choose your own leaders. The history of this country
column3: in large measure
column4: is the history of the expansion of that right to all of our people.

column1: Many of the issues of civil rights are very complex and most difficult. But about this there can and should be no argument. Every American citizen must have an equal right to vote. There is no reason which can excuse the denial of that right. There is no duty which weighs more heavily on us than the duty we have to ensure that right.
Yet the harsh fact is that in many places in this country men and women are kept from voting simply because they are Negroes.
Every device of which human ingenuity is capable has been used to deny this right. The Negro citizen may go to register only to be told that the day is wrong
column2: or the hour is late
column3: or the official in charge is absent. And if he persists
column4: and if he manages to present himself to the registrar
column5: he may be disqualified because he did not spell out his middle name or because he abbreviated a word on the application.

column1: And if he manages to fill out an application he is given a test. The registrar is the sole judge of whether he passes this test. He may be asked to recite the entire Constitution
column2: or explain the most complex provisions of State law. And even a college degree cannot be used to prove that he can read and write.

column1: For the fact is that the only way to pass these barriers is to show a white skin.

Experience has clearly shown that the existing process of law cannot overcome systematic and ingenious discrimination. No law that we now have on the books-and I have helped to put three of them there--can ensure the right to vote when local officials are determined to deny it.

In such a case our duty must be clear to all of us. The Constitution says that no person shall be kept from voting because of his race or his color. We have all sworn an oath before God to support and to defend that Constitution. We must now act in obedience to that oath.
GUARANTEEING THE RIGHT TO VOTE
Wednesday I will send to Congress a law designed to eliminate illegal barriers to the right to vote.
The broad principles of that bill will be in the hands of the Democratic and Republican leaders tomorrow. After they have reviewed it
column2: it will come here formally as a bill. I am grateful for this opportunity to come here tonight at the invitation of the leadership to reason with my friends
column3: to give them my views
column4: and to visit with my former colleagues.

column1: I have had prepared a more comprehensive analysis of the legislation which I had intended to transmit to the clerk tomorrow but which I will submit to the clerks tonight. But I want to really discuss with you now briefly the main proposals of this legislation
This bill will strike down restrictions to voting in all elections--Federal
column2: State
column3: and local--which have been used to deny Negroes the right to vote.

column1: This bill will establish a simple
column2: uniform standard which cannot be used
column3: however ingenious the effort
column4: to flout our Constitution.

column1: It will provide for citizens to be registered by officials of the United States Government if the State officials refuse to register them.
It will eliminate tedious
column2: unnecessary lawsuits which delay the right to vote.

column1: Finally
column2: this legislation will ensure that properly registered individuals are not prohibited from voting.

column1: I will welcome the suggestions from all of the Members of Congress--I have no doubt that I will get some--on ways and means to strengthen this law and to make it effective. But experience has plainly shown that this is the only path to carry out the command of the Constitution.
To those who seek to avoid action by their National Government in their own communities; who want to and who seek to maintain purely local control over elections
column2: the answer is simple:

column1: Open your polling places to all your people.
Allow men and women to register and vote whatever the color of their skin.
Extend the rights of citizenship to every citizen of this land.
THE NEED FOR ACTION
There is no constitutional issue here. The command of the Constitution is plain.
There is no moral issue. It is wrong--deadly wrong--to deny any of your fellow Americans the right to vote in this country.
There is no issue of States rights or national rights. There is only the struggle for human rights.
I have not the slightest doubt what will be your answer.

The last time a President sent a civil rights bill to the Congress it contained a provision to protect voting rights in Federal elections. That civil rights bill was passed after 8 long months of debate. And when that bill came to my desk from the Congress for my signature
column2: the heart of the voting provision had been eliminated.

column1: This time
column2: on this issue
column3: there must be no delay
column4: no hesitation and no compromise with our purpose.

column1: We cannot
column2: we must not
column3: refuse to protect the right of every American to vote in every election that he may desire to participate in. And we ought not and we cannot and we must not wait another 8 months before we get a bill. We have already waited a hundred years and more
column4: and the time for waiting is gone.

column1: So I ask you to join me in working long hours--nights and weekends
column2: if necessary--to pass this bill. And I don't make that request lightly. For from the window where I sit with the problems of our country I recognize that outside this chamber is the outraged conscience of a nation
column3: the grave concern of many nations
column4: and the harsh judgment of history on our acts.

column1: WE SHALL OVERCOME
But even if we pass this bill
column2: the battle will not be over. What happened in Selma is part of a far larger movement which reaches into every section and State of America. It is the effort of American Negroes to secure for themselves the full blessings of American life.

column1: Their cause must be our cause too. Because it is not just Negroes
column2: but really it is all of us
column3: who must overcome the crippling legacy of bigotry and injustice.

column1: And we shall overcome.
As a man whose roots go deeply into Southern soil I know how agonizing racial feelings are. I know how difficult it is to reshape the attitudes and the structure of our society.
But a century has passed
column2: more than a hundred years
column3: since the Negro was freed. And he is not fully free tonight.

column1: It was more than a hundred years ago that Abraham Lincoln
column2: a great President of another party
column3: signed the Emancipation Proclamation
column4: but emancipation is a proclamation and not a fact.

column1: A century has passed
column2: more than a hundred years
column3: since equality was promised. And yet the Negro is not equal.

column1: A century has passed since the day of promise. And the promise is unkept.
The time of justice has now come. I tell you that I believe sincerely that no force can hold it back. It is right in the eyes of man and God that it should come. And when it does
column2: I think that day will brighten the lives of every American.

column1: For Negroes are not the only victims. How many white children have gone uneducated
column2: how many white families have lived in stark poverty
column3: how many white lives have been scarred by fear
column4: because we have wasted our energy and our substance to maintain the barriers of hatred and terror?

column1: So I say to all of you here
column2: and to all in the Nation tonight
column3: that those who appeal to you to hold on to the past do so at the cost of denying you your future.

column1: This great
column2: rich
column3: restless country can offer opportunity and education and hope to all: black and white
column4: North and South
column5: sharecropper and city dweller. These are the enemies: poverty
column6: ignorance
column7: disease. They are the enemies and not our fellow man
column8: not our neighbor. And these enemies too
column9: poverty
column10: disease and ignorance
column11: we shall overcome.

column1: AN AMERICAN PROBLEM
Now let none of us in any sections look with prideful righteousness on the troubles in another section
column2: or on the problems of our neighbors. There is really no part of America where the promise of equality has been fully kept. In Buffalo as well as in Birmingham
column3: in Philadelphia as well as in Selma
column4: Americans are struggling for the fruits of freedom.

column1: This is one Nation. What happens in Selma or in Cincinnati is a matter of legitimate concern to every American. But let each of us look within our own hearts and our own communities
column2: and let each of us put our shoulder to the wheel to root out injustice wherever it exists.

column1: As we meet here in this peaceful
column2: historic chamber tonight
column3: men from the South
column4: some of whom were at Iwo Jima
column5: men from the North who have carried Old Glory to far corners of the world and brought it back without a stain on it
column6: men from the East and from the West
column7: are all fighting together without regard to religion
column8: or color
column9: or region
column10: in Viet-Nam. Men from every region fought for us across the world 20 years ago.

column1: And in these common dangers and these common sacrifices the South made its contribution of honor and gallantry no less than any other region of the great Republic--and in some instances
column2: a great many of them
column3: more.

column1: And I have not the slightest doubt that good men from everywhere in this country
column2: from the Great Lakes to the Gulf of Mexico
column3: from the Golden Gate to the harbors along the Atlantic
column4: will rally together now in this cause to vindicate the freedom of all Americans. For all of us owe this duty; and I believe that all of us will respond to it.

column1: Your President makes that request of every American.
PROGRESS THROUGH THE DEMOCRATIC PROCESS
The real hero of this struggle is the American Negro. His actions and protests
column2: his courage to risk safety and even to risk his life
column3: have awakened the conscience of this Nation. His demonstrations have been designed to call attention to injustice
column4: designed to provoke change
column5: designed to stir reform.

column1: He has called upon us to make good the promise of America. And who among us can say that we would have made the same progress were it not for his persistent bravery
column2: and his faith in American democracy.

column1: For at the real heart of battle for equality is a deep-seated belief in the democratic process. Equality depends not on the force of arms or tear gas but upon the force of moral right; not on recourse to violence but on respect for law and order.

There have been many pressures upon your President and there will be others as the days come and go. But I pledge you tonight that we intend to fight this battle where it should be fought: in the courts
column2: and in the Congress
column3: and in the hearts of men.

column1: We must preserve the right of free speech and the right of free assembly. But the right of free speech does not carry with it
column2: as has been said
column3: the right to holler fire in a crowded theater. We must preserve the right to free assembly
column4: but free assembly does not carry with it the right to block public thoroughfares to traffic.

column1: We do have a right to protest
column2: and a right to march under conditions that do not infringe the constitutional rights of our neighbors. And I intend to protect all those rights as long as I am permitted to serve in this office.

column1: We will guard against violence
column2: knowing it strikes from our hands the very weapons which we seek--progress
column3: obedience to law
column4: and belief in American values.

column1: In Selma as elsewhere we seek and pray for peace. We seek order. We seek unity. But we will not accept the peace of stifled rights
column2: or the order imposed by fear
column3: or the unity that stifles protest. For peace cannot be purchased at the cost of liberty.

column1: In Selma tonight
column2: as in every--and we had a good day there--as in every city
column3: we are working for just and peaceful settlement. We must all remember that after this speech I am making tonight
column4: after the police and the FBI and the Marshals have all gone
column5: and after you have promptly passed this bill
column6: the people of Selma and the other cities of the Nation must still live and work together. And when the attention of the Nation has gone elsewhere they must try to heal the wounds and to build a new community.

column1: This cannot be easily done on a battleground of violence
column2: as the history of the South itself shows. It is in recognition of this that men of both races have shown such an outstandingly impressive responsibility in recent days--last Tuesday
column3: again today

column1: RIGHTS MUST BE OPPORTUNITIES
The bill that I am presenting to you will be known as a civil rights bill. But
column2: in a larger sense
column3: most of the program I am recommending is a civil rights program. Its object is to open the city of hope to all people of all races.

column1: Because all Americans just must have the right to vote. And we are going to give them that right.
All Americans must have the privileges of citizenship regardless of race. And they are going to have those privileges of citizenship regardless of race.
But I would like to caution you and remind you that to exercise these privileges takes much more than just legal right. It requires a trained mind and a healthy body. It requires a decent home
column2: and the chance to find a job
column3: and the opportunity to escape from the clutches of poverty.

column1: Of course
column2: people cannot contribute to the Nation if they are never taught to read or write
column3: if their bodies are stunted from hunger
column4: if their sickness goes untended
column5: if their life is spent in hopeless poverty just drawing a welfare check.

column1: So we want to open the gates to opportunity. But we are also going to give all our people
column2: black and white
column3: the help that they need to walk through those gates.

column1: THE PURPOSE OF THIS GOVERNMENT
My first job after college was as a teacher in Cotulla
column2: Tex.
column3: in a small Mexican-American school. Few of them could speak English
column4: and I couldn't speak much Spanish. My students were poor and they often came to class without breakfast
column5: hungry. They knew even in their youth the pain of prejudice. They never seemed to know why people disliked them. But they knew it was so
column6: because I saw it in their eyes. I often walked home late in the afternoon
column7: after the classes were finished
column8: wishing there was more that I could do. But all I knew was to teach them the little that I knew
column9: hoping that it might help them against the hardships that lay ahead.

column1: Somehow you never forget what poverty and hatred can do when you see its scars on the hopeful face of a young child.
I never thought then
column3: that I would be standing here in 1965. It never even occurred to me in my fondest dreams that I might have the chance to help the sons and daughters of those students and to help people like them all over this country.

column1: But now I do have that chance--and I'll let you in on a secret--I mean to use it. And I hope that you will use it with me.
This is the richest and most powerful country which ever occupied the globe. The might of past empires is little compared to ours. But I do not want to be the President who built empires
column2: or sought grandeur
column3: or extended dominion.

column1: I want to be the President who educated young children to the wonders of their world. I want to be the President who helped to feed the hungry and to prepare them to be taxpayers instead of taxeaters.
I want to be the President who helped the poor to find their own way and who protected the right of every citizen to vote in every election.
I want to be the President who helped to end hatred among his fellow men and who promoted love among the people of all races and all regions and all parties.
I want to be the President who helped to end war among the brothers of this earth.
And so at the request of your beloved Speaker and the Senator from Montana; the majority leader
column2: the Senator from Illinois; the minority leader
column3: Mr. McCulloch
column4: and other Members of both parties
column5: I came here tonight--not as President Roosevelt came down one time in person to veto a bonus bill
column6: not as President Truman came down one time to urge the passage of a railroad bill--but I came down here to ask you to share this task with me and to share it with the people that we both work for. I want this to be the Congress
column7: Republicans and Democrats alike
column8: which did all these things for all these people.

column1: Beyond this great chamber
column2: out yonder in 50 States
column3: are the people that we serve. Who can tell what deep and unspoken hopes are in their hearts tonight as they sit there and listen. We all can guess
column4: from our own lives
column5: how difficult they often find their own pursuit of happiness
column6: how many problems each little family has. They look most of all to themselves for their futures. But I think that they also look to each of us.

column1: Above the pyramid on the great seal of the United States it says--in Latin--"God has favored our undertaking."

God will not favor everything that we do. It is rather our duty to divine His will. But I cannot help believing that He truly understands and that He really favors the undertaking that we begin here tonight.@
Lyndon B. Johnson|Annual Message to the Congress on the State of the Union|1966-01-12|@Mr. Speaker
column2: Mr. President
column3: Members of the House and the Senate
column4: my fellow Americans:

column1: I come before you tonight to report on the State of the Union for the third time.
I come here to thank you and to add my tribute
column2: once more
column3: to the Nation's gratitude for this
column4: the 89th Congress. This Congress has already reserved for itself an honored chapter in the history of America.

column1: Our Nation tonight is engaged in a brutal and bitter conflict in Vietnam. Later on I want to discuss that struggle in some detail with you. It just must be the center of our concerns.
But we will not permit those who fire upon us in Vietnam to win a victory over the desires and the intentions of all the American people. This Nation is mighty enough
column2: its society is healthy enough
column3: its people are strong enough
column4: to pursue our goals in the rest of the world while still building a Great Society here at home.

column1: And that is what I have come here to ask of you tonight.
I recommend that you provide the resources to carry forward
column2: with full vigor
column3: the great health and education programs that you enacted into law last year.

column1: I recommend that we prosecute with vigor and determination our war on poverty.
I recommend that you give a new and daring direction to our foreign aid program
column2: designed to make a maximum attack on hunger and disease and ignorance in those countries that are determined to help themselves
column3: and to help those nations that are trying to control population growth.

column1: I recommend that you make it possible to expand trade between the United States and Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union.
I recommend to you a program to rebuild completely
column2: on a scale never before attempted
column3: entire central and slum areas of several of our cities in America.

column1: I recommend that you attack the wasteful and degrading poisoning of our rivers
column2: and
column3: as the cornerstone of this effort
column4: clean completely entire large river basins.

column1: I recommend that you meet the growing menace of crime in the streets by building up law enforcement and by revitalizing the entire Federal system from prevention to probation.
I recommend that you take additional steps to insure equal justice to all of our people by effectively enforcing nondiscrimination in Federal and State jury selection
column2: by making it a serious Federal crime to obstruct public and private efforts to secure civil rights
column3: and by outlawing discrimination in the sale and rental of housing.

column1: I recommend that you help me modernize and streamline the Federal Government by creating a new Cabinet level Department of Transportation and reorganizing several existing agencies. In turn
column2: I will restructure our civil service in the top grades so that men and women can easily be assigned to jobs where they are most needed
column3: and ability will be both required as well as rewarded.

column1: I will ask you to make it possible for Members of the House of Representatives to work more effectively in the service of the Nation through a constitutional amendment extending the term of a Congressman to 4 years
column2: concurrent with that of the President.

column1: II.
Because of Vietnam we cannot do all that we should
column2: or all that we would like to do. We will ruthlessly attack waste and inefficiency. We will make sure that every dollar is spent with the thrift and with the commonsense which recognizes how hard the taxpayer worked in order to earn it.

column1: We will continue to meet the needs of our people by continuing to develop the Great Society.
Last year alone the wealth that we produced increased $47 billion
column2: and it will soar again this year to a total over $720 billion.

column1: Because our economic policies have produced rising revenues
column2: if you approve every program that I recommend tonight
column3: our total budget deficit will be one of the lowest in many years. It will be only $1.8 billion next year. Total spending in the administrative budget will be $112.8 billion. Revenues next year will be $111 billion.

column1: On a cash basis--which is the way that you and I keep our family budget--the Federal budget next year will actually show a surplus. That is to say
column2: if we include all the money that your Government will take in and all the money that your Government will spend
column3: your Government next year will collect one-half billion dollars more than it will spend in the year 1967.

column1: I have not come here tonight to ask for pleasant luxuries or for idle pleasures. I have come here to recommend that you
column2: the representatives of the richest Nation on earth
column3: you
column4: the elected servants of a people who live in abundance unmatched on this globe
column5: you bring the most urgent decencies of life to all of your fellow Americans.

column1: There are men who cry out: We must sacrifice. Well
column2: let us rather ask them: Who will they sacrifice? Are they going to sacrifice the children who seek the learning
column3: or the sick who need medical care
column4: or the families who dwell in squalor now brightened by the hope of home? Will they sacrifice opportunity for the distressed
column5: the beauty of our land
column6: the hope of our poor?

column1: Time may require further sacrifices. And if it does
column2: then we will make them.

column1: But we will not heed those who wring it from the hopes of the unfortunate here in a land of plenty.
I believe that we can continue the Great Society while we fight in Vietnam. But if there are some who do not believe this
column2: then
column3: in the name of justice
column4: let them call for the contribution of those who live in the fullness of our blessing
column5: rather than try to strip it from the hands of those that are most in need.

column1: And let no one think that the unfortunate and the oppressed of this land sit stifled and alone in their hope tonight. Hundreds of their servants and their protectors sit before me tonight here in this great Chamber.
III.
The Great Society leads us along three roads--growth and justice and liberation.
[1.] First is growth--the national prosperity which supports the well-being of our people and which provides the tools of our progress.
I can report to you tonight what you have seen for yourselves already--in every city and countryside. This Nation is flourishing.
Workers are making more money than ever--with after-tax income in the past 5 years up 33 percent; in the last year alone
column2: up 8 percent.

column1: More people are working than ever before in our history--an increase last year of 2 1/2 million jobs.
Corporations have greater after-tax earnings than ever in history. For the past 5 years those earnings have been up over 65 percent
column2: and last year alone they had a rise of 20 percent.

column1: Average farm income is higher than ever. Over the past 5 years it is up 40 percent
column2: and over the past year it is up 22 percent alone.

column1: I was informed this afternoon by the distinguished Secretary of the Treasury that his preliminary estimates indicate that our balance of payments deficit has been reduced from $2.8 billion in 1964 to $1.3 billion
column2: or less
column3: in 1965. This achievement has been made possible by the patriotic voluntary cooperation of businessmen and bankers working with your Government.

column1: We must now work together with increased urgency to wipe out this balance of payments deficit altogether in the next year.

And as our economy surges toward new heights we must increase our vigilance against the inflation which raises the cost of living and which lowers the savings of every family in this land. It is essential
column2: to prevent inflation
column3: that we ask both labor and business to exercise price and wage restraint
column4: and I do so again tonight.

column1: I believe it desirable
column2: because of increased military expenditures
column3: that you temporarily restore the automobile and certain telephone excise tax reductions made effective only 12 days ago. Without raising taxes--or even increasing the total tax bill paid--we should move to improve our withholding system so that Americans can more realistically pay as they go
column4: speed up the collection of corporate taxes
column5: and make other necessary simplifications of the tax structure at an early date.

column1: I hope these measures will be adequate. But if the necessities of Vietnam require it
column2: I will not hesitate to return to the Congress for additional appropriations
column3: or additional revenues if they are needed.

column1: [2.] The second road is justice. Justice means a man's hope should not be limited by the color of his skin.

I propose legislation to establish unavoidable requirements for nondiscriminatory jury selection in Federal and State courts--and to give the Attorney General the power necessary to enforce those requirements.
I propose legislation to strengthen authority of Federal courts to try those who murder
column2: attack
column3: or intimidate either civil rights workers or others exercising their constitutional rights--and to increase penalties to a level equal to the nature of the crime.

column1: Legislation
column2: resting on the fullest constitutional authority of the Federal Government
column3: to prohibit racial discrimination in the sale or rental of housing.

column1: For that other nation within a Nation--the poor--whose distress has now captured the conscience of America
column2: I will ask the Congress not only to continue
column3: but to speed up the war on poverty. And in so doing
column4: we will provide the added energy of achievement with the increased efficiency of experience.

column1: To improve the life of our rural Americans and our farm population
column2: we will plan for the future through the establishment of several new Community Development Districts
column3: improved education through the use of Teacher Corps teams
column4: better health measures
column5: physical examinations
column6: and adequate and available medical resources.

column1: For those who labor
column2: I propose to improve unemployment insurance
column3: to expand minimum wage benefits
column4: and by the repeal of section 14(b) of the Taft-Hartley Act to make the labor laws in all our States equal to the laws of the 31 States which do not have tonight right-to-work measures.

column1: And I also intend to ask the Congress to consider measures which
column2: without improperly invading State and local authority
column3: will enable us effectively to deal with strikes which threaten irreparable damage to the national interest.

column1: [3.] The third path is the path of liberation. It is to use our success for the fulfillment of our lives. A great nation is one which breeds a great people. A great people flower not from wealth and power
column2: but from a society which spurs them to the fullness of their genius. That alone is a Great Society.

column1: Yet
column2: slowly
column3: painfully
column4: on the edge of victory
column5: has come the knowledge that shared prosperity is not enough. In the midst of abundance modern man walks oppressed by forces which menace and confine the quality of his life
column6: and which individual abundance alone will not overcome.

column1: We can subdue and we can master these forces--bring increased meaning to our lives--if all of us
column2: Government and citizens
column3: are bold enough to change old ways
column4: daring enough to assault new dangers
column5: and if the dream is dear enough to call forth the limitless capacities of this great people.

column1: This year we must continue to improve the quality of American life.
Let us fulfill and improve the great health and education programs of last year
column2: extending special opportunities to those who risk their lives in our Armed Forces.

column1: I urge the House of Representatives to complete action on three programs already passed by the Senate--the Teacher Corps
column2: rent assistance
column3: and home rule for the District of Columbia.

column1: In some of our urban areas we must help rebuild entire sections and neighborhoods containing
column2: in some cases
column3: as many as 100
column4: 000 people. Working together
column5: private enterprise and government must press forward with the task of providing homes and shops
column6: parks and hospitals
column7: and all the other necessary parts of a flourishing community where our people can come to live the good life.

column1: I will offer other proposals to stimulate and to reward planning for the growth of entire metropolitan areas.
Of all the reckless devastations of our national heritage
column2: none is really more shameful than the continued poisoning of our rivers and our air.

column1: We must undertake a cooperative effort to end pollution in several river basins
column2: making additional funds available to help draw the plans and construct the plants that are necessary to make the waters of our entire river systems clean
column3: and make them a source of pleasure and beauty for all of our people.

column1: To attack and to overcome growing crime and lawlessness
column2: I think we must have a stepped-up program to help modernize and strengthen our local police forces.

column1: Our people have a right to feel secure in their homes and on their streets--and that right just must be secured.
Nor can we fail to arrest the destruction of life and property on our highways.
I will propose a Highway Safety Act of 1966 to seek an end to this mounting tragedy.

We must also act to prevent the deception of the American consumer--requiring all packages to state clearly and truthfully their contents--all interest and credit charges to be fully revealed--and keeping harmful drugs and cosmetics away from our stores.
It is the genius of our Constitution that under its shelter of enduring institutions and rooted principles there is ample room for the rich fertility of American political invention.
We must change to master change.
I propose to take steps to modernize and streamline the executive branch
column2: to modernize the relations between city and State and Nation.

column1: A new Department of Transportation is needed to bring together our transportation activities. The present structure--35 Government agencies
column2: spending $5 billion yearly--makes it almost impossible to serve either the growing demands of this great Nation or the needs of the industry
column3: or the right of the taxpayer to full efficiency and real frugality.

column1: I will propose in addition a program to construct and to flight-test a new supersonic transport airplane that will fly three times the speed of sound--in excess of 2
column2: 000 miles per hour.

column1: I propose to examine our Federal system--the relation between city
column2: State
column3: Nation
column4: and the citizens themselves. We need a commission of the most distinguished scholars and men of public affairs to do this job. I will ask them to move on to develop a creative federalism to best use the wonderful diversity of our institutions and our people to solve the problems and to fulfill the dreams of the American people.

column1: As the process of election becomes more complex and more costly
column2: we must make it possible for those without personal wealth to enter public life without being obligated to a few large contributors.

column1: Therefore
column2: I will submit legislation to revise the present unrealistic restriction on contributions--to prohibit the endless proliferation of committees
column3: bringing local and State committees under the act--to attach strong teeth and severe penalties to the requirement of full disclosure of contributions--and to broaden the participation of the people
column4: through added tax incentives
column5: to stimulate small contributions to the party and to the candidate of their choice.

column1: To strengthen the work of Congress I strongly urge an amendment to provide a 4-year term for Members of the House of Representatives--which should not begin before 1972.

The present 2-year term requires most Members of Congress to divert enormous energies to an almost constant process of campaigning--depriving this Nation of the fullest measure of both their skill and their wisdom. Today
column2: too
column3: the work of government is far more complex than in our early years
column4: requiring more time to learn and more time to master the technical tasks of legislating. And a longer term will serve to attract more men of the highest quality to political life. The Nation
column5: the principle of democracy
column6: and
column7: I think
column8: each congressional district
column9: will all be better served by a 4-year term for Members of the House. And I urge your swift action.

column1: IV.
Tonight the cup of peril is full in Vietnam.
That conflict is not an isolated episode
column2: but another great event in the policy that we have followed with strong consistency since World War II.

column1: The touchstone of that policy is the interest of the United States--the welfare and the freedom of the people of the United States. But nations sink when they see that interest only through a narrow glass.
In a world that has grown small and dangerous
column2: pursuit of narrow aims could bring decay and even disaster.

column1: An America that is mighty beyond description--yet living in a hostile or despairing--world would be neither safe nor free to build a civilization to liberate the spirit of man.
In this pursuit we helped rebuild Western Europe. We gave our aid to Greece and Turkey
column2: and we defended the freedom of Berlin.

column1: In this pursuit we have helped new nations toward independence. We have extended the helping hand of the Peace Corps and carried forward the largest program of economic assistance in the world.
And in this pursuit we work to build a hemisphere of democracy and of social justice.

In this pursuit we have defended against Communist aggression--in Korea under President Truman--in the Formosa Straits under President Eisenhower--in Cuba under President Kennedy--and again in Vietnam.
Tonight Vietnam must hold the center of our attention
column2: but across the world problems and opportunities crowd in on the American Nation. I will discuss them fully in the months to come
column3: and I will follow the five continuing lines of policy that America has followed under its last four Presidents.

column1: [1.] The first principle is strength.
Tonight I can tell you that we are strong enough to keep all of our commitments. We will need expenditures of $58.3 billion for the next fiscal year to maintain this necessary defense might.
While special Vietnam expenditures for the next fiscal year are estimated to increase by $5.8 billion
column2: I can tell you that all the other expenditures put together in the entire Federal budget will rise this coming year by only $.6 billion. This is true because of the stringent cost-conscious economy program inaugurated in the Defense Department
column3: and followed by the other departments of Government.

column1: [2.] A second principle of policy is the effort to control
column2: and to reduce
column3: and to ultimately eliminate the modern engines of destruction.

column1: We will vigorously pursue existing proposals--and seek new ones--to control arms and to stop the spread of nuclear weapons.
[3.] A third major principle of our foreign policy is to help build those associations of nations which reflect the opportunities and the necessities of the modern world.
By strengthening the common defense
column2: by stimulating world commerce
column3: by meeting new hopes
column4: these associations serve the cause of a flourishing world.

column1: We will take new steps this year to help strengthen the Alliance for Progress
column2: the unity of Europe
column3: the community of the Atlantic
column4: the regional organizations of developing continents
column5: and that supreme association--the United Nations.

column1: We will work to strengthen economic cooperation
column2: to reduce barriers to trade
column3: and to improve international finance.

column1: [4.] A fourth enduring strand of policy has been to help improve the life of man.
From the Marshall plan to this very moment tonight
column2: that policy has rested on the claims of compassion
column3: and the certain knowledge that only a people advancing in expectation will build secure and peaceful lands.

column1: This year I propose major new directions in our program of foreign assistance to help those countries who will help themselves.
We will conduct a worldwide attack on the problems of hunger and disease and ignorance.
We will place the matchless skill and the resources of our own great America
column2: in farming and in fertilizers
column3: at the service of those countries committed to develop a modern agriculture.

column1: We will aid those who educate the young in other lands
column2: and we will give children in other continents the same head start that we are trying to give our own children. To advance these ends I will propose the International Education Act of 1966.

column1: I will also propose the International Health Act of 1966 to strike at disease by a new effort to bring modern skills and knowledge to the uncared-for
column2: those suffering in the world
column3: and by trying to wipe out smallpox and malaria and control yellow fever over most of the world during this next decade; to help countries trying to control population growth
column4: by increasing our research--and we will earmark funds to help their efforts.

column1: In the next year
column2: from our foreign aid sources
column3: we propose to dedicate $1 billion to these efforts
column4: and we call on all who have the means to join us in this work in the world.

column1: [5.] The fifth and most important principle of our foreign policy is support of national independence--the right of each people to govern themselves--and to shape their own institutions.
For a peaceful world order will be possible only when each country walks the way that it has chosen to walk for itself.
We follow this principle by encouraging the end of colonial rule.
We follow this principle
column2: abroad as well as at home
column3: by continued hostility to the rule of the many by the few--or the oppression of one race by another.

column1: We follow this principle by building bridges to Eastern Europe. And I will ask the Congress for authority to remove the special tariff restrictions which are a barrier to increasing trade between the East and the West.
The insistent urge toward national independence is the strongest force of today's world in which we live.
In Africa and Asia and Latin America it is shattering the designs of those who would subdue others to their ideas or their will.
It is eroding the unity of what was once a Stalinist empire.
In recent months a number of nations have cast out those who would subject them to the ambitions of mainland China.
History is on the side of freedom and is on the side of societies shaped from the genius of each people. History does not favor a single system or belief--unless force is used to make it so.
That is why it has been necessary for us to defend this basic principle of our policy
column2: to defend it in Berlin
column3: in Korea
column4: in Cuba--and tonight in Vietnam.

column1: For tonight
column2: as so many nights before
column3: young Americans struggle and young Americans die in a distant land.

column1: Tonight
column2: as so many nights before
column3: the American Nation is asked to sacrifice the blood of its children and the fruits of its labor for the love of its freedom.

column1: How many times--in my lifetime and in yours--have the American people gathered
column2: as they do now
column3: to hear their President tell them of conflict and tell them of danger?

column1: Each time they have answered. They have answered with all the effort that the security and the freedom of this Nation required.
And they do again tonight in Vietnam.
Not too many years ago Vietnam was a peaceful
column2: if troubled
column3: land. In the North was an independent Communist government. In the South a people struggled to build a nation
column4: with the friendly help of the United States.

column1: There were some in South Vietnam who wished to force Communist rule on their own people. But their progress was slight. Their hope of success was dim. Then
column2: little more than 6 years ago
column3: North Vietnam decided on conquest. And from that day to this
column4: soldiers and supplies have moved from North to South in a swelling stream that is swallowing the remnants of revolution in aggression.

column1: As the assault mounted
column2: our choice gradually became clear. We could leave
column3: abandoning South Vietnam to its attackers and to certain conquest
column4: or we could stay and fight beside the people of South Vietnam.

column1: We stayed.
And we will stay until aggression has stopped.

We will stay because a just nation cannot leave to the cruelties of its enemies a people who have staked their lives and independence on America's solemn pledge--a pledge which has grown through the commitments of three American Presidents.
We will stay because in Asia and around the world are countries whose independence rests
column2: in large measure
column3: on confidence in America's word and in America's protection. To yield to force in Vietnam would weaken that confidence
column4: would undermine the independence of many lands
column5: and would whet the appetite of aggression. We would have to fight in one land
column6: and then we would have to fight in another--or abandon much of Asia to the domination of Communists.

column1: And we do not intend to abandon Asia to conquest.

Last year the nature of the war in Vietnam changed again. Swiftly increasing numbers of armed men from the North crossed the borders to join forces that were already in the South. Attack and terror increased
column2: spurred and encouraged by the belief that the United States lacked the will to continue and that their victory was near.

column1: Despite our desire to limit conflict
column2: it was necessary to act: to hold back the mounting aggression
column3: to give courage to the people of the South
column4: and to make our firmness clear to the North. Thus. we began limited air action against military targets in North Vietnam. We increased our fighting force to its present strength tonight of 190
column5: 000 men.

column1: These moves have not ended the aggression but they have prevented its success. The aims of the enemy have been put out of reach by the skill and the bravery of Americans and their allies--and by the enduring courage of the South Vietnamese who
column2: I can tell you
column3: have lost eight men last year for every one of ours.

column1: The enemy is no longer close to victory. Time is no longer on his side. There is no cause to doubt the American commitment.
Our decision to stand firm has been matched by our desire for peace.
In 1965 alone we had 300 private talks for peace in Vietnam
column2: with friends and adversaries throughout the world.

column1: Since Christmas your Government has labored again
column2: with imagination and endurance
column3: to remove any barrier to peaceful settlement. For 20 days now we and our Vietnamese allies have dropped no bombs in North Vietnam.

column1: Able and experienced spokesmen have visited
column2: in behalf of America
column3: more than 40 countries. We have talked to more than a hundred governments
column4: all 113 that we have relations with
column5: and some that we don't. We have talked to the United Nations and we have called upon all of its members to make any contribution that they can toward helping obtain peace.

column1: In public statements and in private communications
column2: to adversaries and to friends
column3: in Rome and Warsaw
column4: in Paris and Tokyo
column5: in Africa and throughout this hemisphere
column6: America has made her position abundantly clear.

column1: We seek neither territory nor bases
column2: economic domination or military alliance in Vietnam. We fight for the principle of self-determination--that the people of South Vietnam should be able to choose their own course
column3: choose it in free elections without violence
column4: without terror
column5: and without fear.

column1: The people of all Vietnam should make a free decision on the great question of reunification.
This is all we want for South Vietnam. It is all the people of South Vietnam want. And if there is a single nation on this earth that desires less than this for its own people
column2: then let its voice be heard.

column1: We have also made it clear--from Hanoi to New York--that there are no arbitrary limits to our search for peace. We stand by the Geneva Agreements of 1954 and 1962. We will meet at any conference table
column2: we will discuss any proposals--four points or fourteen or forty--and we will consider the views of any group. We will work for a cease-fire now or once discussions have begun. We will respond if others reduce their use of force
column3: and we will withdraw our soldiers once South Vietnam is securely guaranteed the right to shape its own future.

column1: We have said all this
column2: and we have asked--and hoped--and we have waited for a response.

column1: So far we have received no response to prove either success or failure.
We have carried our quest for peace to many nations and peoples because we share this planet with others whose future
column2: in large measure
column3: is tied to our own action
column4: and whose counsel is necessary to our own hopes.

column1: We have found understanding and support. And we know they wait with us tonight for some response that could lead to peace.
I wish tonight that I could give you a blueprint for the course of this conflict over the coming months
column2: but we just cannot know what the future may require. We may have to face long
column3: hard combat or a long
column4: hard conference
column5: or even both at once.

column1: Until peace comes
column2: or if it does not come
column3: our course is clear. We will act as we must to help protect the independence of the valiant people of South Vietnam. We will strive to limit the conflict
column4: for we wish neither increased destruction nor do we want to invite increased danger.

column1: But we will give our fighting men what they must have: every gun
column2: and every dollar
column3: and every decision--whatever the cost or whatever the challenge.

column1: And we will continue to help the people of South Vietnam care for those that are ravaged by battle
column2: create progress in the villages
column3: and carry forward the healing hopes of peace as best they can amidst the uncertain terrors of war.

column1: And let me be absolutely clear: The days may become months
column2: and the months may become years
column3: but we will stay as long as aggression commands us to battle.

column1: There may be some who do not want peace
column2: whose ambitions stretch so far that war in Vietnam is but a welcome and convenient episode in an immense design to subdue history to their will. But for others it must now be clear--the choice is not between peace and victory
column3: it lies between peace and the ravages of a conflict from which they can only lose.

column1: The people of Vietnam
column2: North and South
column3: seek the same things: the shared needs of man
column4: the needs for food and shelter and education--the chance to build and work and till the soil
column5: free from the arbitrary horrors of battle--the desire to walk in the dignity of those who master their own destiny. For many painful years
column6: in war and revolution and infrequent peace
column7: they have struggled to fulfill those needs.

column1: It is a crime against mankind that so much courage
column2: and so much will
column3: and so many dreams
column4: must be flung on the fires of war and death.

column1: To all of those caught up in this conflict we therefore say again tonight: Let us choose peace
column2: and with it the wondrous works of peace
column3: and beyond that
column4: the time when hope reaches toward consummation
column5: and life is the servant of life.

column1: In this work
column2: we plan to discharge our duty to the people whom we serve.

column1: V.
This is the State of the Union.
But over it all--wealth
column2: and promise
column3: and expectation--lies our troubling awareness of American men at war tonight.

column1: How many men who listen to me tonight have served their Nation in other wars? How very many are not here to listen?
The war in Vietnam is not like these other wars. Yet
column2: finally
column3: war is always the same. It is young men dying in the fullness of their promise. It is trying to kill a man that you do not even know well enough to hate.

column1: Therefore
column2: to know war is to know that there is still madness in this world.

column1: Many of you share the burden of this knowledge tonight with me. But there is a difference. For finally I must be the one to order our guns to fire
column2: against all the most inward pulls of my desire. For we have children to teach
column3: and we have sick to be cured
column4: and we have men to be freed. There are poor to be lifted up
column5: and there are cities to be built
column6: and there is a world to be helped.

column1: Yet we do what we must.
I am hopeful
column2: and I will try as best I can
column3: with everything I have got
column4: to end this battle and to return our sons to their desires.

column1: Yet as long as others will challenge America's security and test the clearness of our beliefs with fire and steel
column2: then we must stand or see the promise of two centuries tremble. I believe tonight that you do not want me to try that risk. And from that belief your President summons his strength for the trials that lie ahead in the days to come.

column1: The work must be our work now. Scarred by the weaknesses of man
column2: with whatever guidance God may offer us
column3: we must nevertheless and alone with our mortality
column4: strive to ennoble the life of man on earth.

column1: Thank you
column2: and goodnight.@

column1: Lyndon B. Johnson|Annual Message to the Congress on the State of the Union|1967-01-10|@Mr. Speaker
column2: Mr. Vice President
column3: distinguished Members of the Congress:

column1: I share with all of you the grief that you feel at the death today of one of the most beloved
column2: respected
column3: and effective Members of this body
column4: the distinguished Representative from Rhode Island
column5: Mr. Fogarty.

column1: I have come here tonight to report to you that this is a time of testing for our Nation.
At home
column2: the question is whether we will continue working for better opportunities for all Americans
column3: when most Americans are already living better than any people in history.

column1: Abroad
column2: the question is whether we have the staying power to fight a very costly war
column3: when the objective is limited and the danger to us is seemingly remote.

column1: So our test is not whether we shrink from our country's cause when the dangers to us are obvious and close at hand
column2: but
column3: rather
column4: whether we carry on when they seem obscure and distant--and some think that it is safe to lay down our burdens.

column1: I have come tonight to ask this Congress and this Nation to resolve that issue: to meet our commitments at home and abroad--to continue to build a better America--and to reaffirm this Nation's allegiance to freedom.
As President Abraham Lincoln said
column2: "We must ask where we are
column3: and whither we are tending."

column1: I.
The last 3 years bear witness to our determination to make this a better country.
We have struck down legal barriers to equality.
We have improved the education of 7 million deprived children and this year alone we have enabled almost 1 million students to go to college.
We have brought medical care to older people who were unable to afford it. Three and one-half million Americans have already received treatment under Medicare since July.
We have built a strong economy that has put almost 3 million more Americans on the payrolls in the last year alone.
