We have included more than 9 million new workers under a higher minimum wage.
We have launched new training programs to provide job skills for almost 1 million Americans.
We have helped more than a thousand local communities to attack poverty in the neighborhoods of the poor.
We have set out to rebuild our cities on a scale that has never been attempted before.
We have begun to rescue our waters from the menace of pollution and to restore the beauty of our land and our countryside
column2: our cities and our towns.

column1: We have given 1 million young Americans a chance to earn through the Neighborhood Youth Corps--or through Head Start
column2: a chance to learn.

column1: So together we have tried to meet the needs of our people. And
column2: we have succeeded in creating a better life for the many as well as the few. Now we must answer whether our gains shall be the foundations of further progress
column3: or whether they shall be only monuments to what might have been--abandoned now by a people who lacked the will to see their great work through.

column1: I believe that our people do not want to quit--though the task is great
column2: the work hard
column3: often frustrating
column4: and success is a matter not of days or months
column5: but of years--and sometimes it may be even decades.

column1: II.
I have come here tonight to discuss with you five ways of carrying forward the progress of these last 3 years. These five ways concern programs
column2: partnerships
column3: priorities
column4: prosperity
column5: and peace.

column1: First
column2: programs. We must see to it
column3: I think
column4: that these new programs that we have passed work effectively and are administered in the best possible way.

column1: Three years ago we set out to create these new instruments of social progress. This required trial and error--and it has produced both. But as we learn
column2: through success and failure
column3: we are changing our strategy and we are trying to improve our tactics. In the long run
column4: these starts--some rewarding
column5: others inadequate and disappointing--are crucial to success.

column1: One example is the struggle to make life better for the less fortunate among us.
On a similar occasion
column2: at this rostrum in 1949
column3: I heard a great American President
column4: Harry S. Truman
column5: declare this: "The American people have decided that poverty is just as wasteful and just as unnecessary as preventable disease."

column1: Many listened to President Truman that day here in this Chamber
column2: but few understood what was required and did anything about it. The executive branch and the Congress waited 15 long years before ever taking any action on that challenge
column3: as it did on many other challenges that great President presented. And when
column4: 3 years ago
column5: you here in the Congress joined with me in a declaration of war on poverty
column6: then I warned
column7: "It will not be a short or easy struggle--no single weapon...will suffice--but we shall not rest until that war is won."

column1: And I have come here to renew that pledge tonight.
I recommend that we intensify our efforts to give the poor a chance to enjoy and to join in this Nation's progress.
I shall propose certain administrative changes suggested by the Congress--as well as some that we have learned from our own trial and error.
I shall urge special methods and special funds to reach the hundreds of thousands of Americans that are now trapped in the ghettos of our big cities and
column2: through Head Start
column3: to try to reach out to our very young
column4: little children. The chance to learn is their brightest hope and must command our full determination. For learning brings skills; and skills bring jobs; and jobs bring responsibility and dignity
column5: as well as taxes.

column1: This war--like the war in Vietnam--is not a simple one. There is no single battleline which you can plot each day on a chart. The enemy is not easy to perceive
column2: or to isolate
column3: or to destroy. There are mistakes and there are setbacks. But we are moving
column4: and our direction is forward.

column1: This is true with other programs that are making and breaking new ground. Some do not yet have the capacity to absorb well or wisely all the money that could be put into them. Administrative skills and trained manpower are just as vital to their success as dollars. And I believe those skills will come. But it will take time and patience and hard work. Success cannot be forced at a single stroke. So we must continue to strengthen the administration of every program if that success is to come--as we know it must.
We have done much in the space of 2 short years
column2: working together.

column1: I have recommended
column2: and you
column3: the Congress
column4: have approved
column5: 10 different reorganization plans
column6: combining and consolidating many bureaus of this Government
column7: and creating two entirely new Cabinet departments.

column1: I have come tonight to propose that we establish a new department--a Department of Business and Labor.
By combining the Department of Commerce with the Department of Labor and other related agencies
column2: I think we can create a more economical
column3: efficient
column4: and streamlined instrument that will better serve a growing nation.

column1: This is our goal throughout the entire Federal Government. Every program will be thoroughly evaluated Grant-in-aid programs will be improved and simplified as desired by many of our local administrators and our Governors.
Where there have been mistakes
column2: we will try very hard to correct them.

column1: Where there has been progress
column2: we will try to build upon it.

column1: Our second objective is partnership--to create an effective partnership at all levels of government. And I should treasure nothing more than to have that partnership begin between the executive and the Congress.

The 88th and the 89th Congresses passed more social and economic legislation than any two single Congresses in American history. Most of you who were Members of those Congresses voted to pass most of those measures. But your efforts will come to nothing unless it reaches the people.
Federal energy is essential. But it is not enough. Only a total working partnership among Federal
column2: State
column3: and local governments can succeed. The test of that partnership will be the concern of each public organization
column4: each private institution
column5: and each responsible citizen.

column1: Each State
column2: county
column3: and city needs to examine its capacity for government in today's world
column4: as we are examining ours in the executive department
column5: and as I see you are examining yours. Some will need to reorganize and reshape their methods of administration--as we are doing. Others will need to revise their constitutions and their laws to bring them up to date--as we are doing. Above all
column6: I think we must work together and find ways in which the multitudes of small jurisdictions can be brought together more efficiently.

column1: During the past 3 years we have returned to State and local governments about $40 billion in grants-in-aid. This year alone
column2: 70 percent of our Federal expenditures for domestic programs will be distributed through the State and local governments. With Federal assistance
column3: State and local governments by 1970 will be spending close to $110 billion annually. These enormous sums must be used wisely
column4: honestly
column5: and effectively.

column1: We intend to work closely with the States and the localities to do exactly that.
Our third objective is priorities
column2: to move ahead on the priorities that we have established within the resources that are available.

column1: I wish
column2: of course
column3: that we could do all that should be done--and that we could do it now. But the Nation has many commitments and responsibilities which make heavy demands upon our total resources. No administration would more eagerly utilize for these programs all the resources they require than the administration that started them.

column1: So let us resolve
column2: now
column3: to do all that we can
column4: with what we have--knowing that it is far
column5: far more than we have ever done before
column6: and far
column7: far less than our problems will ultimately require.

column1: Let us create new opportunities for our children and our young Americans who need special help.
We should strengthen the Head Start program
column2: begin it for children 3 years old
column3: and maintain its educational momentum by following through in the early years.

column1: We should try new methods of child development and care from the earliest years
column2: before it is too late to correct.

column1: And I will propose these measures to the 90th Congress.
Let us insure that older Americans
column2: and neglected Americans
column3: share in their Nation's progress.

column1: We should raise social security payments by an overall average of 20 percent. That will add $4 billion 100 million to social security payments in the first year. I will recommend that each of the 23 million Americans now receiving payments get an increase of at least 15 percent.
I will ask that you raise the minimum payments by 59 percent--from $44 to $70 a month
column2: and to guarantee a minimum benefit of $100 a month for those with a total of 25 years of coverage. We must raise the limits that retired workers can earn without losing social security income.

column1: We must eliminate by law unjust discrimination in employment because of age.

We should embark upon a major effort to provide self-help assistance to the forgotten in our midst--the American Indians and the migratory farm workers. And we should reach with the hand of understanding to help those who live in rural poverty.
And I will propose these measures to the 90th Congress.
So let us keep on improving the quality of life and enlarging the meaning of justice for all of our fellow Americans.
We should transform our decaying slums into places of decency through the landmark Model Cities program. I intend to seek for this effort
column2: this year
column3: the full amount that you in Congress authorized last year.

column1: We should call upon the genius of private industry and the most advanced technology to help rebuild our great cities.
We should vastly expand the fight for clean air with a total attack on pollution at its sources
column2: and--because air
column3: like water
column4: does not respect manmade boundaries--we should set up "regional airsheds" throughout this great land.

column1: We should continue to carry to every corner of the Nation our campaign for a beautiful America--to clean up our towns
column2: to make them more beautiful
column3: our cities
column4: our countryside
column5: by creating more parks
column6: and more seashores
column7: and more open spaces for our children to play in
column8: and for the generations that come after us to enjoy.

column1: We should continue to seek equality and justice for each citizen--before a jury
column2: in seeking a job
column3: in exercising his civil rights. We should find a solution to fair housing
column4: so that every American
column5: regardless of color
column6: has a decent home of his choice.

column1: We should modernize our Selective Service System. The National Commission on Selective Service will shortly submit its report. I will send you new recommendations to meet our military manpower needs. But let us resolve that this is to be the Congress that made our draft laws as fair and as effective as possible.
We should protect what Justice Brandeis called the "right most valued by civilized men"--the right to privacy. We should outlaw all wiretapping--public and private--wherever and whenever it occurs
column2: except when the security of this Nation itself is at stake--and only then with the strictest governmental safeguards. And we should exercise the full reach of our constitutional powers to outlaw electronic "bugging" and "snooping."

column1: I hope this Congress will try to help me do more for the consumer. We should demand that the cost of credit be clearly and honestly expressed where average citizens can understand it. We should immediately take steps to prevent massive power failures
column2: to safeguard the home against hazardous household products
column3: and to assure safety in the pipelines that carry natural gas across our Nation.

column1: We should extend Medicare benefits that are now denied to 1
column3: 000 permanently and totally disabled Americans under 65 years of age.

column1: We should improve the process of democracy by passing our election reform and financing proposals
column2: by tightening our laws regulating lobbying
column3: and by restoring a reasonable franchise to Americans who move their residences.

column1: We should develop educational television into a vital public resource to enrich our homes
column2: educate our families
column3: and to provide assistance in our classrooms. We should insist that the public interest be fully served through the public's airwaves.

column1: And I will propose these measures to the 90th Congress.
Now we come to a question that weighs very heavily on all our minds--on yours and mine. This Nation must make an all-out effort to combat crime.

The 89th Congress gave us a new start in the attack on crime by passing the Law Enforcement Assistance Act that I recommended. We appointed the National Crime Commission to study crime in America and to recommend the best ways to carry that attack forward.
And while we do not have all the answers
column2: on the basis of its preliminary recommendations we are ready to move.

column1: This is not a war that Washington alone can win. The idea of a national police force is repugnant to the American people. Crime must be rooted out in local communities by local authorities. Our policemen must be better trained
column2: must be better paid
column3: and must be better supported by the local citizens that they try to serve and to protect.

column1: The National Government can and expects to help.
And so I will recommend to the 90th Congress the Safe Streets and Crime Control Act of 1967. It will enable us to assist those States and cities that try to make their streets and homes safer
column2: their police forces better
column3: their corrections systems more effective
column4: and their courts more efficient.

column1: When the Congress approves
column2: the Federal Government will be able to provide a substantial percentage of the cost:

column1: --90 percent of the cost of developing the State and local plans
column2: master plans
column3: to combat crime in their area;

column1: --60 percent of the cost of training new tactical units
column2: developing instant communications and special alarm systems
column3: and introducing the latest equipment and techniques so that they can become weapons in the war on crime;

column1: --50 percent of the cost of building crime laboratories and police academy-type centers so that our citizens can be protected by the best trained and served by the best equipped police to be found anywhere.

We will also recommend new methods to prevent juvenile delinquents from becoming adult delinquents. We will seek new partnerships with States and cities in order to deal with this hideous narcotics problem. And we will recommend strict controls on the sale of firearms.
At the heart of this attack on crime must be the conviction that a free America--as Abraham Lincoln once said--must "let reverence for the laws . . . become the political religion of the Nation."

Our country's laws must be respected. Order must be maintained. And I will support--with all the constitutional powers the President possesses--our Nation's law enforcement officials in their attempt to control the crime and the violence that tear the fabric of our communities.
Many of these priority proposals will be built on foundations that have already been laid. Some will necessarily be small at first
column2: but "every beginning is a consequence." If we postpone this urgent work now
column3: it will simply have to be done later
column4: and later we will pay a much higher price.

column1: Our fourth objective is prosperity
column2: to keep our economy moving ahead
column3: moving ahead steadily and safely.

column1: We have now enjoyed 6 years of unprecedented and rewarding prosperity.
Last year
--Wages were the highest in history--and the unemployment rate
column2: announced yesterday
column3: reached the lowest point in 13 years;

column1: --Total after-tax income of American families rose nearly 5 percent;
--Corporate profits after taxes rose a little more than 5 percent;
--Our gross national product advanced 5.5 percent
column2: to about $740 billion;

column1: --Income per farm went up 6 percent.

Now we have been greatly concerned because consumer prices rose 4.5 percent over the 18 months since we decided to send troops to Vietnam. This was more than we had expected--and the Government tried to do everything that we knew how to do to hold it down. Yet we were not as successful as we wished to be. In the 18 months after we entered World War II
column2: prices rose not 4.5 percent
column3: but 13.5 percent. In the first 18 months after Korea
column4: after the conflict broke out there
column5: prices rose not 4.5 percent
column6: but 11 percent. During those two periods we had OPA price control that the Congress gave us and War Labor Board wage controls.

column1: Since Vietnam we have not asked for those controls and we have tried to avoid imposing them. We believe that we have done better
column2: but we make no pretense of having been successful or doing as well as we wished.

column1: Our greatest disappointment in the economy during 1966 was the excessive rise in interest rates and the tightening of credit. They imposed very severe and very unfair burdens on our home buyers and on our home builders
column2: and all those associated with the home industry.

column1: Last January
column2: and again last September
column3: I recommended fiscal and moderate tax measures to try to restrain the unbalanced pace of economic expansion. Legislatively and administratively we took several billions out of the economy. With these measures
column4: in both instances
column5: the Congress approved most of the recommendations rather promptly.

column1: As 1966 ended
column2: price stability was seemingly being restored. Wholesale prices are lower tonight than they were in August. So are retail food prices. Monetary conditions are also easing. Most interest rates have retreated from their earlier peaks. More money now seems to be available.

column1: Given the cooperation of the Federal Reserve System
column2: which I so earnestly seek
column3: I am confident that this movement can continue. I pledge the American people that I will do everything in a President's power to lower interest rates and to ease money in this country. The Federal Home Loan Bank Board tomorrow morning will announce that it will make immediately available to savings and loan associations an additional $1 billion
column4: and will lower from 6 percent to 5 3/4 percent the interest rate charged on those loans.

column1: We shall continue on a sensible course of fiscal and budgetary policy that we believe will keep our economy growing without new inflationary spirals; that will finance responsibly the needs of our men in Vietnam and the progress of our people at home; that will support a significant improvement in our export surplus
column2: and will press forward toward easier credit and toward lower interest rates.

column1: I recommend to the Congress a surcharge of 6 percent on both corporate and individual income taxes--to last for 2 years or for so long as the unusual expenditures associated with our efforts in Vietnam continue. I will promptly recommend an earlier termination date if a reduction in these expenditures permits it. This surcharge will raise revenues by some $4.5 billion in the first year. For example
column2: a person whose tax payment
column3: the tax he owes
column4: is $1
column6: will pay
column7: under this proposal
column8: an extra $60 over the 12-month period
column9: or $5 a month. The overwhelming majority of Americans who pay taxes today are below that figure and they will pay substantially less than $5 a month. Married couples with two children
column10: with incomes up to $5
column11: 000 per year
column12: will be exempt from this tax--as will single people with an income of up to $1
column13: 900 a year.

column1: Now if Americans today still paid the income and excise tax rates in effect when I came into the Presidency
column2: in the year 1964
column3: their annual taxes would have been over $20 billion more than at present tax rates. So this proposal is that while we have this problem and this emergency in Vietnam
column4: while we are trying to meet the needs of our people at home
column5: your Government asks for slightly more than one-fourth of that tax cut each year in order to try to hold our budget deficit in fiscal 1968 within prudent limits and to give our country and to give our fighting men the help they need in this hour of trial.

column1: For fiscal 1967
column2: we estimate the budget expenditures to be $126.7 billion and revenues of $117 billion. That will leave us a deficit this year of $9.7 billion.

column1: For fiscal 1968
column2: we estimate budget expenditures of $135 billion. And with the tax measures recommended
column3: and a continuing strong economy
column4: we estimate revenues will be $126.9 billion. The deficit then will be $8.1 billion.

column1: I will very soon forward all of my recommendations to the Congress. Yours is the responsibility to discuss and to debate them--to approve or modify or reject them.
I welcome your views
column2: as I have welcomed working with you for 30 years as a colleague and as Vice President and President.

column1: I should like to say to the Members of the opposition--whose numbers
column2: if I am not mistaken
column3: seem to have increased somewhat--that the genius of the American political system has always been best expressed through creative debate that offers choices and reasonable alternatives. Throughout our history
column4: great Republicans and Democrats have seemed to understand this. So let there be light and reason in our relations. That is the way to a responsible session and a responsive government.

column1: Let us be remembered as a President and a Congress who tried to improve the quality of life for every American--not just the rich
column2: not just the poor
column3: but every man
column4: woman
column5: and child in this great Nation of ours.

column1: We all go to school--to good schools or bad schools. We all take air into our lungs--clean air or polluted air. We all drink water--pure water or polluted water. We all face sickness someday
column2: and some more often than we wish
column3: and old age as well. We all have a stake in this Great Society--in its economic growth
column4: in reduction of civil strife--a great stake in good government.

column1: We just must not arrest the pace of progress we have established in this country in these years. Our children's children will pay the price if we are not wise enough
column2: and courageous enough
column3: and determined enough to stand up and meet the Nation's needs as well as we can in the time allotted us.

column1: III.
Abroad
column2: as at home
column3: there is also risk in change. But abroad
column4: as at home
column5: there is a greater risk in standing still. No part of our foreign policy is so sacred that it ever remains beyond review. We shall be flexible where conditions in the world change--and where man's efforts can change them for the better.

column1: We are in the midst of a great transition--a transition from narrow nationalism to international partnership; from the harsh spirit of the cold war to the hopeful spirit of common humanity on a troubled and a threatened planet.
In Latin America
column2: the American chiefs of state will be meeting very shortly to give our hemispheric policies new direction.

column1: We have come a long way in this hemisphere since the inter-American effort in economic and social development was launched by the conference at Bogota in 1960 under the leadership of President Eisenhower. The Alliance for Progress moved dramatically forward under President Kennedy. There is new confidence that the voice of the people is being heard; that the dignity of the individual is stronger than ever in this hemisphere
column2: and we are facing up to and meeting many of the hemispheric problems together. In this hemisphere that reform under democracy can be made to happen--because it has happened. So together
column3: I think
column4: we must now move to strike down the barriers to full cooperation among the American nations
column5: and to free the energies and the resources of two great continents on behalf of all of our citizens.

column1: Africa stands at an earlier stage of development than Latin America. It has yet to develop the transportation
column2: communications
column3: agriculture
column4: and
column5: above all
column6: the trained men and women without which growth is impossible. There
column7: too
column8: the job will best be done if the nations and peoples of Africa cooperate on a regional basis. More and more our programs for Africa are going to be directed toward self-help.

column1: The future of Africa is shadowed by unsolved racial conflicts. Our policy will continue to reflect our basic commitments as a people to support those who are prepared to work towards cooperation and harmony between races
column2: and to help those who demand change but reject the fool's gold of violence.

column1: In the Middle East the spirit of good will toward all
column2: unfortunately
column3: has not yet taken hold. An already tortured peace seems to be constantly threatened. We shall try to use our influence to increase the possibilities of improved relations among the nations of that region. We are working hard at that task.

column1: In the great subcontinent of South Asia live more than a sixth of the earth's population. Over the years we--and others--have invested very heavily in capital and food for the economic development of India and Pakistan.
We are not prepared to see our assistance wasted
column2: however
column3: in conflict. It must strengthen their capacity to help themselves. It must help these two nations--both our friends--to overcome poverty
column4: to emerge as self-reliant leaders
column5: and find terms for reconciliation and cooperation.

column1: In Western Europe we shall maintain in NATO an integrated common defense. But we also look forward to the time when greater security can be achieved through measures of arms control and disarmament
column2: and through other forms of practical agreement.

column1: We are shaping a new future of enlarged partnership in nuclear affairs
column2: in economic and technical cooperation
column3: in trade negotiations
column4: in political consultation
column5: and in working together with the governments and peoples of Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union.

column1: The emerging spirit of confidence is precisely what we hoped to achieve when we went to work a generation ago to put our shoulder to the wheel and try to help rebuild Europe. We faced new challenges and opportunities then and there--and we faced also some dangers. But I believe that the peoples on both sides of the Atlantic
column2: as well as both sides of this Chamber
column3: wanted to face them together.

column1: Our relations with the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe are also in transition. We have avoided both the acts and the rhetoric of the cold war. When we have differed with the Soviet Union
column2: or other nations
column3: for that matter
column4: I have tried to differ quietly and with courtesy
column5: and without venom.

column1: Our objective is not to continue the cold war
column2: but to end it.

column1: We have reached an agreement at the United Nations on the peaceful uses of outer space.
We have agreed to open direct air flights with the Soviet Union.
We have removed more than 400 nonstrategic items from export control.
We are determined that the Export-Import Bank can allow commercial credits to Poland
column2: Hungary
column3: Bulgaria
column4: and Czechoslovakia
column5: as well as to Romania and Yugoslavia.

column1: We have entered into a cultural agreement with the Soviet Union for another 2 years.
We have agreed with Bulgaria and Hungary to upgrade our legations to embassies.
We have started discussions with international agencies on ways of increasing contacts with Eastern European countries.
This administration has taken these steps even as duty compelled us to fulfill and execute alliances and treaty obligations throughout the world that were entered into before I became President.
So tonight I now ask and urge this Congress to help our foreign and our commercial trade policies by passing an East-West trade bill and by approving our consular convention with the Soviet Union.

The Soviet Union has in the past year increased its long-range missile capabilities. It has begun to place near Moscow a limited antimissile defense. My first responsibility to our people is to assure that no nation can ever find it rational to launch a nuclear attack or to use its nuclear power as a credible threat against us or against our allies.
I would emphasize that that is why an important link between Russia and the United States is in our common interest
column2: in arms control and in disarmament. We have the solemn duty to slow down the arms race between us
column3: if that is at all possible
column4: in both conventional and nuclear weapons and defenses. I thought we were making some progress in that direction the first few months I was in office. I realize that any additional race would impose on our peoples
column5: and on all mankind
column6: for that matter
column7: an additional waste of resources with no gain in security to either side.

column1: I expect in the days ahead to closely consult and seek the advice of the Congress about the possibilities of international agreements bearing directly upon this problem.
Next to the pursuit of peace
column2: the really greatest challenge to the human family is the race between food supply and population increase. That race tonight is being lost.

column1: The time for rhetoric has clearly passed. The time for concerted action is here and we must get on with the job.
We believe that three principles must prevail if our policy is to succeed:
First
column2: the developing nations must give highest priority to food production
column3: including the use of technology and the capital of private enterprise.

column1: Second
column2: nations with food deficits must put more of their resources into voluntary family planning programs.

column1: And third
column2: the developed nations must all assist other nations to avoid starvation in the short run and to move rapidly towards the ability to feed themselves.

column1: Every member of the world community now bears a direct responsibility to help bring our most basic human account into balance.
IV.

I come now finally to Southeast Asia--and to Vietnam in particular. Soon I will submit to the Congress a detailed report on that situation. Tonight I want to just review the essential points as briefly as I can.
We are in Vietnam because the United States of America and our allies are committed by the SEATO Treaty to "act to meet the common danger" of aggression in Southeast Asia.
We are in Vietnam because an international agreement signed by the United States
column2: North Vietnam
column3: and others in 1962 is being systematically violated by the Communists. That violation threatens the independence of all the small nations in Southeast Asia
column4: and threatens the peace of the entire region and perhaps the world.

column1: We are there because the people of South Vietnam have as much right to remain non-Communist--if that is what they choose--as North Vietnam has to remain Communist.
We are there because the Congress has pledged by solemn vote to take all necessary measures to prevent further aggression.
No better words could describe our present course than those once spoken by the great Thomas Jefferson:
It is the melancholy law of human societies to be compelled sometimes to choose a great evil in order to ward off a greater.
We have chosen to fight a limited war in Vietnam in an attempt to prevent a larger war--a war almost certain to follow
column2: I believe
column3: if the Communists succeed in overrunning and taking over South Vietnam by aggression and by force. I believe
column4: and I am supported by some authority
column5: that if they are not checked now the world can expect to pay a greater price to check them later.

column1: That is what our statesmen said when they debated this treaty
column2: and that is why it was ratified 82 to 1 by the Senate many years ago.

column1: You will remember that we stood in Western Europe 20 years ago. Is there anyone in this Chamber tonight who doubts that the course of freedom was not changed for the better because of the courage of that stand?

Sixteen years ago we and others stopped another kind of aggression--this time it was in Korea. Imagine how different Asia might be today if we had failed to act when the Communist army of North Korea marched south. The Asia of tomorrow will be far different because we have said in Vietnam
column2: as we said 16 years ago in Korea: "This far and no further."

column1: I think I reveal no secret when I tell you that we are dealing with a stubborn adversary who is committed to the use of force and terror to settle political questions.
I wish I could report to you that the conflict is almost over. This I cannot do. We face more cost
column2: more loss
column3: and more agony. For the end is not yet. I cannot promise you that it will come this year--or come next year. Our adversary still believes
column4: I think
column5: tonight
column6: that he can go on fighting longer than we can
column7: and longer than we and our allies will be prepared to stand up and resist.

column1: Our men in that area--there are nearly 500
column2: 000 now--have borne well "the burden and the heat of the day." Their efforts have deprived the Communist enemy of the victory that he sought and that he expected a year ago. We have steadily frustrated his main forces. General Westmoreland reports that the enemy can no longer succeed on the battlefield.

column1: So I must say to you that our pressure must be sustained--and will be sustained--until he realizes that the war he started is costing him more than he can ever gain.
I know of no strategy more likely to attain that end than the strategy of "accumulating slowly
column2: but inexorably
column3: every kind of material resource"--of "laboriously teaching troops the very elements of their trade." That
column4: and patience--and I mean a great deal of patience.

column1: Our South Vietnamese allies are also being tested tonight. Because they must provide real security to the people living in the countryside. And this means reducing the terrorism and the armed attacks which kidnaped and killed 26
column2: 900 civilians in the last 32 months
column3: to levels where they can be successfully controlled by the regular South Vietnamese security forces. It means bringing to the villagers an effective civilian government that they can respect
column4: and that they can rely upon and that they can participate in
column5: and that they can have a personal stake in. We hope that government is now beginning to emerge.

column1: While I cannot report the desired progress in the pacification effort
column2: the very distinguished and able Ambassador
column3: Henry Cabot Lodge
column4: reports that South Vietnam is turning to this task with a new sense of urgency. We can help
column5: but only they can win this part of the war. Their task is to build and protect a new life in each rural province.

column1: One result of our stand in Vietnam is already clear.

It is this: The peoples of Asia now know that the door to independence is not going to be slammed shut. They know that it is possible for them to choose their own national destinies--without coercion.

The performance of our men in Vietnam--backed by the American people--has created a feeling of confidence and unity among the independent nations of Asia and the Pacific. I saw it in their faces in the 19 days that I spent in their homes and in their countries. Fear of external Communist conquest in many Asian nations is already subsiding--and with this
column2: the spirit of hope is rising. For the first time in history
column3: a common outlook and common institutions are already emerging.

column1: This forward movement is rooted in the ambitions and the interests of Asian nations themselves. It was precisely this movement that we hoped to accelerate when I spoke at Johns Hopkins in Baltimore in April 1965
column2: and I pledged "a much more massive effort to improve the life of man" in that part of the world
column3: in the hope that we could take some of the funds that we were spending on bullets and bombs and spend it on schools and production.

column1: Twenty months later our efforts have produced a new reality: The doors of the billion dollar Asian Development Bank that I recommended to the Congress
column2: and you endorsed almost unanimously
column3: I am proud to tell you are already open. Asians are engaged tonight in regional efforts in a dozen new directions. Their hopes are high. Their faith is strong. Their confidence is deep.

column1: And even as the war continues
column2: we shall play our part in carrying forward this constructive historic development. As recommended by the Eugene Black mission
column3: and if other nations will join us
column4: I will seek a special authorization from the Congress of $200 million for East Asian regional programs.

column1: We are eager to turn our resources to peace. Our efforts in behalf of humanity I think need not be restricted by any parallel or by any boundary line. The moment that peace comes
column2: as I pledged in Baltimore
column3: I will ask the Congress for funds to join in an international program of reconstruction and development for all the people of Vietnam--and their deserving neighbors who wish our help.

column1: We shall continue to hope for a reconciliation between the people of Mainland China and the world community--including working together in all the tasks of arms control
column2: security
column3: and progress on which the fate of the Chinese people
column4: like their fellow men elsewhere
column5: depends.

column1: We would be the first to welcome a China which decided to respect her neighbors' rights. We would be the first to applaud her were she to apply her great energies and intelligence to improving the welfare of her people. And we have no intention of trying to deny her legitimate needs for security and friendly relations with her neighboring countries.
Our hope that all of this will someday happen rests on the conviction that we
column2: the American people and our allies
column3: will and are going to see Vietnam through to an honorable peace.

column1: We will support all appropriate initiatives by the United Nations
column2: and others
column3: which can bring the several parties together for unconditional discussions of peace--anywhere
column4: any time. And we will continue to take every possible initiative ourselves to constantly probe for peace.

column1: Until such efforts succeed
column2: or until the infiltration ceases
column3: or until the conflict subsides
column4: I think the course of wisdom for this country is that we just must firmly pursue our present course. We will stand firm in Vietnam.

column1: I think you know that our fighting men there tonight bear the heaviest burden of all. With their lives they serve their Nation. We must give them nothing less than our full support--and we have given them that--nothing less than the determination that Americans have always given their fighting men. Whatever our sacrifice here
column2: even if it is more than $5 a month
column3: it is small compared to their own.

column1: How long it will take I cannot prophesy. I only know that the will of the American people
column2: I think
column3: is tonight being tested.

column1: Whether we can fight a war of limited objectives over a period of time
column2: and keep alive the hope of independence and stability for people other than ourselves; whether we can continue to act with restraint when the temptation to "get it over with" is inviting but dangerous; whether we can accept the necessity of choosing "a great evil in order to ward off a greater"; whether we can do these without arousing the hatreds and the passions that are ordinarily loosed in time of war--on all these questions so much turns.

column1: The answers will determine not only where we are
column2: but "whither we are tending."

column1: A time of testing--yes. And a time of transition. The transition is sometimes slow; sometimes unpopular; almost always very painful; and often quite dangerous.
But we have lived with danger for a long time before
column2: and we shall live with it for a long time yet to come. We know that "man is born unto trouble." We also know that this Nation was not forged and did not survive and grow and prosper without a great deal of sacrifice from a great many men.

column1: For all the disorders that we must deal with
column2: and all the frustrations that concern us
column3: and all the anxieties that we are called upon to resolve
column4: for all the issues we must face with the agony that attends them
column5: let us remember that "those who expect to reap the blessings of freedom must
column6: like men
column7: undergo the fatigues of supporting it."

column1: But let us also count not only our burdens but our blessings--for they are many.
And let us give thanks to the One who governs us all.
Let us draw encouragement from the signs of hope--for they
column2: too
column3: are many.

column1: Let us remember that we have been tested before and America has never been found wanting.
So with your understanding
column2: I would hope your confidence
column3: and your support
column4: we are going to persist--and we are going to succeed.@

column1: Lyndon B. Johnson|Annual Message to the Congress on the State of the Union|1968-01-17|@Mr. Speaker
column2: Mr. President
column3: Members of the Congress
column4: and my fellow Americans:

column1: I was thinking as I was walking down the aisle tonight of what Sam Rayburn told me many years ago: The Congress always extends a very warm welcome to the President--as he comes in.
Thank all of you very
column2: very much.

column1: I have come once again to this Chamber--the home of our democracy--to give you
column2: as the Constitution requires
column3: "Information of the State of the Union."

column1: I report to you that our country is challenged
column2: at home and abroad:

column1: --that it is our will that is being tried
column2: not our strength; our sense of purpose
column3: not our ability to achieve a better America;

column1: --that we have the strength to meet our every challenge; the physical strength to hold the course of decency and compassion at home; and the moral strength to support the cause of peace in the world.
And I report to you that I believe
column2: with abiding conviction
column3: that this people--nurtured by their deep faith
column4: tutored by their hard lessons
column5: moved by their high aspirations--have the will to meet the trials that these times impose.

column1: Since I reported to you last January:
--Three elections have been held in Vietnam--in the midst of war and under the constant threat of violence.
--A President
column2: a Vice President
column3: a House and Senate
column4: and village officials have been chosen by popular
column5: contested ballot.

column1: --The enemy has been defeated in battle after battle.
--The number of South Vietnamese living in areas under Government protection tonight has grown by more than a million since January of last year.
These are all marks of progress. Yet:
--The enemy continues to pour men and material across frontiers and into battle
column2: despite his continuous heavy losses.

column1: --He continues to hope that America's will to persevere can be broken. Well--he is wrong. America will persevere. Our patience and our perseverance will match our power. Aggression will never prevail.
But our goal is peace--and peace at the earliest possible moment.
Right now we are exploring the meaning of Hanoi's recent statement. There is no mystery about the questions which must be answered before the bombing is stopped.
We believe that any talks should follow the San Antonio formula that I stated last September
column2: which said:

column1: --The bombing would stop immediately if talks would take place promptly and with reasonable hopes that they would be productive.
--And the other side must not take advantage of our restraint as they have in the past. This Nation simply cannot accept anything less without jeopardizing the lives of our men and of our allies.

If a basis for peace talks can be established on the San Antonio foundations--and it is my hope and my prayer that they can--we would consult with our allies and with the other side to see if a complete cessation of hostilities--a really true cease-fire--could be made the first order of business. I will report at the earliest possible moment the results of these explorations to the American people.

I have just recently returned from a very fruitful visit and talks with His Holiness the Pope and I share his hope--as he expressed it earlier today--that both sides will extend themselves in an effort to bring an end to the war in Vietnam. I have today assured him that we and our allies will do our full part to bring this about.
Since I spoke to you last January
column2: other events have occurred that have major consequences for world peace.

column1: --The Kennedy Round achieved the greatest reduction in tariff barriers in all the history of trade negotiations.
--The nations of Latin America at Punta del Este resolved to move toward economic integration.
--In Asia
column2: the nations from Korea and Japan to Indonesia and Singapore worked behind America's shield to strengthen their economies and to broaden their political cooperation.

column1: --In Africa
column2: from which the distinguished Vice President has just returned
column3: he reports to me that there is a spirit of regional cooperation that is beginning to take hold in very practical ways.

column1: These events we all welcomed. Yet since I last reported to you
column2: we and the world have been confronted by a number of crises:

column1: --During the Arab-Israeli war last June
column2: the hot line between Washington and Moscow was used for the first time in our history. A cease-fire was achieved without a major power confrontation.

column1: Now the nations of the Middle East have the opportunity to cooperate with Ambassador Jarring's U.N. mission and they have the responsibility to find the terms of living together in stable peace and dignity
column2: and we shall do all in our power to help them achieve that result.

column1: --Not far from this scene of conflict
column2: a crisis flared on Cyprus involving two peoples who are America's friends: Greece and Turkey. Our very able representative
column3: Mr. Cyrus Vance
column4: and others helped to ease this tension.

column1: --Turmoil continues on the mainland of China after a year of violent disruption. The radical extremism of their Government has isolated the Chinese people behind their own borders. The United States
column2: however
column3: remains willing to permit the travel of journalists to both our countries; to undertake cultural and educational exchanges; and to talk about the exchange of basic food crop materials.

column1: Since I spoke to you last
column2: the United States and the Soviet Union have taken several important steps toward the goal of international cooperation.

column1: As you will remember
column2: I met with Chairman Kosygin at Glassboro and we achieved if not accord
column3: at least a clearer understanding of our respective positions after 2 days of meeting.

column1: Because we believe the nuclear danger must be narrowed
column2: we have worked with the Soviet Union and with other nations to reach an agreement that will halt the spread of nuclear weapons. On the basis of communications from Ambassador Fisher in Geneva this afternoon
column3: I am encouraged to believe that a draft treaty can be laid before the conference in Geneva in the very near future. I hope to be able to present that treaty to the Senate this year for the Senate's approval.

column1: We achieved
column3: a consular treaty with the Soviets
column4: the first commercial air agreement between the two countries
column5: and a treaty banning weapons in outer space. We shall sign
column6: and submit to the Senate shortly
column7: a new treaty with the Soviets and with others for the protection of astronauts.

column1: Serious differences still remain between us
column2: yet in these relations
column3: we have made some progress since Vienna
column4: the Berlin Wall
column5: and the Cuban missile crisis.

column1: But despite this progress
column2: we must maintain a military force that is capable of deterring any threat to this Nation's security
column3: whatever the mode of aggression. Our choices must not be confined to total war--or to total acquiescence.

column1: We have such a military force today. We shall maintain it.
I wish--with all of my heart--that the expenditures that are necessary to build and to protect our power could all be devoted to the programs of peace. But until world conditions permit
column2: and until peace is assured
column3: America's might--and America's bravest sons who wear our Nation's uniform--must continue to stand guard for all of us--as they gallantly do tonight in Vietnam and other places in the world.

column1: Yet neither great weapons nor individual courage can provide the conditions of peace.
For two decades America has committed itself against the tyranny of want and ignorance in the world that threatens the peace. We shall sustain that commitment.
This year I shall propose:
--That we launch
column2: with other nations
column3: an exploration of the ocean depths to tap its wealth
column4: and its energy
column5: and its abundance.

column1: --That we contribute our fair share to a major expansion of the International Development Association
column2: and to increase the resources of the Asian Development Bank.

column1: --That we adopt a prudent aid program
column2: rooted in the principle of self-help.

column1: --That we renew and extend the food for freedom program.
Our food programs have already helped millions avoid the horrors of famine.
But unless the rapid growth of population in developing countries is slowed
column2: the gap between rich and poor will widen steadily.

column1: Governments in the developing countries must take such facts into consideration. We in the United States are prepared to help assist them in those efforts.

But we must also improve the lives of children already born in the villages and towns and cities on this earth. They can be taught by great teachers through space communications and the miracle of satellite television--and we are going to bring to bear every resource of mind and technology to help make this dream come true.
Let me speak now about some matters here at home.

Tonight our Nation is accomplishing more for its people than has ever been accomplished before. Americans are prosperous as men have never been in recorded history. Yet there is in the land a certain restlessness--a questioning.
The total of our Nation's annual production is now above $800 billion. For 83 months this Nation has been on a steady upward trend of growth.
All about them
column2: most American families can see the evidence of growing abundance: higher paychecks
column3: humming factories
column4: new cars moving down new highways. More and more families own their own homes
column5: equipped with more than 70 million television sets.

column1: A new college is founded every week. Today more than half of the high school graduates go on to college.
There are hundreds of thousands of fathers and mothers who never completed grammar school--who will see their children graduate from college.
Why
column2: then
column3: this restlessness?

column1: Because when a great ship cuts through the sea
column2: the waters are always stirred and troubled.

column1: And our ship is moving. It is moving through troubled and new waters; it is moving toward new and better shores.
We ask now
column2: not how can we achieve abundance?--but how shall we use our abundance? Not
column3: is there abundance enough for all?--but
column4: how can all share in our abundance?

column1: While we have accomplished much
column2: much remains for us to meet and much remains for us to master.

column1: --In some areas
column2: the jobless rate is still three or four times the national average.

column1: --Violence has shown its face in some of our cities.
--Crime increases on our streets.
--Income for farm workers remains far behind that for urban workers; and parity for our farmers who produce our food is still just a hope--not an achievement.
--New housing construction is far less than we need--to assure decent shelter for every family.
--Hospital and medical costs are high
column2: and they are rising.

column1: --Many rivers--and the air in many cities--remain badly polluted. And our citizens suffer from breathing that air.
We have lived with conditions like these for many
column2: many years. But much that we once accepted as inevitable
column3: we now find absolutely intolerable.

column1: In our cities last summer
column2: we saw how wide is the gulf for some Americans between the promise and the reality of our society.

column1: We know that we cannot change all of this in a day. It represents the bitter consequences of more than three centuries.
But the issue is not whether we can change this; the issue is whether we will change this.
Well
column2: I know we can. And I believe we will.

column1: This then is the work we should do in the months that are ahead of us in this Congress.
The first essential is more jobs
column2: useful jobs for tens of thousands who can become productive and can pay their own way.

column1: Our economy has created 7 1/2 million new jobs in the past 4 years. It is adding more than a million and a half new jobs this year.
Through programs passed by the Congress
column2: job training is being given tonight to more than a million Americans in this country.

column1: This year
column2: the time has come when we must get to those who are last in line--the hard-core unemployed--the hardest to reach.

column1: Employment officials estimate that 500
column2: 000 of these persons are now unemployed in the major cities of America. Our objective is to place these 500
column3: 000 in private industry jobs within the next 3 years.

column1: To do this
column2: I propose a $2.1 billion manpower program in the coming fiscal year--a 25 percent increase over the current year. Most of this increase will be used to start a new partnership between government and private industry to train and to hire the hard-core unemployed persons. I know of no task before us of more importance to us
column3: to the country
column4: or to our future.

column1: Another essential is to rebuild our cities.

Last year the Congress authorized $662 million for the Model Cities program. I requested the full amount of that authorization to help meet the crisis in the cities of America. But the Congress appropriated only $312 million--less than half.
This year I urge the Congress to honor my request for model cities funds to rebuild the centers of American cities by granting us the full amount that you in the Congress authorized--$1 billion.
The next essential is more housing--and more housing now.
Surely a nation that can go to the moon can place a decent home within the reach of its families.
Therefore we must call together the resources of industry and labor
column2: to start building 300
column3: 000 housing units for low- and middle-income families next year--that is three times more than this year. We must make it possible for thousands of families to become homeowners
column4: not rent-payers.

column1: I propose
column2: for the consideration of this Congress
column3: a 10-year campaign to build 6 million new housing units for low- and middle-income families. Six million units in the next 10 years. We have built 530
column4: 000 the last 10 years.

column1: Better health for our children--all of our children--is essential if we are to have a better America.
Last year
column2: Medicare
column3: Medicaid
column4: and other new programs that you passed in the Congress brought better health to more than 25 million Americans.

column1: American medicine--with the very strong support and cooperation of public resources-has produced a phenomenal decline in the death rate from many of the dread diseases.
But it is a shocking fact that
column2: in saving the lives of babies
column3: America ranks 15th among the nations of the world. And among children
column4: crippling defects are often discovered too late for any corrective action. This is a tragedy that Americans can
column5: and Americans should
column6: prevent.

column1: I shall
column2: therefore
column3: propose to the Congress a child health program to provide
column4: over the next 5 years
column5: for families unable to afford it--access to health services from prenatal care of the mother through the child's first year.

column1: When we do that you will find it is the best investment we ever made because we will get these diseases in their infancy and we will find a cure in a great many instances that we can never find by overcrowding our hospitals when they are grown.
Now when we act to advance the consumer's cause I think we help every American.
Last year
column2: with very little fanfare the Congress and the executive branch moved in that field.

column1: We enacted the Wholesome Meat Act
column2: the Flammable Fabrics Act
column3: the Product Safety Commission
column4: and a law to improve clinical laboratories.

column1: And now
column2: I think
column3: the time has come to complete our unfinished work. The Senate has already passed the truth-in-lending bill
column4: the fire safety bill
column5: and the pipeline safety laws.

column1: Tonight I plead with the House to immediately act upon these measures and I hope take favorable action upon all of them. I call upon the Congress to enact
column2: without delay
column3: the remainder of the 12 vital consumer protection laws that I submitted to the Congress last year.

column1: I also urge final action on a measure that is already passed by the House to guard against fraud and manipulation in the Nation's commodity exchange market.
These measures are a pledge to our people--to keep them safe in their homes and at work
column2: and to give them a fair deal in the marketplace.

column1: And I think we must do more. I propose:
--New powers for the Federal Trade Commission to stop those who defraud and who swindle our public.
--New safeguards to insure the quality of fish and poultry
column2: and the safety of our community water supplies.

column1: --A major study of automobile insurance.
--Protection against hazardous radiation from television sets and other electronic equipment.
And to give the consumer a stronger voice
column2: I plan to appoint a consumer counsel in the Justice Department--a lawyer for the American consumer--to work directly under the Attorney General
column3: to serve the President's Special Assistant for Consumer Affairs
column4: and to serve the consumers of this land.

column1: This Congress--Democrats and Republicans--can earn the thanks of history. We can make this truly a new day for the American consumer
column2: and by giving him this protection we can live in history as the consumer-conscious Congress.

column1: So let us get on with the work. Let us act soon.
We
column2: at every level of the government
column3: State
column4: local
column5: Federal
column6: know that the American people have had enough of rising crime and lawlessness in this country.

column1: They recognize that law enforcement is first the duty of local police and local government.
They recognize that the frontline headquarters against crime is in the home
column2: the church
column3: the city hall and the county courthouse and the statehouse--not in the far-removed National Capital of Washington.

column1: But the people also recognize that the National Government can and the National Government should help the cities and the States in their war on crime to the full extent of its resources and its constitutional authority. And this we shall do.
This does not mean a national police force. It does mean help and financial support:
--to develop State and local master plans to combat crime
--to provide better training and better pay for police
column2: and

column1: --to bring the most advanced technology to the war on crime in every city and every county in America.

There is no more urgent business before this Congress than to pass the Safe Streets Act this year that I proposed last year. That law will provide these required funds. They are so critically needed that I have doubled my request under this act to $100 million in fiscal 1969.
And I urge the Congress to stop the trade in mail-order murder
column2: to stop it this year by adopting a proper gun control law.

column1: This year
column2: I will propose a Drug Control Act to provide stricter penalties for those who traffic in LSD and other dangerous drugs with our people.

column1: I will ask for more vigorous enforcement of all of our drug laws by increasing the number of Federal drug and narcotics control officials by more than 30 percent. The time has come to stop the sale of slavery to the young. I also request you to give us funds to add immediately 100 assistant United States attorneys throughout the land to help prosecute our criminal laws. We have increased our judiciary by 40 percent and we have increased our prosecutors by 16 percent. The dockets are full of cases because we don't have assistant district attorneys to go before the Federal judge and handle them. We start these young lawyers at $8
column2: 200 a year. And the docket is clogged because we don't have authority to hire more of them.

column1: I ask the Congress for authority to hire 100 more. These young men will give special attention to this drug abuse
column2: too.

column1: Finally
column2: I ask you to add 100 FBI agents to strengthen law enforcement in the Nation and to protect the individual rights of every citizen.

column1: A moment ago I spoke of despair and frustrated hopes in the cities where the fires of disorder burned last summer. We can--and in time we will--change that despair into confidence
column2: and change those frustrations into achievements. But violence will never bring progress.

column1: We can make progress only by attacking the causes of violence and only where there is civil order founded on justice.
Today we are helping local officials improve their capacity to deal promptly with disorders.
Those who preach disorder and those who preach violence must know that local authorities are able to resist them swiftly
column2: to resist them sternly
column3: and to resist them decisively.

column1: I shall recommend other actions:
--To raise the farmers' income by establishing a security commodity reserve that will protect the market from price-depressing stocks and protect the consumer from food scarcity.
--I shall recommend programs to help farmers bargain more effectively for fair prices.
--I shall recommend programs for new air safety measures.
--Measures to stem the rising costs of medical care.
--Legislation to encourage our returning veterans to devote themselves to careers in community service such as teaching
column2: and being firemen
column3: and joining our police force
column4: and our law enforcement officials.

column1: --I shall recommend programs to strengthen and finance our anti-pollution efforts.
--Fully funding all of the $2.18 billion poverty program that you in the Congress had just authorized in order to bring opportunity to those who have been left far behind.
--I shall recommend an Educational Opportunity Act to speed up our drive to break down the financial barriers that are separating our young people from college.
I shall also urge the Congress to act on several other vital pending bills--especially the civil rights measures--fair jury trials
column2: protection of Federal rights
column3: enforcement of equal employment opportunity
column4: and fair housing.

column1: The unfinished work of the first session must be completed--the Higher Education Act
column2: the Juvenile Delinquency Act
column3: conservation measures to save the redwoods of California
column4: and to preserve the wonders of our scenic rivers
column5: the Highway Beautification Act--and all the other measures for a cleaner
column6: and for a better
column7: and for a more beautiful America.

column1: Next month we'll begin our 8th year of uninterrupted prosperity. The economic outlook for this year is one of steady growth--if we are vigilant.
True
column2: there are some clouds on the horizon. Prices are rising. Interest rates have passed the peak of 1966; and if there is continued inaction on the tax bill
column3: they will climb even higher.

column1: I warn the Congress and the Nation tonight that this failure to act on the tax bill will sweep us into an accelerating spiral of price increases
column2: a slump in homebuilding
column3: and a continuing erosion of the American dollar.

column1: This would be a tragedy for every American family. And I predict that if this happens
column2: they will all let us know about it.

column1: We--those of us in the executive branch
column2: in the Congress
column3: and the leaders of labor and business--must do everything we can to prevent that kind of misfortune.

column1: Under the new budget
column2: the expenditures for 1969 will increase by $10.4 billion. Receipts will increase by $22.3 billion including the added tax revenues. Virtually all of this expenditure increase represents the mandatory cost of our defense efforts
column3: $3 billion; increased interest
column4: almost $1 billion; or mandatory payments under laws passed by Congress--such as those provided in the Social Security Act that you passed in 1967
column5: and to Medicare and Medicaid beneficiaries
column6: veterans
column7: and farmers
column8: of about $4 1/2 billion; and the additional $1 billion 600 million next year for the pay increases that you passed in military and civilian pay. That makes up the $10 billion that is added to the budget. With few exceptions
column9: very few
column10: we are holding the fiscal 1969 budget to last year's level
column11: outside of those mandatory and required increases.

column1: A Presidential commission composed of distinguished congressional fiscal leaders and other prominent Americans recommended this year that we adopt a new budget approach. I am carrying out their recommendations in this year's budget. This budget
column2: therefore
column3: for the first time accurately covers all Federal expenditures and all Federal receipts
column4: including for the first time in one budget $47 billion from the social security
column5: Medicare
column6: highway
column7: and other trust funds.

column1: The fiscal 1969 budget has expenditures of approximately $186 billion
column2: with total estimated revenues
column3: including the tax bill
column4: of about $178 billion.

column1: If the Congress enacts the tax increase
column2: we will reduce the budget deficit by some $12 billion. The war in Vietnam is costing us about $25 billion and we are asking for about $12 billion in taxes--and if we get that $12 billion tax bill we will reduce the deficit from about $20 billion in 1968 to about $8 billion in 1969.

column1: Now
column2: this is a tight budget. It follows the reduction that I made in cooperation with the Congress--a reduction made after you had reviewed every appropriations bill and reduced the appropriations by some $5 or $6 billion and expenditures by $1.5 billion. We conferred together and I recommended to the Congress and you subsequently approved taking 2 percent from payrolls and 10 percent from controllable expenditures. We therefore reduced appropriations almost $10 billion last session and expenditures over $4 billion. Now
column3: that was in the budget last year.

column1: I ask the Congress to recognize that there are certain selected programs that meet the Nation's most urgent needs and they have increased. We have insisted that decreases in very desirable but less urgent programs be made before we would approve any increases.
So I ask the Congress tonight:
--to hold its appropriations to the budget requests
column2: and

column1: --to act responsibly early this year by enacting the tax surcharge which for the average American individual amounts to about a penny out of each dollar's income.
This tax increase would yield about half of the $23 billion per year that we returned to the people in the tax reduction bills of 1964 and 1965.
This must be a temporary measure
column2: which expires in less than 2 years. Congress can repeal it sooner if the need has passed. But Congress can never repeal inflation.

column1: The leaders of American business and the leaders of American labor--those who really have power over wages and prices--must act responsibly
column2: and in their Nation's interest by keeping increases in line with productivity. If our recognized leaders do not do this
column3: they and those for whom they speak and all of us are going to suffer very serious consequences.

column1: On January 1st
column2: I outlined a program to reduce our balance of payments deficit sharply this year. We will ask the Congress to help carry out those parts of the program which require legislation. We must restore equilibrium to our balance of payments.

column1: We must also strengthen the international monetary system. We have assured the world that America's full gold stock stands behind our commitment to maintain the price of gold at $35 an ounce. We must back this commitment by legislating now to free our gold reserves.
Americans
column2: traveling more than any other people in history
column3: took $4 billion out of their country last year in travel costs. We must try to reduce the travel deficit that we have of more than $2 billion. We are hoping that we can reduce it by $500 million--without unduly penalizing the travel of teachers
column4: students
column5: business people who have essential and necessary travel
column6: or people who have relatives abroad whom they want to see. Even with this reduction of $500 million
column7: the American people will still be traveling more overseas than they did in 1967
column9: or 1965 or any other year in their history.

column1: If we act together as I hope we can
column2: I believe we can continue our economic expansion which has already broken all past records. And I hope that we can continue that expansion in the days ahead.

column1: Each of these questions I have discussed with you tonight is a question of policy for our people. Therefore
column2: each of them should be--and doubtless will be--debated by candidates for public office this year.

column1: I hope those debates will be marked by new proposals and by a seriousness that matches the gravity of the questions themselves.
These are not appropriate subjects for narrow partisan oratory. They go to the heart of what we Americans are all about--all of us
column2: Democrats and Republicans.

column1: Tonight I have spoken of some of the goals I should like to see America reach. Many of them can be achieved this year--others by the time we celebrate our Nation's 200th birthday--the bicentennial of our independence.

Several of these goals are going to be very hard to reach. But the State of our Union will be much stronger 8 years from now on our 200th birthday if we resolve to reach these goals now. They are more important--much more important--than the identity of the party or the President who will then be in office.
These goals are what the fighting and our alliances are really meant to protect.
Can we achieve these goals?
Of course we can--if we will.
If ever there was a people who sought more than mere abundance
column2: it is our people.

column1: If ever there was a nation that was capable of solving its problems
column2: it is this Nation.

column1: If ever there were a time to know the pride and the excitement and the hope of being an American--it is this time.
So this
column2: my friends
column3: is the State of our Union: seeking
column4: building
column5: tested many times in this past year--and always equal to the test.

column1: Thank you and good night.@
Lyndon B. Johnson|Annual Message to the Congress on the State of the Union|1969-01-14|@Mr. Speaker
column2: Mr. President
column3: Members of the Congress and my fellow
column4: Americans:

column1: For the sixth and the last time
column2: I present to the Congress my assessment of the State of the Union.

column1: I shall speak to you tonight about challenge and opportunity--and about the commitments that all of us have made together that will
column2: if we carry them out
column3: give America our best chance to achieve the kind of great society that we all want.

column1: Every President lives
column2: not only with what is
column3: but with what has been and what could be.

column1: Most of the great events in his Presidency are part of a larger sequence extending back through several years and extending back through several other administrations.
Urban unrest
column2: poverty
column3: pressures on welfare
column4: education of our people
column5: law enforcement and law and order
column6: the continuing crisis in the Middle East
column7: the conflict in Vietnam
column8: the dangers of nuclear war
column9: the great difficulties of dealing with the Communist powers
column10: all have this much in common: They and their causes--the causes that gave rise to them--all of these have existed with us for many years. Several Presidents have already sought to try to deal with them. One or more Presidents will try to resolve them or try to contain them in the years that are ahead of us.

column1: But if the Nation's problems are continuing
column2: so are this great Nation's assets:

column1: --our economy
--the democratic system
--our sense of exploration
column2: symbolized most recently by the wonderful flight of the Apollo 8
column3: in which all Americans took great pride

column1: --the good commonsense and sound judgment of the American people
column2: and

column1: --their essential love of justice.

We must not ignore our problems. But neither should we ignore our strengths. Those strengths are available to sustain a President of either party--to support his progressive efforts both at home and overseas.
Unfortunately
column2: the departure of an administration does not mean the end of the problems that this administration has faced. The effort to meet the problems must go on
column3: year after year
column4: if the momentum that we have all mounted together in these past years is not to be lost.

column1: Although the struggle for progressive change is continuous
column2: there are times when a watershed is reached--when there is--if not really a break with the past--at least the fulfillment of many of its oldest hopes
column3: and a stepping forth into a new environment
column4: to seek new goals.

column1: I think the past 5 years have been such a time.
We have finished a major part of the old agenda.
Some of the laws that we wrote have already
column2: in front of our eyes
column3: taken on the flesh of achievement.

column1: Medicare that we were unable to pass for so many years is now a part of American life.
Voting rights and the voting booth that we debated so long back in the fifties
column2: and the doors to public service
column3: are open at last to all Americans regardless of their color.

column1: Schools and school children all over America tonight are receiving Federal assistance to go to good schools.
Preschool education--Head Start--is already here to stay and
column2: I think
column3: so are the Federal programs that tonight are keeping more than a million and a half of the cream of our young people in the colleges and the universities of this country.

column1: Part of the American earth--not only in description on a map
column2: but in the reality of our shores
column3: our hills
column4: our parks
column5: our forests
column6: and our mountains--has been permanently set aside for the American public and for their benefit. And there is more that will be set aside before this administration ends.

column1: Five million Americans have been trained for jobs in new Federal programs.

I think it is most important that we all realize tonight that this Nation is close to full employment--with less unemployment than we have had at any time in almost 20 years. That is not in theory; that is in fact. Tonight
column2: the unemployment rate is down to 3.3 percent. The number of jobs has grown more than 8 1/2 million in the last 5 years. That is more than in all the preceding 12 years.

column1: These achievements completed the full cycle
column2: from idea to enactment and
column3: finally
column4: to a place in the lives of citizens all across this country.

column1: I wish it were possible to say that everything that this Congress and the administration achieved during this period had already completed that cycle. But a great deal of what we have committed needs additional funding to become a tangible realization.
Yet the very existence of these commitments--these promises to the American people
column2: made by this Congress and by the executive branch of the Government--are achievements in themselves
column3: and failure to carry through on our commitments would be a tragedy for this Nation.

column1: This much is certain: No one man or group of men made these commitments alone. Congress and the executive branch
column2: with their checks and balances
column3: reasoned together and finally wrote them into the law of the land. They now have all the moral force that the American political system can summon when it acts as one.

column1: They express America's common determination to achieve goals. They imply action.
In most cases
column2: you have already begun that action--but it is not fully completed
column3: of course.
