column1: Let me speak for a moment about these commitments. I am going to speak in the language which the Congress itself spoke when it passed these measures.
I am going to quote from your words.

column2: Congress declared that "improving the quality of urban life is the most critical domestic problem facing the United States." Two years later it affirmed the historic goal of "a decent home . . . for every American family." That is your language.

column1: Now to meet these commitments
column2: we must increase our support for the model cities program
column3: where blueprints of change are already being prepared in more than 150 American cities

column1: To achieve the goals of the Housing Act of 1968 that you have already passed
column2: we should begin this year more than 500
column3: 000 homes for needy families in the coming fiscal year. Funds are provided in the new budget to do just this. This is almost 10 times--10 times--the average rate of the past 10 years.

column1: Our cities and our towns are being pressed for funds to meet the needs of their growing populations. So I believe an urban development bank should be created by the Congress. This bank could obtain resources through the issuance of taxable bonds and it could then lend these resources at reduced rates to the communities throughout the land for schools
column2: hospitals
column3: parks
column4: and other public facilities.

column1: Since we enacted the Social Security Act back in 1935
column2: Congress has recognized the necessity to "make more adequate provision for aged persons . . . through maternal and child welfare . . . and public health." Those are the words of the Congress--"more adequate."

column1: The time has come
column2: I think
column3: to make it more adequate. I believe we should increase social security benefits
column4: and I am so recommending tonight.

column1: I am suggesting that there should be an overall increase in benefits of at least 13 percent. Those who receive only the minimum of $55 should get $80 a month.
Our Nation
column2: too
column3: is rightfully proud of our medical advances. But we should remember that our country ranks 15th among the nations of the world in its infant mortality rate.

column1: I think we should assure decent medical care for every expectant mother and for their children during the first year of their life in the United States of America.
I think we should protect our children and their families from the costs of catastrophic illness.
As we pass on from medicine
column2: I think nothing is clearer to the Congress than the commitment that the Congress made to end poverty. Congress expressed it well
column3: I think
column5: when they said: "It is the policy of the United States to eliminate the paradox of poverty in the midst of plenty in this nation."

column1: This is the richest nation in the world. The antipoverty program has had many achievements. It also has some failures. But we must not cripple it after only 3 years of trying to solve the human problems that have been with us and have been building up among us for generations.
I believe the Congress this year will want to improve the administration of the poverty program by reorganizing portions of it and transferring them to other agencies. I believe
column2: though
column3: it will want to continue
column4: until we have broken the back of poverty
column5: the efforts we are now making throughout this land.

column1: I believe
column2: and I hope the next administration--I believe they believe--that the key to success in this effort is jobs. It is work for people who want to work.

column1: In the budget for fiscal 1970
column2: I shall recommend a total of $3.5 billion for our job training program
column3: and that is five times as much as we spent in 1964 trying to prepare Americans where they can work to earn their own living.

column1: The Nation's commitment in the field of civil rights began with the Declaration of Independence. They were extended by the 13th
column2: 14th
column3: and 15th amendments. They have been powerfully strengthened by the enactment of three far-reaching civil rights laws within the past 5 years
column4: that this Congress
column5: in its wisdom
column6: passed.

column1: On January 1 of this year
column2: the Fair Housing Act of 1968 covered over 20 million American homes and apartments. The prohibition against racial discrimination in that act should be remembered and it should be vigorously enforced throughout this land.

column1: I believe we should also extend the vital provisions of the Voting Rights Act for another 5 years.
In the Safe Streets Act of 1968
column2: Congress determined "To assist state and local governments in reducing the incidence of crime."

column1: This year I am proposing that the Congress provide the full $300 million that the Congress last year authorized to do just that.
I hope the Congress will put the money where the authorization is.

I believe this is an essential contribution to justice and to public order in the United States. I hope these grants can be made to the States and they can be used effectively to reduce the crime rate in this country.

But all of this is only a small part of the total effort that must be made--I think chiefly by the local governments throughout the Nation--if we expect to reduce the toll of crime that we all detest.
Frankly
column2: as I leave the Office of the Presidency
column3: one of my greatest disappointments is our failure to secure passage of a licensing and registration act for firearms. I think if we had passed that act
column4: it would have reduced the incidence of crime. I believe that the Congress should adopt such a law
column5: and I hope that it will at a not too distant date.

column1: In order to meet our long-standing commitment to make government as efficient as possible
column2: I believe that we should reorganize our postal system along the lines of the Kappel1 report.

column1: I hope we can all agree that public service should never impose an unreasonable financial sacrifice on able men and women who want to serve their country.
I believe that the recommendations of the Commission on Executive
column2: Legislative and Judicial Salaries are generally sound. Later this week
column3: I shall submit a special message which I reviewed with the leadership this evening containing a proposal that has been reduced and has modified the Commission's recommendation to some extent on the congressional salaries.

column1: For Members of Congress
column2: I will recommend the basic compensation not of the $50
column3: 000 unanimously recommended by the Kappel Commission and the other distinguished Members
column4: but I shall reduce that $50
column6: 500. I will suggest that Congress appropriate a very small additional allowance for official expenses
column7: so that Members will not be required to use their salary increase for essential official business.

column1: I would have submitted the Commission's recommendations
column2: except the advice that I received from the leadership--and you usually are consulted about matters that affect the Congress--was that the Congress would not accept the $50
column3: 000 recommendation
column4: and if I expected my recommendation to be seriously considered
column5: I should make substantial reductions. That is the only reason I didn't go along with the Kappel report.

column1: In 1967 I recommended to the Congress a fair and impartial random selection system for the draft. I submit it again tonight for your most respectful consideration.

I know that all of us recognize that most of the things we do to meet all of these commitments I talk about will cost money. If we maintain the strong rate of growth that we have had in this country for the past 8 years
column2: I think we shall generate the resources that we need to meet these commitments.

column1: We have already been able to increase our support for major social programs--although we have heard a lot about not being able to do anything on the home front because of Vietnam; but we have been able in the last 5 years to increase our commitments for such things as health and education from $30 billion in 1964 to $68 billion in the coming fiscal year. That is more than double. That is more than it has ever been increased in the 188 years of this Republic
column2: notwithstanding Vietnam.

column1: We must continue to budget our resources and budget them responsibly in a way that will preserve our prosperity and will strengthen our dollar.
Greater revenues and the reduced Federal spending required by Congress last year have changed the budgetary picture dramatically since last January when we made our estimates. At that time
column2: you will remember that we estimated we would have a deficit of $8 billion. Well
column3: I am glad to report to you tonight that the fiscal year ending June 30
column5: this June
column6: we are going to have not a deficit
column7: but we are going to have a $2.4 billion surplus.

column1: You will receive the budget tomorrow. The budget for the next fiscal year
column2: that begins July 1--which you will want to examine very carefully in the days ahead--will provide a $3.4 billion surplus.

column1: This budget anticipates the extension of the surtax that Congress enacted last year. I have communicated with the President-elect
column2: Mr. Nixon
column3: in connection with this policy of continuing the surtax for the time being.

column1: I want to tell you that both of us want to see it removed just as soon as circumstances will permit
column2: but the President-elect has told me that he has concluded that until his administration
column3: and this Congress
column4: can examine the appropriation bills
column5: and each item in the budget
column6: and can ascertain that the facts justify permitting the surtax to expire or to be reduced
column7: he
column8: Mr. Nixon
column9: will support my recommendation that the surtax be continued.

column1: Americans
column2: I believe
column3: are united in the hope that the Paris talks will bring an early peace to Vietnam. And if our hopes for an early settlement of the war are realized
column4: then our military expenditures can be reduced and very substantial savings can be made to be used for other desirable purposes
column5: as the Congress may determine.

column1: In any event
column2: I think it is imperative that we do all that we responsibly can to resist inflation while maintaining our prosperity. I think all Americans know that our prosperity is broad and it is deep
column3: and it has brought record profits
column4: the highest in our history
column5: and record wages.

column1: Our gross national product has grown more in the last 5 years than any other period in our Nation's history. Our wages have been the highest. Our profits have been the best. This prosperity has enabled millions to escape the poverty that they would have otherwise had the last few years.
I think also you will be very glad to hear that the Secretary of the Treasury informs me tonight that in 1968 in our balance of payments we have achieved a surplus. It appears that we have
column2: in fact
column3: done better this year than we have done in any year in this regard since the year 1957.

column1: The quest for a durable peace
column2: I think
column3: has absorbed every administration since the end of World War II. It has required us to seek a limitation of arms races not only among the superpowers
column4: but among the smaller nations as well. We have joined in the test ban treaty of 1963
column5: the outer space treaty of 1967
column6: and the treaty against the spread of nuclear weapons in 1968.

column1: This latter agreement--the nonproliferation treaty--is now pending in the Senate and it has been pending there since last July. In my opinion
column2: delay in ratifying it is not going to be helpful to the cause of peace. America took the lead in negotiating this treaty and America should now take steps to have it approved at the earliest possible date.

column1: Until a way can be found to scale down the level of arms among the superpowers
column2: mankind cannot view the future without fear and great apprehension. So
column3: I believe that we should resume the talks with the Soviet Union about limiting offensive and defensive missile systems. I think they would already have been resumed except for Czechoslovakia and our election this year.

column1: It was more than 20 years ago that we embarked on a program of trying to aid the developing nations. We knew then that we could not live in good conscience as a rich enclave on an earth that was seething in misery.
During these years there have been great advances made under our program
column2: particularly against want and hunger
column3: although we are disappointed at the appropriations last year. We thought they were woefully inadequate. This year I am asking for adequate funds for economic assistance in the hope that we can further peace throughout the world.

column1: I think we must continue to support efforts in regional cooperation. Among those efforts
column2: that of Western Europe has a very special place in America's concern.

column1: The only course that is going to permit Europe to play the great world role that its resources permit is to go forward to unity. I think America remains ready to work with a united Europe
column2: to work as a partner on the basis of equality.

column1: For the future
column2: the quest for peace
column3: I believe
column4: requires:

column1: --that we maintain the liberal trade policies that have helped us become the leading nation in world trade
--that we strengthen the international monetary system as an instrument of world prosperity
column2: and

column1: --that we seek areas of agreement with the Soviet Union where the interests of both nations and the interests of world peace are properly served.

The strained relationship between us and the world's leading Communist power has not ended--especially in the light of the brutal invasion of Czechoslovakia. But totalitarianism is no less odious to us because we are able to reach some accommodation that reduces the danger of world catastrophe.
What we do
column2: we do in the interest of peace in the world. We earnestly hope that time will bring a Russia that is less afraid of diversity and individual freedom.

column1: The quest for peace tonight continues in Vietnam
column2: and in the Paris talks.

column1: I regret more than any of you know that it has not been possible to restore peace to South Vietnam.
The prospects
column2: I think
column3: for peace are better today than at any time since North Vietnam began its invasion with its regular forces more than 4 years ago.

column1: The free nations of Asia know what they were not sure of at that time: that America cares about their freedom
column2: and it also cares about America's own vital interests in Asia and throughout the Pacific.

column1: The North Vietnamese know that they cannot achieve their aggressive purposes by force. There may be hard fighting before a settlement is reached; but
column2: I can assure you
column3: it will yield no victory to the Communist cause.

column1: I cannot speak to you tonight about Vietnam without paying a very personal tribute to the men who have carried the battle out there for all of us. I have been honored to be their Commander in Chief. The Nation owes them its unstinting support while the battle continues--and its enduring gratitude when their service is done.
Finally
column2: the quest for stable peace in the Middle East goes on in many capitals tonight. America fully supports the unanimous resolution of the U.N. Security Council which points the way.

column1: There must be a settlement of the armed hostility that exists in that region of the world today. It is a threat not only to Israel and to all the Arab States
column2: but it is a threat to every one of us and to the entire world as well.

column1: Now
column2: my friends in Congress
column3: I want to conclude with a few very personal words to you.

column1: I rejected and rejected and then finally accepted the congressional leadership's invitation to come here to speak this farewell to you in person tonight.
I did that for two reasons. One was philosophical. I wanted to give you my judgment
column2: as I saw it
column3: on some of the issues before our Nation
column4: as I view them
column5: before I leave.

column1: The other was just pure sentimental. Most all of my life as a public official has been spent here in this building. For 38 years--since I worked on that gallery as a doorkeeper in the House of Representatives--I have known these halls
column2: and I have known most of the men pretty well who walked them.

column1: I know the questions that you face. I know the conflicts that you endure. I know the ideals that you seek to serve.
I left here first to become Vice President
column2: and then to become
column3: in a moment of tragedy
column4: the President of the United States.

column1: My term of office has been marked by a series of challenges
column2: both at home and throughout the world.

column1: In meeting some of these challenges
column2: the Nation has found a new confidence. In meeting others
column3: it knew turbulence and doubt
column4: and fear and hate.

column1: Throughout this time
column2: I have been sustained by my faith in representative democracy--a faith that I had learned here in this Capitol Building as an employee and as a Congressman and as a Senator.

column1: I believe deeply in the ultimate purposes of this Nation--described by the Constitution
column2: tempered by history
column3: embodied in progressive laws
column4: and given life by men and women that have been elected to serve their fellow citizens.

column1: Now for 5 most demanding years in the White House
column2: I have been strengthened by the counsel and the cooperation of two great former Presidents
column3: Harry S. Truman and Dwight David Eisenhower. I have been guided by the memory of my pleasant and close association with the beloved John F. Kennedy
column4: and with our greatest modern legislator
column5: Speaker Sam Rayburn.

column1: I have been assisted by my friend every step of the way
column2: Vice President Hubert Humphrey. I am so grateful that I have been supported daily by the loyalty of Speaker McCormack and Majority Leader Albert.

column1: I have benefited from the wisdom of Senator Mike Mansfield
column2: and I am sure that I have avoided many dangerous pitfalls by the good commonsense counsel of the President Pro Tem of the Senate
column3: Senator Richard Brevard Russell.

column1: I have received the most generous cooperation from the leaders of the Republican Party in the Congress of the United States
column2: Senator Dirksen and Congressman Gerald Ford
column3: the Minority Leader.

column1: No President should ask for more
column2: although I did upon occasions. But few Presidents have ever been blessed with so much.

column1: President-elect Nixon
column2: in the days ahead
column3: is going to need your understanding
column4: just as I did. And he is entitled to have it. I hope every Member will remember that the burdens he will bear as our President
column5: will be borne for all of us. Each of us should try not to increase these burdens for the sake of narrow personal or partisan advantage.

column1: Now
column2: it is time to leave. I hope it may be said
column3: a hundred years from now
column4: that by working together we helped to make our country more just
column5: more just for all of its people
column6: as well as to insure and guarantee the blessings of liberty for all of our posterity.

column1: That is what I hope. But I believe that at least it will be said that we tried.@
Richard M. Nixon|Annual Message to the Congress on the State of the Union|1970-01-22|@Mr. Speaker
column2: Mr. President
column3: my colleagues in the Congress
column4: our distinguished guests and my fellow Americans:

column1: To address a joint session of the Congress in this great Chamber in which I was once privileged to serve is an honor for which I am deeply grateful.
The State of the Union Address is traditionally an occasion for a lengthy and detailed account by the President of what he has accomplished in the past
column2: what he wants the Congress to do in the future
column3: and
column4: in an election year
column5: to lay the basis for the political issues which might be decisive in the fall.

column1: Occasionally there comes a time when profound and far-reaching events command a break with tradition.
This is such a time.

I say this not only because 1970 marks the beginning of a new decade in which America will celebrate its 200th birthday. I say it because new knowledge and hard experience argue persuasively that both our programs and our institutions in America need to be reformed.
The moment has arrived to harness the vast energies and abundance of this land to the creation of a new American experience
column2: an experience richer and deeper and more truly a reflection of the goodness and grace of the human spirit.

column1: The seventies will be a time of new beginnings
column2: a time of exploring both on the earth and in the heavens
column3: a time of discovery. But the time has also come for emphasis on developing better ways of managing what we have and of completing what man's genius has begun but left unfinished.

column1: Our land
column2: this land that is ours together
column3: is a great and a good land. It is also an unfinished land
column4: and the challenge of perfecting it is the summons of the seventies.

column1: It is in that spirit that I address myself to those great issues facing our Nation which are above partisanship.
When we speak of America's priorities the first priority must always be peace for America and the world.
The major immediate goal of our foreign policy is to bring an end to the war in Vietnam in a way that our generation will be remembered not so much as the generation that suffered in war
column2: but more for the fact that we had the courage and character to win the kind of a just peace that the next generation was able to keep.

column1: We are making progress toward that goal.
The prospects for peace are far greater today than they were a year ago.
A major part of the credit for this development goes to the Members of this Congress who
column2: despite their differences on the conduct of the war
column3: have overwhelmingly indicated their support of a just peace. By this action
column4: you have completely demolished the enemy's hopes that they can gain in Washington the victory our fighting men have denied them in Vietnam.

column1: No goal could be greater than to make the next generation the first in this century in which America was at peace with every nation in the world.
I shall discuss in detail the new concepts and programs designed to achieve this goal in a separate report on foreign policy
column2: which I shall submit to the Congress at a later date.

column1: Today
column2: let me describe the directions of our new policies.

column1: We have based our policies on an evaluation of the world as it is
column2: not as it was 25 years ago at the conclusion of World War II. Many of the policies which were necessary and right then are obsolete today.

column1: Then
column2: because of America's overwhelming military and economic strength
column3: because of the weakness of other major free world powers and the inability of scores of newly independent nations to defend
column4: or even govern
column5: themselves
column6: America had to assume the major burden for the defense of freedom in the world.

column1: In two wars
column2: first in Korea and now in Vietnam
column3: we furnished most of the money
column4: most of the arms
column5: most of the men to help other nations defend their freedom.

column1: Today the treat industrial nations of Europe
column2: as well as Japan
column3: have regained their economic strength; and the nations of Latin America and many of the nations who acquired their freedom from colonialism after World War II in Asia and Africa have a new sense of pride and dignity and a determination to assume the responsibility for their own defense.

column1: That is the basis of the doctrine I announced at Guam. 1
Neither the defense nor the development of other nations can be exclusively or primarily an American undertaking.
The nations of each part of the world should assume the primary responsibility for their own well-being; and they themselves should determine the terms of that well-being.
We shall be faithful to our treaty commitments
column2: but we shall reduce our involvement and our presence in other nations' affairs.

column1: To insist that other nations play a role is not a retreat from responsibility; it is a sharing of responsibility.
The result of this new policy has been not to weaken our alliances
column2: but to give them new life
column3: new strength
column4: a new sense of common purpose.

column1: Relations with our European allies are once again strong and healthy
column2: based on mutual consultation and mutual responsibility.

column1: We have initiated a new approach to Latin America in which we deal with those nations as partners rather than patrons.
The new partnership concept has been welcomed in Asia. We have developed a historic new basis for Japanese-American friendship and cooperation
column2: which is the linchpin for peace in the Pacific.

column1: If we are to have peace in the last third of the century
column2: a major factor will be the development of a new relationship between the United States and the Soviet Union.

column1: I would not underestimate our differences
column2: but we are moving with precision and purpose from an era of confrontation to an era of negotiation.

column1: Our negotiations on strategic arms limitations and in other areas will have far greater chance for success if both sides enter them motivated by mutual self-interest rather than na?ve sentimentality.
It is with this same spirit that we have resumed discussions with Communist China in our talks at Warsaw.
Our concern in our relations with both these nations is to avoid a catastrophic collision and to build a solid basis for peaceful settlement of our differences.
I would be the last to suggest that the road to peace is not difficult and dangerous
column2: but I believe our new policies have contributed to the prospect that America may have the best chance since World War II to enjoy a generation of uninterrupted peace. And that chance will be enormously increased if we continue to have a relationship between Congress and the Executive in which
column3: despite differences in detail
column4: where the security of America and the peace of mankind are concerned
column5: we act not as Republicans
column6: not as Democrats
column7: but as Americans.

column1: As we move into the decade of the seventies
column2: we have the greatest opportunity for progress at home of any people in world history.

column1: Our gross national product will increase by $500 billion in the next 10 years. This increase alone is greater than the entire growth of the American economy from 1790 to 1950.
The critical question is not whether we will grow
column2: but how we will use that growth.

column1: The decade of the sixties was also a period of great growth economically. But in that same 10-year period we witnessed the greatest growth of crime
column2: the greatest increase in inflation
column3: the greatest social unrest in America in 100 years. Never has a nation seemed to have had more and enjoyed it less.

column1: At heart
column2: the issue is the effectiveness of government.

column1: Ours has become as it continues to be
column2: and should remain a society of large expectations. Government helped to generate these expectations. It undertook to meet them. Yet
column3: increasingly
column4: it proved unable to do so.

column1: As a people
column2: we had too many visions and too little vision.

column1: Now
column2: as we enter the seventies
column3: we should enter also a great age of reform of the institutions of American government.

column1: Our purpose in this period should not be simply better management of the programs of the past. The time has come for a new quest a quest not for a greater quantity of what we have
column2: but for a new quality of life in America.

column1: A major part of the substance for an unprecedented advance in this Nation's approach to its problems and opportunities is contained in more than two score legislative proposals which I sent to the Congress last year and which still await enactment.
I will offer at least a dozen more major programs in the course of this session.
At this point I do not intend to go through a detailed listing of what I have proposed or will propose
column2: but I would like to mention three areas in which urgent priorities demand that we move and move now:

column1: First
column2: we cannot delay longer in accomplishing a total reform of our welfare system. When a system penalizes work
column3: breaks up homes
column4: robs recipients of dignity
column5: there is no alternative to abolishing that system and adopting in its place the program of income support
column6: job training
column7: and work incentives which I recommended to the Congress last year.

column1: Second
column2: the time has come to assess and reform all of our institutions of government at the Federal
column3: State
column4: and local level. It is time for a New Federalism
column5: in which
column6: after 190 years of power flowing from the people and local and State governments to Washington
column7: D.C.
column8: it will begin to flow from Washington back to the States and to the people of the United States.

column1: Third
column2: we must adopt reforms which will expand the range of opportunities for all Americans. We can fulfill the American dream only when each person has a fair chance to fulfill his own dreams. This means equal voting rights
column3: equal employment opportunity
column4: and new opportunities for expanded ownership. Because in order to be secure in their human rights
column5: people need access to property rights.

column1: I could give similar examples of the need for reform in our programs for health
column2: education
column3: housing
column4: transportation
column5: as well as other critical areas which directly affect the well-being of millions of Americans.

column1: The people of the United States should wait no longer for these reforms that would so deeply enhance the quality of their life.
When I speak of actions which would be beneficial to the American people
column2: I can think of none more important than for the Congress to join this administration in the battle to stop the rise in the cost of living.

column1: Now
column2: I realize it is tempting to blame someone else for inflation.

column1: Some blame business for raising prices.
Some blame unions for asking for more wages.
But a review of the stark fiscal facts of the 1960's clearly demonstrates where the primary blame for rising prices must be placed.
In the decade of the sixties the Federal Government spent $57 billion more than it took in in taxes.
In the same decade the American people paid the bill for that deficit in price increases which raised the cost of living for the average family of four by $200 per month in America.

Now millions of Americans are forced to go into debt today because the Federal Government decided to go into debt yesterday. We must balance our Federal budget so that American families will have a better chance to balance their family budgets.
Only with the cooperation of the Congress can we meet this highest priority objective of responsible government.
We are on the right track.
We had a balanced budget in 1969.
This administration cut more than $7 billion out of spending plans in order to produce a surplus in 1970
column2: and in spite of the fact that Congress reduced revenues by $ 3 billion
column3: I shall recommend a balanced budget for 1971.

column1: But I can assure that not only to present
column2: but to stay within
column3: a balanced budget requires some very hard decisions. It means rejecting spending programs which would benefit some of the people when their net effect would result in price increases for all the people.

column1: It is time to quit putting good money into bad programs. Otherwise
column2: we will end up with bad money and bad programs.

column1: I recognize the political popularity of spending programs
column2: and particularly in an election year. But unless we stop the rise in prices
column3: the cost of living for millions of American families will become unbearable and government's ability to plan programs for progress for the future will become impossible.

column1: In referring to budget cuts
column2: there is one area where I have ordered an increase rather than a cut and that is the requests of those agencies with the responsibilities for law enforcement.

column1: We have heard a great deal of overblown rhetoric during the sixties in which the word war has perhaps too often been used the war on poverty
column2: the war on misery
column3: the war on disease
column4: the war on hunger. But if there is one area where the word war  is appropriate it is in the fight against crime. We must declare and win the war against the criminal elements which increasingly threaten our cities
column5: our homes
column6: and our lives.

column1: We have a tragic example of this problem in the Nation's Capital
column2: for whose safety the Congress and the Executive have the primary responsibility. I doubt if many Members of this Congress who live more than a few blocks from here would dare leave their cars in the Capitol garage and walk home alone tonight.

column1: Last year this administration sent to the Congress 13 separate pieces of legislation dealing with organized crime
column2: pornography
column3: street crime
column4: narcotics
column5: crime in the District of Columbia.

column1: None of these bills has reached my desk for signature.
I am confident that the Congress will act now to adopt the legislation I placed before you last year. We in the Executive have done everything we can under existing law
column2: but new and stronger weapons are needed in that fight.

column1: While it is true that State and local law enforcement agencies are the cutting edge in the effort to eliminate street crime
column2: burglaries
column3: murder
column4: my proposals to you have embodied my belief that the Federal Government should play a greater role in working in partnership with these agencies.

column1: That is why 1971 Federal spending for local law enforcement will double that budgeted for 1970.
The primary responsibility for crimes that affect individuals is with local and State rather than with Federal Government. But in the field of organized crime
column2: narcotics
column3: pornography
column4: the Federal Government has a special responsibility it should fulfill. And we should make Washington
column5: D.C.
column6: where we have the primary responsibility
column7: an example to the Nation and the world of respect for law rather than lawlessness.

column1: I now turn to a subject which
column2: next to our desire for peace
column3: may well become the major concern of the American people in the decade of the seventies.

column1: In the next 10 years we shall increase our wealth by 50 percent. The profound question is: Does this mean we will be 50 percent richer in a real sense
column2: 50 percent better off
column3: 50 percent happier?

column1: Or does it mean that in the year 1980 the President standing in this place will look back on a decade in which 70 percent of our people lived in metropolitan areas chocked by traffic
column2: suffocated by smog
column3: poisoned by water
column4: deafened by noise
column5: and terrorized by crime?

column1: These are not the great questions that concern world leaders at summit conferences. But people do not live at the summit. They live in the foothills of everyday experience
column2: and it is time for all of us to concern ourselves with the way real people live in real life.

column1: The great question of the seventies is
column2: shall we surrender to our surroundings
column3: or shall we make our peace with nature and begin to make reparations for the damage we have done to our air
column4: to our land
column5: and to our water?

column1: Restoring nature to its natural state is a cause beyond party and beyond factions. It has become a common cause of all the people of this country. It is a cause of particular concern to young Americans
column2: because they more than we will reap the grim consequences of our failure to act on programs which are needed now if we are to prevent disaster later.

column1: Clean air
column2: clean water
column3: open spaces these should once again be the birthright of every American. If we act now
column4: they can be.

column1: We still think of air as free. But clean air is not free
column2: and neither is clean water. The price tag on pollution control is high. Through our years of past carelessness we incurred a debt to nature
column3: and now that debt is being called.

column1: The program I shall propose to Congress will be the most comprehensive and costly program in this field in America's history.
It is not a program for just one year. A year's plan in this field is no plan at all. This is a time to look ahead not a year
column2: but 5 years or 10 years whatever time is required to do the job.

column1: I shall propose to this Congress a $10 billion nationwide clean waters program to put modern municipal waste treatment plants in every place in America where they are needed to make our waters clean again
column2: and do it now. We have the industrial capacity
column3: if we begin now
column4: to build them all within 5 years. This program will get them built within 5 years.

column1: As our cities and suburbs relentlessly expand
column2: those priceless open spaces needed for recreation areas accessible to their people are swallowed up often forever. Unless we preserve these spaces while they are still available
column3: we will have none to preserve. Therefore
column4: I shall propose new financing methods for purchasing open space and parklands now
column5: before they are lost to us.

column1: The automobile is our worst polluter of the air. Adequate control requires further advances in engine design and fuel composition. We shall intensify our research
column2: set increasingly strict standards
column3: and strengthen enforcement procedures and we shall do it now.

column1: We can no longer afford to consider air and water common property
column2: free to be abused by anyone without regard to the consequences. Instead
column3: we should begin now to treat them as scarce resources
column4: which we are no more free to contaminate than we are free to throw garbage into our neighbor's yard.

column1: This requires comprehensive new regulations. It also requires that
column2: to the extent possible
column3: the price of goods should be made to include the costs of producing and disposing of them without damage to the environment.

column1: Now
column2: I realize that the argument is often made that there is a fundamental contradiction between economic growth and the quality of life
column3: so that to have one we must forsake the other.

column1: The answer is not to abandon growth
column2: but to redirect it. For example
column3: we should turn toward ending congestion and eliminating smog the same reservoir of inventive genius that created them in the first place.

column1: Continued vigorous economic growth provides us with the means to enrich life itself and to enhance our planet as a place hospitable to man.
Each individual must enlist in this fight if it is to be won.
It has been said that no matter how many national parks and historical monuments we buy and develop
column2: the truly significant environment for each of us is that in which we spend 80 percent of our time in our homes
column3: in our places of work
column4: the streets over which we travel.

column1: Street litter
column2: rundown parking strips and yards
column3: dilapidated fences
column4: broken windows
column5: smoking automobiles
column6: dingy working places
column7: all should be the object of our fresh view.

column1: We have been too tolerant of our surroundings and too willing to leave it to others to clean up our environment. It is time for those who make massive demands on society to make some minimal demands on themselves. Each of us must resolve that each day he will leave his home
column2: his property
column3: the public places of the city or town a little cleaner
column4: a little better
column5: a little more pleasant for himself and those around him.

column1: With the help of people we can do anything
column2: and without their help
column3: we can do nothing. In this spirit
column4: together
column5: we can reclaim our land for ours and generations to come.

column1: Between now and the year 2000
column2: over 100 million children will be born in the United States. Where they grow up and how will
column3: more than any one thing
column4: measure the quality of American life in these years ahead.

column1: This should be a warning to us.

For the past 30 years our population has also been growing and shifting. The result is exemplified in the vast areas of rural America emptying out of people and of promise a third of our countries lost population in the sixties.
The violent and decayed central cities of our great metropolitan complexes are the most conspicuous area of failure in American life today.
I propose that before these problems become insoluble
column2: the Nation develop a national growth policy.

column1: In the future
column2: government decisions as to where to build highways
column3: locate airports
column4: acquire land
column5: or sell land should be made with a clear objective of aiding a balanced growth for America.

column1: In particular
column2: the Federal Government must be in a position to assist in the building of new cities and the rebuilding of old ones.

column1: At the same time
column2: we will carry our concern with the quality of life in America to the farm as well as the suburb
column3: to the village as well as to the city. What rural America needs most is a new kind of assistance. It needs to be dealt with
column4: not as a separate nation
column5: but as part of an overall growth policy for America. We must create a new rural environment which will not only stem the migration to urban centers
column6: but reverse it. If we seize our growth as a challenge
column7: we can make the 1970's a historic period when by conscious choice we transformed our land into what we want it to become.

column1: America
column2: which has pioneered in the new abundance
column3: and in the new technology
column4: is called upon today to pioneer in meeting the concerns which have followed in their wake in turning the wonders of science to the service of man.

column1: In the majesty of this great Chamber we hear the echoes of America's history
column2: of debates that rocked the Union and those that repaired it
column3: of the summons to war and the search for peace
column4: of the uniting of the people
column5: the building of a nation.

column1: Those echoes of history remind us of our roots and our strengths.
They remind us also of that special genius of American democracy
column2: which at one critical turning point after another has led us to spot the new road to the future and given us the wisdom and the courage to take it.

column1: As I look down that new road which I have tried to map out today
column2: I see a new America as we celebrate our 200th anniversary 6 years from now.

column1: I see an America in which we have abolished hunger
column2: provided the means for every family in the Nation to obtain a minimum income
column3: made enormous progress in providing better housing
column4: faster transportation
column5: improved health
column6: and superior education.

column1: I see an America in which we have checked inflation
column2: and waged a winning war against crime.

column1: I see an America in which we have made great strides in stopping the pollution of our air
column2: cleaning up our water
column3: opening up our parks
column4: continuing to explore in space.

column1: Most important
column2: I see an America at peace with all the nations of the world.

column1: This is not an impossible dream. These goals are all within our reach.
In times past
column2: our forefathers had the vision but not the means to achieve such goals.

column1: Let it not be recorded that we were the first American generation that had the means but not the vision to make this dream come true.
But let us
column2: above all
column3: recognize a fundamental truth. We can be the best clothed
column4: best fed
column5: best housed people in the world
column6: enjoying clean air
column7: clean water
column8: beautiful parks
column9: but we could still be the unhappiest people in the world without an indefinable spirit the lift of a driving dream which has made America
column10: from its beginning
column11: the hope of the world.

column1: Two hundred years ago this was a new nation of 3 million people
column2: weak militarily
column3: poor economically. But America meant something to the world then which could not be measured in dollars
column4: something far more important than military might.

column1: Listen to President Thomas Jefferson in 1802: We act not for ourselves along
column2: but for the whole human race.

column1: We had a spiritual quality then which caught the imagination of millions of people in the world.
Today
column2: when we are the richest and strongest nation in the world
column3: let it not be recorded that we lack the moral and spiritual idealism which made us the hope of the world at the time of our birth.

column1: The demands of us in 1976 are even greater than in 1776.
It is no longer enough to live and let live. Now we must live and help live.
We need a fresh climate in America
column2: one in which a person can breathe freely and breathe in freedom.

column1: Our recognition of the truth that wealth and happiness are not the same thing requires us to measure success or failure by new criteria.
Even more than the programs I have described today
column2: what this Nation needs is an example from its elected leaders in providing the spiritual and moral leadership which no programs for material progress can satisfy.

column1: Above all
column2: let us inspire young Americans with a sense of excitement
column3: a sense of destiny
column4: a sense of involvement
column5: in meeting the challenges we face in this great period of our history. Only then are they going to have any sense of satisfaction in their lives.

column1: The greatest privilege an individual can have is to serve in a cause bigger than himself. We have such a cause.
How we seize the opportunities I have described today will determine not only our future
column2: but the future of peace and freedom in this world in the last third of the century.

column1: May God give us the wisdom
column2: the strength and
column3: above all
column4: the idealism to be worthy of that challenge
column5: so that America can fulfill its destiny of being the world's best hope for liberty
column6: for opportunity
column7: for progress and peace for all peoples.@

column1: Richard M. Nixon|Annual Message to the Congress on the State of the Union|1971-01-22|@Mr. Speaker
column2: Mr. President
column3: my colleagues in the Congress
column4: our distinguished guests
column5: my fellow Americans:

column1: As this 92d Congress begins its session
column2: America has lost a great Senator
column3: and all of us who had the privilege to know him have lost a loyal friend. I had the privilege of visiting Senator Russell in the hospital just a few days before he died. He never spoke about himself. He only spoke eloquently about the need for a strong national defense.

column1: In tribute to one of the most magnificent Americans of all time
column2: I respectfully ask that all those here will rise in silent prayer for Senator Russell.

column1: Thank you.
Mr. Speaker
column2: before I begin my formal address
column3: I want to use this opportunity to congratulate all of those who were winners in the rather spirited contest for leadership positions in the House and the Senate and
column4: also
column5: to express my condolences to the losers. I know how both of you feel.

column1: And I particularly want to join with all of the Members of the House and the Senate as well in congratulating the new Speaker of the United States Congress.
To those new Members of this House who may have some doubts about the possibilities for advancement in the years ahead
column2: I would remind you that the Speaker and I met just 24 years ago in this Chamber as freshmen Members of the 80th Congress. As you see
column3: we both have come up in the world a bit since then.

column1: Mr. Speaker
column2: this 92d Congress has a chance to be recorded as the greatest Congress in America's history.

column1: In these troubled years just past
column2: America has been going through a long nightmare of war and division
column3: of crime and inflation. Even more deeply
column4: we have gone through a long
column5: dark night of the American spirit. But now that night is ending. Now we must let our spirits soar again. Now we are ready for the lift of a driving dream.

column1: The people of this Nation are eager to get on with the quest for new greatness. They see challenges
column2: and they are prepared to meet those challenges. It is for us here to open the doors that will set free again the real greatness of this Nation the genius of the American people.

column1: How shall we meet this challenge? How can we truly open the doors
column2: and set free the full genius of our people?

column1: The way in which the 92d Congress answers these questions will determine its place in history. More importantly
column2: it can determine this Nation's place in history as we enter the third century of our independence.

column1: Tonight I shall present to the Congress six great goals. I shall ask not simply for more new programs in the old framework. I shall ask to change the framework of government itself to reform the entire structure of American government so we can make it again fully responsive to the needs and the wishes of the American people.

If we act boldly if we size this moment and achieve these goals we can close the gap between promise and performance in American government. We can bring together the resources of this Nation and the spirit of the American people.
In discussing these great goals
column2: I shall deal tonight only with matters on the domestic side of the Nation's agenda. I shall make a separate report to the Congress and the Nation next month on developments in foreign policy.

column1: The first of these great goals is already before the Congress.
I urge that the unfinished business of the 91st Congress be made the first priority business of the 92d Congress.
Over the next 2 weeks
column2: I will call upon Congress to take action on more than 35 pieces of proposed legislation on which action was not completed last year.

column1: The most important is welfare reform.
The present welfare system has become a monstrous
column2: consuming outrage an outrage against the community
column3: against the taxpayer
column4: and particularly against the children it is supposed to help.

column1: We may honestly disagree
column2: as we do
column3: on what to do about it. But we can all agree that we must meet the challenge
column4: not by pouring more money into a bad program
column5: but by abolishing the present welfare system and adopting a new one.

column1: So let us place a floor under the income of every family with children in America and without those demeaning
column2: soul-stifling affronts to human dignity that so blight the lives of welfare children today.

column1: But let us also establish an effective work incentive and an effective work requirement.
Let us provide the means by which more can help themselves. This shall be our goal.
Let us generously help those who are not able to help themselves. But let us stop helping those who are able to help themselves but refuse to do so.
The second great goal is to achieve what Americans have not enjoyed since 1957 full prosperity in peacetime.
The tide of inflation has turned. The rise in the cost of living
column2: which had been gathering dangerous momentum in the late sixties
column3: was reduced last year. Inflation will be further reduced this year.

column1: But as we have moved from runaway inflation toward reasonable price stability and at the same time as we have been moving from a wartime economy to a peacetime economy
column2: we have paid a price in increased unemployment.

column1: We should take no comfort from the fact that the level of unemployment in this transition from a wartime to a peacetime economy is lower than in any peacetime year of the sixties.
This is not good enough for the man who is unemployed in the seventies. We must do better for workers in peacetime and we will do better.
To achieve this
column2: I will admit an expansionary budget this year one that will help stimulate the economy and thereby open up new job opportunities for millions of Americans.

column1: It will be a full employment budget
column2: a budget designed to be in balance if the economy were operating at its peak potential. By spending as if we were at full employment
column3: we will help to bring about full employment.

column1: I ask the Congress to accept these expansionary policies to accept the concept of a full employment budget. At the same time
column2: I ask the Congress to cooperate in resisting expenditures that go beyond the limits of the full employment budget. For as we wage a campaign to bring about a widely shared prosperity
column3: we must not reignite the fires of inflation and so undermine that prosperity.

column1: With the stimulus and the discipline of a full employment budget
column2: with the commitment of the independent Federal Reserve System to provide fully for the monetary needs of a growing economy
column3: and with a much greater effort on the part of labor and management to make their wage and price decisions in the light of the national interest and their own self-interest then for the worker
column4: the farmer
column5: the consumer
column6: for Americans everywhere we shall gain the goal of a new prosperity: more jobs
column7: more income
column8: more profits
column9: without inflation and without war.

column1: This is a great goal
column2: and once that we can achieve together.

column1: The third great goal is to continue the effort so dramatically begun last year: to restore and enhance our natural environment.
Building on the foundation laid in the 37-point program that I submitted to Congress last year
column2: I will propose a strong new set of initiatives to clean up our air and water
column3: to combat noise
column4: and to preserve and restore our surroundings.

column1: I will propose programs to make better use of our land
column2: to encourage a balanced national growth growth that will revitalize our rural heartland and enhance the quality of life in America.

column1: And not only to meet today's needs but to anticipate those of tomorrow
column2: I will put forward the most extensive program ever proposed by a President of the United States to expand the Nation's parks
column3: recreation areas
column4: open spaces
column5: in a way that truly brings parks to the people where the people are. For only if we leave a legacy of parks will the next generation have parks to enjoy.

column1: As a fourth great goal
column2: I will offer a far-reaching set of proposals for improving America's health care and making it available more fairly to more people.

column1: I will propose:
--A Program to insure that no American family will be prevented from obtaining basic medical care by inability to pay.
--I will propose a major increase in and redirection of aid to medical schools
column2: to greatly increase the number of doctors and other health personnel.

column1: --Incentives to improve the delivery of health services
column2: to get more medical care resources into those areas that have not been adequately served
column3: to make greater use of medical assistants
column4: and to slow the alarming rise in the costs of medical care.

column1: --New programs to encourage better preventive medicine
column2: by attacking the causes of disease and injury
column3: and by providing incentives to doctors to keep people well rather than just to treat them when they are sick.

column1: I will also ask for an appropriation of an extra $100 million to launch an intensive campaign to find a cure for cancer
column2: and I will ask later for whatever additional funds can effectively be used. The time has come in America when the same kind of concentrated effort that split the atom and took man to the moon should be turned toward conquering this dread disease. Let us make a total national commitment to achieve this goal.

column1: America has long been the wealthiest nation in the world. Now it is time we became the healthiest nation in the world.
The fifth great goal is to strengthen and to renew our State and local governments.
As we approach our 200th anniversary in 1976
column2: we remember that this Nation launched itself as a loose confederation of separate States
column3: without a workable central government. At that time
column4: the mark of its leaders' vision was that they quickly saw the need to balance the separate powers of the States with a government of central powers.

column1: And so they gave us a constitution of balanced powers
column2: of unity with diversity and so clear was their vision that it survives today as the oldest written constitution still in force in the world.

column1: For almost two centuries since and dramatically in the 1990's at those great turning points when the question has been between the States and the Federal Government
column2: that question has been resolved in favor of a stronger central Federal Government.

column1: During this time the Nation grew and the Nation prospered. But one thing history tells us is that no great movement goes in the same direction forever. Nations change
column2: they adapt
column3: or they slowly die.

column1: The time has now come in America to reverse the flow of power and resources from the States and communities to Washington
column2: and start power and resources flowing back from Washington to the States and communities and
column3: more important
column4: to the people all across America.

column1: The time has come for a new partnership between the Federal Government and the States and localities a partnership in which we entrust the States and localities with a large share of the Nation's responsibilities
column2: and in which we share our Federal revenues with them so that they can meet those responsibilities.

column1: To achieve this goal
column2: I propose to the Congress tonight that we enact a plan of revenue sharing historic in scope and bold in concept.

column1: All across America today
column2: States and cities are confronted with a financial crisis. Some have already been cutting back on essential services for example
column3: just recently San Diego and Cleveland cut back on trash collections. Most are caught between the prospects of bankruptcy on the one hand and adding to an already crushing tax burden on the other.

column1: As one indication of the rising costs of local government
column2: I discovered the other day that my home town of Whittier
column3: California which has a population of 67
column4: 000 has a larger budget for 1971 than the entire Federal budget was in 1791.

column1: Now the time has come to take a new direction
column2: and once again to introduce a new and more creative balance to our approach to government.

column1: So let us put the money where the needs are. And let us put the power to spend it where the people are.

I propose that the Congress make a $16 billion investment in renewing State and local government. Five billion dollars of this will be in new and unrestricted funds to be used as the States and localities see fit. The other $11 billion will be provided by allocating $1 billion of new funds and converting one-third of the money going to the present narrow-purpose aid programs into Federal revenue sharing funds for six broad purposes for urban development
column2: rural development
column3: education
column4: transportation
column5: job training
column6: and law enforcement but with the States and localities making their own decisions on how it should be spent within each category.

column1: For the next fiscal year
column2: this would increase total Federal aid to the States and localities more than 25 percent over the present level.

column1: The revenue sharing proposals I send to the Congress will include the safeguards against discrimination that accompany all other Federal funds allocated to the States. Neither the President nor the Congress nor the conscience of this Nation can permit money which comes from all the people to be used in a way which discriminates against some of the people.

The Federal Government will still have a large and vital role to play in achieving our national progress. Established functions that are clearly and essentially Federal in nature will still be performed by the Federal Government. New functions that need to be sponsored or performed by the Federal government such as those I have urged tonight in welfare and health will be added to the Federal agenda. Whenever it makes the best sense for us to act as a whole nation
column2: the Federal Government should and will lead the way. But where States or local governments can better do what needs to be done
column3: let us see that they have the resources to do it there.

column1: Under this plan
column2: the Federal Government will provide the States and localities with more money and less interference and by cutting down the interference the same amount of money will go a lot further.

column1: Let us share our resources.
Let us share them to rescue the States and localities from the brink of financial crisis.
Let us share them to give homeowners and wage earners a chance to escape from ever-higher property taxes and sales taxes.
Let us share our resources for two other reasons as well.
The first of these reasons has to do with government itself
column2: and the second has to do with each of us
column3: with the individual.

column1: Let's face it. Most Americans today are simply fed up with government at all levels. They will not and they should not continue to tolerate the gap between promise and performance in government.
The fact is that we have made the Federal Government so strong it grows musclebound and the States and localities so weak they approach impotence.
If we put more power in more places
column2: we can make government more creative in more places. That way we multiply the number of people with the ability to make things happen and we can open the way to a new burst of creative energy throughout America.

column1: The final reason I urge this historic shift is much more personal
column2: for each and for every one of us.

column1: As everything seems to have grown bigger and more complex in America
column2: as the forces that shape our lives seem to have grown more distant and more impersonal
column3: a great feeling of frustration has crept across this land.

column1: Whether it is the workingman who feels neglected
column2: the black man who feels oppressed
column3: or the mother concerned about her children
column4: there has been a growing feeling the Things are in the saddle
column5: and ride mankind.

column1: Millions of frustrated young Americans today are crying out asking not what will government do for me
column2: but what can I do
column3: how can I contribute
column4: how can I matter?

column1: And so let us answer them. Let us say to them and let us say to all Americans
column2: We hear you. We will give you a chance. We are going to give you a new chance to have more to say about the decisions that affect your future a chance to participate in government because we are going to provide more centers of power where what you do can make a difference that you can see and feel in your own life and the life of your whole community.

column1: The further away government is from people
column2: the stronger government becomes and the weaker people become. And a nation with a strong government and a weak people is an empty shell.

column1: I reject the patronizing idea that government in Washington
column2: D.C.
column3: is inevitably more wise
column4: more honest
column5: and more efficient than government at the local or State level. The honesty and efficiency of government depends on people. Government at all level has good people and bad people. And the way to get more good people into government is to give them more opportunity to do good things.

column1: The idea that a bureaucratic elite in Washington knows best what is best for people everywhere and that you cannot trust local governments is really a contention that you cannot trust people to govern themselves. This notion is completely foreign to the American experience. Local government is the government closest to the people
column2: it is most responsive to the individual person. It is people's government in a far more intimate way than the Government in Washington can ever be.

column1: People came to America because they wanted to determine their own future rather than to live in a country where others determined their future for them.
more people a chance to do something
column2: we can have government that truly is by the people.

column1: And by setting up a completely modern
column2: functional system of government at the national level
column3: we in Washington will at last be able to provide government that is truly for the people.

column1: I realize that what I am asking is that not only the executive branch in Washington but that even this Congress will have to change by giving up some of its power.
Change is hard. But without change there can be no progress. And for each of us the question then becomes
column2: not Will change cause me inconvenience?  but Will change bring progress for America?

column1: Giving up power is hard. But I would urge all of you
column2: as leaders of this country
column3: to remember that the truly revered leaders in world history are those who gave power to people
column4: and not those who took it away.

column1: As we consider these reforms we will be acting
column2: not for the next 2 years or for the next 10 years
column3: but for the next 100 years.

column1: So let us approach these six great goals with a sense not only of this moment in history but also of history itself.
Let us act with the willingness to work together and the vision and the boldness and the courage of those great Americans who met in Philadelphia almost190 years ago to write a constitution.

Let us leave a heritage as they did not just for our children but for millions yet unborn of a nation where every American will have a chance not only to live in peace and to enjoy prosperity and opportunity but to participate in a system of government where he knows not only his votes but his ideas count a system of government which will provide the means for America to reach heights of achievement undreamed of before.
Those men who met at Philadelphia left a great heritage because they had a vision not only of what the Nation was but of what it could become.
As I think of that vision
column2: I recall that America was founded as the land of the open door as a haven for the oppressed
column3: a land of opportunity
column4: a place of refuge
column5: of hope.

column1: When the first settlers opened the door of America three and a half centuries ago
column2: they came to escape persecution and to find opportunity and they left wide the door of welcome for others to follow.

column1: When the Thirteen Colonies declared their independence almost two centuries ago
column2: they opened the door to a new vision of liberty and of human fulfillment not just for an elite but for all.

column1: To the generations that followed
column2: America's was the open door that beckoned millions from the old world to the new in search of a better life
column3: a freer life
column4: a fuller life
column5: and in which
column6: but their own decisions
column7: they could shape their own destinies.

column1: For the black American
column2: the Indian
column3: the Mexican-American
column4: and for those others in our land who have not had an equal chance
column5: the Nation at last has begun to confront the need to press open the door of full and equal opportunity
column6: and of human dignity.

column1: For all Americans
column2: with these changes I have proposed tonight we can open the door to a new era of opportunity. We can open the door to full and effective participation in the decisions that affect their lives. We can open the door to a new partnership among governments at all levels
column3: between those governments and the people themselves. And by so doing
column4: we can open wide the doors of human fulfillment for millions of people here in America now and in the years to come.

column1: In the next few weeks I will spell out in greater detail the way I propose that we achieve these six great goals. I ask this Congress to be responsive. If it is
column2: then the 92d Congress
column3: your Congress
column4: our Congress
column5: at the end of its term
column6: will be able to look back on a record more splendid than any in our history.

column1: This can be the Congress that helped us end the longest war in the Nation's history
column2: and end it in a way that will give us at last a genuine chance to enjoy what we have not had in this century: a full generation of peace.

column1: This can be the Congress that helped achieve an expanding economy
column2: with full employment and without inflation and without the deadly stimulus of war.

column1: This can be the Congress that reformed a welfare system that has robbed recipients of their dignity and robbed States and cities of their resources.
This can be the Congress that pressed forward the rescue of our environment
column2: and established for the next generation an enduring legacy of parks for the people.

column1: This can be the Congress that launched a new era in American medicine
column2: in which the quality of medical care was enhanced while the costs were made less burdensome.

column1: But above all
column2: what this Congress can be remembered for is opening the way to a new American revolution a peaceful revolution in which power was turned back to the people in which government at all levels was refreshed and renewed and made truly responsive. This can be a revolution as profound
column3: as far-reaching
column4: as exciting as that first revolution almost 200 year ago and it can mean that just 5 years from now America will enter its third century as a young nation new in spirit
column5: with all the vigor and the freshness with which it began its first century.

column1: My colleagues in the Congress
column2: these are great goals. They can make the sessions of this Congress a great moment for America. So let us pledge together to go forward together by achieving these goals to give America the foundation today for a new greatness tomorrow and in all the years to come
column3: and in so doing to make this the greatest Congress in the history of this great and good country.@

column1: Richard M. Nixon|Address on the State of the Union Delivered Before a Joint Session of the Congress|1972-01-20|@Mr. Speaker
column2: Mr. President
column3: my colleagues in the Congress
column4: our distinguished guests
column5: my fellow Americans:

column1: Twenty-five years ago I sat here as a freshman Congressman along with Speaker Albert and listened for the first time to the President address the State of the Union.
I shall never forget that moment. The Senate
column2: the diplomatic corps
column3: the Supreme Court
column4: the Cabinet entered the Chamber
column5: and then the President of the United States. As all of you are aware
column6: I had some differences with President Truman. He had some with me. But I remember that on that day the day he addressed that joint session of the newly elected Republican 80th Congress
column7: he spoke not as a partisan
column8: but as President of all the people calling upon the Congress to put aside partisan considerations in the national interest.

column1: The Greek-Turkish aid program
column2: the Marshall Plan
column3: the great foreign policy initiatives which have been responsible for avoiding a world war for over 25 years were approved by the 80th Congress
column4: by a bipartisan majority of which I was proud to be a part.

column1: Nineteen hundred seventy-two is now before us. It holds precious time in which to accomplish good for the Nation. We must not waste it. I know the political pressures in this session of the Congress will be great. There are more candidates for the Presidency in this Chamber today than there probably have been at any one time in the whole history of the Republic. And there is an honest difference of opinion
column2: not only between the parties
column3: but within each party
column4: on some foreign policy issues and on some domestic policy issues.

column1: However
column2: there are great national problems that are so vital that they transcend partisanship. So let us have our debates. Let us have our honest differences. But let us join in keeping the national interest first. Let us join in making sure that legislation the Nation needs does not become hostage to the political interests of any party or any person.

column1: There is ample precedent
column2: in this election year
column3: for me to present you with a huge list of new proposals
column4: knowing full well that there would not be any possibility of your passing them if you worked night and day.

column1: I shall not do that.
I have presented to the leaders of the Congress today a message of 15
column2: 000 words discussing in some detail where the Nation stands and setting forth specific legislative items on which I have asked the Congress to act. Much of this is legislation which I proposed in 1969
column4: and also in the first session of this 92d congress and on which I feel it is essential that action be completed this year.

column1: I am not presenting proposals which have attractive labels but no hope of passage. I am presenting only vital programs which are within the capacity of this Congress to enact
column2: within the capacity of the budget to finance
column3: and which I believe should be above partisanship programs which deal with urgent priorities for the Nation
column4: which should and must be the subject of bipartisan action by this Congress in the interests of the country in 1972.

column1: When I took the oath of office on the steps of this building just 3 years ago today
column2: the Nation was ending one of the most tortured decades in its history.

column1: The 1960s were a time of great progress in many areas. But as we all know
column2: they were also times of great agony the agonies of war
column3: of inflation
column4: of rapidly rising crime
column5: of deteriorating cities
column6: of hopes raised and disappointed
column7: and of anger and frustration that led finally to violence and to the worst civil disorder in a century.

column1: I recall these troubles not to point any fingers of blame. The Nation was so torn in those final years of the sixties that many in both parties questioned whether America could be governed at all.
The Nation has made significant progress in these first years of the seventies:
Our colleges and universities have again become places of learning instead of battlegrounds.
A beginning has been made in preserving and protecting our environment.
The rate of increase in crime has been slowed and here in the District of Columbia
column2: the one city where the Federal Government has direct jurisdiction
column3: serious crime in 1971 was actually reduced by 13 percent from that year before.

column1: Most important
column2: because of the beginnings that have been made
column3: we can say today that this year 1972 can be the year in which America may make the greatest progress in 25 years toward achieving our goal of being at peace with all the nations of the world.

column1: As our involvement in the war in Vietnam comes to an end
column2: we must now go on to build a generation of peace.

column1: To achieve that goal
column2: we must first face realistically the need to maintain our defense.

column1: In the past 3 years
column2: we have reduced the burden of arms. For the first time in 20 years
column3: spending on defense has been brought below spending on human resources.

column1: As we look to the future
column2: we find encouraging progress in our negotiations with the Soviet Union on limitation of strategic arms. And looking further into the future
column3: we hope there can eventually be agreement on the mutual reduction of arms. But until there is such a mutual agreement
column4: we must maintain the strength necessary to deter war.

column1: And that is why
column2: because of rising research and development costs
column3: because of increases in military and civilian pay
column4: because of the need to proceed with new weapons systems
column5: my budget for the coming fiscal year will provide for an increase in defense spending. Strong military defenses are not the enemy of peace; they are the guardians of peace.

column1: There could be no more misguided set of priorities than one which would tempt others by weakening America
column2: and thereby endanger the peace of the world.

column1: In our foreign policy
column2: we have entered a new era. The world has changed greatly in the 11 years since President John Kennedy said in his Inaugural Address
column3: we shall pay any price
column4: bear any burden
column5: meet any hardship
column6: support any friend
column7: oppose any foe to assure the survival and the success of liberty.

column1: Our policy has been carefully and deliberately adjusted to meet the new realities of the new world we live in. We make today only those commitments we are able and prepared to meet.
Our commitment to freedom remains strong and unshakable. But others must bear their share of the burden of defending freedom around the world.
And so this
column2: then
column3: is our policy:

column1: --We will maintain a nuclear deterrent adequate to meet any threat to the security of the United States or of our allies.
--We will help other nations develop the capability of defending themselves.
--We will faithfully honor all of our treaty commitments.
--We will act to defend our interests
