column2: whenever and wherever they are threatened anyplace in the world.

column1: --But where our interests or our treaty commitments are not involved
column2: our role will be limited.

column1: --We will not intervene militarily.
--But we will use our influence to prevent war.
--If war comes
column2: we will use our influence to stop it.

column1: --Once it is over
column2: will do your share in helping to bind up the wounds of those who have participated in it.

column1: As you know
column2: I will soon be visiting the People's Republic of China and the Soviet Union. I go there with no illusions. We have great differences with both powers. We shall continue to have great differences. But peace depends on the ability of great powers to live together on the same planet despite their differences.

column1: We would not be true to our obligation to generations yet unborn if we failed to seize this moment to do everything in our power to insure that we will be able to talk about those differences
column2: rather than to fight about them
column3: in the future.

column1: As we look back over this century
column2: let us
column3: in the highest spirit of bipartisanship
column4: recognize that we can be proud of our Nation's record in foreign affairs.

column1: America has given more generously of itself toward maintaining freedom
column2: preserving peace
column3: alleviating human suffering around the globe
column4: than any nation has ever done in the history of man.

column1: We have fought four wars in this century
column2: but our power has never been used to break the peace
column3: only to keep it; never been used to destroy freedom
column4: only to defend it; never been used to destroy freedom
column5: only to defend it. We now have within our reach the goal of insuring that the next generation can be the first generation in this century to be spared the scourges of war.

column1: Turning to our problems at home
column2: we are making progress toward our goal of a new prosperity without war.

column1: Industrial production
column2: consumer spending
column3: retail sales
column4: personal income all have been rising. Total employment
column5: real income are the highest in history. New homebuilding starts this past year reached the highest level ever. Business and consumer confidence have both been rising. Interest rates are down. The rate of inflation is down. We can look with confidence to 1972 as the year when the back of inflation will be broken.

column1: Now
column2: this a good record
column3: but it is not good enough not when we still have an unemployment rate of 6 percent.

column1: It is not enough to point out that this was the rate of the early peacetime years of the sixties
column2: or that if the more than 2 million men released from the Armed Forces and defense-related industries were still in their wartime jobs
column3: unemployment would be far lower.

column1: Our goal in this country is full employment in peacetime. We intend to meet that goal
column2: and we can.

column1: The Congress has helped to meet that goal by passing our job-creating tax program last month.
The historic monetary agreements
column2: agreements that we have reached with the major European nations
column3: Canada
column4: and Japan
column5: will help meet it by providing new markets for American products
column6: new jobs for American workers.

column1: Our budget will help meet it by being expansionary without being inflationary a job-producing budget that will help take up the gap as the economy expands to full employment.
Our program to raise farm income will help meet it by helping to revitalize rural America
column2: by giving to America's farmers their fair share of America's increasing productivity.

column1: We also will help meet our goal of full employment in peacetime with a set of major initiatives to stimulate more imaginative use of America's great capacity for technological advance
column2: and to direct it toward improving the quality of life for every American.

column1: In reaching the moon
column2: we demonstrated what miracles American technology is capable of achieving. Now the time has come to move more deliberately toward making full use of that technology here on earth
column3: of harnessing the wonders of science to the service of man.

column1: I shall soon send to the Congress a special message proposing a new program of Federal partnership in technological research and developments with Federal incentives to increase private research
column2: federally supported research on projects designed to improve our everyday lives in ways that will range from improving mass transit to developing new systems of emergency health care that could save thousands of lives annually.

column1: Historically
column2: our superior technology and high productivity have made it possible for American workers to be the highest paid in the world by far
column3: and yet for our goods still to compete in world markets.

column1: Now we face a new situation. As other nations move rapidly forward in technology
column2: the answer to the new competition is not to build a wall around America
column3: but rather to remain competitive by improving our own technology still further and by increasing productivity in American industry.

column1: Our new monetary and trade agreements will make it possible for American goods to compete fairly in the world's markets but they still must compete. The new technology program will put to use the skills of many highly trained Americans
column2: skills that might otherwise be wasted. It will also meet the growing technological challenge from abroad
column3: and it will thus help to create new industries
column4: as well as creating more jobs for America's workers in producing for the world's markets.

column1: This second session of the 92d congress already has before it more than 90 major Administration proposals which still await action.
I have discussed these in the extensive written message that I have presented to the Congress today.
They include
column2: among others
column3: our programs to improve life for the aging; to combat crime and drug abuse; to improve health services and to ensure that no one will be denied needed health care because of inability to pay; to protect workers' pension rights; to promote equal opportunity for members of minorities
column4: and others who have been left behind; to expand consumer protection; to improve the environment; to revitalize rural America; to help the cities; to launch new initiatives in education; to improve transportation
column5: and to put and end to costly labor tie-ups in transportation.

column1: The west coast dock strike is a case in point. This Nation cannot and will not tolerate that kind of irresponsible labor tie-up in the future.
The messages also include basic reforms which are essential if our structure of government is to be adequate in the decades ahead.
They include reform of our wasteful and outmoded welfare system substitution of a new system that provides work requirements and work incentives for those who can help themselves
column2: income support for those who cannot help themselves
column3: and fairness to the working poor.

column1: They include a $17 billion program of Federal revenue sharing with the States and localities as an investment in their renewal
column2: an investment also of faith in the American people.

column1: They also include a sweeping reorganization of the executive branch of the Federal Government so that it will be more efficient
column2: more responsive
column3: and able to meet the challenges of the decades ahead.

column1: One year ago
column2: standing in this place
column3: I laid before the opening session of this Congress six great goals. One of these was welfare reform. That proposal has been before the Congress now for nearly 2 1/2 years.

column1: My proposals on revenue sharing
column2: government reorganization
column3: health care
column4: and the environment have now been before the Congress for nearly a year. Many of the other major proposals that I have referred to have been here that long or longer.

column1: Now
column3: we can say
column4: was a year of consideration of these measures. Now let us join in making 1972 a year of action on them
column5: action by the Congress
column6: for the Nation and for the people of America.

column1: Now
column2: in addition
column3: there is one pressing need which I have not previously covered
column4: but which must be placed on the national agenda.

column1: We long have looked in this Nation to the local property tax as the main source of financing for public primary and secondary education.
As a result
column2: soaring school costs
column3: soaring property tax rates now threaten both our communities and our schools. They threaten communities because property taxes
column4: which more than doubled in the 10 years from 1960 to 70
column5: have become one of the most oppressive and discriminatory of all taxes
column6: hitting most cruelly at the elderly and the retired; and they threaten schools
column7: as hard-pressed voters understandably reject new bond issues at the polls.

column1: The problem has been given even greater urgency by four recent court decisions
column2: which have held that the conventional method of financing schools through local property taxes is discriminatory and unconstitutional.

column1: Nearly 2 years ago
column2: I named a special Presidential commission to study the problems of school finance
column3: and I also directed the Federal departments to look into the same problems. We are developing comprehensive proposals to meet these problems.

column1: This issue involves two complex and interrelated sets of problems: support of the schools and the basic relationships of Federal
column2: State
column3: and local governments in any tax reforms.

column1: Under the leadership of the Secretary of the Treasury
column2: we are carefully reviewing all of the tax aspects
column3: and I have this week enlisted the Advisory Commission on Intergovernmental Relations in addressing the intergovernmental relations aspects.

column1: I have asked this bipartisan Commission to review our proposals for Federal action to cope with the gathering crisis of school finance and property taxes. Later in the year
column2: when both Commissions have completed their studies
column3: I shall make my final recommendations for relieving the burden of property taxes and providing both fair and adequate financing for our children's education.

column1: These recommendations will be revolutionary. But all these recommendations
column2: however
column3: will be rooted in one fundamental principle with which there can be no compromise: Local school boards must have control over local schools.

column1: As we look ahead over the coming decades
column2: vast new growth and change are not only certainties
column3: they will be the dominant reality of this world
column4: and particularly of our life in America.

column1: Surveying the certainty of rapid change
column2: we can be like a fallen rider caught in the stirrups or we can sit high in the saddle
column3: the masters of change
column4: directing it on a course we choose.

column1: The secret of mastering change in today's world is to reach back to old and proven principles
column2: and to adapt them with imagination and intelligence to the new realities of a new age.

column1: That is what we have done in the proposals that I have laid before the Congress. They are rooted in basic principles that are as enduring as human nature
column2: as robust as the American experience; and they are responsive to new conditions. Thus they represent a spirit of change that is truly renewal.

column1: As we look back at those old principles
column2: we find them as timely as they are timeless.

column1: We believe in independence
column2: and self-reliance
column3: and the creative value of the competitive spirit.

column1: We believe in full and equal opportunity for all Americans and in the protection of individual rights and liberties.
We believe in the family as the keystone of the community
column2: and in the community as the keystone of the Nation.

column1: We believe in compassion toward those in need.
We believe in a system of law
column2: justice
column3: and order as the basis of a genuinely free society.

column1: We believe that a person should get what he works for and that those who can
column2: should work for and that those who can
column3: should work for what they get.

column1: We believe in the capacity of people to make their own decisions in their own lives
column2: in their own communities and we believe in their right to make those decisions.

column1: In applying these principles
column2: we have done so with the full understanding that what we seek in the seventies
column3: what our quest is
column4: is not merely for more
column5: but for better for a better quality of life for all Americans.

column1: Thus
column2: for example
column3: we are giving a new measure of attention to cleaning up our air and water
column4: making our surroundings more attractive. We are providing broader support for the arts
column5: helping stimulate a deeper appreciation of what they can contribute to the Nation's activities and to our individual lives.

column1: But nothing really matters more to the quality of our lives than the way we treat one another
column2: than our capacity to live respectfully together as a unified society
column3: with a full
column4: generous regard for the rights of others and also for the feelings of others.

column1: As we recover from the turmoil and violence of recent years
column2: as we learn once again to speak with one another instead of shouting at one another
column3: we are regaining that capacity.

column1: As is customary here
column2: on this occasion
column3: I have been talking about programs. Programs are important. But even more important than programs is what we are as a Nation what we mean as a Nation
column4: to ourselves and to the world.

column1: In New York Harbor stands one of the most famous statues in the world the Statue of Liberty
column2: the gift in 1886 of the people of France to the people of the United States. This statue is more than a landmark; it is a symbol a symbol of what America has meant to the world.

column1: It reminds us that what America has meant is not its wealth
column2: and not its power
column3: but its spirit and purpose a land that enshrines liberty and opportunity
column4: and that has held out a hand of welcome to millions in search of a better and a fuller and
column5: above all
column6: a freer life.

column1: The world's hopes poured into America
column2: along with its people. And those hopes
column3: those dreams
column4: that have been brought here from every corner of the world
column5: have become a part of the hope that we now hold out to the world.

column1: Four years from now
column2: America will celebrate the 200th anniversary of its founding as a Nation. There are those who say that the old Spirit of '76 is dead that we no longer have the strength of character
column3: the idealism
column4: the faith in our founding purposes that that spirit represents.

column1: Those who say this do not know America.
We have been undergoing self-doubts and self-criticism. But these are only the other side of our growing sensitivity to the persistence of want in the midst of plenty
column2: of our impatience with the slowness with which age-old ills are being overcome.

column1: If we were indifferent to the shortcomings of our society
column2: or complacent about our institutions
column3: or blind to the lingering inequities then we would have lost our way.

column1: But the fact that we have those concerns is evidence that our ideals
column2: deep down
column3: are still strong. Indeed
column4: they remind us that what is really best about America is its compassion. They remind us that in the final analysis
column5: America is great not because it is rich
column6: but because this is a good country.

column1: Let us reject the narrow visions of those who would tell us that we are evil because we are not yet perfect
column2: that we are corrupt because we are not yet pure
column3: that all the sweat and trial and sacrifice that have gone into the building of America were for naught because the building is not yet done.

column1: Let us see that the path we are traveling is wide
column2: with room in it for all of us
column3: and that its direction is toward a better Nation and a more peaceful world.

column1: Never has it mattered more that we go forward together.
Look at this Chamber. The leadership of America is here today the Supreme Court
column2: the Cabinet
column3: the Senate
column4: the House of Representatives.

column1: Together
column2: we hold the future of the Nation
column3: and the conscience of the Nation in our hands.

column1: Because this year is an election year
column2: it will be a time of great pressure.

column1: If we yield to that pressure and fail to deal seriously with the historic challenges that we face
column2: we will have failed that trust of millions of Americans and shaken the confidence they have a right to place in us
column3: in their Government.

column1: Never has a Congress had a greater opportunity to leave a legacy of a profound and constructive reform for the Nation than this Congress.
If we succeed in these tasks
column2: there will be credit enough for all not only for doing what is right
column3: but doing it in the right way
column4: by rising above partisan interest to serve the national interest.

column1: And if we fail
column2: more than any one of us
column3: America will be the loser.

column1: That is why my call upon the Congress today is for a high statesmanship
column2: so that in the years to come Americans will look back and say because it withstood the intense pressures of a political year
column3: and achieved such great good for the American people and for the future of this Nation
column4: this was truly a great Congress.@

column1: Richard M. Nixon|State of the Union Message to the Congress: Overview and Goals|February 2
column2: 1973|@To the congress of the United States:

column1: The traditional form of the President's annual report giving to the Congress Information of the State of the Union  is a single message or address. As the affairs and concerns of our Union have multiplied over the years
column2: however
column3: so too have the subjects that require discussion in State of the Union Messages.

column1: This year in particular
column2: with so many changes in Government programs under consideration and with our very philosophy about the relationship between the individual and the State at an historic crossroads a single
column3: all-embracing State of the Union Message would not appear to be adequate.

column1: I have therefore decided to present my 1973 State of the Union report in the form of a series of messages during these early weeks of the 93rd Congress. The purpose of this first message in the series is to give a concise overview of where we stand as a people today
column2: and to outline some of the general goals that I believe we should pursue over the next year and beyond. In coming weeks
column3: I will send to the Congress further State of the Union reports on specific areas of policy including economic affairs
column4: natural resources
column5: human resources
column6: community development and foreign and defense policy.

column1: The new course these messages will outline represents a fresh approach to Government: an approach that addresses the realities of the 1970s
column2: not those of the 1930s or of the 1960s. The role of the Federal Government as we approach our third century of independence should not be to dominate any facet of American life
column3: but rather to aid and encourage people
column4: communities and institutions to deal with as many of the difficulties and challenges facing them as possible
column5: and to help see to it that every American has a full and equal opportunity to realize his or her potential.

column1: If we were to continue to expand the Federal Government at the rate of the past several decades
column2: it soon would consume us entirely. The time has come when we must make clear choices choices between old programs that set worthy goals but failed to reach them and new programs that provide a better way to realize those goals; and choices
column3: too
column4: between competing programs all of which may be desirable in themselves but only some of which we can afford with the finite resources at our command.

column1: Because our resources are not infinite
column2: we also face a critical choice in 1973 between holding the line in Government spending and adopting expensive programs which will surely force up taxes and refuel inflation.

column1: Finally
column2: it is vital at this time that we restore a greater sense of responsibility at the State and local level
column3: and among individual Americans.

column1: WHERE WE STAND
The basic state of our Union today is sound
column2: and full of promise.

column1: We enter 1973 economically strong
column2: militarily secure and
column3: most important of all
column4: at peace after a long and trying war.

column1: America continues to provide a better and more abundant life for more of its people than any other nation in the world.
We have passed through one of the most difficult periods in our history without surrendering to despair and without dishonoring our ideals as a people.
Looking back
column2: there is a lesson in all this for all of us. The lesson is one that we sometimes had to learn the hard way over the past few years. But we did learn it. That lesson is that even potentially destructive forces can be converted into positive forces when we know how to channel them
column3: and when we use common sense and common decency to create a climate of mutual respect and goodwill.

column1: By working together and harnessing the forces of nature
column2: Americans have unlocked some of the great mysteries of the universe.

column1: Men have walked the surface of the moon and soared to new heights of discovery.
This same spirit of discovery is helping us to conquer disease and suffering that have plagued our own planet since the dawn of time.
By working together with the leaders of other nations
column2: we have been able to build a new hope for lasting peace for a structure of world order in which common interest outweighs old animosities
column3: and in which a new generation of the human family can grow up at peace in a changing world.

column1: At home
column2: we have learned that by working together we can create prosperity without fanning inflation; we can restore order without weakening freedom.

column1: THE CHALLENGES WE FACE
These first years of the 1970s have been good years for America.

Our job all of us together is to make 1973 and the years to come even better ones. I believe that we can. I believe that we can make the years leading to our Bicentennial the best four years in American history.
But we must never forget that nothing worthwhile can be achieved without the will to succeed and the strength to sacrifice.
Hard decisions must be made
column2: and we must stick by them.

column1: In the field of foreign policy
column2: we must remember that a strong America an America whose word is believed and whose strength is respected is essential to continued peace and understanding in the world. The peace with honor we have achieved in Vietnam has strengthened this basic American credibility. We must act in such a way in coming years that this credibility will remain intact
column3: and with it
column4: the world stability of which it is so indispensable a part.

column1: At home
column2: we must reject the mistaken notion a notion that has dominated too much of the public dialogue for too long that ever bigger Government is the answer to every problem.

column1: We have learned only too well that heavy taxation and excessive Government spending are not a cure-all. In too many cases
column2: instead of solving the problems they were aimed at
column3: they have merely placed an ever heavier burden on the shoulders of the American taxpayer
column4: in the form of higher taxes and a higher cost of living. At the same time they have deceived our people because many of the intended beneficiaries received far less than was promised
column5: thus undermining public faith in the effectiveness of Government as a whole.

column1: The time has come for us to draw the line. The time has come for the responsible leaders of both political parties to take a stand against overgrown Government and for the American taxpayer. We are not
column2: spending the Federal Government's money
column3: we are spending the taxpayer's money
column4: and it must be spent in a way which guarantees his money's worth and yields the fullest possible benefit to the people being helped.

column1: The answer to many of the domestic problems we face is not higher taxes and more spending. It is less waste
column2: more results and greater freedom for the individual American to earn a rightful place in his own community and for States and localities to address their own needs in their own ways
column3: in the light of their own priorities.

column1: By giving the people and their locally elected leaders a greater voice through changes such as revenue sharing
column2: and by saying no  to excessive Federal spending and higher taxes
column3: we can help achieve this goal.

column1: COMING MESSAGES
The policies which I will outline to the Congress in the weeks ahead represent a reaffirmation
column2: not an abdication
column3: of Federal responsibility. They represent a pragmatic rededication to social compassion and national excellence
column4: in place of the combination of good intentions and fuzzy follow-through which too often in the past was thought sufficient.

column1: In the field of economic affairs
column2: our objectives will be to hold down taxes
column3: to continue controlling inflation
column4: to promote economic growth
column5: to increase productivity
column6: to encourage foreign trade
column7: to keep farm income high
column8: to bolster small business
column9: and to promote better labor-management relations.

column1: In the area of natural resources
column2: my recommendations will include programs to preserve and enhance the environment
column3: to advance science and technology
column4: and to assure balanced use of our irreplaceable natural resources.

column1: In developing human resources
column2: I will have recommendations to advance the Nation's health and education
column3: to improve conditions of people in need
column4: to carry forward our increasingly successful attacks on crime
column5: drug abuse and injustice
column6: and to deal with such important areas of special concern as consumer affairs. We will continue and improve our Nation's efforts to assist those who have served in the Armed Services in Vietnam through better job and training opportunities.

column1: We must do a better job in community development in creating more livable communities
column2: in which all of our children can grow up with fuller access to opportunity and greater immunity to the social evils and blights which now plague so many of our towns and cities. I shall have proposals to help us achieve this.

column1: I shall also deal with our defense and foreign policies
column2: and with our new approaches to the role and structure of Government itself.

column1: Considered as a whole
column2: this series of messages will be a blueprint for modernizing the concept and the functions of American Government to meet the needs of our people.

column1: Converting it into reality will require a spirit of cooperation and shared commitment on the part of all branches of the Government
column2: for the goals we seek are not those of any single party or faction
column3: they are goals for the betterment of all Americans. As President
column4: I recognize that I cannot do this job alone. The Congress must help
column5: and I pledge to do my part to achieve a constructive working relationship with the Congress. My sincere hope is that the executive and legislative branches can work together in this great undertaking in a positive spirit of mutual respect and cooperation.

column1: Working together the Congress
column2: the President and the people I am confident that we can translate these proposals into an action program that can reform and revitalize American Government and
column3: even more important
column4: build a better life for all Americans.

column1: RICHARD NIXON
The White House
February 2
Richard M. Nixon|Address on the State of the Union Delivered Before a Joint Session of the Congress|1974-01-30|@Mr. Speaker
column2: Mr. President
column3: my colleagues in the Congress
column4: our distinguished guests
column5: my fellow Americans:

column1: We meet here tonight at a time of great challenge and great opportunities for America. We meet at a time when we face great problems at home and abroad that will test the strength of our fiber as a nation. But we also meet at a time when that fiber has been tested
column2: and it has proved strong.

column1: America is a great and good land
column2: and we are a great and good land because we are a strong
column3: free
column4: creative people and because America is the single greatest force for peace anywhere in the world. Today
column5: as always in our history
column6: we can base our confidence in what the American people will achieve in the future on the record of what the American people have achieved in the past.

column1: Tonight
column2: for the first time in 12 years
column3: a President of the United States can report to the Congress on the state of a Union at peace with every nation of the world. Because of this
column4: in the 22
column5: 000-word message on the state of the Union that I have just handed to the Speaker of the House and the President of the Senate
column6: I have been able to deal primarily with the problems of peace with what we can do here at home in America for the American people rather than with the problems of war.

column1: The measures I have outlined in this message set an agenda for truly significant progress for this Nation and the world in 1974. Before we chart where we are going
column2: let us see how far we have come.

column1: It was 5 years ago on the steps of this Capitol that I took the oath of office as your President. In those 5 years
column2: because of the initiatives undertaken by this Administration
column3: the world has changed. America has changed. As a result of those changes
column4: America is safer today
column5: more prosperous today
column6: with greater opportunity for more of its people than ever before in our history.

column1: Five years ago
column2: America was at war in Southeast Asia. We were locked in confrontation with the Soviet Union. We were in hostile isolation from a quarter of the world's people who lived in Mainland China.

column1: Five years ago
column2: our cities were burning and besieged.

column1: Five years ago
column2: our college campuses were a battleground.

column1: Five years ago
column2: crime was increasing at a rate that struck fear across the Nation.

column1: Five years ago
column2: the spiraling rise in drug addiction was threatening human and social tragedy of massive proportion
column3: and there was no program to deal with it.

column1: Five years ago as young Americans had done for a generation before that America's youth still lived under the shadow of the military draft.
Five years ago
column2: there was no national program to preserve our environment. Day by day
column3: our air was getting dirtier
column4: our water was getting more foul.

column1: And 5 years ago
column2: American agriculture was practically a depressed industry with 100
column3: 000 farm families abandoning the farm every year.

column1: As we look at America today
column2: we find ourselves challenged by new problems. But we also find a record of progress to confound the professional criers of doom and prophets of despair. We met the challenges we faced 5 years ago
column3: and we will be equally confident of meeting those that we face today.

column1: Let us see for a moment how we have met them.
After more than 10 years of military involvement
column2: all of our troops have returned from Southeast Asia
column3: and they have returned with honor. And we can be proud of the fact that our courageous prisoners of war
column4: for whom a dinner was held in Washington tonight
column5: that they came home with their heads high
column6: on their feet and not on their knees.

column1: In our relations with the Soviet Union
column2: we have turned away from a policy of confrontation to one of negotiation. For the first time since World War II
column3: the world's two strongest powers are working together toward peace in the world. With the People's Republic of China
column4: after a generation of hostile isolation
column5: we have begun a period of peaceful exchange and expanding trade.

column1: Peace has returned to our cities
column2: to our campuses. The 17-year rise in crime has been stopped. We can confidently say today that we are finally beginning to win the war against crime. Right here in this Nation's Capital which a few years ago was threatening to become the crime capital of the world the rate in crime has been cut in half. A massive campaign against drug abuse has been organized. And the rate of new heroin addiction
column3: the most vicious threat of all
column4: is decreasing rather than increasing.

column1: For the first time in a generation
column2: no young Americans are being drafted into the armed services of the United States. And for the first time over
column3: we have organized a massive national effort to protect the environment. Our air is getting cleaner
column4: our water is getting purer
column5: and our agriculture
column6: which was depressed
column7: is prospering. Farm income is up 70 percent
column8: farm production is setting alltime records
column9: and the billions of dollars the taxpayers were paying in subsidies has been cut to nearly zero.

column1: Overall
column2: Americans are living more abundantly than ever before
column3: today. More than 2 1/2 million new jobs were created in the past year alone. That is the biggest percentage increase in nearly 20 years. People are earning more. What they earn buys more
column4: more than ever before in history. In the past 5 years
column5: the average American's real spendable income that is
column6: what you really can buy with your income
column7: even after allowing for taxes and inflation- has increased by 16 percent.

column1: Despite this record of achievement
column2: as we turn to the year ahead we hear once again the familiar voice of the perennial prophets of gloom telling us now that because of the need to fight inflation
column3: because of the energy shortage
column4: America may be headed for a recession.

column1: Let me speak to that issue head on. There will be no recession in the United Stateds of America. Primarily due to our energy crisis
column2: our economy is passing through a difficult period. But I pledge to you tonight that the full powers of this Government will be used to keep America's economy producing and to protect the jobs of America's workers.

column1: We are engaged in a long and hard fight against inflation. There have been
column2: and there will be in the future
column3: ups and downs in that fight. But if this Congress cooperates in our efforts to hold down the cost of Government
column4: we shall win our fight to hold down the cost of living for the American people.

column1: As we look back over our history
column2: the years that stand out as the ones of signal achievement are those in which the Administration and the Congress
column3: whether one party or the other
column4: working together
column5: had the wisdom and the foresight to select those particular initiatives for which the Nation was ready and the moment was right and in which they seized the moment and acted.

column1: Looking at the year 1974 which lies before us
column2: there are 10 key areas in which landmark accomplishments are possible this year in America. If we make these our national agenda
column3: this is what we will achieve in 1974:

column1: We will break the back of the energy crisis; we will lay the foundation for our future capacity to meet America's energy needs from America's own resources.

And we will take another giant stride toward lasting peace in the world not only by continuing our policy of negotiation rather than confrontation where the great powers are concerned but also by helping toward the achievement of a just and lasting settlement in the Middle East.
We will check the rise in prices without administering the harsh medicine of recession
column2: and we will move the economy into a steady period of growth at a sustainable level.

column1: We will establish a new system that makes high-quality health care available to every American in a dignified manner and at a price he can afford.
We will make our States and localities more responsive to the needs of their own citizens.
We will make a crucial breakthrough toward better transportation in our towns and in our cities across America.
We will reform our system of Federal aid to education
column2: to provide it when it is needed
column3: where it is needed
column4: so that it will do the most for those who need it the most.

column1: We will make an historic beginning on the task of defining and protecting the right of personal privacy for every American.
And we will start on a new road toward reform of a welfare system that bleeds the taxpayer
column2: corrodes the community
column3: and demeans those it is intended to assist.

column1: Another together with the other nations of the world
column2: we will establish the economic framework within which Americans will share more fully in an expanding worldwide trade and prosperity in the years ahead
column3: with more open access to both markets and supplies.

column1: In all of the 186 State of the Union messages delivered from this place
column2: in our history this is the first in which the one priority
column3: the first priority
column4: is energy. Let me begin by reporting a new development which I know will be welcome news to every American. As you know
column5: we have committed ourselves to an active role in helping to achieve a just and durable peace in the Middle East
column6: on the basis of full implementation of Security Council Resolutions 242 and 338. The first step in the process is the disengagement of Egyptian and Israeli forces which is now taking place.

column1: Because of this hopeful development
column2: I can announce tonight that I have been assured
column3: through my personal contacts with friendly leaders in the Middle Eastern area
column4: that an urgent meeting will be called in the immediate future to discuss the lifting of the oil embargo.

column1: This is an encouraging sign. However
column2: it should be clearly understood by our friends in the Middle East that the United States will not be coerced on this issue.

column1: Regardless of the outcome of this meeting
column2: the cooperation of the American people in our energy conservation program has already gone a long way towards achieving a goal to which I am deeply dedicated. Let us do everything we can to avoid gasoline rationing in the United States of America.

column1: Last week
column2: I sent to the Congress a comprehensive special message setting forth our energy situation
column3: recommending the legislative measures which are necessary to a program for meeting our needs. If the embargo is lifted
column4: this will ease the crisis
column5: but it will not mean an end to the energy shortage in America. Voluntary conservation will continue to be necessary. And let me take this occasion to pay tribute once again to the splendid spirit of cooperation the American people have shown which has made possible our success in meeting this emergency up to this time.

column1: The new legislation I have requested will also remain necessary. Therefore
column2: I urge again that the energy measures that I have proposed be made the first priority of this session of the Congress. These measures will require the oil companies and other energy producers to provide the public with the necessary information on their supplies. They will prevent the injustice of windfall profits for a few as a result of the sacrifices of the millions of Americans. And they will give us the organization
column3: the incentives
column4: the authorities needed to deal with the short-term emergency and to move toward meeting our long-term needs.

column1: Just as 1970 was the year in which we began a full-scale effort to protect the environment
column2: 1974 must be the year in which we organize a full-scale effort to provide for our energy needs
column3: not only in this decade but through the 21st century.

column1: As we move toward the celebration 2 years from now of the 200th anniversary of this Nation's independence
column2: let us press vigorously on toward the goal I announced last November for Project Independence. Let this be our national goal: At the end of this decade
column3: in the year 1980
column4: the United States will not be dependent on any other country for energy we need to provide our jobs
column5: to heat our homes
column6: and to keep our transportation moving.

column1: To indicate the size of the Government commitment
column2: to spur energy research and development
column3: we plan to spend $10 billion in Federal funds over the next 5 years. That is an enormous amount. But during the same 5 years
column4: private enterprise will be investing as much as $200 billion and in 10 years
column5: $500 billion to develop the new resources
column6: the new technology
column7: the new capacity America will require for its energy needs in the 1980's. That is just a measure of the magnitude of the project we are undertaking.

column1: But America performs best when called to its biggest tasks. It can truly be said that only in America could a task so tremendous be achieved so quickly
column2: and achieved not by regimentation
column3: but through the effort and ingenuity of a free people
column4: working in a free system.

column1: Turning now to the rest of the agenda for 1974
column2: the time is at hand this year to bring comprehensive
column3: high quality health care within the reach of every American. I shall propose a sweeping new program that will assure comprehensive health insurance protection to millions of Americans who cannot now obtain it or afford it
column4: with vastly improved protection against catastrophic illnesses. This will be a plan that maintains the high standards of quality in America's health care. And it will not require additional taxes.

column1: Now
column2: I recognize that other plans have been put forward that would cost $80 billion or even $100 billion and that would put our whole health care system under the heavy hand of the Federal Government. This is the wrong approach. This has been tried abroad
column3: and it has failed. It is not the way we do things here in America. This kind of plan would threaten the quality of care provided by our whole health care system. The right way is one that builds on the strengths of the present system and one that does not destroy those strengths
column4: one based on partnership
column5: not paternalism. Most important of all
column6: let us keep this as the guiding principle of our health programs. Government has a great role to play
column7: but we must always make sure that our doctors will be working for their patients and not for the Federal Government.

column1: Many of you will recall that in my State of the Union Address 3 years ago
column2: I commented that Most Americans today are simply fed up with government at all levels
column3: and I recommended a sweeping set of proposals to revitalize State and local governments
column4: to make them more responsive to the people they serve. I can report to you today that as a result of revenue sharing passed by the Congress
column5: and other measures
column6: we have made progress toward that goal. After 40 years of moving power from the States and the communities to Washington
column7: D.C.
column8: we have begun moving power back from Washington to the States and communities and
column9: most important
column10: to the people of America.

column1: In this session of the Congress
column2: I believe we are near the breakthrough point on efforts which I have suggested
column3: proposals to let people themselves make their own decisions for their own communities and
column4: in particular
column5: on those to provide broad new flexibility in Federal aid for community development
column6: for economic development
column7: for education. And I look forward to working with the Congress
column8: with members of both parties in resolving whatever remaining differences we have in this legislation so that we can make available nearly $5 1/2 billion to our States and localities to use not for what a Federal bureaucrat may want
column9: but for what their own people in those communities want. The decision should be theirs.

column1: I think all of us recognize that the energy crisis has given new urgency to the need to improve public transportation
column2: not only in our cities but in rural areas as well. The program I have proposes this year will give communities not only more money but also more freedom to balance their own transportation needs. It will mark the strongest Federal commitment ever to the improvement of mass transit as an essential element of the improvement of life in our towns and cities.

column1: One goal on which all Americans agree is that our children should have the very best education this great Nation can provide.
In a special message last week
column2: I recommended a number of important new measures that can make 1974 a year of truly significant advances for our schools and for the children they serve. If the Congress will act on these proposals
column3: more flexible funding will enable each Federal dollar to meet better the particular need of each particular school district. Advance funding will give school authorities a chance to make each year's plans
column4: knowing ahead of time what Federal funds they are going to receive. Special targeting will give special help to the truly disadvantaged among our people. College students faced with rising costs for their education will be able to draw on an expanded program of loans and grants. These advances are a needed investment in America's most precious resource
column5: our next generation. And I urge the Congress to act on this legislation in 1974.

column1: One measure of a truly free society is the vigor with which it protects the liberties of its individual citizens. As technology has advanced in America
column2: it has increasingly encroached on one of those liberties what I term the right of personal privacy. Modern information systems
column3: data banks
column4: credit records
column5: mailing list abuses
column6: electronic snooping
column7: the collection of personal data for one purpose that may be used for another all these have left millions of Americans deeply concerned by the privacy they cherish.

column1: And the time has come
column2: therefore
column3: for a major initiative to define the nature and extent of the basic rights of privacy and to erect new safeguards to ensure that those rights are respected.

column1: I shall launch such an effort this year at the highest levels of the Administration
column2: and I look forward again to working with this Congress in establishing a new set of standards that respect the legitimate needs of society
column3: but that also recognize personal privacy as a cardinal principle of American liberty.

column1: Many of those in this Chamber tonight will recall that it was 3 years ago that I termed the Nation's welfare system a monstrous
column2: consuming outrage an outrage against the community
column3: against the taxpayer
column4: and particularly against the children that it is supposed to help.

column1: That system is still an outrage. By improving its administration
column2: we have been able to reduce some of the abuses. As a result
column3: last year
column4: for the first time in 18 years
column5: there has been a halt in the growth of the welfare caseload. But as a system
column6: our welfare program still needs reform as urgently today as it did when I first proposed in 1969 that we completely replace it with a different system.

column1: In these final 3 years of my Administration
column2: I urge the congress to join me in mounting a major new effort to replace the discredited present welfare system with one that works
column3: one that is fair to those who need help or cannot help themselves
column4: fair to the community
column5: and fair to the taxpayer. And let us have as our goal that there will be no Government program which makes it more profitable to go on welfare than to go to work.

column1: I recognize that from the debates that have taken place within the Congress over the past 3 years on this program that we cannot expect enactment overnight of a new reform. But I do propose that the Congress and the Administration together make this the year in which we discuss
column2: debate
column3: and shape such a reform so that it can be enacted as quickly as possible.

column1: America's own prosperity in the years ahead depends on our sharing fully and equitably in an expanding world prosperity. Historic negotiations will take place this year that will enable us to ensure fair treatment in international markets for American workers
column2: American farmers
column3: American investors
column4: and American consumers.

column1: It is vital that the authorities contained in the trade bill I submitted to the Congress be enacted so that the United States can negotiate flexibly and vigorously on behalf of American interests. These negotiations can usher in a new era of international trade that not only increases the prosperity of all nations but also strengthens the peace among all nations.
In the past 5 years
column2: we have made more progress toward a lasting structure of peace in the world than in any comparable time in the Nation's history. We could not have made that progress if we had not maintained the military strength of America. Thomas Jefferson once observed that the price of liberty is eternal vigilance. By the same token
column3: and for the same reason
column4: in today's world the price of peace is a strong defense as far as the United States is concerned.

column1: In the past 5 years
column2: we have steadily reduced the burden of national defense as a share of the budget
column3: bringing it down from 44 percent in 1969 to 29 percent in the current year. We have cut our military manpower over the past 5 years by more than a third
column4: from 3.5 million to 2.2 million.

column1: In the coming year
column2: however
column3: increased expenditures will be needed. They will be needed to assure the continued readiness of our military forces
column4: to preserve present force levels in the face of rising costs
column5: and to give us the military strength we must have if our security is to be maintained and if our initiatives for peace are to succeed.

column1: The question is not whether we can afford to maintain the necessary strength of our defense
column2: the question is whether we can afford not to maintain it
column3: and the answer to that question is no. We must never allow America to become the second strongest nation in the world.

column1: I do not say this with any sense of belligerence
column2: because I recognize the fact that is recognized around the world. America's military strength has always been maintained to keep the peace
column3: never to break it. It has always been used to defend freedom
column4: never to destroy it. The world's peace
column5: as well as our own
column6: depends on our remaining as strong as we need to be as long as we need to be.

column1: In this year 1974
column2: we will be negotiating with the Soviet Union to place further limits on strategic nuclear arms. Together with our allies
column3: we will be negotiating with the nations of the Warsaw Pact on mutual and balanced reduction of forces in Europe. And we will continue our efforts to promote peaceful economic development in Latin America
column4: in Africa
column5: in Asia. We will press for full compliance with the peace accords that brought an end to American fighting in Indochina
column6: including particularly a provision that promised the fullest possible accounting for those Americans who are missing in action.

column1: And having in mind the energy crisis to which I have referred to earlier
column2: we will be working with the other nations of the world toward agreement on means by which oil supplies can be assured at reasonable prices on a stable basis in a fair way to the consuming and producing nations alike.

column1: All of these are steps toward a future in which the world's peace and prosperity
column2: and ours as well as a result
column3: are made more secure.

column1: Throughout the 5 years that I have served as your President
column2: I have had one overriding aim
column3: and that was to establish a new structure of peace in the world that can free future generations of the scourge of war. I can understand that others may have different priorities. This has been and this will remain my first priority and the chief legacy I hope to leave from the 8 years of my Presidency.

column1: This does not mean that we shall not have other priorities
column2: because as we strengthen the peace
column3: we must also continue each year a steady strengthening of our society here at home. Our conscience requires it
column4: our interests require it
column5: and we must insist upon it.

column1: As we create more jobs
column2: as we build a better health care system
column3: as we improve our education
column4: as we develop new sources of energy
column5: as we provide more abundantly for the elderly and the poor
column6: as we strengthen the system of private enterprise that produces our prosperity as we do all of this and even more
column7: we solidify those essential bonds that hold us together as a nation.

column1: Even more importantly
column2: we advance what in the final analysis government in America is all about.

column1: What it is all about is more freedom
column2: more security
column3: a better life for each one of the 211 million people that live in this land.

column1: We cannot afford to neglect progress at home while pursuing peace abroad. But neither can we afford to neglect peace abroad while pursuing progress at home. With a stable peace
column2: all is possible
column3: but without peace
column4: nothing is possible.

column1: In the written message that I have just delivered to the Speaker and to the President of the Senate
column2: I commented that one of the continuing challenges facing us in the legislative process is that of the timing and pacing of our initiatives
column3: selecting each year among many worthy projects those that are ripe for action at that time.

column1: What is true in terms of our domestic initiatives is true also in the world. This period we now are in
column2: in the world and I say this as one who has seen so much of the world
column3: not only in these past 5 years but going back over many years we are in a period which presents a juncture of historic forces unique in this century. They provide an opportunity we may never have again to create a structure of peace solid enough to last a lifetime and more
column4: not just peace in our time but peace in our children's time as well. It is on the way we respond to this opportunity
column5: more than anything else
column6: that history will judge whether we in America have met our responsibility. And I am confident we will meet that great historic responsibility which is ours today.

column1: It was 27 years ago that John F. Kennedy and I sat in this Chamber
column2: as freshmen Congressmen
column3: hearing our first State of the Union address delivered by Harry Truman. I know from my talks with him
column4: as members of the Labor Committee on which we both served
column5: that neither of us then even dreamed that either one or both might eventually be standing in this place that I now stand in now and that he once stood in
column6: before me. It may well be that one of the freshmen Members of the 93d Congress
column7: one of you out there
column8: will deliver his own State of the Union message 27 years from now
column9: in the year 2001.

column1: Well
column2: whichever one it is
column3: I want you to be able to look back with pride and to say that your first years here were great years and recall that you were here in this 93d Congress when America ended its longest war and began its longest peace.

column1: Mr. Speaker
column2: and Mr. President
column3: and my distinguished colleagues and our guests:

column1: I would like to add a personal word with regard to an issue that has been of great concern to all Americans over the past year. I refer
column2: of course
column3: to the investigations of the so-called Watergate affair.

column1: As you know
column2: I have provided to the Special Prosecutor voluntarily a great deal of material. I believe that I have provided all the material that he needs to conclude his investigations and to proceed to prosecute the guilty and to clear the innocent.

column1: I believe the time has come to bring that investigation and the other investigations of this matter to an end. One year of Watergate is enough.
And the time has come
column2: my colleagues
column3: for not only the Executive
column4: the President
column5: but the Members of Congress
column6: for all of us to join together in devoting our full energies to these great issues that I have discussed tonight which involve the welfare of all of the American people in so many different ways
column7: as well as the peace of the world.

column1: I recognize that the House Judiciary Committee has a special responsibility in this area
column2: and I want to indicate on this occasion that I will cooperate with the Judiciary Committee in its investigation. I will cooperate so that it can conclude its investigation
column3: make its decision
column4: and I will cooperate in any way that I consider consistent with my responsibilities to the Office of the Presidency of the United States.

column1: There is only one limitation. I will follow the precedent that has been followed by and defended by every President from George Washington to Lyndon B. Johnson of never doing anything that weakens the Office of the President of the United States or impairs the ability of the Presidents of the future to make the great decisions that are so essential to this Nation and the world.
Another point should like to make very briefly: Like every Member of the House and Senate assembled here tonight
column2: I was elected to the office that I hold. And like every Member of the House and Senate
column3: when I was elected to that office
column4: I knew that I was elected for the purpose of doing a job and doing it as well as I possibly can. And I want you to know that I have no intention whatever of ever walking away from the job that the people elected me to do for the people of the United States.

column1: Now
column2: needless to say
column3: it would be understatement if I were not to admit that the year 1973 was not a very easy year for me personally or for my family. And as I have already indicated
column4: the year 1974 presents very great and serious problems
column5: as very great and serious opportunities are also presented.

column1: But my colleagues
column2: this I believe: With the help of God
column3: who has blessed this land so richly
column4: with the cooperation of the Congress
column5: and with the support of the American people
column6: we can and we will make the year 1974 a year of unprecedented progress toward our goal of building a structure of lasting peace in the world and a new prosperity without war in the United States of America.@

column1: Gerald R. Ford|Address Before a Joint Session of Congress Reporting on the State of the Union|1975-01-15|@Mr. Speaker
column2: Mr. Vice President
column3: Members of the 94th Congress
column4: and distinguished guests:

column1: Twenty-six years ago
column2: a freshman Congressman
column3: a young fellow with lots of idealism who was out to change the world
column4: stood before Sam Rayburn in the well of the House and solemnly swore to the same oath that all of you took yesterday--an unforgettable experience
column5: and I congratulate you all.

column1: Two days later
column2: that same freshman stood at the back of this great Chamber--over there someplace--as President Truman
column3: all charged up by his single-handed election victory
column4: reported as the Constitution requires on the state of the Union.

column1: When the bipartisan applause stopped
column2: President Truman said
column3: "I am happy to report to this 81st Congress that the state of the Union is good. Our Nation is better able than ever before to meet the needs of the American people
column4: and to give them their fair chance in the pursuit of happiness. It is foremost among the nations of the world in the search for peace."

column1: Today
column2: that freshman Member from Michigan stands where Mr. Truman stood
column3: and I must say to you that the state of the Union is not good: Millions of Americans are out of work. Recession and inflation are eroding the money of millions more. Prices are too high
column4: and sales are too slow. This year's Federal deficit will be about $30 billion; next year's probably $45 billion. The national debt will rise to over $500 billion. Our plant capacity and productivity are not increasing fast enough. We depend on others for essential energy. Some people question their Government's ability to make hard decisions and stick with them; they expect Washington politics as usual.

column1: Yet
column2: what President Truman said on January 5
column4: is even more true in 1975. We are better able to meet our people's needs. All Americans do have a fairer chance to pursue happiness. Not only are we still the foremost nation in the pursuit of peace but today's prospects of attaining it are infinitely brighter.

column1: There were 59 million Americans employed at the start of 1949; now there are more than 85 million Americans who have jobs. In comparable dollars
column2: the average income of the American family has doubled during the past 26 years.

column1: Now
column2: I want to speak very bluntly. I've got bad news
column3: and I don't expect much
column4: if any
column5: applause. The American people want action
column6: and it will take both the Congress and the President to give them what they want. Progress and solutions can be achieved
column7: and they will be achieved.

column1: My message today is not intended to address all of the complex needs of America. I will send separate messages making specific recommendations for domestic legislation
column2: such as the extension of general revenue sharing and the Voting Rights Act.

column1: The moment has come to move in a new direction. We can do this by fashioning a new partnership between the Congress on the one hand
column2: the White House on the other
column3: and the people we both represent.

column1: Let us mobilize the most powerful and most creative industrial nation that ever existed on this Earth to put all our people to work. The emphasis on our economic efforts must now shift from inflation to jobs.
To bolster business and industry and to create new jobs
column2: I propose a 1-year tax reduction of $16 billion. Three-quarters would go to individuals and one-quarter to promote business investment.

column1: This cash rebate to individuals amounts to 12 percent of 1974 tax payments--a total cut of $12 billion
column2: with a maximum of $1
column3: 000 per return.

column1: I call on the Congress to act by April 1. If you do--and I hope you will--the Treasury can send the first check for half of the rebate in May and the second by September.
The other one-fourth of the cut
column2: about $4 billion
column3: will go to business
column4: including farms
column5: to promote expansion and to create more jobs.

column1: The 1-year reduction for businesses would be in the form of a liberalized investment tax credit increasing the rate to 12 percent for all businesses.
This tax cut does not include the more fundamental reforms needed in our tax system. But it points us in the right direction--allowing taxpayers rather than the Government to spend their pay.
Cutting taxes now is essential if we are to turn the economy around. A tax cut offers the best hope of creating more jobs. Unfortunately
column2: it will increase the size of the budget deficit. Therefore
column3: it is more important than ever that we take steps to control the growth of Federal expenditures.

column1: Part of our trouble is that we have been self-indulgent. For decades
column2: we have been voting ever-increasing levels of Government benefits
column3: and now the bill has come due. We have been adding so many new programs that the size and the growth of the Federal budget has taken on a life of its own.

column1: One characteristic of these programs is that their cost increases automatically every year because the number of people eligible for most of the benefits increases every year. When these programs are enacted
column2: there is no dollar amount set. No one knows what they will cost. All we know is that whatever they cost last year
column3: they will cost more next year.

column1: It is a question of simple arithmetic. Unless we check the excessive growth of Federal expenditures or impose on ourselves matching increases in taxes
column2: we will continue to run huge inflationary deficits in the Federal budget.

column1: If we project the current built-in momentum of Federal spending through the next 15 years
column2: State
column3: Federal
column4: and local government expenditures could easily comprise half of our gross national product. This compares with less than a third in 1975.

column1: I have just concluded the process of preparing the budget submissions for fiscal year 1976. In that budget
column2: I will propose legislation to restrain the growth of a number of existing programs. I have also concluded that no new spending programs can be initiated this year
column3: except for energy. Further
column4: I will not hesitate to veto any new spending programs adopted by the Congress.

column1: As an additional step toward putting the Federal Government's house in order
column2: I recommend a 5-percent limit on Federal pay increases in 1975. In all Government programs tied to the Consumer Price Index--including social security
column3: civil service and military retirement pay
column4: and food stamps--I also propose a 1-year maximum increase of 5 percent.

column1: None of these recommended ceiling limitations
column2: over which Congress has final authority
column3: are easy to propose
column4: because in most cases they involve anticipated payments to many
column5: many deserving people. Nonetheless
column6: it must be done. I must emphasize that I am not asking to eliminate
column7: to reduce
column8: to freeze these payments. I am merely recommending that we slow down the rate at which these payments increase and these programs grow.

column1: Only a reduction in the growth of spending can keep Federal borrowing down and reduce the damage to the private sector from high interest rates. Only a reduction in spending can make it possible for the Federal Reserve System to avoid an inflationary growth in the money supply and thus restore balance to our economy. A major reduction in the growth of Federal spending can help dispel the uncertainty that so many feel about our economy and put us on the way to curing our economic ills.
If we don't act to slow down the rate of increase in Federal spending
column2: the United States Treasury will be legally obligated to spend more than $360 billion in fiscal year 1976
column3: even if no new programs are enacted. These are not matters of conjecture or prediction
column4: but again
column5: a matter of simple arithmetic. The size of these numbers and their implications for our everyday life and the health of our economic system are shocking.

column1: I submitted to the last Congress a list of budget deferrals and rescissions. There will be more cuts recommended in the budget that I will submit. Even so
column2: the level of outlays for fiscal year 1976 is still much
column3: much too high. Not only is it too high for this year but the decisions we make now will inevitably have a major and growing impact on expenditure levels in future years. I think this is a very fundamental issue that we
column4: the Congress and I
column5: must jointly solve.

column1: Economic disruptions we and others are experiencing stem in part from the fact that the world price of petroleum has quadrupled in the last year. But in all honesty
column2: we cannot put all of the blame on the oil-exporting nations. We
column3: the United States
column4: are not blameless. Our growing dependence upon foreign sources has been adding to our vulnerability for years and years
column5: and we did nothing to prepare ourselves for such an event as the embargo of 1973.

column1: During the 1960's
column2: this country had a surplus capacity of crude oil which we were able to make available to our trading partners whenever there was a disruption of supply. This surplus capacity enabled us to influence both supplies and prices of crude oil throughout the world. Our excess capacity neutralized any effort at establishing an effective cartel
column3: and thus the rest of the world was assured of adequate supplies of oil at reasonable prices.

column2: our surplus capacity had vanished
column3: and as a consequence
column4: the latent power of the oil cartel could emerge in full force. Europe and Japan
column5: both heavily dependent on imported oil
column6: now struggle to keep their economies in balance. Even the United States
column7: our country
column8: which is far more self-sufficient than most other industrial countries
column9: has been put under serious pressure.

column1: I am proposing a program which will begin to restore our country's surplus capacity in total energy. In this way
column2: we will be able to assure ourselves reliable and adequate energy and help foster a new world energy stability for other major consuming nations.

column1: But this Nation and
column2: in fact
column3: the world must face the prospect of energy difficulties between now and 1985. This program will impose burdens on all of us with the aim of reducing our consumption of energy and increasing our production. Great attention has been paid to the considerations of fairness
column4: and I can assure you that the burdens will not fall more harshly on those less able to bear them.

column1: I am recommending a plan to make us invulnerable to cutoffs of foreign oil. It will require sacrifices
column2: but it--and this is most important--it will work.

column1: I have set the following national energy goals to assure that our future is as secure and as productive as our past:
First
column2: we must reduce oil imports by 1 million barrels per day by the end of this year and by 2 million barrels per day by the end of 1977.

column1: Second
column2: we must end vulnerability to economic disruption by foreign suppliers by 1985.

column1: Third
column2: we must develop our energy technology and resources so that the United States has the ability to supply a significant share of the energy needs of the free world by the end of this century.

column1: To attain these objectives
column2: we need immediate action to cut imports. Unfortunately
column3: in the short term there are only a limited number of actions which can increase domestic supply. I will press for all of them.

column1: I urge quick action on the necessary legislation to allow commercial production at the Elk Hills
column2: California
column3: Naval Petroleum Reserve. In order that we make greater use of domestic coal resources
column4: I am submitting amendments to the Energy Supply and Environmental Coordination Act which will greatly increase the number of powerplants that can be promptly converted to coal.

column1: Obviously
column2: voluntary conservation continues to be essential
column3: but tougher programs are needed--and needed now. Therefore
column4: I am using Presidential powers to raise the fee on all imported crude oil and petroleum products. The crude oil fee level will be increased $1 per barrel on February 1
column5: by $2 per barrel on March 1
column6: and by $3 per barrel on April 1. I will take actions to reduce undue hardships on any geographical region. The foregoing are interim administrative actions. They will be rescinded when broader but necessary legislation is enacted.

column1: To that end
column2: I am requesting the Congress to act within 90 days on a more comprehensive energy tax program. It includes: excise taxes and import fees totaling $2 per barrel on product imports and on all crude oil; deregulation of new natural gas and enactment of a natural gas excise tax.

column1: I plan to take Presidential initiative to decontrol the price of domestic crude oil on April 1. I urge the Congress to enact a windfall profits tax by that date to ensure that oil producers do not profit unduly.
The sooner Congress acts
column2: the more effective the oil conservation program will be and the quicker the Federal revenues can be returned to our people.

column1: I am prepared to use Presidential authority to limit imports
column2: as necessary
column3: to guarantee success.

column1: I want you to know that before deciding on my energy conservation program
column2: I considered rationing and higher gasoline taxes as alternatives. In my judgment
column3: neither would achieve the desired results and both would produce unacceptable inequities.

column1: A massive program must be initiated to increase energy supply to cut demand
column2: and provide new standby emergency programs to achieve the independence we want by 1985. The largest part of increased oil production must come from new frontier areas on the Outer Continental Shelf and from the Naval Petroleum Reserve No. 4 in Alaska. It is the intent of this Administration to move ahead with exploration
column3: leasing
column4: and production on those frontier areas of the Outer Continental Shelf where the environmental risks are acceptable.

column1: Use of our most abundant domestic resource--coal--is severely limited. We must strike a reasonable compromise on environmental concerns with coal. I am submitting Clean Air Act amendments which will allow greater coal use without sacrificing clean air goals.
I vetoed the strip mining legislation passed by the last Congress. With appropriate changes
column2: I will sign a revised version when it comes to the White House.

column1: I am proposing a number of actions to energize our nuclear power program. I will submit legislation to expedite nuclear leasing and the rapid selection of sites.
In recent months
column2: utilities have cancelled or postponed over 60 percent of planned nuclear expansion and 30 percent of planned additions to non-nuclear capacity. Financing problems for that industry are worsening. I am therefore recommending that the 1-year investment tax credit of 12 percent be extended an additional 2 years to specifically speed the construction of powerplants that do not use natural gas or oil. I am also submitting proposals for selective reform of State utility commission regulations.

column1: To provide the critical stability for our domestic energy production in the face of world price uncertainty
column2: I will request legislation to authorize and require tariffs
column3: import quotas
column4: or price floors to protect our energy prices at levels which will achieve energy independence.

column1: Increasing energy supplies is not enough. We must take additional steps to cut long-term consumption. I therefore propose to the Congress: legislation to make thermal efficiency standards mandatory for all new buildings in the United States; a new tax credit of up to $150 for those homeowners who install insulation equipment; the establishment of an energy conservation program to help low-income families purchase insulation supplies; legislation to modify and defer automotive pollution standards for 5 years
column2: which will enable us to improve automobile gas mileage by 40 percent by 1980.

column1: These proposals and actions
column2: cumulatively
column3: can reduce our dependence on foreign energy supplies from 3 to 5 million barrels per day by 1985. To make the United States invulnerable to foreign disruption
column4: I propose standby emergency legislation and a strategic storage program of 1 billion barrels of oil for domestic needs and 300 million barrels for national defense purposes.

column1: I will ask for the funds needed for energy research and development activities. I have established a goal of 1 million barrels of synthetic fuels and shale oil production per day by 1985 together with an incentive program to achieve it.
I have a very deep belief in America's capabilities. Within the next 10 years
column2: my program envisions: 200 major nuclear powerplants; 250 major new coal mines; 150 major coal-fired powerplants; 30 major new oil refineries; 20 major new synthetic fuel plants; the drilling of many thousands of new oil wells; the insulation of 18 million homes; and the manufacturing and the sale of millions of new automobiles
column3: trucks
column4: and buses that use much less fuel.

column1: I happen to believe that we can do it. In another crisis--the one in 1942--President Franklin D. Roosevelt said this country would build 60
column2: 000 military aircraft. By 1943
column3: production in that program had reached 125
column4: 000 aircraft annually. They did it then. We can do it now.

column1: If the Congress and the American people will work with me to attain these targets
column2: they will be achieved and will be surpassed.

column1: From adversity
column2: let us seize opportunity. Revenues of some $30 billion from higher energy taxes designed to encourage conservation must be refunded to the American people in a manner which corrects distortions in our tax system wrought by inflation.

column1: People have been pushed into higher tax brackets by inflation
column2: with consequent reduction in their actual spending power. Business taxes are similarly distorted because inflation exaggerates reported profits
column3: resulting in excessive taxes.

column1: Accordingly
