column1: The tax reforms and the tax reductions go together. Only with the long overdue reforms will the full tax cut be advisable.
Almost $17 billion in income tax cuts will go to individuals. Ninety-six percent of all American taxpayers will see their taxes go down. For a typical family of four
column2: this means an annual saving of more than $250 a year
column3: or a tax reduction of about 20 percent. A further $2 billion cut in excise taxes will give more relief and also contribute directly to lowering the rate of inflation.

column1: And we will also provide strong additional incentives for business investment and growth through substantial cuts in the corporate tax rates and improvement in the investment tax credit.
Now
column2: these tax proposals will increase opportunity everywhere in the Nation. But additional jobs for the disadvantaged deserve special attention.

column1: We've already passed laws to assure equal access to the voting booth and to restaurants and to schools
column2: to housing
column3: and laws to permit access to jobs. But job opportunity-the chance to earn a decent livingis also a basic human right
column4: which we cannot and will not ignore.

column1: A major priority for our Nation is the final elimination of the barriers that restrict the opportunities available to women and also to black people and Hispanics and other minorities. We've come a long way toward that goal. But there is still much to do. What we inherited from the past must not be permitted to shackle us in the future.
I'll be asking you for a substantial increase in funds for public jobs for our young people
column2: and I also am recommending that the Congress continue the public service employment programs at more than twice the level of a year ago. When welfare reform is completed
column3: we will have more than a million additional jobs so that those on welfare who are able to work can work.

column1: However
column2: again
column3: we know that in our free society
column4: private business is still the best source of new jobs. Therefore
column5: I will propose a new program to encourage businesses to hire young and disadvantaged Americans. These young people only need skills and a chance in order to take their place in our economic system. Let's give them the chance they need. A major step in the right direction would be the early passage of a greatly improved Humphrey-Hawkins bill.

column1: My budget for 1979 addresses these national needs
column2: but it is lean and tight. I have cut waste wherever possible.

column1: I am proposing an increase of less than 2 percent after adjusting for inflation-the smallest increase in the Federal budget in 4 years.
Lately
column2: Federal spending has taken a steadily increasing portion of what Americans produce. Our new budget reverses that trend
column3: and later I hope to bring the Government's toll down even further. And with your help
column4: we'll do that.

column1: In time of high employment and a strong economy
column2: deficit spending should not be a feature of our budget. As the economy continues to gain strength and as our unemployment rates continue to fall
column3: revenues will grow. With careful planning
column4: efficient management
column5: and proper restraint on spending
column6: we can move rapidly toward a balanced budgetand we will.

column1: Next year the budget deficit will be only slightly less than this year. But one-third of the deficit is due to the necessary tax cuts that I've proposed. This year the right choice is to reduce the burden on taxpayers and provide more jobs for our people.

The third element in our program is a renewed attack on inflation. We've learned the hard way that high unemployment will not prevent or cure inflation. Government can help us by stimulating private investment and by maintaining a responsible economic policy. Through a new top-level review process
column2: we will do a better job of reducing Government regulation that drives up costs and drives up prices.

column1: But again
column2: Government alone cannot bring down the rate of inflation. When a level of high inflation is expected to continue
column3: then companies raise prices to protect their profit margins against prospective increases in wages and other costs
column4: while workers demand higher wages as protection against expected price increases. It's like an escalation in the arms race
column5: and understandably
column6: no one wants to disarm alone.

column1: Now
column2: no one firm or a group of workers can halt this process. It's an effort that we must all make together. I'm therefore asking government
column3: business
column4: labor
column5: and other groups to join in a voluntary program to moderate inflation by holding wage and price increases in each sector of the economy during 1978 below the average increases of the last 2 years.

column1: I do not believe in wage and price controls. A sincere commitment to voluntary constraint provides a wayperhaps the only wayto fight inflation without Government interference.
As I came into the Capitol tonight
column2: I saw the farmers
column3: my fellow farmers
column4: standing out in the snow. I'm familiar with their problem
column5: and I know from Congress action that you are too. When I was running Carters Warehouse
column6: we had spread on our own farms 5-10-15 fertilizer for about $40 a ton. The last time I was home
column7: the price was about $100 a ton. The cost of nitrogen has gone up 150 percent
column8: and the price of products that farmers sell has either stayed the same or gone down a little.

column1: Now
column2: this past year in 1977
column3: you
column4: the Congress
column5: and I together passed a new agricultural act. It went into effect October 1. It'll have its first impact on the 1978 crops. It will help a great deal. It'll add $6 1/2 billion or more to help the farmers with their price supports and target prices.

column1: Last year we had the highest level of exports of farm products in the history of our country$24 billion. We expect to have more this year. We'll be working together. But I think it's incumbent on us to monitor very carefully the farm situation and continue to work harmoniously with the farmers of our country. What's best for the farmers
column2: the farm families
column3: in the long run is also best for the consumers of our country.

column1: Economic success at home is also the key to success in our international economic policy. An effective energy program
column2: strong investment and productivity
column3: and controlled inflation will improve our trade balance and balance it
column4: and it will help to protect the integrity of the dollar overseas.

column1: By working closely with our friends abroad
column2: we can promote the economic health of the whole world
column3: with fair and balanced agreements lowering the barriers to trade.

column1: Despite the inevitable pressures that build up when the world economy suffers from high unemployment
column2: we must firmly resist the demands for self-defeating protectionism. But free trade must also be fair trade. And I am determined to protect American industry and American workers against foreign trade practices which are unfair or illegal.

column1: In a separate written message to Congress
column2: I've outlined other domestic initiatives
column3: such as welfare reform
column4: consumer protection
column5: basic education skills
column6: urban policy
column7: reform of our labor laws
column8: and national health care later on this year. I will not repeat these tonight. But there are several other points that I would like to make directly to you.

column1: During these past years
column2: Americans have seen our Government grow far from us.

column1: For some citizens
column2: the Government has almost become like a foreign country
column3: so strange and distant that we've often had to deal with it through trained ambassadors who have sometimes become too powerful and too influentiallawyers
column4: accountants
column5: and lobbyists. This cannot go on.

column1: We must have what Abraham Lincoln wanteda government for the people.
We've made progress toward that kind of government. You've given me the authority I requested to reorganize the Federal bureaucracy. And I am using that authority.

We've already begun a series of reorganization plans which will be completed over a period of 3 years. We have also proposed abolishing almost 500 Federal advisory and other commissions and boards. But I know that the American people are still sick and tired of Federal paperwork and redtape. Bit by bit we are chopping down the thicket of unnecessary Federal regulations by which Government too often interferes in our personal lives and our personal business. We've cut the public's Federal paperwork load by more than 12 percent in less than a year. And we are not through cutting.
We've made a good start on turning the gobbledygook of Federal regulations into plain English that people can understand. But we know that we still have a long way to go.
We've brought together parts of 11 Government agencies to create a new Department of Energy. And now it's time to take another major step by creating a separate Department of Education.
But even the best organized Government will only be as effective as the people who carry out its policies. For this reason
column2: I consider civil service reform to be absolutely vital. Worked out with the civil servants themselves
column3: this reorganization plan will restore the merit principle to a system which has grown into a bureaucratic maze. It will provide greater management flexibility and better rewards for better performance without compromising job security.

column1: Then and only then can we have a government that is efficient
column2: open
column3: and truly worthy of our people's understanding and respect. I have promised that we will have such a government
column4: and I intend to keep that promise.

column1: In our foreign policy
column2: the separation of people from government has been in the past a source of weakness and error. In a democratic system like ours
column3: foreign policy decisions must be able to stand the test of public examination and public debate. If we make a mistake in this administration
column4: it will be on the side of frankness and openness with the American people.

column1: In our modern world
column2: when the deaths of literally millions of people can result from a few terrifying seconds of destruction
column3: the path of national strength and security is identical to the path of peace.

column1: Tonight
column2: I am happy to report that because we are strong
column3: our Nation is at peace with the world.

column1: We are a confident nation. We've restored a moral basis for our foreign policy. .The very heart of our identity as a nation is our firm commitment to human rights.

We stand for human rights because we believe that government has as a purpose to promote the well-being of its citizens. This is true in our domestic policy; it's also true in our foreign policy. The world must know that in support of human rights
column2: the United States will stand firm.

column1: We expect no quick or easy results
column2: but there has been significant movement toward greater freedom and humanity in several parts of the world.

column1: Thousands of political prisoners have been freed. The leaders of the world-even our ideological adversariesnow see that their attitude toward fundamental human rights affects their standing in the international community
column2: and it affects their relations with the United States.

column1: To serve the interests of every American
column2: our foreign policy has three major goals.

column1: The first and prime concern is and will remain the security of our country.
Security is based on our national will
column2: and security is based on the strength of our Armed Forces. We have the will
column3: and militarily we are very strong.

column1: Security also comes through the strength of our alliances. We have reconfirmed our commitment to the defense of Europe
column2: and this year we will demonstrate that commitment by further modernizing and strengthening our military capabilities there.

column1: Security can also be enhanced by agreements with potential adversaries which reduce the threat of nuclear disaster while maintaining our own relative strategic capability.
In areas of peaceful competition with the Soviet Union
column2: we will continue to more than hold our own.

column1: At the same time
column2: we are negotiating with quiet confidence
column3: without haste
column4: with careful determination
column5: to ease the tensions between us and to ensure greater stability and security.

column1: The strategic arms limitation talks have been long and difficult. We want a mutual limit on both the quality and the quantity of the giant nuclear arsenals of both nations
column2: and then we want actual reductions in strategic arms as a major step toward the ultimate elimination of nuclear weapons from the face of the Earth.

column1: If these talks result in an agreement this yearand I trust they willI pledge to you that the agreement will maintain and enhance the stability of the world's strategic balance and the security of the United States.
For 30 years
column2: concerted but unsuccessful efforts have been made to ban the testing of atomic explosivesboth military weapons and peaceful nuclear devices.

column1: We are hard at work with Great Britain and the Soviet Union on an agreement which will stop testing and will protect our national security and provide for adequate verification of compliance. We are now making
column2: I believe
column3: good progress toward this comprehensive ban on nuclear explosions.

column1: We are also working vigorously to halt the proliferation of nuclear weapons among the nations of the world which do not now have them and to reduce the deadly global traffic in conventional arms sales. Our stand for peace is suspect if we are also the principal arms merchant of the world. so
column2: we've decided to cut down our arms transfers abroad on a year-by-year basis and to work with other major arms exporters to encourage their similar constraint.

column1: Every American has a stake in our second major goala world at peace. In a nuclear age
column2: each of us is threatened when peace is not secured everywhere. We are trying to promote harmony in those parts of the world where major differences exist among other nations and threaten international peace.

column1: In the Middle East
column2: we are contributing our good offices to maintain the momentum of the current negotiations and to keep open the lines of communication among the Middle Eastern leaders. The whole world has a great stake in the success of these efforts. This is a precious opportunity for a historic settlement of a longstanding conflictan opportunity which may never come again in our lifetime.

column1: Our role has been difficult and sometimes thankless and controversial. But it has been constructive and it has been necessary
column2: and it will continue.

column1: Our third major foreign policy goal is one that touches the life of every American citizen every dayworld economic growth and stability.
This requires strong economic performance by the industrialized democracies like ourselves and progress in resolving the global energy crisis. Last fall
column2: with the help of others
column3: we succeeded in our vigorous efforts to maintain the stability of the price of oil. But as many foreign leaders have emphasized to me personally and
column4: I am sure
column5: to you
column6: the greatest future contribution that America can make to the world economy would be an effective energy conservation program here at home. We will not hesitate to take the actions needed to protect the integrity of the American dollar.

column1: We are trying to develop a more just international system. And in this spirit
column2: we are supporting the struggle for human development in Africa
column3: in Asia
column4: and in Latin America.

column1: Finally
column2: the world is watching to see how we act on one of our most important and controversial items of businessapproval of the Panama Canal treaties. The treaties now before the Senate are the result of the work of four administrations-two Democratic
column3: two Republican.

column1: They guarantee that the canal will be open always for unrestricted use by the ships of the world. Our ships have the right to go to the head of the line for priority of passage in times of emergency or need. We retain the permanent right to defend the canal with our own military forces
column2: if necessary
column3: to guarantee its openness and its neutrality.

column1: The treaties are to the clear advantage of ourselves
column2: the Panamanians
column3: and the other users of the canal. Ratifying the Panama Canal treaties will demonstrate our good faith to the world
column4: discourage the spread of hostile ideologies in this hemisphere
column5: and directly contribute to the economic well-being and the security of the United States.

column1: I have to say that that's very welcome applause.
There were two moments on my recent journey which
column2: for me
column3: confirmed the final aims of our foreign policy and what it always must be.

column1: One was in a little village in India
column2: where I met a people as passionately attached to their rights and liberties as we are
column3: but whose children have a far smaller chance for good health or food or education or human fulfillment than a child born in this country.

column1: The other moment was in Warsaw
column2: capital of a nation twice devastated by war in this century. There
column3: people have rebuilt the city which war's destruction took from them. But what was new only emphasized clearly what was lost.

column1: What I saw in those two places crystalized for me the purposes of our own Nation's policy: to ensure economic justice
column2: to advance human rights
column3: to resolve conflicts without violence
column4: and to proclaim in our great democracy our constant faith in the liberty and dignity of human beings everywhere.

column1: We Americans have a great deal of work to do together. In the end
column2: how well we do that work will depend on the spirit in which we approach it. We must seek fresh answers
column3: unhindered by the stale prescriptions of the past.

column1: It has been said that our best years are behind us. But I say again that America's best is still ahead. We have emerged from bitter experiences chastened but proud
column2: confident once again
column3: ready to face challenges once again
column4: and united once again.

column1: We come together tonight at a solemn time. Last week the Senate lost a good and honest manLee Metcalf of Montana.
And today
column2: the flag of the United States flew at half-mast from this Capitol and from American installations and ships all over the world
column3: in mourning for Senator Hubert Humphrey.

column1: Because he exemplified so well the joy and the zest of living
column2: his death reminds us not so much of our own mortality
column3: but of the possibilities offered to us by life. He always looked to the future with a special American kind of confidence
column4: of hope and enthusiasm. And the best way that we can honor him is by following his example.

column1: Our taskto use the words of Senator Humphreyis "reconciliation
column2: rebuilding
column3: and rebirth."

column1: Reconciliation of private needs and interests into a higher purpose.
Rebuilding the old dreams of justice and liberty
column2: and country and community.

column1: Rebirth of our faith in the common good.
Each of us here tonightand all who are listening in your homesmust rededicate ourselves to serving the common good. We are a community
column2: a beloved community
column3: all of us. Our individual fates are linked
column4: our futures intertwined. And if we act in that knowledge and in that spirit
column5: together
column6: as the Bible says
column7: we can move mountains.

column1: Thank you very much.@
Jimmy Carter|The State of the Union Address Delivered Before a Joint Session of the Congress|1979-01-23|@Mr. President
column2: Mr. Speaker
column3: Members of the 96th Congress
column4: and my fellow citizens:

column1: Tonight I want to examine in a broad sense the state of our American Union-how we are building a new foundation for a peaceful and a prosperous world.
Our children who will be born this year will come of age in the 21st century. What kind of society
column2: what kind of world are we building for them? Will we ourselves be at peace? Will our children enjoy a better quality of life? Will a strong and united America still be a force for freedom and prosperity around the world?

column1: Tonight
column2: there is every sign that the state of our Union is sound.

column1: Our economy offers greater prosperity for more of our people than ever before. Real per capita income and real business profits have risen substantially in the last 2 years. Farm exports are setting an all-time record each year
column2: and farm income last year
column3: net farm income
column4: was up more than 25 percent.

column1: Our liberties are secure. Our military defenses are strong and growing stronger. And more importantly
column2: tonight
column3: America-our beloved countryis at peace.

column1: Our earliest national commitments
column2: modified and reshaped by succeeding generations
column3: have served us well. But the problems that we face today are different from those that confronted earlier generations of Americans. They are more subtle
column4: more complex
column5: and more interrelated. At home
column6: we are recognizing ever more clearly that government alone cannot solve these problems. And abroad
column7: few of them can be solved by the United States alone. But Americans as a united people
column8: working with our allies and friends
column9: have never been afraid to face problems and to solve problems
column10: either here or abroad.

column1: The challenge to us is to build a new and firmer foundation for the futurefor a sound economy
column2: for a more effective government
column3: for more political trust
column4: and for a stable peaceso that the America our children inherit will be even stronger and even better than it is today.

column1: We cannot resort to simplistic or extreme solutions which substitute myths for common sense.
In our economy
column2: it is a myth that we must choose endlessly between inflation and recession. Together
column3: we build the foundation for a strong economy
column4: with lower inflation
column5: without contriving either a recession with its high unemployment or unworkable
column6: mandatory government controls.

column1: In our government
column2: it is a myth that we must choose between compassion and competence. Together
column3: we build the foundation for a government that worksand works for people.

column1: In our relations with our potential adversaries
column2: it is a myth that we must choose between confrontation and capitulation. Together
column3: we build the foundation for a stable world of both diversity and peace.

column1: Together
column2: we've already begun to build the foundation for confidence in our economic system. During the last 2 years
column3: in bringing our economy out of the deepest recession since the 1930's
column4: we've created 7
column6: 000 new jobs. The unemployment rate has gone down 25 percent. And now we must redouble our fight against the persistent inflation that has wracked our country for more than a decade. That's our important domestic issue
column7: and we must do it together.

column1: We know that inflation is a burden for all Americans
column2: but it's a disaster for the poor
column3: the sick
column4: and the old. No American family should be forced to choose among food
column5: warmth
column6: health care
column7: or decent housing because the cost of any of these basic necessities has climbed out of reach.

column1: Three months ago
column2: I outlined to the Nation a balanced anti-inflation program that couples responsible government restraint with responsible wage and price restraint. It's based upon my knowledge that there is a more powerful force than government compulsionthe force created by the cooperative efforts of millions of Americans working toward a common goal.

column1: Business and labor have been increasingly supportive. It's imperative that we in government do our part. We must stop excessive government growth
column2: and we must control government spending habits.

column1: I've sent to this Congress a stringent but a fair budget
column2: one that
column3: since I ran for President in 1976
column4: will have cut the Federal deficit in half. And as a percentage of our gross national product
column5: the deficit will have dropped by almost 75 percent.

column1: This Congress had a good record last year
column2: and I now ask the 96th Congress to continue this partnership in holding the line on excess Federal spending. It will not be easy. But we must be strong
column3: and we must be persistent.

column1: This budget is a clear message that
column2: with the help of you and the American people
column3: I am determined
column4: as President
column5: to bring inflation under control.

column1: The 1980 budget provides enough spending restraint to begin unwinding inflation
column2: but enough support for our country to keep American workers productive and to encourage the investments that provide new jobs. We will continue to mobilize our Nation's resources to reduce our trade deficit substantially this year and to maintain the strength of the American dollar.

column1: We've demonstrated in this restrained budget that we can build on the gains of the past 2 years to provide additional support to educate disadvantaged children
column2: to care for the elderly
column3: to provide nutrition and legal services for the poor
column4: and to strengthen the economic base of our urban communities and
column5: also
column6: our rural areas.

column1: This year
column2: we will take our first steps to develop a national health plan.

column1: We must never accept a permanent group of unemployed Americans
column2: with no hope and no stake in building our society. For those left out of the economy because of discrimination
column3: a lack of skills
column4: or poverty
column5: we must maintain high levels of training
column6: and we must continue to provide jobs.

column1: A responsible budget is not our only weapon to control inflation. We must act now to protect all Americans from health care costs that are rising $1 million per hour
column2: 24 hours a day
column3: doubling every 5 years. We must take control of the largest contributor to that inflationskyrocketing hospital costs.

column1: There will be no clearer test of the commitment of this Congress to the anti-inflation fight than the legislation that I will submit again this year to hold down inflation in hospital care.
Over the next 5 years
column2: my proposals will save Americans a total of $60 billion
column3: of which $25 billion will be savings to the American taxpayer in the Federal budget itself. The American people have waited long enough. This year we must act on hospital cost containment.

column1: We must also fight inflation by improvements and better enforcement of our antitrust laws and by reducing government obstacles to competition in the private sector.
We must begin to scrutinize the overall effect of regulation in our economy. Through deregulation of the airline industry we've increased profits
column2: cut prices for all Americans
column3: and begunfor one of the few times in the history of our Nation-to actually dismantle a major Federal bureaucracy. This year
column4: we must begin the effort to reform our regulatory processes for the railroad
column5: bus
column6: and the trucking industries.

column1: America has the greatest economic system in the world. Let's reduce government interference and give it a chance to work.
I call on Congress to take other anti-inflation actionto expand our exports to protect American jobs threatened by unfair trade
column2: to conserve energy
column3: to increase production and to speed development of solar power
column4: and to reassess our Nation's technological superiority. American workers who enlist in the fight against inflation deserve not just our gratitude
column5: but they deserve the protection of the real wage insurance proposal that I have already made to the Congress.

column1: To be successful
column2: we must change our attitudes as well as our policies. We cannot afford to live beyond our means. We cannot afford to create programs that we can neither manage nor finance
column3: or to waste our natural resources
column4: and we cannot tolerate mismanagement and fraud. Above all
column5: we must meet the challenges of inflation as a united people.

column1: With the support of the American people
column2: government in recent decades has helped to dismantle racial barriers
column3: has provided assistance for the jobless and the retired
column4: has fed the hungry
column5: has protected the safety
column6: health
column7: and bargaining rights of American workers
column8: and has helped to preserve our natural heritage.

column1: But it's not enough to have created a lot of government programs. Now we must make the good programs more effective and improve or weed out those which are wasteful or unnecessary.
With the support of the Congress
column2: we've begun to reorganize and to get control of the bureaucracy. We are reforming the civil service system
column3: so that we can recognize and reward those who do a good job and correct or remove those who do not.

column1: This year
column2: we must extend major reorganization efforts to education
column3: to economic development
column4: and to the management of our natural resources. We need to enact a sunshine law that when government programs have outlived their value
column5: they will automatically be terminated.

column1: There's no such thing as an effective and a noncontroversial reorganization and reform. But we know that honest
column2: effective government is essential to restore public faith in our public action.

column1: None of us can be satisfied when twothirds of the American citizens chose not to vote last year in a national election. Too many Americans feel powerless against the influence of private lobbying groups and the unbelievable flood of private campaign money which threatens our electoral process.
This year
column2: we must regain the public's faith by requiring limited financial funds from public funds for congressional election campaigns. House bill 1 provides for this public financing of campaigns. And I look forward with a great deal of anticipation to signing it at an early date.

column1: A strong economy and an effective government will restore confidence in America. But the path of the future must be charted in peace. We must continue to build a new and a firm foundation for a stable world community.
We are building that new foundation from a position of national strengththe strength of our own defenses
column2: the strength of our friendships with other nations
column3: and of our oldest American ideals.

column1: America's military power is a major force for security and stability in the world. We must maintain our strategic capability and continue the progress of the last 2 years with our NATO Allies
column2: with whom we have increased our readiness
column3: modernized our equipment
column4: and strengthened our defense forces in Europe. I urge you to support the strong defense budget which I have proposed to the Congress.

column1: But our national security in this complicated age requires more than just military might. In less than a lifetime
column2: world population has more than doubled
column3: colonial empires have disappeared
column4: and a hundred new nations have been born. Mass communications
column5: literacy
column6: and migration to the world's cities have all awakened new yearnings for economic justice and human rights among people everywhere.

column1: This demand for justice and human rights is a wave of the future. In such a world
column2: the choice is not which super power will dominate the world. None can and none will. The choice instead is between a world of anarchy and destruction
column3: or a world of cooperation and peace.

column1: In such a world
column2: we seek not to stifle inevitable change
column3: but to influence its course in helpful and constructive ways that enhance our values
column4: our national interests
column5: and the cause of peace.

column1: Towering over this volatile
column2: changing world
column3: like a thundercloud on a summer day
column4: looms the awesome power of nuclear weapons.

column1: We will continue to help shape the forces of change
column2: to anticipate emerging problems of nuclear proliferation and conventional arms sales
column3: and to use our great strength and influence to settle international conflicts in other parts of the world before they erupt and spread.

column1: We have no desire to be the world's policeman. But America does want to be the world's peacemaker.
We are building the foundation for truly global cooperation
column2: not only with Western and industrialized nations but with the developing countries as well. Our ties with Japan and our European allies are stronger than ever
column3: and so are our friendly relations with the people of Latin America
column4: Africa
column5: and the Western Pacific and Asia.

column1: We've won new respect in this hemisphere with the Panama Canal treaties. We've gained new trust with the developing world through our opposition to racism
column2: our commitment to human rights
column3: and our support for majority rule in Africa.

column1: The multilateral trade negotiations are now reaching a successful conclusion
column2: and congressional approval is essential to the economic well-being of our own country and of the world. This will be one of our top priorities in 1979.

column1: We are entering a hopeful era in our relations with one-fourth of the world's people who live in China. The presence of Vice Premier Deng Xiaoping next week will help to inaugurate that new era. And with prompt congressional action on authorizing legislation
column2: we will continue our commitment to a prosperous
column3: peaceful
column4: and secure life for the people of Taiwan.

column1: I'm grateful that in the past year
column2: as in the year before
column3: no American has died in combat anywhere in the world. And in Iran
column4: Nicaragua
column5: Cyprus
column6: Namibia
column7: and Rhodesia
column8: our country is working for peaceful solutions to dangerous conflicts.

column1: In the Middle East
column2: under the most difficult circumstances
column3: we have sought to help ancient enemies lay aside deep-seated differences that have produced four bitter wars in our lifetime.

column1: Our firm commitment to Israel's survival and security is rooted in our deepest convictions and in our knowledge of the strategic importance to our own Nation of a stable Middle East. To promote peace and reconciliation in the region
column2: we must retain the trust and the confidence both of Israel and also of the Arab nations that are sincerely searching for peace.

column1: I am determined
column2: as President
column3: to use the full
column4: beneficial influence of our country so that the precious opportunity for lasting peace between Israel and Egypt will not be lost. The new foundation of international cooperation that we seek excludes no nation. Cooperation with the Soviet Union serves the cause of peace
column5: for in this nuclear age
column6: world peace must include peace between the super powersand it must mean the control of nuclear arms.

column1: Ten years ago
column2: the United States and the Soviet Union made the historic decision to open the strategic arms limitations talks
column3: or SALT. The purpose of SALT
column4: then as now
column5: is not to gain a unilateral advantage for either nation
column6: but to protect the security of both nations
column7: to reverse the costly and dangerous momentum of the nuclear arms race
column8: to preserve a stable balance of nuclear forces
column9: and to demonstrate to a concerned world that we are determined to help preserve the peace.

column1: The first SALT agreement was concluded in 1972. And since then
column2: during 6 years of negotiation by both Republican and Democratic leaders
column3: nearly all issues of SALT II have been resolved. If the Soviet Union continues to negotiate in good faith
column4: a responsible SALT agreement will be reached.

column1: It's important that the American people understand the nature of the SALT process.

SALT II is not based on sentiment; it's based on self-interestof the United States and of the Soviet Union. Both nations share a powerful common interest in reducing the threat of a nuclear war. I will sign no agreement which does not enhance our national security.
SALT II does not rely on trust; it will be verifiable. We have very sophisticated
column2: proven means
column3: including our satellites
column4: to determine for ourselves whether or not the Soviet Union is meeting its treaty obligations. I will sign no agreement which cannot he verified.

column1: The American nuclear deterrent will remain strong after SALT II. For example
column2: just one of our relatively invulnerable Poseidon submarinescomprising less than 2 percent of our total nuclear force of submarines
column3: aircraft
column4: and landbased missilescarries enough warheads to destroy every large- and medium-sized city in the Soviet Union. Our deterrent is overwhelming
column5: and I will sign no agreement unless our deterrent force will remain overwhelming.

column1: A SALT agreement
column2: of course
column3: cannot substitute for wise diplomacy or a strong defense
column4: nor will it end the danger of nuclear war. But it will certainly reduce that danger. It will strengthen our efforts to ban nuclear tests and to stop the spread of atomic weapons to other nations. And it can begin the process of negotiating new agreements which will further limit nuclear arms.

column1: The path of arms control
column2: backed by a strong defensethe path our Nation and every President has walked for 30 years-can lead to a world of law and of international negotiation and consultation in which all peoples might live in peace. In this year 1979
column3: nothing is more important than that the Congress and the people of the United States resolve to continue with me on that path of nuclear arms control and world peace. This is paramount.

column1: I've outlined some of the changes that have transformed the world and which are continuing as we meet here tonight. But we in America need not fear change. The values on which our Nation was foundedindividual liberty
column2: self-determination
column3: the potential for human fulfillment in freedomall of these endure. We find these democratic principles praised
column4: even in books smuggled out of totalitarian nations and on wallposters in lands which we thought were closed to our influence. Our country has regained its special place of leadership in the worldwide struggle for human rights. And that is a commitment that we must keep at home
column5: as well as abroad.

column1: The civil rights revolution freed all Americans
column2: black and white
column3: but its full promise still remains unrealized. I will continue to work with all my strength for equal opportunity for all Americans-and for affirmative action for those who carry the extra burden of past denial of equal opportunity.

column1: We remain committed to improving our labor laws to better protect the rights of American workers. And our Nation must make it clear that the legal rights of women as citizens are guaranteed under the laws of our land by ratifying the equal rights amendment.
As long as I'm President
column2: at home and around the world America's examples and America's influence will be marshaled to advance the cause of human rights.

column1: To establish those values
column2: two centuries ago a bold generation of Americans risked their property
column3: their position
column4: and life itself. We are their heirs
column5: and they are sending us a message across the centuries. The words they made so vivid are now growing faintly indistinct
column6: because they are not heard often enough. They are words like "justice
column7: equality
column8: unity
column9: truth
column10: sacrifice
column11: liberty
column12: faith
column13: and love."

column1: These words remind us that the duty of our generation of Americans is to renew our Nation's faithnot focused just against foreign threats but against the threats of selfishness
column2: cynicism
column3: and apathy.

column1: The new foundation I've discussed tonight can help us build a nation and a world where every child is nurtured and can look to the future with hope
column2: where the resources now wasted on war can be turned towards meeting human needs
column3: where all people have enough to eat
column4: a decent home
column5: and protection against disease.

column1: It can help us build a nation and a world where all people are free to seek the truth and to add to human understanding
column2: so that all of us may live our lives in peace.

column1: Tonight
column2: I ask you
column3: the Members of the Congress
column4: to join me in building that new foundationa better foundation-for our beloved country and our world.

column1: Thank you very much.@
Jimmy Carter|The State of the Union Address Delivered Before a Joint Session of the Congress|1980-01-23|@Mr. President
column2: Mr. Speaker
column3: Members of the 96th Congress
column4: fellow citizens:

column1: This last few months has not been an easy time for any of us. As we meet tonight
column2: it has never been more clear that the state of our Union depends on the state of the world. And tonight
column3: as throughout our own generation
column4: freedom and peace in the world depend on the state of our Union.

column1: The 1980's have been born in turmoil
column2: strife
column3: and change. This is a time of challenge to our interests and our values and it's a time that tests our wisdom and our skills.

column1: At this time in Iran
column2: 50 Americans are still held captive
column3: innocent victims of terrorism and anarchy. Also at this moment
column4: massive Soviet troops are attempting to subjugate the fiercely independent and deeply religious people of Afghanistan. These two actsone of international terrorism and one of military aggression-present a serious challenge to the United States of America and indeed to all the nations of the world. Together
column5: we will meet these threats to peace.

column1: I'm determined that the United States will remain the strongest of all nations
column2: but our power will never be used to initiate a threat to the security of any nation or to the rights of any human being. We seek to be and to remain securea nation at peace in a stable world. But to be secure we must face the world as it is.

column1: Three basic developments have helped to shape our challenges: the steady growth and increased projection of Soviet military power beyond its own borders; the overwhelming dependence of the Western democracies on oil supplies from the Middle East; and the press of social and religious and economic and political change in the many nations of the developing world
column2: exemplified by the revolution in Iran.

column1: Each of these factors is important in its own right. Each interacts with the others. All must be faced together
column2: squarely and courageously. We will face these challenges
column3: and we will meet them with the best that is in us. And we will not fail.

column1: In response to the abhorrent act in Iran
column2: our Nation has never been aroused and unified so greatly in peacetime. Our position is clear. The United States will not yield to blackmail.

column1: We continue to pursue these specific goals: first
column2: to protect the present and long-range interests of the United States; secondly
column3: to preserve the lives of the American hostages and to secure
column4: as quickly as possible
column5: their safe release
column6: if possible
column7: to avoid bloodshed which might further endanger the lives of our fellow citizens; to enlist the help of other nations in condemning this act of violence
column8: which is shocking and violates the moral and the legal standards of a civilized world; and also to convince and to persuade the Iranian leaders that the real danger to their nation lies in the north
column9: in the Soviet Union and from the Soviet troops now in Afghanistan
column10: and that the unwarranted Iranian quarrel with the United States hampers their response to this far greater danger to them.

column1: If the American hostages are harmed
column2: a severe price will be paid. We will never rest until every one of the American hostages are released.

column1: But now we face a broader and more fundamental challenge in this region because of the recent military action of the Soviet Union.
Now
column2: as during the last 3 1/2 decades
column3: the relationship between our country
column4: the United States of America
column5: and the Soviet Union is the most critical factor in determining whether the world will live at peace or be engulfed in global conflict.

column1: Since the end of the Second World War
column2: America has led other nations in meeting the challenge of mounting Soviet power. This has not been a simple or a static relationship. Between us there has been cooperation
column3: there has been competition
column4: and at times there has been confrontation.

column1: In the 1940's we took the lead in creating the Atlantic Alliance in response to the Soviet Union's suppression and then consolidation of its East European empire and the resulting threat of the Warsaw Pact to Western Europe.
In the 1950's we helped to contain further Soviet challenges in Korea and in the Middle East
column2: and we rearmed to assure the continuation of that containment.

column1: In the 1960's we met the Soviet challenges in Berlin
column2: and we faced the Cuban missile crisis. And we sought to engage the Soviet Union in the important task of moving beyond the cold war and away from confrontation.

column1: And in the 1970's three American Presidents negotiated with the Soviet leaders in attempts to halt the growth of the nuclear arms race. We sought to establish rules of behavior that would reduce the risks of conflict
column2: and we searched for areas of cooperation that could make our relations reciprocal and productive
column3: not only for the sake of our two nations but for the security and peace of the entire world.

column1: In all these actions
column2: we have maintained two commitments: to be ready to meet any challenge by Soviet military power
column3: and to develop ways to resolve disputes and to keep the peace.

column1: Preventing nuclear war is the foremost responsibility of the two superpowers. That's why we've negotiated the strategic arms limitation treatiesSALT I and SALT II. Especially now
column2: in a time of great tension
column3: observing the mutual constraints imposed by the terms of these treaties will be in the best interest of both countries and will help to preserve world peace. I will consult very closely with the Congress on this matter as we strive to control nuclear weapons. That effort to control nuclear weapons will not be abandoned.

column1: We superpowers also have the responsibility to exercise restraint in the use of our great military force. The integrity and the independence of weaker nations must not be threatened. They must know that in our presence they are secure.

But now the Soviet Union has taken a radical and an aggressive new step. It's using its great military power against a relatively defenseless nation. The implications of the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan could pose the most serious threat to the peace since the Second World War.

The vast majority of nations on Earth have condemned this latest Soviet attempt to extend its colonial domination of others and have demanded the immediate withdrawal of Soviet troops. The Moslem world is especially and justifiably outraged by this aggression against an Islamic people. No action of a world power has ever been so quickly and so overwhelmingly condemned. But verbal condemnation is not enough. The Soviet Union must pay a concrete price for their aggression.
While this invasion continues
column2: we and the other nations of the world cannot conduct business as usual with the Soviet Union. That's why the United States has imposed stiff economic penalties on the Soviet Union. I will not issue any permits for Soviet ships to fish in the coastal waters of the United States. I've cut Soviet access to high-technology equipment and to agricultural products. I've limited other commerce with the Soviet Union
column3: and I've asked our allies and friends to join with us in restraining their own trade with the Soviets and not to replace our own embargoed items. And I have notified the Olympic Committee that with Soviet invading forces in Afghanistan
column4: neither the American people nor I will support sending an Olympic team to Moscow.

column1: The Soviet Union is going to have to answer some basic questions: Will it help promote a more stable international environment in which its own legitimate
column2: peaceful concerns can be pursued? Or will it continue to expand its military power far beyond its genuine security needs
column3: and use that power for colonial conquest? The Soviet Union must realize that its decision to use military force in Afghanistan will be costly to every political and economic relationship it values.

column1: The region which is now threatened by Soviet troops in Afghanistan is of great strategic importance: It contains more than two-thirds of the world's exportable oil. The Soviet effort to dominate Afghanistan has brought Soviet military forces to within 300 miles of the Indian Ocean and close to the Straits of Hormuz
column2: a waterway through which most of the world's oil must flow. The Soviet Union is now attempting to consolidate a strategic position
column3: therefore
column4: that poses a grave threat to the free movement of Middle East oil.

column1: This situation demands careful thought
column2: steady nerves
column3: and resolute action
column4: not only for this year but for many years to come. It demands collective efforts to meet this new threat to security in the Persian Gulf and in Southwest Asia. It demands the participation of all those who rely on oil from the Middle East and who are concerned with global peace and stability. And it demands consultation and close cooperation with countries in the area which might be threatened.

column1: Meeting this challenge will take national will
column2: diplomatic and political wisdom
column3: economic sacrifice
column4: and
column5: of course
column6: military capability. We must call on the best that is in us to preserve the security of this crucial region.

column1: Let our position be absolutely clear: An attempt by any outside force to gain control of the Persian Gulf region will be regarded as an assault on the vital interests of the United States of America
column2: and such an assault will be repelled by any means necessary
column3: including military force.

column1: During the past 3 years
column2: you have joined with me to improve our own security and the prospects for peace
column3: not only in the vital oil-producing area of the Persian Gulf region but around the world. We've increased annually our real commitment for defense
column4: and we will sustain this increase of effort throughout the Five Year Defense Program. It's imperative that Congress approve this strong defense budget for 1981
column5: encompassing a 5-percent real growth in authorizations
column6: without any reduction.

column1: We are also improving our capability to deploy U.S. military forces rapidly to distant areas. We've helped to strengthen NATO and our other alliances
column2: and recently we and other NATO members have decided to develop and to deploy modernized
column3: intermediate-range nuclear forces to meet an unwarranted and increased threat from the nuclear weapons of the Soviet Union.

column1: We are working with our allies to prevent conflict in the Middle East. The peace treaty between Egypt and Israel is a notable achievement which represents a strategic asset for America and which also enhances prospects for regional and world peace. We are now engaged in further negotiations to provide full autonomy for the people of the West Bank and Gaza
column2: to resolve the Palestinian issue in all its aspects
column3: and to preserve the peace and security of Israel. Let no one doubt our commitment to the security of Israel. In a few days we will observe an historic event when Israel makes another major withdrawal from the Sinai and when Ambassadors will be exchanged between Israel and Egypt.

column1: We've also expanded our own sphere of friendship. Our deep commitment to human rights and to meeting human needs has improved our relationship with much of the Third World. Our decision to normalize relations with the People's Republic of China will help to preserve peace and stability in Asia and in the Western Pacific.
We've increased and strengthened our naval presence in the Indian Ocean
column2: and we are now making arrangements for key naval and air facilities to be used by our forces in the region of northeast Africa and the Persian Gulf.

column1: We've reconfirmed our 1959 agreement to help Pakistan preserve its independence and its integrity. The United States will take action consistent with our own laws to assist Pakistan in resisting any outside aggression. And I'm asking the Congress specifically to reaffirm this agreement. I'm also working
column2: along with the leaders of other nations
column3: to provide additional military and economic aid for Pakistan. That request will come to you in just a few days.

column1: In the weeks ahead
column2: we will further strengthen political and military ties with other nations in the region. We believe that there are no irreconcilable differences between us and any Islamic nation. We respect the faith of Islam
column3: and we are ready to cooperate with all Moslem countries.

column1: Finally
column2: we are prepared to work with other countries in the region to share a cooperative security framework that respects differing values and political beliefs
column3: yet which enhances the independence
column4: security
column5: and prosperity of all.

column1: All these efforts combined emphasize our dedication to defend and preserve the vital interests of the region and of the nation which we represent and those of our alliesin Europe and the Pacific
column2: and also in the parts of the world which have such great strategic importance to us
column3: stretching especially through the Middle East and Southwest Asia. With your help
column4: I will pursue these efforts with vigor and with determination. You and I will act as necessary to protect and to preserve our Nation's security.

column1: The men and women of America's Armed Forces are on duty tonight in many parts of the world. I'm proud of the job they are doing
column2: and I know you share that pride. I believe that our volunteer forces are adequate for current defense needs
column3: and I hope that it will not become necessary to impose a draft. However
column4: we must be prepared for that possibility. For this reason
column5: I have determined that the Selective Service System must now be revitalized. I will send legislation and budget proposals to the Congress next month so that we can begin registration and then meet future mobilization needs rapidly if they arise.

column1: We also need clear and quick passage of a new charter to define the legal authority and accountability of our intelligence agencies. We will guarantee that abuses do not recur
column2: but we must tighten our controls on sensitive intelligence information
column3: and we need to remove unwarranted restraints on America's ability to collect intelligence.

column1: The decade ahead will be a time of rapid change
column2: as nations everywhere seek to deal with new problems and age-old tensions. But America need have no fear. We can thrive in a world of change if we remain true to our values and actively engaged in promoting world peace. We will continue to work as we have for peace in the Middle East and southern Africa. We will continue to build our ties with developing nations
column3: respecting and helping to strengthen their national independence which they have struggled so hard to achieve. And we will continue to support the growth of democracy and the protection of human rights.

column1: In repressive regimes
column2: popular frustrations often have no outlet except through violence. But when peoples and their governments can approach their problems together through open
column3: democratic methods
column4: the basis for stability and peace is far more solid and far more enduring. That is why our support for human rights in other countries is in our own national interest as well as part of our own national character.

column1: Peacea peace that preserves freedom-remains America's first goal. In the coming years
column2: as a mighty nation we will continue to pursue peace. But to be strong abroad we must be strong at home. And in order to be strong
column3: we must continue to face up to the difficult issues that confront us as a nation today.

column1: The crises in Iran and Afghanistan have dramatized a very important lesson: Our excessive dependence on foreign oil is a clear and present danger to our Nation's security. The need has never been more urgent. At long last
column2: we must have a clear
column3: comprehensive energy policy for the United States.

column1: As you well know
column2: I have been working with the Congress in a concentrated and persistent way over the past 3 years to meet this need. We have made progress together. But Congress must act promptly now to complete final action on this vital energy legislation. Our Nation will then have a major conservation effort
column3: important initiatives to develop solar power
column4: realistic pricing based on the true value of oil
column5: strong incentives for the production of coal and other fossil fuels in the United States
column6: and our Nation's most massive peacetime investment in the development of synthetic fuels.

column1: The American people are making progress in energy conservation. Last year we reduced overall petroleum consumption by 8 percent and gasoline consumption by 5 percent below what it was the year before. Now we must do more.
After consultation with the Governors
column2: we will set gasoline conservation goals for each of the 50 States
column3: and I will make them mandatory if these goals are not met.

column1: I've established an import ceiling for 1980 of 8.2 million barrels a daywell below the level of foreign oil purchases in 1977. I expect our imports to be much lower than this
column2: but the ceiling will be enforced by an oil import fee if necessary. I'm prepared to lower these imports still further if the other oil-consuming countries will join us in a fair and mutual reduction. If we have a serious shortage
column3: I will not hesitate to impose mandatory gasoline rationing immediately.

column1: The single biggest factor in the inflation rate last year
column2: the increase in the inflation rate last year
column3: was from one cause: the skyrocketing prices of OPEC oil. We must take whatever actions are necessary to reduce our dependence on foreign oil-and at the same time reduce inflation.

column1: As individuals and as families
column2: few of us can produce energy by ourselves. But all of us can conserve energyevery one of us
column3: every day of our lives. Tonight I call on youin fact
column4: all the people of Americato help our Nation. Conserve energy. Eliminate waste. Make 1980 indeed a year of energy conservation.

column1: Of course
column2: we must take other actions to strengthen our Nation's economy.

column1: First
column2: we will continue to reduce the deficit and then to balance the Federal budget.

column1: Second
column2: as we continue to work with business to hold down prices
column3: we'll build also on the historic national accord with organized labor to restrain pay increases in a fair fight against inflation.

column1: Third
column2: we will continue our successful efforts to cut paperwork and to dismantle unnecessary Government regulation.

column1: Fourth
column2: we will continue our progress in providing jobs for America
column3: concentrating on a major new program to provide training and work for our young people
column4: especially minority youth. It has been said that "a mind is a terrible thing to waste." We will give our young people new hope for jobs and a better life in the 1980's.

column1: And fifth
column2: we must use the decade of the 1980's to attack the basic structural weaknesses and problems in our economy through measures to increase productivity
column3: savings
column4: and investment.

column1: With these energy and economic policies
column2: we will make America even stronger at home in this decadejust as our foreign and defense policies will make us stronger and safer throughout the world. We will never abandon our struggle for a just and a decent society here at home. That's the heart of Americaand it's the source of our ability to inspire other people to defend their own rights abroad.

column1: Our material resources
column2: great as they are
column3: are limited. Our problems are too complex for simple slogans or for quick solutions. We cannot solve them without effort and sacrifice. Walter Lippmann once reminded us
column4: "You took the good things for granted. Now you must earn them again. For every right that you cherish
column5: you have a duty which you must fulfill. For every good which you wish to preserve
column6: you will have to sacrifice your comfort and your ease. There is nothing for nothing any longer."

column1: Our challenges are formidable. But there's a new spirit of unity and resolve in our country. We move into the 1980's with confidence and hope and a bright vision of the America we want: an America strong and free
column2: an America at peace
column3: an America with equal rights for all citizens-and for women
column4: guaranteed in the United States Constitutionan America with jobs and good health and good education for every citizen
column5: an America with a clean and bountiful life in our cities and on our farms
column6: an America that helps to feed the world
column7: an America secure in filling its own energy needs
column8: an America of justice
column9: tolerance
column10: and compassion. For this vision to come true
column11: we must sacrifice
column12: but this national commitment will be an exciting enterprise that will unify our people.

column1: Together as one people
column2: let us work to build our strength at home
column3: and together as one indivisible union
column4: let us seek peace and security throughout the world.

column1: Together let us make of this time of challenge and danger a decade of national resolve and of brave achievement.
Thank you very much.@
Ronald Reagan|Address Before a Joint Session of the Congress on the Program for Economic Recovery|1981-02-18|@Mr. Speaker
column2: Mr. President
column3: distinguished Members of Congress
column4: honored guests
column5: and fellow citizens:

column1: Only a month ago I was your guest in this historic building
column2: and I pledged to you my cooperation in doing what is right for this Nation that we all love so much. I'm here tonight to reaffirm that pledge and to ask that we share in restoring the promise that is offered to every citizen by this
column3: the last
column4: best hope of man on Earth.

column1: All of us are aware of the punishing inflation which has for the first time in 60 years held to double-digit figures for 2 years in a row. Interest rates have reached absurd levels of more that 20 percent and over 15 percent for those who would borrow to buy a home. All across this land one can see newly built homes standing vacant
column2: unsold because of mortgage interest rates.

column1: Almost 8 million Americans are out of work. These are people who want to be productive. But as the months go by
column2: despair dominates their lives. The threats of layoff and unemployment hang over other millions
column3: and all who work are frustrated by their inability to keep up with inflation.

column1: One worker in a Midwest city put it to me this way: He said
column2: "I'm bringing home more dollars than I ever believed I could possibly earn
column3: but I seem to be getting worse off." And he is. Not only have hourly earnings of the American worker
column4: after adjusting for inflation
column5: declined 5 percent over the past 5 years
column6: but in these 5 years
column7: Federal personal taxes for the average family have increased 67 percent. We can no longer procrastinate and hope that things will get better. They will not. Unless we act forcefullyand nowthe economy will get worse.

column1: Can we
column2: who man the ship of state
column3: deny it is somewhat out of control? Our national debt is approaching $1 trillion. A few weeks ago I called such a figure
column4: a trillion dollars
column5: incomprehensible
column6: and I've been trying ever since to think of a way to illustrate how big a trillion really is. And the best I could come up with is that if you had a stack of thousand-dollar bills in your hand only 4 inches high
column7: you'd be a millionaire. A trillion dollars would be a stack of thousand-dollar bills 67 miles high. The interest on the public debt this year we know will be over $90 billion
column8: and unless we change the proposed spending for the fiscal year beginning October 1st
column9: we'll add another almost $80 billion to the debt.

column1: Adding to our troubles is a mass of regulations imposed on the shopkeeper
column2: the farmer
column3: the craftsman
column4: professionals
column5: and major industry that is estimated to add $100 billion to the price of the things we buy
column6: and it reduces our ability to produce. The rate of increase in American productivity
column7: once one of the highest in the world
column8: is among the lowest of all major industrial nations. Indeed
column9: it has actually declined in the last 3 years.

column1: Now
column2: I've painted a pretty grim picture
column3: but I think I've painted it accurately. It is within our power to change this picture
column4: and we can act with hope. There's nothing wrong with our internal strengths. There has been no breakdown of the human
column5: technological
column6: and natural resources upon which the economy is built.

column1: Based on this confidence in a system which has never failed us
column2: but which we have failed through a lack of confidence and sometimes through a belief that we could fine-tune the economy and get it tuned to our liking
column3: I am proposing a comprehensive four-point program. Now
column4: let me outline in detail some of the principal parts of this program. You'll each be provided with a completely detailed copy of the entire program.

column1: This plan is aimed at reducing the growth in government spending and taxing
column2: reforming and eliminating regulations which are unnecessary and unproductive or counterproductive
column3: and encouraging a consistent monetary policy aimed at maintaining the value of the currency. If enacted in full
column4: this program can help America create 13 million new jobs
column5: nearly 3 million more than we would have without these measures. It will also help us to gain control of inflation.

column1: It's important to note that we're only reducing the rate of increase in taxing and spending. We're not attempting to cut either spending or taxing levels below that which we presently have. This plan will get our economy moving again
column2: [create] productivity growth
column3: and thus create the jobs that our people must have.

column1: And I'm asking that you join me in reducing direct Federal spending by $41.4 billion in fiscal year 1982
column2: and this goes along with another $7.7 billion in user fees and off-budget savings for a total of $49.1 billion. And this will still allow an increase of $40.8 billion over 1981 spending.

column1: Now
column2: I know that exaggerated and inaccurate stories about these cuts have disturbed many people
column3: particularly those dependent on grant and benefit programs for their basic needs. Some of you have heard from constituents
column4: I know
column5: afraid that social security checks
column6: for example
column7: were going to be taken away from them. Well
column8: I regret the fear that these unfounded stories have caused
column9: and I welcome this opportunity to set things straight.

column1: We will continue to fulfill the obligations that spring from our national conscience. Those who
column2: through no fault of their own
column3: must depend on the rest of usthe poverty stricken
column4: the disabled
column5: the elderly
column6: all those with true needcan rest assured that the social safety net of programs they depend on are exempt from any cuts.

column1: The full retirement benefits of the more than 31 million social security recipients will be continued
column2: along with an annual cost-of-living increase. Medicare will not be cut
column3: nor will supplemental income for the blind
column4: the aged
column5: and the disabled. And funding will continue for veterans pensions. School breakfasts and lunches for the children of low-income families will continue
column6: as will nutrition and other special services for the aging. There will be no cut in Project Head Start or summer youth jobs.

column1: All in all
column2: nearly $216 billion worth of programs providing help for tens of millions of Americans will be fully funded. But government will not continue to subsidize individuals or particular business interests where real need cannot be demonstrated. And while we will reduce some subsidies to regional and local governments
column3: we will at the same time convert a number of categorical grant programs into block grants to reduce wasteful administrative overhead and to give local governments and States more flexibility and control. We call for an end in duplication to Federal programs and reform of those which are not cost-effective.

column1: Now
column2: already some have protested that there must be no reduction in aid to schools. Well
column3: let me point out that Federal aid to education amounts to only 8 percent of the total educational funding
column4: and for this 8 percent
column5: the Federal Government has insisted on tremendously disproportionate share of control over our schools. Whatever reductions we've proposed in that 8 percent will amount to very little in the total cost of education. They will
column6: however
column7: restore more authority to States and local school districts.

column1: Historically
column2: the American people have supported by voluntary contributions more artistic and cultural activities than all the other countries in the world put together. I wholeheartedly support this approach and believe that Americans will continue their generosity. Therefore
column3: I'm proposing a savings of $85 million in the Federal subsidies now going to the arts and humanities.

column1: There are a number of subsidies to business and industry that I believe are unnecessary
column2: not because the activities being subsidized aren't of value
column3: but because the marketplace contains incentives enough to warrant continuing these activities without a government subsidy. One such subsidy is the Department of Energy's synthetic fuels program. We will continue support of research leading to development of new technologies and more independence from foreign oil
column4: but we can save at least $3.2 billion by leaving to private industry the building of plants to make liquid or gas fuels from coal.

column1: We're asking that another major industrybusiness subsidy I should say
column2: the Export-Import Bank loan authority
column3: be reduced by one-third in 1982. We're doing this because the primary beneficiaries of taxpayer funds in this case are the exporting companies themselvesmost of them profitable corporations.

column1: This brings me to a number of other lending programs in which government makes low-interest loans
column2: some of them at an interest rate as low as 2 percent. What has not been very well understood is that the Treasury Department has no money of its own to lend; it has to go into the private capital market and borrow the money. So
column3: in this time of excessive interest rates
column4: the government finds itself borrowing at an interest rate several times as high as the interest it gets back from those it lends the money to. And this difference
column5: of course
column6: is paid by your constituentsthe taxpayers. They get hit again if they try to borrow
column7: because government borrowing contributes to raising all interest rates.

column1: By terminating the Economic Development Administration
column2: we can save hundreds of millions of dollars in 1982 and billions more over the next few years. There's a lack of consistent and convincing evidence that EDA and its Regional Commissions have been effective in creating new jobs. They have been effective in creating an array of planners
column3: grantsmen
column4: and professional middlemen. We believe we can do better just by the expansion of the economy and the job creation which will come from our economic program.

column1: The Food Stamp program will be restored to its original purpose
column2: to assist those without resources to purchase sufficient nutritional food. We will
column3: however
column4: save $1.8 billion in fiscal year 1982 by removing from eligibility those who are not in real need or who are abusing the program. But even with this reduction
column5: the program will be budgeted for more than $10 billion.

column1: We will tighten welfare and give more attention to outside sources of income when determining the amount of welfare that an individual is allowed. This
column2: plus strong and effective work requirements
column3: will save $520 million in the next year.

column1: I stated a moment ago our intention to keep the school breakfast and lunch programs for those in true need. But by cutting back on meals for children of families who can afford to pay
column2: the savings will be $1.6 billion in the fiscal year 1982.

column1: Now
column2: let me just touch on a few other areas which are typical of the kind of reductions we've included in this economic package. The Trade Adjustment Assistance program provides benefits for workers who are unemployed when foreign imports reduce the market for various American products
column3: causing shutdown of plants and layoff of workers. The purpose is to help these workers find jobs in growing sectors of our economy. There's nothing wrong with that
column4: but because these benefits are paid out on top of normal unemployment benefits
column5: we wind up paying greater benefits to those who lose their jobs because of foreign competition than we do to their friends and neighbors who are laid off due to domestic competition. Anyone must agree that this is unfair. Putting these two programs on the same footing will save $1.15 billion in just 1 year.

column1: Earlier I made mention of changing categorical grants to States and local governments into block grants. Now
column2: we know of course that the categorical grant programs burden local and State governments with a mass of Federal regulations and Federal paperwork. Ineffective targeting
column3: wasteful administrative overheadall can be eliminated by shifting the resources and decision-making authority to local and State government. This will also consolidate programs which are scattered throughout the Federal bureaucracy
column4: bringing government closer to the people and saving $23.9 billion over the next 5 years.

column1: Our program for economic renewal deals with a number of programs which at present are not cost-effective. An example is Medicaid. Right now Washington provides the States with unlimited matching payments for their expenditures; at the same time
column2: we here in Washington pretty much  dictate how the States are going to manage those programs. We want to put a cap on how much the Federal Government will contribute
column3: but at the same time allow the States much more flexibility in managing and structuring the programs. I know from our experience in California that such flexibility could have led to far more cost-effective reforms. Now
column4: this will bring a savings of $1 billion next year.

column1: The space program has been and is important to America
column2: and we plan to continue it. We believe
column3: however
column4: that a reordering of priorities to focus on the most important and cost-effective NASA programs can result in a savings of a quarter of a million dollars.

column1: Now
column2: coming down from space to the mailbox
column3: the Postal Service has been consistently unable to live within its operating budget. It is still dependent on large Federal subsidies. We propose reducing those subsidies by $632 million in 1982 to press the Postal Service into becoming more effective
column4: and in subsequent years the savings will continue to add up.

column1: The Economic Regulatory Administration in the Department of Energy has programs to force companies to convert to specific fuels. It has the authority to administer a gas rationing plan
column2: and prior to decontrol it ran the oil price control program. With these and other regulations gone we can save several hundreds of millions of dollars over the next few years.

column1: I'm sure there's one department you've been waiting for me to mention
column2: the Department of Defense. It's the only department in our entire program that will actually be increased over the present budgeted figure. But even here there was no exemption. The Department of Defense came up with a number of cuts which reduce the budget increase needed to restore our military balance. These measures will save $2.9 billion in 1982 outlays
column3: and by 1986 a total of $28.2 billion will have been savedor perhaps I should say
column4: will have been made available for the necessary things that we must do. The aim will be to provide the most effective defense for the lowest possible cost.

column1: I believe that my duty as President requires that I recommend increases in defense spending over the coming years.
