I know that you're all awarebut I think it bears saying againthat since 1970 the Soviet Union has invested $300 billion more in its military forces than we have. As a result of its massive military buildup
column2: the Soviets have made a significant numerical advantage in strategic nuclear delivery systems
column3: tactical aircraft
column4: submarines
column5: artillery
column6: and anti-aircraft defense. To allow this imbalance to continue is a threat to our national security. Notwithstanding our economic straits
column7: making the financial changes beginning now is far less costly than waiting and having to attempt a crash program several years from now.

column1: We remain committed to the goal of arms limitation through negotiation. I hope we can persuade our adversaries to come to realistic balanced and verifiable agreements. But
column2: as we negotiate
column3: our security must be fully protected by a balanced and realistic defense program.

column1: Now
column2: let me say a word here about the general problem of waste and fraud in the Federal Government. One government estimate indicated that fraud alone may account for anywhere from 1 to 10 percent-as much as $25 billion of Federal expenditures for social programs. If the tax dollars that are wasted or mismanaged are added to this fraud total
column3: the staggering dimensions of this problem begin to emerge.

column1: The Office of Management and Budget is now putting together an interagency task force to attack waste and fraud. We're also planning to appoint as Inspectors General highly trained professionals who will spare no effort to do this job. No administration can promise to immediately stop a trend that has grown in recent years as quickly as government expenditures themselves
column2: but let me say this: Waste and fraud in the Federal Government is exactly what I've called it beforean unrelenting national scandal
column3: a scandal we're bound and determined to do something about.

column1: Marching in lockstep with the whole program of reductions in spending is the equally important program of reduced tax rates. Both are essential if we're to have economic recovery. It's time to create new jobs
column2: to build and rebuild industry
column3: and to give the American people room to do what they do best. And that can only be done with a tax program which provides incentive to increase productivity for both workers and industry.

column1: Our proposal is for a 10-percent across the-board cut every year for 3 years in the tax rates for all individual income taxpayers
column2: making a total cut in the tax-cut rates of 30 percent. This 3-year reduction will also apply to the tax on unearned income
column3: leading toward an eventual elimination of the present differential between the tax on earned and unearned income.

column1: Now
column2: I would have hoped that we could be retroactive with this. But as it stands
column3: the effective starting date for these 10-percent personal income tax rate reductions will call for as of July 1st of this year.

column1: Again
column2: let me remind you that while this 30-percent reduction will leave the taxpayers with $500 billion more in their pockets over the next 5 years
column3: it's actually only a reduction in the tax increase already built into the system. Unlike some past "tax reforms
column4:
this is not merely a shift of wealth between different sets of taxpayers. This proposal for an equal reduction in everyone's tax rates will expand our national prosperity, enlarge national incomes, and increase opportunities for all Americans.
Some will argue, I know, that reducing tax rates now will be inflationary. A solid body of economic experts does not agree. And tax cuts adopted over the past three-fourths of a century indicate these economic experts are right. They will not be inflationary. I've had advice that in 1985 our real production in goods and services will grow by 20 percent and be $300 billion higher than it is today. The average worker's wage will rise in real purchasing power 8 percent, and this is in after-tax dollars. And this, of course, is predicated on a complete program of tax cuts and spending reductions being implemented.
The other part of the tax package is aimed directly at providing business and industry with the capital needed to modernize and engage in more research and development. This will involve an increase in depreciation allowances, and this part of our tax proposal will be retroactive to January 1st.
The present depreciation system is obsolete, needlessly complex, and economically counterproductive. Very simply, it bases the depreciation of plant machinery and vehicles and tools on their original cost, with no recognition of how inflation has increased their replacement cost. We're proposing a much shorter write-off time than is presently alloweda 5-year-write-off for machinery, 3 years for vehicles and trucks, and a 10-year write-off for plant. In fiscal year 1982 under this plan, business would acquire nearly $10 billion for investment; by 1985, the figure would be nearly 45 billion.
These changes are essential to provide the new investment which is needed to create millions of new jobs between now and 1985, and to make America competitive once again in the world market. These won't be make-work jobs. They are productive jobs, jobs with a future.
I'm well aware that there are many other desirable and needed tax changes, such as indexing the income tax brackets to protect taxpayers against inflation; the unjust discrimination against married couples if both are working and earning; tuition tax credits; the unfairness of the inheritance tax, especially to the family-owned farm and the family-owned business; and a number of others. But our program for economic recovery is so urgently needed to begin to bring down inflation that I'm asking you to act on this plan first and with great urgency. And then, I pledge I will join with you in seeking these additional tax changes at the earliest date possible.
American society experienced a virtual explosion in government regulation during the past decade. Between 1970 and 1979, expenditures for the major regulatory agencies quadrupled. The number of pages published annually in the Federal Register nearly tripled, and the number of pages in the Code of Federal Regulations increased by nearly two-thirds. The result has been higher prices, higher unemployment, and lower productivity growth. Overregulation causes small and independent business men and women, as well as large businesses to defer or terminate plans for expansion. And since they're responsible for most of the new jobs, those new jobs just aren't created.
Now, we have no intention of dismantling the regulatory agencies, especially those necessary to protect environment and assure the public health and safety. However, we must come to grips with inefficient and burdensome regulations, eliminate those we can and reform the others.
I have asked Vice President Bush to head a Cabinet-level Task Force on Regulatory Relief. Second, I asked each member of my Cabinet to postpone the effective dates of the hundreds of new regulations which have not yet been implemented. Third, in coordination with the Task Force, many of the agency heads have already taken prompt action to review and rescind existing burdensome regulations. And finally, just yesterday I signed an Executive order that for the first time provides for effective and coordinated management of the regulatory process.
Much has been accomplished, but it's only a beginning. We will eliminate those regulations that are unproductive and unnecessary by Executive order where possible and cooperate fully with you on those that require legislation.
The final aspect of our plan requires a national monetary policy which does not allow money growth to increase consistently faster than the growth of goods and services. In order to curb inflation we need to slow the growth in our money supply.
Now, we fully recognize the independence of the Federal Reserve System and will do nothing to interfere with or undermine that independence. We will consult regularly with the Federal Reserve Board on all aspects of our economic program and will vigorously pursue budget policies that'll make their job easier in reducing monetary growth. A successful program to achieve stable and and moderate growth patterns in the money supply will keep both inflation and interest rates down and restore vigor to our financial institutions and markets.
This, then, is our proposalAmerica's new beginning: a program for economic recovery. I don't want it to be simply the plan of my administration. I'm here tonight to ask you to join me in making it our plan. Together we can embark on this road.
Thank you very much. I should have arranged to quit right here.
Well, together we can embark on this road, not to make things easy, but to make things better. Our social, political, and cultural, as well as our economic institutions, can no longer absorb the repeated shocks that have been dealt them over the past decades. Can we do the job? column1: Today marks my first State of the Union address to you

Douglas MacArthur made an unforgettable farewell to a country he loved and served so well. Dwight Eisenhower reminded us that peace was purchased only at the price of strength. And John F. Kennedy spoke of the burden and glory that is freedom.

column1: When I visited this Chamber last year as a newcomer to Washington

column1: It's my duty to report to you tonight on the progress that we have made in our relations with other nations

column1: Seldom have the stakes been higher for America. What we do and say here will make all the difference to autoworkers in Detroit
column2: lumberjacks in the Northwest
column3: steelworkers in Steubenville who are in the unemployment lines; to black teenagers in Newark and Chicago; to hard-pressed farmers and small businessmen; and to millions of everyday Americans who harbor the simple wish of a safe and financially secure future for their children. column4: we must look not only at where we are and where we're going but where we've been. The situation at this time last year was truly ominous.

column3: and again in the spring of 1980. Each time
column4: unemployment increased and inflation soon turned up again. We coined the word "stagflation" to describe this.

column2: as an example
column3: the money supply increased at the fastest rate in postwar history13 percent. Inflation remained in double digits
column4: and government spending increased at an annual rate of 17 percent. Interest rates reached a staggering 21.5 percent. There were 8 million unemployed.

column1: Late in 1981 we sank into the present recession
column2: largely because continued high interest rates hurt the auto industry and construction. And there was a drop in productivity
column3: and the already high unemployment increased.

column1: This time
column2: however
column3: things are different. We have an economic program in place
column4: completely different from the artificial quick fixes of the past. It calls for a reduction of the rate of increase in government spending
column5: and already that rate has been cut nearly in half. But reduced spending the first and smallest phase of a 3-year tax rate reduction designed to stimulate the economy and create jobs. Already interest rates are down to 15 3/4 percent

column9: taxes

column1: A year ago

column3: and I believe that history will remember this as an era of American renewal

column1: Together

column1: Together
column2: after 50 years of taking power away from the hands of the people in their States and local communities

column1: Together

column1: Together
column2: we have created an effective Federal strike force to combat waste and fraud in government. In just 6 months it has saved the taxpayers more than $2 billion

column1: Together we've begun to mobilize the private sector

column1: Together we've begun to restore that margin of military safety that ensures peace. Our country's uniform is being worn once again with pride.
Together we have made a New Beginning

column1: The economy will face difficult moments in the months ahead. And that is why I can report to you tonight that in the near future the state of the Union and the economy will be bettermuch betterif we summon the strength to continue on the course that we've charted.
And so
column2: the question: If the fundamentals are in place

column5: we must understand what's happening at the moment to the economy. Our current problems are not the product of the recovery program that's only just now getting underway

column1: Second
column2: because our economic problems are deeply rooted and will not respond to quick political fixes
column3: we must stick to our carefully integrated plan for recovery. That plan is based on four commonsense fundamentals: continued reduction of the growth in Federal spending; preserving the individual and business tax reductions that will stimulate saving and investment; removing unnecessary Federal regulations to spark productivity; and maintaining a healthy dollar and a stable monetary policy
column4: the latter a responsibility of the Federal Reserve System.

column9: surely

Just 2 weeks ago, in the midst of a terrible tragedy on the Potomac, we saw again the spirit of American heroism at its finestthe heroism of dedicated rescue workers saving crash victims from icy waters. And we saw the heroism of one of our young government employees, Lenny Skutnik, who, when he saw a woman lose her grip on the helicopter line, dived into the water and dragged her to safety.
And then there are countless, quiet, everyday heroes of American life--parents who sacrifice long and hard so their children will know a better life than they've known; church and civic volunteers who help to feed, clothe, nurse, and teach the needy; millions who've made our nation and our nation's destiny so very special-unsung heroes who may not have realized their own dreams themselves but then who reinvest those dreams in their children. Don't let anyone tell you that America's best days are behind her, that the American spirit has been vanquished. We've seen it triumph too often in our lives to stop believing in it now.
A hundred and twenty years ago, the greatest of all our Presidents delivered his second State of the Union message in this Chamber. We cannot escape history

column1: This solemn occasion marks the 196th time that a President of the United States has reported on the State of the Union since George Washington first did so in 1790. That's a lot of reports
column2: but there's no shortage of new things to say about the State of the Union. The very key to our success has been our ability
column3: foremost among nations
column4: to preserve our lasting values by making change work for us rather than against us.

column1: I would like to talk with you this evening about what we can do togethernot as Republicans and Democrats
column2: but as Americans-to make tomorrow's America happy and prosperous at home
column3: strong and respected abroad
column4: and at peace in the world.

column5: lumbermen

column4: and strength of our people

column4: as some of us had warned for so long

Then the recession and the sudden end of inflation withered the expanding wage base and increasing revenues the system needs to support the 36 million Americans who depend on it.

column1: Nearly half a century ago

column1: Throughout the world, he said
column2: "change is the order of the day. In every nation economic problems long in the making have brought crises of many kinds for which the masters of old practice and theory were unprepared." He also reminded us that "the future lies with those wise political leaders who realize that the great public is interested more in Government than in politics."

column1: So
column2: let us
column3: in these next 2 yearsmen and women of both parties

column5: bipartisan responsibilities of government

column1: The problems we inherited were far worse than most inside and out of government had expected; the recession was deeper than most inside and out of government had predicted. Curing those problems has taken more time and a higher toll than any of us wanted. Unemployment is far too high. Projected Federal spendingif government refuses to tighten its own belt-will also be far too high and could weaken and shorten the economic recovery now underway.

This recovery will bring with it a revival of economic confidence and spending for consumer items and capital goodsthe stimulus we need to restart our stalled economic engines. The American people have already stepped up their rate of saving
column2: assuring that the funds needed to modernize our factories and improve our technology will once again flow to business and industry.

column1: The inflationary expectations that led to a 21 1/2-percent interest prime rate and soaring mortgage rates 2 years ago are now reduced by almost half. Leaders have started to realize that double-digit inflation is no longer a way of life. I misspoke there. I should have said "lenders."
So
column2: interest rates have tumbled
column3: paving the way for recovery in vital industries like housing and autos.

column1: The early evidence of that recovery has started coming in. Housing starts for the fourth quarter of 1982 were up 45 percent from a year ago
column2: and housing permits
column3: a sure indicator of future growth
column4: were up a whopping 60 percent.

column1: We're witnessing an upsurge of productivity and impressive evidence that American industry will once again become competitive in markets at home and abroad
column2: ensuring more jobs and better incomes for the Nation's work force. But our confidence must also be tempered by realism and patience. Quick fixes and artificial stimulants repeatedly applied over decades are what brought us the inflationary disorders that we've now paid such a heavy price to cure.

column1: The permanent recovery in employment
column2: production
column3: and investment we seek won't come in a sharp
column4: short spurt. It'll build carefully and steadily in the months and years ahead. In the meantime
column5: the challenge of government is to identify the things that we can do now to ease the massive economic transition for the American people.

column1: The Federal budget is both a symptom and a cause of our economic problems. Unless we reduce the dangerous growth rate in government spending
column2: we could face the prospect of sluggish economic growth into the indefinite future. Failure to cope with this problem now could mean as much as a trillion dollars more in national debt in the next 4 years alone. That would average $4
column3: 300 in additional debt for every man
column4: woman
column5: child
column6: and baby in our nation.

column1: To assure a sustained recovery
column2: we must continue getting runaway spending under control to bring those deficits down. If we don't
column3: the recovery will be too short
column4: unemployment will remain too high
column5: and we will leave an unconscionable burden of national debt for our children. That we must not do.

column1: Let's be clear about where the deficit problem comes from. Contrary to the drumbeat we've been hearing for the last few months
column2: the deficits we face are not rooted in defense spending. Taken as a percentage of the gross national product
column3: our defense spending happens to be only about four-fifths of what it was in 1970. Nor is the deficit
column4: as some would have it
column5: rooted in tax cuts. Even with our tax cuts
column6: taxes as a fraction of gross national product remain about the same as they were in 1970. The fact is
column7: our deficits come from the uncontrolled growth of the budget for domestic spending.

column1: During the 1970's
column2: the share of our national income devoted to this domestic spending increased by more than 60 percent
column3: from 10 cents out of every dollar produced by the American people to 16 cents. In spite of all our economies and efficiencies
column4: and without adding any new programs
column5: basic
column6: necessary domestic spending provided for in this year's budget will grow to almost a trillion dollars over the next 5 years.

column1: The deficit problem is a clear and present danger to the basic health of our Republic. We need a plan to overcome this dangera plan based on these principles. It must be bipartisan. Conquering the deficits and putting the Government's house in order will require the best effort of all of us. It must be fair. Just as all will share in the benefits that will come from recovery
column2: all would share fairly in the burden of transition. It must be prudent. The strength of our national defense must be restored so that we can pursue prosperity and peace and freedom while maintaining our commitment to the truly needy. And finally
column3: it must be realistic. We can't rely on hope alone.

column1: With these guiding principles in mind
column2: let me outline a four-part plan to increase economic growth and reduce deficits.

column1: First
column2: in my budget message
column3: I will recommend a Federal spending freeze. I know this is strong medicine
column4: but so far
column5: we have only cut the rate of increase in Federal spending. The Government has continued to spend more money each year
column6: though not as much more as it did in the past. Taken as a whole
column7: the budget I'm proposing for the fiscal year will increase no more than the rate of inflation. In other words
column8: the Federal Government will hold the line on real spending. Now
column9: that's far less than many American families have had to do in these difficult times.

column1: I will request that the proposed 6-month freeze in cost-of-living adjustments recommended by the bipartisan Social Security Commission be applied to other government-related retirement programs. I will
column2: also
column3: propose a 1-year freeze on a broad range of domestic spending programs
column4: and for Federal civilian and military pay and pension programs. And let me say right here
column5: I'm sorry
column6: with regard to the military
column7: in asking that of them
column8: because for so many years they have been so far behind and so low in reward for what the men and women in uniform are doing. But I'm sure they will understand that this must be across the board and fair.

column1: Second
column2: I will ask the Congress to adopt specific measures to control the growth of the so-called uncontrollable spending programs. These are the automatic spending programs
column3: such as food stamps
column4: that cannot be simply frozen and that have grown by over 400 percent since 1970. They are the largest single cause of the built-in or structural deficit problem. Our standard here will be fairness
column5: ensuring that the taxpayers' hard-earned dollars go only to the truly needy; that none of them are turned away
column6: but that fraud and waste are stamped out. And I'm sorry to say
column7: there's a lot of it out there. In the food stamp program alone
column8: last year
column9: we identified almost $1.1 billion in overpayments. The taxpayers aren't the only victims of this kind of abuse. The truly needy suffer as funds intended for them are taken not by the needy
column10: but by the greedy. For everyone's sake
column11: we must put an end to such waste and corruption.

column1: Third
column2: I will adjust our program to restore America's defenses by proposing $55 billion in defense savings over the next 5 years. These are savings recommended to me by the Secretary of Defense
column3: who has assured me they can be safely achieved and will not diminish our ability to negotiate arms reductions or endanger America's security. We will not gamble with our national survival.

column1: And fourth
column2: because we must ensure reduction and eventual elimination of deficits over the next several years
column3: I will propose a standby tax
column4: limited to no more than 1 percent of the gross national product
column5: to start in fiscal 1986. It would last no more than 3 years
column6: and it would start only if the Congress has first approved our spending freeze and budget control program. And there are several other conditions also that must be met
column7: all of them in order for this program to be triggered.

column1: Now
column2: you could say that this is an insurance policy for the future
column3: a remedy that will be at hand if needed but only resorted to if absolutely necessary. In the meantime
column4: we'll continue to study ways to simplify the tax code and make it more fair for all Americans. This is a goal that every American who's ever struggled with a tax form can understand.

column1: At the same time
column2: however
column3: I will oppose any efforts to undo the basic tax reforms that we've already enacted
column4: including the 10-percent tax break coming to taxpayers this July and the tax indexing which will protect all Americans from inflationary bracket creep in the years ahead.

column1: Now
column2: I realize that this four-part plan is easier to describe than it will be to enact. But the looming deficits that hang over us and over America's future must be reduced. The path I've outlined is fair
column3: balanced
column4: and realistic. If enacted
column5: it will ensure a steady decline in deficits
column6: aiming toward a balanced budget by the end of the decade. It's the only path that will lead to a strong
column7: sustained recovery. Let us follow that path together.

column1: No domestic challenge is more crucial than providing stable
column2: permanent jobs for all Americans who want to work. The recovery program will provide jobs for most

column9: and helping federally funded and State-administered unemployment insurance programs provide workers with training and relocation assistance. Finally
column10: our proposal will include new incentives for summer youth employment to help young people get a start in the job market.

column1: We must offer both short-term help and long-term hope for our unemployed. I hope we can work together on this. I hope we can work together as we did last year in enacting the landmark Job Training Partnership Act. Regulatory reform legislation
column2: a responsible clean air act
column3: and passage of enterprise zone legislation will also create new incentives for jobs and opportunity.

column1: One of out of every five jobs in our country depends on trade. So

We must have adequate export financing to sell American products overseas. I will ask for new negotiating authority to remove barriers and to get more of our products into foreign markets. We must strengthen the organization of our trade agencies and make changes in our domestic laws and international trade policy to promote free trade and the increased flow of American goods
column3: services
column4: and investments.

column3: railroads
column4: trucking industry
column5: and ports. After 2 years of debate

column2: training
column3: and retraining are fundamental to our success as are research and development and productivity. Labor
column4: management

column7: and government programs all need constant reevaluation in terms of our competitiveness. Every American has a role and a stake in international trade.

column1: We Americans are still the technological leaders in most fields. We must keep that edge

column7: teachers
column8: grass roots groups
column9: organized labor
column10: and the business community-to revitalize American education by setting a standard of excellence.

column1: In 1983 we seek four major education goals: a quality education initiative to encourage a substantial upgrading of math and science instruction through block grants to the States; establishment of education savings accounts that will give middle and lower-income families an incentive to save for their children's college education and
column2: at the same time
column3: encourage a real increase in savings for economic growth; passage of tuition tax credits for parents who want to send their children to private or religiously affiliated schools; a constitutional amendment to permit voluntary school prayer. God should never have been expelled from America's classrooms in the first place.

column1: Our commitment to fairness means that we must assure legal and economic equity for women
column2: and eliminate
column3: once and for all
column4: all traces of unjust discrimination against women from the United States Code. We will not tolerate wage discrimination based on sex
column5: and we intend to strengthen enforcement of child support laws to ensure that single parents
column6: most of whom are women
column7: do not suffer unfair financial hardship. We will also take action to remedy inequities in pensions. These initiatives will be joined by others to continue our efforts to promote equity for women.

column1: The time has also come for major reform of our criminal justice statutes and acceleration of the drive against organized crime and drug trafficking. It's high time that we make our cities safe again. This administration hereby declares an all-out war on big-time organized crime and the drug racketeers who are poisoning our young people. We will also implement recommendations of our Task Force on Victims of Crime
column2: which will report to me this week.

column2: the envy of the world
column3: has become the victim of its own successes. With one farmer now producing enough food to feed himself and 77 other people

column5: through innovations like the payment-in-kind crop swap approach and an aggressive export policy
column6: to restore health and vitality to rural America. Meanwhile

column3: labor
column4: education
column5: and government to address the training needs of American workers. Thanks to the Task Force
column6: private sector initiatives are now underway in all 50 States of the Union
column7: and thousands of working people have been helped in making the shift from dead-end jobs and low-demand skills to the growth areas of high technology and the service economy. Additionally
column8: a major effort will be focused on encouraging the expansion of private community child care. The new advisory council on private sector initiatives will carry on and extend this vital work of encouraging private initiative in 1983.

column1: In the coming year
column2: we will also act to improve the quality of life for Americans by curbing the skyrocketing cost of health care that is becoming an unbearable financial burden for so many. And we will submit legislation to provide catastrophic illness insurance coverage for older Americans.

column1: I will also shortly submit a comprehensive federalism proposal that will continue our efforts to restore to States and local governments their roles as dynamic laboratories of change in a creative society.
During the next several weeks
column2: I will send to the Congress a series of detailed proposals on these and other topics and look forward to working with you on the development of these initiatives.

column1: So far
column2: now
column3: I've concentrated mainly on the problems posed by the future. But in almost every home and workplace in America
column4: we're already witnessing reason for great hopethe first flowering of the manmade miracles of high technology
column5: a field pioneered and still led by our country.

column1: To many of us now
column2: computers
column3: silicon chips
column4: data processing
column5: cybernetics
column6: and all the other innovations of the dawning high technology age are as mystifying as the workings of the combustion engine must have been when that first Model T rattled down Main Street
column7: U.S.A. But as surely as America's pioneer spirit made us the industrial giant of the 20th century
column8: the same pioneer spirit today is opening up on another vast front of opportunity
column9: the frontier of high technology.

column1: In conquering the frontier we cannot write off our traditional industries
column2: but we must develop the skills and industries that will make us a pioneer of tomorrow. This administration is committed to keeping America the technological leader of the world now and into the 21st century.

column1: But let us turn briefly to the international arena. America's leadership in the world came to us because of our own strength and because of the values which guide us as a society: free elections
column2: a free press
column3: freedom of religious choice
column4: free trade unions
column5: and above all
column6: freedom for the individual and rejection of the arbitrary power of the state. These values are the bedrock of our strength. They unite us in a stewardship of peace and freedom with our allies and friends in NATO
column7: in Asia
column8: in Latin America
column9: and elsewhere. They are also the values which in the recent past some among us had begun to doubt and view with a cynical eye.

column1: Fortunately
column2: we and our allies have rediscovered the strength of our common democratic values
column3: and we're applying them as a cornerstone of a comprehensive strategy for peace with freedom. In London last year
column4: I announced the commitment of the United States to developing the infrastructure of democracy throughout the world. We intend to pursue this democratic initiative vigorously. The future belongs not to governments and ideologies which oppress their peoples
column5: but to democratic systems of self-government which encourage individual initiative and guarantee personal freedom.

column1: But our strategy for peace with freedom must also be based on strengtheconomic strength and military strength. A strong American economy is essential to the well-being and security of our friends and allies. The restoration of a strong
column2: healthy American economy has been and remains one of the central pillars of our foreign policy. The progress I've been able to report to you tonight will
column3: I know
column4: be as warmly welcomed by the rest of the world as it is by the American people.

column1: We must also recognize that our own economic well-being is inextricably linked to the world economy. We export over 20 percent of our industrial production
column2: and 40 percent of our farmland produces for export. We will continue to work closely with the industrialized democracies of Europe and Japan and with the International Monetary Fund to ensure it has adequate resources to help bring the world economy back to strong
column3: noninflationary growth.

column1: As the leader of the West and as a country that has become great and rich because of economic freedom
column2: America must be an unrelenting advocate of free trade. As some nations are tempted to turn to protectionism
column3: our strategy cannot be to follow them
column4: but to lead the way toward freer trade. To this end
column5: in May of this year America will host an economic summit meeting in Williamsburg
column6: Virginia.

column1: As we begin our third year
column2: we have put in place a defense program that redeems the neglect of the past decade. We have developed a realistic military strategy to deter threats to peace and to protect freedom if deterrence fails. Our Armed Forces are finally properly paid; after years of neglect are well trained and becoming better equipped and supplied. And the American uniform is once again worn with pride. Most of the major systems needed for modernizing our defenses are already underway
column3: and we will be addressing one key system
column4: the MX missile
column5: in consultation with the Congress in a few months.

column1: America's foreign policy is once again based on bipartisanship
column2: on realism
column3: strength
column4: full partnership
column5: in consultation with our allies
column6: and constructive negotiation with potential adversaries. From the Middle East to southern Africa to Geneva

column1: Last September
column2: I outlined principles to carry on the peace process begun so promisingly at Camp David. All the people of the Middle East should know that in the year ahead we will not flag in our efforts to build on that foundation to bring them the blessings of peace.

column4: and democracy. Final passage of the remaining portions of our Caribbean Basin Initiative

column2: and I'm counting on the cooperation and statesmanship of the Congress to help us meet this essential foreign policy goal.

column1: At the heart of our strategy for peace is our relationship with the Soviet Union. The past year saw a change in Soviet leadership. We're prepared for a positive change in Soviet-American relations. But the Soviet Union must show by deeds as well as words a sincere commitment to respect the rights and sovereignty of the family of nations. Responsible members of the world community do not threaten or invade their neighbors. And they restrain their allies from aggression.
For our part
column2: we're vigorously pursuing arms reduction negotiations with the Soviet Union. Supported by our allies
column3: we've put forward draft agreements proposing significant weapon reductions to equal and verifiable lower levels. We insist on an equal balance of forces. And given the overwhelming evidence of Soviet violations of international treaties concerning chemical and biological weapons
column4: we also insist that any agreement we sign can and will be verifiable.

column1: In the case of intermediate-range nuclear forces

column3: let me emphasize that allied steadfastness remains a key to achieving arms reductions.

column1: With firmness and dedication

column4: they will have every reason to join us in the search for greater security and major arms reductions. When that moment comesand I'm confident that it willwe will have taken an important step toward a more peaceful future for all the world's people.

column4: no one can or should minimize the plight of millions of our friends and neighbors who are living in the bleak emptiness of unemployment. But we must and can give them good reason to be hopeful.

column1: Back over the years
column2: citizens like ourselves have gathered within these walls when our nation was threatened; sometimes when its very existence was at stake. Always with courage and common sense
column3: they met the crises of their time and lived to see a stronger
column4: better
column5: and more prosperous country. The present situation is no worse and
column6: in fact
column7: is not as bad as some of those they faced. Time and again
column8: they proved that there is nothing we Americans cannot achieve as free men and women.

column1: Yes
column2: we still have problemsplenty of them. But it's just plain wrongunjust to our country and unjust to our peopleto let those problems stand in the way of the most important truth of all: America is on the mend.

column1: We owe it to the unfortunate to be aware of their plight and to help them in every way we can. No one can quarrel with that. We must and do have compassion for all the victims of this economic crisis. But the big story about America today is the way that millions of confident
column2: caring people-those extraordinary "ordinary" Americans who never make the headlines and will never be interviewedare laying the foundation
column3: not just for recovery from our present problems but for a better tomorrow for all our people.

column1: From coast to coast
column2: on the job and in classrooms and laboratories
column3: at new construction sites and in churches and community groups
column4: neighbors are helping neighbors. And they've already begun the building
column5: the research
column6: the work
column7: and the giving that will make our country great again.

column1: I believe this
column2: because I believe in them-in the strength of their hearts and minds
column3: in the commitment that each one of them brings to their daily lives
column4: be they high or humble. The challenge for us in government is to be worthy of themto make government a help
column5: not a hindrance to our people in the challenging but promising days ahead.

column1: If we do that
column2: if we care what our children and our children's children will say of us
column3: if we want them one day to be thankful for what we did here in these temples of freedom
column4: we will work together to make America better for our having been here-not just in this year or this decade but in the next century and beyond.

column1: Thank you
column2: and God bless you.@

column1: Ronald Reagan|Address Before a Joint Session of the Congress on the State of the Union|1984-01-25|@Mr. Speaker
column2: Mr. President
column3: distinguished Members of the Congress
column4: honored guests
column5: and fellow citizens:

column1: Once again
column2: in keeping with time-honored tradition
column3: I have come to report to you on the state of the Union
column4: and I'm pleased to report that America is much improved
column5: and there's good reason to believe that improvement will continue through the days to come.

column1: You and I have had some honest and open differences in the year past. But they didn't keep us from joining hands in bipartisan cooperation to stop a long decline that had drained this nation's spirit and eroded its health. There is renewed energy and optimism throughout the land. America is back
column2: standing tall
column3: looking to the eighties with courage
column4: confidence
column5: and hope.

column1: The problems we're overcoming are not the heritage of one person
column2: party
column3: or even one generation. It's just the tendency of government to grow
column4: for practices and programs to become the nearest thing to eternal life we'll ever see on this Earth. And there's always that well-intentioned chorus of voices saying
column5: "With a little more power and a little more money
column6: we could do so much for the people." For a time we forgot the American dream isn't one of making government bigger; it's keeping faith with the mighty spirit of free people under God.

column1: As we came to the decade of the eighties
column2: we faced the worst crisis in our postwar history. In the seventies were years of rising problems and falling confidence. There was a feeling government had grown beyond the consent of the governed. Families felt helpless in the face of mounting inflation and the indignity of taxes that reduced reward for hard work
column3: thrift
column4: and risktaking. All this was overlaid by an evergrowing web of rules and regulations.

column1: On the international scene
column2: we had an uncomfortable feeling that we'd lost the respect of friend and foe. Some questioned whether we had the will to defend peace and freedom. But America is too great for small dreams. There was a hunger in the land for a spiritual revival; if you will
column3: a crusade for renewal. The American people said: Let us look to the future with confidence
column4: both at home and abroad. Let us give freedom a chance.

column1: Americans were ready to make a new beginning
column2: and together we have done it. We're confronting our problems one by one. Hope is alive tonight for millions of young families and senior citizens set free from unfair tax increases and crushing inflation. Inflation has been beaten down from 12.4 to 3.2 percent
column3: and that's a great victory for all the people. The prime rate has been cut almost in half
column4: and we must work together to bring it down even more.

column1: Together
column2: we passed the first across-the-board tax reduction for everyone since the Kennedy tax cuts. Next year
column3: tax rates will be indexed so inflation can't push people into higher brackets when they get cost-of-living pay raises. Government must never again use inflation to profit at the people's expense.

column1: Today a working family earning $25
column3: 100 more in purchasing power than if tax and inflation rates were still at the 1980 levels. Real after-tax income increased 5 percent last year. And economic deregulation of key industries like transportation has offered more chancesor choices
column4: I should say
column5: to consumers and new changesor chances for entrepreneurs and protecting safety. Tonight
column6: we can report and be proud of one of the best recoveries in decades. Send away the handwringers and the doubting Thomases. Hope is reborn for couples dreaming of owning homes and for risktakers with vision to create tomorrow's opportunities.

column1: The spirit of enterprise is sparked by the sunrise industries of high-tech and by small business people with big ideaspeople like Barbara Proctor
column2: who rose from a ghetto to build a multimillion-dollar advertising agency in Chicago; Carlos Perez
column3: a Cuban refugee
column4: who turned $27 and a dream into a successful importing business in Coral Gables
column5: Florida.

column1: People like these are heroes for the eighties. They helped 4 million Americans find jobs in 1983. More people are drawing paychecks tonight than ever before. And Congress helpsor progress helps everyone-well
column2: Congress does too  -everyone. In 1983 women filled 73 percent of all the new jobs in managerial
column3: professional
column4: and technical fields.

column1: But we know that many of our fellow countrymen are still out of work
column2: wondering what will come of their hopes and dreams. Can we love America and not reach out to tell them: You are not forgotten; we will not rest until each of you can reach as high as your God-given talents will take you.

column1: The heart of America is strong; it's good and true. The cynics were wrong; America never was a sick society. We're seeing rededication to bedrock values of faith
column2: family
column3: work
column4: neighborhood
column5: peace
column6: and freedomvalues that help bring us together as one people
column7: from the youngest child to the most senior citizen.

column1: The Congress deserves America's thanks for helping us restore pride and credibility to our military. And I hope that you're as proud as I am of the young men and women in uniform who have volunteered to man the ramparts in defense of freedom and whose dedication
column2: valor
column3: and skill increases so much our chance of living in a world at peace.

column1: People everywhere hunger for peace and a better life. The tide of the future is a freedom tide
column2: and our struggle for democracy cannot and will not be denied. This nation champions peace that enshrines liberty
column3: democratic rights
column4: and dignity for every individual. America's new strength
column5: confidence
column6: and purpose are carrying hope and opportunity far from our shores. A world economic recovery is underway. It began here.

column1: We've journeyed far
column2: but we have much farther to go. Franklin Roosevelt told us 50 years ago this month: "Civilization can not go back; civilization must not stand still. We have undertaken new methods. It is our task to perfect
column3: to improve
column4: to alter when necessary
column5: but in all cases to go forward."

column1: It's time to move forward again
column2: time for America to take freedom's next step. Let us unite tonight behind four great goals to keep America free
column3: secure
column4: and at peace in the eighties together.

column1: We can ensure steady economic growth. We can develop America's next frontier. We can strengthen our traditional values. And we can build a meaningful peace to protect our loved ones and this shining star of faith that has guided millions from tyranny to the safe harbor of freedom
column2: progress
column3: and hope.

column1: Doing these things will open wider the gates of opportunity
column2: provide greater security for all
column3: with no barriers of bigotry or discrimination.

column1: The key to a dynamic decade is vigorous economic growth
column2: our first great goal. We might well begin with common sense in Federal budgeting: government spending no more than government takes in.

column1: We must bring Federal deficits down. But how we do that makes all the difference.
We can begin by limiting the size and scope of government. Under the leadership of Vice President Bush
column2: we have reduced the growth of Federal regulations by more than 25 percent and cut well over 300 million hours of government-required paperwork each year. This will save the public more than $150 billion over the next 10 years.

column1: The Grace commission has given us some 2
column2: 500 recommendations for reducing wasteful spending
column3: and they're being examined throughout the administration. Federal spending growth has been cut from 17.4 percent in 1980 to less than half of that today
column4: and we have already achieved over $300 billion in budget savings for the period of 1982 to '86. But that's only a little more than half of what we sought. Government is still spending too large a percentage of the total economy.

column1: Now
column2: some insist that any further budget savings must be obtained by reducing the portion spent on defense. This ignores the fact that national defense is solely the responsibility of the Federal Government; indeed
column3: it is its prime responsibility. And yet defense spending is less than a third of the total budget. During the years of President Kennedy and of the years before that
column4: defense was almost half the total budget. And then came several years in which our military capability was allowed to deteriorate to a very dangerous degree. We are just now restoring
column5: through the essential modernization of our conventional and strategic forces
column6: our capability to meet our present and future security needs. We dare not shirk our responsibility to keep America free
column7: secure
column8: and at peace.

column1: The last decade saw domestic spending surge literally out of control. But the basis for such spending had been laid in previous years. A pattern of overspending has been in place for half a century. As the national debt grew
column2: we were told not to worry
column3: that we owed it to ourselves.

column1: Now we know that deficits are a cause for worry. But there's a difference of opinion as to whether taxes should be increased
column2: spending cut
column3: or some of both. Fear is expressed that government borrowing to fund the deficit could inhibit the economic recovery by taking capital needed for business and industrial expansion. Well
column4: I think that debate is missing an important point. Whether government borrows or increases taxes
column5: it will be taking the same amount of money from the private sector
column6: and
column7: either way
column8: that's too much. Simple fairness dictates that government must not raise taxes on families struggling to pay their bills. The root of the problem is that government's share is more than we can afford if we're to have a sound economy.

column1: We must bring down the deficits to ensure continued economic growth. In the budget that I will submit on February 1st
column2: I will recommend measures that will reduce the deficit over the next 5 years. Many of these will be unfinished business from last year's budget.

column1: Some could be enacted quickly if we could join in a serious effort to address this problem. I spoke today with Speaker of the House O'Neill
column2: Senate Majority Leader Baker
column3: Senate Minority Leader Byrd
column4: and House Minority Leader Michel. I asked them if they would designate congressional representatives to meet with representatives of the administration to try to reach prompt agreement on a bipartisan deficit reduction plan. I know it would take a long
column5: hard struggle to agree on a full-scale plan. So
column6: what I have proposed is that we first see if we can agree on a down payment.

column1: Now
column2: I believe there is basis for such an agreement
column3: one that could reduce the deficits by about a hundred billion dollars over the next 3 years. We could focus on some of the less contentious spending cuts that are still pending before the Congress. These could be combined with measures to close certain tax loopholes
column4: measures that the Treasury Department has previously said to be worthy of support. In addition
column5: we could examine the possibility of achieving further outlay savings based on the work of the Grace commission.

column1: If the congressional leadership is willing
column2: my representatives will be prepared to meet with theirs at the earliest possible time. I would hope the leadership might agree on an expedited timetable in which to develop and enact that down payment.

column1: But a down payment alone is not enough to break us out of the deficit problem. It could help us start on the right path. Yet
column2: we must do more. So
column3: I propose that we begin exploring how together we can make structural reforms to curb the built-in growth of spending.

column1: I also propose improvements in the budgeting process. Some 43 of our 50 States grant their Governors the right to veto individual items in appropriation bills without having to veto the entire bill. California is one of those 43 States. As Governor
column2: I found this line-item veto was a powerful tool against wasteful or extravagant spending. It works in 43 States. Let's put it to work in Washington for all the people.

column1: It would be most effective if done by constitutional amendment. The majority of Americans approve of such an amendment
column2: just as they and I approve of an amendment mandating a balanced Federal budget. Many States also have this protection in their constitutions.

column1: To talk of meeting the present situation by increasing taxes is a Band-Aid solution which does nothing to cure an illness that's been coming on for half a centuryto say nothing of the fact that it poses a real threat to economic recovery. Let's remember that a substantial amount of income tax is presently owed and not paid by people in the underground economy. It would be immoral to make those who are paying taxes pay more to compensate for those who aren't paying their share.
There's a better way. Let us go forward with an historic reform for fairness
column2: simplicity
column3: and incentives for growth. I am asking Secretary Don Regan for a plan for action to simplify the entire tax code
column4: so all taxpayers
column5: big and small
column6: are treated more fairly. And I believe such a plan could result in that underground economy being brought into the sunlight of honest tax compliance. And it could make the tax base broader
column7: so personal tax rates could come down
column8: not go up. I've asked that specific recommendations
column9: consistent with those objectives
column10: be presented to me by December 1984.

column1: Our second great goal is to build on America's pioneer spirit  I said something funny? I said America's next frontierand that's to develop that frontier. A sparkling economy spurs initiatives
column2: sunrise industries
column3: and makes older ones more competitive.

column1: Nowhere is this more important than our next frontier: space. Nowhere do we so effectively demonstrate our technological leadership and ability to make life better on Earth. The Space Age is barely a quarter of a century old. But already we've pushed civilization forward with our advances in science and technology. Opportunities and jobs will multiply as we cross new thresholds of knowledge and reach deeper into the unknown.
Our progress in spacetaking giant steps for all mankindis a tribute to American teamwork and excellence. Our finest minds in government
column2: industry
column3: and academia have all pulled together. And we can be proud to say: We are first; we are the best; and we are so because we're free.

column1: America has always been greatest when we dared to be great. We can reach for greatness again. We can follow our dreams to distant stars
column2: living and working in space for peaceful
column3: economic
column4: and scientific gain. Tonight
column5: I am directing NASA to develop a permanently manned space station and to do it within a decade.

column1: A space station will permit quantum leaps in our research in science
column2: communications
column3: in metals
column4: and in lifesaving medicines which could be manufactured only in space. We want our friends to help us meet these challenges and share in their benefits. NASA will invite other countries to participate so we can strengthen peace
column5: build prosperity
column6: and expand freedom for all who share our goals.

column1: Just as the oceans opened up a new world for clipper ships and Yankee traders
column2: space holds enormous potential for commerce today. The market for space transportation could surpass our capacity to develop it. Companies interested in putting payloads into space must have ready access to private sector launch services. The Department of Transportation will help an expendable launch services industry to get off the ground. We'll soon implement a number of executive initiatives
column3: develop proposals to ease regulatory constraints
column4: and
column5: with NASA's help
column6: promote private sector investment in space.

column1: And as we develop the frontier of space
column2: let us remember our responsibility to preserve our older resources here on Earth. Preservation of our environment is not a liberal or conservative challenge
column3: it's common sense.

column1: Though this is a time of budget constraints
column2: I have requested for EPA one of the largest percentage budget increases of any agency. We will begin the long
column3: necessary effort to clean up a productive recreational area and a special national resourcethe Chesapeake Bay.

column1: To reduce the threat posed by abandoned hazardous waste dumps
column2: EPA will spend $410 million. And I will request a supplemental increase of 50 million. And because the Superfund law expires in 1985
column3: I've asked Bill Ruckelshaus to develop a proposal for its extension so there'll be additional time to complete this important task.

column1: On the question of acid rain
column2: which concerns people in many areas of the United States and Canada
column3: I'm proposing a research program that doubles our current funding. And we'll take additional action to restore our lakes and develop new technology to reduce pollution that causes acid rain.

column1: We have greatly improved the conditions of our natural resources. We'll ask the Congress for $157 million beginning in 1985 to acquire new park and conservation lands. The Department of the Interior will encourage careful
column2: selective exploration and production on our vital resources in an Exclusive Economic Zone within the 200-mile limit off our coastsbut with strict adherence to environmental laws and with fuller State and public participation.

column1: But our most precious resources
column2: our greatest hope for the future
column3: are the minds and hearts of our people
column4: especially our children. We can help them build tomorrow by strengthening our community of shared values. This must be our third great goal. For us
column5: faith
column6: work
column7: family
column8: neighborhood
column9: freedom
column10: and peace are not just words; they're expressions of what America means
column11: definitions of what makes us a good and loving people.

column1: Families stand at the center of our society. And every family has a personal stake in promoting excellence in education. Excellence does not begin in Washington. A 600-percent increase in Federal spending on education between 1960 and 1980 was accompanied by a steady decline in Scholastic Aptitude Test scores. Excellence must begin in our homes and neighborhood schools
column2: where it's the responsibility of every parent and teacher and the right of every child.

column1: Our children come first
column2: and that's why I established a bipartisan National Commission on Excellence in Education
column3: to help us chart a commonsense course for better education. And already
column4: communities are implementing the Commission's recommendations. Schools are reporting progress in math and reading skills. But we must do more to restore discipline to schools; and we must encourage the teaching of new basics
column5: reward teachers of merit
column6: enforce tougher standards
column7: and put our parents back in charge.

column1: I will continue to press for tuition tax credits to expand opportunities for families and to soften the double payment for those paying public school taxes and private school tuition. Our proposal would target assistance to low- and middle-income families. Just as more incentives are needed within our schools
column2: greater competition is needed among our schools. Without standards and competition
column3: there can be no champions
column4: no records broken
column5: no excellence in education or any other walk of life.

column1: And while I'm on this subject
column2: each day your Members observe a 200-year-old tradition meant to signify America is one nation under God. I must ask: If you can begin your day with a member of the clergy standing right here leading you in prayer
column3: then why can't freedom to acknowledge God be enjoyed again by children in every schoolroom across this land?

column1: America was founded by people who believed that God was their rock of safety. He is ours. I recognize we must be cautious in claiming that God is on our side
column2: but I think it's all right to keep asking if we're on His side.

column1: During our first 3 years
column2: we have joined bipartisan efforts to restore protection of the law to unborn children. Now
column3: I know this issue is very controversial. But unless and until it can be proven that an unborn child is not a living human being
column4: can we justify assuming without proof that it isn't? No one has yet offered such proof; indeed
column5: all the evidence is to the contrary. We should rise above bitterness and reproach
column6: and if Americans could come together in a spirit of understanding and helping
column7: then we could find positive solutions to the tragedy of abortion.

column1: Economic recovery
column2: better education
column3: rededication to values
column4: all show the spirit of renewal gaining the upper hand. And all will improve family life in the eighties. But families need more. They need assurance that they and their loved ones can walk the streets of America without being afraid. Parents need to know their children will not be victims of child pornography and abduction. This year we will intensify our drive against these and other horrible crimes like sexual abuse and family violence.

column1: Already our efforts to crack down on career criminals
column2: organized crime
column3: drugpushers
column4: and to enforce tougher sentences and paroles are having effect. In 1982 the crime rate dropped by 4.3 percent
column5: the biggest decline since 1972. Protecting victims is just as important as safeguarding the rights of defendants.

column1: Opportunities for all Americans will increase if we move forward in fair housing and work to ensure women's rights
column2: provide for equitable treatment in pension benefits and Individual Retirement Accounts
column3: facilitate child care
column4: and enforce delinquent parent support payments.

column1: It's not just the home but the workplace and community that sustain our values and shape our future. So
column2: I ask your help in assisting more communities to break the bondage of dependency. Help us to free enterprise by permitting debate and voting "yes" on our proposal for enterprise zones in America. This has been before you for 2 years. Its passage can help high-unemployment areas by creating jobs and restoring neighborhoods.

column1: A society bursting with opportunities
column2: reaching for its future with confidence
column3: sustained by faith
column4: fair play
column5: and a conviction that good and courageous people will flourish when they're freethese are the secrets of a strong and prosperous America at peace with itself and the world.

column1: A lasting and meaningful peace is our fourth great goal. It is our highest aspiration. And our record is clear: Americans resort to force only when we must. We have never been aggressors. We have always struggled to defend freedom and democracy.
We have no territorial ambitions. We occupy no countries. We build no walls to lock people in. Americans build the future. And our vision of a better life for farmers
column2: merchants
column3: and working people
column4: from the Americas to Asia
column5: begins with a simple premise: The future is best decided by ballots
column6: not bullets.

column1: Governments which rest upon the consent of the governed do not wage war on their neighbors. Only when people are given a personal stake in deciding their own destiny
column2: benefiting from their own risks
column3: do they create societies that are prosperous
column4: progressive
column5: and free. Tonight
column6: it is democracies that offer hope by feeding the hungry
column7: prolonging life
column8: and eliminating drudgery.

column1: When it comes to keeping America strong
column2: free
column3: and at peace
column4: there should be no Republicans or Democrats
column5: just patriotic Americans. We can decide the tough issues not by who is right
column6: but by what is right.

column1: Together
column2: we can continue to advance our agenda for peace. We can establish a more stable basis for peaceful relations with the Soviet Union; strengthen allied relations across the board; achieve real and equitable reductions in the levels of nuclear arms; reinforce our peacemaking efforts in the Middle East
column3: Central America
column4: and southern Africa; or assist developing countries
column5: particularly our neighbors in the Western Hemisphere; and assist in the development of democratic institutions throughout the world.

column1: The wisdom of our bipartisan cooperation was seen in the work of the Scowcroft commission
column2: which strengthened our ability to deter war and protect peace. In that same spirit
column3: I urge you to move forward with the Henry Jackson plan to implement the recommendations of the Bipartisan Commission on Central America.

column1: Your joint resolution on the multinational peacekeeping force in Lebanon is also serving the cause of peace. We are making progress in Lebanon. For nearly 10 years
column2: the Lebanese have lived from tragedy to tragedy with no hope for their future. Now the multinational peacekeeping force and our marines are helping them break their cycle of despair. There is hope for a free
column3: independent
column4: and sovereign Lebanon. We must have the courage to give peace a chance. And we must not be driven from our objectives for peace in Lebanon by state-sponsored terrorism. We have seen this ugly specter in Beirut
column5: Kuwait
column6: and Rangoon. It demands international attention. I will forward shortly legislative proposals to help combat terrorism. And I will be seeking support from our allies for concerted action.

column1: Our NATO alliance is strong. 1983 was a banner year for political courage. And we have strengthened our partnerships and our friendships in the Far East. We're committed to dialog
column2: deterrence
column3: and promoting prosperity. We'll work with our trading partners for a new round of negotiations in support of freer world trade
column4: greater competition
column5: and more open markets.

column1: A rebirth of bipartisan cooperation
column2: of economic growth
column3: and military deterrence
column4: and a growing spirit of unity among our people at home and our allies abroad underline a fundamental and far-reaching change: The United States is safer
column5: stronger
column6: and more secure in 1984 than before. We can now move with confidence to seize the opportunities for peace
column7: and we will.

column1: Tonight
column2: I want to speak to the people of the Soviet Union
column3: to tell them it's true that our governments have had serious differences
column4: but our sons and daughters have never fought each other in war. And if we Americans have our way
column5: they never will.

column1: People of the Soviet Union
column2: there is only one sane policy
column3: for your country and mine
column4: to preserve our civilization in this modern age: A nuclear war cannot be won and must never be fought. The only value in our two nations possessing nuclear weapons is to make sure they will never be used. But then would it not be better to do away with them entirely?

column1: People of the Soviet
column2: President Dwight Eisenhower
column3: who fought by your side in World War II
column4: said the essential struggle "is not merely man against man or nation against nation. It is man against war." Americans are people of peace. If your government wants peace
column5: there will be peace. We can come together in faith and friendship to build a safer and far better world for our children and our children's children. And the whole world will rejoice. That is my message to you.

column1: Some days when life seems hard and we reach out for values to sustain us or a friend to help us
column2: we find a person who reminds us what it means to be Americans.

column1: Sergeant Stephen Trujillo
column2: a medic in the 2d Ranger Battalion
column3: 75th Infantry
column4: was in the first helicopter to land at the compound held by Cuban forces in Grenada. He saw three other helicopters crash. Despite the imminent explosion of the burning aircraft
column5: he never hesitated. He ran across 25 yards of open terrain through enemy fire to rescue wounded soldiers. He directed two other medics
column6: administered first aid
column7: and returned again and again to the crash site to carry his wounded friends to safety.

column1: Sergeant Trujillo
column2: you and your fellow service men and women not only saved innocent lives; you set a nation free. You inspire us as a force for freedom
column3: not for despotism; and
column4: yes
column5: for peace
column6: not conquest. God bless you.

column1: And then there are unsung heroes: single parents
column2: couples
column3: church and civic volunteers. Their hearts carry without complaint the pains of family and community problems. They soothe our sorrow
column4: heal our wounds
column5: calm our fears
column6: and share our joy.

column1: A person like Father Ritter is always there. His Covenant House programs in New York and Houston provide shelter and help to thousands of frightened and abused children each year. The same is true of Dr. Charles Carson. Paralyzed in a plane crash
column2: he still believed nothing is impossible. Today in Minnesota
column3: he works 80 hours a week without pay
column4: helping pioneer the field of computer-controlled walking. He has given hope to 500
column5: 000 paralyzed Americans that some day they may walk again.

column1: How can we not believe in the greatness of America? How can we not do what is right and needed to preserve this last best hope of man on Earth? After all our struggles to restore America
column2: to revive confidence in our country
column3: hope for our future
column4: after all our hard-won victories earned through the patience and courage of every citizen
column5: we cannot
column6: must not
column7: and will not turn back. We will finish our job. How could we do less? We're Americans.

column1: Carl Sandburg said
column2: "I see America not in the setting sun of a black night of despair  . . I see America in the crimson light of a rising sun fresh from the burning
column3: creative hand of God... I see great days ahead for men and women of will and vision."

column1: I've never felt more strongly that America's best days and democracy's best days lie ahead. We're a powerful force for good. With faith and courage
column2: we can perform great deeds and take freedom's next step. And we will. We will carry on the tradition of a good and worthy people who have brought light where there was darkness
column3: warmth where there was cold
column4: medicine where there was disease
column5: food where there was hunger
column6: and peace where there was only bloodshed.

column1: Let us be sure that those who come after will say of us in our time
column2: that in our time we did everything that could be done. We finished the race; we kept them free; we kept the faith.

column1: Thank you very much. God bless you
column2: and God bless America.@

column1: Ronald Reagan|Address Before a Joint Session of the Congress on the State of the Union|1985-02-06|@Mr. Speaker
column2: Mr. President
column3: distinguished Members of the Congress
column4: honored guests
column5: and fellow citizens:

column1: I come before you to report on the state of our Union
column2: and I'm pleased to report that after 4 years of united effort
column3: the American people have brought forth a nation renewed
column4: stronger
column5: freer
column6: and more secure than before.

column1: Four years ago we said we would invigorate our economy by giving people greater freedom and incentives to take risks and letting them keep more of what they earned. We did what we promised

For an America of wisdom that honors the family

We have begun well. But it's only a beginning. We're not here to congratulate ourselves on what we have done but to challenge ourselves to finish what has not yet been done.

column2: safe neighborhoods

column4: the entrepreneur

column1: Proverbs tell us

column1: We honor the giants of our history not by going back but forward to the dreams their vision foresaw. My fellow citizens

column3: enabling us to summon greater strength than we've ever known; and a revolution that carries beyond our shores the golden promise of human freedom in a world of peace.

column1: Let us begin by challenging our conventional wisdom. There are no constraints on the human mind

column4: pushing down tax rates has freed our economy to vault forward to record growth.

column1: Let us move together with an historic reform of tax simplification for fairness and growth. Last year I asked Treasury Secretary-then-Regan to develop a plan to simplify the tax code
column2: so all taxpayers would be treated more fairly and personal tax rates could come further down.

column1: We have cut tax rates by almost 25 percent
column2: yet the tax system remains unfair and limits our potential for growth. Exclusions and exemptions cause similar incomes to be taxed at different levels. Low-income families face steep tax barriers that make hard lives even harder. The Treasury Department has produced an excellent reform plan
column3: whose principles will guide the final proposal that we will ask you to enact.

column1: One thing that tax reform will not be is a tax increase in disguise. We will not jeopardize the mortgage interest deduction that families need. We will reduce personal tax rates as low as possible by removing many tax preferences. We will propose a top rate of no more than 35 percent
column2: and possibly lower. And we will propose reducing corporate rates
column3: while maintaining incentives for capital formation.

column1: To encourage opportunity and jobs rather than dependency and welfare

Just as we're positioned as never before to secure justice in our economy

column3: freer
column4: more peaceful world. Our alliances are stronger than ever. Our economy is stronger than ever. We have resumed our historic role as a leader of the free world. And all of these together are a great force for peace.

column1: Since 1981 we've been committed to seeking fair and verifiable arms agreements that would lower the risk of war and reduce the size of nuclear arsenals. Now our determination to maintain a strong defense has influenced the Soviet Union to return to the bargaining table. All of us have no greater dream than to see the day when nuclear weapons are banned from this Earth forever.
Each Member of the Congress has a role to play in modernizing our defenses
column2: thus supporting our chances for a meaningful arms agreement. Your vote this spring on the Peacekeeper missile will be a critical test of our resolve to maintain the strength we need and move toward mutual and verifiable arms reductions.

column3: free speech
