column1: Ronald Reagan|Address Before a Joint Session of Congress on the State of the Union|1986-02-04|@Mr. Speaker
column2: Mr. President
column3: distinguished Members of the Congress
column4: honored guests
column5: and fellow citizens:

column1: Thank you for allowing me to delay my address until this evening. We paused together to mourn and honor the valor of our seven Challenger heroes. And I hope that we are now ready to do what they would want us to do: Go forward
column2: America
column3: and reach for the stars. We will never forget those brave seven
column4: but we shall go forward.

column1: Mr. Speaker
column2: before I begin my prepared remarks
column3: may I point out that tonight marks the 10th and last State of the Union Message that you've presided over. And on behalf of the American people
column4: I want to salute you for your service to Congress and country. Here's to you!

column1: I have come to review with you the progress of our nation
column2: to speak of unfinished work
column3: and to set our sights on the future. I am pleased to report the state of our Union is stronger than a year ago and growing stronger each day. Tonight we look out on a rising America
column4: firm of heart
column5: united in spirit
column6: powerful in pride and patriotism . America is on the move! But it wasn't long ago that we looked out on a different land: locked factory gates
column7: long gasoline lines
column8: intolerable prices
column9: and interest rates turning the greatest country on Earth into a land of broken dreams. Government growing beyond our consent had become a lumbering giant
column10: slamming shut the gates of opportunity
column11: threatening to crush the very roots of our freedom. What brought America back? The American people brought us back with quiet courage and common sense
column12: with undying faith that in this nation under God the future will be ours; for the future belongs to the free.

column1: Tonight the American people deserve our thanks for 37 straight months of economic growth
column2: for sunrise firms and modernized industries creating 9 million new jobs in 3 years
column3: interest rates cut in half
column4: inflation falling over from 12 percent in 1980 to under 4 today
column5: and a mighty river of good works-a record $74 billion in voluntary giving just last year alone. And despite the pressures of our modern world
column6: family and community remain the moral core of our society
column7: guardians of our values and hopes for the future. Family and community are the costars of this great American comeback. They are why we say tonight: Private values must be at the heart of public policies.

column1: What is true for families in America is true for America in the family of free nations. History is no captive of some inevitable force. History is made by men and women of vision and courage. Tonight freedom is on the march. The United States is the economic miracle
column2: the model to which the world once again turns. We stand for an idea whose time is now: Only by lifting the weights from the shoulders of all can people truly prosper and can peace among all nations be secure. Teddy Roosevelt said that a nation that does great work lives forever. We have done well
column3: but we cannot stop at the foothills when Everest beckons. It's time for America to be all that we can be.

column1: We speak tonight of an agenda for the future
column2: an agenda for a safer
column3: more secure world. And we speak about the necessity for actions to steel us for the challenges of growth
column4: trade
column5: and security in the next decade and the year 2000. And we will do itnot by breaking faith with bedrock principles but by breaking free from failed policies. Let us begin where storm clouds loom darkestright here in Washington
column6: DC. This week I will send you our detailed proposals; tonight let us speak of our responsibility to redefine government's role: not to control
column7: not to demand or command
column8: not to contain us
column9: but to help in times of need and
column10: above all
column11: to create a ladder of opportunity to full employment so that all Americans can climb toward economic power and justice on their own.

column1: But we cannot win the race to the future shackled to a system that can't even pass a Federal budget. We cannot win that race held back by horse-and-buggy programs that waste tax dollars and squander human potential. We cannot win that race if we're swamped in a sea of red ink. Now
column2: Mr. Speaker
column3: you know
column4: I know
column5: and the American people know the Federal budget system is broken. It doesn't work. Before we leave this city
column6: let's you and I work together to fix it
column7: and then we can finally give the American people a balanced budget.

column1: Members of Congress
column2: passage of Gramm-Rudman-Hollings gives us an historic opportunity to achieve what has eluded our national leadership for decades: forcing the Federal Government to live within its means. Your schedule now requires that the budget resolution be passed by April 15th
column3: the very day America's families have to foot the bill for the budgets that you produce. How often we read of a husband and wife both working
column4: struggling from paycheck to paycheck to raise a family
column5: meet a mortgage
column6: pay their taxes and bills. And yet some in Congress say taxes must be raised. Well
column7: I'm sorry; they're asking the wrong people to tighten their belts. It's time we reduce the Federal budget and left the family budget alone. We do not face large deficits because American families are undertaxed; we face those deficits because the Federal Government overspends.

column1: The detailed budget that we will submit will meet the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings target for deficit reductions
column2: meet our commitment to ensure a strong national defense
column3: meet our commitment to protect Social Security and the truly less fortunate
column4: and
column5: yes
column6: meet our commitment to not raise taxes. How should we accomplish this? Well
column7: not by taking from those in need. As families take care of their own
column8: government must provide shelter and nourishment for those who cannot provide for themselves. But we must revise or replace programs enacted in the name of compassion that degrade the moral worth of work
column9: encourage family breakups
column10: and drive entire communities into a bleak and heartless dependency. Gramm-Rudman-Hollings can mark a dramatic improvement. But experience shows that simply setting deficit targets does not assure they'll be met. We must proceed with Grace commission reforms against waste.

column1: And tonight I ask you to give me what 43 Governors have: Give me a line-item veto this year. Give me the authority to veto waste
column2: and I'll take the responsibility
column3: I'll make the cuts
column4: I'll take the heat. This authority would not give me any monopoly power
column5: but simply prevent spending measures from sneaking through that could not pass on their own merit. And you can sustain or override my veto; that's the way the system should work. Once we've made the hard choices
column6: we should lock in our gains with a balanced budget amendment to the Constitution.

column2: free
column3: and at peace is solely the responsibility of the Federal Government; it is government's prime responsibility. We have devoted 5 years trying to narrow a dangerous gap born of illusion and neglect
column4: and we've made important gains. Yet the threat from Soviet forces
column5: conventional and strategic
column6: from the Soviet drive for domination
column7: from the increase in espionage and state terror remains great. This is reality. Closing our eyes will not make reality disappear. We pledged together to hold real growth in defense spending to the bare minimum. My budget honors that pledge

column1: Ronald Reagan|Address Before a Joint Session of Congress on the State of the Union|1988-01-25|@Mr. Speaker
column2: Mr. President
column3: and distinguished Members of the House and Senate: When we first met here 7 years ago-many of us for the first timeit was with the hope of beginning something new for America. We meet here tonight in this historic Chamber to continue that work. If anyone expects just a proud recitation of the accomplishments of my administration
column4: I say let's leave that to history; we're not finished yet. So
column5: my message to you tonight is put on your work shoes; we're still on the job.

column1: History records the power of the ideas that brought us here those 7 years ago-ideas like the individual's right to reach as far and as high as his or her talents will permit; the free market as an engine of economic progress. And as an ancient Chinese philosopher
column2: Lao-tzu
column3: said: "Govern a great nation as you would cook a small fish; do not overdo it." Well
column4: these ideas were part of a larger notion
column5: a vision
column6: if you will
column7: of America herselfan America not only rich in opportunity for the individual but an America
column8: too
column9: of strong families and vibrant neighborhoods; an America whose divergent but harmonizing communities were a reflection of a deeper community of values: the value of work
column10: of family
column11: of religion
column12: and of the love of freedom that God places in each of us and whose defense He has entrusted in a special way to this nation.

column1: All of this was made possible by an idea I spoke of when Mr. Gorbachev was here-the belief that the most exciting revolution ever known to humankind began with three simple words: "We the People
column2:
the revolutionary notion that the people grant government its rights, and not the other way around. And there's one lesson that has come home powerfully to me, which I would offer to you now. Just as those who created this Republic pledged to each other their lives, their fortunes, and their sacred honor, so, too, America's leaders today must pledge to each other that we will keep foremost in our hearts and minds not what is best for ourselves or for our party but what is best for America.
In the spirit of Jefferson, let us affirm that in this Chamber tonight there are no Republicans, no Democratsjust Americans. Yes, we will have our differences, but let us always remember what unites us far outweighs whatever divides us. Those who sent us here to serve themthe millions of Americans watching and listening tonight-expect this of us. Let's prove to them and to ourselves that democracy works even in an election year. We've done this before. And as we have worked together to bring down spending, tax rates, and inflation, employment has climbed to record heights; America has created more jobs and better, higher paying jobs; family income has risen for 4 straight years, and America's poor climbed out of poverty at the fastest rate in more than 10 years.
Our record is not just the longest peacetime expansion in history but an economic and social revolution of hope based on work, incentives, growth, and opportunity; a revolution of compassion that led to private sector initiatives and a 77-percent increase in charitable giving; a revolution that at a critical moment in world history reclaimed and restored the American dream.
In international relations, too, there's only one description for what, together, we have achieved: a complete turnabout, a revolution. Seven years ago, America was weak, and freedom everywhere was under siege. Today America is strong, and democracy is everywhere on the move. From Central America to East Asia, ideas like free markets and democratic reforms and human rights are taking hold. We've replaced Blame America" with "Look up to America." We've rebuilt our defenses. And of all our accomplishments
column3: none can give us more satisfaction than knowing that our young people are again proud to wear our country's uniform.

We must protect that peace and deter war by making sure the next President inherits what you and I have a moral obligation to give that President: a national security that is unassailable and a national defense that takes full advantage of new technology and is fully funded.

column1: This is a full agenda. It's meant to be. You see

column1: And let's begin by discussing how to maintain economic growth by controlling and eventually eliminating the problem of Federal deficits. We have had a balanced budget only eight times in the last 57 years. For the first time in 14 years
column2: the Federal Government spent less in real terms last year than the year before. We took $73 billion off last year's deficit compared to the year before. The deficit itself has moved from 6.3 percent of the gross national product to only 3.4 percent. And perhaps the most important sign of progress has been the change in our view of deficits. You know
column3: a few of us can remember when

column6: because we owe it to ourselves. Well

Our approach is not to seek agreement for agreement's sake but to settle only for agreements that truly enhance our national security and that of our allies. We will never put our security at riskor that of our allies-just to reach an agreement with the Soviets. No agreement is better than a bad agreement.

column1: As I mentioned earlier
column2: our efforts are to give future generations what we never hada future free of nuclear terror. Reduction of strategic offensive arms is one step
column3: SDI another. Our funding request for our Strategic Defense Initiative is less than 2 percent of the total defense budget. SDI funding is money wisely appropriated and money well spent. SDI has the same purpose and supports the same goals of arms reduction. It reduces the risk of war and the threat of nuclear weapons to all mankind. column5: a consensus that prevents a paralysis of American power from ever occurring again.

column9: I ask for an honest commitment to our common mission of progress. If we seize the opportunities on the road before us
column10: there'll be praise enough for all. The people didn't send us here to bicker
column11: and it's time to govern.

column1: And many Presidents have come to this Chamber in times of great crisis: war and depression
column2: loss of national spirit. And 8 years ago
column3: I sat in that very chair as President Reagan spoke of punishing inflation and devastatingly high interest rates and people out of work -- American confidence on the wane. And our challenge is different. We're fortunate -- a much changed landscape lies before us tonight. So
column4: I don't propose to reverse direction. We're headed the right way
column5: but we cannot rest. We're a people whose energy and drive have fueled our rise to greatness. And we're a forward-looking nation -- generous
column6: yes
column7: but ambitious
column8: not for ourselves but for the world. Complacency is not in our character -- not before
column9: not now
column10: not ever.

column1: And so
column2: tonight we must take a strong America and make it even better. We must address some very real problems. We must establish some very clear priorities. And we must make a very substantial cut in the Federal budget deficit. Some people find that agenda impossible
column3: but I'm presenting to you tonight a realistic plan for tackling it. My plan has four broad features: attention to urgent priorities
column4: investment in the future
column5: an attack on the deficit
column6: and no new taxes. This budget represents my best judgment of how we can address our priorities. There are many areas in which we would all like to spend more than I propose; I understand that. But we cannot until we get our fiscal house in order.

column1: Next year alone
column2: thanks to economic growth
column3: without any change in the law
column4: the Federal Government will take in over $80 billion more than it does this year. That's right -- over $80 billion in new revenues
column5: with no increases in taxes. And our job is to allocate those new resources wisely. We can afford to increase spending by a modest amount
column6: but enough to invest in key priorities and still cut the deficit by almost 40 percent in 1 year. And that will allow us to meet the targets set forth in the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings law. But to do that
column7: we must recognize that growth above inflation in Federal programs is not preordained
column8: that not all spending initiatives were designed to be immortal.

column1: I make this pledge tonight: My team and I are ready to work with the Congress
column2: to form a special leadership group
column3: to negotiate in good faith
column4: to work day and night -- if that's what it takes -- to meet the budget targets and to produce a budget on time.

column1: We cannot settle for business as usual. Government by continuing resolution
column2: or government by crisis
column3: will not do. And I ask the Congress tonight to approve several measures which will make budgeting more sensible. We could save time and improve efficiency by enacting 2-year budgets. Forty-three Governors have the line-item veto. Presidents should have it
column4: too. And at the very least
column5: when a President proposes to rescind Federal spending
column6: the Congress should be required to vote on that proposal instead of killing it by inaction. And I ask the Congress to honor the public's wishes by passing a constitutional amendment to require a balanced budget. Such an amendment
column7: once phased in
column8: will discipline both the Congress and the executive branch.

column1: Several principles describe the kind of America I hope to build with your help in the years ahead. We will not have the luxury of taking the easy
column2: spendthrift approach to solving problems because higher spending and higher taxes put economic growth at risk. Economic growth provides jobs and hope. Economic growth enables us to pay for social programs. Economic growth enhances the security of the Nation
column3: and low tax rates create economic growth.

column1: I believe in giving Americans greater freedom and greater choice. And I will work for choice for American families
column2: whether in the housing in which they live
column3: the schools to which they send their children
column4: or the child care they select for their young. You see
column5: I believe that we have an obligation to those in need
column6: but that government should not be the provider of first resort for things that the private sector can produce better. I believe in a society that is free from discrimination and bigotry of any kind. And I will work to knock down the barriers left by past discrimination and to build a more tolerant society that will stop such barriers from ever being built again.

column1: I believe that family and faith represent the moral compass of the Nation. And I'll work to make them strong
column2: for as Benjamin Franklin said: "If a sparrow cannot fall to the ground without His notice
column3: can a great nation rise without His aid?" And I believe in giving people the power to make their own lives better through growth and opportunity. And together
column4: let's put power in the hands of people.

column1: Three weeks ago
column2: we celebrated the bicentennial inaugural
column3: the 200th anniversary of the first Presidency. And if you look back
column4: one thing is so striking about the way the Founding Fathers looked at America. They didn't talk about themselves. They talked about posterity. They talked about the future. And we
column5: too
column6: must think in terms bigger than ourselves. We must take actions today that will ensure a better tomorrow. We must extend American leadership in technology
column7: increase long-term investment
column8: improve our educational system
column9: and boost productivity. These are the keys to building a better future
column10: and here are some of my recommendations:

column1: I propose almost $2.2 billion for the National Science Foundation to promote basic research and keep us on track to double its budget by 1993.
I propose to make permanent the tax credit for research and development.
I've asked Vice President Quayle to chair a new Task Force on Competitiveness.
And I request funding for NASA [National Aeronautics and Space Administration] and a strong space program
column2: an increase of almost $2.4 billion over the current fiscal year. We must have a manned space station; a vigorous
column3: safe space shuttle program; and more commercial development in space. The space program should always go "full throttle up." And that's not just our ambition; it's our destiny.

column1: I propose that we cut the maximum tax rate on capital gains to increase long-term investment. History on this is clear -- this will increase revenues
column2: help savings
column3: and create new jobs. We won't be competitive if we leave whole sectors of America behind. This is the year we should finally enact urban enterprise zones and bring hope to the inner cities.

column1: But the most important competitiveness program of all is one which improves education in America. When some of our students actually have trouble locating America on a map of the world
column2: it is time for us to map a new approach to education. We must reward excellence and cut through bureaucracy. We must help schools that need help the most. We must give choice to parents
column3: students
column4: teachers
column5: and principals; and we must hold all concerned accountable. In education
column6: we cannot tolerate mediocrity. I want to cut that dropout rate and make America a more literate nation
column7: because what it really comes down to is this: The longer our graduation lines are today
column8: the shorter our unemployment lines will be tomorrow.

column1: So
column2: tonight I'm proposing the following initiatives: the beginning of a $500 million program to reward America's best schools
column3: merit schools; the creation of special Presidential awards for the best teachers in every State
column4: because excellence should be rewarded; the establishment of a new program of National Science Scholars
column5: one each year for every Member of the House and Senate
column6: to give this generation of students a special incentive to excel in science and mathematics; the expanded use of magnet schools
column7: which give families and students greater choice; and a new program to encourage alternative certification
column8: which will let talented people from all fields teach in our classrooms. I've said I'd like to be the "Education President." And tonight
column9: I'd ask you to join me by becoming the "Education Congress."

column1: Just last week
column2: as I settled into this new office
column3: I received a letter from a mother in Pennsylvania who had been struck by my message in the Inaugural Address. "Not 12 hours before
column4: she wrote, my husband and I received word that our son was addicted to cocaine. He had the world at his feet. Bright
column5: gifted
column6: personable -- he could have done anything with his life. And now he has chosen cocaine." "And please
column7: she wrote, find a way to curb the supply of cocaine. Get tough with the pushers. Our son needs your help."

column1: My friends
column2: that voice crying out for help could be the voice of your own neighbor
column3: your own friend
column4: your own son. Over 23 million Americans used illegal drugs last year
column5: at a staggering cost to our nation's well-being. Let this be recorded as the time when America rose up and said no to drugs. The scourge of drugs must be stopped. And I am asking tonight for an increase of almost a billion dollars in budget outlays to escalate the war against drugs. The war must be waged on all fronts. Our new drug czar
column6: Bill Bennett
column7: and I will be shoulder to shoulder in the executive branch leading the charge.

column1: Some money will be used to expand treatment to the poor and to young mothers. This will offer the helping hand to the many innocent victims of drugs
column2: like the thousands of babies born addicted or with AIDS because of the mother's addiction. Some will be used to cut the waiting time for treatment. Some money will be devoted to those urban schools where the emergency is now the worst. And much of it will be used to protect our borders
column3: with help from the Coast Guard and the Customs Service
column4: the Departments of State and Justice
column5: and
column6: yes
column7: the U.S. military.

column1: I mean to get tough on the drug criminals. And let me be clear: This President will back up those who put their lives on the line every single day -- our local police officers. My budget asks for beefed-up prosecution
column2: for a new attack on organized crime
column3: and for enforcement of tough sentences -- and for the worst kingpins
column4: that means the death penalty. I also want to make sure that when a drug dealer is convicted there's a cell waiting for him. And he should not go free because prisons are too full. And so
column5: let the word go out: If you're caught and convicted
column6: you will do time.

column1: But for all we do in law enforcement
column2: in interdiction and treatment
column3: we will never win this war on drugs unless we stop the demand for drugs. So
column4: some of this increase will be used to educate the young about the dangers of drugs. We must involve the parents. We must involve the teachers. We must involve the communities. And
column5: my friends
column6: we must involve ourselves
column7: each and every one of us in this concern.

column1: One problem related to drug use demands our urgent attention and our continuing compassion
column2: and that is the terrible tragedy of AIDS. I'm asking for $1.6 billion for education to prevent the disease and for research to find a cure.

column1: If we're to protect our future
column2: we need a new attitude about the environment. We must protect the air we breathe. I will send to you shortly legislation for a new
column3: more effective Clean Air Act. It will include a plan to reduce by date certain the emissions which cause acid rain
column4: because the time for study alone has passed
column5: and the time for action is now. We must make use of clean coal. My budget contains full funding
column6: on schedule
column7: for the clean coal technology agreement that we've made with Canada. We've made that agreement with Canada
column8: and we intend to honor that agreement. We must not neglect our parks. So
column9: I'm asking to fund new acquisitions under the Land and Water Conservation Fund. We must protect our oceans. And I support new penalties against those who would dump medical waste and other trash into our oceans. The age of the needle on the beaches must end.

column1: And in some cases
column2: the gulfs and oceans off our shores hold the promise of oil and gas reserves which can make our nation more secure and less dependent on foreign oil. And when those with the most promise can be tapped safely
column3: as with much of the Alaska National Wildlife Refuge
column4: we should proceed. But we must use caution; we must respect the environment. And so
column5: tonight I'm calling for the indefinite postponement of three lease sales which have raised troubling questions
column6: two off the coast of California and one which could threaten the Everglades in Florida. Action on these three lease sales will await the conclusion of a special task force set up to measure the potential for environmental damage.

column1: I'm directing the Attorney General and the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency to use every tool at their disposal to speed and toughen the enforcement of our laws against toxic-waste dumpers. I want faster cleanups and tougher enforcement of penalties against polluters.
In addition to caring for our future
column2: we must care for those around us. A decent society shows compassion for the young
column3: the elderly
column4: the vulnerable
column5: and the poor. Our first obligation is to the most vulnerable -- infants
column6: poor mothers
column7: children living in poverty -- and my proposed budget recognizes this. I ask for full funding of Medicaid
column8: an increase of over $3 billion
column9: and an expansion of the program to include coverage of pregnant women who are near the poverty line. I believe we should help working families cope with the burden of child care. Our help should be aimed at those who need it most: low-income families with young children. I support a new child care tax credit that will aim our efforts at exactly those families
column10: without discriminating against mothers who choose to stay at home.

column1: Now
column2: I know there are competing proposals. But remember this: The overwhelming majority of all preschool child care is now provided by relatives and neighbors and churches and community groups. Families who choose these options should remain eligible for help. Parents should have choice. And for those children who are unwanted or abused or whose parents are deceased
column3: we should encourage adoption. I propose to reenact the tax deduction for adoption expenses and to double it to $3
column4: 000. Let's make it easier for these kids to have parents who love them.

column1: We have a moral contract with our senior citizens. And in this budget
column2: Social Security is fully funded
column3: including a full cost-of-living adjustment. We must honor our contract.

column1: We must care about those in the shadow of life
column2: and I
column3: like many Americans
column4: am deeply troubled by the plight of the homeless. The causes of homelessness are many; the history is long. But the moral imperative to act is clear. Thanks to the deep well of generosity in this great land
column5: many organizations already contribute
column6: but we in government cannot stand on the sidelines. In my budget
column7: I ask for greater support for emergency food and shelter
column8: for health services and measures to prevent substance abuse
column9: and for clinics for the mentally ill. And I propose a new initiative involving the full range of government agencies. We must confront this national shame.

column1: There's another issue that I've decided to mention here tonight. I've long believed that the people of Puerto Rico should have the right to determine their own political future. Personally
column2: I strongly favor statehood. But I urge the Congress to take the necessary steps to allow the people to decide in a referendum.

column1: Certain problems
column2: the result of decades of unwise practices
column3: threaten the health and security of our people. Left unattended
column4: they will only get worse. But we can act now to put them behind us.

column1: Earlier this week
column2: I announced my support for a plan to restore the financial and moral integrity of our savings system. I ask Congress to enact our reform proposals within 45 days. We must not let this situation fester. We owe it to the savers in this country to solve this problem. Certainly
column3: the savings of Americans must remain secure. Let me be clear: Insured depositors will continue to be fully protected
column4: but any plan to refinance the system must be accompanied by major reform. Our proposals will prevent such a crisis from recurring. The best answer is to make sure that a mess like this will never happen again. The majority of thrifts in communities across the Nation have been honest. They've played a major role in helping families achieve the dream of home ownership. But make no mistake
column5: those who are corrupt
column6: those who break the law
column7: must be kicked out of the business; and they should go to jail.

column1: We face a massive task in cleaning up the waste left from decades of environmental neglect at America's nuclear weapons plants. Clearly
column2: we must modernize these plants and operate them safely. That's not at issue; our national security depends on it. But beyond that
column3: we must clean up the old mess that's been left behind. And I propose in this budget to more than double our current effort to do so. This will allow us to identify the exact nature of the various problems so we can clean them up
column4: and clean them up we will.

column1: We've been fortunate during these past 8 years. America is a stronger nation than it was in 1980. Morale in our Armed Forces has been restored; our resolve has been shown. Our readiness has been improved
column2: and we are at peace. There can no longer be any doubt that peace has been made more secure through strength. And when America is stronger
column3: the world is safer.

column1: Most people don't realize that after the successful restoration of our strength
column2: the Pentagon budget has actually been reduced in real terms for each of the last 4 years. We cannot tolerate continued real reduction in defense. In light of the compelling need to reduce the deficit
column3: however
column4: I support a 1-year freeze in the military budget
column5: something I proposed last fall in my flexible freeze plan. And this freeze will apply for only 1 year
column6: and after that
column7: increases above inflation will be required. I will not sacrifice American preparedness
column8: and I will not compromise American strength.

column1: I should be clear on the conditions attached to my recommendation for the coming year: The savings must be allocated to those priorities for investing in our future that I've spoken about tonight. This defense freeze must be a part of a comprehensive budget agreement which meets the targets spelled out in Gramm-Rudman-Hollings law without raising taxes and which incorporates reforms in the budget process.

I've directed the National Security Council to review our national security and defense policies and report back to me within 90 days to ensure that our capabilities and resources meet our commitments and strategies. I'm also charging the Department of Defense with the task of developing a plan to improve the defense procurement process and management of the Pentagon
column2: one which will fully implement the Packard commission report. Many of these changes can only be made with the participation of the Congress
column3: and so
column4: I ask for your help. We need fewer regulations. We need less bureaucracy. We need multiyear procurement and 2-year budgeting. And frankly -- and don't take this wrong -- we need less congressional micromanagement of our nation's military policy. I detect a slight division on that question
column5: but nevertheless -- .

column1: Securing a more peaceful world is perhaps the most important priority I'd like to address tonight. You know
column2: we meet at a time of extraordinary hope. Never before in this century have our values of freedom
column3: democracy
column4: and economic opportunity been such a powerful and intellectual force around the globe. Never before has our leadership been so crucial
column5: because while America has its eyes on the future
column6: the world has its eyes on America.

column1: And it's a time of great change in the world
column2: and especially in the Soviet Union. Prudence and common sense dictate that we try to understand the full meaning of the change going on there
column3: review our policies
column4: and then proceed with caution. But I've personally assured General Secretary Gorbachev that at the conclusion of such a review we will be ready to move forward. We will not miss any opportunity to work for peace. The fundamental facts remain that the Soviets retain a very powerful military machine in the service of objectives which are still too often in conflict with ours. So
column5: let us take the new openness seriously
column6: but let's also be realistic. And let's always be strong.

column1: There are some pressing issues we must address. I will vigorously pursue the Strategic Defense Initiative. The spread
column2: and even use
column3: of sophisticated weaponry threatens global security as never before. Chemical weapons must be banned from the face of the Earth
column4: never to be used again. And look
column5: this won't be easy. Verification -- extraordinarily difficult
column6: but civilization and human decency demand that we try. And the spread of nuclear weapons must be stopped. And I'll work to strengthen the hand of the International Atomic Energy Agency. Our diplomacy must work every day against the proliferation of nuclear weapons.

column1: And around the globe
column2: we must continue to be freedom's best friend. And we must stand firm for self-determination and democracy in Central America
column3: including in Nicaragua. It is my strongly held conviction that when people are given the chance they inevitably will choose a free press
column4: freedom of worship
column5: and certifiably free and fair elections.

column1: We must strengthen the alliance of the industrial democracies
column2: as solid a force for peace as the world has ever known. And this is an alliance forged by the power of our ideals
column3: not the pettiness of our differences. So
column4: let's lift our sights to rise above fighting about beef hormones
column5: to building a better future
column6: to move from protectionism to progress.

column1: I've asked the Secretary of State to visit Europe next week and to consult with our allies on the wide range of challenges and opportunities we face together
column2: including East-West relations. And I look forward to meeting with our NATO partners in the near future.

column1: And I
column2: too
column3: shall begin a trip shortly to the far reaches of the Pacific Basin
column4: where the winds of democracy are creating new hope and the power of free markets is unleashing a new force. When I served as our representative in China 14 or 15 years ago
column5: few would have predicted the scope of the changes we've witnessed since then. But in preparing for this trip
column6: I was struck by something I came across from a Chinese writer. He was speaking of his country
column7: decades ago
column8: but his words speak to each of us in America tonight. "Today
column9: he said, we're afraid of the simple words like `goodness' and `mercy' and `kindness."' My friends
column10: if we're to succeed as a nation
column11: we must rediscover those words.

column1: In just 3 days
column2: we mark the birthday of Abraham Lincoln
column3: the man who saved our Union and gave new meaning to the word "opportunity." Lincoln once said: "I hold that while man exists
column4: it is his duty to improve not only his own condition but to assist in ameliorating that of mankind." It is this broader mission to which I call all Americans
column5: because the definition of a successful life must include serving others.

column1: And to the young people of America
column2: who sometimes feel left out
column3: I ask you tonight to give us the benefit of your talent and energy through a new program called YES
column4: for Youth Entering Service to America.

column1: To those men and women in business
column2: remember the ultimate end of your work: to make a better product
column3: to create better lives. I ask you to plan for the longer term and avoid that temptation of quick and easy paper profits.

column1: To the brave men and women who wear the uniform of the United States of America
column2: thank you. Your calling is a high one: to be the defenders of freedom and the guarantors of liberty. And I want you to know that this nation is grateful for your service.

column1: To the farmers of America
column2: we appreciate the bounty you provide. We will work with you to open foreign markets to American agricultural products.

column1: And to the parents of America
column2: I ask you to get involved in your child's schooling. Check on the homework
column3: go to the school
column4: meet the teachers
column5: care about what is happening there. It's not only your child's future on the line
column6: it's America's.

column1: To kids in our cities
column2: don't give up hope. Say no to drugs; stay in school. And
column3: yes
column4: "Keep hope alive."

column1: To those 37 million Americans with some form of disability
column2: you belong in the economic mainstream. We need your talents in America's work force. Disabled Americans must become full partners in America's opportunity society.

column1: To the families of America watching tonight in your living rooms
column2: hold fast to your dreams because ultimately America's future rests in your hands.

column1: And to my friends in this Chamber
column2: I ask your cooperation to keep America growing while cutting the deficit. That's only fair to those who now have no vote: the generations to come. Let them look back and say that we had the foresight to understand that a time of peace and prosperity is not the time to rest but a time to press forward
column3: a time to invest in the future.

column1: And let all Americans remember that no problem of human making is too great to be overcome by human ingenuity
column2: human energy
column3: and the untiring hope of the human spirit. I believe this. I would not have asked to be your President if I didn't. And tomorrow the debate on the plan I've put forward begins
column4: and I ask the Congress to come forward with your own proposals. Let's not question each other's motives. Let's debate
column5: let's negotiate; but let us solve the problem.

column1: Recalling anniversaries may not be my specialty in speeches ... but tonight is one of some note. On February 9th
column3: just 48 years ago tonight
column4: Sir Winston Churchill took to the airwaves during Britain's hour of peril. He'd received from President Roosevelt a hand-carried letter quoting Longfellow's famous poem: "Sail on
column5: O Ship of State! Sail on
column6: O Union
column7: strong and great! Humanity with all its fears
column8: With all the hopes of future years
column9: Is hanging breathless on thy fate!" And Churchill responded on this night by radio broadcast to a nation at war
column10: but he directed his words to Franklin Roosevelt. "We shall not fail or falter
column11: he said. We shall not weaken or tire. Give us the tools
column12: and we will finish the job."

column1: Tonight
column2: almost half a century later
column3: our peril may be less immediate
column4: but the need for perseverance and clear-sighted fortitude is just as great. Now
column5: as then
column6: there are those who say it can't be done. There are voices who say that America's best days have passed
column7: that we're bound by constraints
column8: threatened by problems
column9: surrounded by troubles which limit our ability to hope. Well
column10: tonight I remain full of hope. We Americans have only begun on our mission of goodness and greatness. And to those timid souls
column11: I repeat the plea: "Give us the tools
column12: and we will do the job."

column1: Thank you. God bless you
column2: and God bless America.@

column1: George Bush|Address Before a Joint Session of the Congress on the State of the Union|1990-01-31|@Mr. President
column2: Mr. Speaker
column3: Members of the United States Congress:

column1: I return as a former President of the Senate and a former Member of this great House. And now
column2: as President
column3: it is my privilege to report to you on the state of the Union.

column1: Tonight I come not to speak about the state of the Government
column2: not to detail every new initiative we plan for the coming year nor to describe every line in the budget. I'm here to speak to you and to the American people about the state of the Union
column3: about our world -- the changes we've seen
column4: the challenges we face -- and what that means for America.

column1: There are singular moments in history
column2: dates that divide all that goes before from all that comes after. And many of us in this Chamber have lived much of our lives in a world whose fundamental features were defined in 1945; and the events of that year decreed the shape of nations
column3: the pace of progress
column4: freedom or oppression for millions of people around the world.

column1: Nineteen forty-five provided the common frame of reference
column2: the compass points of the postwar era we've relied upon to understand ourselves. And that was our world
column3: until now. The events of the year just ended
column4: the Revolution of '89
column5: have been a chain reaction
column6: changes so striking that it marks the beginning of a new era in the world's affairs.

column1: Think back -- think back just 12 short months ago to the world we knew as 1989 began.
One year -- one year ago
column2: the people of Panama lived in fear
column3: under the thumb of a dictator. Today democracy is restored; Panama is free. Operation Just Cause has achieved its objective. The number of military personnel in Panama is now very close to what it was before the operation began. And tonight I am announcing that well before the end of February
column4: the additional numbers of American troops
column5: the brave men and women of our Armed Forces who made this mission a success
column6: will be back home.

column1: A year ago in Poland
column2: Lech Walesa declared that he was ready to open a dialog with the Communist rulers of that country; and today
column3: with the future of a free Poland in their own hands
column4: members of Solidarity lead the Polish Government.

column1: A year ago
column2: freedom's playwright
column3: Vaclav Havel
column4: languished as a prisoner in Prague. And today it's Vaclav Havel
column5: President of Czechoslovakia.

column1: And 1 year ago
column2: Erich Honecker of East Germany claimed history as his guide
column3: and he predicted the Berlin Wall would last another hundred years. And today
column4: less than 1 year later
column5: it's the Wall that's history.

column1: Remarkable events -- events that fulfill the long-held hopes of the American people; events that validate the longstanding goals of American policy
column2: a policy based on a single
column3: shining principle: the cause of freedom.

column1: America
column2: not just the nation but an idea
column3: alive in the minds of people everywhere. As this new world takes shape
column4: America stands at the center of a widening circle of freedom -- today
column5: tomorrow
column6: and into the next century. Our nation is the enduring dream of every immigrant who ever set foot on these shores
column7: and the millions still struggling to be free. This nation
column8: this idea called America
column9: was and always will be a new world -- our new world.

column1: At a workers' rally
column2: in a place called Branik on the outskirts of Prague
column3: the idea called America is alive. A worker
column4: dressed in grimy overalls
column5: rises to speak at the factory gates. He begins his speech to his fellow citizens with these words
column6: words of a distant revolution: "We hold these truths to be self-evident
column7: that all men are created equal
column8: that they are endowed by their Creator with certain unalienable Rights
column9: and that among these are Life
column10: Liberty and the pursuit of Happiness."

column1: It's no secret that here at home freedom's door opened long ago. The cornerstones of this free society have already been set in place: democracy
column2: competition
column3: opportunity
column4: private investment
column5: stewardship
column6: and of course leadership. And our challenge today is to take this democratic system of ours
column7: a system second to none
column8: and make it better: a better America
column9: where there's a job for everyone who wants one; where women working outside the home can be confident their children are in safe and loving care and where government works to expand child-care alternatives for parents; where we reconcile the needs of a clean environment and a strong economy; where "Made in the USA" is recognized around the world as the symbol of quality and progress; where every one of us enjoys the same opportunities to live
column10: to work
column11: and to contribute to society and where
column12: for the first time
column13: the American mainstream includes all of our disabled citizens; where everyone has a roof over his head and where the homeless get the help they need to live in dignity; where our schools challenge and support our kids and our teachers and where all of them make the grade; where every street
column14: every city
column16: and every child is drug-free; and finally
column17: where no American is forgotten -- our hearts go out to our hostages who are ceaselessly on our minds and in our efforts.

column1: That's part of the future we want to see
column2: the future we can make for ourselves
column3: but dreams alone won't get us there. We need to extend our horizon
column4: commit to the long view. And our mission for the future starts today.

column1: In the tough competitive markets around the world
column2: America faces the great challenges and great opportunities. And we know that we can succeed in the global economic arena of the nineties
column3: but to meet that challenge
column4: we must make some fundamental changes -- some crucial investment in ourselves.

column1: Yes
column2: we are going to invest in America. This administration is determined to encourage the creation of capital
column3: capital of all kinds: physical capital -- everything from our farms and factories to our workshops and production lines
column4: all that is needed to produce and deliver quality goods and quality services; intellectual capital -- the source of ideas that spark tomorrow's products; and of course our human capital -- the talented work force that we'll need to compete in the global market.

column1: Let me tell you
column2: if we ignore human capital
column3: if we lose the spirit of American ingenuity
column4: the spirit that is the hallmark of the American worker
column5: that would be bad. The American worker is the most productive worker in the world.

column1: We need to save more. We need to expand the pool of capital for new investments that need more jobs and more growth. And that's the idea behind a new initiative I call the Family Savings Plan
column2: which I will send to Congress tomorrow.

column1: We need to cut the tax on capital gains
column2: encourage risktakers
column3: especially those in our small businesses
column4: to take those steps that translate into economic reward
column5: jobs
column6: and a better life for all of us.

column1: We'll do what it takes to invest in America's future. The budget commitment is there. The money is there. It's there for research and development
column2: R&D -- a record high. It's there for our housing initiative -- HOPE -- to help everyone from first-time homebuyers to the homeless. The money's there to keep our kids drug-free -- 70 percent more than when I took office in 1989. It's there for space exploration. And it's there for education -- another record high.

column1: And one more thing: Last fall at the education summit
column2: the Governors and I agreed to look for ways to help make sure that our kids are ready to learn the very first day they walk into the classroom. And I've made good on that commitment by proposing a record increase in funds -- an extra half-a-billion dollars -- for something near and dear to all of us: Head Start.

column1: Education is the one investment that means more for our future because it means the most for our children. Real improvement in our schools is not simply a matter of spending more: It's a matter of asking more -- expecting more -- of our schools
column2: our teachers
column3: of our kids
column4: of our parents
column5: and ourselves. And that's why tonight I am announcing America's education goals
column6: goals developed with enormous cooperation from the Nation's Governors. And if I might
column7: I'd like to say I'm very pleased that Governor Gardner [Washington] and Governor Clinton [Arkansas]
column8: Governor Branstad [Iowa]
column9: Governor Campbell [South Carolina]
column10: all of whom were very key in these discussions
column11: these deliberations
column12: are with us here tonight.

column1: By the year 2000
column2: every child must start school ready to learn.

column1: The United States must increase the high school graduation rate to no less than 90 percent.
And we are going to make sure our schools' diplomas mean something. In critical subjects -- at the 4th
column2: 8th
column3: and 12th grades -- we must assess our students' performance.

column1: By the year 2000
column2: U.S. students must be first in the world in math and science achievement.

column1: Every American adult must be a skilled
column2: literate worker and citizen.

column1: Every school must offer the kind of disciplined environment that makes it possible for our kids to learn. And every school in America must be drug-free.
Ambitious aims? Of course. Easy to do? Far from it. But the future's at stake. The Nation will not accept anything less than excellence in education.
These investments will keep America competitive. And I know this about the American people: We welcome competition. We'll match our ingenuity
column2: our energy
column3: our experience and technology
column4: our spirit and enterprise against anyone. But let the competition be free
column5: but let it also be fair. America is ready.

column1: Since we really mean it and since we're serious about being ready to meet that challenge
column2: we're getting our own house in order. We have made real progress. Seven years ago
column3: the Federal deficit was 6 percent of our gross national product -- 6 percent. In the new budget I sent up 2 days ago
column4: the deficit is down to 1 percent of gross national product.

column1: That budget brings Federal spending under control. It meets the Gramm-Rudman target. It brings that deficit down further and balances the budget by 1993 with no new taxes. And let me tell you
column2: there's still more than enough Federal spending. For most of us
column3: $1.2 trillion is still a lot of money.

column1: And once the budget is balanced
column2: we can operate the way every family must when it has bills to pay. We won't leave it to our children and our grandchildren. Once it's balanced
column3: we will start paying off the national debt.

column1: And there's something more we owe the generations of the future: stewardship
column2: the safekeeping of America's precious environmental inheritance. It's just one sign of how serious we are. We will elevate the Environmental Protection Agency to Cabinet rank -- not more bureaucracy
column3: not more red-tape
column4: but the certainty that here at home
column5: and especially in our dealings with other nations
column6: environmental issues have the status they deserve.

column1: This year's budget provides over $2 billion in new spending to protect our environment
column2: with over $1 billion for global change research
column3: and a new initiative I call America the Beautiful to expand our national parks and wildlife preserves that improve recreational facilities on public lands
column4: and something else
column5: something that will help keep this country clean from our forestland to the inner cities and keep America beautiful for generations to come: the money to plant a billion trees a year.

column1: And tonight let me say again to all the Members of the Congress: The American people did not send us here to bicker. There is work to do
column2: and they sent us here to get it done. And once again
column3: in the spirit of cooperation
column4: I offer my hand to all of you. Let's work together to do the will of the people: clean air
column5: child care
column6: the Educational Excellence Act
column7: crime
column8: and drugs. It's time to act. The farm bill
column9: transportation policy
column10: product-liability reform
column11: enterprise zones -- it's time to act together.

column1: And there's one thing I hope we will be able to agree on. It's about our commitments. I'm talking about Social Security. To every American out there on Social Security
column2: to every American supporting that system today
column3: and to everyone counting on it when they retire
column4: we made a promise to you
column5: and we are going to keep it.

column1: We rescued the system in 1983
column2: and it's sound again -- bipartisan arrangement. Our budget fully funds today's benefits
column3: and it assures that future benefits will be funded as well. The last thing we need to do is mess around with Social Security.

column1: There's one more problem we need to address. We must give careful consideration to the recommendations of the health-care studies underway now. That's why tonight I'm asking Dr. Sullivan
column2: Lou Sullivan
column3: Secretary of Health and Human Services
column4: to lead a Domestic Policy Council review of recommendations on the quality
column5: accessibility
column6: and cost of our nation's health-care system. I am committed to bring the staggering costs of health care under control.

column1: The state of the Government does indeed depend on many of us in this very chamber. But the state of the Union depends on all Americans. We must maintain the democratic decency that makes a nation out of millions of individuals. I've been appalled at the recent mail bombings across this country. Every one of us must confront and condemn racism
column2: anti-Semitism
column3: bigotry
column4: and hate
column5: not next week
column6: not tomorrow
column7: but right now -- every single one of us.

column1: The state of the Union depends on whether we help our neighbor -- claim the problems of our community as our own. We've got to step forward when there's trouble
column2: lend a hand
column3: be what I call a point of light to a stranger in need. We've got to take the time after a busy day to sit down and read with our kids
column4: help them with their homework
column5: pass along the values we learned as children. That's how we sustain the state of the Union. Every effort is important. It all adds up. It's doing the things that give democracy meaning. It all adds up to who we are and who we will be.

column1: Let me say that so long as we remember the American idea
column2: so long as we live up to the American ideal
column3: the state of the Union will remain sound and strong.

column1: And to those who worry that we've lost our way -- well
column2: I want you to listen to parts of a letter written by Private First Class James Markwell
column3: a 20-year-old Army medic of the 1st Battalion
column4: 75th Rangers. It's dated December 18th
column5: the night before our armed forces went into action in Panama. It's a letter servicemen write and hope will never be sent. And sadly
column6: Private Markwell's mother did receive this letter. She passed it along to me out there in Cincinnati.

column1: And here is some of what he wrote: "I've never been afraid of death
column2: but I know he is waiting at the corner. I've been trained to kill and to save
column3: and so has everyone else. I am frightened what lays beyond the fog
column4: and yet do not mourn for me. Revel in the life that I have died to give you. But most of all
column5: don't forget the Army was my choice. Something that I wanted to do. Remember I joined the Army to serve my country and ensure that you are free to do what you want and live your lives freely."

column1: Let me add that Private Markwell was among the first to see battle in Panama
column2: and one of the first to fall. But he knew what he believed in. He carried the idea we call America in his heart.

column1: I began tonight speaking about the changes we've seen this past year. There is a new world of challenges and opportunities before us
column2: and there's a need for leadership that only America can provide. Nearly 40 years ago
column3: in his last address to the Congress
column4: President Harry Truman predicted such a time would come. He said: "As our world grows stronger
column5: more united
column6: more attractive to men on both sides of the Iron Curtain
column7: then inevitably there will come a time of change within the Communist world." Today
column8: that change is taking place.

column1: For more than 40 years
column2: America and its allies held communism in check and ensured that democracy would continue to exist. And today
column3: with communism crumbling
column4: our aim must be to ensure democracy's advance
column5: to take the lead in forging peace and freedom's best hope: a great and growing commonwealth of free nations. And to the Congress and to all Americans
column6: I say it is time to acclaim a new consensus at home and abroad
column7: a common vision of the peaceful world we want to see.

column1: Here in our own hemisphere
column2: it is time for all the peoples of the Americas
column3: North and South
column4: to live in freedom. In the Far East and Africa
column5: it's time for the full flowering of free governments and free markets that have served as the engine of progress. It's time to offer our hand to the emerging democracies of Eastern Europe so that continent -- for too long a continent divided -- can see a future whole and free. It's time to build on our new relationship with the Soviet Union
column6: to endorse and encourage a peaceful process of internal change toward democracy and economic opportunity.

column1: We are in a period of great transition
column2: great hope
column3: and yet great uncertainty. We recognize that the Soviet military threat in Europe is diminishing
column4: but we see little change in Soviet strategic modernization. Therefore
column5: we must sustain our own strategic offense modernization and the Strategic Defense Initiative.

column1: But the time is right to move forward on a conventional arms control agreement to move us to more appropriate levels of military forces in Europe
column2: a coherent defense program that ensures the U.S. will continue to be a catalyst for peaceful change in Europe. And I've consulted with leaders of NATO. In fact
column3: I spoke by phone with President Gorbachev just today.

column1: I agree with our European allies that an American military presence in Europe is essential and that it should not be tied solely to the Soviet military presence in Eastern Europe. But our troop levels can still be lower. And so
column2: tonight I am announcing a major new step for a further reduction in U.S. and Soviet manpower in Central and Eastern Europe to 195
column3: 000 on each side. This level reflects the advice of our senior military advisers. It's designed to protect American and European interests and sustain NATO's defense strategy. A swift conclusion to our arms control talks -- conventional
column4: chemical
column5: and strategic -- must now be our goal. And that time has come.

column1: Still
column2: we must recognize an unfortunate fact: In many regions of the world tonight
column3: the reality is conflict
column4: not peace. Enduring animosities and opposing interests remain. And thus
column5: the cause of peace must be served by an America strong enough and sure enough to defend our interests and our ideals. It's this American idea that for the past four decades helped inspire this Revolution of '89.

column1: Here at home and in the world
column2: there's history in the making
column3: history to be made. Six months ago
column4: early in this season of change
column5: I stood at the gates of the Gdansk shipyard in Poland at the monument to the fallen workers of Solidarity. It's a monument of simple majesty. Three tall crosses rise up from the stones
column6: and atop each cross
column7: an anchor -- an ancient symbol of hope.

column1: The anchor in our world today is freedom
column2: holding us steady in times of change
column3: a symbol of hope to all the world. And freedom is at the very heart of the idea that is America. Giving life to that idea depends on every one of us. Our anchor has always been faith and family.

column1: In the last few days of this past momentous year
column2: our family was blessed once more
column3: celebrating the joy of life when a little boy became our 12th grandchild. When I held the little guy for the first time
column4: the troubles at home and abroad seemed manageable and totally in perspective.

column1: Now
column2: I know you're probably thinking
column3: well
column4: that's just a grandfather talking. Well
column5: maybe you're right. But I've met a lot of children this past year across this country
column6: as all of you have
column7: everywhere from the Far East to Eastern Europe. And all kids are unique
column8: and yet all kids are alike -- the budding young environmentalists I met this month who joined me in exploring the Florida Everglades; the little leaguers I played catch with in Poland
column9: ready to go from Warsaw to the World Series; and even the kids who are ill or alone -- and God bless those boarder babies
column10: born addicted to drugs and AIDS and coping with problems no child should have to face. But you know
column11: when it comes to hope and the future
column12: every kid is the same -- full of dreams
column13: ready to take on the world -- all special
column14: because they are the very future of freedom. And to them belongs this new world I've been speaking about.

column1: And so
column2: tonight I'm going to ask something of every one of you. Now
column3: let me start with my generation
column4: with the grandparents out there. You are our living link to the past. Tell your grandchildren the story of struggles waged at home and abroad
column5: of sacrifices freely made for freedom's sake. And tell them your own story as well
column6: because every American has a story to tell.

column1: And
column2: parents
column3: your children look to you for direction and guidance. Tell them of faith and family. Tell them we are one nation under God. Teach them that of all the many gifts they can receive liberty is their most precious legacy
column4: and of all the gifts they can give the greatest is helping others.

column1: And to the children and young people out there tonight: With you rests our hope
column2: all that America will mean in the years and decades ahead. Fix your vision on a new century -- your century
column3: on dreams we cannot see
column4: on the destiny that is yours and yours alone.

column1: And finally
column2: let all Americans -- all of us together here in this Chamber
column3: the symbolic center of democracy -- affirm our allegiance to this idea we call America. And let us remember that the state of the Union depends on each and every one of us.

column1: God bless all of you
column2: and may God bless this great nation
column3: the United States of America.@

column1: George Bush|Address Before a Joint Session of the Congress on the State of the Union|1991-01-29|@Mr. President and Mr. Speaker and Members of the United States Congress:
I come to this House of the people to speak to you and all Americans
column2: certain that we stand at a defining hour. Halfway around the world
column3: we are engaged in a great struggle in the skies and on the seas and sands. We know why we're there: We are Americans
column4: part of something larger than ourselves. For two centuries
column5: we've done the hard work of freedom. And tonight
column6: we lead the world in facing down a threat to decency and humanity.

column1: What is at stake is more than one small country; it is a big idea: a new world order
column2: where diverse nations are drawn together in common cause to achieve the universal aspirations of mankind -- peace and security
column3: freedom
column4: and the rule of law. Such is a world worthy of our struggle and worthy of our children's future.

column1: The community of nations has resolutely gathered to condemn and repel lawless aggression. Saddam Hussein's unprovoked invasion -- his ruthless
column2: systematic rape of a peaceful neighbor -- violated everything the community of nations holds dear. The world has said this aggression would not stand
column3: and it will not stand. Together
column4: we have resisted the trap of appeasement
column5: cynicism
column6: and isolation that gives temptation to tyrants. The world has answered Saddam's invasion with 12 United Nations resolutions
column7: starting with a demand for Iraq's immediate and unconditional withdrawal
column8: and backed up by forces from 28 countries of 6 continents. With few exceptions
column9: the world now stands as one.

column1: The end of the cold war has been a victory for all humanity. A year and a half ago
column2: in Germany
column3: I said that our goal was a Europe whole and free. Tonight
column4: Germany is united. Europe has become whole and free
column5: and America's leadership was instrumental in making it possible.

column1: Our relationship to the Soviet Union is important
column2: not only to us but to the world. That relationship has helped to shape these and other historic changes. But like many other nations
column3: we have been deeply concerned by the violence in the Baltics
column4: and we have communicated that concern to the Soviet leadership. The principle that has guided us is simple: Our objective is to help the Baltic peoples achieve their aspirations
column5: not to punish the Soviet Union. In our recent discussions with the Soviet leadership we have been given representations which
column6: if fulfilled
column7: would result in the withdrawal of some Soviet forces
column8: a reopening of dialog with the Republics
column9: and a move away from violence.

column1: We will watch carefully as the situation develops. And we will maintain our contact with the Soviet leadership to encourage continued commitment to democratization and reform. If it is possible
column2: I want to continue to build a lasting basis for U.S.-Soviet cooperation -- for a more peaceful future for all mankind.

column1: The triumph of democratic ideas in Eastern Europe and Latin America and the continuing struggle for freedom elsewhere all around the world all confirm the wisdom of our nation's founders. Tonight
column2: we work to achieve another victory
column3: a victory over tyranny and savage aggression.

column1: We in this Union enter the last decade of the 20th century thankful for our blessings
column2: steadfast in our purpose
column3: aware of our difficulties
column4: and responsive to our duties at home and around the world. For two centuries
column5: America has served the world as an inspiring example of freedom and democracy. For generations
column6: America has led the struggle to preserve and extend the blessings of liberty. And today
column7: in a rapidly changing world
column8: American leadership is indispensable. Americans know that leadership brings burdens and sacrifices. But we also know why the hopes of humanity turn to us. We are Americans; we have a unique responsibility to do the hard work of freedom. And when we do
column9: freedom works.

column1: The conviction and courage we see in the Persian Gulf today is simply the American character in action. The indomitable spirit that is contributing to this victory for world peace and justice is the same spirit that gives us the power and the potential to meet our toughest challenges at home. We are resolute and resourceful. If we can selflessly confront the evil for the sake of good in a land so far away
column2: then surely we can make this land all that it should be. If anyone tells you that America's best days are behind her
column3: they're looking the wrong way.

column1: Tonight I come before this House and the American people with an appeal for renewal. This is not merely a call for new government initiatives; it is a call for new initiatives in government
column2: in our communities
column3: and from every American to prepare for the next American century.

column1: America has always led by example. So
column2: who among us will set the example? Which of our citizens will lead us in this next American century? Everyone who steps forward today -- to get one addict off drugs
column3: to convince one troubled teenager not to give up on life
column4: to comfort one AIDS patient
column5: to help one hungry child.

column1: We have within our reach the promise of a renewed America. We can find meaning and reward by serving some higher purpose than ourselves
column2: a shining purpose
column3: the illumination of a Thousand Points of Light. And it is expressed by all who know the irresistible force of a child's hand
column4: of a friend who stands by you and stays there
column5: a volunteer's generous gesture
column6: an idea that is simply right.

column1: The problems before us may be different
column2: but the key to solving them remains the same. It is the individual -- the individual who steps forward. And the state of our Union is the union of each of us
column3: one to the other -- the sum of our friendships
column4: marriages
column5: families
column6: and communities.

column1: We all have something to give. So
column2: if you know how to read
column3: find someone who can't. If you've got a hammer
column4: find a nail. If you're not hungry
column5: not lonely
column6: not in trouble
column7: seek out someone who is. Join the community of conscience. Do the hard work of freedom. And that will define the state of our Union.

column1: Since the birth of our nation
column2: "We the People" has been the source of our strength. What government can do alone is limited
column3: but the potential of the American people knows no limits.

column1: We are a nation of rock-solid realism and clear-eyed idealism. We are Americans. We are the Nation that believes in the future. We are the Nation that can shape the future. And we've begun to do just that
column2: by strengthening the power and choice of individuals and families.

column1: Together
column2: these last 2 years
column3: we've put dollars for child care directly in the hands of parents instead of bureaucracies; unshackled the potential of Americans with disabilities; applied the creativity of the marketplace in the service of the environment
column4: for clean air; and made home ownership possible for more Americans.

column1: The strength of a democracy is not in bureaucracy. It is in the people and their communities. In everything we do
column2: let us unleash the potential of our most precious resource -- our citizens
column3: our citizens themselves. We must return to families
column4: communities
column5: counties
column6: cities
column7: States
column8: and institutions of every kind the power to chart their own destiny and the freedom and opportunity provided by strong economic growth. And that's what America is all about.

column1: I know that tonight
column2: in some regions of our country
column3: people are in genuine economic distress. And I hear them. Earlier this month
column4: Kathy Blackwell
column5: of Massachusetts
column6: wrote me about what can happen when the economy slows down
column7: saying
column8: "My heart is aching
column9: and I think that you should know your people out here are hurting badly."

column1: I understand
column2: and I'm not unrealistic about the future. But there are reasons to be optimistic about our economy. First
column3: we don't have to fight double-digit inflation. Second
column4: most industries won't have to make big cuts in production because they don't have big inventories piled up. And third
column5: our exports are running solid and strong. In fact
column6: American businesses are exporting at a record rate.

column1: So
column2: let's put these times in perspective. Together
column3: since 1981
column4: we've created almost 20 million jobs
column5: cut inflation in half
column6: and cut interest rates in half. And yes
column7: the largest peacetime economic expansion in history has been temporarily interrupted. But our economy is still over twice as large as our closest competitor.

column1: We will get this recession behind us and return to growth soon. We will get on our way to a new record of expansion and achieve the competitive strength that will carry us into the next American century. We should focus our efforts today on encouraging economic growth
column2: investing in the future
column3: and giving power and opportunity to the individual.

column1: We must begin with control of Federal spending. That's why I'm submitting a budget that holds the growth in spending to less than the rate of inflation. And that's why
column2: amid all the sound and fury of last year's budget debate
column3: we put into law new
column4: enforceable spending caps
column5: so that future spending debates will mean a battle of ideas
column6: not a bidding war.

column1: Though controversial
column2: the budget agreement finally put the Federal Government on a pay-as-you-go plan and cut the growth of debt by nearly $500 billion. And that frees funds for saving and job-creating investment.

column1: Now
column2: let's do more. My budget again includes tax-free family savings accounts; penalty-free withdrawals from IRA's for first-time home buyers; and to increase jobs and growth
column3: a reduced tax for long-term capital gains.

column1: I know there are differences among us ... about the impact and the effects of a capital gains incentive. So tonight
column2: I'm asking the congressional leaders and the Federal Reserve to cooperate with us in a study
column3: led by Chairman Alan Greenspan
column4: to sort out our technical differences so that we can avoid a return to unproductive partisan bickering.

column1: But just as our efforts will bring economic growth now and in the future
column2: they must also be matched by long-term investments for the next American century. That requires a forward-looking plan of action
column3: and that's exactly what we will be sending to the Congress. We've prepared a detailed series of proposals that include: a budget that promotes investment in America's future -- in children
column4: education
column5: infrastructure
column6: space
column7: and high technology; legislation to achieve excellence in education
column8: building on the partnership forged with the 50 Governors at the education summit
column9: enabling parents to choose their children's schools and helping to make America number one in math and science; a blueprint for a new national highway system
column10: a critical investment in our transportation infrastructure; a research and development agenda that includes record levels of Federal investment
column11: and a permanent tax credit to strengthen private R&D and to create jobs; a comprehensive national energy strategy that calls for energy conservation and efficiency
column12: increased development
column13: and greater use of alternative fuels; a banking reform plan to bring America's financial system into the 21st century so that our banks remain safe and secure and can continue to make job-creating loans for our factories
column14: our businesses

column1: You know
column2: I do think there has been too much pessimism. Sound banks should be making sound loans now
column3: and interest rates should be lower
column4: now.

column1: In addition to these proposals
