column2: we must recognize that our economic strength depends on being competitive in world markets. We must continue to expand American exports. A successful Uruguay round of world trade negotiations will create more real jobs and more real growth for all nations. You and I know that if the playing field is level
column3: America's workers and farmers can out-work
column4: out-produce anyone
column5: anytime
column6: anywhere.

column1: And with a Mexican free trade agreement and our Enterprise for the Americas Initiative
column2: we can help our partners strengthen their economies and move toward a free trade zone throughout this entire hemisphere.

column1: The budget also includes a plan of action right here at home to put more power and opportunity in the hands of the individual. And that means new incentives to create jobs in our inner cities by encouraging investment through enterprise zones. It also means tenant control and ownership of public housing. Freedom and the power to choose should not be the privilege of wealth. They are the birthright of every American.
Civil rights are also crucial to protecting equal opportunity. Every one of us has a responsibility to speak out against racism
column2: bigotry
column3: and hate. We will continue our vigorous enforcement of existing statutes
column4: and I will once again press the Congress to strengthen the laws against employment discrimination without resorting to the use of unfair preferences.

column1: We're determined to protect another fundamental civil right: freedom from crime and the fear that stalks our cities. The Attorney General will soon convene a crime summit of our nation's law enforcement officials. And to help us support them
column2: we need tough crime control legislation
column3: and we need it now.

column1: And as we fight crime
column2: we will fully implement our national strategy for combating drug abuse. Recent data show that we are making progress
column3: but much remains to be done. We will not rest until the day of the dealer is over
column4: forever.

column1: Good health care is every American's right and every American's responsibility. And so
column2: we are proposing an aggressive program of new prevention initiatives -- for infants
column3: for children
column4: for adults
column5: and for the elderly -- to promote a healthier America and to help keep costs from spiraling.

column1: It's time to give people more choice in government by reviving the ideal of the citizen politician who comes not to stay but to serve. And one of the reasons that there is so much support across this country for term limitations is that the American people are increasingly concerned about big-money influence in politics. So
column2: we must look beyond the next election to the next generation. And the time has come to put the national interest above the special interest and to totally eliminate political action committees. And that would truly put more competition in elections and more power in the hands of individuals.

column1: And where power cannot be put directly in the hands of the individual
column2: it should be moved closer to the people
column3: away from Washington. The Federal Government too often treats government programs as if they are of Washington
column4: by Washington
column5: and for Washington. Once established
column6: Federal programs seem to become immortal. It's time for a more dynamic program life cycle. Some programs should increase. Some should decrease. Some should be terminated. And some should be consolidated and turned over to the States.

column1: My budget includes a list of programs for potential turnover totaling more than $20 billion. Working with Congress and the Governors
column2: I propose we select at least $15 billion in such programs and turn them over to the States in a single consolidated grant
column3: fully funded
column4: for flexible management by the States.

column1: The value
column2: the value of this turnover approach is straightforward. It allows the Federal Government to reduce overhead. It allows States to manage more flexibly and more efficiently. It moves power and decisionmaking closer to the people. And it reinforces a theme of this administration: appreciation and encouragement of the innovative powers of States as laboratories.

column1: This nation was founded by leaders who understood that power belongs in the hands of people. And they planned for the future. And so must we
column2: here and all around the world.

column1: As Americans
column2: we know that there are times when we must step forward and accept our responsibility to lead the world away from the dark chaos of dictators
column3: toward the brighter promise of a better day. Almost 50 years ago we began a long struggle against aggressive totalitarianism. Now we face another defining hour for America and the world.

column1: There is no one more devoted
column2: more committed to the hard work of freedom than every soldier and sailor
column3: every marine
column4: airman
column5: and coastguardsman
column6: every man and woman now serving in the Persian Gulf. Oh
column7: how they deserve -- and what a fitting tribute to them.

column1: You see -- what a wonderful
column2: fitting tribute to them. Each of them has volunteered
column3: volunteered to provide for this nation's defense
column4: and now they bravely struggle to earn for America
column5: for the world
column6: and for future generations a just and lasting peace. Our commitment to them must be equal to their commitment to their country. They are truly America's finest.

column1: The war in the Gulf is not a war we wanted. We worked hard to avoid war. For more than 5 months we -- along with the Arab League
column2: the European Community
column3: the United Nations -- tried every diplomatic avenue. U.N. Secretary-General Perez de Cuellar; Presidents Gorbachev
column4: Mitterrand
column5: Ozal
column6: Mubarak
column7: and Bendjedid; Kings Fahd and Hassan; Prime Ministers Major and Andreotti -- just to name a few -- all worked for a solution. But time and again
column8: Saddam Hussein flatly rejected the path of diplomacy and peace.

column1: The world well knows how this conflict began and when: It began on August 2d
column2: when Saddam invaded and sacked a small
column3: defenseless neighbor. And I am certain of how it will end. So that peace can prevail
column4: we will prevail.  Thank you.

column1: Tonight I am pleased to report that we are on course. Iraq's capacity to sustain war is being destroyed. Our investment
column2: our training
column3: our planning -- all are paying off. Time will not be Saddam's salvation.

column1: Our purpose in the Persian Gulf remains constant: to drive Iraq out of Kuwait
column2: to restore Kuwait's legitimate government
column3: and to ensure the stability and security of this critical region.

column1: Let me make clear what I mean by the region's stability and security. We do not seek the destruction of Iraq
column2: its culture
column3: or its people. Rather
column4: we seek an Iraq that uses its great resources not to destroy
column5: not to serve the ambitions of a tyrant
column6: but to build a better life for itself and its neighbors. We seek a Persian Gulf where conflict is no longer the rule
column7: where the strong are neither tempted nor able to intimidate the weak.

column1: Most Americans know instinctively why we are in the Gulf. They know we had to stop Saddam now
column2: not later. They know that this brutal dictator will do anything
column3: will use any weapon
column4: will commit any outrage
column5: no matter how many innocents suffer.

column1: They know we must make sure that control of the world's oil resources does not fall into his hands
column2: only to finance further aggression. They know that we need to build a new
column3: enduring peace
column4: based not on arms races and confrontation but on shared principles and the rule of law.

column1: And we all realize that our responsibility to be the catalyst for peace in the region does not end with the successful conclusion of this war.
Democracy brings the undeniable value of thoughtful dissent
column2: and we've heard some dissenting voices here at home -- some
column3: a handful
column4: reckless; most responsible. But the fact that all voices have the right to speak out is one of the reasons we've been united in purpose and principle for 200 years.

column1: Our progress in this great struggle is the result of years of vigilance and a steadfast commitment to a strong defense. Now
column2: with remarkable technological advances like the Patriot missile
column3: we can defend against ballistic missile attacks aimed at innocent civilians.

column1: Looking forward
column2: I have directed that the SDI program be refocused on providing protection from limited ballistic missile strikes
column3: whatever their source. Let us pursue an SDI program that can deal with any future threat to the United States
column4: to our forces overseas
column5: and to our friends and allies.

column1: The quality of American technology
column2: thanks to the American worker
column3: has enabled us to successfully deal with difficult military conditions and help minimize precious loss of life. We have given our men and women the very best. And they deserve it.

column1: We all have a special place in our hearts for the families of our men and women serving in the Gulf. They are represented here tonight by Mrs. Norman Schwarzkopf. We are all very grateful to General Schwarzkopf and to all those serving with him. And I might also recognize one who came with Mrs. Schwarzkopf: Alma Powell
column2: the wife of the distinguished Chairman of the Joint Chiefs. And to the families
column3: let me say our forces in the Gulf will not stay there one day longer than is necessary to complete their mission.

column1: The courage and success of the RAF pilots
column2: of the Kuwaiti
column3: Saudi
column4: French
column5: the Canadians
column6: the Italians
column7: the pilots of Qatar and Bahrain -- all are proof that for the first time since World War II
column8: the international community is united. The leadership of the United Nations
column9: once only a hoped-for ideal
column10: is now confirming its founders' vision.

column1: I am heartened that we are not being asked to bear alone the financial burdens of this struggle. Last year
column2: our friends and allies provided the bulk of the economic costs of Desert Shield. And now
column3: having received commitments of over $40 billion for the first 3 months of 1991
column4: I am confident they will do no less as we move through Desert Storm.

column1: But the world has to wonder what the dictator of Iraq is thinking. If he thinks that by targeting innocent civilians in Israel and Saudi Arabia
column2: that he will gain advantage
column3: he is dead wrong. If he thinks that he will advance his cause through tragic and despicable environmental terrorism
column4: he is dead wrong. And if he thinks that by abusing the coalition prisoners of war he will benefit
column5: he is dead wrong.

column1: We will succeed in the Gulf. And when we do
column2: the world community will have sent an enduring warning to any dictator or despot
column3: present or future
column4: who contemplates outlaw aggression.

column1: The world can
column2: therefore
column3: seize this opportunity to fulfill the long-held promise of a new world order
column4: where brutality will go unrewarded and aggression will meet collective resistance.

column1: Yes
column2: the United States bears a major share of leadership in this effort. Among the nations of the world
column3: only the United States of America has both the moral standing and the means to back it up. We're the only nation on this Earth that could assemble the forces of peace. This is the burden of leadership and the strength that has made America the beacon of freedom in a searching world.

column1: This nation has never found glory in war. Our people have never wanted to abandon the blessings of home and work for distant lands and deadly conflict. If we fight in anger
column2: it is only because we have to fight at all. And all of us yearn for a world where we will never have to fight again.

column1: Each of us will measure within ourselves the value of this great struggle. Any cost in lives -- any cost -- is beyond our power to measure. But the cost of closing our eyes to aggression is beyond mankind's power to imagine. This we do know: Our cause is just; our cause is moral; our cause is right.
Let future generations understand the burden and the blessings of freedom. Let them say we stood where duty required us to stand. Let them know that
column2: together
column3: we affirmed America and the world as a community of conscience.

column1: The winds of change are with us now. The forces of freedom are together
column2: united. We move toward the next century more confident than ever that we have the will at home and abroad to do what must be done -- the hard work of freedom.

column1: May God bless the United States of America. Thank you very
column2: very much.@

column1: George Bush|Address Before a Joint Session of the Congress on the State of the Union|1992-01-28|@Mr. Speaker and Mr. President
column2: distinguished Members of Congress
column3: honored guests
column4: and fellow citizens:

column1: Thank you very much for that warm reception. You know
column2: with the big buildup this address has had
column3: I wanted to make sure it would be a big hit
column4: but I couldn't convince Barbara to deliver it for me.

column1: I see the Speaker and the Vice President are laughing. They saw what I did in Japan
column2: and they're just happy they're sitting behind me.

column1: I mean to speak tonight of big things
column2: of big changes and the promises they hold
column3: and of some big problems and how
column4: together
column5: we can solve them and move our country forward as the undisputed leader of the age.

column1: We gather tonight at a dramatic and deeply promising time in our history and in the history of man on Earth. For in the past 12 months
column2: the world has known changes of almost Biblical proportions. And even now
column3: months after the failed coup that doomed a failed system
column4: I'm not sure we've absorbed the full impact
column5: the full import of what happened. But communism died this year.

column1: Even as President
column2: with the most fascinating possible vantage point
column3: there were times when I was so busy managing progress and helping to lead change that I didn't always show the joy that was in my heart. But the biggest thing that has happened in the world in my life
column4: in our lives
column5: is this: By the grace of God
column6: America won the cold war.

column1: I mean to speak this evening of the changes that can take place in our country
column2: now that we can stop making the sacrifices we had to make when we had an avowed enemy that was a superpower. Now we can look homeward even more and move to set right what needs to be set right.

column1: I will speak of those things. But let me tell you something I've been thinking these past few months. It's a kind of rollcall of honor. For the cold war didn't end; it was won. And I think of those who won it
column2: in places like Korea and Vietnam. And some of them didn't come back. Back then they were heroes
column3: but this year they were victors.

column1: The long rollcall
column2: all the G.I. Joes and Janes
column3: all the ones who fought faithfully for freedom
column4: who hit the ground and sucked the dust and knew their share of horror. This may seem frivolous
column5: and I don't mean it so
column6: but it's moving to me how the world saw them. The world saw not only their special valor but their special style: their rambunctious
column7: optimistic bravery
column8: their do-or-die unity unhampered by class or race or region. What a group we've put forth
column9: for generations now
column10: from the ones who wrote "Kilroy was here" on the walls of the German stalags to those who left signs in the Iraqi desert that said
column11: "I saw Elvis." What a group of kids we've sent out into the world.

column1: And there's another to be singled out
column2: though it may seem inelegant
column3: and I mean a mass of people called the American taxpayer. No one ever thinks to thank the people who pay a country's bill or an alliance's bill. But for half a century now
column4: the American people have shouldered the burden and paid taxes that were higher than they would have been to support a defense that was bigger than it would have been if imperial communism had never existed. But it did; doesn't anymore. And here's a fact I wouldn't mind the world acknowledging: The American taxpayer bore the brunt of the burden and deserves a hunk of the glory.

column1: So now
column2: for the first time in 35 years
column3: our strategic bombers stand down. No longer are they on 'round-the-clock alert. Tomorrow our children will go to school and study history and how plants grow. And they won't have
column4: as my children did
column5: air raid drills in which they crawl under their desks and cover their heads in case of nuclear war. My grandchildren don't have to do that and won't have the bad dreams children had once
column6: in decades past. There are still threats. But the long
column7: drawn-out dread is over.

column1: A year ago tonight
column2: I spoke to you at a moment of high peril. American forces had just unleashed Operation Desert Storm. And after 40 days in the desert skies and 4 days on the ground
column3: the men and women of America's Armed Forces and our allies accomplished the goals that I declared and that you endorsed: We liberated Kuwait. Soon after
column4: the Arab world and Israel sat down to talk seriously and comprehensively about peace
column5: an historic first. And soon after that
column6: at Christmas
column7: the last American hostages came home. Our policies were vindicated.

column1: Much good can come from the prudent use of power. And much good can come of this: A world once divided into two armed camps now recognizes one sole and preeminent power
column2: the United States of America. And they regard this with no dread. For the world trusts us with power
column3: and the world is right. They trust us to be fair and restrained. They trust us to be on the side of decency. They trust us to do what's right.

column1: I use those words advisedly. A few days after the war began
column2: I received a telegram from Joanne Speicher
column3: the wife of the first pilot killed in the Gulf
column4: Lieutenant Commander Scott Speicher. Even in her grief
column5: she wanted me to know that some day when her children were old enough
column6: she would tell them "that their father went away to war because it was the right thing to do." And she said it all: It was the right thing to do.

column1: And we did it together. There were honest differences right here in this Chamber. But when the war began
column2: you put partisanship aside
column3: and we supported our troops. This is still a time for pride
column4: but this is no time to boast. For problems face us
column5: and we must stand together once again and solve them and not let our country down.

column1: Two years ago
column2: I began planning cuts in military spending that reflected the changes of the new era. But now
column3: this year
column4: with imperial communism gone
column5: that process can be accelerated. Tonight I can tell you of dramatic changes in our strategic nuclear force. These are actions we are taking on our own because they are the right thing to do. After completing 20 planes for which we have begun procurement
column6: we will shut down further production of the B - 2 bombers. We will cancel the small ICBM program. We will cease production of new warheads for our sea-based ballistic missiles. We will stop all new production of the Peacekeeper missile. And we will not purchase any more advanced cruise missiles.

column1: This weekend I will meet at Camp David with Boris Yeltsin of the Russian Federation. I've informed President Yeltsin that if the Commonwealth
column2: the former Soviet Union
column3: will eliminate all land-based multiple-warhead ballistic missiles
column4: I will do the following: We will eliminate all Peacekeeper missiles. We will reduce the number of warheads on Minuteman missiles to one and reduce the number of warheads on our sea-based missiles by about one-third. And we will convert a substantial portion of our strategic bombers to primarily conventional use. President Yeltsin's early response has been very positive
column5: and I expect our talks at Camp David to be fruitful.

column1: I want you to know that for half a century
column2: American Presidents have longed to make such decisions and say such words. But even in the midst of celebration
column3: we must keep caution as a friend. For the world is still a dangerous place. Only the dead have seen the end of conflict. And though yesterday's challenges are behind us
column4: tomorrow's are being born.

column1: The Secretary of Defense recommended these cuts after consultation with the Joint Chiefs of Staff. And I make them with confidence. But do not misunderstand me. The reductions I have approved will save us an additional $50 billion over the next 5 years. By 1997
column2: we will have cut defense by 30 percent since I took office. These cuts are deep
column3: and you must know my resolve: This deep
column4: and no deeper. To do less would be insensible to progress
column5: but to do more would be ignorant of history. We must not go back to the days of "the hollow army." We cannot repeat the mistakes made twice in this century when armistice was followed by recklessness and defense was purged as if the world were permanently safe.

column1: I remind you this evening that I have asked for your support in funding a program to protect our country from limited nuclear missile attack. We must have this protection because too many people in too many countries have access to nuclear arms. And I urge you again to pass the Strategic Defense Initiative
column2: SDI.

column1: There are those who say that now we can turn away from the world
column2: that we have no special role
column3: no special place. But we are the United States of America
column4: the leader of the West that has become the leader of the world. And as long as I am President
column5: I will continue to lead in support of freedom everywhere
column6: not out of arrogance
column7: not out of altruism
column8: but for the safety and security of our children. This is a fact: Strength in the pursuit of peace is no vice; isolationism in the pursuit of security is no virtue.

column1: And now to our troubles at home. They're not all economic; the primary problem is our economy. There are some good signs. Inflation
column2: that thief
column3: is down. And interest rates are down. But unemployment is too high
column4: some industries are in trouble
column5: and growth is not what it should be. Let me tell you right from the start and right from the heart
column6: I know we're in hard times. But I know something else: This will not stand.

column1: In this Chamber
column2: in this Chamber we can bring the same courage and sense of common purpose to the economy that we brought to Desert Storm. And we can defeat hard times together. I believe you'll help. One reason is that you're patriots
column3: and you want the best for your country. And I believe that in your hearts you want to put partisanship aside and get the job done because it's the right thing to do.

column1: The power of America rests in a stirring but simple idea
column2: that people will do great things if only you set them free. Well
column3: we're going to set the economy free. For if this age of miracles and wonders has taught us anything
column4: it's that if we can change the world we can change America. We must encourage investment. We must make it easier for people to invest money and create new products
column5: new industries
column6: and new jobs. We must clear away the obstacles to growth: high taxes
column7: high regulation
column8: redtape
column9: and yes
column10: wasteful Government spending.

column1: None of this will happen with a snap of the fingers
column2: but it will happen. And the test of a plan isn't whether it's called new or dazzling. The American people aren't impressed by gimmicks; they're smarter on this score than all of us in this room. The only test of a plan is: Is it sound
column3: and will it work?

column1: We must have a short-term plan to address our immediate needs and heat up the economy. And then we need a longer term plan to keep combustion going and to guarantee our place in the world economy. There are certain things that a President can do without Congress
column2: and I'm going to do them.

column1: I have
column2: this evening
column3: asked major Cabinet departments and Federal agencies to institute a 90-day moratorium on any new Federal regulations that could hinder growth. In those 90 days
column4: major departments and agencies will carry out a top-to-bottom review of all regulations
column5: old and new
column6: to stop the ones that will hurt growth and speed up those that will help growth.

column1: Further
column2: for the untold number of hard-working
column3: responsible American workers and business men and women who've been forced to go without needed bank loans
column4: the banking credit crunch must end. I won't neglect my responsibility for sound regulations that serve the public good
column5: but regulatory overkill must be stopped. And I've instructed our Government regulators to stop it.

column1: I have directed Cabinet departments and Federal agencies to speed up progrowth expenditures as quickly as possible. This should put an extra $10 billion into the economy in the next 6 months. And our new transportation bill provides more than $150 billion for construction and maintenance projects that are vital to our growth and well-being. And that means jobs building roads
column2: jobs building bridges
column3: and jobs building railways.

column1: And I have
column2: this evening
column3: directed the Secretary of the Treasury to change the Federal tax withholding tables. With this change
column4: millions of Americans from whom the Government withholds more than necessary can now choose to have the Government withhold less from their paychecks. Something tells me a number of taxpayers may take us up on this one. This initiative could return about $25 billion back into our economy over the next 12 months
column5: money people can use to help pay for clothing
column6: college
column7: or to get a new car. Finally
column8: working with the Federal Reserve
column9: we will continue to support monetary policy that keeps both interest rates and inflation down.

column1: Now
column2: these are the things I can do. And now
column3: Members of Congress
column4: let me tell you what you can do for your country. You must pass the other elements of my plan to meet our economic needs. Everyone knows that investment spurs recovery. I am proposing this evening a change in the alternative minimum tax and the creation of a new 15-percent investment tax allowance. This will encourage businesses to accelerate investment and bring people back to work.

column1: Real estate has led our economy out of almost all the tough times we've ever had. Once building starts
column2: carpenters and plumbers work; people buy homes and take out mortgages. My plan would modify the passive loss rule for active real estate developers. And it would make it easier for pension plans to purchase real estate. For those Americans who dream of buying a first home but who can't quite afford it
column3: my plan would allow first-time homebuyers to withdraw savings from IRA's without penalty and provide a $5
column4: 000 tax credit for the first purchase of that home.

column1: And finally
column2: my immediate plan calls on Congress to give crucial help to people who own a home
column3: to everyone who has a business or a farm or a single investment. This time
column4: at this hour
column5: I cannot take no for an answer. You must cut the capital gains tax on the people of our country. Never has an issue been more demagogued by its opponents. But the demagogs are wrong. They are wrong
column6: and they know it. Sixty percent of the people who benefit from lower capital gains have incomes under $50
column7: 000. A cut in the capital gains tax increases jobs and helps just about everyone in our country. And so
column8: I'm asking you to cut the capital gains tax to a maximum of 15.4 percent.

column1: I'll tell you
column2: those of you who say
column3: "Oh
column4: no
column5: someone who's comfortable may benefit from that
column6:
you kind of remind me of the old definition of the Puritan who couldn't sleep at night, worrying that somehow, someone somewhere was out having a good time.  The opponents of this measure and those who have authored various so-called soak-the-rich bills that are floating around this Chamber should be reminded of something: When they aim at the big guy, they usually hit the little guy. And maybe it's time that stopped.
This, then, is my short-term plan. Your part, Members of Congress, requires enactment of these commonsense proposals that will have a strong effect on the economy without breaking the budget agreement and without raising tax rates.
While my plan is being passed and kicking in, we've got to care for those in trouble today. I have provided for up to $4.4 billion in my budget to extend Federal unemployment benefits. And I ask for congressional action right away. And I thank the committee.  Well, at last.
Let's be frank. Let's be frank. Let me level with you. I know and you know that my plan is unveiled in a political season.  I know and you know that everything I propose will be viewed by some in merely partisan terms. But I ask you to know what is in my heart. And my aim is to increase our Nation's good. I'm doing what I think is right, and I am proposing what I know will help.
I pride myself that I'm a prudent man, and I believe that patience is a virtue. But I understand that politics is, for some, a game and that sometimes the game is to stop all progress and then decry the lack of improvement.  But let me tell you: Far more important than my political future and far more important than yours is the well-being of our country. Members of this Chamber are practical people, and I know you won't resent some practical advice. When people put their party's fortunes, whatever the party, whatever side of this aisle, before the public good, they court defeat not only for their country but for themselves. And they will certainly deserve it.
I submit my plan tomorrow, and I'm asking you to pass it by March 20th. And I ask the American people to let you know they want this action by March 20th. From the day after that, if it must be, the battle is joined. And you know, when principle is at stake I relish a good, fair fight.
I said my plan has two parts, and it does. And it's the second part that is the heart of the matter. For it's not enough to get an immediate burst. We need long-term improvement in our economic position. We all know that the key to our economic future is to ensure that America continues as an economic leader of the world. We have that in our power. Here, then, is my long-term plan to guarantee our future.
First, trade: We will work to break down the walls that stop world trade. We will work to open markets everywhere. And in our major trade negotiations, I will continue pushing to eliminate tariffs and subsidies that damage America's farmers and workers. And we'll get more good American jobs within our own hemisphere through the North American free trade agreement and through the Enterprise for the Americas Initiative.
But changes are here, and more are coming. The workplace of the future will demand more highly skilled workers than ever, more people who are computer-literate, highly educated. We must be the world's leader in education. And we must revolutionize America's schools. My America 2000 strategy will help us reach that goal. My plan will give parents more choice, give teachers more flexibility, and help communities create new American schools. Thirty States across the Nation have established America 2000 programs. Hundreds of cities and towns have joined in. Now Congress must join this great movement: Pass my proposals for new American schools.
That was my second long-term proposal, and here's my third: We must make commonsense investments that will help us compete, long-term, in the marketplace. We must encourage research and development. My plan is to make the R&D tax credit permanent and to provide record levels of support, over $76 billion this year alone, for people who will explore the promise of emerging technologies.
Fourth, we must do something about crime and drugs. It is time for a major, renewed investment in fighting violent street crime. It saps our strength and hurts our faith in our society and in our future together. Surely a tired woman on her way to work at 6 in the morning on a subway deserves the right to get there safely. And surely it's true that everyone who changes his or her life because of crime, from those afraid to go out at night to those afraid to walk in the parks they pay for, surely these people have been denied a basic civil right. It is time to restore it. Congress, pass my comprehensive crime bill. It is tough on criminals and supportive of police, and it has been languishing in these hallowed halls for years now. Pass it. Help your country.
Fifth, I ask you tonight to fund our HOPE housing proposal and to pass my enterprise zone legislation which will get businesses into the inner city. We must empower the poor with the pride that comes from owning a home, getting a job, becoming a part of things. My plan would encourage real estate construction by extending tax incentives for mortgage revenue bonds and low-income housing. And I ask tonight for record expenditures for the program that helps children born into want move into excellence, Head Start.
Step six, we must reform our health care system. For this, too, bears on whether or not we can compete in the world. American health costs have been exploding. This year America will spend over $800 billion on health, and that is expected to grow to 1.6 trillion by the end of the decade. We simply cannot afford this. The cost of health care shows up not only in your family budget but in the price of everything we buy and everything we sell. When health coverage for a fellow on an assembly line costs thousands of dollars, the cost goes into the products he makes, and you pay the bill.
We must make a choice. Now, some pretend we can have it both ways. They call it play or pay
column7:
but that expensive approach is unstable. It will mean higher taxes, fewer jobs, and eventually a system under complete Government control.
Really, there are only two options. And we can move toward a nationalized system, a system which will restrict patient choice in picking a doctor and force the Government to ration services arbitrarily. And what we'll get is patients in long lines, indifferent service, and a huge new tax burden. Or we can reform our own private health care system, which still gives us, for all its flaws, the best quality health care in the world.
Well, let's build on our strengths. My plan provides insurance security for all Americans while preserving and increasing the idea of choice. We make basic health insurance affordable for all low-income people not now covered, and we do it by providing a health insurance tax credit of up to $3,750 for each low-income family. And the middle class gets help, too. And by reforming the health insurance market, my plan assures that Americans will have access to basic health insurance even if they change jobs or develop serious health problems. We must bring costs under control, preserve quality, preserve choice, and reduce the people's nagging daily worry about health insurance. My plan, the details of which I'll announce very shortly, does just that.
Seventh, we must get the Federal deficit under control. We now have, in law, enforceable spending caps and a requirement that we pay for the programs we create. There are those in Congress who would ease that discipline now. But I cannot let them do it, and I won't.
My plan would freeze all domestic discretionary budget authority, which means no more next year than this year. I will not tamper with Social Security, but I would put real caps on the growth of uncontrolled spending. And I would also freeze Federal domestic Government employment. And with the help of Congress, my plan will get rid of 246 programs that don't deserve Federal funding. Some of them have noble titles, but none of them is indispensable. We can get rid of each and every one of them.
You know, it's time we rediscovered a home truth the American people have never forgotten: This Government is too big and spends too much. And I call upon Congress to adopt a measure that will help put an end to the annual ritual of filling the budget with pork barrel appropriations. Every year, the press has a field day making fun of outrageous examples: a Lawrence Welk museum, research grants for Belgian endive. We all know how these things get into the budget, and maybe you need someone to help you say no. I know how to say it, and I know what I need to make it stick. Give me the same thing 43 Governors have, the line-item veto, and let me help you control spending.
We must put an end to unfinanced Federal Government mandates. These are the requirements Congress puts on our cities, counties, and States without supplying the money. If Congress passes a mandate, it should be forced to pay for it and balance the cost with savings elsewhere. After all, a mandate just increases someone else's burden, and that means higher taxes at the State and local level.
Step eight, Congress should enact the bold reform proposals that are still awaiting congressional action: bank reform, civil justice reform, tort reform, and my national energy strategy.
And finally, we must strengthen the family because it is the family that has the greatest bearing on our future. When Barbara holds an AIDS baby in her arms and reads to children, she's saying to every person in this country: Family matters.
And I am announcing tonight a new Commission on America's Urban Families. I've asked Missouri's Governor John Ashcroft to be Chairman, former Dallas Mayor Annette Strauss to be Cochair. You know, I had mayors, the leading mayors from the League of Cities, in the other day at the White House, and they told me something striking. They said that every one of them, Republican or Democrat, agreed on one thing, that the major cause of the problems of the cities is the dissolution of the family. They asked for this Commission, and they were right to ask because it's time to determine what we can do to keep families together, strong and sound.
There's one thing we can do right away: Ease the burden of rearing a child. I ask you tonight to raise the personal exemption by $500 per child for every family. For a family with four kids, that's an increase of $2,000. This is a good start in the right direction, and it's what we can afford.
It's time to allow families to deduct the interest they pay on student loans. I am asking you to do just that. And I'm asking you to allow people to use money from their IRA's to pay medical and education expenses, all without penalties.
And I'm asking for more. Ask American parents what they dislike about how things are going in our country, and chances are good that pretty soon they'll get to welfare. Americans are the most generous people on Earth. But we have to go back to the insight of Franklin Roosevelt who, when he spoke of what became the welfare program, warned that it must not become a narcotic" and a "subtle destroyer" of the spirit. Welfare was never meant to be a lifestyle. It was never meant to be a habit. It was never supposed to be passed from generation to generation like a legacy. It's time to replace the assumptions of the welfare state and help reform the welfare system.

column1: States throughout the country are beginning to operate with new assumptions that when able-bodied people receive Government assistance
column2: they have responsibilities to the taxpayer: A responsibility to seek work
column3: education
column4: or job training; a responsibility to get their lives in order; a responsibility to hold their families together and refrain from having children out of wedlock; and a responsibility to obey the law. We are going to help this movement. Often
column5: State reform requires waiving certain Federal regulations. I will act to make that process easier and quicker for every State that asks for our help.

column1: I want to add
column2: as we make these changes
column3: we work together to improve this system
column4: that our intention is not scapegoating or finger-pointing. If you read the papers and watch TV
column5: you know there's been a rise these days in a certain kind of ugliness: racist comments
column6: anti-Semitism
column7: an increased sense of division. Really
column8: this is not us. This is not who we are. And this is not acceptable.

column1: And so
column2: you have my plan for America. And I'm asking for big things
column3: but I believe in my heart you'll do what's right.

column1: You know
column2: it's kind of an American tradition to show a certain skepticism toward our democratic institutions. I myself have sometimes thought the aging process could be delayed if it had to make its way through Congress.  You will deliberate
column3: and you will discuss
column4: and that is fine. But
column5: my friends
column6: the people cannot wait. They need help now.

column1: There's a mood among us. People are worried. There's been talk of decline. Someone even said our workers are lazy and uninspired. And I thought: Really? You go tell Neil Armstrong standing on the moon. Tell the men and women who put him there. Tell the American farmer who feeds his country and the world. Tell the men and women of Desert Storm.
Moods come and go
column2: but greatness endures. Ours does. And maybe for a moment it's good to remember what
column3: in the dailiness of our lives
column4: we forget: We are still and ever the freest nation on Earth
column5: the kindest nation on Earth
column6: the strongest nation on Earth. And we have always risen to the occasion. And we are going to lift this Nation out of hard times inch by inch and day by day
column7: and those who would stop us had better step aside. Because I look at hard times
column8: and I make this vow: This will not stand.

column1: And so
column2: we move on together
column3: a rising nation
column4: the once and future miracle that is still
column5: this night
column6: the hope of the world. Thank you. God bless you
column7: and God bless our beloved country. Thank you very
column8: very much.@

column1: William J. Clinton|Address Before a Joint Session of Congress on Administration Goals|1993-02-17|@Mr. President
column2: Mr. Speaker
column3: Members of the House and the Senate
column4: distinguished Americans here as visitors in this Chamber
column5: as am I. It is nice to have a fresh excuse for giving a long speech.

column1: When Presidents speak to Congress and the Nation from this podium
column2: typically they comment on the full range in challenges and opportunities that face the United States. But this is not an ordinary time
column3: and for all the many tasks that require our attention
column4: I believe tonight one calls on us to focus
column5: to unite
column6: and to act. And that is our economy. For more than anything else
column7: our task tonight as Americans is to make our economy thrive again.

column1: Let me begin by saying that it has been too long
column2: at least three decades
column3: since a President has come and challenged Americans to join him on a great national journey
column4: not merely to consume the bounty of today but to invest for a much greater one tomorrow.

column1: Like individuals
column2: nations must ultimately decide how they wish to conduct themselves
column3: how they wish to be thought of by those with whom they live
column4: and later
column5: how they wish to be judged by history. Like every individual man and woman
column6: nations must decide whether they are prepared to rise to the occasions history presents them.

column1: We have always been a people of youthful energy and daring spirit. And at this historic moment
column2: as communism has fallen
column3: as freedom is spreading around the world
column4: as a global economy is taking shape before our eyes
column5: Americans have called for change. And now it is up to those of us in this room to deliver for them.

column1: Our Nation needs a new direction. Tonight I present to you a comprehensive plan to set our Nation on that new course. I believe we will find our new direction in the basic old values that brought us here over the last two centuries: a commitment to opportunity
column2: to individual responsibility
column3: to community
column4: to work
column5: to family
column6: and to faith. We must now break the habits of both political parties and say there can be no more something for nothing and admit frankly that we are all in this together.

column1: The conditions which brought us as a nation to this point are well-known: two decades of low productivity
column2: growth
column3: and stagnant wages; persistent unemployment and underemployment; years of huge Government deficits and declining investment in our future; exploding health care costs and lack of coverage for millions of Americans; legions of poor children; education and job training opportunities inadequate to the demands of this tough
column4: global economy. For too long we have drifted without a strong sense of purpose or responsibility or community.

column1: And our political system so often has seemed paralyzed by special interest groups
column2: by partisan bickering
column3: and by the sheer complexity of our problems. I believe we can do better because we remain the greatest nation on Earth
column4: the world's strongest economy
column5: the world's only military superpower. If we have the vision
column6: the will
column7: and the heart to make the changes we must
column8: we can still enter the 21st century with possibilities our parents could not even have imagined and enter it having secured the American dream for ourselves and for future generations.

column1: I well remember 12 years ago President Reagan stood at this very podium and told you and the American people that if our national debt were stacked in thousand-dollar bills
column2: the stack would reach 67 miles into space. Well
column3: today that stack would reach 267 miles. I tell you this not to assign blame for this problem. There is plenty of blame to go around in both branches of the Government and both parties. The time has come for the blame to end. I did not seek this office to place blame. I come here tonight to accept responsibility
column4: and I want you to accept responsibility with me. And if we do right by this country
column5: I do not care who gets the credit for it.

column1: The plan I offer you has four fundamental components. First
column2: it shifts our emphasis in public and private spending from consumption to investment
column3: initially by jumpstarting the economy in the short term and investing in our people
column4: their jobs
column5: and their incomes over the long run. Second
column6: it changes the rhetoric of the past into the actions of the present by honoring work and families in every part of our public decision-making. Third
column7: it substantially reduces the Federal deficit honestly and credibly by using in the beginning the most conservative estimates of Government revenues
column8: not
column9: as the executive branch has done so often in the past
column10: using the most optimistic ones. And finally
column11: it seeks to earn the trust of the American people by paying for these plans first with cuts in Government waste and efficiency; second
column12: with cuts
column13: not gimmicks
column14: in Government spending; and by fairness
column16: in the way additional burdens are borne.

column1: Tonight I want to talk with you about what Government can do because I believe Government must do more. But let me say first that the real engine of economic growth in this country is the private sector
column2: and second
column3: that each of us must be an engine of growth and change. The truth is that as Government creates more opportunity in this new and different time
column4: we must also demand more responsibility in turn.

column1: Our immediate priority must be to create jobs
column2: create jobs now. Some people say
column3: "Well
column4: we're in a recovery
column5: and we don't have to do that." Well
column6: we all hope we're in a recovery
column7: but we're sure not creating new jobs. And there's no recovery worth its salt that doesn't put the American people back to work.

column1: To create jobs and guarantee a strong recovery
column2: I call on Congress to enact an immediate package of jobs investments of over $30 billion to put people to work now
column3: to create a half a million jobs: jobs to rebuild our highways and airports
column4: to renovate housing
column5: to bring new life to rural communities
column6: and spread hope and opportunity among our Nation's youth. Especially I want to emphasize
column7: after the events of last year in Los Angeles and the countless stories of despair in our cities and in our poor rural communities
column8: this proposal will create almost 700
column9: 000 new summer jobs for displaced
column10: unemployed young people alone this summer. And tonight I invite America's business leaders to join us in this effort so that together we can provide over one million summer jobs in cities and poor rural areas for our young people.

column1: Second
column2: our plan looks beyond today's business cycle because our aspirations extend into the next century. The heart of this plan deals with the long term. It is an investment program designed to increase public and private investment in areas critical to our economic future. And it has a deficit reduction program that will increase the savings available for the private sector to invest
column3: will lower interest rates
column4: will decrease the percentage of the Federal budget claimed by interest payments
column5: and decrease the risk of financial market disruptions that could adversely affect our economy.

column1: Over the long run
column2: all this will bring us a higher rate of economic growth
column3: improved productivity
column4: more high-quality jobs
column5: and an improved economic competitive position in the world. In order to accomplish both increased investment and deficit reduction
column6: something no American Government has ever been called upon to do at the same time before
column7: spending must be cut and taxes must be raised.

column1: The spending cuts I recommend were carefully thought through in a way to minimize any adverse economic impact
column2: to capture the peace dividend for investment purposes
column3: and to switch the balance in the budget from consumption to more investment. The tax increases and the spending cuts were both designed to assure that the cost of this historic program to face and deal with our problems will be borne by those who could readily afford it the most. Our plan is designed
column4: furthermore
column5: and perhaps in some ways most importantly
column6: to improve the health of American business through lower interest rates
column7: more incentives to invest
column8: and better trained workers.

column1: Because small business has created such a high percentage of all the new jobs in our Nation over the last 10 or 15 years
column2: our plan includes the boldest targeted incentives for small business in history. We propose a permanent investment tax credit for the smallest firms in this country
column3: with revenues of under $5 million. That's about 90 percent of the firms in America
column4: employing about 40 percent of the work force but creating a big majority of the net new jobs for more than a decade. And we propose new rewards for entrepreneurs who take new risks. We propose to give small business access to all the new technologies of our time. And we propose to attack this credit crunch which has denied small business the credit they need to flourish and prosper.

column1: With a new network of community development banks and $1 billion to make the dream of enterprise zones real
column2: we propose to bring new hope and new jobs to storefronts and factories from south Boston to south Texas to south central Los Angeles. This plan invests in our roads
column3: our bridges
column4: our transit systems
column5: in high-speed railways and high-tech information systems. And it provides the most ambitious environmental cleanup in partnership with State and local government of our time
column6: to put people to work and to preserve the environment for our future.

column1: Standing as we are on the edge of a new century
column2: we know that economic growth depends as never before on opening up new markets overseas and expanding the volume of world trade. And so
column3: we will insist on fair trade rules in international markets as a part of a national economic strategy to expand trade
column4: including the successful completion of the latest round of world trade talks and the successful completion of a North American Free Trade Agreement with appropriate safeguards for our workers and for the environment.

column1: At the same timeand I say this to you in both parties and across America tonight
column2: all the people who are listeningit is not enough to pass a budget or even to have a trade agreement. This world is changing so fast that we must have aggressive
column3: targeted attempts to create the high-wage jobs of the future. That's what all our competitors are doing. We must give special attention to those critical industries that are going to explode in the 21st century but that are in trouble in America today
column4: like aerospace. We must provide special assistance to areas and to workers displaced by cuts in the defense budget and by other unavoidable economic dislocations.

column1: And again I will say we must do this together. I pledge to you that I will do my best to see that business and labor and Government work together for a change.
But all of our efforts to strengthen the economy will faillet me say this again; I feel so strongly about thisall of our efforts to strengthen the economy will fail unless we also take this year
column2: not next year
column3: not 5 years from now but this year
column4: bold steps to reform our health care system.

column2: we spent 14 percent of our income on health care
column3: more than 30 percent more than any other country in the world
column4: and yet we were the only advanced nation that did not provide a basic package of health care benefits to all of its citizens. Unless we change the present pattern
column5: 50 percent of the growth in the deficit between now and the year 2000 will be in health care costs. By the year 2000 almost 20 percent of our income will be in health care. Our families will never be secure
column6: our businesses will never be strong
column7: and our Government will never again be fully solvent until we tackle the health care crisis. We must do it this year.

column1: The combination of the rising cost of care and the lack of care and the fear of losing care are endangering the security and the very lives of millions of our people. And they are weakening our economy every day. Reducing health care costs can liberate literally hundreds of billions of dollars for new investment in growth and jobs. Bringing health costs in line with inflation would do more for the private sector in this country than any tax cut we could give and any spending program we could promote. Reforming health care over the long run is critically essential to reducing not only our deficit but to expanding investment in America.
Later this spring
column2: after the First Lady and the many good people who are helping her all across the country complete their work
column3: I will deliver to Congress a comprehensive plan for health care reform that finally will bring costs under control and provide security to all of our families
column4: so that no one will be denied the coverage they need but so that our economic future will not be compromised either. We'll have to root out fraud and overcharges and make sure that paperwork no longer chokes your doctor. We'll have to maintain the highest American standards and the right to choose in a system that is the world's finest for all those who can access it. But first we must make choices. We must choose to give the American people the quality they demand and deserve with a system that will not bankrupt the country or further drive more Americans into agony.

column1: Let me further say that I want to work with all of you on this. I realize this is a complicated issue. But we must address it. And I believe if there is any chance that Republicans and Democrats who disagree on taxes and spending or anything else could agree on one thing
column2: surely we can all look at these numbers and go home and tell our people the truth. We cannot continue these spending patterns in public or private dollars for health care for less and less and less every year. We can do better. And I will work to do better.

column1: Perhaps the most fundamental change the new direction I propose offers is its focus on the future and its investment which I seek in our children. Each day we delay really making a commitment to our children carries a dear cost. Half of the 2-year-olds in this country today don't receive the immunizations they need against deadly diseases. Our plan will provide them for every eligible child. And we know now that we will save $10 later for every $1 we spend by eliminating preventable childhood diseases. That's a good investment no matter how you measure it.
I recommend that the women
column2: infants
column3: and children's nutrition program be expanded so that every expectant mother who needs the help gets it. We all know that Head Start
column4: a program that prepares children for school
column5: is a success story. We all know that it saves money. But today it just reaches barely over one-third of all the eligible children. Under this plan
column6: every eligible child will be able to get a head start. This is not just the right thing to do; it is the smart thing to do. For every dollar we invest today
column7: we'll save $3 tomorrow. We have to start thinking about tomorrow. I've heard that somewhere before.

column1: We have to ask more in our schools of our students
column2: our teachers
column3: our principals
column4: our parents. Yes
column5: we must give them the resources they need to meet high standards
column6: but we must also use the authority and the influence and the funding of the Education Department to promote strategies that really work in learning. Money alone is not enough. We have to do what really works to increase learning in our schools.

column1: We have to recognize that all of our high school graduates need some further education in order to be competitive in this global economy. So we have to establish a partnership between businesses and education and the Government for apprenticeship programs in every State in this country to give our people the skills they need. Lifelong learning must benefit not just young high school graduates but workers
column2: too
column3: throughout their career. The average 18-year-old today will change jobs seven times in a lifetime. We have done a lot in this country on worker training in the last few years
column4: but the system is too fractured. We must develop a unified
column5: simplified
column6: sensible
column7: streamlined worker-training program so that workers receive the training they need regardless of why they lost their jobs or whether they simply need to learn something new to keep them. We have got to do better on this.

column1: And finally
column2: I propose a program that got a great response from the American people all across this country last year: a program of national service to make college loans available to all Americans and to challenge them at the same time to give something back to their country as teachers or police officers or community service workers; to give them the option to pay the loans back
column3: but at tax time so they can't beat the bill
column4: but to encourage them instead to pay it back by making their country stronger and making their country better and giving us the benefit of their knowledge.

column1: A generation ago when President Kennedy proposed and the United States Congress embraced the Peace Corps
column2: it defined the character of a whole generation of Americans committed to serving people around the world. In this national service program
column3: we will provide more than twice as many slots for people before they go to college to be in national service than ever served in the Peace Corps. This program could do for this generation of Members of Congress what the land grant college act did and what the GI bill did for former Congressmen. In the future
column4: historians who got their education through the national service loan will look back on you and thank you for giving America a new lease on life
column5: if you meet this challenge.

column1: If we believe in jobs and we believe in learning
column2: we must believe in rewarding work. If we believe in restoring the values that make America special
column3: we must believe that there is dignity in all work
column4: and there must be dignity for all workers. To those who care for our sick
column5: who tend our children
column6: who do our most difficult and tiring jobs
column7: the new direction I propose will make this solemn
column8: simple commitment: By expanding the refundable earned-income tax credit
column9: we will make history. We will reward the work of millions of working poor Americans by realizing the principle that if you work 40 hours a week and you've got a child in the house
column10: you will no longer be in poverty.

column1: Later this year
column2: we will offer a plan to end welfare as we know it. I have worked on this issue for the better part of a decade. And I know from personal conversations with many people that no one
column3: no one wants to change the welfare system as badly as those who are trapped in it. I want to offer the people on welfare the education
column4: the training
column5: the child care
column6: the health care they need to get back on their feet
column7: but say after 2 years they must get back to work
column8: too
column9: in private business if possible
column10: in public service if necessary. We have to end welfare as a way of life and make it a path to independence and dignity.

column1: Our next great goal should be to strengthen our families. I compliment the Congress for passing the Family and Medical Leave Act as a good first step
column2: but it is time to do more. This plan will give this country the toughest child support enforcement system it has ever had. It is time to demand that people take responsibility for the children they bring in this world.

column1: And I ask you to help to protect our families against the violent crime which terrorizes our people and which tears our communities apart. We must pass a tough crime bill. I support not only the bill which didn't quite make it to the President's desk last year but also an initiative to put 100
column2: 000 more police officers on the street
column3: to provide boot camps for first-time nonviolent offenders for more space for the hardened criminals in jail. And I support an initiative to do what we can to keep guns out of the hands of criminals. Let me say this. I will make you this bargain: If you will pass the Brady bill
column4: I'll sure sign it.

column1: Let me say now
column2: we should move to the harder parts.

column1: I think it is clear to every American
column2: including every Member of Congress of both parties
column3: that the confidence of the people who pay our bills in our institutions in Washington is not high. We must restore it. We must begin again to make Government work for ordinary taxpayers
column4: not simply for organized interest groups. And that beginning must start with real political reform. I am asking the United States Congress to pass a real campaign finance reform bill this year. I ask you to increase the participation of the American people by passing the motor voter bill promptly. I ask you to deal with the undue influence of special interests by passing a bill to end the tax deduction for lobbying and to act quickly to require all the people who lobby you to register as lobbyists by passing the lobbying registration bill.

column1: Believe me
column2: they were cheering that last section at home. I believe lobby reform and campaign finance reform are a sure path to increased popularity for Republicans and Democrats alike because it says to the voters back home
column3: "This is your House. This is your Senate. We're your hired hands
column4: and every penny we draw is your money."

column1: Next
column2: to revolutionize Government we have to ensure that we live within our means
column3: and that should start at the top and with the White House. In the last few days I have announced a cut in the White House staff of 25 percent
column4: saving approximately $10 million. I have ordered administrative cuts in budgets of agencies and departments. I have cut the Federal bureaucracy
column5: or will over the next 4 years
column6: by approximately 100
column7: 000 positions
column8: for a combined savings of $9 billion. It is time for Government to demonstrate
column9: in the condition we're in
column10: that we can be as frugal as any household in America.

column1: And that's why I also want to congratulate the Congress. I noticed the announcement of the leadership today that Congress is taking similar steps to cut its costs. I think that is important. I think it will send a very clear signal to the American people.
But if we really want to cut spending
column2: we're going to have to do more
column3: and some of it will be difficult. Tonight I call for an across-the-board freeze in Federal Government salaries for one year. And thereafter
column4: during this 4-year period
column5: I recommend that salaries rise at one point lower than the cost of living allowance normally involved in Federal pay increases.

column1: Next
column2: I recommend that we make 150 specific budget cuts
column3: as you know
column4: and that all those who say we should cut more be as specific as I have been.

column1: Finally
column2: let me say to my friends on both sides of the aisle
column3: it is not enough simply to cut Government; we have to rethink the whole way it works. When I became President I was amazed at just the way the White House worked
column4: in ways that added lots of money to what taxpayers had to pay
column5: outmoded ways that didn't take maximum advantage of technology and didn't do things that any business would have done years ago to save taxpayers' money.

column1: So I want to bring a new spirit of innovation into every Government Department. I want to push education reform
column2: as I said
column3: not just to spend more money but to really improve learning. Some things work
column4: and some things don't. We ought to be subsidizing the things that work and discouraging the things that don't. I'd like to use that Superfund to clean up pollution for a change and not just pay lawyers.

column1: In the aftermath of all the difficulties with the savings and loans
column2: we must use Federal bank regulators to protect the security and safety of our financial institutions
column3: but they should not be used to continue the credit crunch and to stop people from making sensible loans.

column1: I'd like for us to not only have welfare reform but to reexamine the whole focus of all of our programs that help people
column2: to shift them from entitlement programs to empowerment programs. In the end we want people not to need us anymore. I think that's important.

column1: But in the end we have to get back to the deficit. For years there's been a lot of talk about it but very few credible efforts to deal with it. And now I understand why
column2: having dealt with the real numbers for 4 weeks. But I believe this plan does; it tackles the budget deficit seriously and over the long term. It puts in place one of the biggest deficit reductions and one of the biggest changes in Federal priorities
column3: from consumption to investment
column4: in the history of this country at the same time over the next 4 years.

column1: Let me say to all the people watching us tonight who will ask me these questions beginning tomorrow as I go around the country and who've asked it in the past: We're not cutting the deficit just because experts say it's the thing to do or because it has some intrinsic merit. We have to cut the deficit because the more we spend paying off the debt
column2: the less tax dollars we have to invest in jobs and education and the future of this country. And the more money we take out of the pool of available savings
column3: the harder it is for people in the private sector to borrow money at affordable interest rates for a college loan for their children
column4: for a home mortgage
column5: or to start a new business.

column1: That's why we've got to reduce the debt
column2: because it is crowding out other activities that we ought to be engaged in and that the American people ought to be engaged in. We cut the deficit so that our children will be able to buy a home
column3: so that our companies can invest in the future and in retraining their workers
column4: so that our Government can make the kinds of investments we need to be a stronger and smarter and safer nation.

column1: If we don't act now
column2: you and I might not even recognize this Government 10 years from now. If we just stay with the same trends of the last 4 years
column3: by the end of the decade the deficit will be $635 billion a year
column4: almost 80 percent of our gross domestic product. And paying interest on that debt will be the costliest Government program of all. We'll still be the world's largest debtor. And when Members of Congress come here
column5: they'll be devoting over 20 cents on the dollar to interest payments
column6: more than half of the budget to health care and to other entitlements. And you'll come here and deliberate and argue over 6 or 7 cents on the dollar
column7: no matter what America's problems are. We will not be able to have the independence we need to chart the future that we must. And we'll be terribly dependent on foreign funds for a large portion of our investment.

column1: This budget plan
column2: by contrast
column3: will by 1997 cut $140 billion in that year alone from the deficit
column4: a real spending cut
column5: a real revenue increase
column6: a real deficit reduction
column7: using the independent numbers of the Congressional Budget Office.  Well
column8: you can laugh
column9: my fellow Republicans
column10: but I'll point out that the Congressional Budget Office was normally more conservative in what was going to happen and closer to right than previous Presidents have been.

column1: I did this so that we could argue about priorities with the same set of numbers. I did this so that no one could say I was estimating my way out of this difficulty. I did this because if we can agree together on the most prudent revenues we're likely to get if the recovery stays and we do right things economically
column2: then it will turn out better for the American people than we say. In the last 12 years
column3: because there were differences over the revenue estimates
column4: you and I know that both parties were given greater elbow room for irresponsibility. This is tightening the rein on the Democrats as well as the Republicans. Let's at least argue about the same set of numbers so the American people will think we're shooting straight with them.

column1: As I said earlier
column2: my recommendation makes more than 150 difficult reductions to cut the Federal spending by a total of $246 billion. We are eliminating programs that are no longer needed
column3: such as nuclear power research and development. We're slashing subsidies and canceling wasteful projects. But many of these programs were justified in their time
column4: and a lot of them are difficult for me to recommend reductions in
column5: some really tough ones for me personally. I recommend that we reduce interest subsidies to the Rural Electric Administration. That's a difficult thing for me to recommend. But I think that I cannot exempt the things that exist in my State or in my experience
column6: if I ask you to deal with things that are difficult for you to deal with. We're going to have to have no sacred cows except the fundamental abiding interest of the American people.

column1: I have to say that we all know our Government has been just great at building programs. The time has come to show the American people that we can limit them too; that we can not only start things
column2: that we can actually stop things.

column1: About the defense budget
column2: I raise a hope and a caution. As we restructure our military forces to meet the new threats of the post-cold-war world
column3: it is true that we can responsibly reduce our defense budget. And we may all doubt what that range of reductions is
column4: but let me say that as long as I am President
column5: I will do everything I can to make sure that the men and women who serve under the American flag will remain the best trained
column6: the best prepared
column7: the best equipped fighting force in the world. And every one of you should make that solemn pledge. We still have responsibilities around the world. We are the world's only superpower. This is still a dangerous and uncertain time
column8: and we owe it to the people in uniform to make sure that we adequately provide for the national defense and for their interests and needs. Backed by an effective national defense and a stronger economy
column9: our Nation will be prepared to lead a world challenged as it is everywhere by ethnic conflict
column10: by the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction
column11: by the global democratic revolution
column12: and by challenges to the health of our global environment.

column1: I know this economic plan is ambitious
column2: but I honestly believe it is necessary for the continued greatness of the United States. And I think it is paid for fairly
column3: first by cutting Government
column4: then by asking the most of those who benefited the most in the past
column5: and by asking more Americans to contribute today so that all of us can prosper tomorrow.

column1: For the wealthiest
column2: those earning more than $180
column3: 000 per year
column4: I ask you all who are listening tonight to support a raise in the top rate for Federal income taxes from 31 to 36 percent. We recommend a 10 percent surtax on incomes over $250
column5: 000 a year
column6: and we recommend closing some loopholes that let some people get away without paying any tax at all.

column1: For businesses with taxable incomes in excess of $10 million
column2: we recommend a raise in the corporate tax rate
column3: also to 36 percent
column4: as well as a cut in the deduction for business entertainment expenses. Our plan seeks to attack tax subsidies that actually reward companies more for shutting their operations down here and moving them overseas than for staying here and reinvesting in America. I say that as someone who believes that American companies should be free to invest around the world and as a former Governor who actively sought investment of foreign companies in my State. But the Tax Code should not express a preference to American companies for moving somewhere else
column5: and it does in particular cases today.

column1: We will seek to ensure that
column2: through effective tax enforcement
column3: foreign corporations who do make money in America simply pay the same taxes that American companies make on the same income.

column1: To middle class Americans who have paid a great deal for the last 12 years and from whom I ask a contribution tonight
column2: I will say again as I did on Monday night: You're not going alone any more
column3: you're certainly not going first
column4: and you're not going to pay more for less as you have too often in the past. I want to emphasize the facts about this plan: 98.8 percent of America's families will have no increase in their income tax rates
column5: only 1.2 percent at the top.

column1: Let me be clear: There will also be no new cuts in benefits for Medicare. As we move toward the 4th year
column2: with the explosion in health care costs
column3: as I said
column4: projected to account for 50 percent of the growth of the deficit between now and the year 2000
column5: there must be planned cuts in payments to providers
column6: to doctors
column7: to hospitals
column8: to labs
column9: as a way of controlling health care costs. But I see these only as a stopgap until we can reform the entire health care system. If you'll help me do that
column10: we can be fair to the providers and to the consumers of health care. Let me repeat this
column11: because I know it matters to a lot of you on both sides of the aisle. This plan does not make a recommendation for new cuts in Medicare benefits for any beneficiary.

column1: Secondly
column2: the only change we are making in Social Security is one that has already been publicized. The plan does ask older Americans with higher incomes
column3: who do not rely solely on Social Security to get by
column4: to contribute more. This plan will not affect the 80 percent of Social Security recipients who do not pay taxes on Social Security now. Those who do not pay tax on Social Security now will not be affected by this plan.

column1: Our plan does include a broad-based tax on energy
column2: and I want to tell you why I selected this and why I think it's a good idea. I recommend that we adopt a Btu tax on the heat content of energy as the best way to provide us with revenue to lower the deficit because it also combats pollution
column3: promotes energy efficiency
column4: promotes the independence
column5: economically
column6: of this country as well as helping to reduce the debt
column7: and because it does not discriminate against any area. Unlike a carbon tax
column8: that's not too hard on the coal States; unlike a gas tax
column9: that's not too tough on people who drive a long way to work; unlike an ad valorem tax
