column10: it doesn't increase just when the price of an energy source goes up. And it is environmentally responsible. It will help us in the future as well as in the present with the deficit.

column1: Taken together
column2: these measures will cost an American family with an income of about $40
column3: 000 a year less than $17 a month. It will cost American families with incomes under $30
column4: 000 nothing because of other programs we propose
column5: principally those raising the earned-income tax credit.

column1: Because of our publicly stated determination to reduce the deficit
column2: if we do these things
column3: we will see the continuation of what's happened just since the election. Just since the election
column4: since the Secretary of the Treasury
column5: the Director of the Office of Management and Budget
column6: and others who have begun to speak out publicly in favor of a tough deficit reduction plan
column7: interest rates have continued to fall long-term. That means that for the middle class who will pay something more each month
column8: if they had any credit needs or demands
column9: their increased energy costs will be more than offset by lower interest costs for mortgages
column10: consumer loans
column11: credit cards. This can be a wise investment for them and their country now.

column1: I would also point out what the American people already know
column2: and that is
column3: because we're a big
column4: vast country where we drive long distances
column5: we have maintained far lower burdens on energy than any other advanced country. We will still have far lower burdens on energy than any other advanced country. And these will be spread fairly
column6: with real attempts to make sure that no cost is imposed on families with incomes under $30
column7: 000 and that the costs are very modest until you get into the higher income groups where the income taxes trigger in.

column1: Now
column2: I ask all of you to consider this: Whatever you think of the tax program
column3: whatever you think of the spending cuts
column4: consider the cost of not changing. Remember the numbers that you all know. If we just keep on doing what we're doing
column5: by the end of the decade we'll have a $650-billion-a-year deficit. If we just keep on doing what we're doing
column6: by the end of the decade 20 percent of our national income will go to health care every year
column7: twice as much as any other country on the face of the globe. If we just keep on doing what we're doing
column8: over 20 cents on the dollar will have to go to service the debt.

column1: Unless we have the courage now to start building our future and stop borrowing from it
column2: we're condemning ourselves to years of stagnation interrupted by occasional recessions
column3: to slow growth in jobs
column4: to no more growth in income
column5: to more debt
column6: to more disappointment. Worse
column7: unless we change
column8: unless we increase investment and reduce the debt to raise productivity so that we can generate both jobs and incomes
column9: we will be condemning our children and our children's children to a lesser life than we enjoyed. Once Americans looked forward to doubling their living standards every 25 years. At present productivity rates
column10: it will take 100 years to double living standards
column11: until our grandchildren's grandchildren are born. I say that is too long to wait.

column1: Tonight the American people know we have to change. But they're also likely to ask me tomorrow and all of you for the weeks and months ahead whether we have the fortitude to make the changes happen in the right way. They know that as soon as I leave this Chamber and you go home
column2: various interest groups will be out in force lobbying against this or that piece of this plan
column3: and that the forces of conventional wisdom will offer a thousand reasons why we well ought to do this but we just can't do it.

column1: Our people will be watching and wondering
column2: not to see whether you disagree with me on a particular issue but just to see whether this is going to be business as usual or a real new day
column3: whether we're all going to conduct ourselves as if we know we're working for them. We must scale the walls of the people's scepticisms
column4: not with our words but with our deeds. After so many years of gridlock and indecision
column5: after so many hopeful beginnings and so few promising results
column6: the American people are going to be harsh in their judgments of all of us if we fail to seize this moment.

column1: This economic plan can't please everybody. If the package is picked apart
column2: there will be something that will anger each of us
column3: won't please anybody. But if it is taken as a whole
column4: it will help all of us. So I ask you all to begin by resisting the temptation to focus only on a particular spending cut you don't like or some particular investment that wasn't made. And nobody likes the tax increases
column5: but let's just face facts. For 20 years
column6: through administrations of both parties
column7: incomes have stalled and debt has exploded and productivity has not grown as it should. We cannot deny the reality of our condition. We have got to play the hand we were dealt and play it as best we can.

column1: My fellow Americans
column2: the test of this plan cannot be "what is in it for me." It has got to be "what is in it for us." If we work hard and if we work together
column3: if we rededicate ourselves to creating jobs
column4: to rewarding work
column5: to strengthening our families
column6: to reinventing our Government
column7: we can lift our country's fortunes again.

column1: Tonight I ask everyone in this Chamber and every American to look simply into your heart
column2: to spark your own hopes
column3: to fire your own imagination. There is so much good
column4: so much possibility
column5: so much excitement in this country now that if we act boldly and honestly
column6: as leaders should
column7: our legacy will be one of prosperity and progress. This must be America's new direction. Let us summon the courage to seize it.

column1: Thank you. God bless America.@
William J. Clinton|Address Before a Joint Session of the Congress on the State of the Union|1994-01-25|@Thank you very much. Mr. Speaker
column2: Mr. President
column3: Members of the 103d Congress
column4: my fellow Americans:

column1: I'm not at all sure what speech is in the TelePrompter tonight ... but I hope we can talk about the state of the Union.

I ask you to begin by recalling the memory of the giant who presided over this Chamber with such force and grace. Tip O'Neill liked to call himself "a man of the House." And he surely was that. But even more
column2: he was a man of the people
column3: a bricklayer's son who helped to build the great American middle class. Tip O'Neill never forgot who he was
column4: where he came from
column5: or who sent him here. Tonight he's smiling down on us for the first time from the Lord's gallery. But in his honor
column6: may we
column7: too
column8: always remember who we are
column9: where we come from
column10: and who sent us here. If we do that we will return over and over again to the principle that if we simply give ordinary people equal opportunity
column11: quality education
column12: and a fair shot at the American dream
column13: they will do extraordinary things.

column1: We gather tonight in a world of changes so profound and rapid that all nations are tested. Our American heritage has always been to master such change
column2: to use it to expand opportunity at home and our leadership abroad. But for too long and in too many ways
column3: that heritage was abandoned
column4: and our country drifted.

column1: For 30 years
column2: family life in America has been breaking down. For 20 years
column3: the wages of working people have been stagnant or declining. For the 12 years of trickle-down economics
column4: we built a false prosperity on a hollow base as our national debt quadrupled. From 1989 to 1992
column5: we experienced the slowest growth in a half century. For too many families
column6: even when both parents were working
column7: the American dream has been slipping away.

column2: the American people demanded that we change. A year ago I asked all of you to join me in accepting responsibility for the future of our country. Well
column3: we did. We replaced drift and deadlock with renewal and reform. And I want to thank every one of you here who heard the American people
column4: who broke gridlock
column5: who gave them the most successful teamwork between a President and a Congress in 30 years.

column1: This Congress produced a budget that cut the deficit by half a trillion dollars
column2: cut spending
column3: and raised income taxes on only the wealthiest Americans. This Congress produced tax relief for millions of low-income workers to reward work over welfare. It produced NAFTA. It produced the Brady bill
column4: now the Brady law. And thank you
column5: Jim Brady
column6: for being here
column7: and God bless you
column8: sir.

column1: This Congress produced tax cuts to reduce the taxes of 9 out of 10 small businesses who use the money to invest more and create more jobs. It produced more research and treatment for AIDS
column2: more childhood immunizations
column3: more support for women's health research
column4: more affordable college loans for the middle class
column5: a new national service program for those who want to give something back to their country and their communities for higher education
column6: a dramatic increase in high-tech investments to move us from a defense to a domestic high-tech economy. This Congress produced a new law
column7: the motor voter bill
column8: to help millions of people register to vote. It produced family and medical leave. All passed; all signed into law with not one single veto.

column1: These accomplishments were all commitments I made when I sought this office. And in fairness
column2: they all had to be passed by you in this Congress. But I am persuaded that the real credit belongs to the people who sent us here
column3: who pay our salaries
column4: who hold our feet to the fire.

column1: But what we do here is really beginning to change lives. Let me just give you one example. I will never forget what the family and medical leave law meant to just one father I met early one Sunday morning in the White House. It was unusual to see a family there touring early Sunday morning
column2: but he had his wife and his three children there
column3: one of them in a wheelchair. I came up
column4: and after we had our picture taken and had a little visit
column5: I was walking off and that man grabbed me by the arm and he said
column6: "Mr. President
column7: let me tell you something. My little girl here is desperately ill. She's probably not going to make it. But because of the family leave law
column8: I was able to take time off to spend with her
column9: the most important time I ever spent in my life
column10: without losing my job and hurting the rest of my family. It means more to me than I will ever be able to say. Don't you people up here ever think what you do doesn't make a difference. It does."

column1: Though we are making a difference
column2: our work has just begun. Many Americans still haven't felt the impact of what we've done. The recovery still hasn't touched every community or created enough jobs. Incomes are still stagnant. There's still too much violence and not enough hope in too many places. Abroad
column3: the young democracies we are strongly supporting still face very difficult times and look to us for leadership. And so tonight
column4: let us resolve to continue the journey of renewal
column5: to create more and better jobs
column6: to guarantee health security for all
column7: to reward work over welfare
column8: to promote democracy abroad
column9: and to begin to reclaim our streets from violent crime and drugs and gangs
column10: to renew our own American community.

column1: Last year we began to put our house in order by tackling the budget deficit that was driving us toward bankruptcy. We cut $255 billion in spending
column2: including entitlements
column3: and over 340 separate budget items. We froze domestic spending and used honest budget numbers.

column1: Led by the Vice President
column2: we launched a campaign to reinvent Government. We cut staff
column3: cut perks
column4: even trimmed the fleet of Federal limousines. After years of leaders whose rhetoric attacked bureaucracy but whose action expanded it
column5: we will actually reduce it by 252
column6: 000 people over the next 5 years. By the time we have finished
column7: the Federal bureaucracy will be at its lowest point in 30 years.

column1: Because the deficit was so large and because they benefited from tax cuts in the 1980's
column2: we did ask the wealthiest Americans to pay more to reduce the deficit. So on April 15th
column3: the American people will discover the truth about what we did last year on taxes. Only the top 1 ... yes
column4: listen
column5: the top 1.2 percent of Americans
column6: as I said all along
column7: will pay higher income tax rates. Let me repeat: Only the wealthiest 1.2 percent of Americans will face higher income tax rates
column8: and no one else will. And that is the truth.

column1: Of course
column2: there were
column3: as there always are in politics
column4: naysayers who said this plan wouldn't work. But they were wrong. When I became President
column5: the experts predicted that next year's deficit would be $300 billion. But because we acted
column6: those same people now say the deficit is going to be under $180 billion
column7: 40 percent lower than was previously predicted.

column1: Our economic program has helped to produce the lowest core inflation rate and the lowest interest rates in 20 years. And because those interest rates are down
column2: business investment and equipment is growing at 7 times the rate of the previous 4 years. Auto sales are way up. Home sales are at a record high. Millions of Americans have refinanced their homes. And our economy has produced 1.6 million private sector jobs in 1993
column3: more than were created in the previous 4 years combined.

column1: The people who supported this economic plan should be proud of its early results
column2: proud. But everyone in this Chamber should know and acknowledge that there is more to do.

column1: Next month I will send you one of the toughest budgets ever presented to Congress. It will cut spending in more than 300 programs
column2: eliminate 100 domestic programs
column3: and reform the ways in which governments buy goods and services. This year we must again make the hard choices to live within the hard spending ceilings we have set. We must do it. We have proved we can bring the deficit down without choking off recovery
column4: without punishing seniors or the middle class
column5: and without putting our national security at risk. If you will stick with this plan
column6: we will post 3 consecutive years of declining deficits for the first time since Harry Truman lived in the White House. And once again
column7: the buck stops here.

column1: Our economic plan also bolsters our strength and our credibility around the world. Once we reduced the deficit and put the steel back into our competitive edge
column2: the world echoed with the sound of falling trade barriers. In one year
column3: with NAFTA
column4: with GATT
column5: with our efforts in Asia and the national export strategy
column6: we did more to open world markets to American products than at any time in the last two generations. That means more jobs and rising living standards for the American people
column7: low deficits
column8: low inflation
column9: low interest rates
column10: low trade barriers
column11: and high investments. These are the building blocks of our recovery. But if we want to take full advantage of the opportunities before us in the global economy
column12: you all know we must do more.

column1: As we reduce defense spending
column2: I ask Congress to invest more in the technologies of tomorrow. Defense conversion will keep us strong militarily and create jobs for our people here at home. As we protect our environment
column3: we must invest in the environmental technologies of the future which will create jobs. This year we will fight for a revitalized Clean Water Act and a Safe Drinking Water Act and a reformed Superfund program. And the Vice President is right
column4: we must also work with the private sector to connect every classroom
column5: every clinic
column6: every library
column7: every hospital in America into a national information superhighway by the year 2000. Think of it: Instant access to information will increase productivity
column8: will help to educate our children. It will provide better medical care. It will create jobs. And I call on the Congress to pass legislation to establish that information superhighway this year.

column1: As we expand opportunity and create jobs
column2: no one can be left out. We must continue to enforce fair lending and fair housing and all civil rights laws
column3: because America will never be complete in its renewal until everyone shares in its bounty.

column1: But we all know
column2: too
column3: we can do all these thingsput our economic house in order
column4: expand world trade
column5: target the jobs of the future
column6: guarantee equal opportunitybut if we're honest we'll all admit that this strategy still cannot work unless we also give our people the education
column7: training
column8: and skills they need to seize the opportunities of tomorrow.

column1: We must set tough
column2: world-class academic and occupational standards for all our children and give our teachers and students the tools they need to meet them. Our Goals 2000 proposal will empower individual school districts to experiment with ideas like chartering their schools to be run by private corporations or having more public school choice
column3: to do whatever they wish to do as long as we measure every school by one high standard: Are our children learning what they need to know to compete and win in the global economy? Goals 2000 links world-class standards to grassroots reforms. And I hope Congress will pass it without delay.

column1: Our school-to-work initiative will for the first time link school to the world of work
column2: providing at least one year of apprenticeship beyond high school. After all
column3: most of the people we're counting on to build our economic future won't graduate from college. It's time to stop ignoring them and start empowering them.

column1: We must literally transform our outdated unemployment system into a new reemployment system. The old unemployment system just sort of kept you going while you waited for your old job to come back. We've got to have a new system to move people into new and better jobs
column2: because most of those old jobs just don't come back. And we know that the only way to have real job security in the future
column3: to get a good job with a growing income
column4: is to have real skills and the ability to learn new ones. So we've got to streamline today's patchwork of training programs and make them a source of new skills for our people who lose their jobs. Reemployment
column5: not unemployment
column6: must become the centerpiece of our economic renewal. I urge you to pass it in this session of Congress.

column1: And just as we must transform our unemployment system
column2: so must we also revolutionize our welfare system. It doesn't work. It defies our values as a nation. If we value work
column3: we can't justify a system that makes welfare more attractive than work if people are worried about losing their health care. If we value responsibility
column4: we can't ignore the $34 billion in child support absent parents ought to be paying to millions of parents who are taking care of their children. If we value strong families
column5: we can't perpetuate a system that actually penalizes those who stay together. Can you believe that a child who has a child gets more money from the Government for leaving home than for staying home with a parent or a grandparent? That's not just bad policy
column6: it's wrong. And we ought to change it.

column1: I worked on this problem for years before I became President
column2: with other Governors and with Members of Congress of both parties and with the previous administration of another party. I worked on it with people who were on welfare
column3: lots of them. And I want to say something to everybody here who cares about this issue. The people who most want to change this system are the people who are dependent on it. They want to get off welfare. They want to go back to work. They want to do right by their kids.

column1: I once had a hearing when I was a Governor
column2: and I brought in people on welfare from all over America who had found their way to work. The woman from my State who testified was asked this question: What's the best thing about being off welfare and in a job? And without blinking an eye
column3: she looked at 40 Governors
column4: and she said
column5: "When my boy goes to school and they say
column6: What does your mother do for a living?' he can give an answer." These people want a better system
column7: and we ought to give it to them.

column1: Last year we began this. We gave the States more power to innovate because we know that a lot of great ideas come from outside Washington
column2: and many States are already using it. Then this Congress took a dramatic step. Instead of taxing people with modest incomes into poverty
column3: we helped them to work their way out of poverty by dramatically increasing the earned-income tax credit. It will lift 15 million working families out of poverty
column4: rewarding work over welfare
column5: making it possible for people to be successful workers and successful parents. Now that's real welfare reform.

column1: But there is more to be done. This spring I will send you a comprehensive welfare reform bill that builds on the Family Support Act of 1988 and restores the basic values of work and responsibility. We'll say to teenagers
column2: "If you have a child out of wedlock
column3: we will no longer give you a check to set up a separate household. We want families to stay together"; say to absent parents who aren't paying their child support
column4: "If you're not providing for your children
column5: we'll garnish your wages
column6: suspend your license
column7: track you across State lines
column8: and if necessary
column9: make some of you work off what you owe." People who bring children into this world cannot and must not walk away from them. But to all those who depend on welfare
column10: we should offer ultimately a simple compact. We'll provide the support
column11: the job training
column12: the child care you need for up to 2 years. But after that
column13: anyone who can work
column14: must
column15: in the private sector wherever possible
column16: in community service if necessary. That's the only way we'll ever make welfare what it ought to be

column1: I know it will be difficult to tackle welfare reform in 1994 at the same time we tackle health care. But let me point out
column2: I think it is inevitable and imperative. It is estimated that one million people are on welfare today because it's the only way they can get health care coverage for their children. Those who choose to leave welfare for jobs without health benefits
column3: and many entry-level jobs don't have health benefits
column4: find themselves in the incredible position of paying taxes that help to pay for health care coverage for those who made the other choice
column5: to stay on welfare. No wonder people leave work and go back to welfare to get health care coverage. We've got to solve the health care problem to have real welfare reform.

column1: So this year
column2: we will make history by reforming the health care system. And I would say to you
column3: all of you
column4: my fellow public servants
column5: this is another issue where the people are way ahead of the politicians. That may not be popular with either party
column6: but it happens to be the truth.

column1: You know
column2: the First Lady has received now almost a million letters from people all across America and from all walks of life. I'd like to share just one of them with you. Richard Anderson of Reno
column3: Nevada
column4: lost his job and with it
column5: his health insurance. Two weeks later his wife
column6: Judy
column7: suffered a cerebral aneurysm. He rushed her to the hospital
column8: where she stayed in intensive care for 21 days. The Andersons' bills were over $120
column9: 000. Although Judy recovered and Richard went back to work at $8 an hour
column10: the bills were too much for them
column11: and they were literally forced into bankruptcy. "Mrs. Clinton
column12: he wrote to Hillary, no one in the United States of America should have to lose everything they've worked for all their lives because they were unfortunate enough to become ill." It was to help the Richard and Judy Andersons of America that the First Lady and so many others have worked so hard and so long on this health care reform issue. We owe them our thanks and our action.

column1: I know there are people here who say there's no health care crisis. Tell it to Richard and Judy Anderson. Tell it to the 58 million Americans who have no coverage at all for some time each year. Tell it to the 81 million Americans with those preexisting conditions. Those folks are paying more
column2: or they can't get insurance at all
column3: or they can't ever change their jobs because they or someone in their family has one of those preexisting conditions. Tell it to the small businesses burdened by the skyrocketing cost of insurance. Most small businesses cover their employees
column4: and they pay on average 35 percent more in premiums than big businesses or Government. Or tell it to the 76 percent of insured Americans
column5: three out of four
column6: whose policies have lifetime limits
column7: and that means they can find themselves without any coverage at all just when they need it the most. So if any of you believe there's no crisis
column8: you tell it to those people
column9: because I can't.

column1: There are some people who literally do not understand the impact of this problem on people's lives. And all you have to do is go out and listen to them. Just go talk to them anywhere in any congressional district in this country. They're Republicans and Democrats and independents; it doesn't have a lick to do with party. They think we don't get it. And it's time we show them that we do get it.
From the day we began
column2: our health care initiative has been designed to strengthen what is good about our health care system: the world's best health care professionals
column3: cutting-edge research and wonderful research institutions
column4: Medicare for older Americans. None of this
column5: none of it should be put at risk.

column1: But we're paying more and more money for less and less care. Every year fewer and fewer Americans even get to choose their doctors. Every year doctors and nurses spend more time on paperwork and less time with patients because of the absolute bureaucratic nightmare the present system has become. This system is riddled with inefficiency
column2: with abuse
column3: with fraud
column4: and everybody knows it. In today's health care system
column5: insurance companies call the shots. They pick whom they cover and how they cover them. They can cut off your benefits when you need your coverage the most. They are in charge.

column1: What does it mean? It means every night millions of well-insured Americans go to bed just an illness
column2: an accident
column3: or a pink slip away from having no coverage or financial ruin. It means every morning millions of Americans go to work without any health insurance at all
column4: something the workers in no other advanced country in the world do. It means that every year more and more hard-working people are told to pick a new doctor because their boss has had to pick a new plan. And countless others turn down better jobs because they know if they take the better job
column5: they will lose their health insurance. If we just let the health care system continue to drift
column6: our country will have people with less care
column7: fewer choices
column8: and higher bills.

column1: Now
column2: our approach protects the quality of care and people's choices. It builds on what works today in the private sector
column3: to expand employer-based coverage
column4: to guarantee private insurance for every American. And I might say
column5: employer-based private insurance for every American was proposed 20 years ago by President Richard Nixon to the United States Congress. It was a good idea then
column6: and it's a better idea today.

column1: Why do we want guaranteed private insurance? Because right now 9 out of 10 people who have insurance get it through their employers. And that should continue. And if your employer is providing good benefits at reasonable prices
column2: that should continue
column3: too. That ought to make the Congress and the President feel better.

column1: Our goal is health insurance everybody can depend on: comprehensive benefits that cover preventive care and prescription drugs; health premiums that don't just explode when you get sick or you get older; the power
column2: no matter how small your business is
column3: to choose dependable insurance at the same competitive rates governments and big business get today; one simple form for people who are sick; and most of all
column4: the freedom to choose a plan and the right to choose your own doctor.

column1: Our approach protects older Americans. Every plan before the Congress proposes to slow the growth of Medicare. The difference is this: We believe those savings should be used to improve health care for senior citizens. Medicare must be protected
column2: and it should cover prescription drugs
column3: and we should take the first steps in covering long-term care. To those who would cut Medicare without protecting seniors
column4: I say the solution to today's squeeze on middle class working people's health care is not to put the squeeze on middle class retired people's health care. We can do better than that.

column1: When it's all said and done
column2: it's pretty simple to me. Insurance ought to mean what it used to mean: You pay a fair price for security
column3: and when you get sick
column4: health care's always there
column5: no matter what.

column1: Along with the guarantee of health security
column2: we all have to admit
column3: too
column4: there must be more responsibility on the part of all of us in how we use this system. People have to take their kids to get immunized. We should all take advantage of preventive care. We must all work together to stop the violence that explodes our emergency rooms. We have to practice better health habits
column5: and we can't abuse the system. And those who don't have insurance under our approach will get coverage
column6: but they'll have to pay something for it
column7: too. The minority of businesses that provide no insurance at all
column8: and in so doing shift the cost of the care of their employees to others
column9: should contribute something. People who smoke should pay more for a pack of cigarettes. Everybody can contribute something if we want to solve the health care crisis. There can't be any more something for nothing. It will not be easy but it can be done.

column1: Now
column2: in the coming months I hope very much to work with both Democrats and Republicans to reform a health care system by using the market to bring down costs and to achieve lasting health security. But if you look at history we see that for 60 years this country has tried to reform health care. President Roosevelt tried. President Truman tried. President Nixon tried. President Carter tried. Every time the special interests were powerful enough to defeat them. But not this time.

column1: I know that facing up to these interests will require courage. It will raise critical questions about the way we finance our campaigns and how lobbyists yield their influence. The work of change
column2: frankly
column3: will never get any easier until we limit the influence of well-financed interests who profit from this current system. So I also must now call on you to finish the job both Houses began last year by passing tough and meaningful campaign finance reform and lobby reform legislation this year.

column1: You know
column2: my fellow Americans
column3: this is really a test for all of us. The American people provide those of us in Government service with terrific health care benefits at reasonable costs. We have health care that's always there. I think we need to give every hard-working
column4: tax-paying American the same health care security they have already given to us.

column1: I want to make this very clear. I am open
column2: as I have said repeatedly
column3: to the best ideas of concerned Members of both parties. I have no special brief for any specific approach
column4: even in our own bill
column5: except this: If you send me legislation that does not guarantee every American private health insurance that can never be taken away
column6: you will force me to take this pen
column7: veto the legislation
column8: and we'll come right back here and start all over again.

column1: But I don't think that's going to happen. I think we're ready to act now. I believe that you're ready to act now. And if you're ready to guarantee every American the same health care that you have
column2: health care that can never be taken away
column3: nownot next year or the year afternow is the time to stand with the people who sent us here
column4: now.

column1: As we take these steps together to renew our strength at home
column2: we cannot turn away from our obligation to renew our leadership abroad. This is a promising moment. Because of the agreements we have reached this year
column3: last year
column4: Russia's strategic nuclear missiles soon will no longer be pointed at the United States
column5: nor will we point ours at them. Instead of building weapons in space
column6: Russian scientists will help us to build the international space station.

column1: Of course
column2: there are still dangers in the world: rampant arms proliferation
column3: bitter regional conflicts
column4: ethnic and nationalist tensions in many new democracies
column5: severe environmental degradation the world over
column6: and fanatics who seek to cripple the world's cities with terror. As the world's greatest power
column7: we must
column8: therefore
column9: maintain our defenses and our responsibilities.

column1: This year
column2: we secured indictments against terrorists and sanctions against those who harbor them. We worked to promote environmentally sustainable economic growth. We achieved agreements with Ukraine
column3: with Belarus
column4: with Kazahkstan to eliminate completely their nuclear arsenal. We are working to achieve a Korean Peninsula free of nuclear weapons. We will seek early ratification of a treaty to ban chemical weapons worldwide. And earlier today
column5: we joined with over 30 nations to begin negotiations on a comprehensive ban to stop all nuclear testing.

column1: But nothing
column2: nothing is more important to our security than our Nation's Armed Forces. We honor their contributions
column3: including those who are carrying out the longest humanitarian air lift in history in Bosnia
column4: those who will complete their mission in Somalia this year and their brave comrades who gave their lives there. Our forces are the finest military our Nation has ever had. And I have pledged that as long as I am President
column5: they will remain the best equipped
column6: the best trained
column7: and the best prepared fighting force on the face of the Earth.

column1: Last year I proposed a defense plan that maintains our post-cold-war security at a lower cost. This year many people urged me to cut our defense spending further to pay for other Government programs. I said no. The budget I send to Congress draws the line against further defense cuts. It protects the readiness and quality of our forces. Ultimately
column2: the best strategy is to do that. We must not cut defense further. I hope the Congress
column3: without regard to party
column4: will support that position.

column1: Ultimately
column2: the best strategy to ensure our security and to build a durable peace is to support the advance of democracy elsewhere. Democracies don't attack each other. They make better trading partners and partners in diplomacy. That is why we have supported
column3: you and I
column4: the democratic reformers in Russia and in the other states of the former Soviet bloc. I applaud the bipartisan support this Congress provided last year for our initiatives to help Russia
column5: Ukraine
column6: and the other states through their epic transformations.

column1: Our support of reform must combine patience for the enormity of the task and vigilance for our fundamental interest and values. We will continue to urge Russia and the other states to press ahead with economic reforms. And we will seek to cooperate with Russia to solve regional problems
column2: while insisting that if Russian troops operate in neighboring states
column3: they do so only when those states agree to their presence and in strict accord with international standards.

column1: But we must also remember as these nations chart their own futuresand they must chart their own futureshow much more secure and more prosperous our own people will be if democratic and market reforms succeed all across the former Communist bloc. Our policy has been to support that move
column2: and that has been the policy of the Congress. We should continue it.

column1: That is why I went to Europe earlier this month
column2: to work with our European partners
column3: to help to integrate all the former Communist countries into a Europe that has a possibility of becoming unified for the first time in its entire history
column4: its entire history
column5: based on the simple commitments of all nations in Europe to democracy
column6: to free markets
column7: and to respect for existing borders.

column1: With our allies we have created a Partnership For Peace that invites states from the former Soviet bloc and other non-NATO members to work with NATO in military cooperation. When I met with Central Europe's leaders
column2: including Lech Walesa and Vaclav Havel
column3: men who put their lives on the line for freedom
column4: I told them that the security of their region is important to our country's security.

column1: This year we must also do more to support democratic renewal and human rights and sustainable development all around the world. We will ask Congress to ratify the new GATT accord. We will continue standing by South Africa as it works its way through its bold and hopeful and difficult transition to democracy. We will convene a summit of the Western Hemisphere's democratic leaders from Canada to the tip of South America. And we will continue to press for the restoration of true democracy in Haiti. And as we build a more constructive relationship with China
column2: we must continue to insist on clear signs of improvement in that nation's human rights record.

column1: We will also work for new progress toward the Middle East peace. Last year the world watched Yitzhak Rabin and Yasser Arafat at the White House when they had their historic handshake of reconciliation. But there is a long
column2: hard road ahead. And on that road I am determined that I and our administration will do all we can to achieve a comprehensive and lasting peace for all the peoples of the region.

column1: Now
column2: there are some in our country who argue that with the cold war
column3: America should turn its back on the rest of the world. Many around the world were afraid we would do just that. But I took this office on a pledge that had no partisan tinge
column4: to keep our Nation secure by remaining engaged in the rest of the world. And this year
column5: because of our work together
column6: enacting NAFTA
column7: keeping our military strong and prepared
column8: supporting democracy abroad
column9: we have reaffirmed America's leadership
column10: America's engagement. And as a result
column11: the American people are more secure than they were before.

column1: But while Americans are more secure from threats abroad
column2: I think we all know that in many ways we are less secure from threats here at home. Every day the national peace is shattered by crime. In Petaluma
column3: California
column4: an innocent slumber party gives way to agonizing tragedy for the family of Polly Klaas. An ordinary train ride on Long Island ends in a hail of 9-millimeter rounds. A tourist in Florida is nearly burned alive by bigots simply because he is black. Right here in our Nation's Capital
column5: a brave young man named Jason White
column6: a policeman
column7: the son and grandson of policemen
column8: is ruthlessly gunned down. Violent crime and the fear it provokes are crippling our society
column9: limiting personal freedom
column10: and fraying the ties that bind us.

column1: The crime bill before Congress gives you a chance to do something about it
column2: a chance to be tough and smart. What does that mean? Let me begin by saying I care a lot about this issue. Many years ago
column3: when I started out in public life
column4: I was the attorney general of my State. I served as a Governor for a dozen years. I know what it's like to sign laws increasing penalties
column5: to build more prison cells
column6: to carry out the death penalty. I understand this issue. And it is not a simple thing.

column1: First
column2: we must recognize that most violent crimes are committed by a small percentage of criminals who too often break the laws even when they are on parole. Now those who commit crimes should be punished. And those who commit repeated violent crimes should be told
column3: "When you commit a third violent crime
column4: you will be put away
column5: and put away for good; three strikes and you are out."

column1: Second
column2: we must take serious steps to reduce violence and prevent crime
column3: beginning with more police officers and more community policing. We know right now that police who work the streets
column4: know the folks
column5: have the respect of the neighborhood kids
column6: focus on high crime areas
column7: we know that they are more likely to prevent crime as well as catch criminals. Look at the experience of Houston
column8: where the crime rate dropped 17 percent in one year when that approach was taken.

column1: Here tonight is one of those community policemen
column2: a brave
column3: young detective
column4: Kevin Jett
column5: whose beat is eight square blocks in one of the toughest neighborhoods in New York. Every day he restores some sanity and safety and a sense of values and connections to the people whose lives he protects. I'd like to ask him to stand up and be recognized tonight. Thank you
column6: sir.

column1: You will be given a chance to give the children of this country
column2: the law-abiding working people of this countryand don't forget
column3: in the toughest neighborhoods in this country
column4: in the highest crime neighborhoods in this country
column5: the vast majority of people get up every day and obey the law
column6: pay their taxes
column7: do their best to raise their kids. They deserve people like Kevin Jett. And you're going to be given a chance to give the American people another 100
column8: 000 of them
column9: well trained. And I urge you to do it.

column1: You have before you crime legislation which also establishes a police corps to encourage young people to get an education and pay it off by serving as police officers; which encourages retiring military personnel to move into police forces
column2: an inordinate resource for our country; one which has a safe schools provision which will give our young people the chance to walk to school in safety and to be in school in safety instead of dodging bullets. These are important things.

column1: The third thing we have to do is to build on the Brady bill
column2: the Brady law
column3: to take further steps to keep guns out of the hands of criminals. I want to say something about this issue. Hunters must always be free to hunt. Law-abiding adults should always be free to own guns and protect their homes. I respect that part of our culture; I grew up in it. But I want to ask the sportsmen and others who lawfully own guns to join us in this campaign to reduce gun violence. I say to you
column4: I know you didn't create this problem
column5: but we need your help to solve it. There is no sporting purpose on Earth that should stop the United States Congress from banishing assault weapons that out-gun police and cut down children.

column1: Fourth
column2: we must remember that drugs are a factor in an enormous percentage of crimes. Recent studies indicate
column3: sadly
column4: that drug use is on the rise again among our young people. The crime bill containsall the crime bills contain more money for drug treatment for criminal addicts and boot camps for youthful offenders that include incentives to get off drugs and to stay off drugs. Our administration's budget
column5: with all its cuts
column6: contains a large increase in funding for drug treatment and drug education. You must pass them both. We need them desperately.

column1: My fellow Americans
column2: the problem of violence is an American problem. It has no partisan or philosophical element. Therefore
column3: I urge you to find ways as quickly as possible to set aside partisan differences and pass a strong
column4: smart
column5: tough crime bill. But further
column6: I urge you to consider this: As you demand tougher penalties for those who choose violence
column7: let us also remember how we came to this sad point. In our toughest neighborhoods
column8: on our meanest streets
column9: in our poorest rural areas
column10: we have seen a stunning and simultaneous breakdown of community
column11: family
column12: and work
column13: the heart and soul of civilized society. This has created a vast vacuum which has been filled by violence and drugs and gangs. So I ask you to remember that even as we say no to crime
column14: we must give people

column1: Many of our initiatives
column2: from job training to welfare reform to health care to national service
column3: will help to rebuild distressed communities
column4: to strengthen families
column5: to provide work. But more needs to be done. That's what our community empowerment agenda is all about
column6: challenging businesses to provide more investment through empowerment zones
column7: ensuring banks will make loans in the same communities their deposits come from
column8: passing legislation to unleash the power of capital through community development banks to create jobs
column9: opportunity
column10: and hope where they're needed most.

column1: I think you know that to really solve this problem
column2: we'll all have to put our heads together
column3: leave our ideological armor aside
column4: and find some new ideas to do even more. And let's be honest
column5: we all know something else too: Our problems go way beyond the reach of Government. They're rooted in the loss of values
column6: in the disappearance of work
column7: and the breakdown of our families and our communities.

column1: My fellow Americans
column2: we can cut the deficit
column3: create jobs
column4: promote democracy around the world
column5: pass welfare reform and health care
column6: pass the toughest crime bill in history
column7: but still leave too many of our people behind. The American people have got to want to change from within if we're going to bring back work and family and community. We cannot renew our country when within a decade more than half of the children will be born into families where there has been no marriage. We cannot renew this country when 13-year-old boys get semiautomatic weapons to shoot 9-year-olds for kicks. We can't renew our country when children are having children and the fathers walk away as if the kids don't amount to anything. We can't renew the country when our businesses eagerly look for new investments and new customers abroad but ignore those people right here at home who would give anything to have their jobs and would gladly buy their products if they had the money to do it. We can't renew our country unless more of usI mean
column8: all of us are willing to join the churches and the other good citizens
column9: people like all thelike ministers I've worked with over the years or the priests and the nuns I met at Our Lady of Help in east Los Angeles or my good friend Tony Campollo in Philadelphia
column10: unless we're willing to work with people like that
column11: people who are saving kids
column12: adopting schools
column13: making streets safer. All of us can do that. We can't renew our country until we realize that governments don't raise children
column14: parents do.

column1: Parents who know their children's teachers and turn off the television and help with the homework and teach their kids right from wrong
column2: those kinds of parents can make all the difference. I know; I had one. I'm telling you
column3: we have got to stop pointing our fingers at these kids who have no future and reach our hands out to them. Our country needs it
column4: we need it
column5: and they deserve it.

column1: So I say to you tonight
column2: let's give our children a future. Let us take away their guns and give them books. Let us overcome their despair and replace it with hope. Let us
column3: by our example
column4: teach them to obey the law
column5: respect our neighbors
column6: and cherish our values. Let us weave these sturdy threads into a new American community that can once more stand strong against the forces of despair and evil because everybody has a chance to walk into a better tomorrow.

column1: Oh
column2: there will be naysayers who fear that we won't be equal to the challenges of this time. But they misread our history
column3: our heritage. Even today's headlines
column4: all those things tell us we can and we will overcome any challenge.

column1: When the earth shook and fires raged in California
column2: when I saw the Mississippi deluge the farmlands of the Midwest in a 500-year flood
column3: when the century's bitterest cold swept from North Dakota to Newport News
column4: it seemed as though the world itself was coming apart at the seams. But the American people
column5: they just came together. They rose to the occasion
column6: neighbor helping neighbor
column7: strangers risking life and limb to save total strangers
column8: showing the better angels of our nature.

column1: Let us not reserve the better angels only for natural disasters
column2: leaving our deepest and most profound problems to petty political fighting. Let us instead be true to our spirit
column3: facing facts
column4: coming together
column5: bringing hope
column6: and moving forward.

column1: Tonight
column2: my fellow Americans
column3: we are summoned to answer a question as old as the Republic itself: What is the state of our Union? It is growing stronger
column4: but it must be stronger still. With your help and God's help
column5: it will be.

column1: Thank you
column2: and God bless America.@

column1: William J. Clinton|Address Before a Joint Session of the Congress on the State of the Union|1995-01-24|@Mr. President
column2: Mr. Speaker
column3: Members of the 104th Congress
column4: my fellow Americans: Again we are here in the sanctuary of democracy
column5: and once again our democracy has spoken. So let me begin by congratulating all of you here in the 104th Congress and congratulating you
column6: Mr. Speaker.

column1: If we agree on nothing else tonight
column2: we must agree that the American people certainly voted for change in 1992 and in 1994. And as I look out at you
column3: I know how some of you must have felt in 1992.

column1: I must say that in both years we didn't hear America singing
column2: we heard America shouting. And now all of us
column3: Republicans and Democrats alike
column4: must say
column5: "We hear you. We will work together to earn the jobs you have given us." For we are the keepers of a sacred trust
column6: and we must be faithful to it in this new and very demanding era.

column1: Over 200 years ago
column2: our Founders changed the entire course of human history by joining together to create a new country based on a single powerful idea: "We hold these truths to be self-evident
column3: that all men are created equal
column4: . . . endowed by their Creator with certain unalienable Rights
column5: and among these are Life
column6: Liberty and the pursuit of Happiness."

column1: It has fallen to every generation since then to preserve that idea
column2: the American idea
column3: and to deepen and expand its meaning in new and different times: to Lincoln and to his Congress to preserve the Union and to end slavery; to Theodore Roosevelt and Woodrow Wilson to restrain the abuses and excesses of the industrial revolution and to assert our leadership in the world; to Franklin Roosevelt to fight the failure and pain of the Great Depression and to win our country's great struggle against fascism; and to all our Presidents since to fight the cold war. Especially
column4: I recall two who struggled to fight that cold war in partnership with Congresses where the majority was of a different party: to Harry Truman
column5: who summoned us to unparalleled prosperity at home and who built the architecture of the cold war; and to Ronald Reagan
column6: whom we wish well tonight and who exhorted us to carry on until the twilight struggle against communism was won.

column1: In another time of change and challenge
column2: I had the honor to be the first President to be elected in the post-cold-war era
column3: an era marked by the global economy
column4: the information revolution
column5: unparalleled change and opportunity and insecurity for the American people. I came to this hallowed Chamber 2 years ago on a mission
column6: to restore the American dream for all our people and to make sure that we move into the 21st century still the strongest force for freedom and democracy in the entire world. I was determined then to tackle the tough problems too long ignored. In this effort I am frank to say that I have made my mistakes
column7: and I have learned again the importance of humility in all human endeavor. But I am also proud to say tonight that our country is stronger than it was 2 years ago.  Thank you.

column1: Record numbers of Americans are succeeding in the new global economy. We are at peace
column2: and we are a force for peace and freedom throughout the world. We have almost 6 million new jobs since I became President
column3: and we have the lowest combined rate of unemployment and inflation in 25 years. Our businesses are more productive. And here we have worked to bring the deficit down
column4: to expand trade
column5: to put more police on our streets
column6: to give our citizens more of the tools they need to get an education and to rebuild their own communities.

column1: But the rising tide is not lifting all boats. While our Nation is enjoying peace and prosperity
column2: too many of our people are still working harder and harder
column3: for less and less. While our businesses are restructuring and growing more productive and competitive
column4: too many of our people still can't be sure of having a job next year or even next month. And far more than our material riches are threatened
column5: things far more precious to us
column6: our children
column7: our families
column8: our values.

column1: Our civil life is suffering in America today. Citizens are working together less and shouting at each other more. The common bonds of community which have been the great strength of our country from its very beginning are badly frayed. What are we to do about it?
More than 60 years ago
column2: at the dawn of another new era
column3: President Roosevelt told our Nation
column4: "New conditions impose new requirements on Government and those who conduct Government." And from that simple proposition
column5: he shaped the New Deal
column6: which helped to restore our Nation to prosperity and define the relationship between our people and their Government for half a century.

column1: That approach worked in its time. But we today
column2: we face a very different time and very different conditions. We are moving from an industrial age built on gears and sweat to an information age demanding skills and learning and flexibility. Our Government
column3: once a champion of national purpose
column4: is now seen by many as simply a captive of narrow interests
column5: putting more burdens on our citizens rather than equipping them to get ahead. The values that used to hold us all together seem to be coming apart.

column1: So tonight we must forge a new social compact to meet the challenges of this time. As we enter a new era
column2: we need a new set of understandings
column3: not just with Government but
column4: even more important
column5: with one another as Americans.

column1: That's what I want to talk with you about tonight. I call it the New Covenant. But it's grounded in a very
column2: very old idea
column3: that all Americans have not just a right but a solemn responsibility to rise as far as their God-given talents and determination can take them and to give something back to their communities and their country in return. Opportunity and responsibility: They go hand in hand. We can't have one without the other. And our national community can't hold together without both.

column1: Our New Covenant is a new set of understandings for how we can equip our people to meet the challenges of a new economy
column2: how we can change the way our Government works to fit a different time
column3: and
column4: above all
column5: how we can repair the damaged bonds in our society and come together behind our common purpose. We must have dramatic change in our economy
column6: our Government
column7: and ourselves.

column1: My fellow Americans
column2: without regard to party
column3: let us rise to the occasion. Let us put aside partisanship and pettiness and pride. As we embark on this new course
column4: let us put our country first
column5: remembering that regardless of party label
column6: we are all Americans. And let the final test of everything we do be a simple one: Is it good for the American people?

column1: Let me begin by saying that we cannot ask Americans to be better citizens if we are not better servants. You made a good start by passing that law which applies to Congress all the laws you put on the private sector
column2: and I was proud to sign it yesterday. But we have a lot more to do before people really trust the way things work around here. Three times as many lobbyists are in the streets and corridors of Washington as were here 20 years ago. The American people look at their Capital
column3: and they see a city where the well-connected and the well-protected can work the system
column4: but the interests of ordinary citizens are often left out.

column1: As the new Congress opened its doors
column2: lobbyists were still doing business as usual; the gifts
column3: the trips
column4: all the things that people are concerned about haven't stopped. Twice this month you missed opportunities to stop these practices. I know there were other considerations in those votes
column5: but I want to use something that I've heard my Republican friends say from time to time
column6: "There doesn't have to be a law for everything." So tonight I ask you to just stop taking the lobbyists' perks. Just stop. We don't have to wait for legislation to pass to send a strong signal to the American people that things are really changing. But I also hope you will send me the strongest possible lobby reform bill
column7: and I'll sign that
column8: too.

column1: We should require lobbyists to tell the people for whom they work what they're spending
column2: what they want. We should also curb the role of big money in elections by capping the cost of campaigns and limiting the influence of PAC's. And as I have said for 3 years
column3: we should work to open the airwaves so that they can be an instrument of democracy
column4: not a weapon of destruction
column5: by giving free TV time to candidates for public office.

column1: When the last Congress killed political reform last year
column2: it was reported in the press that the lobbyists actually stood in the Halls of this sacred building and cheered. This year
column3: let's give the folks at home something to cheer about.

column1: More important
column2: I think we all agree that we have to change the way the Government works. Let's make it smaller
column3: less costly
column4: and smarter; leaner
column5: not meaner.

column1: I just told the Speaker the equal time doctrine is alive and well.

The New Covenant approach to governing is as different from the old bureaucratic way as the computer is from the manual typewriter. The old way of governing around here protected organized interests. We should look out for the interests of ordinary people. The old way divided us by interest
column2: constituency
column3: or class. The New Covenant way should unite us behind a common vision of what's best for our country. The old way dispensed services through large
column4: top-down
column5: inflexible bureaucracies. The New Covenant way should shift these resources and decisionmaking from bureaucrats to citizens
column6: injecting choice and competition and individual responsibility into national policy. The old way of governing around here actually seemed to reward failure. The New Covenant way should have built-in incentives to reward success. The old way was centralized here in Washington. The New Covenant way must take hold in the communities all across America. And we should help them to do that.

column1: Our job here is to expand opportunity
column2: not bureaucracy
column3: to empower people to make the most of their own lives
column4: and to enhance our security here at home and abroad. We must not ask Government to do what we should do for ourselves. We should rely on Government as a partner to help us to do more for ourselves and for each other.

column1: I hope very much that as we debate these specific and exciting matters
column2: we can go beyond the sterile discussion between the illusion that there is somehow a program for every problem
column3: on the one hand
column4: and the other illusion that the Government is a source of every problem we have. Our job is to get rid of yesterday's Government so that our own people can meet today's and tomorrow's needs. And we ought to do it together.

column1: You know
column2: for years before I became President
column3: I heard others say they would cut Government and how bad it was
column4: but not much happened. We actually did it. We cut over a quarter of a trillion dollars in spending
column5: more than 300 domestic programs
column6: more than 100
column7: 000 positions from the Federal bureaucracy in the last 2 years alone. Based on decisions already made
column8: we will have cut a total of more than a quarter of a million positions from the Federal Government
column9: making it the smallest it has been since John Kennedy was President
column10: by the time I come here again next year.

column1: Under the leadership of Vice President Gore
column2: our initiatives have already saved taxpayers $63 billion. The age of the $500 hammer and the ashtray you can break on "David Letterman" is gone. Deadwood programs
column3: like mohair subsidies
column4: are gone. We've streamlined the Agriculture Department by reducing it by more than 1
column5: 200 offices. We've slashed the small business loan form from an inch thick to a single page. We've thrown away the Government's 10
column6: 000page personnel manual.

column1: And the Government is working better in important ways: FEMA
column2: the Federal Emergency Management Agency
column3: has gone from being a disaster to helping people in disasters. You can ask the farmers in the Middle West who fought the flood there or the people in California who have dealt with floods and earthquakes and fires
column4: and they'll tell you that. Government workers
column5: working hand in hand with private business
column6: rebuilt southern California's fractured freeways in record time and under budget. And because the Federal Government moved fast
column7: all but one of the 5
column8: 600 schools damaged in the earthquake are back in business.

column1: Now
column2: there are a lot of other things that I could talk about. I want to just mention one because it will be discussed here in the next few weeks. University administrators all over the country have told me that they are saving weeks and weeks of bureaucratic time now because of our direct college loan program
column3: which makes college loans cheaper and more affordable with better repayment terms for students
column4: costs the Government less
column5: and cuts out paperwork and bureaucracy for the Government and for the universities. We shouldn't cap that program. We should give every college in America the opportunity to be a part of it.

column1: Previous Government programs gathered dust. The reinventing Government report is getting results. And we're not through. There's going to be a second round of reinventing Government. We propose to cut $130 billion in spending by shrinking departments
column2: extending our freeze on domestic spending
column3: cutting 60 public housing programs down to 3
column4: getting rid of over 100 programs we do not need
column5: like the Interstate Commerce Commission and the Helium Reserve Program. And we're working on getting rid of unnecessary regulations and making them more sensible. The programs and regulations that have outlived their usefulness should go. We have to cut yesterday's Government to help solve tomorrow's problems.

column1: And we need to get Government closer to the people it's meant to serve. We need to help move programs down to the point where States and communities and private citizens in the private sector can do a better job. If they can do it
column2: we ought to let them do it. We should get out of the way and let them do what they can do better. Taking power away from Federal bureaucracies and giving it back to communities and individuals is something everyone should be able to be for.

column1: It's time for Congress to stop passing on to the States the cost of decisions we make here in Washington. I know there are still serious differences over the details of the unfunded mandates legislation
column2: but I want to work with you to make sure we pass a reasonable bill which will protect the national interests and give justified relief where we need to give it.

column1: For years
column2: Congress concealed in the budget scores of pet spending projects. Last year was no difference. There was a $1 million to study stress in plants and $12 million for a tick removal program that didn't work. It's hard to remove ticks. Those of us who have had them know.  But I'll tell you something
column3: if you'll give me line-item veto
column4: I'll remove some of that unnecessary spending.

column1: But I think we should all remember
column2: and almost all of us would agree
column3: that Government still has important responsibilities. Our young peoplewe should think of this when we cut our young people hold our future in their hands. We still owe a debt to our veterans. And our senior citizens have made us what we are. Now
column4: my budget cuts a lot. But it protects education
column5: veterans
column6: Social Security
column7: and Medicare
column8: and I hope you will do the same thing. You should
column9: and I hope you will.

column1: And when we give more flexibility to the States
column2: let us remember that there are certain fundamental national needs that should be addressed in every State
column3: North and South
column4: East and West: Immunization against childhood disease
column5: school lunches in all our schools
column6: Head Start
column7: medical care and nutrition for pregnant women and infants
column8: all these things
column9: all these things are in the national interest.

column1: I applaud your desire to get rid of costly and unnecessary regulations. But when we deregulate
column2: let's remember what national action in the national interest has given us: safer food for our families
column3: safer toys for our children
column4: safer nursing homes for our parents
column5: safer cars and highways
column6: and safer workplaces
column7: cleaner air
column8: and cleaner water. Do we need common sense and fairness in our regulations? You bet we do. But we can have common sense and still provide for safe drinking water. We can have fairness and still clean up toxic dumps
column9: and we ought to do it.

column1: Should we cut the deficit more? Well
column2: of course we should. Of course we should. But we can bring it down in a way that still protects our economic recovery and does not unduly punish people who should not be punished but instead should be helped.

column1: I know many of you in this Chamber support the balanced budget amendment. I certainly want to balance the budget. Our administration has done more to bring the budget down and to save money than any in a very
column2: very long time. If you believe passing this amendment is the right thing to do
column3: then you have to be straight with the American people. They have a right to know what you're going to cut
column4: what taxes you're going to raise
column5: and how it's going to affect them. We should be doing things in the open around here. For example
column6: everybody ought to know if this proposal is going to endanger Social Security. I would oppose that
column7: and I think most Americans would.

column1: Nothing has done more to undermine our sense of common responsibility than our failed welfare system. This is one of the problems we have to face here in Washington in our New Covenant. It rewards welfare over work. It undermines family values. It lets millions of parents get away without paying their child support.
It keeps a minority but a significant minority of the people on welfare trapped on it for a very long time.
I've worked on this problem for a long time
column2: nearly 15 years now. As a Governor
column3: I had the honor of working with the Reagan administration to write the last welfare reform bill back in 1988. In the last 2 years
column4: we made a good start at continuing the work of welfare reform. Our administration gave two dozen States the right to slash through Federal rules and regulations to reform their own welfare systems and to try to promote work and responsibility over welfare and dependency.

column1: Last year I introduced the most sweeping welfare reform plan ever presented by an administration. We have to make welfare what it was meant to be
column2: a second chance
column3: not a way of life. We have to help those on welfare move to work as quickly as possible
column4: to provide child care and teach them skills
column5: if that's what they need
column6: for up to 2 years. And after that
column7: there ought to be a simple
column8: hard rule: Anyone who can work must go to work. If a parent isn't paying child support
column9: they should be forced to pay. We should suspend drivers' license
column10: track them across State lines
column11: make them work off what they owe. That is what we should do. Governments do not raise children
column12: people do. And the parents must take responsibility for the children they bring into this world.

column1: I want to work with you
column2: with all of you
column3: to pass welfare reform. But our goal must be to liberate people and lift them up from dependence to independence
column4: from welfare to work
column5: from mere childbearing to responsible parenting. Our goal should not be to punish them because they happen to be poor.

column1: We should
column2: we should require work and mutual responsibility. But we shouldn't cut people off just because they're poor
column3: they're young
column4: or even because they're unmarried. We should promote responsibility by requiring young mothers to live at home with their parents or in other supervised settings
column5: by requiring them to finish school. But we shouldn't put them and their children out on the street. And I know all the arguments
column6: pro and con
column7: and I have read and thought about this for a long time. I still don't think we can in good conscience punish poor children for the mistakes of their parents.

column1: My fellow Americans
column2: every single survey shows that all the American people care about this without regard to party or race or region.

column1: So let this be the year we end welfare as we know it. But also let this be the year that we are all able to stop using this issue to divide America. No one is more eager to end welfare ... I may be the only President who has actually had the opportunity to sit in a welfare office
column2: who's actually spent hours and hours talking to people on welfare. And I am telling you
column3: the people who are trapped on it know it doesn't work; they also want to get off. So we can promote
column4: together
column5: education and work and good parenting. I have no problem with punishing bad behavior or the refusal to be a worker or a student or a responsible parent. I just don't want to punish poverty and past mistakes. All of us have made our mistakes
column6: and none of us can change our yesterdays. But every one of us can change our tomorrows. And America's best example of that may be Lynn Woolsey
column7: who worked her way off welfare to become a Congresswoman from the State of California.

column1: I know the Members of this Congress are concerned about crime
column2: as are all the citizens of our country. And I remind you that last year we passed a very tough crime bill: longer sentences
column3: "three strikes and you're out
column4:
almost 60 new capital punishment offenses, more prisons, more prevention, 100,000 more police. And we paid for it all by reducing the size of the Federal bureaucracy and giving the money back to local communities to lower the crime rate.
There may be other things we can do to be tougher on crime, to be smarter with crime, to help to lower that rate first. Well, if there are, let's talk about them, and let's do them. But let's not go back on the things that we did last year that we know work, that we know work because the local law enforcement officers tell us that we did the right thing, because local community leaders who have worked for years and years to lower the crime rate tell us that they work. Let's look at the experience of our cities and our rural areas where the crime rate has gone down and ask the people who did it how they did it. And if what we did last year supports the decline in the crime rate and I am convinced that it doeslet us not go back on it. Let's stick with it, implement it. We've got 4 more hard years of work to do to do that.
I don't want to destroy the good atmosphere in the room or in the country tonight, but I have to mention one issue that divided this body greatly last year. The last Congress also passed the Brady bill and, in the crime bill, the ban on 19 assault weapons. I don't think it's a secret to anybody in this room that several Members of the last Congress who voted for that aren't here tonight because they voted for it. And I know, therefore, that some of you who are here because they voted for it are under enormous pressure to repeal it. I just have to tell you how I feel about it.
The Members of Congress who voted for that bill and I would never do anything to infringe on the right to keep and bear arms to hunt and to engage in other appropriate sporting activities. I've done it since I was a boy, and I'm going to keep right on doing it until I can't do it anymore. But a lot of people laid down their seats in Congress so that police officers and kids wouldn't have to lay down their lives under a hail of assault weapon attack, and I will not let that be repealed. I will not let it be repealed.
I'd like to talk about a couple of other issues we have to deal with. I want us to cut more spending, but I hope we won't cut Government programs that help to prepare us for the new economy, promote responsibility, and are organized from the grassroots up, not by Federal bureaucracy. The very best example of this is the national service corps, AmeriCorps. It passed with strong bipartisan support. And now there are 20,000 Americans, more than ever served in one year in the Peace Corps, working all over this country, helping people person-to-person in local grassroots volunteer groups, solving problems, and in the process earning some money for their education. This is citizenship at its best. It's good for the AmeriCorps members, but it's good for the rest of us, too. It's the essence of the New Covenant, and we shouldn't stop it.
All Americans, not only in the States most heavily affected but in every place in this country, are rightly disturbed by the large numbers of illegal aliens entering our country. The jobs they hold might otherwise be held by citizens or legal immigrants. The public service they use impose burdens on our taxpayers. That's why our administration has moved aggressively to secure our borders more by hiring a record number of new border guards, by deporting twice as many criminal aliens as ever before, by cracking down on illegal hiring, by barring welfare benefits to illegal aliens. In the budget I will present to you, we will try to do more to speed the deportation of illegal aliens who are arrested for crimes, to better identify illegal aliens in the workplace as recommended by the commission headed by former Congresswoman Barbara Jordan. We are a nation of immigrants. But we are also a nation of laws. It is wrong and ultimately self-defeating for a nation of immigrants to permit the kind of abuse of our immigration laws we have seen in recent years, and we must do more to stop it.
The most important job of our Government in this new era is to empower the American people to succeed in the global economy. America has always been a land of opportunity, a land where, if you work hard, you can get ahead. We've become a great middle class country. Middle class values sustain us.
