We must expand that middle class and shrink the under class, even as we do everything we can to support the millions of Americans who are already successful in the new economy.
America is once again the world's strongest economic power: almost 6 million new jobs in the last 2 years, exports booming, inflation down. High-wage jobs are coming back. A record number of American entrepreneurs are living the American dream. If we want it to stay that way, those who work and lift our Nation must have more of its benefits.
Today, too many of those people are being left out. They're working harder for less. They have less security, less income, less certainty that they can even afford a vacation, much less college for their kids or retirement for themselves. We cannot let this continue. If we don't act, our economy will probably keep doing what it's been doing since about 1978, when the income growth began to go to those at the very top of our economic scale and the people in the vast middle got very little growth, and people who worked like crazy but were on the bottom then fell even further and further behind in the years afterward, no matter how hard they worked.
We've got to have a Government that can be a real partner in making this new economy work for all of our people, a Government that helps each and every one of us to get an education and to have the opportunity to renew our skills. That's why we worked so hard to increase educational opportunities in the last 2 years, from Head Start to public schools, to apprenticeships for young people who don't go to college, to making college loans more available and more affordable. That's the first thing we have to do. We've got to do something to empower people to improve their skills.
The second thing we ought to do is to help people raise their incomes immediately by lowering their taxes. We took the first step in 1993 with a working family tax cut for 15 million families with incomes under $27,000, a tax cut that this year will average about $1,000 a family. And we also gave tax reductions to most small and new businesses. Before we could do more than that, we first had to bring down the deficit we inherited, and we had to get economic growth up. Now we've done both. And now we can cut taxes in a more comprehensive way. But tax cuts should reinforce and promote our first obligation: to empower our citizens through education and training to make the most of their own lives. The spotlight should shine on those who make the right choices for themselves, their families, and their communities.
I have proposed the middle class bill of rights, which should properly be called the bill of rights and responsibilities because its provisions only benefit those who are working to educate and raise their children and to educate themselves. It will, therefore, give needed tax relief and raise incomes in both the short run and the long run in a way that benefits all of us.
There are four provisions. First, a tax deduction for all education and training after high school. If you think about it, we permit businesses to deduct their investment, we permit individuals to deduct interest on their home mortgages, but today an education is even more important to the economic well-being of our whole country than even those things are. We should do everything we can to encourage it. And I hope you will support it. Second, we ought to cut taxes $500 for families with children under 13. Third, we ought to foster more savings and personal responsibility by permitting people to establish an individual retirement account and withdraw from it, tax-free, for the cost of education, health care, first-time homebuying, or the care of a parent. And fourth, we should pass a GI bill" for America's workers. We propose to collapse nearly 70 Federal programs and not give the money to the States but give the money directly to the American people
column5: offer vouchers to them so that they
column6: if they're laid off or if they're working for a very low wage
column7: can get a voucher worth $2
column8: 600 a year for up to 2 years to go to their local community colleges or wherever else they want to get the skills they need to improve their lives. Let's empower people in this way
column9: move it from the Government directly to the workers of America.

column1: Now
column2: any one of us can call for a tax cut
column3: but I won't accept one that explodes the deficit or puts our recovery at risk. We ought to pay for our tax cuts fully and honestly.

column1: Just 2 years ago
column2: it was an open question whether we would find the strength to cut the deficit. Thanks to the courage of the people who were here then
column3: many of whom didn't return
column4: we did cut the deficit. We began to do what others said would not be done. We cut the deficit by over $600 billion
column5: about $10
column6: 000 for every family in this country. It's coming down 3 years in a row for the first time since Mr. Truman was President
column7: and I don't think anybody in America wants us to let it explode again.

column1: In the budget I will send you
column2: the middle class bill of rights is fully paid for by budget cuts in bureaucracy
column3: cuts in programs
column4: cuts in special interest subsidies. And the spending cuts will more than double the tax cuts. My budget pays for the middle class bill of rights without any cuts in Medicare. And I will oppose any attempts to pay for tax cuts with Medicare cuts. That's not the right thing to do.

column1: I know that a lot of you have your own ideas about tax relief
column2: and some of them I find quite interesting. I really want to work with all of you. My test for our proposals will be: Will it create jobs and raise incomes; will it strengthen our families and support our children; is it paid for; will it build the middle class and shrink the under class? If it does
column3: I'll support it. But if it doesn't
column4: I won't.

column1: The goal of building the middle class and shrinking the under class is also why I believe that you should raise the minimum wage. It rewards work. Two and a half million Americans
column2: two and a half million Americans
column3: often women with children
column4: are working out there today for $4.25 an hour. In terms of real buying power
column5: by next year that minimum wage will be at a 40-year low. That's not my idea of how the new economy ought to work.

column1: Now
column2: I've studied the arguments and the evidence for and against a minimum wage increase. I believe the weight of the evidence is that a modest increase does not cost jobs and may even lure people back into the job market. But the most important thing is
column3: you can't make a living on $4.25 an hour
column4: especially if you have children
column5: even with the working families tax cut we passed last year. In the past
column6: the minimum wage has been a bipartisan issue
column7: and I think it should be again. So I want to challenge you to have honest hearings on this
column8: to get together
column9: to find a way to make the minimum wage a living wage.

column1: Members of Congress have been here less than a month
column2: but by the end of the week
column3: 28 days into the new year
column4: every Member of Congress will have earned as much in congressional salary as a minimum wage worker makes all year long.

column1: Everybody else here
column2: including the President
column3: has something else that too many Americans do without
column4: and that's health care. Now
column5: last year we almost came to blows over health care
column6: but we didn't do anything. And the cold
column7: hard fact is that
column8: since last year
column9: since I was here
column10: another 1.1 million Americans in working families have lost their health care. And the cold
column11: hard fact is that many millions more
column12: most of them farmers and small business people and self-employed people
column13: have seen their premiums skyrocket
column14: their copays and deductibles go up. There's a whole bunch of people in this country that in the statistics have health insurance but really what they've got is a piece of paper that says they won't lose their home if they get sick.

column1: Now
column2: I still believe our country has got to move toward providing health security for every American family. But I know that last year
column3: as the evidence indicates
column4: we bit off more than we could chew. So I'm asking you that we work together. Let's do it step by step. Let's do whatever we have to do to get something done. Let's at least pass meaningful insurance reform so that no American risks losing coverage for facing skyrocketing prices
column5: that nobody loses their coverage because they face high prices or unavailable insurance when they change jobs or lose a job or a family member gets sick.

column1: I want to work together with all of you who have an interest in this
column2: with the Democrats who worked on it last time
column3: with the Republican leaders like Senator Dole
column4: who has a longtime commitment to health care reform and made some constructive proposals in this area last year. We ought to make sure that self-employed people in small businesses can buy insurance at more affordable rates through voluntary purchasing pools. We ought to help families provide long-term care for a sick parent or a disabled child. We can work to help workers who lose their jobs at least keep their health insurance coverage for a year while they look for work. And we can find a wayit may take some time
column5: but we can find a wayto make sure that our children have health care.

column1: You know
column2: I think everybody in this room
column3: without regard to party
column4: can be proud of the fact that our country was rated as having the world's most productive economy for the first time in nearly a decade. But we can't be proud of the fact that we're the only wealthy country in the world that has a smaller percentage of the work force and their children with health insurance today than we did 10 years ago
column5: the last time we were the most productive economy in the world. So let's work together on this. It is too important for politics as usual.

column1: Much of what the American people are thinking about tonight is what we've already talked about. A lot of people think that the security concerns of America today are entirely internal to our borders. They relate to the security of our jobs and our homes and our incomes and our children
column2: our streets
column3: our health
column4: and protecting those borders. Now that the cold war has passed
column5: it's tempting to believe that all the security issues
column6: with the possible exception of trade
column7: reside here at home. But it's not so. Our security still depends upon our continued world leadership for peace and freedom and democracy. We still can't be strong at home unless we're strong abroad.

column1: The financial crisis in Mexico is a case in point. I know it's not popular to say it tonight
column2: but we have to act
column3: not for the Mexican people but for the sake of the millions of Americans whose livelihoods are tied to Mexico's wellbeing. If we want to secure American jobs
column4: preserve American exports
column5: safeguard America's borders
column6: then we must pass the stabilization program and help to put Mexico back on track.

column1: Now let me repeat: It's not a loan. It's not foreign aid. It's not a bailout. We will be given a guarantee like cosigning a note
column2: with good collateral that will cover our risks. This legislation is the right thing for America. That's why the bipartisan leadership has supported it. And I hope you in Congress will pass it quickly. It is in our interest
column3: and we can explain it to the American people because we're going to do it in the right way.

column1: You know
column2: tonight
column3: this is the first State of the Union Address ever delivered since the beginning of the cold war when not a single Russian missile is pointed at the children of America. And along with the Russians
column4: we're on our way to destroying the missiles and the bombers that carry 9
column5: 000 nuclear warheads. We've come so far so fast in this post-cold-war world that it's easy to take the decline of the nuclear threat for granted. But it's still there
column6: and we aren't finished yet.

column1: This year I'll ask the Senate to approve START II to eliminate weapons that carry 5
column2: 000 more warheads. The United States will lead the charge to extend indefinitely the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty
column3: to enact a comprehensive nuclear test ban
column4: and to eliminate chemical weapons. To stop and roll back North Korea's potentially deadly nuclear program
column5: we'll continue to implement the agreement we have reached with that nation. It's smart. It's tough. It's a deal based on continuing inspection with safeguards for our allies and ourselves.

column1: This year I'll submit to Congress comprehensive legislation to strengthen our hand in combating terrorists
column2: whether they strike at home or abroad. As the cowards who bombed the World Trade Center found out
column3: this country will hunt down terrorists and bring them to justice.

column1: Just this week
column2: another horrendous terrorist act in Israel killed 19 and injured scores more. On behalf of the American people and all of you
column3: I send our deepest sympathy to the families of the victims. I know that in the face of such evil
column4: it is hard for the people in the Middle East to go forward. But the terrorists represent the past
column5: not the future. We must and we will pursue a comprehensive peace between Israel and all her neighbors in the Middle East.

column1: Accordingly
column2: last night I signed an Executive order that will block the assets in the United States of terrorist organizations that threaten to disrupt the peace process. It prohibits financial transactions with these groups. And tonight I call on all our allies and peace-loving nations throughout the world to join us with renewed fervor in a global effort to combat terrorism. We cannot permit the future to be marred by terror and fear and paralysis.

column1: From the day I took the oath of office
column2: I pledged that our Nation would maintain the best equipped
column3: best trained
column4: and best prepared military on Earth. We have
column5: and they are. They have managed the dramatic downsizing of our forces after the cold war with remarkable skill and spirit. But to make sure our military is ready for action and to provide the pay and the quality of life the military and their families deserve
column6: I'm asking the Congress to add $25 billion in defense spending over the next 6 years.

column1: I have visited many bases at home and around the world since I became President. Tonight I repeat that request with renewed conviction. We ask a very great deal of our Armed Forces. Now that they are smaller in number
column2: we ask more of them. They go out more often to more different places and stay longer. They are called to service in many
column3: many ways. And we must give them and their families what the times demand and what they have earned.

column1: Just think about what our troops have done in the last year
column2: showing America at its best
column3: helping to save hundreds of thousands of people in Rwanda
column4: moving with lightning speed to head off another threat to Kuwait
column5: giving freedom and democracy back to the people of Haiti. We have proudly supported peace and prosperity and freedom from South Africa to Northern Ireland
column6: from Central and Eastern Europe to Asia
column7: from Latin America to the Middle East. All these endeavors are good in those places
column8: but they make our future more confident and more secure.

column1: Well
column2: my fellow Americans
column3: that's my agenda for America's future: expanding opportunity
column4: not bureaucracy; enhancing security at home and abroad; empowering our people to make the most of their own lives. It's ambitious and achievable
column5: but it's not enough. We even need more than new ideas for changing the world or equipping Americans to compete in the new economy
column6: more than a Government that's smaller
column7: smarter
column8: and wiser
column9: more than all of the changes we can make in Government and in the private sector from the outside in.

column1: Our fortunes and our posterity also depend upon our ability to answer some questions from within
column2: from the values and voices that speak to our hearts as well as our heads; voices that tell us we have to do more to accept responsibility for ourselves and our families
column3: for our communities
column4: and yes
column5: for our fellow citizens. We see our families and our communities all over this country coming apart
column6: and we feel the common ground shifting from under us. The PTA
column7: the town hall meeting
column8: the ball park
column9: it's hard for a lot of overworked parents to find the time and space for those things that strengthen the bonds of trust and cooperation. Too many of our children don't even have parents and grandparents who can give them those experiences that they need to build their own character and their sense of identity.

column1: We all know that while we here in this Chamber can make a difference on those things
column2: that the real differences will be made by our fellow citizens
column3: where they work and where they live and that it will be made almost without regard to party. When I used to go to the softball park in Little Rock to watch my daughter's league and people would come up to me
column4: fathers and mothers
column5: and talk to me
column6: I can honestly say I had no idea whether 90 percent of them were Republicans or Democrats. When I visited the relief centers after the floods in California
column7: northern California
column8: last week
column9: a woman came up to me and did something that very few of you would do. She hugged me and said
column10: "Mr. President
column11: I'm a Republican
column12: but I'm glad you're here."

column1: Now
column2: why? We can't wait for disasters to act the way we used to act every day
column3: because as we move into this next century
column4: everybody matters. We don't have a person to waste. And a lot of people are losing a lot of chances to do better. That means that we need a New Covenant for everybody.

column1: For our corporate and business leaders
column2: we're going to work here to keep bringing the deficit down
column3: to expand markets
column4: to support their success in every possible way. But they have an obligation when they're doing well to keep jobs in our communities and give their workers a fair share of the prosperity they generate.

column1: For people in the entertainment industry in this country
column2: we applaud your creativity and your worldwide success
column3: and we support your freedom of expression. But you do have a responsibility to assess the impact of your work and to understand the damage that comes from the incessant
column4: repetitive
column5: mindless violence and irresponsible conduct that permeates our media all the time.

column1: We've got to ask our community leaders and all kinds of organizations to help us stop our most serious social problem
column2: the epidemic of teen pregnancies and births where there is no marriage. I have sent to Congress a plan to target schools all over this country with antipregnancy programs that work. But Government can only do so much. Tonight I call on parents and leaders all across this country to join together in a national campaign against teen pregnancy to make a difference. We can do this
column3: and we must.

column1: And I would like to say a special word to our religious leaders. You know
column2: I'm proud of the fact the United States has more houses of worship per capita than any country in the world. These people who lead our houses of worship can ignite their congregations to carry their faith into action
column3: can reach out to all of our children
column4: to all of the people in distress
column5: to those who have been savaged by the breakdown of all we hold dear. Because so much of what must be done must come from the inside out and our religious leaders and their congregations can make all the difference
column6: they have a role in the New Covenant as well.

column1: There must be more responsibility for all of our citizens. You know
column2: it takes a lot of people to help all the kids in trouble stay off the streets and in school. It takes a lot of people to build the Habitat for Humanity houses that the Speaker celebrates on his lapel pin. It takes a lot of people to provide the people power for all of the civic organizations in this country that made our communities mean so much to most of us when we were kids. It takes every parent to teach the children the difference between right and wrong and to encourage them to learn and grow and to say no to the wrong things but also to believe that they can be whatever they want to be.

column1: I know it's hard when you're working harder for less
column2: when you're under great stress
column3: to do these things. A lot of our people don't have the time or the emotional stress
column4: they think
column5: to do the work of citizenship.

column1: Most of us in politics haven't helped very much. For years
column2: we've mostly treated citizens like they were consumers or spectators
column3: sort of political couch potatoes who were supposed to watch the TV ads either promise them something for nothing or play on their fears and frustrations. And more and more of our citizens now get most of their information in very negative and aggressive ways that are hardly conducive to honest and open conversations. But the truth is
column4: we have got to stop seeing each other as enemies just because we have different views.

column1: If you go back to the beginning of this country
column2: the great strength of America
column3: as de Tocqueville pointed out when he came here a long time ago
column4: has always been our ability to associate with people who were different from ourselves and to work together to find common ground. And in this day
column5: everybody has a responsibility to do more of that. We simply cannot want for a tornado
column6: a fire
column7: or a flood to behave like Americans ought to behave in dealing with one another.

column1: I want to finish up here by pointing out some folks that are up with the First Lady that represent what I'm trying to talk aboutcitizens. I have no idea what their party affiliation is or who they voted for in the last election. But they represent what we ought to be doing.

Cindy Perry teaches second graders to read in AmeriCorps in rural Kentucky. She gains when she gives. She's a mother of four. She says that her service inspired her to get her high school equivalency last year. She was married when she was a teenagerstand up
column2: Cindy. She was married when she was a teenager. She had four children. But she had time to serve other people
column3: to get her high school equivalency
column4: and she's going to use her AmeriCorps money to go back to college.

column1: Chief Stephen Bishop is the police chief of Kansas City. He's been a national leaderstand up
column2: Steve. He's been a national leader in using more police in community policing
column3: and he's worked with AmeriCorps to do it. And the crime rate in Kansas City has gone down as a result of what he did.

column1: Corporal Gregory Depestre went to Haiti as part of his adopted country's force to help secure democracy in his native land. And I might add
column2: we must be the only country in the world that could have gone to Haiti and taken Haitian-Americans there who could speak the language and talk to the people. And he was one of them
column3: and we're proud of him.

column1: The next two folks I've had the honor of meeting and getting to know a little bit
column2: the Reverend John and the Reverend Diana Cherry of the A.M.E. Zion Church in Temple Hills
column3: Maryland. I'd like to ask them to stand. I want to tell you about them. In the early eighties
column4: they left Government service and formed a church in a small living room in a small house
column5: in the early eighties. Today that church has 17
column6: 000 members. It is one of the three or four biggest churches in the entire United States. It grows by 200 a month. They do it together. And the special focus of their ministry is keeping families together.

column1: Two things they did make a big impression on me. I visited their church once
column2: and I learned they were building a new sanctuary closer to the Washington
column3: DC
column4: line in a higher crime
column5: higher drug rate area because they thought it was part of their ministry to change the lives of the people who needed them. The second thing I want to say is that once Reverend Cherry was at a meeting at the White House with some other religious leaders
column6: and he left early to go back to this church to minister to 150 couples that he had brought back to his church from all over America to convince them to come back together
column7: to save their marriages
column8: and to raise their kids. This is the kind of work that citizens are doing in America. We need more of it
column9: and it ought to be lifted up and supported.

column1: The last person I want to introduce is Jack Lucas from Hattiesburg
column2: Mississippi. Jack
column3: would you stand up? Fifty years ago
column4: in the sands of Iwo Jima
column5: Jack Lucas taught and learned the lessons of citizenship. On February 20th
column7: he and three of his buddies encountered the enemy and two grenades at their feet. Jack Lucas threw himself on both of them. In that moment
column8: he saved the lives of his companions
column9: and miraculously in the next instant
column10: a medic saved his life. He gained a foothold for freedom
column11: and at the age of 17
column12: just a year older than his grandson who is up there with him today and his son
column13: who is a West Point graduate and a veteranat 17
column14: Jack Lucas became the youngest Marine in history and the youngest soldier in this century to win the Congressional Medal of Honor. All these years later
column16: here's what he said about that day: "It didn't matter where you were from or who you were
column17: you relied on one another. You did it for your country."

column1: We all gain when we give
column2: and we reap what we sow. That's at the heart of this New Covenant. Responsibility
column3: opportunity
column4: and citizenship
column5: more than stale chapters in some remote civic book
column6: they're still the virtue by which we can fulfill ourselves and reach our God-given potential and be like them and also to fulfill the eternal promise of this country
column7: the enduring dream from that first and most sacred covenant. I believe every person in this country still believes that we are created equal and given by our Creator the right to life
column8: liberty and the pursuit of happiness. This is a very
column9: very great country. And our best days are still to come.

column1: Thank you
column2: and God bless you all.@

column1: William J. Clinton|Address Before a Joint Session of the Congress on the State of the Union|1996-01-23|@Thank you very much. Mr. Speaker
column2: Mr. Vice President
column3: Members of the 104th Congress
column4: distinguished guests
column5: my fellow Americans all across our land: Let me begin tonight by saying to our men and women in uniform around the world and especially those helping peace take root in Bosnia and to their families
column6: I thank you. America is very
column7: very proud of you.

column1: My duty tonight is to report on the state of the Union
column2: not the state of our Government but of our American community
column3: and to set forth our responsibilities
column4: in the words of our Founders
column5: to form a more perfect Union.

column1: The state of the Union is strong. Our economy is the healthiest it has been in three decades. We have the lowest combined rates of unemployment and inflation in 27 years. We have completedcreated nearly 8 million new jobs
column2: over a million of them in basic industries like construction and automobiles. America is selling more cars than Japan for the first time since the 1970's. And for 3 years in a row
column3: we have had a record number of new businesses started in our country.

column1: Our leadership in the world is also strong
column2: bringing hope for new peace. And perhaps most important
column3: we are gaining ground in restoring our fundamental values. The crime rate
column4: the welfare and food stamp rolls
column5: the poverty rate
column6: and the teen pregnancy rate are all down. And as they go down
column7: prospects for America's future go up.

column1: We live in an age of possibility. A hundred years ago we moved from farm to factory. Now we move to an age of technology
column2: information
column3: and global competition. These changes have opened vast new opportunities for our people
column4: but they have also presented them with stiff challenges. While more Americans are living better
column5: too many of our fellow citizens are working harder just to keep up
column6: and they are rightly concerned about the security of their families.

column1: We must answer here three fundamental questions: First
column2: how do we make the American dream of opportunity for all a reality for all Americans who are willing to work for it? Second
column3: how do we preserve our old and enduring values as we move into the future? And third
column4: how do we meet these challenges together
column5: as one America?

column1: We know big Government does not have all the answers. We know there's not a program for every problem. We know
column2: and we have worked to give the American people a smaller
column3: less bureaucratic Government in Washington. And we have to give the American people one that lives within its means. The era of big Government is over. But we cannot go back to the time when our citizens were left to fend for themselves.

column1: Instead
column2: we must go forward as one America
column3: one nation working together to meet the challenges we face together. Self-reliance and teamwork are not opposing virtues; we must have both. I believe our new
column4: smaller Government must work in an old-fashioned American way
column5: together with all of our citizens through State and local governments
column6: in the workplace
column7: in religious
column8: charitable
column9: and civic associations. Our goal must be to enable all our people to make the most of their own lives
column10: with stronger families
column11: more educational opportunity
column12: economic security
column13: safer streets
column14: a cleaner environment in a safer world.

column1: To improve the state of our Union
column2: we must ask more of ourselves
column3: we must expect more of each other
column4: and we must face our challenges together.

column1: Here
column2: in this place
column3: our responsibility begins with balancing the budget in a way that is fair to all Americans. There is now broad bipartisan agreement that permanent deficit spending must come to an end. I compliment the Republican leadership and the membership for the energy and determination you have brought to this task of balancing the budget. And I thank the Democrats for passing the largest deficit reduction plan in history in 1993
column4: which has already cut the deficit nearly in half in 3 years.

column1: Since 1993
column2: we have all begun to see the benefits of deficit reduction. Lower interest rates have made it easier for businesses to borrow and to invest and to create new jobs. Lower interest rates have brought down the cost of home mortgages
column3: car payments
column4: and credit card rates to ordinary citizens. Now it is time to finish the job and balance the budget.

column1: Though differences remain among us which are significant
column2: the combined total of the proposed savings that are common to both plans is more than enough
column3: using the numbers from your Congressional Budget Office
column4: to balance the budget in 7 years and to provide a modest tax cut.

column1: These cuts are real. They will require sacrifice from everyone. But these cuts do not undermine our fundamental obligations to our parents
column2: our children
column3: and our future by endangering Medicare or Medicaid or education or the environment or by raising taxes on working families.

column1: I have said before
column2: and let me say again
column3: many good ideas have come out of our negotiations. I have learned a lot about the way both Republicans and Democrats view the debate before us. I have learned a lot about the good ideas that each side has that we could all embrace.

column1: We ought to resolve our remaining differences. I am willing to work to resolve them. I am ready to meet tomorrow. But I ask you to consider that we should at least enact these savings that both plans have in common and give the American people their balanced budget
column2: a tax cut
column3: lower interest rates
column4: and a brighter future. We should do that now and make permanent deficits yesterday's legacy.

column1: Now it is time for us to look also to the challenges of today and tomorrow
column2: beyond the burdens of yesterday. The challenges are significant. But our Nation was built on challenges. America was built on challenges
column3: not promises. And when we work together to meet them
column4: we never fail. That is the key to a more perfect Union. Our individual dreams must be realized by our common efforts.

column1: Tonight I want to speak to you about the challenges we all face as a people. Our first challenge is to cherish our children and strengthen America's families. Family is the foundation of American life. If we have stronger families
column2: we will have a stronger America.

column1: Before I go on
column2: I'd like to take just a moment to thank my own family and to thank the person who has taught me more than anyone else over 25 years about the importance of families and children
column3: a wonderful wife
column4: a magnificent mother
column5: and a great First Lady. Thank you
column6: Hillary.

column1: All strong families begin with taking more responsibility for our children. I've heard Mrs. Gore say that it's hard to be a parent today
column2: but it's even harder to be a child. So all of us
column3: not just as parents but all of us in our other rolesour media
column4: our schools
column5: our teachers
column6: our communities
column7: our churches and synagogues
column8: our businesses
column9: our governmentsall of us have a responsibility to help our children to make it and to make the most of their lives and their God-given capacities.

column1: To the media
column2: I say you should create movies and CD's and television shows you'd want your own children and grandchildren to enjoy.

column1: I call on Congress to pass the requirement for a V-chip in TV sets so that parents can screen out programs they believe are inappropriate for their children. When parents control what their young children see
column2: that is not censorship; that is enabling parents to assume more personal responsibility for their children's upbringing. And I urge them to do it. The Vchip requirement is part of the important telecommunications bill now pending in this Congress. It has bipartisan support
column3: and I urge you to pass it now.

column1: To make the V-chip work
column2: I challenge the broadcast industry to do what movies have done
column3: to identify your program in ways that help parents to protect their children. And I invite the leaders of major media corporations in the entertainment industry to come to the White House next month to work with us in a positive way on concrete ways to improve what our children see on television. I am ready to work with you.

column1: I say to those who make and market cigarettes
column2: every year a million children take up smoking
column3: even though it's against the law. Three hundred thousand of them will have their lives shortened as a result. Our administration has taken steps to stop the massive marketing campaigns that appeal to our children. We are simply saying: Market your products to adults
column4: if you wish
column5: but draw the line on children.

column1: I say to those who are on welfare
column2: and especially to those who have been trapped on welfare for a long time: For too long our welfare system has undermined the values of family and work instead of supporting them. The Congress and I are near agreement on sweeping welfare reform. We agree on time limits
column3: tough work requirements
column4: and the toughest possible child support enforcement. But I believe we must also provide child care so that mothers who are required to go to work can do so without worrying about what is happening to their children.

column1: I challenge this Congress to send me a bipartisan welfare reform bill that will really move people from welfare to work and do the right thing by our children. I will sign it immediately.
Let us be candid about this difficult problem. Passing a law
column2: even the best possible law
column3: is only a first step. The next step is to make it work. I challenge people on welfare to make the most of this opportunity for independence. I challenge American businesses to give people on welfare the chance to move into the work force. I applaud the work of religious groups and others who care for the poor. More than anyone else in our society
column4: they know the true difficulty of the task before us
column5: and they are in a position to help. Every one of us should join them. That is the only way we can make real welfare reform a reality in the lives of the American people.

column1: To strengthen the family we must do everything we can to keep the teen pregnancy rate going down. I am gratified
column2: as I'm sure all Americans are
column3: that it has dropped for 2 years in a row. But we all know it is still far too high. Tonight I am pleased to announce that a group of prominent Americans is responding to that challenge by forming an organization that will support grassroots community efforts all across our country in a national campaign against teen pregnancy. And I challenge all of us and every American to join their efforts.

column1: I call on American men and women in families to give greater respect to one another. We must end the deadly scourge of domestic violence in our country. And I challenge America's families to work harder to stay together. For families who stay together not only do better economically
column2: their children do better as well.

column1: In particular
column2: I challenge the fathers of this country to love and care for their children. If your family has separated
column3: you must pay your child support. We're doing more than ever to make sure you do
column4: and we're going to do more. But let's all admit something about that
column5: too: A check will never substitute for a parent's love and guidance. And only youonly you can make the decision to help raise your children. No matter who you are
column6: how low or high your station in life
column7: it is the most basic human duty of every American to do that job to the best of his or her ability.

column1: Our second challenge is to provide Americans with the educational opportunities we'll all need for this new century. In our schools
column2: every classroom in America must be connected to the information superhighway
column3: with computers and good software and well-trained teachers. We are working with the telecommunications industry
column4: educators
column5: and parents to connect 20 percent of California's classrooms by this spring
column6: and every classroom and every library in the entire United States by the year 2000. I ask Congress to support this education technology initiative so that we can make sure this national partnership succeeds.

column1: Every diploma ought to mean something. I challenge every community
column2: every school
column3: and every State to adopt national standards of excellence
column4: to measure whether schools are meeting those standards
column5: to cut bureaucratic redtape so that schools and teachers have more flexibility for grassroots reform
column6: and to hold them accountable for results. That's what our Goals 2000 initiative is all about. I challenge every State to give all parents the right to choose which public school their children will attend and to let teachers form new schools with a charter they can keep only if they do a good job.

column1: I challenge all our schools to teach character education
column2: to teach good values and good citizenship. And if it means that teenagers will stop killing each other over designer jackets
column3: then our public schools should be able to require their students to wear school uniforms.

column1: I challenge our parents to become their children's first teachers. Turn off the TV. See that the homework is done. And visit your children's classroom. No program
column2: no teacher
column3: no one else can do that for you.

column1: My fellow Americans
column2: higher education is more important today than ever before. We've created a new student loan program that's made it easier to borrow and repay those loans
column3: and we have dramatically cut the student loan default rate. That's something we should all be proud of because it was unconscionably high just a few years ago.

column1: Through AmeriCorps
column2: our national service program
column3: this year 25
column4: 000 young people will earn college money by serving their local communities to improve the lives of their friends and neighbors.

column1: These initiatives are right for America
column2: and we should keep them going. And we should also work hard to open the doors of college even wider. I challenge Congress to expand work-study and help one million young Americans work their way through college by the year 2000
column3: to provide a $1
column4: 000 merit scholarship for the top 5 percent of graduates in every high school in the United States
column5: to expand Pell grant scholarships for deserving and needy students
column6: and to make up to $10
column7: 000 a year of college tuition tax deductible. It's a good idea for America.

column1: Our third challenge is to help every American who is willing to work for it achieve economic security in this new age. People who work hard still need support to get ahead in the new economy. They need education and training for a lifetime. They need more support for families raising children. They need retirement security. They need access to health care. More and more Americans are finding that the education of their childhood simply doesn't last a lifetime.
So I challenge Congress to consolidate 70 overlapping
column2: antiquated job training programs into a simple voucher worth $2
column3: 600 for unemployed or underemployed workers to use as they please for community college tuition or other training. This is a "GI bill" for America's workers we should all be able to agree on.

column1: More and more Americans are working hard without a raise. Congress sets the minimum wage. Within a year
column2: the minimum wage will fall to a 40-year low in purchasing power. Four dollars and 25 cents an hour is no longer a minimum wage
column3: but millions of Americans and their children are trying to live on it. I challenge you to raise their minimum wage.

column2: Congress cut the taxes of 15 million hard-pressed working families to make sure that no parents who work full time would have to raise their children in poverty and to encourage people to move from welfare to work. This expanded earned-income tax credit is now worth about $1
column3: 800 a year to a family of four living on $20
column4: 000. The budget bill I vetoed would have reversed this achievement and raised taxes on nearly 8 million of these people. We should not do that. We should not do that.

column1: But I also agree that the people who are helped under this initiative are not all those in our country who are working hard to do a good job raising their children and at work. I agree that we need a tax credit for working families with children. That's one of the things most of us in this Chamber
column2: I hope
column3: can agree on. I know it is strongly supported by the Republican majority. And it should be part of any final budget agreement.

column1: I want to challenge every business that can possibly afford it to provide pensions for your employees. And I challenge Congress to pass a proposal recommended by the White House Conference on Small Business that would make it easier for small businesses and farmers to establish their own pension plans. That is something we should all agree on.
We should also protect existing pension plans. Two years ago
column2: with bipartisan support that was almost unanimous on both sides of the aisle
column3: we moved to protect the pensions of 8 million working people and to stabilize the pensions of 32 million more. Congress should not now let companies endanger those workers' pension funds. I know the proposal to liberalize the ability of employers to take money out of pension funds for other purposes would raise money for the Treasury
column4: but I believe it is false economy. I vetoed that proposal last year
column5: and I would have to do so again.

column1: Finally
column2: if our working families are going to succeed in the new economy
column3: they must be able to buy health insurance policies that they do not lose when they change jobs or when someone in their family gets sick. Over the past 2 years
column4: over one million Americans in working families have lost their health insurance. We have to do more to make health care available to every American. And Congress should start by passing the bipartisan bill sponsored by Senator Kennedy and Senator Kassebaum that would require insurance companies to stop dropping people when they switch jobs and stop denying coverage for preexisting conditions. Let's all do that.

column1: And even as we enact savings in these programs
column2: we must have a common commitment to preserve the basic protections of Medicare and Medicaid
column3: not just to the poor but to people in working families
column4: including children
column5: people with disabilities
column6: people with AIDS
column7: senior citizens in nursing homes. In the past 3 years
column8: we've saved $15 billion just by fighting health care fraud and abuse. We have all agreed to save much more. We have all agreed to stabilize the Medicare Trust Fund. But we must not abandon our fundamental obligations to the people who need Medicare and Medicaid. America cannot become stronger if they become weaker.

column1: The "GI bill" for workers
column2: tax relief for education and childrearing
column3: pension availability and protection
column4: access to health care
column5: preservation of Medicare and Medicaid
column6: these things
column7: along with the Family and Medical Leave Act passed in 1993
column8: these things will help responsible
column9: hardworking American families to make the most of their own lives.

column1: But employers and employees must do their part as well
column2: as they are doing in so many of our finest companies
column3: working together
column4: putting the long-term prosperity ahead of the short-term gain. As workers increase their hours and their productivity
column5: employers should make sure they get the skills they need and share the benefits of the good years as well as the burdens of the bad ones. When companies and workers work as a team they do better
column6: and so does America.

column1: Our fourth great challenge is to take our streets back from crime and gangs and drugs. At last we have begun to find a way to reduce crime
column2: forming community partnerships with local police forces to catch criminals and prevent crime. This strategy
column3: called community policing
column4: is clearly working. Violent crime is coming down all across America. In New York City
column5: murders are down 25 percent; in St. Louis
column6: 18 percent; in Seattle
column7: 32 percent. But we still have a long way to go before our streets are safe and our people are free from fear.

column1: The crime bill of 1994 is critical to the success of community policing. It provides funds for 100
column2: 000 new police in communities of all sizes. We're already a third of the way there. And I challenge the Congress to finish the job. Let us stick with a strategy that's working and keep the crime rate coming down.

column1: Community policing also requires bonds of trust between citizens and police. I ask all Americans to respect and support our law enforcement officers. And to our police
column2: I say
column3: our children need you as role models and heroes. Don't let them down.

column1: The Brady bill has already stopped 44
column2: 000 people with criminal records from buying guns. The assault weapons ban is keeping 19 kinds of assault weapons out of the hands of violent gangs. I challenge the Congress to keep those laws on the books.

column1: Our next step in the fight against crime is to take on gangs the way we once took on the mob. I'm directing the FBI and other investigative agencies to target gangs that involve juveniles in violent crime
column2: and to seek authority to prosecute as adults teenagers who maim and kill like adults.

column1: And I challenge local housing authorities and tenant associations: Criminal gang members and drug dealers are destroying the lives of decent tenants. From now on
column2: the rule for residents who commit crime and peddle drugs should be "one strike and you're out."

column1: I challenge every State to match Federal policy to assure that serious violent criminals serve at least 85 percent of their sentence.
More police and punishment are important
column2: but they're not enough. We have got to keep more of our young people out of trouble
column3: with prevention strategies not dictated by Washington but developed in communities. I challenge all of our communities
column4: all of our adults
column5: to give our children futures to say yes to. And I challenge Congress not to abandon the crime bill's support of these grassroots prevention efforts.

column1: Finally
column2: to reduce crime and violence we have to reduce the drug problem. The challenge begins in our homes
column3: with parents talking to their children openly and firmly. It embraces our churches and synagogues
column4: our youth groups and our schools. I challenge Congress not to cut our support for drug-free schools. People like the D.A.R.E. officers are making a real impression on grade-school children that will give them the strength to say no when the time comes.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: we continue our efforts to cut the flow of drugs into America. For the last 2 years
column3: one man in particular has been on the front lines of that effort. Tonight I am nominating him
column4: a hero of the Persian Gulf war and the commander in chief of the United States Military Southern Command
column5: General Barry McCaffrey
column6: as America's new drug czar. General McCaffrey has earned three Purple Hearts and two Silver Stars fighting for this country. Tonight I ask that he lead our Nation's battle against drugs at home and abroad. To succeed
column7: he needs a force far larger than he has ever commanded before. He needs all of us. Every one of us has a role to play on this team.

column1: Thank you
column2: General McCaffrey
column3: for agreeing to serve your country one more time.

column1: Our fifth challenge: to leave our environment safe and clean for the next generation. Because of a generation of bipartisan effort we do have cleaner water and air
column2: lead levels in children's blood has been cut by 70 percent
column3: toxic emissions from factories cut in half. Lake Erie was dead
column4: and now it's a thriving resource. But 10 million children under 12 still live within 4 miles of a toxic waste dump. A third of us breathe air that endangers our health. And in too many communities the water is not safe to drink. We still have much to do.

column1: Yet Congress has voted to cut environmental enforcement by 25 percent. That means more toxic chemicals in our water
column2: more smog in our air
column3: more pesticides in our food. Lobbyists for polluters have been allowed to write their own loopholes into bills to weaken laws that protect the health and safety of our children. Some say that the taxpayer should pick up the tab for toxic waste and let polluters who can afford to fix it off the hook. I challenge Congress to reexamine those policies and to reverse them.

column1: This issue has not been a partisan issue. The most significant environmental gains in the last 30 years were made under a Democratic Congress and President Richard Nixon. We can work together. We have to believe some basic things. Do you believe we can expand the economy without hurting the environment? I do. Do you believe we can create more jobs over the long run by cleaning the environment up? I know we can. That should be our commitment.
We must challenge businesses and communities to take more initiative in protecting the environment
column2: and we have to make it easier for them to do it. To businesses this administration is saying
column3: if you can find a cheaper
column4: more efficient way than Government regulations require to meet tough pollution standards
column5: do it
column6: as long as you do it right. To communities we say
column7: we must strengthen community right-toknow laws requiring polluters to disclose their emissions
column8: but you have to use the information to work with business to cut pollution. People do have a right to know that their air and their water are safe.

column1: Our sixth challenge is to maintain America's leadership in the fight for freedom and peace throughout the world. Because of American leadership
column2: more people than ever before live free and at peace. And Americans have known 50 years of prosperity and security.

column1: We owe thanks especially to our veterans of World War II. I would like to say to Senator Bob Dole and to all others in this Chamber who fought in World War II
column2: and to all others on both sides of the aisle who have fought bravely in all our conflicts since: I salute your service
column3: and so do the American people.

column1: All over the world
column2: even after the cold war
column3: people still look to us and trust us to help them seek the blessings of peace and freedom. But as the cold war fades into memory
column4: voices of isolation say America should retreat from its responsibilities. I say they are wrong.

column1: The threats we face today as Americans respect no nation's borders. Think of them: terrorism
column2: the spread of weapons of mass destruction
column3: organized crime
column4: drug trafficking
column5: ethnic and religious hatred
column6: aggression by rogue states
column7: environmental degradation. If we fail to address these threats today
column8: we will suffer the consequences in all our tomorrows.

column1: Of course
column2: we can't be everywhere. Of course
column3: we can't do everything. But where our interests and our values are at stake
column4: and where we can make a difference
column5: America must lead. We must not be isolationist. We must not be the world's policeman. But we can and should be the world's very best peacemaker.

column1: By keeping our military strong
column2: by using diplomacy where we can and force where we must
column3: by working with others to share the risk and the cost of our efforts
column4: America is making a difference for people here and around the world. For the first time since the dawn of the nuclear agefor the first time since the dawn of the nuclear agethere is not a single Russian missile pointed at America's children.

column1: North Korea has now frozen its dangerous nuclear weapons program. In Haiti
column2: the dictators are gone
column3: democracy has a new day
column4: the flow of desperate refugees to our shores has subsided. Through tougher trade deals for America
column5: over 80 of them
column6: we have opened markets abroad
column7: and now exports are at an all-time high
column8: growing faster than imports and creating good American jobs.

column1: We stood with those taking risks for peace: in Northern Ireland
column2: where Catholic and Protestant children now tell their parents violence must never return; in the Middle East
column3: where Arabs and Jews who once seemed destined to fight forever now share knowledge and resources and even dreams.

column1: And we stood up for peace in Bosnia. Remember the skeletal prisoners
column2: the mass graves
column3: the campaign to rape and torture
column4: the endless lines of refugees
column5: the threat of a spreading war. All these threats
column6: all these horrors have now begun to give way to the promise of peace. Now our troops and a strong NATO
column7: together with our new partners from central Europe and elsewhere
column8: are helping that peace to take hold.

column1: As all of you know
column2: I was just there with a bipartisan congressional group
column3: and I was so proud not only of what our troops were doing but of the pride they evidenced in what they were doing. They knew what America's mission in this world is
column4: and they were proud to be carrying it out.

column1: Through these efforts
column2: we have enhanced the security of the American people
column3: but make no mistake about it: Important challenges remain.

column1: The START II treaty with Russia will cut our nuclear stockpiles by another 25 percent. I urge the Senate to ratify it now. We must end the race to create new nuclear weapons by signing a truly comprehensive nuclear test ban treaty this year.
As we remember what happened in the Japanese subway
column2: we can outlaw poison gas forever if the Senate ratifies the Chemical Weapons Convention this year. We can intensify the fight against terrorists and organized criminals at home and abroad if Congress passes the antiterrorism legislation I proposed after the Oklahoma City bombing
column3: now. We can help more people move from hatred to hope all across the world in our own interest if Congress gives us the means to remain the world's leader for peace.

column1: My fellow Americans
column2: the six challenges I have just discussed are for all of us. Our seventh challenge is really America's challenge to those of us in this hallowed Hall tonight: to reinvent our Government and make our democracy work for them.

column1: Last year this Congress applied to itself the laws it applies to everyone else. This Congress banned gifts and meals from lobbyists. This Congress forced lobbyists to disclose who pays them and what legislation they are trying to pass or kill. This Congress did that
column2: and I applaud you for it.

column1: Now I challenge Congress to go further
column2: to curb special interest influence in politics by passing the first truly bipartisan campaign finance reform bill in a generation. You
column3: Republicans and Democrats alike
column4: can show the American people that we can limit spending and we can open the airwaves to all candidates.

column1: I also appeal to Congress to pass the line item veto you promised the American people.
Our administration is working hard to give the American people a Government that works better and costs less. Thanks to the work of Vice President Gore
column2: we are eliminating 16
column3: 000 pages of unnecessary rules and regulations
column4: shifting more decisionmaking out of Washington
column5: back to States and local communities.

column1: As we move into the era of balanced budgets and smaller Government
column2: we must work in new ways to enable people to make the most of their own lives. We are helping America's communities
column3: not with more bureaucracy but with more opportunities. Through our successful empowerment zones and community development banks
column4: we're helping people to find jobs
column5: to start businesses. And with tax incentives for companies that clean up abandoned industrial property
column6: we can bring jobs back to places that desperately
column7: desperately need them.

column1: But there are some areas that the Federal Government should not leave and should address and address strongly. One of these areas is the problem of illegal immigration. After years of neglect
column2: this administration has taken a strong stand to stiffen the protection of our borders. We are increasing border controls by 50 percent. We are increasing inspections to prevent the hiring of illegal immigrants. And tonight I announce I will sign an Executive order to deny Federal contracts to businesses that hire illegal immigrants.

column1: Let me be very clear about this: We are still a nation of immigrants; we should be proud of it. We should honor every legal immigrant here
column2: working hard to be a good citizen
column3: working hard to become a new citizen. But we are also a nation of laws.

column1: I want to say a special word now to those who work for our Federal Government. Today the Federal work force is 200
column2: 000 employees smaller than it was the day I took office as President. Our Federal Government today is the smallest it has been in 30 years
column3: and it's getting smaller every day. Most of our fellow Americans probably don't know that. And there's a good reasona good reason: The remaining Federal work force is composed of hard-working Americans who are now working harder and working smarter than ever before to make sure the quality of our services does not decline.

column1: I'd like to give you one example. His name is Richard Dean. He's a 49-year-old Vietnam veteran who's worked for the Social Security Administration for 22 years now. Last year he was hard at work in the Federal Building in Oklahoma City when the blast killed 169 people and brought the rubble down all around him. He reentered that building four times. He saved the lives of three women. He's here with us this evening
column2: and I want to recognize Richard and applaud both his public service and his extraordinary personal heroism. But Richard Dean's story doesn't end there. This last November
column3: he was forced out of his office when the Government shut down. And the second time the Government shut down he continued helping Social Security recipients
column4: but he was working without pay.

column1: On behalf of Richard Dean and his family
column2: and all the other people who are out there working every day doing a good job for the American people
column3: I challenge all of you in this Chamber: Let's never
column4: ever shut the Federal Government down again.

column1: On behalf of all Americans
column2: especially those who need their Social Security payments at the beginning of March
column3: I also challenge the Congress to preserve the full faith and credit of the United States
column4: to honor the obligations of this great Nation as we have for 220 years
column5: to rise above partisanship and pass a straightforward extension of the debt limit and show people America keeps its word.

column1: I know that this evening I have asked a lot of Congress and even more from America. But I am confident: When Americans work together in their homes
column2: their schools
column3: their churches
column4: their synagogues
column5: their civic groups
column6: their workplace
column7: they can meet any challenge.

column1: I say again
column2: the era of big Government is over. But we can't go back to the era of fending for yourself. We have to go forward to the era of working together as a community
column3: as a team
column4: as one America
column5: with all of us reaching across these lines that divide usthe division
column6: the discrimination
column7: the rancorwe have to reach across it to find common ground. We have got to work together if we want America to work.

column1: I want you to meet two more people tonight who do just that. Lucius Wright is a teacher in the Jackson
column2: Mississippi
column3: public school system. A Vietnam veteran
column4: he has created groups to help inner-city children turn away from gangs and build futures they can believe in. Sergeant Jennifer Rodgers is a police officer in Oklahoma City. Like Richard Dean
column5: she helped to pull her fellow citizens out of the rubble and deal with that awful tragedy. She reminds us that in their response to that atrocity the people of Oklahoma City lifted all of us with their basic sense of decency and community.

column1: Lucius Wright and Jennifer Rodgers are special Americans. And I have the honor to announce tonight that they are the very first of several thousand Americans who will be chosen to carry the Olympic torch on its long journey from Los Angeles to the centennial of the modern Olympics in Atlanta this summer
column2: not because they are star athletes but because they are star citizens
column3: community heroes meeting America's challenges. They are our real champions. Please stand up.

column1: Now each of us must hold high the torch of citizenship in our own lives. None of us can finish the race alone. We can only achieve our destiny together
column2: one hand
column3: one generation
column4: one American connecting to another.

column1: There have always been things we could do together
column2: dreams we could make real which we could never have done on our own. We Americans have forged our identity
column3: our very Union
column4: from the very point of view that we can accommodate every point on the planet
column5: every different opinion. But we must be bound together by a faith more powerful than any doctrine that divides us
column6: by our belief in progress
column7: our love of liberty
column8: and our relentless search for common ground.

column1: America has always sought and always risen to every challenge. Who would say that having come so far together
column2: we will not go forward from here? Who would say that this age of possibility is not for all Americans?

column1: Our country is and always has been a great and good nation. But the best is yet to come if we all do our parts.
Thank you. God bless you
column2: and God bless the United States of America. Thank you.@

column1: William J. Clinton|Address Before a Joint Session of the Congress on the State of the Union|1997-02-04|@Mr. Speaker
column2: Mr. Vice President
column3: Members of the 105th Congress
column4: distinguished guests
column5: and my fellow Americans: I think I should start by saying thanks for inviting me back. I come before you tonight with a challenge as great as any in our peacetime history and a plan of action to meet that challenge
column6: to prepare our people for the bold new world of the 21st century.

column1: We have much to be thankful for. With 4 years of growth
column2: we have won back the basic strength of our economy. With crime and welfare rolls declining
column3: we are winning back our optimism
column4: the enduring faith that we can master any difficulty. With the cold war receding and global commerce at record levels
column5: we are helping to win an unrivaled peace and prosperity all across the world.

column1: My fellow Americans
column2: the state of our Union is strong. But now we must rise to the decisive moment
column3: to make a nation and a world better than any we have ever known. The new promise of the global economy
column4: the information age
column5: unimagined new work
column6: life-enhancing technology
column7: all these are ours to seize. That is our honor and our challenge. We must be shapers of events
column8: not observers
column9: for if we do not act
column10: the moment will pass
column11: and we will lose the best possibilities of our future.

column1: We face no imminent threat
column2: but we do have an enemy. The enemy of our time is inaction. So tonight I issue a call to action: action by this Congress
column3: action by our States
column4: by our people
column5: to prepare America for the 21st century; action to keep our economy and our democracy strong and working for all our people; action to strengthen education and harness the forces of technology and science; action to build stronger families and stronger communities and a safer environment; action to keep America the world's strongest force for peace
column6: freedom
column7: and prosperity; and above all
column8: action to build a more perfect Union here at home.

column1: The spirit we bring to our work will make all the difference. We must be committed to the pursuit of opportunity for all Americans
column2: responsibility from all Americans
column3: in a community of all Americans. And we must be committed to a new kind of Government
column4: not to solve all our problems for us but to give our people
column5: all our people
column6: the tools they need to make the most of their own lives.

column1: And we must work together. The people of this Nation elected us all. They want us to be partners
column2: not partisans. They put us all right here in the same boat
column3: they gave us all oars
column4: and they told us to row. Now
column5: here is the direction I believe we should take.

column1: First
column2: we must move quickly to complete the unfinished business of our country
column3: to balance the budget
column4: renew our democracy
column5: and finish the job of welfare reform.

column1: Over the last 4 years
column2: we have brought new economic growth by investing in our people
column3: expanding our exports
column4: cutting our deficits
column5: creating over 11 million new jobs
column6: a 4-year record. Now we must keep our economy the strongest in the world. We here tonight have an historic opportunity. Let this Congress be the Congress that finally balances the budget.  Thank you.

column1: In 2 days I will propose a detailed plan to balance the budget by 2002. This plan will balance the budget and invest in our people while protecting Medicare
column2: Medicaid
column3: education
column4: and the environment. It will balance the budget and build on the Vice President's efforts to make our Government work better
column5: even as it costs less. It will balance the budget and provide middle class tax relief to pay for education and health care
column6: to help to raise a child
column7: to buy and sell a home.

column1: Balancing the budget requires only your vote and my signature. It does not require us to rewrite our Constitution. I believe it is both unnecessary and unwise to adopt a balanced budget amendment that could cripple our country in time of economic crisis and force unwanted results
column2: such as judges halting Social Security checks or increasing taxes. Let us at least agree
column3: we should not pass any measureno measure should be passed that threatens Social Security. Whatever your view on that
column4: we all must concede: We don't need a constitutional amendment; we need action.

column1: Whatever our differences
column2: we should balance the budget now. And then
column3: for the long-term health of our society
column4: we must agree to a bipartisan process to preserve Social Security and reform Medicare for the long run
column5: so that these fundamental programs will be as strong for our children as they are for our parents.

column1: And let me say something that's not in my script tonight. I know this is not going to be easy. But I really believe one of the reasons the American people gave me a second term was to take the tough decisions in the next 4 years that will carry our country through the next 50 years. I know it is easier for me than for you to say or do. But another reason I was elected is to support all of you
column2: without regard to party
column3: to give you what is necessary to join in these decisions. We owe it to our country and to our future.

column1: Our second piece of unfinished business requires us to commit ourselves tonight
column2: before the eyes of America
column3: to finally enacting bipartisan campaign finance reform. Now
column4: Senators McCain and Feingold
column5: Representatives Shays and Meehan have reached across party lines here to craft tough and fair reform. Their proposal would curb spending
column6: reduce the role of special interests
column7: create a level playing field between challengers and incumbents
column8: and ban contributions from noncitizens
column9: all corporate sources
column10: and the other large soft money contributions that both parties receive.

column1: You know and I know that this can be delayed. And you know and I know the delay will mean the death of reform. So let's set our own deadline. Let's work together to write bipartisan campaign finance reform into law and pass McCain-Feingold by the day we celebrate the birth of our democracy
column2: July the fourth.

column1: There is a third piece of unfinished business. Over the last 4 years
column2: we moved a record 2 1/4 million people off the welfare rolls. Then last year
column3: Congress enacted landmark welfare reform legislation
column4: demanding that all able-bodied recipients assume the responsibility of moving from welfare to work. Now each and every one of us has to fulfill our responsibility
column5: indeed
column6: our moral obligation
column7: to make sure that people who now must work
column8: can work.

column1: Now we must act to meet a new goal: 2 million more people off the welfare rolls by the year 2000. Here is my plan: Tax credits and other incentives for businesses that hire people off welfare; incentives for job placement firms and States to create more jobs for welfare recipients; training
column2: transportation
column3: and child care to help people go to work.

column1: Now I challenge every State: Turn those welfare checks into private sector paychecks. I challenge every religious congregation
column2: every community nonprofit
column3: every business to hire someone off welfare. And I'd like to say especially to every employer in our country who ever criticized the old welfare system
column4: you can't blame that old system anymore. We have torn it down. Now do your part. Give someone on welfare the chance to go to work.

column1: Tonight I am pleased to announce that five major corporations
column2: Sprint
column3: Monsanto
column4: UPS
column5: Burger King
column6: and United Airlines
column7: will be the first to join in a new national effort to marshal America's businesses
column8: large and small
column9: to create jobs so that people can move from welfare to work.

column1: We passed welfare reform. All of you know I believe we were right to do it. But no one can walk out of this Chamber with a clear conscience unless you are prepared to finish the job.
And we must join together to do something else
column2: too
column3: something both Republican and Democratic Governors have asked us to do
column4: to restore basic health and disability benefits when misfortune strikes immigrants who came to this country legally
column5: who work hard
column6: pay taxes
column7: and obey the law. To do otherwise is simply unworthy of a great nation of immigrants.

column1: Now
column2: looking ahead
column3: the greatest step of all
column4: the high threshold of the future we must now cross
column5: and my number one priority for the next 4 years is to ensure that all Americans have the best education in the world.

column1: Let's work together to meet these three goals: Every 8-year-old must be able to read; every 12-year-old must be able to log on to the Internet; every 18-year-old must be able to go to college; and every adult American must be able to keep on learning for a lifetime.
My balanced budget makes an unprecedented commitment to these goals
column2: $51 billion next year. But far more than money is required. I have a plan
column3: a call to action for American education
column4: based on these 10 principles:

column1: First
column2: a national crusade for education standards
column3: not Federal Government standards but national standards
column4: representing what all our students must know to succeed in the knowledge economy of the 21st century. Every State and school must shape the curriculum to reflect these standards and train teachers to lift students up to them. To help schools meet the standards and measure their progress
column5: we will lead an effort over the next 2 years to develop national tests of student achievement in reading and math. Tonight I issue a challenge to the Nation: Every State should adopt high national standards
column6: and by 1999
column7: every State should test every fourth grader in reading and every eighth grader in math to make sure these standards are met.

column1: Raising standards will not be easy
column2: and some of our children will not be able to meet them at first. The point is not to put our children down but to lift them up. Good tests will show us who needs help
column3: what changes in teaching to make
column4: and which schools need to improve. They can help us end social promotions
column5: for no child should move from grade school to junior high or junior high to high school until he or she is ready.

column1: Last month our Secretary of Education
column2: Dick Riley
column3: and I visited northern Illinois
column4: where eighth-grade students from 20 school districts
column5: in a project aptly called First in the World
column6: took the Third International Math and Science Study. That's a test that reflects the world-class standards our children must meet for the new era. And those students in Illinois tied for first in the world in science and came in second in math. Two of them
column7: Kristen Tanner and Chris Getsler
column8: are here tonight
column9: along with their teacher
column10: Sue Winski. They're up there with the First Lady. And they prove that when we aim high and challenge our students
column11: they will be the best in the world. Let's give them a hand. Stand up
column12: please.

column1: Second
column2: to have the best schools
column3: we must have the best teachers. Most of us in this Chamber would not be here tonight without the help of those teachers; I know that I wouldn't be here. For years
column4: many of our educators
column5: led by North Carolina's Governor Jim Hunt and the National Board for Professional Teaching Standards
column6: have worked very hard to establish nationally accepted credentials for excellence in teaching. Just 500 of these teachers have been certified since 1995. My budget will enable 100
column7: 000 more to seek national certification as master teachers. We should reward and recognize our best teachers
column8: and as we reward them
column9: we should quickly and fairly remove those few who don't measure up. And we should challenge more of our finest young people to consider teaching as a career.

column1: Third
