column2: we must do more to help all our children read. Forty percent40 percentof our 8-year-olds cannot read on their own. That's why we have just launched the America Reads initiative
column3: to build a citizen army of one million volunteer tutors to make sure every child can read independently by the end of the third grade. We will use thousands of AmeriCorps volunteers to mobilize this citizen army. We want at least 100
column4: 000 college students to help
column5: and tonight I am pleased that 60 college presidents have answered my call
column6: pledging that thousands of their work-study students will serve for one year as reading tutors. This is also a challenge to every teacher and every principal: You must use these tutors to help students read. And it is especially a challenge to our parents: You must read with your children every night.

column1: This leads to the fourth principle: Learning begins in the first days of life. Scientists are now discovering how young children develop emotionally and intellectually from their very first days and how important it is for parents to begin immediately talking
column2: singing
column3: even reading to their infants. The First Lady has spent years writing about this issue
column4: studying it. And she and I are going to convene a White House conference on early learning and the brain this spring
column5: to explore how parents and educators can best use these startling new findings.

column1: We already know we should start teaching children before they start school. That's why this balanced budget expands Head Start to one million children by 2002. And that is why the Vice President and Mrs. Gore will host their annual family conference this June on what we can do to make sure that parents are an active part of their children's learning all the way through school. They've done a great deal to highlight the importance of family in our life
column2: and now they're turning their attention to getting more parents involved in their children's learning all the way through school. And I thank you
column3: Mr. Vice President
column4: and I thank you especially
column5: Tipper
column6: for what you do.

column1: Fifth
column2: every State should give parents the power to choose the right public school for their children. Their right to choose will foster competition and innovation that can make public schools better. We should also make it possible for more parents and teachers to start charter schools
column3: schools that set and meet the highest standards and exist only as long as they do. Our plan will help America to create 3
column4: 000 of these charter schools by the next century
column5: nearly 7 times as there are in the country today
column6: so that parents will have even more choices in sending their children to the best schools.

column1: Sixth
column2: character education must be taught in our schools. We must teach our children to be good citizens. And we must continue to promote order and discipline
column3: supporting communities that introduce school uniforms
column4: impose curfews
column5: enforce truancy laws
column6: remove disruptive students from the classroom
column7: and have zero tolerance for guns and drugs in school.

column1: Seventh
column2: we cannot expect our children to raise themselves up in schools that are literally falling down. With the student population at an all-time high and record numbers of school buildings falling into disrepair
column3: this has now become a serious national concern. Therefore
column4: my budget includes a new initiative
column5: $5 billion to help communities finance $20 billion in school construction over the next 4 years.

column1: Eighth
column2: we must make the 13th and 14th years of education
column3: at least 2 years of college
column4: just as universal in America by the 21st century as a high school education is today
column5: and we must open the doors of college to all Americans. To do that
column6: I propose America's HOPE scholarship
column7: based on Georgia's pioneering program: 2 years of a $1
column8: 500 tax credit for college tuition
column9: enough to pay for the typical community college. I also propose a tax deduction of up to $10
column10: 000 a year for all tuition after high school
column11: an expanded IRA you can withdraw from tax-free for education
column12: and the largest increase in Pell grant scholarships in 20 years. Now
column13: this plan will give most families the ability to pay no taxes on money they save for college tuition. I ask you to pass it and give every American who works hard the chance to go to college.

column1: Ninth
column2: in the 21st century
column3: we must expand the frontiers of learning across a lifetime. All our people
column4: of whatever age
column5: must have the chance to learn new skills. Most Americans live near a community college. The roads that take them there can be paths to a better future. My "GI bill" for America's workers will transform the confusing tangle of Federal training programs into a simple skill grant to go directly into eligible workers' hands. For too long
column6: this bill has been sitting on that desk there without action. I ask you to pass it now. Let's give more of our workers the ability to learn and to earn for a lifetime.

column1: Tenth
column2: we must bring the power of the information age into all our schools. Last year
column3: I challenged America to connect every classroom and library to the Internet by the year 2000
column4: so that
column5: for the first time in our history
column6: children in the most isolated rural towns
column7: the most comfortable suburbs
column8: the poorest inner-city schools
column9: will have the same access to the same universe of knowledge.

column1: That is my plan
column2: a call to action for American education. Some may say that it is unusual for a President to pay this kind of attention to education. Some may say it is simply because the President and his wonderful wife have been obsessed with this subject for more years than they can recall. That is not what is driving these proposals.

column1: We must understand the significance of this endeavor. One of the greatest sources of our strength throughout the cold war was a bipartisan foreign policy. Because our future was at stake
column2: politics stopped at the water's edge. Now I ask you and I ask all our Nation's Governors
column3: I ask parents
column4: teachers
column5: and citizens all across America for a new nonpartisan commitment to education
column6: because education is a critical national security issue for our future
column7: and politics must stop at the schoolhouse door.

column1: To prepare America for the 21st century
column2: we must harness the powerful forces of science and technology to benefit all Americans. This is the first State of the Union carried live in video over the Internet. But we've only begun to spread the benefits of a technology revolution that should become the modern birthright of every citizen.

column1: Our effort to connect every classroom is just the beginning. Now we should connect every hospital to the Internet
column2: so that doctors can instantly share data about their patients with the best specialists in the field. And I challenge the private sector tonight to start by connecting every children's hospital as soon as possible
column3: so that a child in bed can stay in touch with school
column4: family
column5: and friends. A sick child need no longer be a child alone.

column1: We must build the second generation of the Internet so that our leading universities and national laboratories can communicate in speeds 1
column2: 000 times faster than today
column3: to develop new medical treatments
column4: new sources of energy
column5: new ways of working together.

column1: But we cannot stop there. As the Internet becomes our new town square
column2: a computer in every home
column3: a teacher of all subjects
column4: a connection to all cultures
column5: this will no longer be a dream but a necessity. And over the next decade
column6: that must be our goal.

column1: We must continue to explore the heavens
column2: pressing on with the Mars probes and the international space station
column3: both of which will have practical applications for our everyday living.

column1: We must speed the remarkable advances in medical science. The human genome project is now decoding the genetic mysteries of life. American scientists have discovered genes linked to breast cancer and ovarian cancer and medication that stops a stroke in progress and begins to reverse its effects and treatments that dramatically lengthen the lives of people with HIV and AIDS.
Since I took office
column2: funding for AIDS research at the National Institutes of Health has increased dramatically to $1.5 billion. With new resources
column3: NIH will now become the most powerful discovery engine for an AIDS vaccine
column4: working with other scientists to finally end the threat of AIDS. Remember that every year every yearwe move up the discovery of an AIDS vaccine will save millions of lives around the world. We must reinforce our commitment to medical science.

column1: To prepare America for the 21st century
column2: we must build stronger families. Over the past 4 years
column3: the family and medical leave law has helped millions of Americans to take time off to be with their families. With new pressures on people in the way they work and live
column4: I believe we must expand family leave so that workers can take time off for teacher conferences and a child's medical checkup. We should pass flextime
column5: so workers can choose to be paid for overtime in income or trade it in for time off to be with their families.

column1: We must continue
column2: step by step
column3: to give more families access to affordable
column4: quality health care. Forty million Americans still lack health insurance. Ten million children still lack health insurance; 80 percent of them have working parents who pay taxes. That is wrong. My balanced budget will extend health coverage to up to 5 million of those children. Since nearly half of all children who lose their insurance do so because their parents lose or change a job
column5: my budget will also ensure that people who temporarily lose their jobs can still afford to keep their health insurance. No child should be without a doctor just because a parent is without a job.

column1: My Medicare plan modernizes Medicare
column2: increases the life of the Trust Fund to 10 years
column3: provides support for respite care for the many families with loved ones afflicted with Alzheimer's
column4: and for the first time
column5: it would fully pay for annual mammograms.

column1: Just as we ended drive-through deliveries of babies last year
column2: we must now end the dangerous and demeaning practice of forcing women home from the hospital only hours after a mastectomy. I ask your support for bipartisan legislation to guarantee that a woman can stay in the hospital for 48 hours after a mastectomy. With us tonight is Dr. Kristen Zarfos
column3: a Connecticut surgeon whose outrage at this practice spurred a national movement and inspired this legislation. I'd like her to stand so we can thank her for her efforts. Dr. Zarfos
column4: thank you.

column1: In the last 4 years
column2: we have increased child support collections by 50 percent. Now we should go further and do better by making it a felony for any parent to cross a State line in an attempt to flee from this
column3: his or her most sacred obligation.

column1: Finally
column2: we must also protect our children by standing firm in our determination to ban the advertising and marketing of cigarettes that endanger their lives.

column1: To prepare America for the 21st century
column2: we must build stronger communities. We should start with safe streets. Serious crime has dropped 5 years in a row. The key has been community policing. We must finish the job of putting 100
column3: 000 community police on the streets of the United States. We should pass the victims' rights amendment to the Constitution. And I ask you to mount a full-scale assault on juvenile crime with legislation that declares war on gangs with new prosecutors and tougher penalties; extends the Brady bill so violent teen criminals will not be able to buy handguns; requires child safety locks on handguns to prevent unauthorized use; and helps to keep our schools open after hours
column4: on weekends
column5: and in the summer
column6: so our young people will have someplace to go and something to say yes to.

column1: This balanced budget includes the largest antidrug effort ever
column2: to stop drugs at their source
column3: punish those who push them
column4: and teach our young people that drugs are wrong
column5: drugs are illegal
column6: and drugs will kill them. I hope you will support it.

column1: Our growing economy has helped to revive poor urban and rural neighborhoods. But we must do more to empower them to create the conditions in which all families can flourish and to create jobs through investment by business and loans by banks. We should double the number of empowerment zones. They've already brought so much hope to communities like Detroit
column2: where the unemployment rate has been cut in half in 4 years. We should restore contaminated urban land and buildings to productive use. We should expand the network of community development banks. And together we must pledge tonight that we will use this empowerment approach
column3: including private-sector tax incentives
column4: to renew our Capital City
column5: so that Washington is a great place to work and live and once again the proud face America shows the world.

column1: We must protect our environment in every community. In the last 4 years
column2: we cleaned up 250 toxic waste sites
column3: as many as in the previous 12. Now we should clean up 500 more
column4: so that our children grow up next to parks
column5: not poison. I urge you to pass my proposal to make big polluters live by a simple rule: If you pollute our environment
column6: you should pay to clean it up.

column1: In the last 4 years
column2: we strengthened our Nation's safe food and clean drinking water laws. We protected some of America's rarest
column3: most beautiful land in Utah's Red Rocks region
column4: created three new national parks in the California desert
column5: and began to restore the Florida Everglades. Now we must be as vigilant with our rivers as we are with our lands. Tonight I announce that this year I will designate 10 American Heritage Rivers
column6: to help communities alongside them revitalize their waterfronts and clean up pollution in the rivers
column7: proving once again that we can grow the economy as we protect the environment.

column1: We must also protect our global environment
column2: working to ban the worst toxic chemicals and to reduce the greenhouse gases that challenge our health even as they change our climate.

column1: Now
column2: we all know that in all of our communities
column3: some of our children simply don't have what they need to grow and learn in their own homes or schools or neighborhoods. And that means the rest of us must do more
column4: for they are our children
column5: too. That's why President Bush
column6: General Colin Powell
column7: former Housing Secretary Henry Cisneros will join the Vice President and me to lead the Presidents' Summit of Service in Philadelphia in April.

column1: Our national service program
column2: AmeriCorps
column3: has already helped 70
column4: 000 young people to work their way through college as they serve America. Now we intend to mobilize millions of Americans to serve in thousands of ways. Citizen service is an American responsibility which all Americans should embrace
column5: and I ask your support for that endeavor.

column1: I'd like to make just one last point about our national community. Our economy is measured in numbers and statistics
column2: and it's very important. But the enduring worth of our Nation lies in our shared values and our soaring spirit. So instead of cutting back on our modest efforts to support the arts and humanities
column3: I believe we should stand by them and challenge our artists
column4: musicians
column5: and writers
column6: challenge our museums
column7: libraries
column8: and theaters. We should challenge all Americans in the arts and humanities to join with our fellow citizens to make the year 2000 a national celebration of the American spirit in every community
column9: a celebration of our common culture in the century that has passed and in the new one to come in the new millennium
column10: so that we can remain the world's beacon not only of liberty but of creativity long after the fireworks have faded.

column1: To prepare America for the 21st century
column2: we must master the forces of change in the world and keep American leadership strong and sure for an uncharted time. Fifty years ago
column3: a farsighted America led in creating the institutions that secured victory in the cold war and built a growing world economy. As a result
column4: today more people than ever embrace our ideals and share our interests. Already we have dismantled many of the blocs and barriers that divided our parents' world. For the first time
column5: more people live under democracy than dictatorship
column6: including every nation in our own hemisphere but one
column7: and its day
column8: too
column9: will come.

column1: Now we stand at another moment of change and choice and another time to be farsighted
column2: to bring America 50 more years of security and prosperity. In this endeavor
column3: our first task is to help to build
column4: for the very first time
column5: an undivided
column6: democratic Europe. When Europe is stable
column7: prosperous
column8: and at peace
column9: America is more secure. To that end
column10: we must expand NATO by 1999
column11: so that countries that were once our adversaries can become our allies. At the special NATO summit this summer
column12: that is what we will begin to do. We must strengthen NATO's Partnership For Peace with non-member allies. And we must build a stable partnership between NATO and a democratic Russia. An expanded NATO is good for America
column13: and a Europe in which all democracies define their future not in terms of what they can do to each other but in terms of what they can do together for the good of allthat kind of Europe is good for America.

column1: Second
column2: America must look to the East no less than to the West. Our security demands it. Americans fought three wars in Asia in this century. Our prosperity requires it. More than 2 million American jobs depend upon trade with Asia. There
column3: too
column4: we are helping to shape an Asia-Pacific community of cooperation
column5: not conflict. Let our progress there not mask the peril that remains. Together with South Korea
column6: we must advance peace talks with North Korea and bridge the cold war's last divide. And I call on Congress to fund our share of the agreement under which North Korea must continue to freeze and then dismantle its nuclear weapons program.

column1: We must pursue a deeper dialog with China for the sake of our interests and our ideals. An isolated China is not good for America; a China playing its proper role in the world is. I will go to China
column2: and I have invited China's President to come here
column3: not because we agree on everything but because engaging China is the best way to work on our common challenges like ending nuclear testing and to deal frankly with our fundamental differences like human rights.

column1: The American people must prosper in the global economy. We've worked hard to tear down trade barriers abroad so that we can create good jobs at home. I am proud to say that today America is once again the most competitive nation and the number one exporter in the world.
Now we must act to expand our exports
column2: especially to Asia and Latin America
column3: two of the fastest growing regions on Earth
column4: or be left behind as these emerging economies forge new ties with other nations. That is why we need the authority now to conclude new trade agreements that open markets to our goods and services even as we preserve our values.

column1: We need not shrink from the challenge of the global economy. After all
column2: we have the best workers and the best products. In a truly open market
column3: we can out-compete anyone
column4: anywhere on Earth.

column1: But this is about more than economics. By expanding trade
column2: we can advance the cause of freedom and democracy around the world. There is no better example of this truth than Latin America
column3: where democracy and open markets are on the march together. That is why I will visit there in the spring to reinforce our important tie.

column1: We should all be proud that America led the effort to rescue our neighbor Mexico from its economic crisis. And we should all be proud that last month Mexico repaid the United States 3 full years ahead of schedule
column2: with half a billion dollar profit to us.

column1: America must continue to be an unrelenting force for peace from the Middle East to Haiti
column2: from Northern Ireland to Africa. Taking reasonable risks for peace keeps us from being drawn into far more costly conflicts later.

column1: With American leadership
column2: the killing has stopped in Bosnia. Now the habits of peace must take hold. The new NATO force will allow reconstruction and reconciliation to accelerate. Tonight I ask Congress to continue its strong support of our troops. They are doing a remarkable job there for America
column3: and America must do right by them.

column1: Fifth
column2: we must move strongly against new threats to our security. In the past 4 years
column3: we agreed to banwe led the way to a worldwide agreement to ban nuclear testing. With Russia
column4: we dramatically cut nuclear arsenals
column5: and we stopped targeting each other's citizens. We are acting to prevent nuclear materials from falling into the wrong hands and to rid the world of landmines. We are working with other nations with renewed intensity to fight drug traffickers and to stop terrorists before they act and hold them fully accountable if they do.

column1: Now we must rise to a new test of leadership
column2: ratifying the Chemical Weapons Convention. Make no mistake about it. It will make our troops safer from chemical attack. It will help us to fight terrorism. We have no more important obligations
column3: especially in the wake of what we now know about the Gulf war. This treaty has been bipartisan from the beginning
column4: supported by Republican and Democratic administrations and Republican and Democratic Members of Congress and already approved by 68 nations. But if we do not act by April 29th
column5: when this convention goes into force with or without us
column6: we will lose the chance to have Americans leading and enforcing this effort. Together we must make the Chemical Weapons Convention law
column7: so that at last we can begin to outlaw poison gas from the Earth.

column1: Finally
column2: we must have the tools to meet all these challenges. We must maintain a strong and ready military. We must increase funding for weapons modernization by the year 2000
column3: and we must take good care of our men and women in uniform. They are the world's finest.

column1: We must also renew our commitment to America's diplomacy and pay our debts and dues to international financial institutions like the World Bank and to a reforming United Nations. Every dollar we devote to preventing conflicts
column2: to promoting democracy
column3: to stopping the spread of disease and starvation
column4: brings a sure return in security and savings. Yet international affairs spending today is just one percent of the Federal budget
column5: a small fraction of what America invested in diplomacy to choose leadership over escapism at the start of the cold war. If America is to continue to lead the world
column6: we here who lead America simply must find the will to pay our way.

column1: A farsighted America moved the world to a better place over these last 50 years. And so it can be for another 50 years. But a shortsighted America will soon find its words falling on deaf ears all around the world.
Almost exactly 50 years ago
column2: in the first winter of the cold war
column3: President Truman stood before a Republican Congress and called upon our country to meet its responsibilities of leadership. This was his warning; he said
column4: "If we falter
column5: we may endanger the peace of the world
column6: and we shall surely endanger the welfare of this Nation." That Congress
column7: led by Republicans like Senator Arthur Vandenberg
column8: answered President Truman's call. Together
column9: they made the commitments that strengthened our country for 50 years. Now let us do the same. Let us do what it takes to remain the indispensable nation
column10: to keep America strong
column11: secure
column12: and prosperous for another 50 years.

column1: In the end
column2: more than anything else
column3: our world leadership grows out of the power of our example here at home
column4: out of our ability to remain strong as one America. All over the world
column5: people are being torn asunder by racial
column6: ethnic
column7: and religious conflicts that fuel fanaticism and terror. We are the world's most diverse democracy
column8: and the world looks to us to show that it is possible to live and advance together across those kinds of differences.

column1: America has always been a nation of immigrants. From the start
column2: a steady stream of people in search of freedom and opportunity have left their own lands to make this land their home. We started as an experiment in democracy fueled by Europeans. We have grown into an experiment in democratic diversity fueled by openness and promise.

column1: My fellow Americans
column2: we must never
column3: ever believe that our diversity is a weakness. It is our greatest strength. Americans speak every language
column4: know every country. People on every continent can look to us and see the reflection of their own great potential
column5: and they always will
column6: as long as we strive to give all of our citizens
column7: whatever their background
column8: an opportunity to achieve their own greatness.

column1: We're not there yet. We still see evidence of abiding bigotry and intolerance in ugly words and awful violence
column2: in burned churches and bombed buildings. We must fight against this
column3: in our country and in our hearts.

column1: Just a few days before my second Inauguration
column2: one of our country's best known pastors
column3: Reverend Robert Schuller
column4: suggested that I read Isaiah 58:12. Here's what it says: "Thou shalt raise up the foundations of many generations
column5: and thou shalt be called the repairer of the breach
column6: the restorer of paths to dwell in." I placed my hand on that verse when I took the oath of office
column7: on behalf of all Americans
column8: for no matter what our differences in our faiths
column9: our backgrounds
column10: our politics
column11: we must all be repairers of the breach.

column1: I want to say a word about two other Americans who show us how. Congressman Frank Tejeda was buried yesterday
column2: a proud American whose family came from Mexico. He was only 51 years old. He was awarded the Silver Star
column3: the Bronze Star
column4: and the Purple Heart fighting for his country in Vietnam. And he went on to serve Texas and America fighting for our future here in this Chamber. We are grateful for his service and honored that his mother
column5: Lillie Tejeda
column6: and his sister
column7: Mary Alice
column8: have come from Texas to be with us here tonight. And we welcome you.

column1: Gary Locke
column2: the newly elected Governor of Washington State
column3: is the first Chinese-American Governor in the history of our country. He's the proud son of two of the millions of Asian-American immigrants who have strengthened America with their hard work
column4: family values
column5: and good citizenship. He represents the future we can all achieve. Thank you
column6: Governor
column7: for being here. Please stand up.

column1: Reverend Schuller
column2: Congressman Tejeda
column3: Governor Locke
column4: along with Kristen Tanner and Chris Getsler
column5: Sue Winski and Dr. Kristen Zarfos
column6: they're all Americans from different roots whose lives reflect the best of what we can become when we are one America. We may not share a common past
column7: but we surely do share a common future. Building one America is our most important mission
column8: the foundation for many generations of every other strength we must build for this new century. Money cannot buy it. Power cannot compel it. Technology cannot create it. It can only come from the human spirit.

column1: America is far more than a place. It is an idea
column2: the most powerful idea in the history of nations. And all of us in this Chamber
column3: we are now the bearers of that idea
column4: leading a great people into a new world. A child born tonight will have almost no memory of the 20th century. Everything that child will know about America will be because of what we do now to build a new century.

column1: We don't have a moment to waste. Tomorrow there will be just over 1
column2: 000 days until the year 2000; 1
column3: 000 days to prepare our people; 1
column4: 000 days to work together; 1
column5: 000 days to build a bridge to a land of new promise. My fellow Americans
column6: we have work to do. Let us seize those days and the century.

column1: Thank you
column2: God bless you
column3: and God bless America.@

column1: William J. Clinton|Address Before a Joint Session of the Congress on the State of the Union|1998-01-27|@Mr. Speaker
column2: Mr. Vice President
column3: Members of the 105th Congress
column4: distinguished guests
column5: my fellow Americans: Since the last time we met in this Chamber
column6: America has lost two patriots and fine public servants. Though they sat on opposite sides of the aisle
column7: Representatives Walter Capps and Sonny Bono shared a deep love for this House and an unshakable commitment to improving the lives of all our people. In the past few weeks
column8: they've both been eulogized. Tonight I think we should begin by sending a message to their families and their friends that we celebrate their lives and give thanks for their service to our Nation.

column1: For 209 years
column2: it has been the President's duty to report to you on the state of the Union. Because of the hard work and high purpose of the American people
column3: these are good times for America. We have more than 14 million new jobs
column4: the lowest unemployment in 24 years
column5: the lowest core inflation in 30 years; incomes are rising; and we have the highest homeownership in history. Crime has dropped for a record 5 years in a row
column6: and the welfare rolls are at their lowest levels in 27 years. Our leadership in the world is unrivaled. Ladies and gentlemen
column7: the state of our Union is strong.

column1: But with barely 700 days left in the 20th century
column2: this is not a time to rest. It is a time to build
column3: to build the America within reach
column4: an America where everybody has a chance to get ahead with hard work; where every citizen can live in a safe community; where families are strong
column5: schools are good
column6: and all our young people can go on to college; an America where scientists find cures for diseases from diabetes to Alzheimer's to AIDS; an America where every child can stretch a hand across a keyboard and reach every book ever written
column7: every painting ever painted
column8: every symphony ever composed; where government provides opportunity and citizens honor the responsibility to give something back to their communities; an America which leads the world to new heights of peace and prosperity. This is the America we have begun to build; this is the America we can leave to our children if we join together to finish the work at hand. Let us strengthen our Nation for the 21st century.

column1: Rarely have Americans lived through so much change in so many ways in so short a time. Quietly
column2: but with gathering force
column3: the ground has shifted beneath our feet as we have moved into an information age
column4: a global economy
column5: a truly new world. For 5 years now
column6: we have met the challenge of these changes
column7: as Americans have at every turning point in our history
column8: by renewing the very idea of America: widening the circle of opportunity
column9: deepening the meaning of our freedom
column10: forging a more perfect Union.

column1: We shaped a new kind of Government for the information age. I thank the Vice President for his leadership and the Congress for its support in building a Government that is leaner
column2: more flexible
column3: a catalyst for new ideas
column4: and most of all
column5: a Government that gives the American people the tools they need to make the most of their own lives.

column1: We have moved past the sterile debate between those who say government is the enemy and those who say government is the answer. My fellow Americans
column2: we have found a third way. We have the smallest Government in 35 years
column3: but a more progressive one. We have a smaller Government
column4: but a stronger Nation. We are moving steadily toward an even stronger America in the 21st century: an economy that offers opportunity
column5: a society rooted in responsibility
column6: and a nation that lives as a community.

column1: First
column2: Americans in this Chamber and across our Nation have pursued a new strategy for prosperity: fiscal discipline to cut interest rates and spur growth; investments in education and skills
column3: in science and technology and transportation
column4: to prepare our people for the new economy; new markets for American products and American workers.

column1: When I took office
column2: the deficit for 1998 was projected to be $357 billion and heading higher. This year
column3: our deficit is projected to be $10 billion and heading lower. For three decades
column4: six Presidents have come before you to warn of the damage deficits pose to our Nation. Tonight I come before you to announce that the Federal deficit
column5: once so incomprehensibly large that it had 11 zeros
column6: will be
column7: simply
column8: zero. I will submit to Congress for 1999 the first balanced budget in 30 years. And if we hold fast to fiscal discipline
column9: we may balance the budget this year4 years ahead of schedule.

column1: You can all be proud of that
column2: because turning a sea of red ink into black is no miracle. It is the product of hard work by the American people and of two visionary actions in Congress: the courageous vote in 1993 that led to a cut in the deficit of 90 percent
column3: and the truly historic bipartisan balanced budget agreement passed by this Congress. Here's the really good news: If we maintain our resolve
column4: we will produce balanced budgets as far as the eye can see.

column1: We must not go back to unwise spending or untargeted tax cuts that risk reopening the deficit. Last year
column2: together
column3: we enacted targeted tax cuts so that the typical middle class family will now have the lowest tax rates in 20 years. My plan to balance the budget next year includes both new investments and new tax cuts targeted to the needs of working families
column4: for education
column5: for child care
column6: for the environment.

column1: But whether the issue is tax cuts or spending
column2: I ask all of you to meet this test: Approve only those priorities that can actually be accomplished without adding a dime to the deficit.

column1: Now
column2: if we balance the budget for next year
column3: it is projected that we'll then have a sizable surplus in the years that immediately follow. What should we do with this projected surplus? I have a simple four-word answer: Save Social Security first.

column1: Tonight I propose that we reserve 100 percent of the surplusthat's every penny of any surplusuntil we have taken all the necessary measures to strengthen the Social Security system for the 21st century. Let us say to all Americans watching tonightwhether you're 70 or 50 or whether you just started paying into the systemSocial Security will be there when you need it. Let us make this commitment: Social Security first. Let's do that together.
I also want to say that all the American people who are watching us tonight should be invited to join in this discussion
column2: in facing these issues squarely and forming a true consensus on how we should proceed. We'll start by conducting nonpartisan forums in every region of the country
column3: and I hope that lawmakers of both parties will participate. We'll hold a White House conference on Social Security in December. And one year from now
column4: I will convene the leaders of Congress to craft historic
column5: bipartisan legislation to achieve a landmark for our generation: a Social Security system that is strong in the 21st century.

column1: In an economy that honors opportunity
column2: all Americans must be able to reap the rewards of prosperity. Because these times are good
column3: we can afford to take one simple
column4: sensible step to help millions of workers struggling to provide for their families: We should raise the minimum wage.

column1: The information age is
column2: first and foremost
column3: an education age
column4: in which education must start at birth and continue throughout a lifetime. Last year
column5: from this podium
column6: I said that education has to be our highest priority. I laid out a 10point plan to move us forward and urged all of us to let politics stop at the schoolhouse door. Since then
column7: this Congressacross party lines and the American people have responded
column8: in the most important year for education in a generation
column9: expanding public school choice
column10: opening the way to 3
column11: 000 new charter schools
column12: working to connect every classroom in the country to the information superhighway
column13: committing to expand Head Start to a million children
column14: launching America Reads
column15: sending literally thousands of college students into our elementary schools to make sure all our 8-year-olds can read.

column1: Last year I proposed and you passed 220
column2: 000 new Pell grant scholarships for deserving students. Student loans
column3: already less expensive and easier to repaynow you get to deduct the interest. Families all over America now can put their savings into new tax-free education IRA's. And this year
column4: for the first 2 years of college
column5: families will get a $1
column6: 500 tax credita HOPE scholarship that will cover the cost of most community college tuition. And for junior and senior year
column7: graduate school
column8: and job training
column9: there is a lifetime learning credit. You did that
column10: and you should be very proud of it.

column1: And because of these actions
column2: I have something to say to every family listening to us tonight: Your children can go on to college. If you know a child from a poor family
column3: tell her not to give up; she can go on to college. If you know a young couple struggling with bills
column4: worried they won't be able to send their children to college
column5: tell them not to give up; their children can go on to college. If you know somebody who's caught in a dead-end job and afraid he can't afford the classes necessary to get better jobs for the rest of his life
column6: tell him not to give up; he can go on to college. Because of the things that have been done
column7: we can make college as universal in the 21st century as high school is today. And my friends
column8: that will change the face and future of America.

column1: We have opened wide the doors of the world's best system of higher education. Now we must make our public elementary and secondary schools the world's best
column2: as well
column3: by raising standards
column4: raising expectations
column5: and raising accountability. Thanks to the actions of this Congress last year
column6: we will soon have
column7: for the very first time
column8: a voluntary national test based on national standards in fourth grade reading and eighth grade math. Parents have a right to know whether their children are mastering the basics. And every parent already knows the key: good teachers and small classes.

column1: Tonight I propose the first ever national effort to reduce class size in the early grades. My balanced budget will help to hire 100
column2: 000 new teachers who've passed a State competency test. Now
column3: with these teacherslistenwith these teachers
column4: we will actually be able to reduce class size in the first
column5: second
column6: and third grades to an average of 18 students a class
column7: all across America.

column1: If I've got the math right
column2: more teachers teaching smaller classes requires more classrooms. So I also propose a school construction tax cut to help communities modernize or build 5
column3: 000 schools.

column1: We must also demand greater accountability. When we promote a child from grade to grade who hasn't mastered the work
column2: we don't do that child any favors. It is time to end social promotion in America's schools. Last year
column3: in Chicago
column4: they made that decisionnot to hold our children back but to lift them up. Chicago stopped social promotion and started mandatory summer school to help students who are behind to catch up. I propose to help other communities follow Chicago's lead. Let's say to them: Stop promoting children who don't learn
column5: and we will give you the tools to make sure they do.

column1: I also ask this Congress to support our efforts to enlist colleges and universities to reach out to disadvantaged children
column2: starting in the sixth grade
column3: so that they can get the guidance and hope they need so they can know that they
column4: too
column5: will be able to go on to college.

column1: As we enter the 21st century
column2: the global economy requires us to seek opportunity not just at home but in all the markets of the world. We must shape this global economy
column3: not shrink from it. In the last 5 years
column4: we have led the way in opening new markets
column5: with 240 trade agreements that remove foreign barriers to products bearing the proud stamp "Made in the USA." Today
column6: record high exports account for fully one-third of our economic growth. I want to keep them going
column7: because that's the way to keep America growing and to advance a safer
column8: more stable world.

column1: All of you know
column2: whatever your views are
column3: that I think this is a great opportunity for America. I know there is opposition to more comprehensive trade agreements. I have listened carefully
column4: and I believe that the opposition is rooted in two fears: first
column5: that our trading partners will have lower environmental and labor standards which will give them an unfair advantage in our market and do their own people no favors
column6: even if there's more business; and
column7: second
column8: that if we have more trade
column9: more of our workers will lose their jobs and have to start over. I think we should seek to advance worker and environmental standards around the world. I have made it abundantly clear that it should be a part of our trade agenda. But we cannot influence other countries' decisions if we send them a message that we're backing away from trade with them.

column1: This year I will send legislation to Congress
column2: and ask other nations to join us
column3: to fight the most intolerable labor practice of all: abusive child labor. We should also offer help and hope to those Americans temporarily left behind by the global marketplace or by the march of technology
column4: which may have nothing to do with trade. That's why we have more than doubled funding for training dislocated workers since 1993. And if my new budget is adopted
column5: we will triple funding. That's why we must do more
column6: and more quickly
column7: to help workers who lose their jobs for whatever reason.

column1: You know
column2: we help communities in a special way when their military base closes; we ought to help them in the same way if their factory closes. Again
column3: I ask the Congress to continue its bipartisan work to consolidate the tangle of training programs we have today into one single "GI bill" for workers
column4: a simple skills grant so people can
column5: on their own
column6: move quickly to new jobs
column7: to higher incomes
column8: and brighter futures.

column1: We all know
column2: in every way in life
column3: change is not always easy
column4: but we have to decide whether we're going to try to hold it back and hide from it or reap its benefits. And remember the big picture here: While we've been entering into hundreds of new trade agreements
column5: we've been creating millions of new jobs.

column1: So this year we will forge new partnerships with Latin America
column2: Asia
column3: and Europe. And we should pass the new "African Trade Act"; it has bipartisan support. I will also renew my request for the fast-track negotiating authority necessary to open more new markets
column4: create more new jobs
column5: which every President has had for two decades.

column1: You know
column2: whether we like it or not
column3: in ways that are mostly positive
column4: the world's economies are more and more interconnected and interdependent. Today
column5: an economic crisis anywhere can affect economies everywhere. Recent months have brought serious financial problems to Thailand
column6: Indonesia
column7: South Korea
column8: and beyond.

column1: Now
column2: why should Americans be concerned about this? First
column3: these countries are our customers. If they sink into recession
column4: they won't be able to buy the goods we'd like to sell them. Second
column5: they're also our competitors. So if their currencies lose their value and go down
column6: then the price of their goods will drop
column7: flooding our market and others with much cheaper goods
column8: which makes it a lot tougher for our people to compete. And finally
column9: they are our strategic partners. Their stability bolsters our security.

column1: The American economy remains sound and strong
column2: and I want to keep it that way. But because the turmoil in Asia will have an impact on all the world's economies
column3: including ours
column4: making that negative impact as small as possible is the right thing to do for America and the right thing to do for a safer world.

column1: Our policy is clear: No nation can recover if it does not reform itself. But when nations are willing to undertake serious economic reform
column2: we should help them do it. So I call on Congress to renew America's commitment to the International Monetary Fund. And I think we should say to all the people we're trying to represent here that preparing for a far-off storm that may reach our shores is far wiser than ignoring the thunder till the clouds are just overhead.

column1: A strong nation rests on the rock of responsibility. A society rooted in responsibility must first promote the value of work
column2: not welfare. We can be proud that after decades of fingerpointing and failure
column3: together we ended the old welfare system. And we're now replacing welfare checks with paychecks.

column1: Last year
column2: after a record 4-year decline in welfare rolls
column3: I challenged our Nation to move 2 million more Americans off welfare by the year 2000. I'm pleased to report we have also met that goal
column4: 2 full years ahead of schedule.

column1: This is a grand achievement
column2: the sum of many acts of individual courage
column3: persistence
column4: and hope. For 13 years
column5: Elaine Kinslow of Indianapolis
column6: Indiana
column7: was on and off welfare. Today
column8: she's a dispatcher with a van company. She's saved enough money to move her family into a good neighborhood
column9: and she's helping other welfare recipients go to work. Elaine Kinslow and all those like her are the real heroes of the welfare revolution. There are millions like her all across America. And I'm happy she could join the First Lady tonight. Elaine
column10: we're very proud of you. Please stand up.

column1: We still have a lot more to do
column2: all of us
column3: to make welfare reform a successproviding child care
column4: helping families move closer to available jobs
column5: challenging more companies to join our welfare-to-work partnership
column6: increasing child support collections from deadbeat parents who have a duty to support their own children. I also want to thank Congress for restoring some of the benefits to immigrants who are here legally and working hard
column7: and I hope you will finish that job this year.

column1: We have to make it possible for all hardworking families to meet their most important responsibilities. Two years ago we helped guarantee that Americans can keep their health insurance when they change jobs. Last year we extended health care to up to 5 million children. This year I challenge Congress to take the next historic steps.
A hundred and sixty million of our fellow citizens are in managed care plans. These plans save money
column2: and they can improve care. But medical decisions ought to be made by medical doctors
column3: not insurance company accountants. I urge this Congress to reach across the aisle and write into law a consumer bill of rights that says this: You have the right to know all your medical options
column4: not just the cheapest. You have the right to choose the doctor you want for the care you need. You have the right to emergency room care
column5: wherever and whenever you need it. You have the right to keep your medical records confidential. Traditional care or managed care
column6: every American deserves quality care.

column1: Millions of Americans between the ages of 55 and 65 have lost their health insurance. Some are retired; some are laid off; some lose their coverage when their spouses retire. After a lifetime of work
column2: they are left with nowhere to turn. So I ask the Congress
column3: let these hardworking Americans buy into the Medicare system. It won't add a dime to the deficit
column4: but the peace of mind it will provide will be priceless.

column1: Next
column2: we must help parents protect their children from the gravest health threat that they face: an epidemic of teen smoking
column3: spread by multimillion-dollar marketing campaigns. I challenge Congress: Let's pass bipartisan
column4: comprehensive legislation that will improve public health
column5: protect our tobacco farmers
column6: and change the way tobacco companies do business forever. Let's do what it takes to bring teen smoking down. Let's raise the price of cigarettes by up to a dollar and a half a pack over the next 10 years
column7: with penalties on the tobacco industry if it keeps marketing to our children. Tomorrow
column8: like every day
column10: 000 children will start smoking
column11: and 1
column12: 000 will die early as a result. Let this Congress be remembered as the Congress that saved their lives.

column1: In the new economy
column2: most parents work harder than ever. They face a constant struggle to balance their obligations to be good workers and their even more important obligations to be good parents. The Family and Medical Leave Act was the very first bill I was privileged to sign into law as President in 1993. Since then
column3: about 15 million people have taken advantage of it
column4: and I've met a lot of them all across this country. I ask you to extend that law to cover 10 million more workers and to give parents time off when they have to go see their children's teachers or take them to the doctor.

column1: Child care is the next frontier we must face to enable people to succeed at home and at work. Last year I cohosted the very first White House Conference on Child Care with one of our foremost experts
column2: America's First Lady. From all corners of America
column3: we heard the same message
column4: without regard to region or income or political affiliation: We've got to raise the quality of child care. We've got to make it safer. We've got to make it more affordable.

column1: So here's my plan: Help families to pay for child care for a million more children; scholarships and background checks for child care workers
column2: and a new emphasis on early learning; tax credits for businesses that provide child care for their employees; and a larger child care tax credit for working families. Now
column3: if you pass my plan
column4: what this means is that a family of four with an income of $35
column5: 000 and high child care costs will no longer pay a single penny of Federal income tax.

column1: I think this is such a big issue with me because of my own personal experience. I have often wondered how my mother
column2: when she was a young widow
column3: would have been able to go away to school and get an education and come back and support me if my grandparents hadn't been able to take care of me. She and I were really very lucky. How many other families have never had that same opportunity? The truth is
column4: we don't know the answer to that question. But we do know what the answer should be: Not a single American family should ever have to choose between the job they need and the child they love.

column1: A society rooted in responsibility must provide safe streets
column2: safe schools
column3: and safe neighborhoods. We pursued a strategy of more police
column4: tougher punishment
column5: smarter prevention
column6: with crimefighting partnerships with local law enforcement and citizen groups
column7: where the rubber hits the road. I can report to you tonight that it's working. Violent crime is down; robbery is down; assault is down; burglary is downfor 5 years in a row
column8: all across America. We need to finish the job of putting 100
column9: 000 more police on our streets.

column1: Again
column2: I ask Congress to pass a juvenile crime bill that provides more prosecutors and probation officers
column3: to crack down on gangs and guns and drugs
column4: and bar violent juveniles from buying guns for life. And I ask you to dramatically expand our support for after-school programs. I think every American should know that most juvenile crime is committed between the hours of 3 in the afternoon and 8 at night. We can keep so many of our children out of trouble in the first place if we give them someplace to go other than the streets
column5: and we ought to do it.

column1: Drug use is on the decline. I thank General McCaffrey for his leadership
column2: and I thank this Congress for passing the largest antidrug budget in history. Now I ask you to join me in a groundbreaking effort to hire 1
column3: 000 new Border Patrol agents and to deploy the most sophisticated available new technologies to help close the door on drugs at our borders.

column1: Police
column2: prosecutors
column3: and prevention programs
column4: as good as they are
column5: they can't work if our court system doesn't work. Today
column6: there are large numbers of vacancies in our Federal courts. Here is what the Chief Justice of the United States wrote: "Judicial vacancies cannot remain at such high levels indefinitely without eroding the quality of justice." I simply ask the United States Senate to heed this plea and vote on the highly qualified judicial nominees before you
column7: up or down.

column1: We must exercise responsibility not just at home but around the world. On the eve of a new century
column2: we have the power and the duty to build a new era of peace and security. But make no mistake about it; today's possibilities are not tomorrow's guarantees. America must stand against the poisoned appeals of extreme nationalism. We must combat an unholy axis of new threats from terrorists
column3: international criminals
column4: and drug traffickers. These 21st century predators feed on technology and the free flow of information and ideas and people. And they will be all the more lethal if weapons of mass destruction fall into their hands.

column1: To meet these challenges
column2: we are helping to write international rules of the road for the 21st century
column3: protecting those who join the family of nations and isolating those who do not. Within days
column4: I will ask the Senate for its advice and consent to make Hungary
column5: Poland
column6: and the Czech Republic the newest members of NATO. For 50 years
column7: NATO contained communism and kept America and Europe secure. Now
column8: these three formerly Communist countries have said yes to democracy. I ask the Senate to say yes to them
column9: our new allies. By taking in new members and working closely with new partners
column10: including Russia and Ukraine
column11: NATO can help to assure that Europe is a stronghold for peace in the 21st century.

column1: Next
column2: I will ask Congress to continue its support of our troops and their mission in Bosnia. This Christmas
column3: Hillary and I traveled to Sarajevo with Senator and Mrs. Dole and a bipartisan congressional delegation. We saw children playing in the streets
column4: where 2 years ago they were hiding from snipers and shells. The shops are filled with food; the cafes were alive with conversation. The progress there is unmistakable
column5: but it is not yet irreversible. To take firm root
column6: Bosnia's fragile peace still needs the support of American and allied troops when the current NATO mission ends in June. I think Senator Dole actually said it best. He said
column7: "This is like being ahead in the fourth quarter of a football game. Now is not the time to walk off the field and forfeit the victory."

column1: I wish all of you could have seen our troops in Tuzla. They're very proud of what they're doing in Bosnia
column2: and we're all very proud of them. One of those brave soldiers is sitting with the First Lady tonight: Army Sergeant Michael Tolbert. His father was a decorated Vietnam vet. After college in Colorado
column3: he joined the Army. Last year he led an infantry unit that stopped a mob of extremists from taking over a radio station that is a voice of democracy and tolerance in Bosnia. Thank you very much
column4: Sergeant
column5: for what you represent. Please stand up.

column1: In Bosnia and around the world
column2: our men and women in uniform always do their mission well. Our mission must be to keep them welltrained and ready
column3: to improve their quality of life
column4: and to provide the 21st century weapons they need to defeat any enemy.

column1: I ask Congress to join me in pursuing an ambitious agenda to reduce the serious threat of weapons of mass destruction. This year
column2: four decades after it was first proposed by President Eisenhower
column3: a comprehensive nuclear test ban is within reach. By ending nuclear testing
column4: we can help to prevent the development of new and more dangerous weapons and make it more difficult for non-nuclear states to build them. I'm pleased to announce that four former Chairmen of the Joint Chiefs of StaffGenerals John Shalikashvili
column5: Colin Powell
column6: and David Jones and Admiral William Crowehave endorsed this treaty. And I ask the Senate to approve it this year.

column1: Together
column2: we must confront the new hazards of chemical and biological weapons and the outlaw states
column3: terrorists
column4: and organized criminals seeking to acquire them. Saddam Hussein has spent the better part of this decade and much of his nation's wealth not on providing for the Iraqi people but on developing nuclear
column5: chemical
column6: and biological weapons and the missiles to deliver them. The United Nations weapons inspectors have done a truly remarkable job finding and destroying more of Iraq's arsenal than was destroyed during the entire Gulf war. Now Saddam Hussein wants to stop them from completing their mission.

column1: I know I speak for everyone in this chamber
column2: Republicans and Democrats
column3: when I say to Saddam Hussein
column4: "You cannot defy the will of the world
column5: and when I say to him, You have used weapons of mass destruction before. We are determined to deny you the capacity to use them again."

column1: Last year the Senate ratified the Chemical Weapons Convention to protect our soldiers and citizens from poison gas. Now we must act to prevent the use of disease as a weapon of war and terror. The Biological Weapons Convention has been in effect for 23 years now. The rules are good
column2: but the enforcement is weak. We must strengthen it with a new international inspection system to detect and deter cheating.

column1: In the months ahead
column2: I will pursue our security strategy with old allies in Asia and Europe and new partners from Africa to India and Pakistan
column3: from South America to China. And from Belfast to Korea to the Middle East
column4: America will continue to stand with those who stand for peace.

column1: Finally
column2: it's long past time to make good on our debt to the United Nations. More and more
column3: we are working with other nations to achieve common goals. If we want America to lead
column4: we've got to set a good example. As we see so clearly in Bosnia
column5: allies who share our goals can also share our burdens. In this new era
column6: our freedom and independence are actually enriched
column7: not weakened
column8: by our increasing interdependence with other nations. But we have to do our part.

column1: Our Founders set America on a permanent course toward a more perfect Union. To all of you I say
column2: it is a journey we can only make together
column3: living as one community. First
column4: we have to continue to reform our Government
column5: the instrument of our national community. Everyone knows elections have become too expensive
column6: fueling a fundraising arms race. This year
column7: by March 6th
column8: at long last the Senate will actually vote on bipartisan campaign finance reform proposed by Senators McCain and Feingold. Let's be clear: A vote against McCain-Feingold is a vote for soft money and for the status quo. I ask you to strengthen our democracy and pass campaign finance reform this year.

column1: At least equally important
column2: we have to address the real reason for the explosion in campaign costs: the high cost of media advertising.

column1: To the folks watching at home
column2: those were the groans of pain in the audience.  I will formally request that the Federal Communications Commission act to provide free or reduced-cost television time for candidates who observe spending limits voluntarily. The airwaves are a public trust
column3: and broadcasters also have to help us in this effort to strengthen our democracy.

column1: Under the leadership of Vice President Gore
column2: we've reduced the Federal payroll by 300
column3: 000 workers
column4: cut 16
column5: 000 pages of regulation
column6: eliminated hundreds of programs
column7: and improved the operations of virtually every Government agency. But we can do more. Like every taxpayer
column8: I'm outraged by the reports of abuses by the IRS. We need some changes there: new citizen advocacy panels
column9: a stronger taxpayer advocate
column10: phone lines open 24 hours a day
column11: relief for innocent taxpayers. Last year
column12: by an overwhelming bipartisan margin
column13: the House of Representatives passed sweeping IRS reforms. This bill must not now languish in the Senate. Tonight I ask the Senate: Follow the House; pass the bipartisan package as your first order of business.

column1: I hope to goodness before I finish I can think of something to say "follow the Senate" on
column2: so I'll be out of trouble.

column1: A nation that lives as a community must value all its communities. For the past 5 years
column2: we have worked to bring the spark of private enterprise to inner city and poor rural areas
column3: with community development banks
column4: more commercial loans in the poor neighborhoods
column5: cleanup of polluted sites for development. Under the continued leadership of the Vice President
column6: we propose to triple the number of empowerment zones to give business incentives to invest in those areas. We should also give poor families more help to move into homes of their own
column7: and we should use tax cuts to spur the construction of more low-income housing.

column1: Last year
column2: this Congress took strong action to help the District of Columbia. Let us renew our resolve to make our Capital City a great city for all who live and visit here. Our cities are the vibrant hubs of great metropolitan areas. They are still the gateways for new immigrants from every continent
column3: who come here to work for their own American dreams. Let's keep our cities going strong into the 21st century; they're a very important part of our future.

column1: Our communities are only as healthy as the air our children breathe
column2: the water they drink
column3: the Earth they will inherit. Last year we put in place the toughest-ever controls on smog and soot. We moved to protect Yellowstone
column4: the Everglades
column5: Lake Tahoe. We expanded every community's right to know about the toxins that threaten their children. Just yesterday
column6: our food safety plan took effect
column7: using new science to protect consumers from dangers like E. coli and salmonella.

column1: Tonight I ask you to join me in launching a new clean water initiative
column2: a far-reaching effort to clean our rivers
column3: our lakes
column4: and our coastal waters for our children.

column1: Our overriding environmental challenge tonight is the worldwide problem of climate change
column2: global warming
column3: the gathering crisis that requires worldwide action. The vast majority of scientists have concluded unequivocally that if we don't reduce the emission of greenhouse gases
column4: at some point in the next century
column5: we'll disrupt our climate and put our children and grandchildren at risk. This past December
column6: America led the world to reach a historic agreement committing our Nation to reduce greenhouse gas emissions through market forces
column7: new technologies
column8: energy efficiency. We have it in our power to act right here
column9: right now. I propose $6 billion in tax cuts and research and development to encourage innovation
column10: renewable energy
column11: fuel-efficient cars
column12: energy-efficient homes.

column1: Every time we have acted to heal our environment
column2: pessimists have told us it would hurt the economy. Well
column3: today
column4: our economy is the strongest in a generation
column5: and our environment is the cleanest in a generation. We have always found a way to clean the environment and grow the economy at the same time. And when it comes to global warming
column6: we'll do it again.

column1: Finally
column2: community means living by the defining American value
column3: the ideal heard 'round the world
column4: that we are all created equal. Throughout our history
column5: we haven't always honored that ideal and we've never fully lived up to it. Often it's easier to believe that our differences matter more than what we have in common. It may be easier
column6: but it's wrong.

column1: What we have to do in our day and generation to make sure that America becomes truly one nationwhat do we have to do? We're becoming more and more and more diverse. Do you believe we can become one nation? The answer cannot be to dwell on our differences but to build on our shared values. We all cherish family and faith
column2: freedom and responsibility. We all want our children to grow up in a world where their talents are matched by their opportunities.

column1: I've launched this national initiative on race to help us recognize our common interests and to bridge the opportunity gaps that are keeping us from becoming one America. Let us begin by recognizing what we still must overcome. Discrimination against any American is un-American. We must vigorously enforce the laws that make it illegal. I ask your help to end the backlog at the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission. Sixty thousand of our fellow citizens are waiting in line for justice
column2: and we should act now to end their wait.

column1: We also should recognize that the greatest progress we can make toward building one America lies in the progress we make for all Americans
column2: without regard to race. When we open the doors of college to all Americans
column3: when we rid all our streets of crime
column4: when there are jobs available to people from all our neighborhoods
column5: when we make sure all parents have the child care they need
column6: we're helping to build one nation.

column1: We
column2: in this Chamber and in this Government
column3: must do all we can to address the continuing American challenge to build one America. But we'll only move forward if all our fellow citizens
column4: including every one of you at home watching tonight
column5: is also committed to this cause. We must work together
column6: learn together
column7: live together
column8: serve together. On the forge of common enterprise
column9: Americans of all backgrounds can hammer out a common identity. We see it today in the United States military
column10: in the Peace Corps
column11: in AmeriCorps. Wherever people of all races and backgrounds come together in a shared endeavor and get a fair chance
column12: we do just fine. With shared values and meaningful opportunities and honest communication and citizen service
column13: we can unite a diverse people in freedom and mutual respect. We are many; we must be one.

column1: In that spirit
column2: let us lift our eyes to the new millennium. How will we mark that passage? It just happens once every 1
column3: 000 years. This year Hillary and I launched the White House Millennium Program to promote America's creativity and innovation
column4: and to preserve our heritage and culture into the 21st century. Our culture lives in every community
column5: and every community has places of historic value that tell our stories as Americans. We should protect them. I am proposing a public-private partnership to advance our arts and humanities and to celebrate the millennium by saving American's treasures
column6: great and small.

column1: And while we honor the past
column2: let us imagine the future. Now
column3: think about this: The entire store of human knowledge now doubles every 5 years. In the 1980's
column4: scientists identified the gene causing cystic fibrosis; it took 9 years. Last year scientists located the gene that causes Parkinson's disease in only 9 days. Within a decade
column5: "gene chips" will offer a roadmap for prevention of illnesses throughout a lifetime. Soon we'll be able to carry all the phone calls on Mother's Day on a single strand of fiber the width of a human hair. A child born in 1998 may well live to see the 22d century.

column1: Tonight
column2: as part of our gift to the millennium
column3: I propose a 21st century research fund for pathbreaking scientific inquiry
column4: the largest funding increase in history for the National Institutes of Health
column5: the National Science Foundation
column6: the National Cancer Institute. We have already discovered genes for breast cancer and diabetes. I ask you to support this initiative so ours will be the generation that finally wins the war against cancer and begins a revolution in our fight against all deadly diseases.

column1: As important as all this scientific progress is
column2: we must continue to see that science serves humanity
column3: not the other way around. We must prevent the misuse of genetic tests to discriminate against any American. And we must ratify the ethical consensus of the scientific and religious communities and ban the cloning of human beings.

column1: We should enable all the world's people to explore the far reaches of cyberspace. Think of this: The first time I made a State of the Union speech to you
column2: only a handful of physicists used the World Wide Webliterally
column3: just a handful of people. Now
column4: in schools
column5: in libraries
column6: homes
column7: and businesses
column8: millions and millions of Americans surf the Net every day. We must give parents the tools they need to help protect their children from inappropriate material on the Internet
column9: but we also must make sure that we protect the exploding global commercial potential of the Internet. We can do the kinds of things that we need to do and still protect our kids. For one thing
column10: I ask Congress to step up support for building the next generation Internet. It's getting kind of clogged
column11: you know
column12: and the next generation Internet will operate at speeds up to 1
column13: 000 times faster than today.

column1: Even as we explore this inner space in the new millennium
column2: we're going to open new frontiers in outer space. Throughout all history
column3: humankind has had only one place to call home
column4: our planet
column5: Earth. Beginning this year
column7: men and women from 16 countries will build a foothold in the heavens
column8: the international space station. With its vast expanses
column9: scientists and engineers will actually set sail on an uncharted sea of limitless mystery and unlimited potential.

column1: And this October
column2: a true American hero
column3: a veteran pilot of 149 combat missions and one 5-hour space flight that changed the world
column4: will return to the heavens. Godspeed
column5: John Glenn.  John
column6: you will carry with you America's hopes. And on your uniform
column7: once again
column8: you will carry America's flag
column9: marking the unbroken connection between the deeds of America's past and the daring of America's future.

column1: Nearly 200 years ago
column2: a tattered flag
column3: its broad stripes and bright stars still gleaming through the smoke of a fierce battle
column4: moved Francis Scott Key to scribble a few words on the back of an envelope
column5: the words that became our national anthem. Today
column6: that Star-Spangled Banner
column7: along with the Declaration of Independence
column8: the Constitution
column9: and the Bill of Rights
column10: are on display just a short walk from here. They are America's treasures
column11: and we must also save them for the ages.

column1: I ask all Americans to support our project to restore all our treasures so that the generations of the 21st century can see for themselves the images and the words that are the old and continuing glory of America
column2: an America that has continued to rise through every age
column3: against every challenge
column4: a people of great works and greater possibilities
column5: who have always
column6: always found the wisdom and strength to come together as one nation to widen the circle of opportunity
column7: to deepen the meaning of our freedom
column8: to form that more perfect Union. Let that be our gift to the 21st century.

column1: God bless you
column2: and God bless the United States.@

column1: William J. Clinton|Address Before a Joint Session of the Congress on the State of the Union|1999-01-19|@Mr. Speaker
column2: Mr. Vice President
column3: Members of Congress
column4: honored guests
column5: my fellow Americans: Tonight I have the honor of reporting to you on the State of the Union.

column1: Let me begin by saluting the new Speaker of the House and thanking him especially tonight for extending an invitation to two guests sitting in the gallery with Mrs. Hastert: Lyn Gibson and Wenling Chestnut are the widows of the two brave Capitol Hill police officers who gave their lives to defend freedom's house.
Mr. Speaker
column2: at your swearing-in
column3: you asked us all to work together in a spirit of civility and bipartisanship. Mr. Speaker
column4: let's do exactly that.

column1: Tonight I stand before you to report that America has created the longest peacetime economic expansion in our history with nearly 18 million new jobs
column2: wages rising at more than twice the rate of inflation
column3: the highest homeownership in history
column4: the smallest welfare rolls in 30 years
column5: and the lowest peacetime unemployment since 1957.

column1: For the first time in three decades
column2: the budget is balanced. From a deficit of $290 billion in 1992
column3: we had a surplus of $70 billion last year. And now we are on course for budget surpluses for the next 25 years.

column1: Thanks to the pioneering leadership of all of you
column2: we have the lowest violent crime rate in a quarter century and the cleanest environment in a quarter century. America is a strong force for peace from Northern Ireland to Bosnia to the Middle East.

column1: Thanks to the leadership of Vice President Gore
column2: we have a Government for the information age
column3: once again
column4: a Government that is a progressive instrument of the common good rooted in our oldest values of opportunity
column5: responsibility
column6: and community; devoted to fiscal responsibility; determined to give our people the tools they need to make the most of their own lives in the 21st centurya 21st century Government for 21st century America.

column1: My fellow Americans
column2: I stand before you tonight to report that the state of our Union is strong.

column1: Now
column2: America is working again. The promise of our future is limitless. But we cannot realize that promise if we allow the hum of our prosperity to lull us into complacency. How we fare as a nation far into the 21st century depends upon what we do as a nation today. So with our budget surplus growing
column3: our economy expanding
column4: our confidence rising
column5: now is the moment for this generation to meet our historic responsibility to the 21st century.

column1: Our fiscal discipline gives us an unsurpassed opportunity to address a remarkable new challenge
column2: the aging of America. With the number of elderly Americans set to double by 2030
column3: the baby boom will become a senior boom. So first
column4: and above all
column5: we must save Social Security for the 21st century.

column1: Early in this century
column2: being old meant being poor. When President Roosevelt created Social Security
column3: thousands wrote to thank him for eliminating what one woman called "the stark terror of penniless
column4: helpless old age." Even today
column5: without Social Security
column6: half our Nation's elderly would be forced into poverty.

column1: Today
