column2: Social Security is strong. But by 2013
column3: payroll taxes will no longer be sufficient to cover monthly payments. By 2032
column4: the Trust Fund will be exhausted and Social Security will be unable to pay the full benefits older Americans have been promised.

column1: The best way to keep Social Security a rocksolid guarantee is not to make drastic cuts in benefits
column2: not to raise payroll tax rates
column3: not to drain resources from Social Security in the name of saving it. Instead
column4: I propose that we make the historic decision to invest the surplus to save Social Security.

column1: Specifically
column2: I propose that we commit 60 percent of the budget surplus for the next 15 years to Social Security
column3: investing a small portion in the private sector
column4: just as any private or State Government pension would do. This will earn a higher return and keep Social Security sound for 55 years.

column1: But we must aim higher. We should put Social Security on a sound footing for the next 75 years. We should reduce poverty among elderly women
column2: who are nearly twice as likely to be poor as our other seniors. And we should eliminate the limits on what seniors on Social Security can earn.

column1: Now
column2: these changes will require difficult but fully achievable choices
column3: over and above the dedication of the surplus. They must be made on a bipartisan basis. They should be made this year. So let me say to you tonight
column4: I reach out my hand to all of you in both Houses
column5: in both parties
column6: and ask that we join together in saying to the American people: We will save Social Security now.

column1: Now
column2: last year we wisely reserved all of the surplus until we knew what it would take to save Social Security. Again
column3: I say
column4: we shouldn't spend any of it
column5: not any of it
column6: until after Social Security is truly saved. First things first.

column1: Second
column2: once we have saved Social Security
column3: we must fulfill our obligation to save and improve Medicare. Already
column4: we have extended the life of the Medicare Trust Fund by 10 years
column5: but we should extend it for at least another decade. Tonight I propose that we use one out of every $6 in the surplus for the next 15 years to guarantee the soundness of Medicare until the year 2020.

column1: But again
column2: we should aim higher. We must be willing to work in a bipartisan way and look at new ideas
column3: including the upcoming report of the bipartisan Medicare Commission. If we work together
column4: we can secure Medicare for the next two decades and cover the greatest growing need of seniors
column5: affordable prescription drugs.

column1: Third
column2: we must help all Americans
column3: from their first day on the job
column4: to save
column5: to invest
column6: to create wealth. From its beginning
column7: Americans have supplemented Social Security with private pensions and savings. Yet today
column8: millions of people retire with little to live on other than Social Security. Americans living longer than ever simply must save more than ever.

column1: Therefore
column2: in addition to saving Social Security and Medicare
column3: I propose a new pension initiative for retirement security in the 21st century. I propose that we use a little over 11 percent of the surplus to establish universal savings accountsUSA accountsto give all Americans the means to save. With these new accounts
column4: Americans can invest as they choose and receive funds to match a portion of their savings
column5: with extra help for those least able to save. USA accounts will help all Americans to share in our Nation's wealth and to enjoy a more secure retirement. I ask you to support them.

column1: Fourth
column2: we must invest in long-term care. I propose a tax credit of $1
column3: 000 for the aged
column4: ailing or disabled
column5: and the families who care for them. Long-term care will become a bigger and bigger challenge with the aging of America
column6: and we must do more to help our families deal with it.

column1: I was born in 1946
column2: the first year of the baby boom. I can tell you that one of the greatest concerns of our generation is our absolute determination not to let our growing old place an intolerable burden on our children and their ability to raise our grandchildren. Our economic success and our fiscal discipline now give us an opportunity to lift that burden from their shoulders
column3: and we should take it.

column1: Saving Social Security
column2: Medicare
column3: creating USA accounts
column4: this is the right way to use the surplus. If we do soif we do sowe will still have resources to meet critical needs in education and defense. And I want to point out that this proposal is fiscally sound. Listen to this: If we set aside 60 percent of the surplus for Social Security and 16 percent for Medicare
column5: over the next 15 years
column6: that saving will achieve the lowest level of publicly held debt since right before World War I

column1: So with these four measuressaving Social Security
column2: strengthening Medicare
column3: establishing the USA accounts
column4: supporting long-term care we can begin to meet our generation's historic responsibility to establish true security for 21st century seniors.

column1: Now
column2: there are more children from more diverse backgrounds in our public schools than at any time in our history. Their education must provide the knowledge and nurture the creativity that will allow our entire Nation to thrive in the new economy.

column1: Today we can say something we couldn't say 6 years ago: With tax credits and more affordable student loans
column2: with more work-study grants and more Pell grants
column3: with education IRA's and the new HOPE scholarship tax cut that more than 5 million Americans will receive this year
column4: we have finally opened the doors of college to all Americans.

column1: With our support
column2: nearly every State has set higher academic standards for public schools
column3: and a voluntary national test is being developed to measure the progress of our students. With over $1 billion in discounts available this year
column4: we are well on our way to our goal of connecting every classroom and library to the Internet.

column1: Last fall
column2: you passed our proposal to start hiring 100
column3: 000 new teachers to reduce class size in the early grades. Now I ask you to finish the job.

column1: You know
column2: our children are doing better. SAT scores are up; math scores have risen in nearly all grades. But there's a problem. While our fourth graders outperform their peers in other countries in math and science
column3: our eighth graders are around average
column4: and our twelfth graders rank near the bottom. We must do better. Now
column5: each year the National Government invests more than $15 billion in our public schools. I believe we must change the way we invest that money
column6: to support what works and to stop supporting what does not work.

column1: First
column2: later this year
column3: I will send to Congress a plan that
column4: for the first time
column5: holds States and school districts accountable for progress and rewards them for results. My "Education Accountability Act" will require every school district receiving Federal help to take the following five steps.

column1: First
column2: all schools must end social promotion. No child should graduate from high school with a diploma he or she can't read. We do our children no favors when we allow them to pass from grade to grade without mastering the material. But we can't just hold students back because the system fails them. So my balanced budget triples the funding for summer school and after-school programs
column3: to keep a million children learning.

column1: Now
column2: if you doubt this will work
column3: just look at Chicago
column4: which ended social promotion and made summer school mandatory for those who don't master the basics. Math and reading scores are up 3 years running
column5: with some of the biggest gains in some of the poorest neighborhoods. It will work
column6: and we should do it.

column1: Second
column2: all States and school districts must turn around their worst performing schools or shut them down. That's the policy established in North Carolina by Governor Jim Hunt. North Carolina made the biggest gains in test scores in the Nation last year. Our budget includes $200 million to help States turn around their own failing schools.

column1: Third
column2: all States and school districts must be held responsible for the quality of their teachers. The great majority of our teachers do a fine job. But in too many schools
column3: teachers don't have college majors or even minors in the subjects they teach. New teachers should be required to pass performance exams
column4: and all teachers should know the subjects they're teaching. This year's balanced budget contains resources to help them reach higher standards.

column1: And to attract talented young teachers to the toughest assignments
column2: I recommend a sixfold increase in our program for college scholarships for students who commit to teach in the inner cities and isolated rural areas and in Indian communities. Let us bring excellence to every part of America.

column1: Fourth
column2: we must empower parents with more information and more choices. In too many communities
column3: it's easier to get information on the quality of the local restaurants than on the quality of the local schools. Every school district should issue report cards on every school. And parents should be given more choices in selecting their public school. When I became President
column4: there was just one independent public charter school in all America. With our support
column5: on a bipartisan basis
column6: today there are 1
column7: 100. My budget assures that early in the next century
column8: there will be 3

column1: Fifth
column2: to assure that our classrooms are truly places of learning and to respond to what teachers have been asking us to do for years
column3: we should say that all States and school districts must both adopt and implement sensible discipline policies.

column1: Now
column2: let's do one more thing for our children. Today
column3: too many schools are so old they're falling apart
column4: or so over-crowded students are learning in trailers. Last fall
column5: Congress missed the opportunity to change that. This year
column6: with 53 million children in our schools
column7: Congress must not miss that opportunity again. I ask you to help our communities build or modernize 5
column8: 000 schools.

column1: If we do these thingsend social promotion; turn around failing schools; build modern ones; support qualified teachers; promote innovation
column2: competition and disciplinethen we will begin to meet our generation's historic responsibility to create 21st century schools.

column1: Now
column2: we also have to do more to support the millions of parents who give their all every day at home and at work. The most basic tool of all is a decent income. So let's raise the minimum wage by a dollar an hour over the next 2 years. And let's make sure that women and men get equal pay for equal work by strengthening enforcement of equal pay laws.  That was encouraging
column3: you know.  There was more balance on the seesaw. I like that. Let's give them a hand. That's great.

column1: Working parents also need quality child care. So again this year
column2: I ask Congress to support our plan for tax credits and subsidies for working families
column3: for improved safety and quality
column4: for expanded after-school programs. And our plan also includes a new tax credit for stayat-home parents
column5: too. They need support
column6: as well.

column1: Parents should never have to worry about choosing between their children and their work. Now
column2: the Family and Medical Leave Act
column3: the very first bill I signed into law
column4: has now
column5: since 1993
column6: helped millions and millions of Americans to care for a newborn baby or an ailing relative without risking their jobs. I think it's time
column7: with all the evidence that it has been so little burdensome to employers
column8: to extend family leave to 10 million more Americans working for smaller companies. And I hope you will support it.

column1: Finally on the matter of work
column2: parents should never have to face discrimination in the workplace. So I want to ask Congress to prohibit companies from refusing to hire or promote workers simply because they have children. That is not right.

column1: America's families deserve the world's best medical care. Thanks to bipartisan Federal support for medical research
column2: we are now on the verge of new treatments to prevent or delay diseases
column3: from Parkinson's to Alzheimer's to arthritis to cancer. But as we continue our advances in medical science
column4: we can't let our medical system lag behind. Managed care has literally transformed medicine in America
column5: driving down costs but threatening to drive down quality as well.

column1: I think we ought to say to every American: You should have the right to know all your medical options
column2: not just the cheapest. If you need a specialist
column3: you should have a right to see one. You have a right to the nearest emergency care if you're in an accident. These are things that we ought to say. And I think we ought to say: You should have a right to keep your doctor during a period of treatment
column4: whether it's a pregnancy or a chemotherapy treatment
column5: or anything else. I believe this.

column1: Now
column2: I've ordered these rights to be extended to the 85 million Americans served by Medicare
column3: Medicaid
column4: and other Federal health programs. But only Congress can pass a Patients' Bill of Rights for all Americans. Now
column5: last year
column6: Congress missed that opportunity
column7: and we must not miss that opportunity again. For the sake of our families
column8: I ask us to join together across party lines and pass a strong
column9: enforceable Patients' Bill of Rights.

column1: As more of our medical records are stored electronically
column2: the threats to all our privacy increase. Because Congress has given me the authority to act if it does not do so by August
column3: one way or another
column4: we can all say to the American people
column5: "We will protect the privacy of medical records
column6: and we will do it this year."

column1: Now 2 years ago
column2: the Congress extended health coverage to up to 5 million children. Now we should go beyond that. We should make it easier for small businesses to offer health insurance. We should give people between the ages of 55 and 65 who lose their health insurance the chance to buy into Medicare. And we should continue to ensure access to family planning.

column1: No one should have to choose between keeping health care and taking a job. And therefore
column2: I especially ask you tonight to join hands to pass the landmark bipartisan legislation proposed by Senators Kennedy and Jeffords
column3: Roth
column4: and Moynihan to allow people with disabilities to keep their health insurance when they go to work.

column1: We need to enable our public hospitals
column2: our community
column3: our university health centers to provide basic
column4: affordable care for all the millions of working families who don't have any insurance. They do a lot of that today
column5: but much more can be done. And my balanced budget makes a good downpayment toward that goal. I hope you will think about them and support that provision.

column1: Let me say we must step up our efforts to treat and prevent mental illness. No American should ever be afraideverto address this disease. This year we will host a White House Conference on Mental Health. With sensitivity
column2: commitment
column3: and passion
column4: Tipper Gore is leading our efforts here
column5: and I'd like to thank her for what she's done. Thank you.  Thank you.

column1: As everyone knows
column2: our children are targets of a massive media campaign to hook them on cigarettes. Now
column3: I ask this Congress to resist the tobacco lobby
column4: to reaffirm the FDA's authority to protect our children from tobacco
column5: and to hold tobacco companies accountable while protecting tobacco farmers.

column1: Smoking has cost taxpayers hundreds of billions of dollars under Medicare and other programs. You know
column2: the States have been right about this: Taxpayers shouldn't pay for the cost of lung cancer
column3: emphysema
column4: and other smokingrelated illnesses; the tobacco companies should. So tonight I announce that the Justice Department is preparing a litigation plan to take the tobacco companies to court and
column5: with the funds we recover
column6: to strengthen Medicare.

column1: Now
column2: if we act in these areasminimum wage
column3: family leave
column4: child care
column5: health care
column6: the safety of our childrenthen we will begin to meet our generation's historic responsibility to strengthen our families for the 21st century.

column1: Today
column2: America is the most dynamic
column3: competitive
column4: job-creating economy in history. But we can do even better in building a 21st century economy that embraces all Americans.

column1: Today's income gap is largely a skills gap. Last year
column2: the Congress passed a law enabling workers to get a skills grant to choose the training they need. And I applaud all of you here who were part of that. This year
column3: I recommend a 5-year commitment to the new system so that we can provide
column4: over the next 5 years
column5: appropriate training opportunities for all Americans who lose their jobs and expand rapid response teams to help all towns which have been really hurt when businesses close. I hope you will support this.

column1: Also
column2: I ask your support for a dramatic increase in Federal support for adult literacy
column3: to mount a national campaign aimed at helping the millions and millions of working people who still read at less than a fifth grade level. We need to do this.

column1: Here's some good news: In the past 6 years
column2: we have cut the welfare rolls nearly in half. You can all be proud of that. Two years ago
column3: from this podium
column4: I asked five companies to lead a national effort to hire people off welfare. Tonight
column5: our Welfare to Work Partnership includes 10
column6: 000 companies who have hired hundreds of thousands of people. And our balanced budget will help another 200
column7: 000 people move to the dignity and pride of work. I hope you will support it.

column1: We must do more to bring the spark of private enterprise to every corner of America
column2: to build a bridge from Wall Street to Appalachia to the Mississippi Delta to our Native American communities
column3: with more support for community development banks
column4: for empowerment zones
column5: for 100
column6: 000 more vouchers for affordable housing. And I ask Congress to support our bold new plan to help businesses raise up to $15 billion in private sector capital to bring jobs and opportunities to our inner cities and rural areas with tax credits
column7: loan guarantees
column8: including the new "American Private Investment Company" modeled on the Overseas Private Investment Company. For years and years and years
column9: we've had this OPIC
column10: this Overseas Private Investment Corporation
column11: because we knew we had untapped markets overseas. But our greatest untapped markets are not overseas; they are right here at home. And we should go after them.

column1: We must work hard to help bring prosperity back to the family farm. As this Congress knows very well
column2: dropping prices and the loss of foreign markets have devastated too many family farms. Last year
column3: the Congress provided substantial assistance to help stave off a disaster in American agriculture. And I am ready to work with lawmakers of both parties to create a farm safety net that will include crop insurance reform and farm income assistance. I ask you to join with me and do this. This should not be a political issue. Everyone knows what an economic problem is going on out there in rural America today
column4: and we need an appropriate means to address it.

column1: We must strengthen our lead in technology. It was Government investment that led to the creation of the Internet. I propose a 28-percent increase in long-term computing research. We also must be ready for the 21st century from its very first moment
column2: by solving the so-called Y2K computer problem.

column1: We had one Member of Congress stand up and applaud.  And we may have about that ratio out there applauding at home
column2: in front of their television sets. But remember
column3: this is a big
column4: big problem. And we've been working hard on it. Already
column5: we've made sure that the Social Security checks will come on time. But I want all the folks at home listening to this to know that we need every State and local government
column6: every business
column7: large and small
column8: to work with us to make sure that this Y2K computer bug will be remembered as the last headache of the 20th century
column9: not the first crisis of the 21st.

column1: For our own prosperity
column2: we must support economic growth abroad. You know
column3: until recently
column4: a third of our economic growth came from exports. But over the past year and a half
column5: financial turmoil overseas has put that growth at risk. Today
column6: much of the world is in recession
column7: with Asia hit especially hard. This is the most serious financial crisis in half a century. To meet it
column8: the United States and other nations have reduced interest rates and strengthened the International Monetary Fund. And while the turmoil is not over
column9: we have worked very hard with other nations to contain it.

column1: At the same time
column2: we have to continue to work on the long-term project
column3: building a global financial system for the 21st century that promotes prosperity and tames the cycle of boom and bust that has engulfed so much of Asia. This June I will meet with other world leaders to advance this historic purpose
column4: and I ask all of you to support our endeavors.

column1: I also ask you to support creating a freer and fairer trading system for 21st century America. I'd like to say something really serious to everyone in this Chamber in both parties. I think trade has divided us
column2: and divided Americans outside this Chamber
column3: for too long. Somehow we have to find a common ground on which business and workers and environmentalists and farmers and Government can stand together. I believe these are the things we ought to all agree on. So let me try.

column1: First
column2: we ought to tear down barriers
column3: open markets
column4: and expand trade. But at the same time
column5: we must ensure that ordinary citizens in all countries actually benefit from trade
column6: a trade that promotes the dignity of work and the rights of workers and protects the environment. We must insist that international trade organizations be more open to public scrutiny
column7: instead of mysterious
column8: secret things subject to wild criticism. When you come right down to it
column9: now that the world economy is becoming more and more integrated
column10: we have to do in the world what we spent the better part of this century doing here at home. We have got to put a human face on the global economy.

column1: We must enforce our trade laws when imports unlawfully flood our Nation. I have already informed the Government of Japan that if that nation's sudden surge of steel imports into our country is not reversed
column2: America will respond.

column1: We must help all manufacturers hit hard by the present crisis with loan guarantees and other incentives to increase American exports by nearly $2 billion.
I'd like to believe we can achieve a new consensus on trade
column2: based on these principles. And I ask the Congress again to join me in this common approach and to give the President the trade authority long used and now overdue and necessary to advance our prosperity in the 21st century.

column1: Tonight I issue a call to the nations of the world to join the United States in a new round of global trade negotiations to expand exports of services
column2: manufactures
column3: and farm products. Tonight I say we will work with the International Labor Organization on a new initiative to raise labor standards around the world. And this year
column4: we will lead the international community to conclude a treaty to ban abusive child labor everywhere in the world.

column1: If we do these thingsinvest in our people
column2: our communities
column3: our technology
column4: and lead in the global economythen we will begin to meet our historic responsibility to build a 21st century prosperity for America.

column1: You know
column2: no nation in history has had the opportunity and the responsibility we now have to shape a world that is more peaceful
column3: more secure
column4: more free. All Americans can be proud that our leadership helped to bring peace in Northern Ireland. All Americans can be proud that our leadership has put Bosnia on the path to peace. And with our NATO allies
column5: we are pressing the Serbian Government to stop its brutal repression in Kosovo
column6: to bring those responsible to justice
column7: and to give the people of Kosovo the self-government they deserve.

column1: All Americans can be proud that our leadership renewed hope for lasting peace in the Middle East. Some of you were with me last December as we watched the Palestinian National Council completely renounce its call for the destruction of Israel. Now I ask Congress to provide resources so that all parties can implement the Wye agreement to protect Israel's security
column2: to stimulate the Palestinian economy
column3: to support our friends in Jordan. We must notwe dare notlet them down. I hope you will help.

column1: As we work for peace
column2: we must also meet threats to our Nation's security
column3: including increased dangers from outlaw nations and terrorism. We will defend our security wherever we are threatened
column4: as we did this summer when we struck at Usama bin Ladin's network of terror. The bombing of our Embassies in Kenya and Tanzania reminds us again of the risks faced every day by those who represent America to the world. So let's give them the support they need
column5: the safest possible workplaces
column6: and the resources they must have so America can continue to lead.

column1: We must work to keep terrorists from disrupting computer networks. We must work to prepare local communities for biological and chemical emergencies
column2: to support research into vaccines and treatments.

column1: We must increase our efforts to restrain the spread of nuclear weapons and missiles
column2: from Korea to India and Pakistan. We must expand our work with Russia
column3: Ukraine
column4: and other former Soviet nations to safeguard nuclear materials and technology so they never fall into the wrong hands. Our balanced budget will increase funding for these critical efforts by almost two-thirds over the next 5 years.

column1: With Russia
column2: we must continue to reduce our nuclear arsenals. The START II treaty and the framework we have already agreed to for START III could cut them by 80 percent from their cold war height.

column1: It's been 2 years since I signed the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty. If we don't do the right thing
column2: other nations won't either. I ask the Senate to take this vital step: Approve the treaty now
column3: to make it harder for other nations to develop nuclear arms
column4: and to make sure we can end nuclear testing forever.

column1: For nearly a decade
column2: Iraq has defied its obligations to destroy its weapons of terror and the missiles to deliver them. America will continue to contain Saddam
column3: and we will work for the day when Iraq has a Government worthy of its people.

column1: Now
column2: last month in our action over Iraq

column4: a 10-year veteran of the Air Force
column5: flew a B-1B bomber over Iraq as we attacked Saddam's war machine. He's here with us tonight. I'd like to ask you to honor him and all the 33

column1: Captain Taliaferro.
It is time to reverse the decline in defense spending that began in 1985. Since April
column2: together we have added nearly $6 billion to maintain our military readiness. My balanced budget calls for a sustained increase over the next 6 years for readiness
column3: for modernization
column4: and for pay and benefits for our troops and their families. We are the heirs of a legacy of bravery represented in every community in America by millions of our veterans. America's defenders today still stand ready at a moment's notice to go where comforts are few and dangers are many
column5: to do what needs to be done as no one else can. They always come through for America. We must come through for them.

column1: The new century demands new partnerships for peace and security. The United Nations plays a crucial role
column2: with allies sharing burdens America might otherwise bear alone. America needs a strong and effective U.N. I want to work with this new Congress to pay our dues and our debts.

column1: We must continue to support security and stability in Europe and Asia

column4: with Korea
column5: with our other Asian allies
column6: and engaging China.

column2: last year

column4: strengthen democracy and increase trade. In this hemisphere

column3: they saw thousands of our troops and thousands of American volunteers.

column4: increase our strength
column5: renew our allianceswe will begin to meet our generation's historic responsibility to build a stronger 21st century America in a freer

column2: so have our own communities. We must make them safer
column3: more livable
column4: and more united. This year

column8: and stalkers from buying handguns. And now
column9: the murder rate is the lowest in 30 years and the crime rate has dropped for 6 straight years.

column1: Tonight I propose a 21st century crime bill to deploy the latest technologies and tactics to make our communities even safer. Our balanced budget will help put up to 50
column2: 000 more police on the street in the areas hardest hit by crime and then to equip them with new tools
column3: from crime-mapping computers to digital mug shots.

column1: We must break the deadly cycle of drugs and crime. Our budget expands support for drug testing and treatment
column2: saying to prisoners: If you stay on drugs
column3: you have to stay behind bars; and to those on parole: If you want to keep your freedom
column4: you must stay free of drugs.

column1: I ask Congress to restore the 5-day waiting period for buying a handgun and extend the Brady bill to prevent juveniles who commit violent crimes from buying a gun.
We must do more to keep our schools the safest places in our communities. Last year
column2: every American was horrified and heartbroken by the tragic killings in Jonesboro
column3: Paducah
column4: Pearl
column5: Edinboro
column6: Springfield. We were deeply moved by the courageous parents now working to keep guns out of the hands of children and to make other efforts so that other parents don't have to live through their loss.

column1: After she lost her daughter
column2: Suzann Wilson of Jonesboro
column3: Arkansas
column4: came here to the White House with a powerful plea. She said
column5: "Please
column6: please
column7: for the sake of your children
column8: lock up your guns. Don't let what happened in Jonesboro happen in your town." It's a message she is passionately advocating every day. Suzann is here with us tonight
column9: with the First Lady. I'd like to thank her for her courage and her commitment.  Thank you.

column1: In memory of all the children who lost their lives to school violence
column2: I ask you to strengthen the Safe and Drug-Free School Act
column3: to pass legislation to require child trigger locks
column4: to do everything possible to keep our children safe.

column1: A century ago
column2: President Theodore Roosevelt defined our "great
column3: central task" as "leaving this land even a better land for our descendants than it is for us." Today
column4: we're restoring the Florida Everglades
column5: saving Yellowstone
column6: preserving the red rock canyons of Utah
column7: protecting California's redwoods and our precious coasts. But our most fateful new challenge is the threat of global warming; 1998 was the warmest year ever recorded. Last year's heat waves
column8: floods
column9: and storms are but a hint of what future generations may endure if we do not act now.

column1: Tonight I propose a new clean air fund to help communities reduce greenhouse and other pollution
column2: and tax incentives and investments to spur clean energy technology. And I want to work with Members of Congress in both parties to reward companies that take early
column3: voluntary action to reduce greenhouse gases.

column1: All our communities face a preservation challenge
column2: as they grow and green space shrinks. Seven thousand acres of farmland and open space are lost every day. In response
column3: I propose two major initiatives: First
column4: a $1-billion livability agenda to help communities save open space
column5: ease traffic congestion
column6: and grow in ways that enhance every citizen's quality of life; and second
column7: a $1-billion lands legacy initiative to preserve places of natural beauty all across America
column8: from the most remote wilderness to the nearest city park.

column1: These are truly landmark initiatives
column2: which could not have been developed without the visionary leadership of the Vice President
column3: and I want to thank him very much for his commitment here.

column1: Now
column2: to get the most out of your community
column3: you have to give something back. That's why we created AmeriCorps
column4: our national service program that gives today's generation a chance to serve their communities and earn money for college.

column1: So far
column2: in just 4 years
column4: 000 young Americans have built low-income homes with Habitat for Humanity
column5: helped to tutor children with churches
column6: worked with FEMA to ease the burden of natural disasters
column7: and performed countless other acts of service that have made America better. I ask Congress to give more young Americans the chance to follow their lead and serve America in AmeriCorps.

column1: Now
column2: we must work to renew our national community as well for the 21st century. Last year the House passed the bipartisan campaign finance reform legislation sponsored by Representatives Shays and Meehan and Senators McCain and Feingold. But a partisan minority in the Senate blocked reform. So I'd like to say to the House: Pass it again
column3: quickly. And I'd like to say to the Senate: I hope you will say yes to a stronger American democracy in the year 2000.

column1: Since 1997
column2: our initiative on race has sought to bridge the divides between and among our people. In its report last fall
column3: the initiative's advisory board found that Americans really do want to bring our people together across racial lines.

column1: We know it's been a long journey. For some
column2: it goes back to before the beginning of our Republic; for others
column3: back since the Civil War; for others
column4: throughout the 20th century. But for most of us alive today
column5: in a very real sense
column6: this journey began 43 years ago
column7: when a woman named Rosa Parks sat down on a bus in Alabama and wouldn't get up. She's sitting down with the First Lady tonight
column8: and she may get up or not
column9: as she chooses. We thank her.  Thank you
column10: Rosa.

column1: We know that our continuing racial problems are aggravated
column2: as the Presidential initiative said
column3: by opportunity gaps. The initiative I've outlined tonight will help to close them. But we know that the discrimination gap has not been fully closed either. Discrimination or violence because of race or religion
column4: ancestry or gender
column5: disability or sexual orientation
column6: is wrong
column7: and it ought to be illegal. Therefore
column8: I ask Congress to make the "Employment Non-Discrimination Act" and the "Hate Crimes Prevention Act" the law of the land.

column1: Now
column2: since every person in America counts
column3: every American ought to be counted. We need a census that uses modern scientific methods to do that.

column1: Our new immigrants must be part of our One America. After all
column2: they're revitalizing our cities; they're energizing our culture; they're building up our economy. We have a responsibility to make them welcome here
column3: and they have a responsibility to enter the mainstream of American life. That means learning English and learning about our democratic system of government. There are now long waiting lines of immigrants that are trying to do just that. Therefore
column4: our budget significantly expands our efforts to help them meet their responsibility. I hope you will support it.

column1: Whether our ancestors came here on the Mayflower
column2: on slave ships
column3: whether they came to Ellis Island or LAX in Los Angeles
column4: whether they came yesterday or walked this land a thousand years ago
column5: our great challenge for the 21st century is to find a way to be one America. We can meet all the other challenges if we can go forward as one America.

column1: You know
column2: barely more than 300 days from now
column3: we will cross that bridge into the new millennium. This is a moment
column4: as the First Lady has said
column5: "to honor the past and imagine the future."

column1: I'd like to take just a minute to honor her. For leading our Millennium Project
column2: for all she's done for our children
column3: for all she has done in her historic role to serve our Nation and our best ideals at home and abroad
column4: I honor her.

column1: Last year
column2: I called on Congress and every citizen to mark the millennium by saving America's treasures. Hillary has traveled all across the country to inspire recognition and support for saving places like Thomas Edison's invention factory or Harriet Tubman's home. Now we have to preserve our treasures in every community. And tonight
column3: before I close
column4: I want to invite every town
column5: every city
column6: every community to become a nationally recognized "millennium community" by launching projects that save our history
column7: promote our arts and humanities
column8: prepare our children for the 21st century.

column1: Already
column2: the response has been remarkable. And I want to say a special word of thanks to our private sector partners and to Members in Congress of both parties for their support. Just one example: Because of you
column3: the Star-Spangled Banner will be preserved for the ages. In ways large and small
column4: as we look to the millennium we are keeping alive what George Washington called "the sacred fire of liberty."

column1: Six years ago
column2: I came to office in a time of doubt for America
column3: with our economy troubled
column4: our deficit high
column5: our people divided. Some even wondered whether our best days were behind us. But across this country
column6: in a thousand neighborhoods
column7: I have seen
column8: even amidst the pain and uncertainty of recession
column9: the real heart and character of America. I knew then that we Americans could renew this country.

column1: Tonight
column2: as I deliver the last State of the Union Address of the 20th century
column3: no one anywhere in the world can doubt the enduring resolve and boundless capacity of the American people to work toward that "more perfect Union" of our Founders' dream.

column1: We're now at the end of a century when generation after generation of Americans answered the call to greatness
column2: overcoming depression
column3: lifting up the disposed
column4: bringing down barriers to racial prejudice
column5: building the largest middle class in history
column6: winning two World Wars and the long twilight struggle of the cold war. We must all be profoundly grateful for the magnificent achievement of our forebears in this century. Yet perhaps
column7: in the daily press of events
column8: in the clash of controversy
column9: we don't see our own time for what it truly is
column10: a new dawn for America.

column1: A hundred years from tonight
column2: another American President will stand in this place and report on the state of the Union. Heor shehe or she will look back on a 21st century shaped in so many ways by the decisions we make here and now. So let it be said of us then that we were thinking not only of our time but of their time
column3: that we reached as high as our ideals
column4: that we put aside our divisions and found a new hour of healing and hopefulness
column5: that we joined together to serve and strengthen the land we love.

column1: My fellow Americans
column2: this is our moment. Let us lift our eyes as one Nation
column3: and from the mountaintop of this American Century
column4: look ahead to the next one
column5: asking God's blessing on our endeavors and on our beloved country.

column1: Thank you
column2: and good evening.@

column1: William J. Clinton|Address Before a Joint Session of the Congress on the State of the Union|2000-01-27|@Mr. Speaker
column2: Mr. Vice President
column3: Members of Congress
column4: honored guests
column5: my fellow Americans:

column1: We are fortunate to be alive at this moment in history. Never before has our Nation enjoyed
column2: at once
column3: so much prosperity and social progress with so little internal crisis and so few external threats. Never before have we had such a blessed opportunity and
column4: therefore
column5: such a profound obligation to build the more perfect Union of our Founders' dreams.

column1: We begin the new century with over 20 million new jobs; the fastest economic growth in more than 30 years; the lowest unemployment rates in 30 years; the lowest poverty rates in 20 years; the lowest African-American and Hispanic unemployment rates on record; the first back-to-back surpluses in 42 years; and next month
column2: America will achieve the longest period of economic growth in our entire history. We have built a new economy.

column1: And our economic revolution has been matched by a revival of the American spirit: crime down by 20 percent
column2: to its lowest level in 25 years; teen births down 7 years in a row; adoptions up by 30 percent; welfare rolls cut in half
column3: to their lowest levels in 30 years.

column1: My fellow Americans
column2: the state of our Union is the strongest it has ever been.

column1: As always
column2: the real credit belongs to the American people. My gratitude also goes to those of you in this Chamber who have worked with us to put progress over partisanship.

column1: Eight years ago
column2: it was not so clear to most Americans there would be much to celebrate in the year 2000. Then our Nation was gripped by economic distress
column3: social decline
column4: political gridlock. The title of a best-selling book asked: "America: What Went Wrong?"

column1: In the best traditions of our Nation
column2: Americans determined to set things right. We restored the vital center
column3: replacing outmoded ideologies with a new vision anchored in basic
column4: enduring values: opportunity for all
column5: responsibility from all
column6: a community of all Americans. We reinvented Government
column7: transforming it into a catalyst for new ideas that stress both opportunity and responsibility and give our people the tools they need to solve their own problems.

column1: With the smallest Federal work force in 40 years
column2: we turned record deficits into record surpluses and doubled our investment in education. We cut crime with 100
column3: 000 community police and the Brady law
column4: which has kept guns out of the hands of half a million criminals.

column1: We ended welfare as we knew it
column2: requiring work while protecting health care and nutrition for children and investing more in child care
column3: transportation
column4: and housing to help their parents go to work. We've helped parents to succeed at home and at work with family leave
column5: which 20 million Americans have now used to care for a newborn child or a sick loved one. We've engaged 150
column6: 000 young Americans in citizen service through AmeriCorps
column7: while helping them earn money for college.

column2: we just had a roadmap. Today
column3: we have results.

column1: Even more important
column2: America again has the confidence to dream big dreams. But we must not let this confidence drift into complacency. For we
column3: all of us
column4: will be judged by the dreams and deeds we pass on to our children. And on that score
column5: we will be held to a high standard
column6: indeed
column7: because our chance to do good is so great.

column1: My fellow Americans
column2: we have crossed the bridge we built to the 21st century. Now
column3: we must shape a 21st century American revolution of opportunity
column4: responsibility
column5: and community. We must be now
column6: as we were in the beginning
column7: a new nation.

column1: At the dawn of the last century
column2: Theodore Roosevelt said
column3: "The one characteristic more essential than any other is foresight . . . it should be the growing Nation with a future that takes the long look ahead." So tonight let us take our long look ahead and set great goals for our Nation.

column1: To 21st century America
column2: let us pledge these things: Every child will begin school ready to learn and graduate ready to succeed. Every family will be able to succeed at home and at work
column3: and no child will be raised in poverty. We will meet the challenge of the aging of America. We will assure quality
column4: affordable health care
column5: at last
column6: for all Americans. We will make America the safest big country on Earth. We will pay off our national debt for the first time since 1835.* We will bring prosperity to every American community. We will reverse the course of climate change and leave a safer
column7: cleaner planet. America will lead the world toward shared peace and prosperity and the far frontiers of science and technology. And we will become at last what our Founders pledged us to be so long ago: One Nation
column8: under God
column9: indivisible
column10: with liberty and justice for all.

column1: These are great goals
column2: worthy of a great nation. We will not reach them all this year
column3: not even in this decade. But we will reach them. Let us remember that the first American Revolution was not won with a single shot; the continent was not settled in a single year. The lesson of our history and the lesson of the last 7 years is that great goals are reached step by step
column4: always building on our progress
column5: always gaining ground.

column1: Of course
column2: you can't gain ground if you're standing still. And for too long this Congress has been standing still on some of our most pressing national priorities. So let's begin tonight with them.

column1: Again
column2: I ask you to pass a real Patients' Bill of Rights. I ask you to pass commonsense gun safety legislation. I ask you to pass campaign finance reform. I ask you to vote up or down on judicial nominations and other important appointees. And again
column3: I ask youI implore you to raise the minimum wage.

column1: Now
column2: 2 years agolet me try to balance the seesaw here ... 2 years ago
column3: as we reached across party lines to reach our first balanced budget
column4: I asked that we meet our responsibility to the next generation by maintaining our fiscal discipline. Because we refused to stray from that path
column5: we are doing something that would have seemed unimaginable 7 years ago. We are actually paying down the national debt. Now
column6: if we stay on this path
column7: we can pay down the debt entirely in just 13 years now and make America debt-free for the first time since Andrew Jackson was President in 1835.

column1: In 1993 we began to put our fiscal house in order with the Deficit Reduction Act
column2: which you'll all remember won passages in both Houses by just a single vote. Your former colleague
column3: my first Secretary of the Treasury
column4: led that effort and sparked our long boom. He's here with us tonight. Lloyd Bentsen
column5: you have served America well
column6: and we thank you.

column1: Beyond paying off the debt
column2: we must ensure that the benefits of debt reduction go to preserving two of the most important guarantees we make to every American
column3: Social Security and Medicare. Tonight I ask you to work with me to make a bipartisan downpayment on Social Security reform by crediting the interest savings from debt reduction to the Social Security Trust Fund so that it will be strong and sound for the next 50 years.

column1: But this is just the start of our journey. We must also take the right steps toward reaching our great goals. First and foremost
column2: we need a 21st century revolution in education
column3: guided by our faith that every single child can learn. Because education is more important than ever
column4: more than ever the key to our children's future
column5: we must make sure all our children have that key. That means quality preschool and afterschool
column6: the best trained teachers in the classroom
column7: and college opportunities for all our children.

column1: For 7 years now
column2: we've worked hard to improve our schools
column3: with opportunity and responsibility
column4: investing more but demanding more in turn. Reading
column5: math
column6: college entrance scores are up. Some of the most impressive gains are in schools in very poor neighborhoods.

column1: But all successful schools have followed the same proven formula: higher standards
column2: more accountability
column3: and extra help so children who need it can get it to reach those standards. I have sent Congress a reform plan based on that formula. It holds States and school districts accountable for progress and rewards them for results. Each year
column4: our National Government invests more than $15 billion in our schools. It is time to support what works and stop supporting what doesn't.

column1: Now
column2: as we demand more from our schools
column3: we should also invest more in our schools. Let's double our investment to help States and districts turn around their worst performing schools or shut them down. Let's double our investments in after-school and summer school programs
column4: which boost achievement and keep people off the streets and out of trouble. If we do this
column5: we can give every single child in every failing school in Americaeveryonethe chance to meet high standards.

column1: Since 1993
column2: we've nearly doubled our investment in Head Start and improved its quality. Tonight I ask you for another $1 billion for Head Start
column3: the largest increase in the history of the program.

column1: We know that children learn best in smaller classes with good teachers. For 2 years in a row
column2: Congress has supported my plan to hire 100
column3: 000 new qualified teachers to lower class size in the early grades. I thank you for that
column4: and I ask you to make it 3 in a row. And to make sure all teachers know the subjects they teach
column5: tonight I propose a new teacher quality initiative
column6: to recruit more talented people into the classroom
column7: reward good teachers for staying there
column8: and give all teachers the training they need.

column1: We know charter schools provide real public school choice. When I became President
column2: there was just one independent public charter school in all America. Today
column3: thanks to you
column4: there are 1
column5: 700. I ask you now to help us meet our goal of 3
column6: 000 charter schools by next year.

column1: We know we must connect all our classrooms to the Internet
column2: and we're getting there. In 1994
column3: only 3 percent of our classrooms were connected. Today
column4: with the help of the Vice President's E-rate program
column5: more than half of them are
column6: and 90 percent of our schools have at least one Internet connection. But we cannot finish the job when a third of all our schools are in serious disrepair. Many of them have walls and wires so old
column7: they're too old for the Internet. So tonight I propose to help 5
column8: 000 schools a year make immediate and urgent repairs and
column9: again
column10: to help build or modernize 6
column11: 000 more
column12: to get students out of trailers and into high-tech classrooms.

column1: I ask all of you to help me double our bipartisan GEAR UP program
column2: which provides mentors for disadvantaged young people. If we double it
column3: we can provide mentors for 1.4 million of them. Let's also offer these kids from disadvantaged backgrounds the same chance to take the same college test-prep courses wealthier students use to boost their test scores.

column1: To make the American dream achievable for all
column2: we must make college affordable for all. For 7 years
column3: on a bipartisan basis
column4: we have taken action toward that goal: larger Pell grants
column5: more affordable student loans
column6: education IRA's
column7: and our HOPE scholarships
column8: which have already benefited 5 million young people.

column1: Now
column2: 67 percent of high school graduates are going on to college. That's up 10 percent since 1993. Yet millions of families still strain to pay college tuition. They need help. So I propose a landmark $30 billion college opportunity tax cut
column3: a middle class tax deduction for up to $10
column4: 000 in college tuition costs. The previous actions of this Congress have already made 2 years of college affordable for all. It's time make 4 years of college affordable for all. If we take all these steps
column5: we'll move a long way toward making sure every child starts school ready to learn and graduates ready to succeed.

column1: We also need a 21st century revolution to reward work and strengthen families by giving every parent the tools to succeed at work and at the most important work of all
column2: raising children. That means making sure every family has health care and the support to care for aging parents
column3: the tools to bring their children up right
column4: and that no child grows up in poverty.

column1: From my first days as President
column2: we've worked to give families better access to better health care. In 1997
column3: we passed the Children's Health Insurance ProgramCHIPso that workers who don't have coverage through their employers at least can get it for their children. So far
column4: we've enrolled 2 million children. We're well on our way to our goal of 5 million.

column1: But there are still more than 40 million of our fellow Americans without health insurance
column2: more than there were in 1993. Tonight I propose that we follow Vice President Gore's suggestion to make low income parents eligible for the insurance that covers their children. Together with our children's initiativethink of thistogether with our children's initiative
column3: this action would enable us to cover nearly a quarter of all the uninsured people in America.

column1: Again
column2: I want to ask you to let people between the ages of 55 and 65
column3: the fastest growing group of uninsured
column4: buy into Medicare. And this year I propose to give them a tax credit to make that choice an affordable one. I hope you will support that
column5: as well.

column1: When the baby boomers retire
column2: Medicare will be faced with caring for twice as many of our citizens; yet
column3: it is far from ready to do so. My generation must not ask our children's generation to shoulder our burden. We simply must act now to strengthen and modernize Medicare.

column1: My budget includes a comprehensive plan to reform Medicare
column2: to make it more efficient and more competitive. And it dedicates nearly $400 billion of our budget surplus to keep Medicare solvent past 2025. And at long last
column3: it also provides funds to give every senior a voluntary choice of affordable coverage for prescription drugs.

column1: Lifesaving drugs are an indispensable part of modern medicine. No one creating a Medicare program today would even think of excluding coverage for prescription drugs. Yet more than three in five of our seniors now lack dependable drug coverage which can lengthen and enrich their lives. Millions of older Americans
column2: who need prescription drugs the most
column3: pay the highest prices for them. In good conscience
column4: we cannot let another year pass without extending to all our seniors this lifeline of affordable prescription drugs.

column1: Record numbers of Americans are providing for aging or ailing loved ones at home. It's a loving but a difficult and often very expensive choice. Last year
column2: I proposed a $1
column3: 000 tax credit for long-term care. Frankly
column4: it wasn't enough. This year
column5: let's triple it to $3
column6: 000. But this year
column7: let's pass it.

column1: We also have to make needed investments to expand access to mental health care. I want to take a moment to thank the person who led our first White House Conference on Mental Health last year and who for 7 years has led all our efforts to break down the barriers to decent treatment of people with mental illness. Thank you
column2: Tipper Gore.

column1: Taken together
column2: these proposals would mark the largest investment in health care in the 35 years since Medicare was createdthe largest investment in 35 years. That would be a big step toward assuring quality health care for all Americans
column3: young and old. And I ask you to embrace them and pass them.

column1: We must also make investments that reward work and support families. Nothing does that better than the earned-income tax credit
column2: the EITC. The "E" in the EITC is about earning
column3: working
column4: taking responsibility
column5: and being rewarded for it. In my very first address to you
column6: I asked Congress to greatly expand this credit
column7: and you did. As a result
column8: in 1998 alone
column9: the EITC helped more than 4.3 million Americans work their way out of poverty toward the middle class. That's double the number in 1993.

column1: Tonight I propose another major expansion of the EITC: to reduce the marriage penalty
column2: to make sure it rewards marriage as it rewards work
column3: and also to expand the tax credit for families that have more than two children. It punishes people with more than two children today. Our proposal would allow families with three or more children to get up to $1
column4: 100 more in tax relief. These are working families; their children should not be in poverty.

column1: We also can't reward work and family unless men and women get equal pay for equal work. Today the female unemployment rate is the lowest it has been in 46 years. Yet
column2: women still only earn about 75 cents for every dollar men earn. We must do better
column3: by providing the resources to enforce present equal pay laws
column4: training more women for high-paying
column5: high-tech jobs
column6: and passing the "Paycheck Fairness Act."

column1: Many working parents spend up to a quartera quarterof their income on child care. Last year
column2: we helped parents provide child care for about 2 million children. My child care initiative before you now
column3: along with funds already secured in welfare reform
column4: would make child care better
column5: safer
column6: and more affordable for another 400
column7: 000 children. I ask you to pass that. They need it out there.

column1: For hard-pressed middle income families
column2: we should also expand the child care tax credit. And I believe strongly we should take the next big step and make that tax credit refundable for low income families. For people making under $30
column3: 000 a year
column4: that could mean up to $2
column5: 400 for child care costs. You know
column6: we all say we're pro-work and pro-family. Passing this proposal would prove it.

column1: Ten of millions of Americans live from paycheck to paycheck. As hard as they work
column2: they still don't have the opportunity to save. Too few can make use of IRA's and 401k plans. We should do more to help all working families save and accumulate wealth. That's the idea behind the Individual Development Accounts
column3: the IDA's. I ask you to take that idea to a new level
column4: with new retirement savings accounts that enable every low and moderate income family in America to save for retirement
column5: a first home
column6: a medical emergency
column7: or a college education. I propose to match their contributions
column8: however small
column9: dollar for dollar
column10: every year they save. And I propose to give a major new tax credit to any small business that will provide a meaningful pension to its workers. Those people ought to have retirement as well as the rest of us.

column1: Nearly one in three American children grows up without a father. These children are 5 times more likely to live in poverty than children with both parents at home. Clearly
column2: demanding and supporting responsible fatherhood is critical to lifting all our children out of poverty. We've doubled child support collections since 1992. And I'm proposing to you tough new measures to hold still more fathers responsible.

column1: But we should recognize that a lot of fathers want to do right by their children but need help to do it. Carlos Rosas of St. Paul
column2: Minnesota
column3: wanted to do right by his son
column4: and he got the help to do it. Now he's got a good job
column5: and he supports his little boy. My budget will help 40
column6: 000 more fathers make the same choices Carlos Rosas did. I thank him for being here tonight. Stand up
column7: Carlos.  Thank you.

column1: If there is any single issue on which we should be able to reach across party lines
column2: it is in our common commitment to reward work and strengthen families. Just remember what we did last year. We came together to help people with disabilities keep their health insurance when they go to work. And I thank you for that. Thanks to overwhelming bipartisan support from this Congress
column3: we have improved foster care. We've helped those young people who leave it when they turn 18
column4: and we have dramatically increased the number of foster care children going into adoptive homes. I thank all of you for all of that.

column1: Of course
column2: I am forever grateful to the person who has led our efforts from the beginning and who's worked so tirelessly for children and families for 30 years now
column3: my wife
column4: Hillary
column5: and I thank her.

column1: If we take the steps just discussed
column2: we can go a long
column3: long way toward empowering parents to succeed at home and at work and ensuring that no child is raised in poverty. We can make these vital investments in health care
column4: education
column5: support for working families
column6: and still offer tax cuts to help pay for college
column7: for retirement
column8: to care for aging parents
column9: to reduce the marriage penalty. We can do these things without forsaking the path of fiscal discipline that got us to this point here tonight. Indeed
column10: we must make these investments and these tax cuts in the context of a balanced budget that strengthens and extends the life of Social Security and Medicare and pays down the national debt.

column1: Crime in America has dropped for the past 7 yearsthat's the longest decline on record thanks to a national consensus we helped to forge on community police
column2: sensible gun safety laws
column3: and effective prevention. But nobody
column4: nobody here
column5: nobody in America believes we're safe enough. So again
column6: I ask you to set a higher goal. Let's make this country the safest big country in the world.

column1: Last fall
column2: Congress supported my plan to hire
column3: in addition to the 100
column4: 000 community police we've already funded
column6: 000 more
column7: concentrated in high-crime neighborhoods. I ask your continued support for that.

column1: Soon after the Columbine tragedy
column2: Congress considered commonsense gun legislation
column3: to require Brady background checks at the gun shows
column4: child safety locks for new handguns
column5: and a ban on the importation of large capacity ammunition clips. With courage and a tie-breaking vote by the Vice President ... the Senate faced down the gun lobby
column6: stood up for the American people
column7: and passed this legislation. But the House failed to follow suit.

column1: Now
column2: we have all seen what happens when guns fall into the wrong hands. Daniel Mauser was only 15 years old when he was gunned down at Columbine. He was an amazing kid
column3: a straight-A student
column4: a good skier. Like all parents who lose their children
column5: his father
column6: Tom
column7: has borne unimaginable grief. Somehow he has found the strength to honor his son by transforming his grief into action. Earlier this month
column8: he took a leave of absence from his job to fight for tougher gun safety laws. I pray that his courage and wisdom will at long last move this Congress to make commonsense gun legislation the very next order of business. Tom Mauser
column9: stand up. We thank you for being here tonight. Tom. Thank you
column10: Tom.

column1: We must strengthen our gun laws and enforce those already on the books better. Federal gun crime prosecutions are up 16 percent since I took office. But we must do more. I propose to hire more Federal and local gun prosecutors and more ATF agents to crack down on illegal gun traffickers and bad-apple dealers. And we must give them the enforcement tools that they need
column2: tools to trace every gun and every bullet used in every gun crime in the United States. I ask you to help us do that.

column1: Every State in this country already requires hunters and automobile drivers to have a license. I think they ought to do the same thing for handgun purchases. Now
column2: specifically
column3: I propose a plan to ensure that all new handgun buyers must first have a photo license from their State showing they passed the Brady background check and a gun safety course
column4: before they get the gun. I hope you'll help me pass that in this Congress.

column1: Listen to thislisten to this. The accidental gun ratethe accidental gun death rate of children under 15 in the United States is 9 times higher than in the other 25 industrialized countries combined. Now
column2: technologies now exist that could lead to guns that can only be fired by the adults who own them. I ask Congress to fund research into smart gun technology to save these children's lives. I ask responsible leaders in the gun industry to work with us on smart guns and other steps to keep guns out of the wrong hands
column3: to keep our children safe.

column1: You know
column2: every parent I know worries about the impact of violence in the media on their children. I want to begin by thanking the entertainment industry for accepting my challenge to put voluntary ratings on TV programs and video and Internet games. But frankly
column3: the ratings are too numerous
column4: diverse
column5: and confusing to be really useful to parents. So tonight I ask the industry to accept the First Lady's challenge to develop a single voluntary rating system for all children's entertainment that is easier for parents to understand and enforce.

column1: The steps I outline will take us well on our way to making America the safest big country in the world.
Now
column2: to keep our historic economic expansion going
column3: the subject of a lot of discussion in this community and others
column4: I believe we need a 21st century revolution to open new markets
column5: start new businesses
column6: hire new workers right here in America
column7: in our inner cities
column8: poor rural areas
column9: and Native American reservations.

column1: Our Nation's prosperity hasn't yet reached these places. Over the last 6 months
column2: I've traveled to a lot of them
column3: joined by many of you and many far-sighted business people
column4: to shine a spotlight on the enormous potential in communities from Appalachia to the Mississippi Delta
column5: from Watts to the Pine Ridge Reservation. Everywhere I go
column6: I meet talented people eager for opportunity and able to work. Tonight I ask you
column7: let's put them to work. For business
column8: it's the smart thing to do. For America
column9: it's the right thing to do. And let me ask you something: If we don't do this now
column10: when in the wide world will we ever get around to it?

column1: So I ask Congress to give businesses the same incentives to invest in America's new markets they now have to invest in markets overseas. Tonight I propose a large new markets tax credit and other incentives to spur $22 billion in private-sector capital to create new businesses and new investments in our inner cities and rural areas. Because empowerment zones have been creating these opportunities for 5 years now
column2: I also ask you to increase incentives to invest in them and to create more of them.

column1: And let me say to all of you again what I have tried to say at every turn: This is not a Democratic or a Republican issue. Giving people a chance to live their dreams is an American issue.
Mr. Speaker
column2: it was a powerful moment last November when you joined Reverend Jesse Jackson and me in your home State of Illinois and committed to working toward our common goal by combining the best ideas from both sides of the aisle. I want to thank you again and to tell you
column3: Mr. Speaker
column4: I look forward to working with you. This is a worthy joint endeavor. Thank you.

column1: I also ask you to make special efforts to address the areas of our Nation with the highest rates of poverty
column2: our Native American reservations and the Mississippi Delta. My budget includes a $110 million initiative to promote economic development in the Delta and a billion dollars to increase economic opportunity
column3: health care
column4: education
column5: and law enforcement for our Native American communities. We should begin this new century by honoring our historic responsibility to empower the first Americans. And I want to thank tonight the leaders and the members from both parties who've expressed to me an interest in working with us on these efforts. They are profoundly important.

column1: There's another part of our American community in trouble tonight
column2: our family farmers. When I signed the farm bill in 1996
column3: I said there was great danger it would work well in good times but not in bad. Well
column4: droughts
column5: floods
column6: and historically low prices have made these times very bad for the farmers. We must work together to strengthen the farm safety net
column7: invest in land conservation
column8: and create some new markets for them by expanding our programs for bio-based fuels and products. Please
column9: they need help. Let's do it together.

column1: Opportunity for all requires something else today
column2: having access to a computer and knowing how to use it. That means we must close the digital divide between those who've got the tools and those who don't. Connecting classrooms and libraries to the Internet is crucial
column3: but it's just a start. My budget ensures that all new teachers are trained to teach 21st century skills
column4: and it creates technology centers in 1
column5: 000 communities to serve adults. This spring
column6: I'll invite high-tech leaders to join me on another new markets tour
column7: to close the digital divide and open opportunity for our people. I want to thank the high-tech companies that already are doing so much in this area. I hope the new tax incentives I have proposed will get all the rest of them to join us. This is a national crusade. We have got to do this and do it quickly.

column1: Now
column2: again I say to you
column3: these are steps
column4: but step by step
column5: we can go a long way toward our goal of bringing opportunity to every community.

column1: To realize the full possibilities of this economy
column2: we must reach beyond our own borders to shape the revolution that is tearing down barriers and building new networks among nations and individuals and economies and cultures: globalization. It's the central reality of our time.

column1: Of course
column2: change this profound is both liberating and threatening to people. But there's no turning back. And our open
column3: creative society stands to benefit more than any other if we understand and act on the realities of interdependence. We have to be at the center of every vital global network
column4: as a good neighbor and a good partner. We have to recognize that we cannot build our future without helping others to build theirs.

column1: The first thing we have got to do is to forge a new consensus on trade. Now
column2: those of us who believe passionately in the power of open trade
column3: we have to ensure that it lifts both our living standards and our values
column4: never tolerating abusive child labor or a race to the bottom in the environment and worker protection. But others must recognize that open markets and rule-based trade are the best engines we know of for raising living standards
column5: reducing global poverty and environmental destruction
column6: and assuring the free flow of ideas.

column1: I believe
column2: as strongly tonight as I did the first day I got here
column3: the only direction forward for America on tradethe only direction for America on trade is to keep going forward. I ask you to help me forge that consensus. We have to make developing economies our partners in prosperity. That's why I would like to ask you again to finalize our groundbreaking African and Caribbean Basin trade initiatives.

column1: But globalization is about more than economics. Our purpose must be to bring together the world around freedom and democracy and peace and to oppose those who would tear it apart. Here are the fundamental challenges I believe America must meet to shape the 21st century world.
First
column2: we must continue to encourage our former adversaries
column3: Russia and China
column4: to emerge as stable
column5: prosperous
column6: democratic nations. Both are being held back today from reaching their full potential: Russia by the legacy of communism
column7: an economy in turmoil
column8: a cruel and self-defeating war in Chechnya; China by the illusion that it can buy stability at the expense of freedom.

column1: But think how much has changed in the past decade: 5
column2: 000 former Soviet nuclear weapons taken out of commission; Russian soldiers actually serving with ours in the Balkans; Russian people electing their leaders for the first time in 1
column3: 000 years; and in China
column4: an economy more open to the world than ever before.

column1: Of course
column2: no one
column3: not a single person in this Chamber tonight can know for sure what direction these great nations will take. But we do know for sure that we can choose what we do. And we should do everything in our power to increase the chance that they will choose wisely
column4: to be constructive members of our global community.

column1: That's why we should support those Russians who are struggling for a democratic
column2: prosperous future; continue to reduce both our nuclear arsenals; and help Russia to safeguard weapons and materials that remain.

column1: And that's why I believe Congress should support the agreement we negotiated to bring China into the WTO
column2: by passing permanent normal trade relations with China as soon as possible this year. I think you ought to do it for two reasons: First of all
column3: our markets are already open to China; this agreement will open China's markets to us. And second
column4: it will plainly advance the cause of peace in Asia and promote the cause of change in China. No
column5: we don't know where it's going. All we can do is decide what we're going to do. But when all is said and done
column6: we need to know we did everything we possibly could to maximize the chance that China will choose the right future.

column1: A second challenge we've got is to protect our own security from conflicts that pose the risk of wider war and threaten our common humanity. We can't prevent every conflict or stop every outrage. But where our interests are at stake and we can make a difference
column2: we should be
column3: and we must be
column4: peacemakers.

column1: We should be proud of our role in bringing the Middle East closer to a lasting peace
column2: building peace in Northern Ireland
column3: working for peace in East Timor and Africa
column4: promoting reconciliation between Greece and Turkey and in Cyprus
column5: working to defuse these crises between India and Pakistan
column6: in defending human rights and religious freedom. And we should be proud of the men and women of our Armed Forces and those of our allies who stopped the ethnic cleansing in Kosovo
column7: enabling a million people to return to their homes.

column1: When Slobodan Milosevic unleashed his terror on Kosovo
column2: Captain John Cherrey was one of the brave airmen who turned the tide. And when another American plane was shot down over Serbia
column3: he flew into the teeth of enemy air defenses to bring his fellow pilot home. Thanks to our Armed Forces' skill and bravery
column4: we prevailed in Kosovo without losing a single American in combat. I want to introduce Captain Cherrey to you. We honor Captain Cherrey
column5: and we promise you
column6: Captain
column7: we'll finish the job you began. Stand up so we can see you.

column1: A third challenge we have is to keep this inexorable march of technology from giving terrorists and potentially hostile nations the means to undermine our defenses. Keep in mind
column2: the same technological advances that have shrunk cell phones to fit in the palms of our hands can also make weapons of terror easier to conceal and easier to use.

column1: We must meet this threat by making effective agreements to restrain nuclear and missile programs in North Korea
column2: curbing the flow of lethal technology to Iran
column3: preventing Iraq from threatening its neighbors
