column4: increasing our preparedness against chemical and biological attack
column5: protecting our vital computer systems from hackers and criminals
column6: and developing a system to defend against new missile threats
column7: while working to preserve our ABM missile treaty with Russia. We must do all these things.

column1: I predict to you
column2: when most of us are long gone but some time in the next 10 to 20 years
column3: the major security threat this country will face will come from the enemies of the nation-state
column4: the narcotraffickers and the terrorists and the organized criminals who will be organized together
column5: working together
column6: with increasing access to ever more sophisticated chemical and biological weapons. And I want to thank the Pentagon and others for doing what they're doing right now to try to help protect us and plan for that
column7: so that our defenses will be strong. I ask for your support to ensure they can succeed.

column1: I also want to ask you for a constructive bipartisan dialog this year to work to build a consensus which I hope will eventually lead to the ratification of the Comprehensive Nuclear-Test-Ban Treaty.

I hope we can also have a constructive effort to meet the challenge that is presented to our planet by the huge gulf between rich and poor. We cannot accept a world in which part of humanity lives on the cutting edge of a new economy and the rest live on the bare edge of survival. I think we have to do our part to change that with expanded trade
column2: expanded aid
column3: and the expansion of freedom.

column1: This is interesting: From Nigeria to Indonesia
column2: more people got the right to choose their leaders in 1999 than in 1989
column3: when the Berlin Wall fell. We've got to stand by these democracies
column4: including and especially tonight Colombia
column5: which is fighting narcotraffickers
column6: for its own people's lives and our children's lives. I have proposed a strong 2-year package to help Colombia win this fight. I want to thank the leaders in both parties in both Houses for listening to me and the President of Colombia about it. We have got to pass this. I want to ask your help. A lot is riding on it. And it's so important for the long-term stability of our country and for what happens in Latin America.

column1: I also want you to know I'm going to send you new legislation to go after what these drug barons value the most
column2: their money. And I hope you'll pass that as well.

column1: In a world where over a billion people live on less than a dollar a day
column2: we also have got to do our part in the global endeavor to reduce the debts of the poorest countries
column3: so they can invest in education
column4: health care
column5: and economic growth. That's what the Pope and other religious leaders have urged us to do. And last year
column6: Congress made a downpayment on America's share. I ask you to continue that. I thank you for what you did and ask you to stay the course.

column1: I also want to say that America must help more nations to break the bonds of disease. Last year in Africa
column2: 10 times as many people died from AIDS as were killed in wars10 times. The budget I give you invests $150 million more in the fight against this and other infectious killers. And today I propose a tax credit to speed the development of vaccines for diseases like malaria
column3: TB
column4: and AIDS. I ask the private sector and our partners around the world to join us in embracing this cause. We can save millions of lives together
column5: and we ought to do it.

column1: I also want to mention our final challenge
column2: which
column3: as always
column4: is the most important. I ask you to pass a national security budget that keeps our military the best trained and best equipped in the world
column5: with heightened readiness and 21st century weapons
column6: which raises salaries for our service men and women
column7: which protects our veterans
column8: which fully funds the diplomacy that keeps our soldiers out of war
column9: which makes good on our commitment to our U.N. dues and arrears. I ask you to pass this budget.

column1: I also want to say something
column2: if I might
column3: very personal tonight. The American people watching us at home
column4: with the help of all the commentators
column5: can tell
column6: from who stands and who sits and who claps and who doesn't
column7: that there's still modest differences of opinion in this room.  But I want to thank you for something
column8: every one of you. I want to thank you for the extraordinary support you have given
column9: Republicans and Democrats alike
column10: to our men and women in uniform. I thank you for that.

column1: I also want to thank
column2: especially
column3: two people. First
column4: I want to thank our Secretary of Defense
column5: Bill Cohen
column6: for symbolizing our bipartisan commitment to national security. Thank you
column7: sir. Even more
column8: I want to thank his wife
column9: Janet
column10: who
column11: more than any other American citizen
column12: has tirelessly traveled this world to show the support we all feel for our troops. Thank you
column13: Janet Cohen. I appreciate that. Thank you.

column1: These are the challenges we have to meet so that we can lead the world toward peace and freedom in an era of globalization.

I want to tell you that I am very grateful for many things as President. But one of the things I'm grateful for is the opportunity that the Vice President and I have had to finally put to rest the bogus idea that you cannot grow the economy and protect the environment at the same time.
As our economy has grown
column2: we've rid more than 500 neighborhoods of toxic waste
column3: ensured cleaner air and water for millions of people. In the past 3 months alone
column4: we've helped preserve 40 million acres of roadless lands in the national forests
column5: created three new national monuments.

column1: But as our communities grow
column2: our commitment to conservation must continue to grow. Tonight I propose creating a permanent conservation fund
column3: to restore wildlife
column4: protect coastlines
column5: save natural treasures
column6: from the California redwoods to the Florida Everglades. This lands legacy endowment would represent by far the most enduring investment in land preservation ever proposed in this House. I hope we can get together with all the people with different ideas and do this. This is a gift we should give to our children and our grandchildren for all time
column7: across party lines. We can make an agreement to do this.

column1: Last year the Vice President launched a new effort to make communities more liberallivable ... liberal
column2: I know.  Wait a minute
column3: I've got a punchline now. That's this year's agenda; last year was livable
column4: right?  That's what Senator Lott is going to say in the commentary afterwards ... to make our communities more livable. This is big business. This is a big issue. What does that mean? You ask anybody that lives in an unlivable community
column5: and they'll tell you. They want their kids to grow up next to parks
column6: not parking lots; the parents don't have to spend all their time stalled in traffic when they could be home with their children.

column1: Tonight I ask you to support new funding for the following things
column2: to make American communities more liberallivable.  I've done pretty well with this speech
column3: but I can't say that.

column1: One
column2: I want you to help us to do three things. We need more funding for advanced transit systems. We need more funding for saving open spaces in places of heavy development. And we need more fundingthis ought to have bipartisan appealwe need more funding for helping major cities around the Great Lakes protect their waterways and enhance their quality of life. We need these things
column3: and I want you to help us.

column1: The greatest environmental challenge of the new century is global warming. The scientists tell us the 1990's were the hottest decade of the entire millennium. If we fail to reduce the emission of greenhouse gases
column2: deadly heat waves and droughts will become more frequent
column3: coastal areas will flood
column4: and economies will be disrupted. That is going to happen
column5: unless we act.

column1: Many people in the United States
column2: some people in this Chamber
column3: and lots of folks around the world still believe you cannot cut greenhouse gas emissions without slowing economic growth. In the industrial age
column4: that may well have been true. But in this digital economy
column5: it is not true anymore. New technologies make it possible to cut harmful emissions and provide even more growth.

column1: For example
column2: just last week
column3: automakers unveiled cars that get 70 to 80 miles a gallon
column4: the fruits of a unique research partnership between Government and industry. And before you know it
column5: efficient production of bio-fuels will give us the equivalent of hundreds of miles from a gallon of gasoline.

column1: To speed innovation in these kind of technologies
column2: I think we should give a major tax incentive to business for the production of clean energy and to families for buying energy-saving homes and appliances and the next generation of superefficient cars when they hit the showroom floor. I also ask the auto industry to use the available technologies to make all new cars more fuel-efficient right away.

column1: And I ask this Congress to do something else. Please help us make more of our clean energy technology available to the developing world. That will create cleaner growth abroad and a lot more new jobs here in the United States of America.
In the new century
column2: innovations in science and technology will be key not only to the health of the environment but to miraculous improvements in the quality of our lives and advances in the economy. Later this year
column3: researchers will complete the first draft of the entire human genome
column4: the very blueprint of life. It is important for all our fellow Americans to recognize that Federal tax dollars have funded much of this research and that this and other wise investments in science are leading to a revolution in our ability to detect
column5: treat
column6: and prevent disease.

column1: For example
column2: researchers have identified genes that cause Parkinson's
column3: diabetes
column4: and certain kinds of cancer. They are designing precision therapies that will block the harmful effect of these genes for good. Researchers already are using this new technique to target and destroy cells that cause breast cancer. Soon
column5: we may be able to use it to prevent the onset of Alzheimer's. Scientists are also working on an artificial retina to help many blind people to see andlisten to thismicrochips that would actually directly stimulate damaged spinal cords in a way that could allow people now paralyzed to stand up and walk.

column1: These kinds of innovations are also propelling our remarkable prosperity. Information technology only includes 8 percent of our employment but now accounts for a third of our economic growth along with jobs that pay
column2: by the way
column3: about 80 percent above the private sector average. Again
column4: we ought to keep in mind
column5: Government-funded research brought supercomputers
column6: the Internet
column7: and communications satellites into being. Soon researchers will bring us devices that can translate foreign languages as fast as you can talk
column8: materials 10 times stronger than steel at a fraction of the weight
column9: and this is unbelievable to memolecular computers the size of a teardrop with the power of today's fastest supercomputers.

column1: To accelerate the march of discovery across all these disciplines in science and technology
column2: I ask you to support my recommendation of an unprecedented $3 billion in the 21st century research fund
column3: the largest increase in civilian research in a generation. We owe it to our future.

column1: Now
column2: these new breakthroughs have to be used in ways that reflect our values. First and foremost
column3: we have to safeguard our citizens' privacy. Last year we proposed to protect every citizen's medical record. This year we will finalize those rules. We've also taken the first steps to protect the privacy of bank and credit card records and other financial statements. Soon I will send legislation to you to finish that job. We must also act to prevent any genetic discrimination whatever by employers or insurers. I hope you will support that.

column1: These steps will allow us to lead toward the far frontiers of science and technology. They will enhance our health
column2: the environment
column3: the economy in ways we can't even imagine today. But we all know that at a time when science
column4: technology
column5: and the forces of globalization are bringing so many changes into all our lives
column6: it's more important than ever that we strengthen the bonds that root us in our local communities and in our national community.

column1: No tie binds different people together like citizen service. There's a new spirit of service in America
column2: a movement we've tried to support with AmeriCorps
column3: expanded Peace Corps
column4: unprecedented new partnerships with businesses
column5: foundations
column6: community groups; partnerships
column7: for example
column8: like the one that enlisted 12
column9: 000 companies which have now moved 650
column10: 000 of our fellow citizens from welfare to work; partnerships to battle drug abuse
column11: AIDS
column12: teach young people to read
column13: save America's treasures
column14: strengthen the arts
column17: promote racial healing. The American people are working together.

column1: But we should do more to help Americans help each other. First
column2: we should help faithbased organizations to do more to fight poverty and drug abuse and help people get back on the right track
column3: with initiatives like Second Chance Homes that do so much to help unwed teen mothers. Second
column4: we should support Americans who tithe and contribute to charities but don't earn enough to claim a tax deduction for it. Tonight I propose new tax incentives that would allow low and middle income citizens who don't itemize to get that deduction. It's nothing but fair
column5: and it will get more people to give.

column1: We should do more to help new immigrants to fully participate in our community. That's why I recommend spending more to teach them civics and English. And since everybody in our community counts
column2: we've got to make sure everyone is counted in this year's census.

column1: Within 10 yearsjust 10 yearsthere will be no majority race in our largest State of California. In a little more than 50 years
column2: there will be no majority race in America. In a more interconnected world
column3: this diversity can be our greatest strength. Just look around this Chamber. Look around. We have Members in this Congress from virtually every racial
column4: ethnic
column5: and religious background. And I think you would agree that America is stronger because of it.

column1: You also have to agree that all those differences you just clapped for all too often spark hatred and division even here at home. Just in the last couple of years
column2: we've seen a man dragged to death in Texas just because he was black. We saw a young man murdered in Wyoming just because he was gay. Last year we saw the shootings of African-Americans
column3: Asian-Americans
column4: and Jewish children just because of who they were. This is not the American way
column5: and we must draw the line.

column1: I ask you to draw that line by passing without delay the "Hate Crimes Prevention Act" and the "Employment Non-Discrimination Act." And I ask you to reauthorize the Violence Against Women Act.
Finally tonight
column2: I propose the largest ever investment in our civil rights laws for enforcement
column3: because no American should be subjected to discrimination in finding a home
column4: getting a job
column5: going to school
column6: or securing a loan. Protections in law should be protections in fact.

column1: Last February
column2: because I thought this was so important
column3: I created the White House Office of One America to promote racial reconciliation. That's what one of my personal heroes
column4: Hank Aaron
column5: has done all his life. From his days as our all-time home run king to his recent acts of healing
column6: he has always brought people together. We should follow his example
column7: and we're honored to have him with us tonight. Stand up
column8: Hank Aaron.

column1: I just want to say one more thing about this
column2: and I want every one of you to think about this the next time you get mad at one of your colleagues on the other side of the aisle. This fall
column3: at the White House
column4: Hillary had one of her millennium dinners
column5: and we had this very distinguished scientist there
column6: who is an expert in this whole work in the human genome. And he said that we are all
column7: regardless of race
column8: genetically 99.9 percent the same.

column1: Now
column2: you may find that uncomfortable when you look around here.  But it is worth remembering. We can laugh about this
column3: but you think about it. Modern science has confirmed what ancient faiths have always taught: the most important fact of life is our common humanity. Therefore
column4: we should do more than just tolerate our diversity; we should honor it and celebrate it.

column1: My fellow Americans
column2: every time I prepare for the State of the Union
column3: I approach it with hope and expectation and excitement for our Nation. But tonight is very special
column4: because we stand on the mountaintop of a new millennium. Behind us we can look back and see the great expanse of American achievement
column5: and before us we can see even greater
column6: grander frontiers of possibility. We should
column7: all of us
column8: be filled with gratitude and humility for our present progress and prosperity. We should be filled with awe and joy at what lies over the horizon. And we should be filled with absolute determination to make the most of it.

column1: You know
column2: when the Framers finished crafting our Constitution in Philadelphia
column3: Benjamin Franklin stood in Independence Hall
column4: and he reflected on the carving of the Sun that was on the back of a chair he saw. The Sun was low on the horizon. So he said thishe said
column5: "I've often wondered whether that Sun was rising or setting. Today
column6: Franklin said, I have the happiness to know it's a rising Sun." Today
column7: because each succeeding generation of Americans has kept the fire of freedom burning brightly
column8: lighting those frontiers of possibility
column9: we all still bask in the glow and the warmth of Mr. Franklin's rising Sun.

column1: After 224 years
column2: the American revolution continues. We remain a new nation. And as long as our dreams outweigh our memories
column3: America will be forever young. That is our destiny. And this is our moment.

column1: Thank you
column2: God bless you
column3: and God bless America.@

column1: George W. Bush|Address Before a Joint Session of the Congress on Administration Goals|2001-02-27|@Mr. Speaker
column2: Mr. Vice President
column3: Members of Congress: It's a great privilege to be here to outline a new budget and a new approach for governing our great country. I thank you for your invitation to speak here tonight. I know Congress had to formally invite me
column4: and it could have been a close vote.  So
column5: Mr. Vice President
column6: I appreciate you being here to break the tie.

column1: I want to thank so many of you who have accepted my invitation to come to the White House to discuss important issues. We're off to a good start. I will continue to meet with you and ask for your input. You have been kind and candid
column2: and I thank you for making a new President feel welcome.

column1: The last time I visited the Capitol
column2: I came to take an oath on the steps of this building. I pledged to honor our Constitution and laws
column3: and I asked you to join me in setting a tone of civility and respect in Washington. I hope America is noticing the difference
column4: because we're making progress. Together
column5: we are changing the tone in the Nation's Capital. And this spirit of respect and cooperation is vital because
column6: in the end
column7: we will be judged not only by what we say or how we say it
column8: we will be judged by what we're able to accomplish.

column1: America today is a nation with great challenges but greater resources. An artist using statistics as a brush could paint two very different pictures of our country. One would have warning signs: increasing layoffs
column2: rising energy prices
column3: too many failing schools
column4: persistent poverty
column5: the stubborn vestiges of racism. Another picture would be full of blessings: a balanced budget
column6: big surpluses
column7: a military that is second to none
column8: a country at peace with its neighbors
column9: technology that is revolutionizing the world
column10: and our greatest strength
column11: concerned citizens who care for our country and care for each other.

column1: Neither picture is complete in and of itself. And tonight I challenge and invite Congress to work with me to use the resources of one picture to repaint the other
column2: to direct the advantages of our time to solve the problems of our people. Some of these resources will come from Governmentsome
column3: but not all.

column1: Year after year in Washington
column2: budget debates seem to come down to an old
column3: tired argument: on one side
column4: those who want more Government
column5: regardless of the cost; on the other
column6: those who want less Government
column7: regardless of the need. We should leave those arguments to the last century and chart a different course.

column1: Government has a role
column2: and an important role. Yet
column3: too much Government crowds out initiative and hard work
column4: private charity and the private economy. Our new governing vision says Government should be active but limited
column5: engaged but not overbearing.

column1: And my budget is based on that philosophy. It is reasonable
column2: and it is responsible. It meets our obligations and funds our growing needs. We increase spending next year for Social Security and Medicare and other entitlement programs by $81 billion. We've increased spending for discretionary programs by a very responsible 4 percent
column3: above the rate of inflation. My plan pays down an unprecedented amount of our national debt. And then
column4: when money is still left over
column5: my plan returns it to the people who earned it in the first place.

column1: A budget's impact is counted in dollars but measured in lives. Excellent schools
column2: quality health care
column3: a secure retirement
column4: a cleaner environment
column5: a stronger defense: These are all important needs
column6: and we fund them. The highest percentage increase in our budget should go to our children's education. Education is not my top priority education is my top priority
column7: and by supporting this budget
column8: you'll make it yours
column9: as well.

column1: Reading is the foundation of all learning. So during the next 5 years
column2: we triple spending
column3: adding $5 billion to help every child in America learn to read. Values are important
column4: so we've tripled funding for character education to teach our children not only reading and writing but right from wrong. We've increased funding to train and recruit teachers
column5: because we know a good education starts with a good teacher.

column1: And I have a wonderful partner in this effort. I like teachers so much
column2: I married one. Laura has begun a new effort to recruit Americans to the profession that will shape our future
column3: teaching. She will travel across America to promote sound teaching practices and early reading skills in our schools and in programs such as Head Start.

column1: When it comes to our schools
column2: dollars alone do not always make the difference. Funding is important
column3: and so is reform. So we must tie funding to higher standards and accountability for results.

column1: I believe in local control of schools. We should not
column2: and we will not
column3: run public schools from Washington
column4: DC. Yet when the Federal Government spends tax dollars
column5: we must insist on results. Children should be tested on basic reading and math skills every year between grades three and eight. Measuring is the only way to know whether all our children are learning. And I want to know
column6: because I refuse to leave any child behind in America.

column1: Critics of testing contend it distracts from learning. They talk about teaching to the test. But let's put that logic to the test. If you test a child on basic math and reading skills and you're teaching to the test
column2: you're teaching math and reading. And that's the whole idea. As standards rise
column3: local schools will need more flexibility to meet them
column4: so we must streamline the dozens of Federal education programs into five and let States spend money in those categories as they see fit.

column1: Schools will be given a reasonable chance to improve and the support to do so. Yet if they don't
column2: if they continue to fail
column3: we must give parents and students different options: a better public school
column4: a private school
column5: tutoring
column6: or a charter school. In the end
column7: every child in a bad situation must be given a better choice because
column8: when it comes to our children
column9: failure is simply not an option.

column1: Another priority in my budget is to keep the vital promises of Medicare and Social Security
column2: and together we will do so. To meet the health care needs of all America's seniors
column3: we double the Medicare budget over the next 10 years. My budget dedicates $238 billion to Medicare next year alone
column4: enough to fund all current programs and to begin a new prescription drug benefit for low-income seniors. No senior in America should have to choose between buying food and buying prescriptions.

column1: To make sure the retirement savings of America's seniors are not diverted into any other program
column2: my budget protects all $2.6 trillion of the Social Security surplus for Social Security and for Social Security alone.

column1: My budget puts a priority on access to health care
column2: without telling Americans what doctor they have to see or what coverage they must choose. Many working Americans do not have health care coverage
column3: so we will help them buy their own insurance with refundable tax credits. And to provide quality care in low-income neighborhoods
column4: over the next 5 years we will double the number of people served at community health care centers. And we will address the concerns of those who have health coverage
column5: yet worry their insurance company doesn't care and won't pay.

column1: Together this Congress and this President will find common ground to make sure doctors make medical decisions and patients get the health care they deserve with a Patients' Bill of Rights.
When it comes to their health
column2: people want to get the medical care they need
column3: not be forced to go to court because they didn't get it. We will ensure access to the courts for those with legitimate claims. But first
column4: let's put in place a strong
column5: independent review so we promote quality health care
column6: not frivolous lawsuits.

column1: My budget also increases funding for medical research
column2: which gives hope to many who struggle with serious disease. Our prayers tonight are with one of your own who is engaged in his own fight against cancer
column3: a fine Representative and a good man
column4: Congressman Joe Moakley. I can think of no more appropriate tribute to Joe than to have the Congress finish the job of doubling the budget for the National Institutes of Health.

column1: My New Freedom Initiative for Americans with disabilities funds new technologies
column2: expands opportunities to work
column3: and makes our society more welcoming. For the more than 50 million Americans with disabilities
column4: we must continue to break down barriers to equality.

column1: The budget I propose to you also supports the people who keep our country strong and free
column2: the men and women who serve in the United States military. I'm requesting $5.7 billion in increased military pay and benefits and health care and housing. Our men and women in uniform give America their best
column3: and we owe them our support.

column1: America's veterans honored their commitment to our country through their military service. I will honor our commitment to them with a billion-dollar increase to ensure better access to quality care and faster decisions on benefit claims.

My budget will improve our environment by accelerating the cleanup of toxic brownfields. And I propose we make a major investment in conservation by fully funding the Land and Water Conservation Fund. Our national parks have a special place in our country's life. Our parks are places of great natural beauty and history. As good stewards
column2: we must leave them better than we found them. So I propose providing $4.9 billion over 5 years for the upkeep of these national treasures.

column1: And my budget adopts a hopeful new approach to help the poor and the disadvantaged. We must encourage and support the work of charities and faith-based and community groups that offer help and love
column2: one person at a time. These groups are working in every neighborhood in America to fight homelessness and addiction and domestic violence
column3: to provide a hot meal or a mentor or a safe haven for our children. Government should welcome these groups to apply for funds
column4: not discriminate against them.

column1: Government cannot be replaced by charities or volunteers. Government should not fund religious activities. But our Nation should support the good works of these good people who are helping their neighbors in need. So I propose allowing all taxpayers
column2: whether they itemize or not
column3: to deduct their charitable contributions. Estimates show this could encourage as much as $14 billion a year in new charitable giving
column4: money that will save and change lives.

column1: Our budget provides more than $700 million over the next 10 years for a Federal compassion capital fund
column2: with a focused and noble mission
column3: to provide a mentor to the more than one million children with a parent in prison and to support other local efforts to fight illiteracy
column4: teen pregnancy
column5: drug addiction
column6: and other difficult problems.

column1: With us tonight is the mayor of Philadelphia. Please help me welcome Mayor John Street.  Mayor Street has encouraged faith-based and community organizations to make a significant difference in Philadelphia. He's invited me to his city this summer to see compassionate action. I'm personally aware of just how effective the mayor is. Mayor Street's a Democrat. Let the record show
column2: I lost his citybig time. But some things are bigger than politics. So I look forward to coming to your city
column3: to see your faith-based programs in action.

column1: As Government promotes compassion
column2: it also must promote justice. Too many of our citizens have cause to doubt our Nation's justice when the law points a finger of suspicion at groups instead of individuals. All our citizens are created equal and must be treated equally.

column1: Earlier today I asked John Ashcroft
column2: the Attorney General
column3: to develop specific recommendations to end racial profiling. It's wrong
column4: and we will end it in America. In so doing
column5: we will not hinder the work of our Nation's brave police officers. They protect us every day
column6: often at great risk. But by stopping the abuses of a few
column7: we will add to the public confidence our police officers earn and deserve.

column1: My budget has funded a responsible increase in our ongoing operations. It has funded our Nation's important priorities. It has protected Social Security and Medicare. And our surpluses are big enough that there is still money left over.
Many of you have talked about the need to pay down our national debt. I listened
column2: and I agree. We owe it to our children and grandchildren to act now
column3: and I hope you will join me to pay down $2 trillion in debt during the next 10 years. At the end of those 10 years
column4: we will have paid down all the debt that is available to retire. That is more debt
column5: repaid more quickly than has ever been repaid by any nation at any time in history.

column1: We should also prepare for the unexpected
column2: for the uncertainties of the future. We should approach our Nation's budget as any prudent family would
column3: with a contingency fund for emergencies or additional spending needs. For example
column4: after a strategic review
column5: we may need to increase defense spending. We may need to increase spending for our farmers or additional money to reform Medicare. And so
column6: my budget sets aside almost a trillion dollars over 10 years for additional needs. That is one trillion additional reasons you can feel comfortable supporting this budget.

column1: We have increased our budget at a responsible 4 percent. We have funded our priorities. We paid down all the available debt. We have prepared for contingencies. And we still have money left over.
Yogi Berra once said
column2: "When you come to a fork in the road
column3: take it."  Now
column4: we come to a fork in the road; we have two choices. Even though we have already met our needs
column5: we could spend the money on more and bigger Government. That's the road our Nation has traveled in recent years.

column1: Last year Government spending shot up 8 percent. That's far more than our economy grew
column2: far more than personal income grew
column3: and far more than the rate of inflation. If you continue on that road
column4: you will spend the surplus and have to dip into Social Security to pay other bills. Unrestrained Government spending is a dangerous road to deficits
column5: so we must take a different path.

column1: The other choice is to let the American people spend their own money to meet their own needs. I hope you will join me in standing firmly on the side of the people. You see
column2: the growing surplus exists because taxes are too high and Government is charging more than it needs. The people of America have been overcharged
column3: and on their behalf
column4: I am here asking for a refund.

column1: Some say my tax plan is too big. Others say it's too small. I respectfully disagree.  This plan is just right. I didn't throw darts at a board to come up with a number for tax relief. I didn't take a poll or develop an arbitrary formula that might sound good. I looked at problems in the Tax Code and calculated the cost to fix them.
A tax rate of 15 percent is too high for those who earn low wages
column2: so we must lower the rate to 10 percent. No one should pay more than a third of the money they earn in Federal income taxes
column3: so we lowered the top rate to 33 percent.

column1: This reform will be welcome relief for America's small businesses
column2: which often pay taxes at the highest rate. And help for small business means jobs for Americans. We simplified the Tax Code by reducing the number of tax rates from the current five rates to four lower ones
column3: 10 percent
column6: and 33 percent. In my plan
column7: no one is targeted in or targeted out. Everyone who pays income taxes will get relief.

column1: Our Government should not tax and
column2: thereby
column3: discourage marriage
column4: so we reduced the marriage penalty. I want to help families rear and support their children
column5: so we doubled the child credit to $1
column6: 000 per child. It's not fair to tax the same earnings twiceonce when you earn them
column7: and again when you dieso we must repeal the death tax.

column1: These changes add up to significant help. A typical family with two children will save $1
column2: 600 a year on their Federal income taxes. Now
column4: 600 may not sound like a lot to some
column5: but it means a lot to many families: $1
column6: 600 buys gas for two cars for an entire year; it pays tuition for a year at a community college; it pays the average family grocery bill for 3 months. That's real money.

column1: With us tonight
column2: representing many American families
column3: are Steven and Josefina Ramos. They are from Pennsylvania
column4: but they could be from any one of your districts. Steven is the network administrator for a school district. Josefina is a Spanish teacher at a charter school. And they have a 2-year-old daughter.

column1: Steven and Josefina tell me they pay almost $8
column2: 000 a year in Federal income taxes. My plan will save them more than $2
column3: 000. Let me tell you what Steven says: "Two thousand dollars a year means a lot to my family. If we had this money
column4: it would help us reach our goal of paying off our personal debt in 2 years' time." After that
column5: Steven and Josefina want to start saving for Lianna's college education.

column1: My attitude is
column2: Government should never stand in the way of families achieving their dreams. And as we debate this issue
column3: always remember
column4: the surplus is not the Government's money; the surplus is the people's money.

column1: For lower income families
column2: my tax plan restores basic fairness. Right now
column3: complicated tax rules punish hard work. A waitress supporting two children on $25
column4: 000 a year can lose nearly half of every additional dollar she earns above the $25
column5: 000. Her overtime
column6: her hardest hours
column7: are taxed at nearly 50 percent. This sends a terrible message: "You'll never get ahead."

column1: But America's message must be different. We must honor hard work
column2: never punish it. With tax relief
column3: overtime will no longer be over-taxed-time for the waitress. People with the smallest incomes will get the highest percentage of reductions. And millions of additional American families will be removed from the income tax rolls entirely.

column1: Tax relief is right
column2: and tax relief is urgent. The long economic expansion that began almost 10 years ago is faltering. Lower interest rates will eventually help
column3: but we cannot assume they will do the job all by themselves.

column1: Forty years ago
column2: and then 20 years ago
column3: two Presidents
column4: one Democrat
column5: one Republican
column6: John F. Kennedy and Ronald Reagan
column7: advocated tax cuts to
column8: in President Kennedy's words
column9: "get this country moving again." They knew then what we must do now. To create economic growth and opportunity
column10: we must put money back into the hands of the people who buy goods and create jobs.

column1: We must act quickly. The Chairman of the Federal Reserve has testified before Congress that tax cuts often come too late to stimulate economic recovery. So I want to work with you to give our economy an important jump-start by making tax relief retroactive.
We must act now because it is the right thing to do. We must also act now because we have other things to do. We must show courage to confront and resolve tough challenges
column2: to restructure our Nation's defenses
column3: to meet our growing need for energy
column4: and to reform Medicare and Social Security.

column1: America has a window of opportunity to extend and secure our present peace by promoting a distinctly American internationalism. We will work with our allies and friends to be a force for good and a champion of freedom. We will work for free markets
column2: free trade
column3: and freedom from oppression. Nations making progress toward freedom will find America is their friend. We will promote our values. We will promote the peace
column4: and we need a strong military to keep the peace.

column1: But our military was shaped to confront the challenges of the past. So I've asked the Secretary of Defense to review America's Armed Forces and prepare to transform them to meet emerging threats. My budget makes a downpayment on the research and development that will be required. Yet
column2: in our broader transformation effort
column3: we must put strategy first
column4: then spending. Our defense vision will drive our defense budget
column5: not the other way around.

column1: Our Nation also needs a clear strategy to confront the threats of the 21st century
column2: threats that are more widespread and less certain. They range from terrorists who threaten with bombs to tyrants in rogue nations intent upon developing weapons of mass destruction. To protect our own people
column3: our allies
column4: and friends
column5: we must develop and we must deploy effective missile defenses. And as we transform our military
column6: we can discard cold war relics and reduce our own nuclear forces to reflect today's needs.

column1: A strong America is the world's best hope for peace and freedom. Yet the cause of freedom rests on more than our ability to defend ourselves and our allies. Freedom is exported every day
column2: as we ship goods and products that improve the lives of millions of people. Free trade brings greater political and personal freedom. Each of the previous five Presidents has had the ability to negotiate far-reaching trade agreements. Tonight I ask you to give me the strong hand of Presidential trade promotion authority and to do so quickly.

column1: As we meet tonight
column2: many citizens are struggling with the high cost of energy. We have a serious energy problem that demands a national energy policy. The West is confronting a major energy shortage that has resulted in high prices and uncertainty. I've asked Federal agencies to work with California officials to help speed construction of new energy sources
column3: and I have directed Vice President Cheney
column4: Commerce Secretary Evans
column5: Energy Secretary Abraham
column6: and other senior members in my administration to develop a national energy policy.

column1: Our energy demand outstrips our supply. We can produce more energy at home while protecting our environment
column2: and we must. We can produce more electricity to meet demand
column3: and we must. We can promote alternative energy sources and conservation
column4: and we must. America must become more energy independent
column5: and we will.

column1: Perhaps the biggest test of our foresight and courage will be reforming Medicare and Social Security. Medicare's finances are strained
column2: and its coverage is outdated. Ninety-nine percent of employer-provided health plans offer some form of prescription drug coverage. Medicare does not. The framework for reform has been developed by Senators Frist and Breaux and Congressman Thomas
column3: and now is the time to act.

column1: Medicare must be modernized
column2: and we must make sure that every senior on Medicare can choose a health care plan that offers prescription drugs.

column1: Seven years from now
column2: the baby boom generation will begin to claim Social Security benefits. Every one in this Chamber knows that Social Security is not prepared to fully fund their retirement. And we only have a couple of years to get prepared. Without reform
column3: this country will one day awaken to a stark choice: Either a drastic rise in payroll taxes or a radical cut in retirement benefits. There is a better way.

column1: This spring I will form a Presidential commission to reform Social Security. The commission will make its recommendations by next fall. Reform should be based on these principles: It must preserve the benefits of all current retirees and those nearing retirement; it must return Social Security to sound financial footing; and it must offer personal savings accounts to younger workers who want them.
Social Security now offers workers a return of less than 2 percent on the money they pay into the system. To save the system
column2: we must increase that by allowing younger workers to make safe
column3: sound investments that yield a higher rate of return. Ownership
column4: access to wealth
column5: and independence should not be the privilege of the few. They are the hope of every American
column6: and we must make them the foundation of Social Security.

column1: By confronting the tough challenge of reform
column2: by being responsible with our budget
column3: we can earn the trust of the American people. And we can add to that trust by enacting fair and balanced election and campaign reforms.

column1: The agenda I have set before you tonight is worthy of a great nation. America is a nation at peace but not a nation at rest. Much has been given to us
column2: and much is expected. Let us agree to bridge old divides. But let us also agree that our good will must be dedicated to great goals. Bipartisanship is more than minding our manners; it is doing our duty.

column1: No one can speak in this Capitol and not be awed by its history. At so many turning points
column2: debates in these chambers have reflected the collected or divided conscience of our country. And when we walk through Statuary Hall and see those men and women of marble
column3: we're reminded of their courage and achievement.

column1: Yet America's purpose is never found only in statues or history. America's purpose always stands before us. Our generation must show courage in a time of blessing
column2: as our Nation has always shown in times of crisis. And our courage
column3: issue by issue
column4: can gather to greatness and serve our country. This is the privilege and responsibility we share. And if we work together
column5: we can prove that public service is noble.

column1: We all came here for a reason. We all have things we want to accomplish and promises to keep. Juntos podemostogether we can.

We can make Americans proud of their Government. Together we can share in the credit of making our country more prosperous and generous and just and earn from our conscience and from our fellow citizens the highest possible praise: Well done
column2: good and faithful servants.

column1: Thank you all. Good night
column2: and God bless.@

column1: George W. Bush|Address Before a Joint Session of the Congress on the State of the Union|2002-01-29|@Thank you very much. Mr. Speaker
column2: Vice President Cheney
column3: Members of Congress
column4: distinguished guests
column5: fellow citizens: As we gather tonight
column6: our Nation is at war; our economy is in recession; and the civilized world faces unprecedented dangers. Yet
column7: the state of our Union has never been stronger.

column1: We last met in an hour of shock and suffering. In 4 short months
column2: our Nation has comforted the victims
column3: begun to rebuild New York and the Pentagon
column4: rallied a great coalition
column5: captured
column6: arrested
column7: and rid the world of thousands of terrorists
column8: destroyed Afghanistan's terrorist training camps
column9: saved a people from starvation
column10: and freed a country from brutal oppression.

column1: The American flag flies again over our Embassy in Kabul. Terrorists who once occupied Afghanistan now occupy cells at Guantanamo Bay. And terrorist leaders who urged followers to sacrifice their lives are running for their own.
America and Afghanistan are now allies against terror. We'll be partners in rebuilding that country. And this evening we welcomed the distinguished interim leader of a liberated Afghanistan
column2: Chairman Hamid Karzai.

column1: The last time we met in this Chamber
column2: the mothers and daughters of Afghanistan were captives in their own homes
column3: forbidden from working or going to school. Today
column4: women are free and are part of Afghanistan's new Government. And we welcome the new Minister of Women's Affairs
column5: Dr. Sima Samar.

column1: Our progress is a tribute to the spirit of the Afghan people
column2: to the resolve of our coalition
column3: and to the might of the United States military. When I called our troops into action
column4: I did so with complete confidence in their courage and skill. And tonight
column5: thanks to them
column6: we are winning the war on terror. The men and women of our Armed Forces have delivered a message now clear to every enemy of the United States: Even 7
column7: 000 miles away
column8: across oceans and continents
column9: on mountaintops and in caves
column10: you will not escape the justice of this Nation.

column1: For many Americans
column2: these 4 months have brought sorrow and pain that will never completely go away. Every day a retired firefighter returns to Ground Zero to feel closer to his two sons who died there. At a memorial in New York
column3: a little boy left his football with a note for his lost father: "Dear Daddy
column4: please take this to heaven. I don't want to play football until I can play with you again some day."

column1: Last month
column2: at the grave of her husband
column3: Micheal
column4: a CIA officer and marine who died in Mazar-e-Sharif
column5: Shannon Spann said these words of farewell
column6: "Semper Fi
column7: my love." Shannon is with us tonight. Shannon
column8: I assure you and all who have lost a loved one that our cause is just
column9: and our country will never forget the debt we owe Micheal and all who gave their lives for freedom.

column1: Our cause is just
column2: and it continues. Our discoveries in Afghanistan confirmed our worst fears and showed us the true scope of the task ahead. We have seen the depth of our enemies' hatred in videos where they laugh about the loss of innocent life. And the depth of their hatred is equaled by the madness of the destruction they design. We have found diagrams of American nuclear powerplants and public water facilities
column3: detailed instructions for making chemical weapons
column4: surveillance maps of American cities
column5: and thorough descriptions of landmarks in America and throughout the world.

column1: What we have found in Afghanistan confirms that
column2: far from ending there
column3: our war against terror is only beginning. Most of the 19 men who hijacked planes on September the 11th were trained in Afghanistan's camps
column4: and so were tens of thousands of others. Thousands of dangerous killers
column5: schooled in the methods of murder
column6: often supported by outlaw regimes
column7: are now spread throughout the world like ticking timebombs
column8: set to go off without warning.

column1: Thanks to the work of our law enforcement officials and coalition partners
column2: hundreds of terrorists have been arrested. Yet
column3: tens of thousands of trained terrorists are still at large. These enemies view the entire world as a battlefield
column4: and we must pursue them wherever they are. So long as training camps operate
column5: so long as nations harbor terrorists
column6: freedom is at risk. And America and our allies must not and will not allow it.

column1: Our Nation will continue to be steadfast and patient and persistent in the pursuit of two great objectives. First
column2: we will shut down terrorist camps
column3: disrupt terrorist plans
column4: and bring terrorists to justice. And second
column5: we must prevent the terrorists and regimes who seek chemical
column6: biological
column7: or nuclear weapons from threatening the United States and the world.

column1: Our military has put the terror training camps of Afghanistan out of business
column2: yet camps still exist in at least a dozen countries. A terrorist underworld
column3: including groups like Hamas
column4: Hizballah
column5: Islamic Jihad
column6: Jaish-e-Mohammed
column7: operates in remote jungles and deserts and hides in the centers of large cities.

column1: While the most visible military action is in Afghanistan
column2: America is acting elsewhere. We now have troops in the Philippines
column3: helping to train that country's armed forces to go after terrorist cells that have executed an American and still hold hostages. Our soldiers
column4: working with the Bosnian Government
column5: seized terrorists who were plotting to bomb our Embassy. Our Navy is patrolling the coast of Africa to block the shipment of weapons and the establishment of terrorist camps in Somalia.

column1: My hope is that all nations will heed our call and eliminate the terrorist parasites who threaten their countries and our own. Many nations are acting forcefully. Pakistan is now cracking down on terror
column2: and I admire the strong leadership of President Musharraf. But some governments will be timid in the face of terror. And make no mistake about it: If they do not act
column3: America will.

column1: Our second goal is to prevent regimes that sponsor terror from threatening America or our friends and allies with weapons of mass destruction. Some of these regimes have been pretty quiet since September the 11th
column2: but we know their true nature.

column1: North Korea is a regime arming with missiles and weapons of mass destruction
column2: while starving its citizens.

column1: Iran aggressively pursues these weapons and exports terror
column2: while an unelected few repress the Iranian people's hope for freedom.

column1: Iraq continues to flaunt its hostility toward America and to support terror. The Iraqi regime has plotted to develop anthrax and nerve gas and nuclear weapons for over a decade. This is a regime that has already used poison gas to murder thousands of its own citizens
column2: leaving the bodies of mothers huddled over their dead children. This is a regime that agreed to international inspections
column3: then kicked out the inspectors. This is a regime that has something to hide from the civilized world.

column2: called Project Bio-Shield. The budget I send you will propose almost $6 billion to quickly make available effective vaccines and treatments against agents like anthrax
column3: botulinum toxin
column4: Ebola
column5: and plague. We must assume that our enemies would use these diseases as weapons
column6: and we must act before the dangers are upon us.

column1: Since September the 11th
column2: our intelligence and law enforcement agencies have worked more closely than ever to track and disrupt the terrorists. The FBI is improving its ability to analyze intelligence and is transforming itself to meet new threats. Tonight I am instructing the leaders of the FBI
column3: the CIA
column4: the Homeland Security
column5: and the Department of Defense to develop a Terrorist Threat Integration Center
column6: to merge and analyze all threat information in a single location. Our Government must have the very best information possible
column7: and we will use it to make sure the right people are in the right places to protect all our citizens.

column1: Our war against terror is a contest of will in which perseverance is power. In the ruins of two towers
column2: at the western wall of the Pentagon
column3: on a field in Pennsylvania
column4: this Nation made a pledge
column5: and we renew that pledge tonight: Whatever the duration of this struggle and whatever the difficulties
column6: we will not permit the triumph of violence in the affairs of men; free people will set the course of history.

column1: Today
column2: the gravest danger in the war on terror
column3: the gravest danger facing America and the world
column4: is outlaw regimes that seek and possess nuclear
column5: chemical
column6: and biological weapons. These regimes could use such weapons for blackmail
column7: terror
column8: and mass murder. They could also give or sell those weapons to terrorist allies
column9: who would use them without the least hesitation.

column1: This threat is new. America's duty is familiar. Throughout the 20th century
column2: small groups of men seized control of great nations
column3: built armies and arsenals
column4: and set out to dominate the weak and intimidate the world. In each case
column5: their ambitions of cruelty and murder had no limit. In each case
column6: the ambitions of Hitlerism
column7: militarism
column8: and communism were defeated by the will of free peoples
column9: by the strength of great alliances
column10: and by the might of the United States of America.

column1: Now
column2: in this century
column3: the ideology of power and domination has appeared again and seeks to gain the ultimate weapons of terror. Once again
column4: this Nation and all our friends are all that stand between a world at peace and a world of chaos and constant alarm. Once again
column5: we are called to defend the safety of our people and the hopes of all mankind. And we accept this responsibility.

column1: America is making a broad and determined effort to confront these dangers. We have called on the United Nations to fulfill its charter and stand by its demand that Iraq disarm. We're strongly supporting the International Atomic Energy Agency in its mission to track and control nuclear materials around the world. We're working with other governments to secure nuclear materials in the former Soviet Union and to strengthen global treaties banning the production and shipment of missile technologies and weapons of mass destruction.
In all these efforts
column2: however
column3: America's purpose is more than to follow a process; it is to achieve a result
column4: the end of terrible threats to the civilized world. All free nations have a stake in preventing sudden and catastrophic attacks. And we're asking them to join us
column5: and many are doing so. Yet the course of this Nation does not depend on the decisions of others. Whatever action is required
column6: whenever action is necessary
column7: I will defend the freedom and security of the American people.

column1: Different threats require different strategies. In Iran
column2: we continue to see a Government that represses its people
column3: pursues weapons of mass destruction
column4: and supports terror. We also see Iranian citizens risking intimidation and death as they speak out for liberty and human rights and democracy. Iranians
column5: like all people
column6: have a right to choose their own Government and determine their own destiny
column7: and the United States supports their aspirations to live in freedom.

column1: On the Korean Peninsula
column2: an oppressive regime rules a people living in fear and starvation. Throughout the 1990s
column3: the United States relied on a negotiated framework to keep North Korea from gaining nuclear weapons. We now know that that regime was deceiving the world and developing those weapons all along. And today
column4: the North Korean regime is using its nuclear program to incite fear and seek concessions. America and the world will not be blackmailed.

column1: America is working with the countries of the region
column2: South Korea
column3: Japan
column4: China
column5: and Russia
column6: to find a peaceful solution and to show the North Korean Government that nuclear weapons will bring only isolation
column7: economic stagnation
column8: and continued hardship. The North Korean regime will find respect in the world and revival for its people only when it turns away from its nuclear ambitions.

column1: Our Nation and the world must learn the lessons of the Korean Peninsula and not allow an even greater threat to rise up in Iraq. A brutal dictator
column2: with a history of reckless aggression
column3: with ties to terrorism
column4: with great potential wealth
column5: will not be permitted to dominate a vital region and threaten the United States.

column1: Twelve years ago
column2: Saddam Hussein faced the prospect of being the last casualty in a war he had started and lost. To spare himself
column3: he agreed to disarm of all weapons of mass destruction. For the next 12 years
column4: he systematically violated that agreement. He pursued chemical
column5: biological
column6: and nuclear weapons
column7: even while inspectors were in his country. Nothing to date has restrained him from his pursuit of these weapons
column8: not economic sanctions
column9: not isolation from the civilized world
column10: not even cruise missile strikes on his military facilities.

column1: Almost 3 months ago
column2: the United Nations Security Council gave Saddam Hussein his final chance to disarm. He has shown instead utter contempt for the United Nations and for the opinion of the world. The 108 U.N. inspectors were sent to conduct were not sent to conduct a scavenger hunt for hidden materials across a country the size of California. The job of the inspectors is to verify that Iraq's regime is disarming. It is up to Iraq to show exactly where it is hiding its banned weapons
column3: lay those weapons out for the world to see
column4: and destroy them as directed. Nothing like this has happened.

column1: The United Nations concluded in 1999 that Saddam Hussein had biological weapons sufficient to produce over 25
column2: 000 liters of anthrax
column3: enough doses to kill several million people. He hasn't accounted for that material. He's given no evidence that he has destroyed it.

column1: The United Nations concluded that Saddam Hussein had materials sufficient to produce more than 38
column2: 000 liters of botulinum toxin
column3: enough to subject millions of people to death by respiratory failure. He hasn't accounted for that material. He's given no evidence that he has destroyed it.

column1: Our intelligence officials estimate that Saddam Hussein had the materials to produce as much as 500 tons of sarin
column2: mustard
column3: and VX nerve agent. In such quantities
column4: these chemical agents could also kill untold thousands. He's not accounted for these materials. He has given no evidence that he has destroyed them.

column1: U.S. intelligence indicates that Saddam Hussein had upwards of 30
column2: 000 munitions capable of delivering chemical agents. Inspectors recently turned up 16 of them
column3: despite Iraq's recent declaration denying their existence. Saddam Hussein has not accounted for the remaining 29
column4: 984 of these prohibited munitions. He's given no evidence that he has destroyed them.

column1: From three Iraqi defectors we know that Iraq
column2: in the late 1990s
column3: had several mobile biological weapons labs. These are designed to produce germ warfare agents and can be moved from place to a place to evade inspectors. Saddam Hussein has not disclosed these facilities. He's given no evidence that he has destroyed them.

column1: The International Atomic Energy Agency confirmed in the 1990s that Saddam Hussein had an advanced nuclear weapons development program
column2: had a design for a nuclear weapon
column3: and was working on five different methods of enriching uranium for a bomb. The British Government has learned that Saddam Hussein recently sought significant quantities of uranium from Africa. Our intelligence sources tell us that he has attempted to purchase high-strength aluminum tubes suitable for nuclear weapons production. Saddam Hussein has not credibly explained these activities. He clearly has much to hide.

column1: The dictator of Iraq is not disarming. To the contrary
column2: he is deceiving. From intelligence sources we know
column3: for instance
column4: that thousands of Iraqi security personnel are at work hiding documents and materials from the U.N. inspectors
column5: sanitizing inspection sites
column6: and monitoring the inspectors themselves. Iraqi officials accompany the inspectors in order to intimidate witnesses. Iraq is blocking U-2 surveillance flights requested by the United Nations. Iraqi intelligence officers are posing as the scientists inspectors are supposed to interview. Real scientists have been coached by Iraqi officials on what to say. Intelligence sources indicate that Saddam Hussein has ordered that scientists who cooperate with U.N. inspectors in disarming Iraq will be killed
column7: along with their families.

column1: Year after year
column2: Saddam Hussein has gone to elaborate lengths
column3: spent enormous sums
column4: taken great risks to build and keep weapons of mass destruction. But why? The only possible explanation
column5: the only possible use he could have for those weapons
column6: is to dominate
column7: intimidate
column8: or attack.

column1: With nuclear arms or a full arsenal of chemical and biological weapons
column2: Saddam Hussein could resume his ambitions of conquest in the Middle East and create deadly havoc in that region. And this Congress and the American people must recognize another threat. Evidence from intelligence sources
column3: secret communications
column4: and statements by people now in custody reveal that Saddam Hussein aids and protects terrorists
column5: including members of Al Qaida. Secretly and without fingerprints
column6: he could provide one of his hidden weapons to terrorists or help them develop their own.

column1: Before September the 11th
column2: many in the world believed that Saddam Hussein could be contained. But chemical agents
column3: lethal viruses
column4: and shadowy terrorist networks are not easily contained. Imagine those 19 hijackers with other weapons and other plans
column5: this time armed by Saddam Hussein. It would take one vial
column6: one canister
column7: one crate slipped into this country to bring a day of horror like none we have ever known. We will do everything in our power to make sure that that day never comes.

column1: Some have said we must not act until the threat is imminent. Since when have terrorists and tyrants announced their intentions
column2: politely putting us on notice before they strike? If this threat is permitted to fully and suddenly emerge
column3: all actions
column4: all words
column5: and all recriminations would come too late. Trusting in the sanity and restraint of Saddam Hussein is not a strategy
column6: and it is not an option.

column1: The dictator who is assembling the world's most dangerous weapons has already used them on whole villages
column2: leaving thousands of his own citizens dead
column3: blind
column4: or disfigured. Iraqi refugees tell us how forced confessions are obtained
column5: by torturing children while their parents are made to watch. International human rights groups have cataloged other methods used in the torture chambers of Iraq: electric shock
column6: burning with hot irons
column7: dripping acid on the skin
column8: mutilation with electric drills
column9: cutting out tongues
column10: and rape. If this is not evil
column11: then evil has no meaning.

column1: And tonight I have a message for the brave and oppressed people of Iraq: Your enemy is not surrounding your country; your enemy is ruling your country. And the day he and his regime are removed from power will be the day of your liberation.

The world has waited 12 years for Iraq to disarm. America will not accept a serious and mounting threat to our country and our friends and our allies. The United States will ask the U.N. Security Council to convene on February the 5th to consider the facts of Iraq's ongoing defiance of the world. Secretary of State Powell will present information and intelligence about Iraqi's legalIraq's illegal weapons programs
column2: its attempt to hide those weapons from inspectors
column3: and its links to terrorist groups.

column1: We will consult. But let there be no misunderstanding: If Saddam Hussein does not fully disarm
column2: for the safety of our people and for the peace of the world
column3: we will lead a coalition to disarm him.

column1: Tonight I have a message for the men and women who will keep the peace
column2: members of the American Armed Forces: Many of you are assembling in or near the Middle East
column3: and some crucial hours may lay ahead. In those hours
column4: the success of our cause will depend on you. Your training has prepared you. Your honor will guide you. You believe in America
column5: and America believes in you.

column1: Sending Americans into battle is the most profound decision a President can make. The technologies of war have changed; the risks and suffering of war have not. For the brave Americans who bear the risk
column2: no victory is free from sorrow. This Nation fights reluctantly
column3: because we know the cost and we dread the days of mourning that always come.

column1: We seek peace. We strive for peace. And sometimes peace must be defended. A future lived at the mercy of terrible threats is no peace at all. If war is forced upon us
column2: we will fight in a just cause and by just means
column3: sparing
column4: in every way we can
column5: the innocent. And if war is forced upon us
column6: we will fight with the full force and might of the United States military
column7: and we will prevail.

column1: And as we and our coalition partners are doing in Afghanistan
column2: we will bring to the Iraqi people food and medicines and supplies and freedom.

column1: Many challenges
column2: abroad and at home
column3: have arrived in a single season. In 2 years
column4: America has gone from a sense of invulnerability to an awareness of peril
column5: from bitter division in small matters to calm unity in great causes. And we go forward with confidence
column6: because this call of history has come to the right country.

column1: Americans are a resolute people who have risen to every test of our time. Adversity has revealed the character of our country
column2: to the world and to ourselves. America is a strong nation and honorable in the use of our strength. We exercise power without conquest
column3: and we sacrifice for the liberty of strangers.

column1: Americans are a free people who know that freedom is the right of every person and the future of every nation. The liberty we prize is not America's gift to the world; it is God's gift to humanity.
We Americans have faith in ourselves
column2: but not in ourselves alone. We do not knowwe do not claim to know all the ways of providence
column3: yet we can trust in them
column4: placing our confidence in the loving God behind all of life and all of history.

column1: May He guide us now. And may God continue to bless the United States of America.@
George W. Bush|Address Before a Joint Session of the Congress on the State of the Union|2004-01-20|@Mr. Speaker
column2: Vice President Cheney
column3: Members of Congress
column4: distinguished guests
column5: and fellow citizens: America this evening is a nation called to great responsibilities
column6: and we are rising to meet them.

column1: As we gather tonight
column2: hundreds of thousands of American service men and women are deployed across the world in the war on terror. By bringing hope to the oppressed and delivering justice to the violent
column3: they are making America more secure.

column1: Each day
column2: law enforcement personnel and intelligence officers are tracking terrorist threats; analysts are examining airline passenger lists; the men and women of our new Homeland Security Department are patrolling our coasts and borders. And their vigilance is protecting America.

column1: Americans are proving once again to be the hardest working people in the world. The American economy is growing stronger. The tax relief you passed is working.
Tonight Members of Congress can take pride in the great works of compassion and reform that skeptics had thought impossible. You're raising the standards for our public schools
column2: and you are giving our senior citizens prescription drug coverage under Medicare.

column1: We have faced serious challenges together
column2: and now we face a choice: We can go forward with confidence and resolve
column3: or we can turn back to the dangerous illusion that terrorists are not plotting and outlaw regimes are no threat to us. We can press on with economic growth and reforms in education and Medicare
column4: or we can turn back to old policies and old divisions.

column1: We've not come all this way
column2: through tragedy and trial and war
column3: only to falter and leave our work unfinished. Americans are rising to the tasks of history
column4: and they expect the same from us. In their efforts
column5: their enterprise
column6: and their character
column7: the American people are showing that the state of our Union is confident and strong.

column1: Our greatest responsibility is the active defense of the American people. Twenty-eight months have passed since September the 11th
column2: 2001over 2 years without an attack on American soil. And it is tempting to believe that the danger is behind us. That hope is understandable
column3: comforting and false. The killing has continued in Bali
column4: Jakarta
column5: Casablanca
column6: Riyadh
column7: Mombasa
column8: Jerusalem
column9: Istanbul
column10: and Baghdad. The terrorists continue to plot against America and the civilized world. And by our will and courage
column11: this danger will be defeated.

column1: Inside the United States
column2: where the war began
column3: we must continue to give our homeland security and law enforcement personnel every tool they need to defend us. And one of those essential tools is the PATRIOT Act
column4: which allows Federal law enforcement to better share information to track terrorists
column5: to disrupt their cells
column6: and to seize their assets. For years
column7: we have used similar provisions to catch embezzlers and drug traffickers. If these methods are good for hunting criminals
column8: they are even more important for hunting terrorists.

column1: Key provisions of the PATRIOT Act are set to expire next year. The terrorist threat will not expire on that schedule. Our law enforcement needs this vital legislation to protect our citizens. You need to renew the PATRIOT Act.
America is on the offensive against the terrorists who started this war. Last March
column2: Khalid Sheik Mohammed
column3: a mastermind of September the 11th
column4: awoke to find himself in the custody of U.S. and Pakistani authorities. Last August the 11th brought the capture of the terrorist Hambali
column5: who was a key player in the attack in Indonesia that killed over 200 people. We're tracking Al Qaida around the world
column6: and nearly two-thirds of their known leaders have now been captured or killed. Thousands of very skilled and determined military personnel are on the manhunt
column7: going after the remaining killers who hide in cities and caves
column8: and one by one
column9: we will bring these terrorists to justice.

column1: As part of the offensive against terror
column2: we are also confronting the regimes that harbor and support terrorists and could supply them with nuclear
column3: chemical
column4: or biological weapons. The United States and our allies are determined: We refuse to live in the shadow of this ultimate danger.

column1: The first to see our determination were the Taliban
column2: who made Afghanistan the primary training base of Al Qaida killers. As of this month
column3: that country has a new constitution guaranteeing free elections and full participation by women. Businesses are opening. Health care centers are being established
column4: and the boys and girls of Afghanistan are back in school. With the help from the new Afghan army
column5: our coalition is leading aggressive raids against the surviving members of the Taliban and Al Qaida. The men and women of Afghanistan are building a nation that is free and proud and fighting terror
column6: and America is honored to be their friend.

column1: Since we last met in this Chamber
column2: combat forces of the United States
column3: Great Britain
column4: Australia
column5: Poland
column6: and other countries enforced the demands of the United Nations
column7: ended the rule of Saddam Hussein. And the people of Iraq are free.

column1: Having broken the Ba'athist regime
column2: we face a remnant of violent Saddam supporters. Men who ran away from our troops in battle are now dispersed and attack from the shadows. These killers
column3: joined by foreign terrorists
column4: are a serious
column5: continuing danger. Yet we're making progress against them. The once all-powerful ruler of Iraq was found in a hole and now sits in a prison cell. Of the top 55 officials of the former regime
column6: we have captured or killed 45. Our forces are on the offensive
column7: leading over 1
column8: 600 patrols a day and conducting an average of 180 raids a week. We are dealing with these thugs in Iraq just as surely as we dealt with Saddam Hussein's evil regime.

column1: The work of building a new Iraq is hard
column2: and it is right. And America has always been willing to do what it takes for what is right. Last January
column3: Iraq's only law was the whim of one brutal man. Today
column4: our coalition is working with the Iraqi Governing Council to draft a basic law with a bill of rights. We're working with Iraqis and the United Nations to prepare for a transition to full Iraqi sovereignty by the end of June.

column1: As democracy takes hold in Iraq
column2: the enemies of freedom will do all in their power to spread violence and fear. They are trying to shake the will of our country and our friends
column3: but the United States of America will never be intimidated by thugs and assassins. The killers will fail
column4: and the Iraqi people will live in freedom.

column1: Month by month
column2: Iraqis are assuming more responsibility for their own security and their own future. And tonight we are honored to welcome one of Iraq's most respected leaders
column3: the current President of the Iraqi Governing Council
column4: Adnan Pachachi. Sir
column5: America stands with you and the Iraqi people as you build a free and peaceful nation.

column1: Because of American leadership and resolve
column2: the world is changing for the better. Last month
column3: the leader of Libya voluntarily pledged to disclose and dismantle all of his regime's weapons of mass destruction programs
column4: including a uranium enrichment project for nuclear weapons. Colonel Qadhafi correctly judged that his country would be better off and far more secure without weapons of mass murder.

column1: Nine months of intense negotiations involving the United States and Great Britain succeeded with Libya
column2: while 12 years of diplomacy with Iraq did not. And one reason is clear: For diplomacy to be effective
column3: words must be credible
column4: and no one can now doubt the word of America.

column1: Different threats require different strategies. Along with nations in the region
