column2: we're insisting that North Korea eliminate its nuclear program. America and the international community are demanding that Iran meet its commitments and not develop nuclear weapons. America is committed to keeping the world's most dangerous weapons out of the hands of the most dangerous regimes.

column1: When I came to this rostrum on September the 20th
column3: I brought the police shield of a fallen officer
column4: my reminder of lives that ended and a task that does not end. I gave to you and to all Americans my complete commitment to securing our country and defeating our enemies. And this pledge
column5: given by one
column6: has been kept by many.

column1: You in the Congress have provided the resources for our defense and cast the difficult votes of war and peace. Our closest allies have been unwavering. America's intelligence personnel and diplomats have been skilled and tireless. And the men and women of the American militarythey have taken the hardest duty. We've seen their skill and their courage in armored charges and midnight raids and lonely hours on faithful watch. We have seen the joy when they return and felt the sorrow when one is lost. I've had the honor of meeting our service men and women at many posts
column2: from the deck of a carrier in the Pacific to a mess hall in Baghdad.

column1: Many of our troops are listening tonight
column2: and I want you and your families to know: America is proud of you
column3: and my administration and this Congress will give you the resources you need to fight and win the war on terror.

column1: I know that some people question if America is really in a war at all. They view terrorism more as a crime
column2: a problem to be solved mainly with law enforcement and indictments. After the World Trade Center was first attacked in 1993
column3: some of the guilty were indicted and tried and convicted and sent to prison. But the matter was not settled. The terrorists were still training and plotting in other nations and drawing up more ambitious plans. After the chaos and carnage of September the 11th
column4: it is not enough to serve our enemies with legal papers. The terrorists and their supporters declared war on the United States
column5: and war is what they got.

column1: Some in this Chamber and in our country did not support the liberation of Iraq. Objections to war often come from principled motives
column2: but let us be candid about the consequences of leaving Saddam Hussein in power. We're seeking all the facts. Already
column3: the Kay Report identified dozens of weapons-of-mass-destruction-related program activities and significant amounts of equipment that Iraq concealed from the United Nations. Had we failed to act
column4: the dictator's weapons of mass destruction programs would continue to this day. Had we failed to act
column5: Security Council resolutions on Iraq would have been revealed as empty threats
column6: weakening the United Nations and encouraging defiance by dictators around the world. Iraq's torture chambers would still be filled with victims
column7: terrified and innocent. The killing fields of Iraq
column8: where hundreds of thousands of men and women and children vanished into the sands
column9: would still be known only to the killers. For all who love freedom and peace
column10: the world without Saddam Hussein's regime is a better and safer place.

column1: Some critics have said our duties in Iraq must be internationalized. This particular criticism is hard to explain to our partners in Britain
column2: Australia
column3: Japan
column4: South Korea
column5: the Philippines
column6: Thailand
column7: Italy
column8: Spain
column9: Poland
column10: Denmark
column11: Hungary
column12: Bulgaria
column13: Ukraine
column14: Romania
column18: and the 17 other countries that have committed troops to Iraq. As we debate at home
column19: we must never ignore the vital contributions of our international partners or dismiss their sacrifices.

column1: From the beginning
column2: America has sought international support for our operations in Afghanistan and Iraq
column3: and we have gained much support. There is a difference
column4: however
column5: between leading a coalition of many nations and submitting to the objections of a few. America will never seek a permission slip to defend the security of our country.

column1: We also hear doubts that democracy is a realistic goal for the greater Middle East
column2: where freedom is rare. Yet it is mistaken and condescending to assume that whole cultures and great religions are incompatible with liberty and self-government. I believe that God has planted in every human heart the desire to live in freedom
column3: and even when that desire is crushed by tyranny for decades
column4: it will rise again.

column1: As long as the Middle East remains a place of tyranny and despair and anger
column2: it will continue to produce men and movements that threaten the safety of America and our friends. So America is pursuing a forward strategy of freedom in the greater Middle East. We will challenge the enemies of reform
column3: confront the allies of terror
column4: and expect a higher standard from our friend. To cut through the barriers of hateful propaganda
column5: the Voice of America and other broadcast services are expanding their programming in Arabic and Persian
column6: and soon a new television service will begin providing reliable news and information across the region. I will send you a proposal to double the budget of the National Endowment for Democracy and to focus its new work on the development of free elections and free markets
column7: free press
column8: and free labor unions in the Middle East. And above all
column9: we will finish the historic work of democracy in Afghanistan and Iraq so those nations can light the way for others and help transform a troubled part of the world.

column1: America is a nation with a mission
column2: and that mission comes from our most basic beliefs. We have no desire to dominate
column3: no ambitions of empire. Our aim is a democratic peace
column4: a peace founded upon the dignity and rights of every man and woman. America acts in this cause with friends and allies at our side
column5: yet we understand our special calling: This great Republic will lead the cause of freedom.

column1: In the last 3 years
column2: adversity has also revealed the fundamental strengths of the American economy. We have come through recession and terrorist attack and corporate scandals and the uncertainties of war. And because you acted to stimulate our economy with tax relief
column3: this economy is strong and growing stronger.

column1: You have doubled the child tax credit from 500 to $1
column3: reduced the marriage penalty
column4: begun to phase out the death tax
column5: reduced taxes on capital gains and stock dividends
column6: cut taxes on small businesses
column7: and you have lowered taxes for every American who pays income taxes.

column1: Americans took those dollars and put them to work
column2: driving this economy forward. The pace of economic growth in the third quarter of 2003 was the fastest in nearly 20 years; new home construction
column3: the highest in almost 20 years; homeowner-ship rates
column4: the highest ever. Manufacturing activity is increasing. Inflation is low. Interest rates are low. Exports are growing. Productivity is high
column5: and jobs are on the rise. These numbers confirm that the American people are using their money far better than Government would have
column6: and you were right to return it.

column1: America's growing economy is also a changing economy. As technology transforms the way almost every job is done
column2: America becomes more productive and workers need new skills. Much of our job growth will be found in high-skilled fields like health care and biotechnology. So we must respond by helping more Americans gain the skills to find good jobs in our new economy.

column1: All skills begin with the basics of reading and math
column2: which are supposed to be learned in the early grades of our schools. Yet for too long
column3: for too many children
column4: those skills were never mastered. By passing the No Child Left Behind Act
column5: you have made the expectation of literacy the law of our country. We're providing more funding for our schools
column6: a 36-percent increase since 2001. We're requiring higher standards. We are regularly testing every child on the fundamentals. We are reporting results to parents and making sure they have better options when schools are not performing. We are making progress toward excellence for every child in America.

column1: But the status quo always has defenders. Some want to undermine the No Child Left Behind Act by weakening standards and accountability. Yet the results we require are really a matter of common sense: We expect third graders to read and do math at the third grade level
column2: and that's not asking too much. Testing is the only way to identify and help students who are falling behind. This Nation will not go back to the days of simply shuffling children along from grade to grade without them learning the basics. I refuse to give up on any child
column3: and the No Child Left Behind Act is opening the door of opportunity to all of America's children.

column1: At the same time
column2: we must ensure that older students and adults can gain the skills they need to find work now. Many of the fastest growing occupations require strong math and science preparation and training beyond the high school level. So tonight
column3: I propose a series of measures called Jobs for the 21st Century. This program will provide extra help to middle and high school students who fall behind in reading and math
column4: expand advanced placement programs in low-income schools
column5: invite math and science professionals from the private sector to teach part-time in our high schools. I propose larger Pell grants for students who prepare for college with demanding courses in high school. I propose increasing our support for America's fine community colleges
column6: so they canI do so
column7: so they can train workers for industries that are creating the most new jobs. By all these actions
column8: we'll help more and more Americans to join in the growing prosperity of our country. Job training is important
column9: and so is job creation. We must continue to pursue an aggressive
column10: progrowth economic agenda.

column1: Congress has some unfinished business on the issue of taxes. The tax reductions you passed are set to expire. Unless you act
column2: the unfair tax on marriage will go back up. Unless you act
column3: millions of families will be charged $300 more in Federal taxes for every child. Unless you act
column4: small businesses will pay higher taxes. Unless you act
column5: the death tax will eventually come back to life. Unless you act
column6: Americans face a tax increase. What Congress has given
column7: the Congress should not take away. For the sake of job growth
column8: the tax cuts you passed should be permanent.

column1: Our agenda for jobs and growth must help small-business owners and employees with relief from needless Federal regulation and protect them from junk and frivolous lawsuits.
Consumers and businesses need reliable supplies of energy to make our economy run
column2: so I urge you to pass legislation to modernize our electricity system
column3: promote conservation
column4: and make America less dependent on foreign sources of energy.

column1: My administration is promoting free and fair trade to open up new markets for America's entrepreneurs and manufacturers and farmers
column2: to create jobs for American workers. Younger workers should have the opportunity to build a nest egg by saving part of their Social Security taxes in a personal retirement account. We should make the Social Security system a source of ownership for the American people. And we should limit the burden of Government on this economy by acting as good stewards of taxpayers' dollars.

column1: In 2 weeks
column2: I will send you a budget that funds the war
column3: protects the homeland
column4: and meets important domestic needs while limiting the growth in discretionary spending to less than 4 percent. This will require that Congress focus on priorities
column5: cut wasteful spending
column6: and be wise with the people's money. By doing so
column7: we can cut the deficit in half over the next 5 years.

column1: Tonight I also ask you to reform our immigration laws so they reflect our values and benefit our economy. I propose a new temporary-worker program to match willing foreign workers with willing employers when no Americans can be found to fill the job. This reform will be good for our economy because employers will find needed workers in an honest and orderly system. A temporary-worker program will help protect our homeland
column2: allowing Border Patrol and law enforcement to focus on true threats to our national security.

column1: I oppose amnesty
column2: because it would encourage further illegal immigration and unfairly reward those who break our laws. My temporary-worker program will preserve the citizenship path for those who respect the law while bringing millions of hard-working men and women out from the shadows of American life.

column1: Our Nation's health care system
column2: like our economy
column3: is also in a time of change. Amazing medical technologies are improving and saving lives. This dramatic progress has brought its own challenge
column4: in the rising costs of medical care and health insurance. Members of Congress
column5: we must work together to help control those costs and extend the benefits of modern medicine throughout our country.

column1: Meeting these goals requires bipartisan effort
column2: and 2 months ago
column3: you showed the way. By strengthening Medicare and adding a prescription drug benefit
column4: you kept a basic commitment to our seniors. You are giving them the modern medicine they deserve.

column1: Starting this year
column2: under the law you passed
column3: seniors can choose to receive a drug discount card
column4: saving them 10 to 25 percent off the retail price of most prescription drugs
column5: and millions of low-income seniors can get an additional $600 to buy medicine. Beginning next year
column6: seniors will have new coverage for preventive screenings against diabetes and heart disease
column7: and seniors just entering Medicare can receive wellness exams.

column1: In January of 2006
column2: seniors can get prescription drug coverage under Medicare. For a monthly premium of about $35
column3: most seniors who do not have that coverage today can expect to see their drug bills cut roughly in half. Under this reform
column4: senior citizens will be able to keep their Medicare just as it is
column5: or they can choose a Medicare plan that fits them best
column6: just as you
column7: as Members of Congress
column8: can choose an insurance plan that meets your needs. And starting this year
column9: millions of Americans will be able to save money tax-free for their medical expenses in a health savings account.

column1: I signed this measure proudly
column2: and any attempt to limit the choices of our seniors or to take away their prescription drug coverage under Medicare will meet my veto.

column1: On the critical issue of health care
column2: our goal is to ensure that Americans can choose and afford private health care coverage that best fits their individual needs. To make insurance more affordable
column3: Congress must act to address rapidly rising health care costs. Small businesses should be able to band together and negotiate for lower insurance rates
column4: so they can cover more workers with health insurance. I urge you to pass association health plans. I ask you to give lower income Americans a refundable tax credit that would allow millions to buy their own basic health insurance.

column1: By computerizing health records
column2: we can avoid dangerous medical mistakes
column3: reduce costs
column4: and improve care. To protect the doctor-patient relationship and keep good doctors doing good work
column5: we must eliminate wasteful and frivolous medical lawsuits. And tonight I propose that individuals who buy catastrophic health care coverage as part of our new health savings accounts be allowed to deduct 100 percent of the premiums from their taxes.

column1: A Government-run health care system is the wrong prescription. By keeping costs under control
column2: expanding access
column3: and helping more Americans afford coverage
column4: we will preserve the system of private medicine that makes America's health care the best in the world.

column1: We are living in a time of great change in our world
column2: in our economy
column3: in science and medicine. Yet some things endure: courage and compassion
column4: reverence and integrity
column5: respect for differences of faith and race. The values we try to live by never change
column6: and they are instilled in us by fundamental institutions such as families and schools and religious congregations. These institutions
column7: these unseen pillars of civilization
column8: must remain strong in America
column9: and we will defend them. We must stand with our families to help them raise healthy
column10: responsible children. When it comes to helping children make right choices
column11: there is work for all of us to do.

column1: One of the worst decisions our children can make is to gamble their lives and futures on drugs. Our Government is helping parents confront this problem with aggressive education
column2: treatment
column3: and law enforcement. Drug use in high school has declined by 11 percent over the last 2 years. Four hundred thousand fewer young people are using illegal drugs than in the year 2001. In my budget
column4: I propose new funding to continue our aggressive
column5: community-based strategy to reduce demand for illegal drugs. Drug testing in our schools has proven to be an effective part of this effort. So tonight I propose an additional 23 million for schools that want to use drug testing as a tool to save children's lives. The aim here is not to punish children but to send them this message: We love you
column6: and we do not want to lose you.

column1: To help children make right choices
column2: they need good examples. Athletics play such an important role in our society
column3: but unfortunately
column4: some in professional sports are not setting much of an example. The use of performance-enhancing drugs like steroids in baseball
column5: football
column6: and other sports is dangerous
column7: and it sends the wrong message
column8: that there are shortcuts to accomplishment and that performance is more important than character. So tonight I call on team owners
column9: union representatives
column10: coaches
column11: and players to take the lead
column12: to send the right signal
column13: to get tough
column14: and to get rid of steroids now.

column1: To encourage right choices
column2: we must be willing to confront the dangers young people face
column3: even when they're difficult to talk about. Each year
column4: about 3 million teenagers contract sexually transmitted diseases that can harm them or kill them or prevent them from ever becoming parents. In my budget
column5: I propose a grassroots campaign to help inform families about these medical risks. We will double Federal funding for abstinence programs
column6: so schools can teach this fact of life: Abstinence for young people is the only certain way to avoid sexually transmitted diseases.

column1: Decisions children now make can affect their health and character for the rest of their lives. All of us
column2: parents and schools and government
column3: must work together to counter the negative influence of the culture and to send the right messages to our children.

column1: A strong America must also value the institution of marriage. I believe we should respect individuals as we take a principled stand for one of the most fundamental
column2: enduring institutions of our civilization. Congress has already taken a stand on this issue by passing the Defense of Marriage Act
column3: signed in 1996 by President Clinton. That statute protects marriage under Federal law as a union of a man and a woman and declares that one State may not redefine marriage for other States.

column1: Activist judges
column2: however
column3: have begun redefining marriage by court order
column4: without regard for the will of the people and their elected representatives. On an issue of such great consequence
column5: the people's voice must be heard. If judges insist on forcing their arbitrary will upon the people
column6: the only alternative left to the people would be the constitutional process. Our Nation must defend the sanctity of marriage.

column1: The outcome of this debate is important
column2: and so is the way we conduct it. The same moral tradition that defines marriage also teaches that each individual has dignity and value in God's sight.

column1: It's also important to strengthen our communities by unleashing the compassion of America's religious institutions. Religious charities of every creed are doing some of the most vital work in our country: mentoring children
column2: feeding the hungry
column3: taking the hand of the lonely. Yet Government has often denied social service grants and contracts to these groups
column4: just because they have a cross or a Star of David or a crescent on the wall. By Executive order
column5: I have opened billions of dollars in grant money to competition that includes faith-based charities. Tonight I ask you to codify this into law
column6: so people of faith can know that the law will never discriminate against them again.

column1: In the past
column2: we've worked together to bring mentors to children of prisoners and provide treatment for the addicted and help for the homeless. Tonight I ask you to consider another group of Americans in need of help. This year
column3: some 600
column4: 000 inmates will be released from prison back into society. We know from long experience that if they can't find work or a home or help
column5: they are much more likely to commit crime and return to prison. So tonight I propose a 4-year
column6: $300 million prisoner reentry initiative to expand job training and placement services
column7: to provide transitional housing
column8: and to help newly released prisoners get mentoring
column9: including from faith-based groups. America is the land of second chance
column10: and when the gates of the prison open
column11: the path ahead should lead to a better life.

column1: For all Americans
column2: the last 3 years have brought tests we did not ask for and achievements shared by all. By our actions
column3: we have shown what kind of nation we are. In grief
column4: we have found the grace to go on. In challenge
column5: we rediscovered the courage and daring of a free people. In victory
column6: we have shown the noble aims and good heart of America. And having come this far
column7: we sense that we live in a time set apart.

column1: I've been witness to the character of the people of America
column2: who have shown calm in times of danger
column3: compassion for one another
column4: and toughness for the long haul. All of us have been partners in a great enterprise. And even some of the youngest understand that we are living in historic times. Last month a girl in Lincoln
column5: Rhode Island
column6: sent me a letter. It began
column7: "Dear George W. Bush. If there's anything you know I
column8: Ashley Pearson
column9: age 10
column10: can do to help anyone
column11: please send me a letter and tell me what I can do to save our country." She added this P.S.: "If you can send a letter to the troops
column12: please put
column13: 'Ashley Pearson believes in you."'

column1: Tonight
column2: Ashley
column3: your message to our troops has just been conveyed. And yes
column4: you have some duties yourself: Study hard in school; listen to your mom or dad; help someone in need; and when you and your friends see a man or woman in uniform
column5: say
column6: "Thank you." And Ashley
column7: while you do your part
column8: all of us here in this great Chamber will do our best to keep you and the rest of America safe and free.

column1: My fellow citizens
column2: we now move forward with confidence and faith. Our Nation is strong and steadfast. The cause we serve is right
column3: because it is the cause of all mankind. The momentum of freedom in our world is unmistakable
column4: and it is not carried forward by our power alone. We can trust in that greater power who guides the unfolding of the years. And in all that is to come
column5: we can know that His purposes are just and true.

column1: May God continue to bless America.@
George W. Bush|Address Before a Joint Session of the Congress on the State of the Union|2005-02-02|@Mr. Speaker
column2: Vice President Cheney
column3: Members of Congress
column4: fellow citizens:

column1: As a new Congress gathers
column2: all of us in the elected branches of Government share a great privilege: We've been placed in office by the votes of the people we serve. And tonight that is a privilege we share with newly elected leaders of Afghanistan
column3: the Palestinian Territories
column4: Ukraine
column5: and a free and sovereign Iraq.

column1: Two weeks ago
column2: I stood on the steps of this Capitol and renewed the commitment of our Nation to the guiding ideal of liberty for all. This evening I will set forth policies to advance that ideal at home and around the world.

column1: Tonight
column2: with a healthy
column3: growing economy
column4: with more Americans going back to work
column5: with our Nation an active force for good in the world
column6: the state of our Union is confident and strong.

column1: Our generation has been blessed by the expansion of opportunity
column2: by advances in medicine
column3: by the security purchased by our parents' sacrifice. Now
column4: as we see a little gray in the mirroror a lot of gray ... and we watch our children moving into adulthood
column5: we ask the question: What will be the state of their Union? Members of Congress
column6: the choices we make together will answer that question. Over the next several months
column7: on issue after issue
column8: let us do what Americans have always done and build a better world for our children and our grandchildren.

column1: First
column2: we must be good stewards of this economy and renew the great institutions on which millions of our fellow citizens rely. America's economy is the fastest growing of any major industrialized nation. In the past 4 years
column3: we've provided tax relief to every person who pays income taxes
column4: overcome a recession
column5: opened up new markets abroad
column6: prosecuted corporate criminals
column7: raised homeownership to its highest level in history. And in the last year alone
column8: the United States has added 2.3 million new jobs. When action was needed
column9: the Congress delivered
column10: and the Nation is grateful.

column1: Now we must add to these achievements. By making our economy more flexible
column2: more innovative
column3: and more competitive
column4: we will keep America the economic leader of the world.

column1: America's prosperity requires restraining the spending appetite of the Federal Government. I welcome the bipartisan enthusiasm for spending discipline. I will send you a budget that holds the growth of discretionary spending below inflation
column2: makes tax relief permanent
column3: and stays on track to cut the deficit in half by 2009. My budget substantially reduces or eliminates more than 150 Government programs that are not getting results or duplicate current efforts or do not fulfill essential priorities. The principle here is clear: Taxpayer dollars must be spent wisely or not at all.

column1: To make our economy stronger and more dynamic
column2: we must prepare a rising generation to fill the jobs of the 21st century. Under the No Child Left Behind Act
column3: standards are higher
column4: test scores are on the rise
column5: and we're closing the achievement gap for minority students. Now we must demand better results from our high schools
column6: so every high school diploma is a ticket to success. We will help an additional 200
column7: 000 workers to get training for a better career by reforming our job training system and strengthening America's community colleges. And we'll make it easier for Americans to afford a college education by increasing the size of Pell grants.

column1: To make our economy stronger and more competitive
column2: America must reward
column3: not punish
column4: the efforts and dreams of entrepreneurs. Small business is the path of advancement
column5: especially for women and minorities
column6: so we must free small businesses from needless regulation and protect honest job-creators from junk lawsuits. Justice is distorted and our economy is held back by irresponsible class actions and frivolous asbestos claims
column7: and I urge Congress to pass legal reforms this year.

column1: To make our economy stronger and more productive
column2: we must make health care more affordable and give families greater access to good coverage and more control over their health decisions. I ask Congress to move forward on a comprehensive health care agenda with tax credits to help low-income workers buy insurance
column3: a community health center in every poor county
column4: improved information technology to prevent medical error and needless costs
column5: association health plans for small businesses and their employees
column6: expanded health savings accounts
column7: and medical liability reform that will reduce health care costs and make sure patients have the doctors and care they need.

column1: To keep our economy growing
column2: we also need reliable supplies of affordable
column3: environmentally responsible energy. Nearly 4 years ago
column4: I submitted a comprehensive energy strategy that encourages conservation
column5: alternative sources
column6: a modernized electricity grid
column7: and more production here at home
column8: including safe
column9: clean nuclear energy. My Clear Skies legislation will cut powerplant pollution and improve the health of our citizens. And my budget provides strong funding for leading-edge technology
column10: from hydrogen-fueled cars to clean coal to renewable sources such as ethanol. Four years of debate is enough. I urge Congress to pass legislation that makes America more secure and less dependent on foreign energy.

column1: All these proposals are essential to expand this economy and add new jobs
column2: but they are just the beginning of our duty. To build the prosperity of future generations
column3: we must update institutions that were created to meet the needs of an earlier time. Year after year
column4: Americans are burdened by an archaic
column5: incoherent Federal Tax Code. I've appointed a bipartisan panel to examine the Tax Code from top to bottom. And when their recommendations are delivered
column6: you and I will work together to give this Nation a Tax Code that is progrowth
column7: easy to understand
column8: and fair to all.

column1: America's immigration system is also outdated
column2: unsuited to the needs of our economy and to the values of our country. We should not be content with laws that punish hard-working people who want only to provide for their families and deny businesses willing workers and invite chaos at our border. It is time for an immigration policy that permits temporary-guest workers to fill jobs Americans will not take
column3: that rejects amnesty
column4: that tells us who is entering and leaving our country
column5: and that closes the border to drug dealers and terrorists.

column1: One of America's most important institutions
column2: a symbol of the trust between generations
column3: is also in need of wise and effective reform. Social Security was a great moral success of the 20th century
column4: and we must honor its great purposes in this new century. The system
column5: however
column6: on its current path
column7: is headed toward bankruptcy. And so we must join together to strengthen and save Social Security.

column1: Today
column2: more than 45 million Americans receive Social Security benefits
column3: and millions more are nearing retirement. And for them the system is sound and fiscally strong. I have a message for every American who is 55 or older: Do not let anyone mislead you; for you
column4: the Social Security system will not change in any way.

column1: For younger workers
column2: the Social Security system has serious problems that will grow worse with time. Social Security was created decades ago for a very different era. In those days
column3: people did not live as long. Benefits were much lower than they are today. And a half century ago
column4: about 16 workers paid into the system for each person drawing benefits.

column1: Our society has changed in ways the founders of Social Security could not have foreseen. In today's world
column2: people are living longer and
column3: therefore
column4: drawing benefits longer. And those benefits are scheduled to rise dramatically over the next few decades. And instead of 16 workers paying in for every beneficiary
column5: right now it's only about 3 workers. And over the next few decades
column6: that number will fall to just 2 workers per beneficiary. With each passing year
column7: fewer workers are paying ever-higher benefits to an ever-larger number of retirees.

column1: So here is the result: Thirteen years from now
column3: Social Security will be paying out more than it takes in. And every year afterward will bring a new shortfall
column4: bigger than the year before. For example
column5: in the year 2027
column6: the Government will somehow have to come up with an extra $200 billion to keep the system afloat
column7: and by 2033
column8: the annual shortfall would be more than $300 billion. By the year 2042
column9: the entire system would be exhausted and bankrupt. If steps are not taken to avert that outcome
column10: the only solutions would be dramatically higher taxes
column11: massive new borrowing
column12: or sudden and severe cuts in Social Security benefits or other Government programs.

column1: I recognize that 2018 and 2042 may seem a long way off. But those dates are not so distant
column2: as any parent will tell you. If you have a 5-year-old
column3: you're already concerned about how you'll pay for college tuition 13 years down the road. If you've got children in their twenties
column4: as some of us do
column5: the idea of Social Security collapsing before they retire does not seem like a small matter. And it should not be a small matter to the United States Congress. You and I share a responsibility. We must pass reforms that solve the financial problems of Social Security once and for all.

column1: Fixing Social Security permanently will require an open
column2: candid review of the options. Some have suggested limiting benefits for wealthy retirees. Former Congressman Tim Penny has raised the possibility of indexing benefits to prices rather than wages. During the 1990s
column3: my predecessor
column4: President Clinton
column5: spoke of increasing the retirement age. Former Senator John Breaux suggested discouraging early collection of Social Security benefits. The late Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan recommended changing the way benefits are calculated. All these ideas are on the table.

column1: I know that none of these reforms would be easy. But we have to move ahead with courage and honesty
column2: because our children's retirement security is more important than partisan politics. I will work with Members of Congress to find the most effective combination of reforms. I will listen to anyone who has a good idea to offer. We must
column3: however
column4: be guided by some basic principles. We must make Social Security permanently sound
column5: not leave that task for another day. We must not jeopardize our economic strength by increasing payroll taxes. We must ensure that lower income Americans get the help they need to have dignity and peace of mind in their retirement. We must guarantee there is no change for those now retired or nearing retirement. And we must take care that any changes in the system are gradual
column6: so younger workers have years to prepare and plan for their future.

column1: As we fix Social Security
column2: we also have the responsibility to make the system a better deal for younger workers. And the best way to reach that goal is through voluntary personal retirement accounts. Here is how the idea works. Right now
column3: a set portion of the money you earn is taken out of your paycheck to pay for the Social Security benefits of today's retirees. If you're a younger worker
column4: I believe you should be able to set aside part of that money in your own retirement account
column5: so you can build a nest egg for your own future.

column1: Here's why the personal accounts are a better deal. Your money will grow over time at a greater rate than anything the current system can deliver
column2: and your account will provide money for retirement over and above the check you will receive from Social Security. In addition
column3: you'll be able to pass along the money that accumulates in your personal account
column4: if you wish
column5: to your children andor grandchildren. And best of all
column6: the money in the account is yours
column7: and the Government can never take it away.

column1: The goal here is greater security in retirement
column2: so we will set careful guidelines for personal accounts. We'll make sure the money can only go into a conservative mix of bonds and stock funds. We'll make sure that your earnings are not eaten up by hidden Wall Street fees. We'll make sure there are good options to protect your investments from sudden market swings on the eve of your retirement. We'll make sure a personal account cannot be emptied out all at once but rather paid out over time as an addition to traditional Social Security benefits. And we'll make sure this plan is fiscally responsible by starting personal retirement accounts gradually and raising the yearly limits on contributions over time
column3: eventually permitting all workers to set aside 4 percentage points of their payroll taxes in their accounts.

column1: Personal retirement accounts should be familiar to Federal employees
column2: because you already have something similar called the Thrift Savings Plan
column3: which lets workers deposit a portion of their paychecks into any of five different broadly based investment funds. It's time to extend the same security and choice and ownership to young Americans.

column1: Our second great responsibility to our children and grandchildren is to honor and to pass along the values that sustain a free society. So many of my generation
column2: after a long journey
column3: have come home to family and faith and are determined to bring up responsible
column4: moral children. Government is not the source of these values
column5: but Government should never undermine them.

column1: Because marriage is a sacred institution and the foundation of society
column2: it should not be redefined by activist judges. For the good of families
column3: children
column4: and society
column5: I support a constitutional amendment to protect the institution of marriage.

column1: Because a society is measured by how it treats the weak and vulnerable
column2: we must strive to build a culture of life. Medical research can help us reach that goal by developing treatments and cures that save lives and help people overcome disabilities
column3: and I thank the Congress for doubling the funding of the National Institutes of Health.

column1: To build a culture of life
column2: we must also ensure that scientific advances always serve human dignity
column3: not take advantage of some lives for the benefit of others. We should all be able to agree on some clear standards. I will work with Congress to ensure that human embryos are not created for experimentation or grown for body parts and that human life is never bought or sold as a commodity. America will continue to lead the world in medical research that is ambitious
column4: aggressive
column5: and always ethical.

column1: Because courts must always deliver impartial justice
column2: judges have a duty to faithfully interpret the law
column3: not legislate from the bench. As President
column4: I have a constitutional responsibility to nominate men and women who understand the role of courts in our democracy and are well-qualified to serve on the bench
column5: and I have done so. The Constitution also gives the Senate a responsibility: Every judicial nominee deserves an up-or-down vote.

column1: Because one of the deepest values of our country is compassion
column2: we must never turn away from any citizen who feels isolated from the opportunities of America. Our Government will continue to support faith-based and community groups that bring hope to harsh places. Now we need to focus on giving young people
column3: especially young men in our cities
column4: better options than apathy or gangs or jail. Tonight I propose a 3-year initiative to help organizations keep young people out of gangs and show young men an ideal of manhood that respects women and rejects violence. Taking on gang life will be one part of a broader outreach to at-risk youth
column5: which involves parents and pastors
column6: coaches and community leaders in programs ranging from literacy to sports. And I am proud that the leader of this nationwide effort will be our First Lady
column7: Laura Bush.

column1: Because HIV/AIDS brings suffering and fear into so many lives
column2: I ask you to reauthorize the Ryan White Act to encourage prevention and provide care and treatment to the victims of that disease. And as we update this important law
column3: we must focus our efforts on fellow citizens with the highest rates of new cases
column4: African American men and women.

column1: Because one of the main sources of our national unity is our belief in equal justice
column2: we need to make sure Americans of all races and backgrounds have confidence in the system that provides justice. In America
column3: we must make doubly sure no person is held to account for a crime he or she did not commit
column4: so we are dramatically expanding the use of DNA evidence to prevent wrongful conviction. Soon I will send to Congress a proposal to fund special training for defense counsel in capital cases
column5: because people on trial for their lives must have competent lawyers by their side.

column1: Our third responsibility to future generations is to leave them an America that is safe from danger and protected by peace.We will pass along to our children all the freedoms we enjoy
column2: and chief among them is freedom from fear.

column1: In the 3 1/2 years since September the 11th
column3: we have taken unprecedented actions to protect Americans. We've created a new department of Government to defend our homeland
column4: focused the FBI on preventing terrorism
column5: begun to reform our intelligence agencies
column6: broken up terror cells across the country
column7: expanded research on defenses against biological and chemical attack
column8: improved border security
column9: and trained more than a half million first-responders. Police and firefighters
column10: air marshals
column11: researchers
column12: and so many others are working every day to make our homeland safer
column13: and we thank them all.

column1: Our Nation
column2: working with allies and friends
column3: has also confronted the enemy abroad with measures that are determined
column4: successful
column5: and continuing. The Al Qaida terror network that attacked our country still has leaders
column6: but many of its top commanders have been removed. There are still governments that sponsor and harbor terrorists
column7: but their number has declined. There are still regimes seeking weapons of mass destruction but no longer without attention and without consequence. Our country is still the target of terrorists who want to kill many and intimidate us all
column8: and we will stay on the offensive against them until the fight is won.

column1: Pursuing our enemies is a vital commitment of the war on terror
column2: and I thank the Congress for providing our service men and women with the resources they have needed. During this time of war
column3: we must continue to support our military and give them the tools for victory.

column1: Other nations around the globe have stood with us. In Afghanistan
column2: an international force is helping provide security. In Iraq
column3: 28 countries have troops on the ground
column4: the United Nations and the European Union provided technical assistance for the elections
column5: and NATO is leading a mission to help train Iraqi officers. We're cooperating with 60 governments in the Proliferation Security Initiative to detect and stop the transit of dangerous materials. We're working closely with the governments in Asia to convince North Korea to abandon its nuclear ambitions. Pakistan
column6: Saudi Arabia
column7: and nine other countries have captured or detained Al Qaida terrorists. In the next 4 years
column8: my administration will continue to build the coalitions that will defeat the dangers of our time.

column1: In the long term
column2: the peace we seek will only be achieved by eliminating the conditions that feed radicalism and ideologies of murder. If whole regions of the world remain in despair and grow in hatred
column3: they will be the recruiting grounds for terror
column4: and that terror will stalk America and other free nations for decades. The only force powerful enough to stop the rise of tyranny and terror and replace hatred with hope is the force of human freedom. Our enemies know this
column5: and that is why the terrorist Zarqawi recently declared war on what he called the "evil principle" of democracy. And we've declared our own intention: America will stand with the allies of freedom to support democratic movements in the Middle East and beyond
column6: with the ultimate goal of ending tyranny in our world.

column1: The United States has no right
column2: no desire
column3: and no intention to impose our form of government on anyone else. That is one of the main differences between us and our enemies. They seek to impose and expand an empire of oppression in which a tiny group of brutal
column4: self-appointed rulers control every aspect of every life. Our aim is to build and preserve a community of free and independent nations
column5: with governments that answer to their citizens and reflect their own cultures. And because democracies respect their own people and their neighbors
column6: the advance of freedom will lead to peace.

column1: That advance has great momentum in our time
column2: shown by women voting in Afghanistan and Palestinians choosing a new direction and the people of Ukraine asserting their democratic rights and electing a President. We are witnessing landmark events in the history of liberty
column3: and in the coming years
column4: we will add to that story.

column1: The beginnings of reform and democracy in the Palestinian Territories are now showing the power of freedom to break old patterns of violence and failure. Tomorrow morning Secretary of State Rice departs on a trip that will take her to Israel and the West Bank for meetings with Prime Minister Sharon and President Abbas. She will discuss with them how we and our friends can help the Palestinian people end terror and build the institutions of a peaceful
column2: independent
column3: democratic state. To promote this democracy
column4: I will ask Congress for $350 million to support Palestinian political
column5: economic
column6: and security reforms. The goal of two democratic states
column7: Israel and Palestine
column8: living side by side in peace is within reach
column9: and America will help them achieve that goal.

column1: To promote peace and stability in the broader Middle East
column2: the United States will work with our friends in the region to fight the common threat of terror
column3: while we encourage a higher standard of freedom. Hopeful reform is already taking hold in an arc from Morocco to Jordan to Bahrain. The Government of Saudi Arabia can demonstrate its leadership in the region by expanding the role of its people in determining their future. And the great and proud nation of Egypt
column4: which showed the way toward peace in the Middle East
column5: can now show the way toward democracy in the Middle East.

column1: To promote peace in the broader Middle East
column2: we must confront regimes that continue to harbor terrorists and pursue weapons of mass murder. Syria still allows its territory and parts of Lebanon to be used by terrorists who seek to destroy every chance of peace in the region. You have passed and we are applying the Syrian Accountability Act
column3: and we expect the Syrian Government to end all support for terror and open the door to freedom. Today
column4: Iran remains the world's primary state sponsor of terror
column5: pursuing nuclear weapons while depriving its people of the freedom they seek and deserve. We are working with European allies to make clear to the Iranian regime that it must give up its uranium enrichment program and any plutonium reprocessing and end its support for terror. And to the Iranian people
column6: I say tonight: As you stand for your own liberty
column7: America stands with you.

column1: Our generational commitment to the advance of freedom
column2: especially in the Middle East
column3: is now being tested and honored in Iraq. That country is a vital front in the war on terror
column4: which is why the terrorists have chosen to make a stand there. Our men and women in uniform are fighting terrorists in Iraq so we do not have to face them here at home. And the victory of freedom in Iraq will strengthen a new ally in the war on terror
column5: inspire democratic reformers from Damascus to Tehran
column6: bring more hope and progress to a troubled region
column7: and thereby lift a terrible threat from the lives of our children and grandchildren.

column1: We will succeed because the Iraqi people value their own liberty
column2: as they showed the world last Sunday. Across Iraq
column3: often at great risk
column4: millions of citizens went to the polls and elected 275 men and women to represent them in a new Transitional National Assembly. A young woman in Baghdad told of waking to the sound of mortar fire on election day and wondering if it might be too dangerous to vote. She said
column5: "Hearing those explosions
column6: it occurred to me: The insurgents are weak; they are afraid of democracy; they are losing. So I got my husband and I got my parents
column7: and we all came out and voted together."

column1: Americans recognize that spirit of liberty
column2: because we share it. In any nation
column3: casting your vote is an act of civic responsibility. For millions of Iraqis
column4: it was also an act of personal courage
column5: and they have earned the respect of us all.

column1: One of Iraq's leading democracy and human rights advocates is Safia Taleb al-Suhail. She says of her country
column2: "We were occupied for 35 years by Saddam Hussein. That was the real occupation. Thank you to the American people who paid the cost but
column3: most of all
column4: to the soldiers." Eleven years ago
column5: Safia's father was assassinated by Saddam's intelligence service. Three days ago in Baghdad
column6: Safia was finally able to vote for the leaders of her country
column7: and we are honored that she is with us tonight.

column1: The terrorists and insurgents are violently opposed to democracy and will continue to attack it. Yet the terrorists' most powerful myth is being destroyed. The whole world is seeing that the car bombers and assassins are not only fighting coalition forces; they are trying to destroy the hopes of Iraqis
column2: expressed in free elections. And the whole world now knows that a small group of extremists will not overturn the will of the Iraqi people.

column1: We will succeed in Iraq because Iraqis are determined to fight for their own freedom and to write their own history. As Prime Minister Allawi said in his speech to Congress last September
column2: "Ordinary Iraqis are anxious to shoulder all the security burdens of our country as quickly as possible." That is the natural desire of an independent nation
column3: and it is also the stated mission of our coalition in Iraq. The new political situation in Iraq opens a new phase of our work in that country.

column1: At the recommendation of our commanders on the ground and in consultation with the Iraqi Government
column2: we will increasingly focus our efforts on helping prepare more capable Iraqi security forces
column3: forces with skilled officers and an effective command structure. As those forces become more self-reliant and take on greater security responsibilities
column4: America and its coalition partners will increasingly be in a supporting role. In the end
column5: Iraqis must be able to defend their own country
column6: and we will help that proud new nation secure its liberty.

column1: Recently an Iraqi interpreter said to a reporter
column2: "Tell America not to abandon us." He and all Iraqis can be certain: While our military strategy is adapting to circumstances
column3: our commitment remains firm and unchanging. We are standing for the freedom of our Iraqi friends
column4: and freedom in Iraq will make America safer for generations to come. We will not set an artificial timetable for leaving Iraq
column5: because that would embolden the terrorists and make them believe they can wait us out. We are in Iraq to achieve a result
column6: a country that is democratic
column7: representative of all its people
column8: at peace with its neighbors
column9: and able to defend itself. And when that result is achieved
column10: our men and women serving in Iraq will return home with the honor they have earned.

column1: Right now
column2: Americans in uniform are serving at posts across the world
column3: often taking great risks on my orders. We have given them training and equipment
column4: and they have given us an example of idealism and character that makes every American proud. The volunteers of our military are unrelenting in battle
column5: unwavering in loyalty
column6: unmatched in honor and decency
column7: and every day they're making our Nation more secure. Some of our service men and women have survived terrible injuries
column8: and this grateful country will do everything we can to help them recover. And we have said farewell to some very good men and women who died for our freedom and whose memory this Nation will honor forever.

column1: One name we honor is Marine Corps Sergeant Byron Norwood of Pflugerville
column2: Texas
column3: who was killed during the assault on Fallujah. His mom
column4: Janet
column5: sent me a letter and told me how much Byron loved being a marine and how proud he was to be on the frontline against terror. She wrote
column6: "When Byron was home the last time
column7: I said that I wanted to protect him like I had since he was born. He just hugged me and said
column8: 'You've done your job
column9: Mom. Now it is my turn to protect you."' Ladies and gentlemen
column10: with grateful hearts we honor freedom's defenders and our military families
column11: represented here this evening by Sergeant Norwood's mom and dad
column12: Janet and Bill Norwood.

column1: [At this point
column2: in the First Lady's box
column3: guest Safia Taleb al-Suhail embraced guest Janet Norwood.]

column1: In these 4 years
column2: Americans have seen the unfolding of large events. We have known times of sorrow and hours of uncertainty and days of victory. In all this history
column3: even when we have disagreed
column4: we have seen threads of purpose that unite us. The attack on freedom in our world has reaffirmed our confidence in freedom's power to change the world. We are all part of a great venture: To extend the promise of freedom in our country
column5: to renew the values that sustain our liberty
column6: and to spread the peace that freedom brings.

column1: As Franklin Roosevelt once reminded Americans
column2: "Each age is a dream that is dying
column3: or one that is coming to birth." And we live in the country where the biggest dreams are born. The abolition of slavery was only a dream until it was fulfilled. The liberation of Europe from fascism was only a dream until it was achieved. The fall of imperial communism was only a dream until
column4: one day
column5: it was accomplished. Our generation has dreams of its own
column6: and we also go forward with confidence. The road of providence is uneven and unpredictable
column7: yet we know where it leads: It leads to freedom.

column1: Thank you
column2: and may God bless America.@

column1: George W. Bush|Address Before a Joint Session of the Congress on the State of the Union|2006-01-31|@Thank you all. Mr. Speaker
column2: Vice President Cheney
column3: Members of Congress
column4: members of the Supreme Court and diplomatic corps
column5: distinguished guests
column6: and fellow citizens: Today our Nation lost a beloved
column7: graceful
column8: courageous woman who called America to its founding ideals and carried on a noble dream. Tonight we are comforted by the hope of a glad reunion with the husband who was taken so long ago
column9: and we are grateful for the good life of Coretta Scott King.

column1: Every time I'm invited to this rostrum
column2: I'm humbled by the privilege and mindful of the history we've seen together. We have gathered under this Capitol dome in moments of national mourning and national achievement. We have served America through one of the most consequential periods of our history
column3: and it has been my honor to serve with you.

column1: In a system of two parties
column2: two chambers
column3: and two elected branches
column4: there will always be differences and debate. But even tough debates can be conducted in a civil tone
column5: and our differences cannot be allowed to harden into anger. To confront the great issues before us
column6: we must act in a spirit of good will and respect for one another
column7: and I will do my part. Tonight the state of our Union is strong
column8: and together we will make it stronger.

column1: In this decisive year
column2: you and I will make choices that determine both the future and the character of our country. We will choose to act confidently in pursuing the enemies of freedom
column3: or retreat from our duties in the hope of an easier life. We will choose to build our prosperity by leading the world economy
column4: or shut ourselves off from trade and opportunity. In a complex and challenging time
column5: the road of isolationism and protectionism may seem broad and inviting
column6: yet it ends in danger and decline. The only way to protect our people
column7: the only way to secure the peace
column8: the only way to control our destiny is by our leadership. So the United States of America will continue to lead.

column1: Abroad
column2: our Nation is committed to an historic
column3: long-term goal: We seek the end of tyranny in our world. Some dismiss that goal as misguided idealism. In reality
column4: the future security of America depends on it. On September the 11th
column6: we found that problems originating in a failed and oppressive state 7
column7: 000 miles away could bring murder and destruction to our country. Dictatorships shelter terrorists
column8: and feed resentment and radicalism
column9: and seek weapons of mass destruction. Democracies replace resentment with hope
column10: respect the rights of their citizens and their neighbors
column11: and join the fight against terror. Every step toward freedom in the world makes our country safer
column12: so we will act boldly in freedom's cause.

column1: Far from being a hopeless dream
column2: the advance of freedom is the great story of our time. In 1945
column3: there were about two dozen lonely democracies in the world. Today
column4: there are 122. And we're writing a new chapter in the story of self-governmentwith women lining up to vote in Afghanistan
column5: and millions of Iraqis marking their liberty with purple ink
column6: and men and women from Lebanon to Egypt debating the rights of individuals and the necessity of freedom. At the start of 2006
column7: more than half the people of our world live in democratic nations. And we do not forget the other halfin places like Syria and Burma
column8: Zimbabwe
column9: North Korea
column10: and Iranbecause the demands of justice and the peace of this world require their freedom as well.

column1: No one can deny the success of freedom
column2: but some men rage and fight against it. And one of the main sources of reaction and opposition is radical Islamthe perversion by a few of a noble faith into an ideology of terror and death. Terrorists like bin Laden are serious about mass murder
column3: and all of us must take their declared intentions seriously. They seek to impose a heartless system of totalitarian control throughout the Middle East and arm themselves with weapons of mass murder.

column1: Their aim is to seize power in Iraq and use it as a safe haven to launch attacks against America and the world. Lacking the military strength to challenge us directly
column2: the terrorists have chosen the weapon of fear. When they murder children at a school in Beslan or blow up commuters in London or behead a bound captive
column3: the terrorists hope these horrors will break our will
column4: allowing the violent to inherit the Earth. But they have miscalculated: We love our freedom
column5: and we will fight to keep it.

column1: In a time of testing
column2: we cannot find security by abandoning our commitments and retreating within our borders. If we were to leave these vicious attackers alone
column3: they would not leave us alone. They would simply move the battlefield to our own shores. There is no peace in retreat
column4: and there is no honor in retreat. By allowing radical Islam to work its will
column5: by leaving an assaulted world to fend for itself
column6: we would signal to all that we no longer believe in our own ideals or even in our own courage. But our enemies and our friends can be certain: The United States will not retreat from the world
column7: and we will never surrender to evil.

column1: America rejects the false comfort of isolationism. We are the nation that saved liberty in Europe and liberated death camps and helped raise up democracies and faced down an evil empire. Once again
column2: we accept the call of history to deliver the oppressed and move this world toward peace. We remain on the offensive against terror networks. We have killed or captured many of their leaders. And for the others
column3: their day will come.

column1: We remain on the offensive in Afghanistan
column2: where a fine President and a National Assembly are fighting terror while building the institutions of a new democracy. We're on the offensive in Iraq with a clear plan for victory.

column1: First
column2: we're helping Iraqis build an inclusive government
column3: so that old resentments will be eased and the insurgency will be marginalized. Second
column4: we're continuing reconstruction efforts and helping the Iraqi Government to fight corruption and build a modern economy
column5: so all Iraqis can experience the benefits of freedom. And third
column6: we're striking terrorist targets while we train Iraqi forces that are increasingly capable of defeating the enemy. Iraqis are showing their courage every day
column7: and we are proud to be their allies in the cause of freedom.

column1: Our work in Iraq is difficult because our enemy is brutal. But that brutality has not stopped the dramatic progress of a new democracy. In less than 3 years
column2: the nation has gone from dictatorship to liberation
column3: to sovereignty
column4: to a Constitution
column5: to national elections. At the same time
column6: our coalition has been relentless in shutting off terrorist infiltration
column7: clearing out insurgent strongholds
column8: and turning over territory to Iraqi security forces. I am confident in our plan for victory; I am confident in the will of the Iraqi people; I am confident in the skill and spirit of our military. Fellow citizens
column9: we are in this fight to win
column10: and we are winning.

column1: The road of victory is the road that will take our troops home. As we make progress on the ground and Iraqi forces increasingly take the lead
column2: we should be able to further decrease our troop levels. But those decisions will be made by our military commanders
column3: not by politicians in Washington
column4: DC.

column1: Our coalition has learned from our experience in Iraq. We've adjusted our military tactics and changed our approach to reconstruction. Along the way
column2: we have benefited from responsible criticism and counsel offered by Members of Congress of both parties. In the coming year
column3: I will continue to reach out and seek your good advice. Yet there is a difference between responsible criticism that aims for success and defeatism that refuses to acknowledge anything but failure. Hindsight alone is not wisdom
column4: and second-guessing is not a strategy.

column1: With so much in the balance
column2: those of us in public office have a duty to speak with candor. A sudden withdrawal of our forces from Iraq would abandon our Iraqi allies to death and prison
column3: would put men like bin Laden and Zarqawi in charge of a strategic country
column4: and show that a pledge from America means little. Members of Congress
column5: however we feel about the decisions and debates of the past
column6: our Nation has only one option: We must keep our word
column7: defeat our enemies
column8: and stand behind the American military in this vital mission.

column1: Our men and women in uniform are making sacrifices and showing a sense of duty stronger than all fear. They know what it's like to fight house to house in a maze of streets
column2: to wear heavy gear in the desert heat
column3: to see a comrade killed by a roadside bomb. And those who know the costs also know the stakes. Marine Staff Sergeant Dan Clay was killed last month fighting in Fallujah. He left behind a letter to his family
column4: but his words could just as well be addressed to every American. Here is what Dan wrote: "I know what honor is it has been an honor to protect and serve all of you. I faced death with the secure knowledge that you would not have to. Never falter. Don't hesitate to honor and support those of us who have the honor of protecting that which is worth protecting."

column1: Staff Sergeant Dan Clay's wife
column2: Lisa
column3: and his mom and dad
column4: Sara Jo and Bud
column5: are with us this evening. Welcome.

column1: Our Nation is grateful to the fallen
column2: who live in the memory of our country. We're grateful to all who volunteer to wear our Nation's uniform. And as we honor our brave troops
column3: let us never forget the sacrifices of America's military families.

column1: Our offensive against terror involves more than military action. Ultimately
column2: the only way to defeat the terrorists is to defeat their dark vision of hatred and fear by offering the hopeful alternative of political freedom and peaceful change. So the United States of America supports democratic reform across the broader Middle East. Elections are vital
column3: but they are only the beginning. Raising up a democracy requires the rule of law and protection of minorities and strong
column4: accountable institutions that last longer than a single vote.

column1: The great people of Egypt have voted in a multiparty Presidential election
column2: and now their Government should open paths of peaceful opposition that will reduce the appeal of radicalism. The Palestinian people have voted in elections
column3: and now the leaders of Hamas must recognize Israel
column4: disarm
column5: reject terrorism
column6: and work for lasting peace. Saudi Arabia has taken the first steps of reform; now it can offer its people a better future by pressing forward with those efforts. Democracies in the Middle East will not look like our own
column7: because they will reflect the traditions of their own citizens. Yet liberty is the future of every nation in the Middle East because liberty is the right and hope of all humanity.

column1: The same is true of Iran
column2: a nation now held hostage by a small clerical elite that is isolating and repressing its people. The regime in that country sponsors terrorists in the Palestinian territories and in Lebanon
column3: and that must come to an end. The Iranian Government is defying the world with its nuclear ambitions
column4: and the nations of the world must not permit the Iranian regime to gain nuclear weapons. America will continue to rally the world to confront these threats.

column1: Tonight let me speak directly to the citizens of Iran: America respects you
column2: and we respect your country. We respect your right to choose your own future and win your own freedom. And our Nation hopes one day to be the closest of friends with a free and democratic Iran.

column1: To overcome dangers in our world
column2: we must also take the offensive by encouraging economic progress and fighting disease and spreading hope in hopeless lands. Isolationism would not only tie our hands in fighting enemies
column3: it would keep us from helping our friends in desperate need. We show compassion abroad because Americans believe in the God-given dignity and worth of a villager with HIV/AIDS or an infant with malaria or a refugee fleeing genocide or a young girl sold into slavery. We also show compassion abroad because regions overwhelmed by poverty
column4: corruption
column5: and despair are sources of terrorism and organized crime and human trafficking and the drug trade.

column1: In recent years
column2: you and I have taken unprecedented action to fight AIDS and malaria
column3: expand the education of girls
column4: and reward developing nations that are moving forward with economic and political reform. For people everywhere
column5: the United States is a partner for a better life. Shortchanging these efforts would increase the suffering and chaos of our world
column6: undercut our long-term security
column7: and dull the conscience of our country. I urge Members of Congress to serve the interests of America by showing the compassion of America.

column1: Our country must also remain on the offensive against terrorism here at home. The enemy has not lost the desire or capability to attack us. Fortunately
column2: this Nation has superb professionals in law enforcement
column3: intelligence
column4: the military
column5: and homeland security. These men and women are dedicating their lives
column6: protecting us all
column7: and they deserve our support and our thanks. They also deserve the same tools they already use to fight drug trafficking and organized crime
column8: so I ask you to reauthorize the PATRIOT Act.

column1: It is said that prior to the attacks of September the 11th
column2: our Government failed to connect the dots of the conspiracy. We now know that two of the hijackers in the United States placed telephone calls to Al Qaida operatives overseas. But we did not know about their plans until it was too late. So to prevent another attackbased on authority given to me by the Constitution and by statuteI have authorized a terrorist surveillance program to aggressively pursue the international communications of suspected Al Qaida operatives and affiliates to and from America.

column1: Previous Presidents have used the same constitutional authority I have
column2: and Federal courts have approved the use of that authority. Appropriate Members of Congress have been kept informed. The terrorist surveillance program has helped prevent terrorist attacks. It remains essential to the security of America. If there are people inside our country who are talking with Al Qaida
column3: we want to know about it
column4: because we will not sit back and wait to be hit again.

column1: In all these areasfrom the disruption of terror networks
column2: to victory in Iraq
column3: to the spread of freedom and hope in troubled regionswe need the support of our friends and allies. To draw that support
column4: we must always be clear in our principles and willing to act. The only alternative to American leadership is a dramatically more dangerous and anxious world. Yet we also choose to lead because it is a privilege to serve the values that gave us birth. American leadersfrom Roosevelt to Truman to Kennedy to Reaganrejected isolation and retreat
column5: because they knew that America is always more secure when freedom is on the march.

column1: Our own generation is in a long war against a determined enemy
column2: a war that will be fought by Presidents of both parties who will need steady bipartisan support from the Congress. And tonight I ask for yours. Together
column3: let us protect our country
column4: support the men and women who defend us
column5: and lead this world toward freedom.

column1: Here at home
column2: America also has a great opportunity: We will build the prosperity of our country by strengthening our economic leadership in the world.

column1: Our economy is healthy and vigorous and growing faster than other major industrialized nations. In the last 2 1/2 years
column2: America has created 4.6 million new jobs
column3: more than Japan and the European Union combined. Even in the face of higher energy prices and natural disasters
column4: the American people have turned in an economic performance that is the envy of the world.

column1: The American economy is preeminent
column2: but we cannot afford to be complacent. In a dynamic world economy
column3: we are seeing new competitors like China and India
column4: and this creates uncertainty
column5: which makes it easier to feed people's fears. So we're seeing some old temptations return. Protectionists want to escape competition
column6: pretending that we can keep our high standard of living while walling off our economy. Others say that the government needs to take a larger role in directing the economy
column7: centralizing more power in Washington and increasing taxes. We hear claims that immigrants are somehow bad for the economy
column8: even though this economy could not function without them. All these are forms of economic retreat
column9: and they lead in the same direction
column10: toward a stagnant and second-rate economy.

column1: Tonight I will set out a better path: an agenda for a nation that competes with confidence; an agenda that will raise standards of living and generate new jobs. Americans should not fear our economic future because we intend to shape it.
Keeping America competitive begins with keeping our economy growing. And our economy grows when Americans have more of their own money to spend
column2: save
column3: and invest. In the last 5 years
column4: the tax relief you passed has left $880 billion in the hands of American workers
column5: investors
column6: small businesses
column7: and families. And they have used it to help produce more than 4 years of uninterrupted economic growth. Yet the tax relief is set to expire in the next few years. If we do nothing
column8: American families will face a massive tax increase they do not expect and will not welcome. Because America needs more than a temporary expansion
column9: we need more than temporary tax relief
column10: I urge the Congress to act responsibly and make the tax cuts permanent.

column1: Keeping America competitive requires us to be good stewards of tax dollars. Every year of my Presidency
column2: we've reduced the growth of nonsecurity discretionary spending
column3: and last year
column4: you passed bills that cut this spending. This year
column5: my budget will cut it again and reduce or eliminate more than 140 programs that are performing poorly or not fulfilling essential priorities. By passing these reforms
column6: we will save the American taxpayer another $14 billion next year and stay on track to cut the deficit in half by 2009.

column1: I am pleased that Members of Congress are working on earmark reform
column2: because the Federal budget has too many special interest projects. And we can tackle this problem together
column3: if you pass the line-item veto.

column1: We must also confront the larger challenge of mandatory spending
column2: or entitlements. This year
column3: the first of about 78 million baby boomers turn 60
column4: including two of my dad's favorite peopleme and President Clinton.  This milestone is more than a personal crisis ... it is a national challenge. The retirement of the baby boom generation will put unprecedented strains on the Federal Government. By 2030
column5: spending for Social Security
column6: Medicare
column7: and Medicaid alone will be almost 60 percent of the entire Federal budget. And that will present future Congresses with impossible choices: staggering tax increases
column8: immense deficits
column9: or deep cuts in every category of spending. Congress did not act last year on my proposal to save Social Security
column10: yet the rising cost of entitlements is a problem that is not going away. And every year we fail to act
column11: the situation gets worse.

column1: So tonight I ask you to join me in creating a commission to examine the full impact of baby boom retirements on Social Security
column2: Medicare
column3: and Medicaid. This commission should include Members of Congress of both parties and offer bipartisan solutions. We need to put aside partisan politics and work together and get this problem solved.

column1: Keeping America competitive requires us to open more markets for all that Americans make and grow. One out of every five factory jobs in America is related to global trade
column2: and we want people everywhere to buy American. With open markets and a level playing field
column3: no one can outproduce or outcompete the American worker.

column1: Keeping America competitive requires an immigration system that upholds our laws
column2: reflects our values
column3: and serves the interests of our economy. Our Nation needs orderly and secure borders. To meet this goal
column4: we must have stronger immigration enforcement and border protection. And we must have a rational
column5: humane guest-worker program that rejects amnesty
column6: allows temporary jobs for people who seek them legally
