column7: and reduces smuggling and crime at the border.

column1: Keeping America competitive requires affordable health care. Our Government has a responsibility to provide health care for the poor and the elderly
column2: and we are meeting that responsibility. For all Americans
column3: we must confront the rising cost of care
column4: strengthen the doctor-patient relationship
column5: and help people afford the insurance coverage they need.

column1: We will make wider use of electronic records and other health information technology to help control costs and reduce dangerous medical errors. We will strengthen health savings accounts
column2: making sure individuals and small-business employees can buy insurance with the same advantages that people working for big businesses now get. We will do more to make this coverage portable
column3: so workers can switch jobs without having to worry about losing their health insurance. And because lawsuits are driving many good doctors out of practice
column4: leaving women in nearly 1
column5: 500 American counties without a single ob-gyn
column6: I ask the Congress to pass medical liability reform this year.

column1: Keeping America competitive requires affordable energy. And here we have a serious problem: America is addicted to oil
column2: which is often imported from unstable parts of the world. The best way to break this addiction is through technology. Since 2001
column3: we have spent nearly $10 billion to develop cleaner
column4: cheaper
column5: and more reliable alternative energy sources. And we are on the threshold of incredible advances.

column1: So tonight I announce the Advanced Energy Initiativea 22-percent increase in clean-energy research at the Department of Energyto push for breakthroughs in two vital areas. To change how we power our homes and offices
column2: we will invest more in zero-emission coal-fired plants
column3: revolutionary solar and wind technologies
column4: and clean
column5: safe nuclear energy.

column1: We must also change how we power our automobiles. We will increase our research in better batteries for hybrid and electric cars and in pollution-free cars that run on hydrogen. We'll also fund additional research in cutting-edge methods of producing ethanol
column2: not just from corn but from wood chips and stalks or switchgrass. Our goal is to make this new kind of ethanol practical and competitive within 6 years.

column1: Breakthroughs on this and other new technologies will help us reach another great goal: to replace more than 75 percent of our oil imports from the Middle East by 2025. By applying the talent and technology of America
column2: this country can dramatically improve our environment
column3: move beyond a petroleum-based economy
column4: and make our dependence on Middle Eastern oil a thing of the past.

column1: And to keep America competitive
column2: one commitment is necessary above all: We must continue to lead the world in human talent and creativity. Our greatest advantage in the world has always been our educated
column3: hard-working
column4: ambitious people. And we're going to keep that edge. Tonight I announce an American Competitiveness Initiative to encourage innovation throughout our economy and to give our Nation's children a firm grounding in math and science.

column1: First
column2: I propose to double the Federal commitment to the most critical basic research programs in the physical sciences over the next 10 years. This funding will support the work of America's most creative minds as they explore promising areas such as nanotechnology
column3: supercomputing
column4: and alternative energy sources.

column1: Second
column2: I propose to make permanent the research and development tax credit to encourage bolder private sector initiative in technology. With more research in both the public and private sectors
column3: we will improve our quality of life and ensure that America will lead the world in opportunity and innovation for decades to come.

column1: Third
column2: we need to encourage children to take more math and science
column3: and to make sure those courses are rigorous enough to compete with other nations. We've made a good start in the early grades with the No Child Left Behind Act
column4: which is raising standards and lifting test scores across our country. Tonight I propose to train 70
column5: 000 high school teachers to lead Advanced Placement courses in math and science
column6: bring 30
column7: 000 math and science professionals to teach in classrooms
column8: and give early help to students who struggle with math
column9: so they have a better chance at good
column10: high-wage jobs. If we ensure that America's children succeed in life
column11: they will ensure that America succeeds in the world.

column1: Preparing our Nation to compete in the world is a goal that all of us can share. I urge you to support the American Competitiveness Initiative
column2: and together we will show the world what the American people can achieve.

column1: America is a great force for freedom and prosperity. Yet our greatness is not measured in power or luxuries but by who we are and how we treat one another. So we strive to be a compassionate
column2: decent
column3: hopeful society.

column1: In recent years
column2: America has become a more hopeful nation. Violent crime rates have fallen to their lowest levels since the 1970s. Welfare cases have dropped by more than half over the past decade. Drug use among youth is down 19 percent since 2001. There are fewer abortions in America than at any point in the last three decades
column3: and the number of children born to teenage mothers has been falling for a dozen years in a row.

column1: These gains are evidence of a quiet transformation
column2: a revolution of conscience
column3: in which a rising generation is finding that a life of personal responsibility is a life of fulfillment. Government has played a role. Wise policies
column4: such as welfare reform and drug education and support for abstinence and adoption have made a difference in the character of our country. And everyone here tonight
column5: Democrat and Republican
column6: has a right to be proud of this record.

column1: Yet many Americans
column2: especially parents
column3: still have deep concerns about the direction of our culture and the health of our most basic institutions. They're concerned about unethical conduct by public officials and discouraged by activist courts that try to redefine marriage. They worry about children in our society who need direction and love
column4: and about fellow citizens still displaced by natural disaster
column5: and about suffering caused by treatable diseases.

column1: As we look at these challenges
column2: we must never give in to the belief that America is in decline or that our culture is doomed to unravel. The American people know better than that. We have proven the pessimists wrong before
column3: and we will do it again.

column1: A hopeful society depends on courts that deliver equal justice under the law. The Supreme Court now has two superb new members on its bench
column2: Chief Justice John Roberts and Justice Sam Alito. I thank the Senate for confirming both of them. I will continue to nominate men and women who understand that judges must be servants of the law and not legislate from the bench.

column1: Today marks the official retirement of a very special American. For 24 years of faithful service to our Nation
column2: the United States is grateful to Justice Sandra Day O'Connor.

column1: A hopeful society has institutions of science and medicine that do not cut ethical corners and that recognize the matchless value of every life. Tonight I ask you to pass legislation to prohibit the most egregious abuses of medical research: human cloning in all its forms; creating or implanting embryos for experiments; creating human-animal hybrids; and buying
column2: selling
column3: or patenting human embryos. Human life is a gift from our Creator
column4: and that gift should never be discarded
column5: devalued
column6: or put up for sale.

column1: A hopeful society expects elected officials to uphold the public trust. Honorable people in both parties are working on reforms to strengthen the ethical standards of Washington. I support your efforts. Each of us has made a pledge to be worthy of public responsibility
column2: and that is a pledge we must never forget
column3: never dismiss
column4: and never betray.

column1: As we renew the promise of our institutions
column2: let us also show the character of America in our compassion and care for one another.

column1: A hopeful society gives special attention to children who lack direction and love. Through the Helping America's Youth Initiative
column2: we are encouraging caring adults to get involved in the life of a child. And this good work is being led by our First Lady
column3: Laura Bush. This year
column4: we will add resources to encourage young people to stay in school
column5: so more of America's youth can raise their sights and achieve their dreams.

column1: A hopeful society comes to the aid of fellow citizens in times of suffering and emergency and stays at it until they're back on their feet. So far the Federal Government has committed $85 billion to the people of the gulf coast and New Orleans. We're removing debris and repairing highways and rebuilding stronger levees. We're providing business loans and housing assistance. Yet as we meet these immediate needs
column2: we must also address deeper challenges that existed before the storm arrived.

column1: In New Orleans and in other places
column2: many of our fellow citizens have felt excluded from the promise of our country. The answer is not only temporary relief but schools that teach every child and job skills that bring upward mobility and more opportunities to own a home and start a business. As we recover from a disaster
column3: let us also work for the day when all Americans are protected by justice
column4: equal in hope
column5: and rich in opportunity.

column1: A hopeful society acts boldly to fight diseases like HIV/AIDS
column2: which can be prevented and treated and defeated. More than a million Americans live with HIV
column3: and half of all AIDS cases occur among African Americans. I ask Congress to reform and reauthorize the Ryan White Act and provide new funding to States
column4: so we end the waiting lists for AIDS medicines in America. We will also lead a nationwide effort
column5: working closely with African American churches and faith-based groups
column6: to deliver rapid HIV tests to millions
column7: end the stigma of AIDS
column8: and come closer to the day when there are no new infections in America.

column1: Fellow citizens
column2: we've been called to leadership in a period of consequence. We've entered a great ideological conflict we did nothing to invite. We see great changes in science and commerce that will influence all our lives. Sometimes it can seem that history is turning in a wide arc toward an unknown shore. Yet the destination of history is determined by human action
column3: and every great movement of history comes to a point of choosing.

column1: Lincoln could have accepted peace at the cost of disunity and continued slavery. Martin Luther King could have stopped at Birmingham or at Selma and achieved only half a victory over segregation. The United States could have accepted the permanent division of Europe and been complicit in the oppression of others. Today
column2: having come far in our own historical journey
column3: we must decide: Will we turn back or finish well?

column1: Before history is written down in books
column2: it is written in courage. Like Americans before us
column3: we will show that courage
column4: and we will finish well. We will lead freedom's advance. We will compete and excel in the global economy. We will renew the defining moral commitments of this land. And so we move forward
column5: optimistic about our country
column6: faithful to its cause
column7: and confident of the victories to come.

column1: May God bless America.@

George W. Bush|Address Before a Joint Session of the Congress on the State of the Union|2007-01-23|@Thank you very much. And tonight I have the high privilege and distinct honor of my own as the first President to begin the State of the Union message with these words: Madam Speaker.
In his day
column2: the late Congressman Thomas D'Alesandro
column3: Jr.
column4: from Baltimore
column5: Maryland
column6: saw Presidents Roosevelt and Truman at this rostrum. But nothing could compare with the sight of his only daughter
column7: Nancy
column8: presiding tonight as Speaker of the House of Representatives. Congratulations
column9: Madam Speaker.

column1: Two Members of the House and Senate are not with us tonight
column2: and we pray for the recovery and speedy return of Senator Tim Johnson and Congressman Charlie Norwood.

column1: Madam Speaker
column2: Vice President Cheney
column3: Members of Congress
column4: distinguished guests
column5: and fellow citizens: The rite of custom brings us together at a defining hour when decisions are hard and courage is needed. We enter the year 2007 with large endeavors underway and others that are ours to begin. In all of this
column6: much is asked of us. We must have the will to face difficult challenges and determined enemies and the wisdom to face them together.

column1: Some in this Chamber are new to the House and the Senate
column2: and I congratulate the Democrat majority. Congress has changed
column3: but not our responsibilities. Each of us is guided by our own convictions
column4: and to these we must stay faithful. Yet we're all held to the same standards and called to serve the same good purposes: to extend this Nation's prosperity
column5: to spend the people's money wisely
column6: to solve problems
column7: not leave them to future generations
column8: to guard America against all evil
column9: and to keep faith with those we have sent forth to defend us.

column1: We're not the first to come here with a government divided and uncertainty in the air. Like many before us
column2: we can work through our differences
column3: and we can achieve big things for the American people. Our citizens don't much care which side of the aisle we sit on
column4: as long as we're willing to cross that aisle when there is work to be done. Our job is to make life better for our fellow Americans and to help them build a future of hope and opportunity
column5: and this is the business before us tonight.

column1: A future of hope and opportunity begins with a growing economy
column2: and that is what we have. We're now in the 41st month of uninterrupted job growth
column3: a recovery that has created 7.2 million new jobs so far. Unemployment is low; inflation is low; wages are rising. This economy is on the move
column4: and our job is to keep it that way
column5: not with more government but with more enterprise.

column1: Next week
column2: I'll deliver a full report on the state of our economy. Tonight I want to discuss three economic reforms that deserve to be priorities for this Congress.

column1: First
column2: we must balance the Federal budget. We can do so without raising taxes. What we need is spending discipline in Washington
column3: DC. We set a goal of cutting the deficit in half by 2009 and met that goal 3 years ahead of schedule. Now let us take the next step. In the coming weeks
column4: I will submit a budget that eliminates the Federal deficit within the next 5 years. I ask you to make the same commitment. Together
column5: we can restrain the spending appetite of the Federal Government
column6: and we can balance the Federal budget.

column1: Next
column2: there is the matter of earmarks. These special interest items are often slipped into bills at the last hour
column3: when not even C-SPAN is watching.  In 2005 alone
column4: the number of earmarks grew to over 13
column5: 000 and totaled nearly $18 billion. Even worse
column6: over 90 percent of the earmarks never make it to the floor of the House and Senate. They are dropped into committee reports that are not even part of the bill that arrives on my desk. You didn't vote them into law
column7: I didn't sign them into law
column8: yet they're treated as if they have the force of law. The time has come to end this practice. So let us work together to reform the budget process
column9: expose every earmark to the light of day and to a vote in Congress
column10: and cut the number and cost of earmarks at least in half by the end of this session.

column1: And finally
column2: to keep this economy strong
column3: we must take on the challenge of entitlements. Social Security and Medicare and Medicaid are commitments of conscience
column4: and so it is our duty to keep them permanently sound. Yet we're failing in that duty. And this failure will one day leave our children with three bad options: huge tax increases
column5: huge deficits
column6: or huge and immediate cuts in benefits. Everyone in this Chamber knows this to be true
column7: yet somehow we have not found it in ourselves to act. So let us work together and do it now. With enough good sense and good will
column8: you and I can fix Medicare and Medicaid and save Social Security.

column1: Spreading opportunity and hope in America also requires public schools that give children the knowledge and character they need in life. Five years ago
column2: we rose above partisan differences to pass the No Child Left Behind Act
column3: preserving local control
column4: raising standards
column5: and holding schools accountable for results. And because we acted
column6: students are performing better in reading and math
column7: and minority students are closing the achievement gap.

column1: Now the task is to build on the success without watering down standards
column2: without taking control from local communities
column3: and without backsliding and calling it reform. We can lift student achievement even higher by giving local leaders flexibility to turn around failing schools and by giving families with children stuck in failing schools the right to choose someplace better. We must increase funds for students who struggle and make sure these children get the special help they need. And we can make sure our children are prepared for the jobs of the future and our country is more competitive by strengthening math and science skills. The No Child Left Behind Act has worked for America's children
column4: and I ask Congress to reauthorize this good law.

column1: A future of hope and opportunity requires that all our citizens have affordable and available health care. When it comes to health care
column2: Government has an obligation to care for the elderly
column3: the disabled
column4: and poor children
column5: and we will meet those responsibilities. For all other Americans
column6: private health insurance is the best way to meet their needs.

column1: But many Americans cannot afford a health insurance policy
column2: and so tonight I propose two new initiatives to help more Americans afford their own insurance. First
column3: I propose a standard tax deduction for health insurance that will be like the standard tax deduction for dependents. Families with health insurance will pay no income on payroll taxor payroll taxes on $15
column4: 000 of their income. Single Americans with health insurance will pay no income or payroll taxes on $7
column5: 500 of their income. With this reform
column6: more than 100 million men
column7: women
column8: and children who are now covered by employer-provided insurance will benefit from lower tax bills. At the same time
column9: this reform will level the playing field for those who do not get health insurance through their job. For Americans who now purchase health insurance on their own
column10: this proposal would mean a substantial tax savings
column12: 500 for a family of four making $60
column13: 000 a year. And for the millions of other Americans who have no health insurance at all
column14: this deduction would help put a basic
column15: private health insurance plan within their reach. Changing the Tax Code is a vital and necessary step to making health care affordable for more Americans.

column1: My second proposal is to help the States that are coming up with innovative ways to cover the uninsured. States that make basic private health insurance available to all their citizens should receive Federal funds to help them provide this coverage to the poor and the sick. I have asked the Secretary of Health and Human Services to work with Congress to take existing Federal funds and use them to create Affordable Choices grants. These grants would give our Nation's Governors more money and more flexibility to get private health insurance to those most in need.

There are many other ways that Congress can help. We need to expand health savings accounts. We need to help small businesses through association health plans. We need to reduce costs and medical errors with better information technology. We will encourage price transparency. And to protect good doctors from junk lawsuits
column2: we need to pass medical liability reform. In all we do
column3: we must remember that the best health care decisions are not made by government and insurance companies but by patients and their doctors.

column1: Extending hope and opportunity in our country requires an immigration system worthy of America
column2: with laws that are fair and borders that are secure. When laws and borders are routinely violated
column3: this harms the interests of our country. To secure our border
column4: we're doubling the size of the Border Patrol and funding new infrastructure and technology.

column1: Yet even with all these steps
column2: we cannot fully secure the border unless we take pressure off the border
column3: and that requires a temporary-worker program. We should establish a legal and orderly path for foreign workers to enter our country to work on a temporary basis. As a result
column4: they won't have to try to sneak in
column5: and that will leave border agents free to chase down drug smugglers and criminals and terrorists. We'll enforce our immigration laws at the worksite and give employers the tools to verify the legal status of their workers
column6: so there's no excuse left for violating the law.

column1: We need to uphold the great tradition of the melting pot that welcomes and assimilates new arrivals. We need to resolve the status of the illegal immigrants who are already in our country without animosity and without amnesty. Convictions run deep in this Capitol when it comes to immigration. Let us have a serious
column2: civil
column3: and conclusive debate
column4: so that you can pass and I can sign comprehensive immigration reform into law.

column1: Extending hope and opportunity depends on a stable supply of energy that keeps America's economy running and America's environment clean. For too long
column2: our Nation has been dependent on foreign oil. And this dependence leaves us more vulnerable to hostile regimes and to terrorists who could cause huge disruptions of oil shipments and raise the price of oil and do great harm to our economy.

column1: It's in our vital interest to diversify America's energy supply. The way forward is through technology. We must continue changing the way America generates electric power by even greater use of clean coal technology
column2: solar and wind energy
column3: and clean
column4: safe nuclear power. We need to press on with battery research for plug-in and hybrid vehicles and expand the use of clean diesel vehicles and biodiesel fuel. We must continue investing in new methods of producing ethanol
column5: using everything from wood chips to grasses to agricultural wastes.

column1: We made a lot of progress
column2: thanks to good policies here in Washington and the strong response of the market. And now even more dramatic advances are within reach. Tonight I ask Congress to join me in pursuing a great goal. Let us build on the work we've done and reduce gasoline usage in the United States by 20 percent in the next 10 years. When we do that
column3: we will have cut our total imports by the equivalent of three-quarters of all the oil we now import from the Middle East.

column1: To reach this goal
column2: we must increase the supply of alternative fuels by setting a mandatory fuels standard to require 35 billion gallons of renewable and alternative fuels in 2017
column3: and that is nearly five times the current target. At the same time
column4: we need to reform and modernize fuel economy standards for cars the way we did for light trucks
column5: and conserve up to 812 billion more gallons of gasoline by 2017.

column1: Achieving these ambitious goals will dramatically reduce our dependence on foreign oil
column2: but it's not going to eliminate it. And so as we continue to diversify our fuel supply
column3: we must step up domestic oil production in environmentally sensitive ways. And to further protect America against severe disruptions to our oil supply
column4: I ask Congress to double the current capacity of the Strategic Petroleum Reserve.

column1: America is on the verge of technological breakthroughs that will enable us to live our lives less dependent on oil. And these technologies will help us be better stewards of the environment
column2: and they will help us to confront the serious challenge of global climate change.

column1: A future of hope and opportunity requires a fair
column2: impartial system of justice. The lives of our citizens across our Nation are affected by the outcome of cases pending in our Federal courts. We have a shared obligation to ensure that the Federal courts have enough judges to hear those cases and deliver timely rulings. As President
column3: I have a duty to nominate qualified men and women to vacancies on the Federal bench
column4: and the United States Senate has a duty as well
column5: to give those nominees a fair hearing and a prompt up-or-down vote on the Senate floor.

column1: For all of us in this room
column2: there is no higher responsibility than to protect the people of this country from danger. Five years have come and gone since we saw the scenes and felt the sorrow that the terrorists can cause. We've had time to take stock of our situation. We've added many critical protections to guard the homeland. We know with certainty that the horrors of that September morning were just a glimpse of what the terrorists intend for us
column3: unless we stop them.

column1: With the distance of time
column2: we find ourselves debating the causes of conflict and the course we have followed. Such debates are essential when a great democracy faces great questions. Yet one question has surely been settled: that to win the war on terror
column3: we must take the fight to the enemy.

column1: From the start
column2: America and our allies have protected our people by staying on the offense. The enemy knows that the days of comfortable sanctuary
column3: easy movement
column4: steady financing
column5: and free flowing communications are long over. For the terrorists
column6: life since 9/11 has never been the same.

column1: Our success in this war is often measured by the things that did not happen. We cannot know the full extent of the attacks that we and our allies have prevented
column2: but here is some of what we do know. We stopped an Al Qaida plot to fly a hijacked airplane into the tallest building on the west coast. We broke up a Southeast Asian terror cell grooming operatives for attacks inside the United States. We uncovered an Al Qaida cell developing anthrax to be used in attacks against America. And just last August
column3: British authorities uncovered a plot to blow up passenger planes bound for America over the Atlantic Ocean. For each life saved
column4: we owe a debt of gratitude to the brave public servants who devote their lives to finding the terrorists and stopping them.

column1: Every success against the terrorists is a reminder of the shoreless ambitions of this enemy. The evil that inspired and rejoiced in 9/11 is still at work in the world. And so long as that's the case
column2: America is still a nation at war.

column1: In the mind of the terrorists
column2: this war began well before September the 11th and will not end until their radical vision is fulfilled. And these past 5 years have given us a much clearer view of the nature of this enemy. Al Qaida and its followers are Sunni extremists possessed by hatred and commanded by a harsh and narrow ideology. Take almost any principle of civilization
column3: and their goal is the opposite. They preach with threats
column4: instruct with bullets and bombs
column5: and promise paradise for the murder of the innocent.

column1: Our enemies are quite explicit about their intentions. They want to overthrow moderate governments and establish safe havens from which to plan and carry out new attacks on our country. By killing and terrorizing Americans

Listen to this warning from the late terrorist Zarqawi: "We will sacrifice our blood and bodies to put an end to your dreams

column1: These men are not given to idle words
column2: and they are just one camp in the Islamist radical movement. In recent times
column3: it has also become clear that we face an escalating danger from Shi'a extremists who are just as hostile to America and are also determined to dominate the Middle East. Many are known to take direction from the regime in Iran
column4: which is funding and arming terrorists like Hizballah
column5: a group second only to Al Qaida in the American lives it has taken.

column1: The Shi'a and Sunni extremists are different faces of the same totalitarian threat. Whatever slogans they chant when they slaughter the innocent

column3: kill democracy in the Middle East
column4: and gain the weapons to kill on an even more horrific scale.

column1: In the sixth year since our Nation was attacked

column3: diplomacy
column4: law enforcement
column5: and military action to do our duty
column6: to find these enemies
column7: and to protect the American people.

column1: This war is more than a clash of arms; it is a decisive ideological struggle. And the security of our Nation is in the balance. To prevail

column3: answer to their own conscience
column4: and live by their hopes instead of their resentments. Free people are not drawn to violent and malignant ideologies
column5: and most will choose a better way when they're given a chance. So we advance our own security interests by helping moderates and reformers and brave voices for democracy. column6: for the sake of our own security

column1: In the last 2 years

column8: adopting the most progressive
column9: democratic Constitution in the Arab world

column1: A thinking enemy watched all of these scenes
column2: adjusted their tactics
column3: and
column5: they struck back. In Lebanon

column6: insurgents

column1: My fellow citizens

column3: and
column4: in time

column5: new recruits

column10: and to spare the American people from this danger.

column1: This is where matters stand tonight
column2: in the here and now. I have spoken with many of you in person. I respect you and the arguments you've made. We went into this largely united
column3: in our assumptions and in our convictions. And whatever you voted for
column4: you did not vote for failure. Our country is pursuing a new strategy in Iraq
column5: and I ask you to give it a chance to work. And I ask you to support our troops in the field and those on their way.

column1: The war on terror we fight today is a generational struggle that will continue long after you and I have turned our duties over to others. And that's why it's important to work together so our Nation can see this great effort through. Both parties and both branches should work in close consultation. It's why I've proposed to establish a special advisory council on the war on terror
column2: made up of leaders in Congress from both political parties. We will share ideas for how to position America to meet every challenge that confronts us. We'll show our enemies abroad that we are united in the goal of victory.

column1: And one of the first steps we can take together is to add to the ranks of our military so that the American Armed Forces are ready for all the challenges ahead. Tonight I ask the Congress to authorize an increase in the size of our active Army and Marine Corps by 92
column2: 000 in the next 5 years. A second task we can take on together is to design and establish a volunteer civilian reserve corps. Such a corps would function much like our military reserve. It would ease the burden on the Armed Forces by allowing us to hire civilians with critical skills to serve on missions abroad when America needs them. It would give people across America who do not wear the uniform a chance to serve in the defining struggle of our time.

column1: Americans can have confidence in the outcome of this struggle because we're not in this struggle alone. We have a diplomatic strategy that is rallying the world to join in the fight against extremism. In Iraq
column2: multinational forces are operating under a mandate from the United Nations. We're working with Jordan and Saudi Arabia and Egypt and the Gulf States to increase support for Iraq's Government.

column1: The United Nations has imposed sanctions on Iran and made it clear that the world will not allow the regime in Tehran to acquire nuclear weapons. With the other members of the Quartetthe U.N.
column2: the EU
column3: and Russiawe're pursuing diplomacy to help bring peace to the Holy Land and pursuing the establishment of a democratic Palestinian state living side by side with Israel in peace and security. In Afghanistan
column4: NATO has taken the lead in turning back the Taliban and Al Qaida offensive
column5: the first time the Alliance has deployed forces outside the North Atlantic area. Together with our partners in China and Japan
column6: Russia and South Korea
column7: we're pursuing intensive diplomacy to achieve a Korean Peninsula free of nuclear weapons.

column1: We will continue to speak out for the cause of freedom in places like Cuba
column2: Belarus
column3: and Burma
column4: and continue to awaken the conscience of the world to save the people of Darfur.

column1: American foreign policy is more than a matter of war and diplomacy. Our work in the world is also based on a timeless truth: To whom much is given
column2: much is required. We hear the call to take on the challenges of hunger and poverty and disease
column3: and that is precisely what America is doing. We must continue to fight HIV/ AIDS
column4: especially on the continent of Africa. Because you funded the Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief
column5: the number of people receiving lifesaving drugs has grown from 50
column6: 000 to more than 800
column7: 000 in 3 short years. I ask you to continue funding our efforts to fight HIV/AIDS
column8: and I ask you to provide $1.2 billion over 5 years so we can combat malaria in 15 African countries.

column1: I ask that you fund the Millennium Challenge Account
column2: so that American aid reaches the people who need it
column3: in nations where democracy is on the rise and corruption is in retreat. And let us continue to support the expanded trade and debt relief that are the best hope for lifting lives and eliminating poverty.

column1: When America serves others in this way
column2: we show the strength and generosity of our country. These deeds reflect the character of our people. The greatest strength we have is the heroic kindness and courage and self-sacrifice of the American people. You see this spirit often if you know where to look
column3: and tonight we need only look above to the gallery.

column1: Dikembe Mutombo grew up in Africa amid great poverty and disease. He came to Georgetown University on a scholarship to study medicine
column2: but Coach John Thompson took a look at Dikembe and had a different idea.  Dikembe became a star in the NBA and a citizen of the United States
column3: but he never forgot the land of his birth or the duty to share his blessings with others. He built a brand new hospital in his old hometown. A friend has said of this good-hearted man: "Mutombo believes that God has given him this opportunity to do great things." And we are proud to call this son of the Congo a citizen of the United States of America.

column1: After her daughter was born
column2: Julie Aigner-Clark searched for ways to share her love of music and art with her child. So she borrowed some equipment and began filming children's videos in her basement. The Baby Einstein Company was born
column3: and in just 5 years
column4: her business grew to more than $20 million in sales. In November 2001
column5: Julie sold Baby Einstein to Walt Disney Company
column6: and with her help
column7: Baby Einstein has grown into a $200 million business. Julie represents the great enterprising spirit of America. And she is using her success to help others
column8: producing child safety videos with John Walsh of the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children. Julie says of her new project: "I believe it is the most important thing I have ever done. I believe that children have the right to live in a world that is safe." And so tonight we are pleased to welcome this talented business entrepreneur and generous social entrepreneur
column9: Julie Aigner-Clark.

column1: Three weeks ago
column2: Wesley Autrey was waiting at a Harlem subway station with his two little girls when he saw a man fall into the path of a train. With seconds to act
column3: Wesley jumped onto the tracks
column4: pulled the man into the space between the rails
column5: and held him as the train passed right above their heads. He insists he's not a hero. He says: "We got guys and girls overseas dying for us to have our freedoms. We have got to show each other some love." There is something wonderful about a country that produces a brave and humble man like Wesley Autrey.

column1: Tommy Rieman was a teenager pumping gas in Independence
column2: Kentucky
column3: when he enlisted in the United States Army. In December 2003
column4: he was on a reconnaissance mission in Iraq when his team came under heavy enemy fire. From his Humvee
column5: Sergeant Rieman returned fire. He used his body as a shield to protect his gunner. He was shot in the chest and arm and received shrapnel wounds to his legs
column6: yet he refused medical attention and stayed in the fight. He helped to repel a second attack
column7: firing grenades at the enemy's position. For his exceptional courage
column8: Sergeant Rieman was awarded the Silver Star. And like so many other Americans who have volunteered to defend us
column9: he has earned the respect and the gratitude of our entire country.

column1: In such courage and compassion
column2: ladies and gentlemen
column3: we see the spirit and character of America. And these qualities are not in short supply. This is a decent and honorable country and resilient too. We've been through a lot together. We've met challenges and faced dangers
column4: and we know that more lie ahead. Yet we can go forward with confidence
column5: because the State of our Union is strong; our cause in the world is right; and tonight that cause goes on. God bless.

column1: See you next year. Thank you for your prayers.@
George W. Bush|Address Before a Joint Session of the Congress on the State of the Union|2008-01-28|@Thank you all. Madam Speaker
column2: Vice President Cheney
column3: Members of Congress
column4: distinguished guests
column5: and fellow citizens: Seven years have passed since I first stood before you at this rostrum. In that time
column6: our country has been tested in ways none of us could have imagined. We faced hard decisions about peace and war
column7: rising competition in the world economy
column8: and the health and welfare of our citizens. These issues call for vigorous debate
column9: and I think it's fair to say
column10: we've answered the call.  Yet history will record that amid our differences
column11: we acted with purpose
column12: and together we showed the world the power and resilience of American self-government.

column1: All of us were sent to Washington to carry out the people's business. That is the purpose of this body. It is the meaning of our oath. It remains our charge to keep.
The actions of the 110th Congress will affect the security and prosperity of our Nation long after this session has ended. In this election year
column2: let us show our fellow Americans that we recognize our responsibilities and are determined to meet them. Let us show them that Republicans and Democrats can compete for votes and cooperate for results at the same time.

column1: From expanding opportunity to protecting our country
column2: we've made good progress. Yet we have unfinished business before us
column3: and the American people expect us to get it done.

column1: In the work ahead
column2: we must be guided by the philosophy that made our Nation great. As Americans
column3: we believe in the power of individuals to determine their destiny and shape the course of history. We believe that the most reliable guide for our country is the collective wisdom of ordinary citizens. And so in all we do
column4: we must trust in the ability of free peoples to make wise decisions and empower them to improve their lives for their futures.

column1: To build a prosperous future
column2: we must trust people with their own money and empower them to grow our economy. As we meet tonight
column3: our economy is undergoing a period of uncertainty. America has added jobs for a record 52 straight months
column4: but jobs are now growing at a slower pace. Wages are up
column5: but so are prices for food and gas. Exports are rising
column6: but the housing market has declined. At kitchen tables across our country
column7: there is a concern about our economic future.

column1: In the long run
column2: Americans can be confident about our economic growth. But in the short run
column3: we can all see that that growth is slowing. So last week
column4: my administration reached agreement with Speaker Pelosi and Republican Leader Boehner on a robust growth package that includes tax relief for individuals and families and incentives for business investment. The temptation will be to load up the bill. That would delay it or derail it
column5: and neither option is acceptable. This is a good agreement that will keep our economy growing and our people working
column6: and this Congress must pass it as soon as possible.

column1: We have other work to do on taxes. Unless Congress acts
column2: most of the tax relief we've delivered over the past 7 years will be taken away. Some in Washington argue that letting tax relief expire is not a tax increase. Try explaining that to 116 million American taxpayers who would see their taxes rise by an average of $1
column3: 800. Others have said they would personally be happy to pay higher taxes. I welcome their enthusiasm. I'm pleased to report that the IRS accepts both checks and money orders.

column1: Most Americans think their taxes are high enough. With all the other pressures on their finances
column2: American families should not have to worry about their Federal Government taking a bigger bite out of their paychecks. There's only one way to eliminate this uncertainty: Make the tax relief permanent. And Members of Congress should know
column3: if any bill raises taxes reaches my desk
column4: I will veto it.

column1: Just as we trust Americans with their own money
column2: we need to earn their trust by spending their tax dollars wisely. Next week
column3: I'll send you a budget that terminates or substantially reduces 151 wasteful or bloated programs
column4: totaling more than $18 billion. The budget that I will submit will keep America on track for a surplus in 2012. American families have to balance their budgets; so should their Government.

column1: The people's trust in their Government is undermined by congressional earmarks
column2: special interest projects that are often snuck in at the last minute
column3: without discussion or debate. Last year
column4: I asked you to voluntarily cut the number and cost of earmarks in half. I also asked you to stop slipping earmarks into committee reports that never even come to a vote. Unfortunately
column5: neither goal was met. So this time
column6: if you send me an appropriations bill that does not cut the number and cost of earmarks in half
column7: I'll send it back to you with my veto.

column1: And tomorrow I will issue an Executive order that directs Federal agencies to ignore any future earmark that is not voted on by Congress. If these items are truly worth funding
column2: Congress should debate them in the open and hold a public vote.

column1: Our shared responsibilities extend beyond matters of taxes and spending. On housing
column2: we must trust Americans with the responsibility of homeownership and empower them to weather turbulent times in the housing market. My administration brought together the HOPE NOW Alliance
column3: which is helping many struggling homeowners avoid foreclosure. And Congress can help even more. Tonight I ask you to pass legislation to reform Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac
column4: modernize the Federal Housing Administration
column5: and allow State housing agencies to issue tax-free bonds to help homeowners refinance their mortgages. These are difficult times for many American families
column6: and by taking these steps
column7: we can help more of them keep their homes.

column1: To build a future of quality health care
column2: we must trust patients and doctors to make medical decisions and empower them with better information and better options. We share a common goal: making health care more affordable and accessible for all Americans. The best way to achieve that goal is by expanding consumer choice
column3: not Government control. So I have proposed ending the bias in the Tax Code against those who do not get their health insurance through their employer. This one reform would put private coverage within reach for millions
column4: and I call on the Congress to pass it this year.

column1: Congress must also expand health savings accounts
column2: create association health plans for small businesses
column3: promote health information technology
column4: and confront the epidemic of junk medical lawsuits. With all these steps
column5: we will ensure that decisions about your medical care are made in the privacy of your doctor's office
column6: not in the Halls of Congress.

column1: On education
column2: we must trust students to learn
column3: if given the chance
column4: and empower parents to demand results from our schools. In neighborhoods across our country
column5: there are boys and girls with dreams
column6: and a decent education is their only hope of achieving them.

column1: Six years ago
column2: we came together to pass the No Child Left Behind Act
column3: and today
column4: no one can deny its results. Last year
column5: fourth and eighth graders achieved the highest math scores on record. Reading scores are on the rise. African American and Hispanic students posted alltime highs. Now we must work together to increase accountability
column6: add flexibilities for States and districts
column7: reduce the number of high school dropouts
column8: provide extra help for struggling schools.

column1: Members of Congress
column2: the No Child Left Behind Act is a bipartisan achievement. It is succeeding
column3: and we owe it to America's children
column4: their parents
column5: and their teachers to strengthen this good law.

column1: We must also do more to help children when their schools do not measure up. Thanks to the DC Opportunity Scholarships you approved
column2: more than 2
column3: 600 of the poorest children in our Nation's Capital have found new hope at a faith-based or other nonpublic school. Sadly
column4: these schools are disappearing at an alarming rate in many of America's inner cities. So I will convene a White House summit aimed at strengthening these lifelines of learning. And to open the doors of these schools to more children
column5: I ask you to support a new $300 million program called Pell Grants for Kids. We have seen how Pell grants help low-income college students realize their full potential. Together
column6: we've expanded the size and reach of these grants. Now let us apply the same spirit to help liberate poor children trapped in failing public schools.

column1: On trade
column2: we must trust American workers to compete with anyone in the world and empower them by opening up new markets overseas. Today
column3: our economic growth increasingly depends on our ability to sell American goods and crops and services all over the world. So we're working to break down barriers to trade and investment wherever we can. We're working for a successful Doha round of trade talks
column4: and we must complete a good agreement this year. At the same time
column5: we're pursuing opportunities to open up new markets by passing free trade agreements.

column1: I thank the Congress for approving a good agreement with Peru. And now I ask you to approve agreements with Colombia and Panama and South Korea. Many products from these nations now enter America duty free
column2: yet many of our products face steep tariffs in their markets. These agreements will level the playing field. They will give us better access to nearly 100 million customers. They will support good jobs for the finest workers in the world
column3: those whose products say "Made in the U.S.A."

column1: These agreements also promote America's strategic interests. The first agreement that will come before you is with Colombia
column2: a friend of America that is confronting violence and terror and fighting drug traffickers. If we fail to pass this agreement
column3: we will embolden the purveyors of false populism in our hemisphere. So we must come together
column4: pass this agreement
column5: and show our neighbors in the region that democracy leads to a better life.

column1: Trade brings better jobs and better choices and better prices. Yet for some Americans
column2: trade can mean losing a job
column3: and the Federal Government has a responsibility to help. I ask Congress to reauthorize and reform trade adjustment assistance so we can help these displaced workers learn new skills and find new jobs.

column1: To build a future of energy security
column2: we must trust in the creative genius of American researchers and entrepreneurs and empower them to pioneer a new generation of clean energy technology. Our security
column3: our prosperity
column4: and our environment all require reducing our dependence on oil.

column1: Last year
column2: I asked you to pass legislation to reduce oil consumption over the next decade
column3: and you responded. Together
column4: we should take the next steps. Let us fund new technologies that can generate coal power while capturing carbon emissions. Let us increase the use of renewable power and emissions-free nuclear power. Let us continue investing in advanced battery technology and renewable fuels to power the cars and trucks of the future. Let us create a new international clean technology fund
column5: which will help developing nations like India and China make a greater use of clean energy sources. And let us complete an international agreement that has the potential to slow
column6: stop
column7: and eventually reverse the growth of greenhouse gases.

column1: This agreement will be effective only if it includes commitments by every major economy and gives none a free ride. The United States is committed to strengthening our energy security and confronting global climate change. And the best way to meet these goals is for America to continue leading the way toward the development of cleaner and more energy efficient technology.
To keep America competitive into the future
column2: we must trust in the skill of our scientists and engineers and empower them to pursue the breakthroughs of tomorrow. Last year
column3: Congress passed legislation supporting the American Competitiveness Initiative
column4: but never followed through with the funding. This funding is essential to keeping our scientific edge. So I ask Congress to double Federal support for critical basic research in the physical sciences and ensure America remains the most dynamic nation on Earth.

column1: On matters of life and science
column2: we must trust in the innovative spirit of medical researchers and empower them to discover new treatments while respecting moral boundaries. In November
column3: we witnessed a landmark achievement when scientists discovered a way to reprogram adult skin cells to act like embryonic stem cells. This breakthrough has the potential to move us beyond the divisive debates of the past by extending the frontiers of medicine without the destruction of human life.

column1: So we're expanding funding for this type of ethical medical research. And as we explore promising avenues of research
column2: we must also ensure that all life is treated with the dignity it deserves. And so I call on Congress to pass legislation that bans unethical practices
column3: such as the buying
column4: selling
column5: patenting
column6: or cloning of human life.

column1: On matters of justice
column2: we must trust in the wisdom of our Founders and empower judges who understand that the Constitution means what it says. I've submitted judicial nominees who will rule by the letter of the law
column3: not the whim of the gavel. Many of these nominees are being unfairly delayed. They are worthy of confirmation
column4: and the Senate should give each of them a prompt up-or-down vote.

column1: In communities across our land
column2: we must trust in the good heart of the American people and empower them to serve their neighbors in need. Over the past 7 years
column3: more of our fellow citizens have discovered that the pursuit of happiness leads to the path of service. Americans have volunteered in record numbers. Charitable donations are higher than ever. Faith-based groups are bringing hope to pockets of despair
column4: with newfound support from the Federal Government. And to help guarantee equal treatment of faith-based organizations when they compete for Federal funds
column5: I ask you to permanently extend charitable choice.

column1: Tonight the armies of compassion continue the march to a new day in the Gulf Coast. America honors the strength and resilience of the people of this region. We reaffirm our pledge to help them build stronger and better than before. And tonight I'm pleased to announce that in April
column2: we will host this year's North American Summit of Canada
column3: Mexico
column4: and the United States in the great city of New Orleans.

column1: There are two other pressing challenges that I've raised repeatedly before this body and that this body has failed to address: entitlement spending and immigration. Every Member in this Chamber knows that spending on entitlement programs like Social Security
column2: Medicare
column3: and Medicaid is growing faster than we can afford. We all know the painful choices ahead if America stays on this path: massive tax increases
column4: sudden and drastic cuts in benefits
column5: or crippling deficits. I've laid out proposals to reform these programs. Now I ask Members of Congress to offer your proposals and come up with a bipartisan solution to save these vital programs for our children and our grandchildren.

column1: The other pressing challenge is immigration. America needs to secure our borders
column2: and with your help
column3: my administration is taking steps to do so. We're increasing worksite enforcement
column4: deploying fences and advanced technologies to stop illegal crossings. We've effectively ended the policy of catch-and-release at the border
column5: and by the end of this year
column6: we will have doubled the number of Border Patrol agents. Yet we also need to acknowledge that we will never fully secure our border until we create a lawful way for foreign workers to come here and support our economy. This will take pressure off the border and allow law enforcement to concentrate on those who mean us harm.

column1: We must also find a sensible and humane way to deal with people here illegally. Illegal immigration is complicated
column2: but it can be resolved. And it must be resolved in a way that upholds both our laws and our highest ideals.

column1: This is the business of our Nation here at home. Yet building a prosperous future for our citizens also depends on confronting enemies abroad and advancing liberty in troubled regions of the world.
Our foreign policy is based on a clear premise: We trust that people
column2: when given the chance
column3: will choose a future of freedom and peace. In the last 7 years
column4: we have witnessed stirring moments in the history of liberty. We've seen citizens in Georgia and Ukraine stand up for their right to free and fair elections. We've seen people in Lebanon take to the streets to demand their independence. We've seen Afghans emerge from the tyranny of the Taliban and choose a new President and a new parliament. We've seen jubilant Iraqis holding up ink-stained fingers and celebrating their freedom. These images of liberty have inspired us.

column1: In the past 7 years
column2: we've also seen the images that have sobered us. We've watched throngs of mourners in Lebanon and Pakistan carrying the caskets of beloved leaders taken by the assassin's hand. We've seen wedding guests in blood-soaked finery staggering from a hotel in Jordan
column3: Afghans and Iraqis blown up in mosques and markets
column4: and trains in London and Madrid ripped apart by bombs. On a clear September day
column5: we saw thousands of our fellow citizens taken from us in an instant. These horrific images serve as a grim reminder: The advance of liberty is opposed by terrorists and extremists
column6: evil men who despise freedom
column7: despise America
column8: and aim to subject millions to their violent rule.

column1: Since 9/11
column2: we have taken the fight to these terrorists and extremists. We will stay on the offense
column3: we will keep up the pressure
column4: and we will deliver justice to our enemies.

column1: We are engaged in the defining ideological struggle of the 21st century. The terrorists oppose every principle of humanity and decency that we hold dear. Yet in this war on terror
column2: there is one thing we and our enemies agree on: In the long run
column3: men and women who are free to determine their own destinies will reject terror and refuse to live in tyranny. And that is why the terrorists are fighting to deny this choice to the people in Lebanon
column4: Iraq
column5: Afghanistan
column6: Pakistan
column7: and the Palestinian Territories. And that is why
column8: for the security of America and the peace of the world
column9: we are spreading the hope of freedom.

column1: In Afghanistan
column2: America
column3: our 25 NATO allies
column4: and 15 partner nations are helping the Afghan people defend their freedom and rebuild their country. Thanks to the courage of these military and civilian personnel
column5: a nation that was once a safe haven for Al Qaida is now a young democracy where boys and girls are going to school
column6: new roads and hospitals are being built
column7: and people are looking to the future with new hope. These successes must continue
column8: so we're adding 3
column9: 200 marines to our forces in Afghanistan
column10: where they will fight the terrorists and train the Afghan Army and police. Defeating the Taliban and Al Qaida is critical to our security
column11: and I thank the Congress for supporting America's vital mission in Afghanistan.

column1: In Iraq
column2: the terrorists and extremists are fighting to deny a proud people their liberty and fighting to establish safe havens for attacks across the world. One year ago
column3: our enemies were succeeding in their efforts to plunge Iraq into chaos. So we reviewed our strategy and changed course. We launched a surge of American forces into Iraq. We gave our troops a new mission: work with the Iraqi forces to protect the Iraqi people
column4: pursue the enemy in its strongholds
column5: and deny the terrorists sanctuary anywhere in the country.

column1: The Iraqi people quickly realized that something dramatic had happened. Those who had worried that America was preparing to abandon them instead saw tens of thousands of American forces flowing into their country. They saw our forces moving into neighborhoods
column2: clearing out the terrorists
column3: and staying behind to ensure the enemy did not return. And they saw our troops
column4: along with Provincial Reconstruction Teams that include Foreign Service officers and other skilled public servants
column5: coming in to ensure that improved security was followed by improvements in daily life. Our military and civilians in Iraq are performing with courage and distinction
column6: and they have the gratitude of our whole Nation.

column1: The Iraqis launched a surge of their own. In the fall of 2006
column2: Sunni tribal leaders grew tired of Al Qaida's brutality
column3: started a popular uprising called the Anbar Awakening. Over the past year
column4: similar movements have spread across the country. And today
column5: the grassroots surge includes more than 80
column6: 000 Iraqi citizens who are fighting the terrorists. The Government in Baghdad has stepped forward as well
column7: adding more than 100
column8: 000 new Iraqi soldiers and police during the past year.

column1: While the enemy is still dangerous and more work remains
column2: the American and Iraqi surges have achieved results few of us could have imagined just 1 year ago. When we met last year
column3: many said that containing the violence was impossible. A year later
column4: high-profile terrorist attacks are down
column5: civilian deaths are down
column6: sectarian killings are down.

column1: When we met last year
column2: militia extremistssome armed and trained by Iran were wreaking havoc in large areas of Iraq. A year later
column3: coalition and Iraqi forces have killed or captured hundreds of militia fighters. And Iraqis of all backgrounds increasingly realize that defeating these militia fighters is critical to the future of their country.

column1: When we met last year
column2: Al Qaida had sanctuaries in many areas of Iraq
column3: and their leaders had just offered American forces safe passage out of the country. Today
column4: it is Al Qaida that is searching for safe passage. They have been driven from many of the strongholds they once held. And over the past year
column5: we've captured or killed thousands of extremists in Iraq
column6: including hundreds of key Al Qaida leaders and operatives.

column1: Last month
column2: Usama bin Laden released a tape in which he railed against Iraqi tribal leaders who have turned on Al Qaida and admitted that coalition forces are growing stronger in Iraq. Ladies and gentlemen
column3: some may deny the surge is working
column4: but among the terrorists there is no doubt. Al Qaida is on the run in Iraq
column5: and this enemy will be defeated.

column1: When we met last year
column2: our troop levels in Iraq were on the rise. Today
column3: because of the progress just described
column4: we are implementing a policy of return on success
column5: and the surge forces we sent to Iraq are beginning to come home.

column1: This progress is a credit to the valor of our troops and the brilliance of their commanders. This evening I want to speak directly to our men and women on the frontlines. Soldiers and sailors
column2: airmen
column3: marines
column4: and coastguardsmen: In the past year
column5: you have done everything we've asked of you and more. Our Nation is grateful for your courage. We are proud of your accomplishments. And tonight in this hallowed Chamber
column6: with the American people as our witness
column7: we make you a solemn pledge: In the fight ahead
column8: you will have all you need to protect our Nation. And I ask Congress to meet its responsibilities to these brave men and women by fully funding our troops.

column1: Our enemies in Iraq have been hit hard. They are not yet defeated
column2: and we can still expect tough fighting ahead. Our objective in the coming year is to sustain and build on the gains we made in 2007 while transitioning to the next phase of our strategy. American troops are shifting from leading operations to partnering with Iraqi forces and
column3: eventually
column4: to a protective overwatch mission. As part of this transition
column5: one Army brigade combat team and one Marine expeditionary unit have already come home and will not be replaced. In the coming months
column6: four additional brigades and two Marine battalions will follow suit. Taken together
column7: this means more than 20
column8: 000 of our troops are coming home.

column1: Any further drawdown of U.S. troops will be based on conditions in Iraq and the recommendations of our commanders. General Petraeus has warned that too fast a drawdown could result in
column2: quote
column3: "the disintegration of the Iraqi security forces
column4: Al Qaida-Iraq regaining lost ground
column5: and a marked increase in violence." Members of Congress
column6: having come so far and achieved so much
column7: we must not allow this to happen.

column1: In the coming year
column2: we will work with Iraqi leaders as they build on the progress they're making toward political reconciliation. At the local level
column3: Sunnis
column4: Shi'a
column5: and Kurds are beginning to come together to reclaim their communities and rebuild their lives. Progress in the Provinces must be matched by progress in Baghdad. We're seeing some encouraging signs. The national Government is sharing oil revenues with the Provinces. The parliament recently passed both a pension law and de-Ba'athification reform. They're now debating a Provincial powers law. The Iraqis still have a distance to travel
column6: but after decades of dictatorship and the pain of sectarian violence
column7: reconciliation is taking place
column8: and the Iraqi people are taking control of their future.

column1: The mission in Iraq has been difficult and trying for our Nation
column2: but it is in the vital interest of the United States that we succeed. A free Iraq will deny Al Qaida a safe haven. A free Iraq will show millions across the Middle East that a future of liberty is possible. A free Iraq will be a friend of America
column3: a partner in fighting terror
column4: and a source of stability in a dangerous part of the world.

column1: By contrast
column2: a failed Iraq would embolden the extremists
column3: strengthen Iran
column4: and give terrorists a base from which to launch new attacks on our friends
column5: our allies
column6: and our homeland. The enemy has made its intentions clear. At a time when the momentum seemed to favor them
column7: Al Qaida's top commander in Iraq declared that they will not rest until they have attacked us here in Washington. My fellow Americans
column8: we will not rest either. We will not rest until this enemy has been defeated. We must do the difficult work today so that years from now
column9: people will look back and say that this generation rose to the moment
column10: prevailed in a tough fight
column11: and left behind a more hopeful region and a safer America.

column1: We're also standing against the forces of extremism in the Holy Land
column2: where we have new cause for hope. Palestinians have elected a President who recognizes that confronting terror is essential to achieving a state where his people can live in dignity and at peace with Israel. Israelis have leaders who recognize that a peaceful
column3: democratic Palestinian state will be a source of lasting security. This month in Ramallah and Jerusalem
column4: I assured leaders from both sides that America will do
column5: and I will do
column6: everything we can to help them achieve a peace agreement that defines a Palestinian state by the end of this year. The time has come for a Holy Land where a democratic Israel and a democratic Palestine live side by side in peace.

column1: We're also standing against the forces of extremism embodied by the regime in Tehran. Iran's rulers oppress a good and talented people. And wherever freedom advances in the Middle East
column2: it seems the Iranian regime is there to oppose it. Iran is funding and training militia groups in Iraq
column3: supporting Hizballah terrorists in Lebanon
column4: and backing Hamas efforts to undermine peace in the Holy Land. Tehran is also developing ballistic missiles of increasing range and continues to develop its capability to enrich uranium
column5: which could be used to create a nuclear weapon.

column1: Our message to the people of Iran is clear: We have no quarrel with you. We respect your traditions and your history. We look forward to the day when you have your freedom. Our message to the leaders of Iran is also clear: Verifiably suspend your nuclear enrichment so negotiations can begin. And to rejoin the community of nations
column2: come clean about your nuclear intentions and past actions
column3: stop your oppression at home
column4: cease your support for terror abroad. But above all
column5: know this: America will confront those who threaten our troops
column6: we will stand by our allies
column7: and we will defend our vital interests in the Persian Gulf.

column1: On the homefront
column2: we will continue to take every lawful and effective measure to protect our country. This is our most solemn duty. We are grateful that there has not been another attack on our soil since 9/11. This is not for the lack of desire or effort on the part of the enemy. In the past 6 years
column3: we've stopped numerous attacks
column4: including a plot to fly a plane into the tallest building in Los Angeles and another to blow up passenger jets bound for America over the Atlantic. Dedicated men and women in our Government toil day and night to stop the terrorists from carrying out their plans. These good citizens are saving American lives
column5: and everyone in this Chamber owes them our thanks.

column1: And we owe them something more; we owe them the tools they need to keep our people safe. And one of the most important tools we can give them is the ability to monitor terrorist communications. To protect America
column2: we need to know who the terrorists are talking to
column3: what they are saying
column4: and what they're planning. Last year
column5: Congress passed legislation to help us do that. Unfortunately
column6: Congress set the legislations to expire on February the 1st. That means if you don't act by Friday
column7: our ability to track terrorist threats would be weakened and our citizens will be in greater danger. Congress must ensure the flow of vital intelligence is not disrupted. Congress must pass liability protection for companies believed to have assisted in the efforts to defend America. We've had ample time for debate. The time to act is now.

column1: Protecting our Nation from the dangers of a new century requires more than good intelligence and a strong military. It also requires changing the conditions that breed resentment and allow extremists to prey on despair. So America is using its influence to build a freer
column2: more hopeful
column3: and more compassionate world. This is a reflection of our national interests; it is the calling of our conscience.

column1: America opposes genocide in Sudan. We support freedom in countries from Cuba and Zimbabwe to Belarus and Burma.

America is leading the fight against global poverty with strong education initiatives and humanitarian assistance. We've also changed the way we deliver aid by launching the Millennium Challenge Account. This program strengthens democracy
column2: transparency
column3: and the rule of law in developing nations
column4: and I ask you to fully fund this important initiative.

column1: America is leading the fight against global hunger. Today
column2: more than half the world's food aid comes from the United States. And tonight I ask Congress to support an innovative proposal to provide food assistance by purchasing crops directly from farmers in the developing world
column3: so we can build up local agriculture and help break the cycle of famine.

column1: America is leading the fight against disease. With your help
column2: we're working to cut by half the number of malaria-related deaths in 15 African nations. And our Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief is treating 1.4 million people. We can bring healing and hope to many more. So I ask you to maintain the principles that have changed behavior and made this program a success. And I call on you to double our initial commitment to fighting HIV/AIDS by approving an additional $30 billion over the next 5 years.

column1: America is a force for hope in the world because we are a compassionate people
column2: and some of the most compassionate Americans are those who have stepped forward to protect us. We must keep faith with all who have risked life and limb so that we might live in freedom and peace. Over the past 7 years
column3: we've increased funding for veterans by more than 95 percent. And as we increase funding
column4: we must also reform our veterans system to meet the needs of a new war and a new generation. I call on Congress to enact the reforms recommended by Senator Bob Dole and Secretary Donna Shalala so we can improve the system of care for our wounded warriors and help them build lives of hope and promise and dignity.

column1: Our military families also sacrifice for America. They endure sleepless nights and the daily struggle of providing for children while a loved one is serving far from home. We have a responsibility to provide for them. So I ask you to join me in expanding their access to child care
column2: creating new hiring preferences for military spouses across the Federal Government
column3: and allowing our troops to transfer their unused education benefits to their spouses or children. Our military families serve our Nation
column4: they inspire our Nation
column5: and tonight our Nation honors them.

column1: The strengththe secret of our strength
column2: the miracle of America
column3: is that our greatness lies not in our Government
column4: but in the spirit and determination of our people. When the Federal Convention met in Philadelphia in 1787
column5: our Nation was bound by the Articles of Confederation
column6: which began with the words
column7: "We the undersigned delegates." When Gouverneur Morris was asked to draft the preamble to our new Constitution
column8: he offered an important revision and opened with words that changed the course of our Nation and the history of the world: "We the people."

column1: By trusting the people
column2: our Founders wagered that a great and noble nation could be built on the liberty that resides in the hearts of all men and women. By trusting the people
column3: succeeding generations transformed our fragile
column4: young democracy into the most powerful nation on Earth and a beacon of hope for millions. And so long as we continue to trust the people
column5: our Nation will prosper
column6: our liberty will be secure
column7: and the state of our Union will remain strong.

column1: So tonight
column2: with confidence in freedom's power and trust in the people
column3: let us set forth to do their business. God bless America.@

column1: Barack Obama|Address Before a Joint Session of the Congress|2009-02-24|@Madam Speaker
column2: Mr. Vice President
column3: Members of Congress
column4: the First Lady of the United States--she's around here somewhere: I have come here tonight not only to address the distinguished men and women in this great Chamber
column5: but to speak frankly and directly to the men and women who sent us here.

column1: I know that for many Americans watching right now
column2: the state of our economy is a concern that rises above all others
column3: and rightly so. If you haven't been personally affected by this recession
column4: you probably know someone who has: a friend
column5: a neighbor
column6: a member of your family. You don't need to hear another list of statistics to know that our economy is in crisis
column7: because you live it every day. It's the worry you wake up with and the source of sleepless nights. It's the job you thought you'd retire from but now have lost
column8: the business you built your dreams upon that's now hanging by a thread
column9: the college acceptance letter your child had to put back in the envelope. The impact of this recession is real
column10: and it is everywhere.

column1: But while our economy may be weakened and our confidence shaken
column2: though we are living through difficult and uncertain times
column3: tonight I want every American to know this: We will rebuild
column4: we will recover
column5: and the United States of America will emerge stronger than before.

column1: The weight of this crisis will not determine the destiny of this Nation. The answers to our problems don't lie beyond our reach. They exist in our laboratories and our universities
column2: in our fields and our factories
column3: in the imaginations of our entrepreneurs and the pride of the hardest working people on Earth. Those qualities that have made America the greatest force of progress and prosperity in human history
column4: we still possess in ample measure. What is required now is for this country to pull together
column5: confront boldly the challenges we face
column6: and take responsibility for our future once more.

column1: Now
column2: if we're honest with ourselves
column3: we'll admit that for too long
column4: we have not always met these responsibilities as a Government or as a people. I say this not to lay blame or to look backwards
column5: but because it is only by understanding how we arrived at this moment that we'll be able to lift ourselves out of this predicament.

column1: The fact is
column2: our economy did not fall into decline overnight
column3: nor did all of our problems begin when the housing market collapsed or the stock market sank. We have known for decades that our survival depends on finding new sources of energy
column4: yet we import more oil today than ever before. The cost of health care eats up more and more of our savings each year
column5: yet we keep delaying reform. Our children will compete for jobs in a global economy that too many of our schools do not prepare them for. And though all these challenges went unsolved
column6: we still managed to spend more money and pile up more debt
column7: both as individuals and through our Government
column8: than ever before.

column1: In other words
