column2: we have lived through an era where too often short-term gains were prized over long-term prosperity
column3: where we failed to look beyond the next payment
column4: the next quarter
column5: or the next election. A surplus became an excuse to transfer wealth to the wealthy instead of an opportunity to invest in our future. Regulations were gutted for the sake of a quick profit at the expense of a healthy market. People bought homes they knew they couldn't afford from banks and lenders who pushed those bad loans anyway. And all the while
column6: critical debates and difficult decisions were put off for some other time
column7: on some other day. Well
column8: that day of reckoning has arrived
column9: and the time to take charge of our future is here.

column1: Now is the time to act boldly and wisely to not only revive this economy
column2: but to build a new foundation for lasting prosperity. Now is the time to jump-start job creation
column3: restart lending
column4: and invest in areas like energy
column5: health care
column6: and education that will grow our economy
column7: even as we make hard choices to bring our deficit down. That is what my economic agenda is designed to do
column8: and that is what I'd like to talk to you about tonight. It's an agenda that begins with jobs.

column1: As soon as I took office
column2: I asked this Congress to send me a recovery plan by President's Day that would put people back to work and put money in their pockets
column3: not because I believe in bigger Government--I don't--not because I'm not mindful of the massive debt we've inherited--I am. I called for action because the failure to do so would have cost more jobs and caused more hardship. In fact
column4: a failure to act would have worsened our long-term deficit by assuring weak economic growth for years. And that's why I pushed for quick action. And tonight I am grateful that this Congress delivered and pleased to say that the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act is now law.

column1: Over the next 2 years
column2: this plan will save or create 3.5 million jobs. More than 90 percent of these jobs will be in the private sector: jobs rebuilding our roads and bridges
column3: constructing wind turbines and solar panels
column4: laying broadband and expanding mass transit.

column1: Because of this plan
column2: there are teachers who can now keep their jobs and educate our kids
column3: health care professionals can continue caring for our sick. There are 57 police officers who are still on the streets of Minneapolis tonight because this plan prevented the layoffs their department was about to make. Because of this plan
column4: 95 percent of working households in America will receive a tax cut; a tax cut that you will see in your paychecks beginning on April 1st. Because of this plan
column5: families who are struggling to pay tuition costs will receive a $2
column6: 500 tax credit for all 4 years of college
column7: and Americans who have lost their jobs in this recession will be able to receive extended unemployment benefits and continued health care coverage to help them weather this storm.

column1: Now
column2: I know there are some in this Chamber and watching at home who are skeptical of whether this plan will work
column3: and I understand that skepticism. Here in Washington
column4: we've all seen how quickly good intentions can turn into broken promises and wasteful spending. And with a plan of this scale comes enormous responsibility to get it right.

column1: And that's why I've asked Vice President Biden to lead a tough
column2: unprecedented oversight effort; because nobody messes with Joe. I--am I right? They don't mess with him. I have told each of my Cabinet
column3: as well as mayors and Governors across the country
column4: that they will be held accountable by me and the American people for every dollar they spend. I've appointed a proven and aggressive Inspector General to ferret out any and all cases of waste and fraud. And we have created a new web site called recovery.gov
column5: so that every American can find out how and where their money is being spent.

column1: So the recovery plan we passed is the first step in getting our economy back on track. But it is just the first step. Because even if we manage this plan flawlessly
column2: there will be no real recovery unless we clean up the credit crisis that has severely weakened our financial system.

column1: I want to speak plainly and candidly about this issue tonight
column2: because every American should know that it directly affects you and your family's well-being. You should also know that the money you've deposited in banks across the country is safe
column3: your insurance is secure
column4: you can rely on the continued operation of our financial system. That's not the source of concern. The concern is that if we do not restart lending in this country
column5: our recovery will be choked off before it even begins.

column1: You see
column2: the flow of credit is the lifeblood of our economy. The ability to get a loan is how you finance the purchase of everything from a home to a car to a college education
column3: how stores stock their shelves
column4: farms buy equipment
column5: and businesses make payroll.

column1: But credit has stopped flowing the way it should. Too many bad loans from the housing crisis have made their way onto the books of too many banks. And with so much debt and so little confidence
column2: these banks are now fearful of lending out any more money to households
column3: to businesses
column4: or even to each other. And when there is no lending
column5: families can't afford to buy homes or cars
column6: so businesses are forced to make layoffs. Our economy suffers even more
column7: and credit dries up even further. That is why this administration is moving swiftly and aggressively to break this destructive cycle
column8: to restore confidence
column9: and restart lending. And we will do so in several ways.

column1: First
column2: we are creating a new lending fund that represents the largest effort ever to help provide auto loans
column3: college loans
column4: and small-business loans to the consumers and entrepreneurs who keep this economy running.

column1: Second
column2: we have launched a housing plan that will help responsible families facing the threat of foreclosure lower their monthly payments and refinance their mortgages. It's a plan that won't help speculators or that neighbor down the street who bought a house he could never hope to afford
column3: but it will help millions of Americans who are struggling with declining home values; Americans who will now be able to take advantage of the lower interest rates that this plan has already helped to bring about. In fact
column4: the average family who refinances today can save nearly $2
column5: 000 per year on their mortgage.

column1: Third
column2: we will act with the full force of the Federal Government to ensure that the major banks that Americans depend on have enough confidence and enough money to lend even in more difficult times. And when we learn that a major bank has serious problems
column3: we will hold accountable those responsible
column4: force the necessary adjustments
column5: provide the support to clean up their balance sheets
column6: and assure the continuity of a strong
column7: viable institution that can serve our people and our economy.

column1: Now
column2: I understand that on any given day
column3: Wall Street may be more comforted by an approach that gives bank bailouts with no strings attached and that holds nobody accountable for their reckless decisions. But such an approach won't solve the problem
column4: and our goal is to quicken the day when we restart lending to the American people and American business and end this crisis once and for all.

column1: And I intend to hold these banks fully accountable for the assistance they receive
column2: and this time
column3: they will have to clearly demonstrate how taxpayer dollars result in more lending for the American taxpayer. This time
column4: CEOs won't be able to use taxpayer money to pad their paychecks or buy fancy drapes or disappear on a private jet. Those days are over.

column1: Still
column2: this plan will require significant resources from the Federal Government--and
column3: yes
column4: probably more than we've already set aside. But while the cost of action will be great
column5: I can assure you that the cost of inaction will be far greater
column6: for it could result in an economy that sputters along for not months or years
column7: but perhaps a decade. That would be worse for our deficit
column8: worse for business
column9: worse for you
column10: and worse for the next generation. And I refuse to let that happen.

column1: Now
column2: I understand that when the last administration asked this Congress to provide assistance for struggling banks
column3: Democrats and Republicans alike were infuriated by the mismanagement and the results that followed. So were the American taxpayers; so was I. So I know how unpopular it is to be seen as helping banks right now
column4: especially when everyone is suffering in part from their bad decisions. I promise you
column5: I get it.

column1: But I also know that in a time of crisis
column2: we cannot afford to govern out of anger or yield to the politics of the moment. My job--our job is to solve the problem. Our job is to govern with a sense of responsibility. I will not send--I will not spend a single penny for the purpose of rewarding a single Wall Street executive
column3: but I will do whatever it takes to help the small business that can't pay its workers or the family that has saved and still can't get a mortgage. That's what this is about. It's not about helping banks; it's about helping people.

column1: It's not about helping banks; it's about helping people. Because when credit is available again
column2: that young family can finally buy a new home. And then some company will hire workers to build it. And then those workers will have money to spend. And if they can get a loan too
column3: maybe they'll finally buy that car or open their own business. Investors will return to the market
column4: and American families will see their retirement secured once more. Slowly but surely
column5: confidence will return and our economy will recover.

column1: So I ask this Congress to join me in doing whatever proves necessary
column2: because we cannot consign our Nation to an open-ended recession. And to ensure that a crisis of this magnitude never happens again
column3: I ask Congress to move quickly on legislation that will finally reform our outdated regulatory system. It is time to put in place tough
column4: new
column5: commonsense rules of the road so that our financial market rewards drive and innovation
column6: and punishes shortcuts and abuse.

column1: The recovery plan and the financial stability plan are the immediate steps we're taking to revive our economy in the short term. But the only way to fully restore America's economic strength is to make the long-term investments that will lead to new jobs
column2: new industries
column3: and a renewed ability to compete with the rest of the world. The only way this century will be another American century is if we confront at last the price of our dependence on oil and the high cost of health care
column4: the schools that aren't preparing our children and the mountain of debt they stand to inherit. That is our responsibility.

column1: In the next few days
column2: I will submit a budget to Congress. So often
column3: we've come to view these documents as simply numbers on a page or a laundry list of programs. I see this document differently. I see it as a vision for America
column4: as a blueprint for our future.

column1: My budget does not attempt to solve every problem or address every issue. It reflects the stark reality of what we've inherited
column2: a trillion-dollar deficit
column3: a financial crisis
column4: and a costly recession. Given these realities
column5: everyone in this Chamber
column6: Democrats and Republicans
column7: will have to sacrifice some worthy priorities for which there are no dollars. And that includes me. But that does not mean we can afford to ignore our long-term challenges. I reject the view that says our problems will simply take care of themselves
column8: that says Government has no role in laying the foundation for our common prosperity.

column1: For history tells a different story. History reminds us that at every moment of economic upheaval and transformation
column2: this Nation has responded with bold action and big ideas. In the midst of Civil War
column3: we laid railroad tracks from one coast to another that spurred commerce and industry. From the turmoil of the Industrial Revolution came a system of public high schools that prepared our citizens for a new age. In the wake of war and depression
column4: the GI bill sent a generation to college and created the largest middle class in history. And a twilight struggle for freedom led to a nation of highways
column5: an American on the Moon
column6: and an explosion of technology that still shapes our world. In each case
column7: Government didn't supplant private enterprise; it catalyzed private enterprise. It created the conditions for thousands of entrepreneurs and new businesses to adapt and to thrive.

column1: We are a nation that has seen promise amid peril and claimed opportunity from ordeal. Now we must be that nation again
column2: and that is why
column3: even as it cuts back on programs we don't need
column4: the budget I submit will invest in the three areas that are absolutely critical to our economic future: energy
column5: health care
column6: and education.

column1: It begins with energy. We know the country that harnesses the power of clean
column2: renewable energy will lead the 21st century. And yet
column3: it is China that has launched the largest effort in history to make their economy energy efficient. We invented solar technology
column4: but we've fallen behind countries like Germany and Japan in producing it. New plug-in hybrids roll off our assembly lines
column5: but they will run on batteries made in Korea. Well
column6: I do not accept a future where the jobs and industries of tomorrow take root beyond our borders
column7: and I know you don't either. It is time for America to lead again.

column1: Thanks to our recovery plan
column2: we will double this Nation's supply of renewable energy in the next 3 years. We've also made the largest investment in basic research funding in American history
column3: an investment that will spur not only new discoveries in energy but breakthroughs in medicine and science and technology.

column1: We will soon lay down thousands of miles of power lines that can carry new energy to cities and towns across this country. And we will put Americans to work making our homes and buildings more efficient so that we can save billions of dollars on our energy bills.
But to truly transform our economy
column2: to protect our security
column3: and save our planet from the ravages of climate change
column4: we need to ultimately make clean
column5: renewable energy the profitable kind of energy. So I ask this Congress to send me legislation that places a market-based cap on carbon pollution and drives the production of more renewable energy in America. That's what we need. And to support that innovation
column6: we will invest $15 billion a year to develop technologies like wind power and solar power
column7: advanced biofuels
column8: clean coal
column9: and more efficient cars and trucks built right here in America.

column1: Speaking of our auto industry
column2: everyone recognizes that years of bad decisionmaking and a global recession have pushed our automakers to the brink. We should not
column3: and will not
column4: protect them from their own bad practices. But we are committed to the goal of a retooled
column5: reimagined auto industry that can compete and win. Millions of jobs depend on it; scores of communities depend on it. And I believe the Nation that invented the automobile cannot walk away from it.

column1: Now
column2: none of this will come without cost
column3: nor will it be easy. But this is America. We don't do what's easy. We do what's necessary to move this country forward.

column1: And for that same reason
column2: we must also address the crushing cost of health care. This is a cost that now causes a bankruptcy in America every 30 seconds. By the end of the year
column3: it could cause 1.5 million Americans to lose their homes. In the last 8 years
column4: premiums have grown four times faster than wages. And in each of these years
column5: 1 million more Americans have lost their health insurance. It is one of the major reasons why small businesses close their doors and corporations ship jobs overseas. And it's one of the largest and fastest growing parts of our budget. Given these facts
column6: we can no longer afford to put health care reform on hold. We can't afford to do it. It's time.

column1: Already
column2: we've done more to advance the cause of health care reform in the last 30 days than we've done in the last decade. When it was days old
column3: this Congress passed a law to provide and protect health insurance for 11 million American children whose parents work full time. Our recovery plan will invest in electronic health records
column4: a new technology that will reduce errors
column5: bring down costs
column6: ensure privacy
column7: and save lives. It will launch a new effort to conquer a disease that has touched the life of nearly every American
column8: including me
column9: by seeking a cure for cancer in our time. And it makes the largest investment ever in preventive care
column10: because that's one of the best ways to keep our people healthy and our costs under control.

column1: This budget builds on these reforms. It includes a historic commitment to comprehensive health care reform
column2: a down payment on the principle that we must have quality
column3: affordable health care for every American. It's a commitment that's paid for in part by efficiencies in our system that are long overdue. And it's a step we must take if we hope to bring down our deficit in the years to come.

column1: Now
column2: there will be many different opinions and ideas about how to achieve reform
column3: and that's why I'm bringing together businesses and workers
column4: doctors and health care providers
column5: Democrats and Republicans to begin work on this issue next week.

column1: I suffer no illusions that this will be an easy process. Once again
column2: it will be hard. But I also know that nearly a century after Teddy Roosevelt first called for reform
column3: the cost of our health care has weighed down our economy and our conscience long enough. So let there be no doubt: Health care reform cannot wait
column4: it must not wait
column5: and it will not wait another year.

column1: The third challenge we must address is the urgent need to expand the promise of education in America. In a global economy where the most valuable skill you can sell is your knowledge
column2: a good education is no longer just a pathway to opportunity
column3: it is a prerequisite. Right now
column4: three-quarters of the fastest growing occupations require more than a high school diploma. And yet
column5: just over half of our citizens have that level of education. We have one of the highest high school dropout rates of any industrialized nation
column6: and half of the students who begin college never finish.

column1: This is a prescription for economic decline
column2: because we know the countries that out-teach us today will outcompete us tomorrow. That is why it will be the goal of this administration to ensure that every child has access to a complete and competitive education
column3: from the day they are born to the day they begin a career. That is a promise we have to make to the children of America.

column1: Already
column2: we've made historic investment in education through the economic recovery plan. We've dramatically expanded early childhood education and will continue to improve its quality
column3: because we know that the most formative learning comes in those first years of life. We've made college affordable for nearly 7 million more students--7 million. And we have provided the resources necessary to prevent painful cuts and teacher layoffs that would set back our children's progress.

column1: But we know that our schools don't just need more resources
column2: they need more reform. And that is why this budget creates new teachers--new incentives for teacher performance
column3: pathways for advancement
column4: and rewards for success. We'll invest in innovative programs that are already helping schools meet high standards and close achievement gaps
column5: and we will expand our commitment to charter schools.

column1: It is our responsibility as lawmakers and as educators to make this system work. But it is the responsibility of every citizen to participate in it. So tonight I ask every American to commit to at least 1 year or more of higher education or career training. This can be community college or a 4-year school
column2: vocational training or an apprenticeship. But whatever the training may be
column3: every American will need to get more than a high school diploma.

column1: And dropping out of high school is no longer an option. It's not just quitting on yourself
column2: it's quitting on your country
column3: and this country needs and values the talents of every American. That's why we will support--we will provide the support necessary for all young Americans to complete college and meet a new goal. By 2020
column4: America will once again have the highest proportion of college graduates in the world. That is a goal we can meet. That's a goal we can meet.

column1: Now
column2: I know that the price of tuition is higher than ever
column3: which is why if you are willing to volunteer in your neighborhood or give back to your community or serve your country
column4: we will make sure that you can afford a higher education. And to encourage a renewed spirit of national service for this and future generations
column5: I ask Congress to send me the bipartisan legislation that bears the name of Senator Orrin Hatch
column6: as well as an American who has never stopped asking what he can do for his country
column7: Senator Edward Kennedy.

column1: These education policies will open the doors of opportunity for our children
column2: but it is up to us to ensure they walk through them. In the end
column3: there is no program or policy that can substitute for a parent
column4: for a mother or father who will attend those parent-teacher conferences or help with homework or turn off the TV
column5: put away the video games
column6: read to their child. I speak to you not just as a President
column7: but as a father
column8: when I say that responsibility for our children's education must begin at home. That is not a Democratic issue or a Republican issue; that's an American issue.

column1: There is
column2: of course
column3: another responsibility we have to our children. And that's the responsibility to ensure that we do not pass on to them a debt they cannot pay. That is critical.  I agree
column4: absolutely. See
column5: I know we can get some consensus in here.  With the deficit we inherited
column6: the cost of the crisis we face
column7: and the long-term challenges we must meet
column8: it has never been more important to ensure that as our economy recovers
column9: we do what it takes to bring this deficit down. That is critical.

column1: Now
column2: I'm proud that we passed a recovery plan free of earmarks
column3: and I want to pass a budget next year that ensures that each dollar we spend reflects only our most important national priorities.

column1: And yesterday I held a fiscal summit where I pledged to cut the deficit in half by the end of my first term in office. My administration has also begun to go line by line through the Federal budget in order to eliminate wasteful and ineffective programs. As you can imagine
column2: this is a process that will take some time. But we have already identified $2 trillion in savings over the next decade.

column1: In this budget
column2: we will end education programs that don't work and end direct payments to large agribusiness that don't need them. We'll eliminate the no-bid contracts that have wasted billions in Iraq and reform our defense budget so that we're not paying for cold war-era weapons systems we don't use. We will root out the waste and fraud and abuse in our Medicare program that doesn't make our seniors any healthier. We will restore a sense of fairness and balance to our Tax Code by finally ending the tax breaks for corporations that ship our jobs overseas.

column1: In order to save our children from a future of debt
column2: we will also end the tax breaks for the wealthiest 2 percent of Americans. Now
column3: let me be clear--let me be absolutely clear
column4: because I know you'll end up hearing some of the same claims that rolling back these tax breaks means a massive tax increase on the American people: If your family earns less than $250
column5: 000 a year
column6: a quarter million dollars a year
column7: you will not see your taxes increased a single dime. I repeat: Not one single dime. In fact--not a dime--in fact
column8: the recovery plan provides a tax cut--that's right
column9: a tax cut--for 95 percent of working families. And by the way
column10: these checks are on the way.

column1: Now
column2: to preserve our long-term fiscal health
column3: we must also address the growing costs in Medicare and Social Security. Comprehensive health care reform is the best way to strengthen Medicare for years to come. And we must also begin a conversation on how to do the same for Social Security
column4: while creating tax-free universal savings accounts for all Americans.

column1: Finally
column2: because we're also suffering from a deficit of trust
column3: I am committed to restoring a sense of honesty and accountability to our budget. That is why this budget looks ahead 10 years and accounts for spending that was left out under the old rules. And for the first time
column4: that includes the full cost of fighting in Iraq and Afghanistan. For 7 years
column5: we have been a nation at war. No longer will we hide its price.

column1: Along with our outstanding national security team
column2: I'm now carefully reviewing our policies in both wars
column3: and I will soon announce a way forward in Iraq that leaves Iraq to its people and responsibly ends this war.

column1: And with our friends and allies
column2: we will forge a new and comprehensive strategy for Afghanistan and Pakistan to defeat Al Qaida and combat extremism
column3: because I will not allow terrorists to plot against the American people from safe havens halfway around the world. We will not allow it.

column1: As we meet here tonight
column2: our men and women in uniform stand watch abroad and more are readying to deploy. To each and every one of them and to the families who bear the quiet burden of their absence
column3: Americans are united in sending one message: We honor your service; we are inspired by your sacrifice; and you have our unyielding support.

column1: To relieve the strain on our forces
column2: my budget increases the number of our soldiers and marines. And to keep our sacred trust with those who serve
column3: we will raise their pay and give our veterans the expanded health care and benefits that they have earned.

column1: To overcome extremism
column2: we must also be vigilant in upholding the values our troops defend
column3: because there is no force in the world more powerful than the example of America. And that is why I have ordered the closing of the detention center at Guantanamo Bay and will seek swift and certain justice for captured terrorists. Because living our values doesn't make us weaker
column4: it makes us safer and it makes us stronger. And that is why I can stand here tonight and say without exception or equivocation that the United States of America does not torture. We can make that commitment here tonight.

column1: In words and deeds
column2: we are showing the world that a new era of engagement has begun. For we know that America cannot meet the threats of this century alone
column3: but the world cannot meet them without America. We cannot shun the negotiating table
column4: nor ignore the foes or forces that could do us harm. We are instead called to move forward with the sense of confidence and candor that serious times demand.

column1: To seek progress towards a secure and lasting peace between Israel and her neighbors
column2: we have appointed an envoy to sustain our effort. To meet the challenges of the 21st century--from terrorism to nuclear proliferation
column3: from pandemic disease to cyber threats to crushing poverty--we will strengthen old alliances
column4: forge new ones
column5: and use all elements of our national power.

column1: And to respond to an economic crisis that is global in scope
column2: we are working with the nations of the G-20 to restore confidence in our financial system
column3: avoid the possibility of escalating protectionism
column4: and spur demand for American goods in markets across the globe. For the world depends on us having a strong economy
column5: just as our economy depends on the strength of the world's.

column1: As we stand at this crossroads of history
column2: the eyes of all people in all nations are once again upon us
column3: watching to see what we do with this moment
column4: waiting for us to lead. Those of us gathered here tonight have been called to govern in extraordinary times. It is a tremendous burden
column5: but also a great privilege
column6: one that has been entrusted to few generations of Americans. For in our hands lies the ability to shape our world for good or for ill.

column1: I know that it's easy to lose sight of this truth
column2: to become cynical and doubtful
column3: consumed with the petty and the trivial. But in my life
column4: I have also learned that hope is found in unlikely places
column5: that inspiration often comes not from those with the most power or celebrity
column6: but from the dreams and aspirations of ordinary Americans who are anything but ordinary.

column1: I think of Leonard Abess
column2: a bank president from Miami who reportedly cashed out of his company
column3: took a $60 million bonus
column4: and gave it out to all 399 people who worked for him
column5: plus another 72 who used to work for him. He didn't tell anyone
column6: but when the local newspaper found out
column7: he simply said
column8: "I knew some of these people since I was 7 years old. It didn't feel right getting the money myself."

column1: I think about Greensburg
column2: Kansas
column3: a town that was completely destroyed by a tornado
column4: but is being rebuilt by its residents as a global example of how clean energy can power an entire community
column5: how it can bring jobs and businesses to a place where piles of bricks and rubble once lay. "The tragedy was terrible
column6: said one of the men who helped them rebuild. But the folks here know that it also provided an incredible opportunity."

column1: I think about Ty'Sheoma Bethea
column2: the young girl from that school I visited in Dillon
column3: South Carolina
column4: a place where the ceilings leak
column5: the paint peels off the walls
column6: and they have to stop teaching six times a day because the train barrels by their classroom. She had been told that her school is hopeless
column7: but the other day after class she went to the public library and typed up a letter to the people sitting in this Chamber. She even asked her principal for the money to buy a stamp. The letter asks us for help and says: "We are just students trying to become lawyers
column8: doctors
column9: Congressmen like yourself
column10: and one day President
column11: so we can make a change to not just the State of South Carolina
column12: but also the world. We are not quitters." That's what she said: "We are not quitters."

column1: These words and these stories tell us something about the spirit of the people who sent us here. They tell us that even in the most trying times
column2: amid the most difficult circumstances
column3: there is a generosity
column4: a resilience
column5: a decency
column6: and a determination that perseveres
column7: a willingness to take responsibility for our future and for posterity. Their resolve must be our inspiration. Their concerns must be our cause. And we must show them and all our people that we are equal to the task before us.

column1: I know--look
column2: I know that we haven't agreed on every issue thus far.  There are surely times in the future where we will part ways. But I also know that every American who is sitting here tonight loves this country and wants it to succeed. I know that. That must be the starting point for every debate we have in the coming months and where we return after those debates are done. That is the foundation on which the American people expect us to build common ground.

column1: And if we do
column2: if we come together and lift this Nation from the depths of this crisis
column3: if we put our people back to work and restart the engine of our prosperity
column4: if we confront without fear the challenges of our time and summon that enduring spirit of an America that does not quit
column5: then someday years from now our children can tell their children that this was the time when we performed
column6: in the words that are carved into this very Chamber
column7: "something worthy to be remembered."

column1: Thank you. God bless you
column2: and may God bless the United States of America. Thank you.@

column1: Barack Obama|Address Before a Joint Session of the Congress on the State of the Union|2010-01-27|@Madam Speaker
column2: Vice President Biden
column3: Members of Congress
column4: distinguished guests
column5: and fellow Americans: Our Constitution declares that from time to time
column6: the President shall give to Congress information about the state of our Union. For 220 years
column7: our leaders have fulfilled this duty. They've done so during periods of prosperity and tranquility
column8: and they've done so in the midst of war and depression
column9: at moments of great strife and great struggle.

column1: It's tempting to look back on these moments and assume that our progress was inevitable
column2: that America was always destined to succeed. But when the Union was turned back at Bull Run and the Allies first landed at Omaha Beach
column3: victory was very much in doubt. When the market crashed on Black Tuesday and marchers were beaten on Bloody Sunday
column4: the future was anything but certain. These were the times that tested the courage of our convictions and the strength of our Union. And despite all our divisions and disagreements
column5: our hesitations and our fears
column6: America prevailed because we chose to move forward as one Nation
column7: as one people. Again
column8: we are tested. And again
column9: we must answer history's call.

column1: One year ago
column2: I took office amid two wars
column3: an economy rocked by a severe recession
column4: a financial system on the verge of collapse
column5: and a Government deeply in debt. Experts from across the political spectrum warned that if we did not act
column6: we might face a second depression. So we acted
column7: immediately and aggressively. And 1 year later
column8: the worst of the storm has passed.

column1: But the devastation remains. One in 10 Americans still cannot find work. Many businesses have shuttered. Home values have declined. Small towns and rural communities have been hit especially hard. And for those who'd already known poverty
column2: life's become that much harder.

column1: This recession has also compounded the burdens that America's families have been dealing with for decades: the burden of working harder and longer for less
column2: of being unable to save enough to retire or help kids with college.

column1: So I know the anxieties that are out there right now. They're not new. These struggles are the reason I ran for President. These struggles are what I've witnessed for years
column2: in places like Elkhart
column3: Indiana; Galesburg
column4: Illinois. I hear about them in the letters that I read each night. The toughest to read are those written by children asking why they have to move from their home
column5: asking when their mom or dad will be able to go back to work.

column1: For these Americans and so many others
column2: change has not come fast enough. Some are frustrated
column3: some are angry. They don't understand why it seems like bad behavior on Wall Street is rewarded
column4: but hard work on Main Street isn't
column5: or why Washington has been unable or unwilling to solve any of our problems. They're tired of the partisanship and the shouting and the pettiness. They know we can't afford it. Not now.

column1: So we face big and difficult challenges. And what the American people hope
column2: what they deserve
column3: is for all of us
column4: Democrats and Republicans
column5: to work through our differences
column6: to overcome the numbing weight of our politics. For while the people who sent us here have different backgrounds
column7: different stories
column8: different beliefs
column9: the anxieties they face are the same. The aspirations they hold are shared: a job that pays the bills
column10: a chance to get ahead
column11: most of all
column12: the ability to give their children a better life.

column1: And you know what else they share? They share a stubborn resilience in the face of adversity. After one of the most difficult years in our history
column2: they remain busy building cars and teaching kids
column3: starting businesses and going back to school. They're coaching Little League and helping their neighbors. One woman wrote to me and said
column4: "We are strained but hopeful
column5: struggling but encouraged."

column1: It's because of this spirit
column2: this great decency and great strength
column3: that I have never been more hopeful about America's future than I am tonight. Despite our hardships
column4: our Union is strong. We do not give up. We do not quit. We do not allow fear or division to break our spirit. In this new decade
column5: it's time the American people get a Government that matches their decency
column6: that embodies their strength. And tonight I'd like to talk about how together we can deliver on that promise.

column1: It begins with our economy. Our most urgent task upon taking office was to shore up the same banks that helped cause this crisis. It was not easy to do. And if there's one thing that has unified Democrats and Republicans and everybody in between
column2: it's that we all hated the bank bailout. I hated it. I hated it; you hated it. It was about as popular as a root canal.

column1: But when I ran for President
column2: I promised I wouldn't just do what was popular; I would do what was necessary. And if we had allowed the meltdown of the financial system
column3: unemployment might be double what it is today. More businesses would certainly have closed. More homes would have surely been lost.

column1: So I supported the last administration's efforts to create the financial rescue program. And when we took that program over
column2: we made it more transparent and more accountable. And as a result
column3: the markets are now stabilized
column4: and we've recovered most of the money we spent on the banks--most but not all.

column1: To recover the rest
column2: I've proposed a fee on the biggest banks. Now
column3: I know Wall Street isn't keen on this idea. But if these firms can afford to hand out big bonuses again
column4: they can afford a modest fee to pay back the taxpayers who rescued them in their time of need.

column1: Now
column2: as we stabilized the financial system
column3: we also took steps to get our economy growing again
column4: save as many jobs as possible
column5: and help Americans who had become unemployed. That's why we extended or increased unemployment benefits for more than 18 million Americans
column6: made health insurance 65 percent cheaper for families who get their coverage through COBRA
column7: and passed 25 different tax cuts.

column1: Now
column2: let me repeat: We cut taxes. We cut taxes for 95 percent of working families. We cut taxes for small businesses. We cut taxes for first-time home buyers. We cut taxes for parents trying to care for their children. We cut taxes for 8 million Americans paying for college.  I thought I'd get some applause on that one.

column1: As a result
column2: millions of Americans had more to spend on gas and food and other necessities
column3: all of which helped businesses keep more workers. And we haven't raised income taxes by a single dime on a single person--not a single dime.

column1: Now
column2: because of the steps we took
column3: there are about 2 million Americans working right now who would otherwise be unemployed. Two hundred thousand work in construction and clean energy. Three hundred thousand are teachers and other education workers. Tens of thousands are cops
column4: firefighters
column5: correctional officers
column6: first-responders. And we're on track to add another 1 1/2 million jobs to this total by the end of the year.

column1: The plan that has made all of this possible
column2: from the tax cuts to the jobs
column3: is the Recovery Act. That's right
column4: the Recovery Act
column5: also known as the stimulus bill. Economists on the left and the right say this bill has helped save jobs and avert disaster. But you don't have to take their word for it. Talk to the small business in Phoenix that will triple its workforce because of the Recovery Act. Talk to the window manufacturer in Philadelphia who said he used to be skeptical about the Recovery Act
column6: until he had to add two more work shifts just because of the business it created. Talk to the single teacher raising two kids who was told by her principal in the last week of school that because of the Recovery Act
column7: she wouldn't be laid off after all.

column1: There are stories like this all across America. And after 2 years of recession
column2: the economy is growing again. Retirement funds have started to gain back some of their value. Businesses are beginning to invest again
column3: and slowly some are starting to hire again.

column1: But I realize that for every success story
column2: there are other stories
column3: of men and women who wake up with the anguish of not knowing where their next paycheck will come from
column4: who send out resumes week after week and hear nothing in response. That is why jobs must be our number-one focus in 2010
column5: and that's why I'm calling for a new jobs bill tonight.

column1: Now
column2: the true engine of job creation in this country will always be America's businesses.  I agree
column3: absolutely. But Government can create the conditions necessary for businesses to expand and hire more workers. We should start where most new jobs do
column4: in small businesses
column5: companies that begin when an entrepreneur takes a chance on a dream or a worker decides it's time she became her own boss. Through sheer grit and determination
column6: these companies have weathered the recession
column7: and they're ready to grow. But when you talk to small-business owners in places like Allentown
column8: Pennsylvania
column9: or Elyria
column10: Ohio
column11: you find out that even though banks on Wall Street are lending again
column12: they're mostly lending to bigger companies. Financing remains difficult for small-business owners across the country
column13: even those that are making a profit.

column1: So tonight I'm proposing that we take $30 billion of the money Wall Street banks have repaid and use it to help community banks give small businesses the credit they need to stay afloat. I'm also proposing a new small business tax credit
column2: one that will go to over 1 million small businesses who hire new workers or raise wages. While we're at it
column3: let's also eliminate all capital gains taxes on small-business investment and provide a tax incentive for all large businesses and all small businesses to invest in new plants and equipment.

column1: Next
column2: we can put Americans to work today building the infrastructure of tomorrow. From the first railroads to the Interstate Highway System
column3: our Nation has always been built to compete. There's no reason Europe or China should have the fastest trains or the new factories that manufacture clean energy products. Tomorrow I'll visit Tampa
column4: Florida
column5: where workers will soon break ground on a new high-speed railroad funded by the Recovery Act. There are projects like that all across this country that will create jobs and help move our Nation's goods
column6: services
column7: and information.

column1: We should put more Americans to work building clean energy facilities and give rebates to Americans who make their homes more energy efficient
column2: which supports clean energy jobs. And to encourage these and other businesses to stay within our borders
column3: it is time to finally slash the tax breaks for companies that ship our jobs overseas and give those tax breaks to companies that create jobs right here in the United States of America.

column1: Now
column2: the House has passed a jobs bill that includes some of these steps. As the first order of business this year
column3: I urge the Senate to do the same
column4: and I know they will. They will. People are out of work. They're hurting. They need our help. And I want a jobs bill on my desk without delay.

column1: But the truth is
column2: these steps won't make up for the 7 million jobs that we've lost over the last 2 years. The only way to move to full employment is to lay a new foundation for long-term economic growth and finally address the problems that America's families have confronted for years.

column1: We can't afford another so-called economic expansion like the one from the last decade
column2: what some call the "lost decade
column3:
where jobs grew more slowly than during any prior expansion, where the income of the average American household declined while the cost of health care and tuition reached record highs, where prosperity was built on a housing bubble and financial speculation.
From the day I took office, I've been told that addressing our larger challenges is too ambitious; such an effort would be too contentious. I've been told that our political system is too gridlocked and that we should just put things on hold for a while. For those who make these claims, I have one simple question: How long should we wait? How long should America put its future on hold?
You see, Washington has been telling us to wait for decades, even as the problems have grown worse. Meanwhile, China's not waiting to revamp its economy. Germany's not waiting. India's not waiting. These nations are--they're not standing still. These nations aren't playing for second place. They're putting more emphasis on math and science. They're rebuilding their infrastructure. They're making serious investments in clean energy because they want those jobs. Well, I do not accept second place for the United States of America. As hard as it may be, as uncomfortable and contentious as the debates may become, it's time to get serious about fixing the problems that are hampering our growth.
Now, one place to start is serious financial reform. Look, I am not interested in punishing banks. I'm interested in protecting our economy. A strong, healthy financial market makes it possible for businesses to access credit and create new jobs. It channels the savings of families into investments that raise incomes. But that can only happen if we guard against the same recklessness that nearly brought down our entire economy.
We need to make sure consumers and middle class families have the information they need to make financial decisions. We can't allow financial institutions, including those that take your deposits, to take risks that threaten the whole economy.
Now, the House has already passed financial reform with many of these changes, and the lobbyists are trying to kill it. But we cannot let them win this fight. And if the bill that ends up on my desk does not meet the test of real reform, I will send it back until we get it right. We've got to get it right.
Next, we need to encourage American innovation. Last year, we made the largest investment in basic research funding in history, an investment that could lead to the world's cheapest solar cells or treatment that kills cancer cells, but leaves healthy ones untouched. And no area is more ripe for such innovation than energy. You can see the results of last year's investments in clean energy in the North Carolina company that will create 1,200 jobs nationwide helping to make advanced batteries or in the California business that will put a thousand people to work making solar panels.
But to create more of these clean energy jobs, we need more production, more efficiency, more incentives. And that means building a new generation of safe, clean nuclear power plants in this country. It means making tough decisions about opening new offshore areas for oil and gas development. It means continued investment in advanced biofuels and clean coal technologies. And yes, it means passing a comprehensive energy and climate bill with incentives that will finally make clean energy the profitable kind of energy in America. Now, I am grateful to the House for passing such a bill last year. And this year, I'm eager to help advance the bipartisan effort in the Senate.
I know there have been questions about whether we can afford such changes in a tough economy. I know that there are those who disagree with the overwhelming scientific evidence on climate change. But here's the thing: Even if you doubt the evidence, providing incentives for energy efficiency and clean energy are the right thing to do for our future, because the nation that leads the clean energy economy will be the nation that leads the global economy. And America must be that nation.
Third, we need to export more of our goods, because the more products we make and sell to other countries, the more jobs we support right here in America. So tonight we set a new goal: We will double our exports over the next 5 years, an increase that will support 2 million jobs in America. To help meet this goal, we're launching a National Export Initiative that will help farmers and small businesses increase their exports and reform export controls consistent with national security.
We have to seek new markets aggressively, just as our competitors are. If America sits on the sidelines while other nations sign trade deals, we will lose the chance to create jobs on our shores. But realizing those benefits also means enforcing those agreements so our trading partners play by the rules. And that's why we'll continue to shape a Doha trade agreement that opens global markets and why we will strengthen our trade relations in Asia and with key partners like South Korea and Panama and Colombia.
Fourth, we need to invest in the skills and education of our people. Now, this year, we've broken through the stalemate between left and right by launching a national competition to improve our schools. And the idea here is simple: Instead of rewarding failure, we only reward success. Instead of funding the status quo, we only invest in reform, reform that raises student achievement, inspires students to excel in math and science, and turns around failing schools that steal the future of too many young Americans, from rural communities to the inner city. In the 21st century, the best antipoverty program around is a world-class education. And in this country, the success of our children cannot depend more on where they live than on their potential. When we renew the Elementary and Secondary Education Act, we will work with Congress to expand these reforms to all 50 States.
Still, in this economy, a high school diploma no longer guarantees a good job. That's why I urge the Senate to follow the House and pass a bill that will revitalize our community colleges, which are a career pathway to the children of so many working families.
To make college more affordable, this bill will finally end the unwarranted taxpayer subsidies that go to banks for student loans. Instead, let's take that money and give families a $10,000 tax credit for 4 years of college and increase Pell grants. And let's tell another 1 million students that when they graduate, they will be required to pay only 10 percent of their income on student loans and all of their debt will be forgiven after 20 years and forgiven after 10 years if they choose a career in public service, because in the United States of America, no one should go broke because they chose to go to college. And by the way, it's time for colleges and universities to get serious about cutting their own costs, because they too have a responsibility to help solve this problem.
Now, the price of college tuition is just one of the burdens facing the middle class. That's why last year, I asked Vice President Biden to chair a task force on middle class families. That's why we're nearly doubling the childcare tax credit and making it easier to save for retirement by giving access to every worker a retirement account and expanding the tax credit for those who start a nest egg. That's why we're working to lift the value of a family's single largest investment, their home. The steps we took last year to shore up the housing market have allowed millions of Americans to take out new loans and save an average of $1,500 on mortgage payments. This year, we will step up refinancing so that homeowners can move into more affordable mortgages.
And it is precisely to relieve the burden on middle class families that we still need health insurance reform. Yes, we do.
Now, let's clear a few things up. I didn't choose to tackle this issue to get some legislative victory under my belt. And by now it should be fairly obvious that I didn't take on health care because it was good politics.  I took on health care because of the stories I've heard from Americans with preexisting conditions whose lives depend on getting coverage, patients who've been denied coverage, families, even those with insurance, who are just one illness away from financial ruin.
After nearly a century of trying--Democratic administrations, Republican administrations--we are closer than ever to bringing more security to the lives of so many Americans. The approach we've taken would protect every American from the worst practices of the insurance industry. It would give small businesses and uninsured Americans a chance to choose an affordable health care plan in a competitive market. It would require every insurance plan to cover preventive care.
And by the way, I want to acknowledge our First Lady, Michelle Obama, who this year is creating a national movement to tackle the epidemic of childhood obesity and make kids healthier.  Thank you, honey. She gets embarrassed.
Our approach would preserve the right of Americans who have insurance to keep their doctor and their plan. It would reduce costs and premiums for millions of families and businesses. And according to the Congressional Budget Office, the independent organization that both parties have cited as the official scorekeeper for Congress, our approach would bring down the deficit by as much as $1 trillion over the next two decades.
Still, this is a complex issue, and the longer it was debated, the more skeptical people became. I take my share of the blame for not explaining it more clearly to the American people. And I know that with all the lobbying and horse-trading, the process left most Americans wondering, What's in it for me?"

column1: But I also know this problem is not going away. By the time I'm finished speaking tonight
column2: more Americans will have lost their health insurance. Millions will lose it this year. Our deficit will grow. Premiums will go up. Patients will be denied the care they need. Small-business owners will continue to drop coverage altogether. I will not walk away from these Americans
column3: and neither should the people in this Chamber.

column1: So as temperatures cool
column2: I want everyone to take another look at the plan we've proposed. There's a reason why many doctors
column3: nurses
column4: and health care experts who know our system best consider this approach a vast improvement over the status quo. But if anyone from either party has a better approach that will bring down premiums
column5: bring down the deficit
column6: cover the uninsured
column7: strengthen Medicare for seniors
column8: and stop insurance company abuses
column9: let me know. Let me know. Let me know. I'm eager to see it.

column1: Here's what I ask Congress
column2: though: Don't walk away from reform. Not now. Not when we are so close. Let us find a way to come together and finish the job for the American people. Let's get it done. Let's get it done.

column1: Now
column2: even as health care reform would reduce our deficit
column3: it's not enough to dig us out of a massive fiscal hole in which we find ourselves. It's a challenge that makes all others that much harder to solve and one that's been subject to a lot of political posturing. So let me start the discussion of Government spending by setting the record straight.

column1: At the beginning of the last decade
column2: the year 2000
column3: America had a budget surplus of over $200 billion. By the time I took office
column4: we had a 1-year deficit of over $1 trillion and projected deficits of $8 trillion over the next decade. Most of this was the result of not paying for two wars
column5: two tax cuts
column6: and an expensive prescription drug program. On top of that
column7: the effects of the recession put a $3 trillion hole in our budget. All this was before I walked in the door.

column1: Now ... just stating the facts. Now
column2: if we had taken office in ordinary times
column3: I would have liked nothing more than to start bringing down the deficit. But we took office amid a crisis. And our efforts to prevent a second depression have added another $1 trillion to our national debt. That too is a fact.

column1: I'm absolutely convinced that was the right thing to do. But families across the country are tightening their belts and making tough decisions. The Federal Government should do the same. So tonight I'm proposing specific steps to pay for the trillion dollars that it took to rescue the economy last year.
Starting in 2011
column2: we are prepared to freeze Government spending for 3 years. Spending related to our national security
column3: Medicare
column4: Medicaid
column5: and Social Security will not be affected. But all other discretionary Government programs will. Like any cash-strapped family
column6: we will work within a budget to invest in what we need and sacrifice what we don't. And if I have to enforce this discipline by veto
column7: I will.

column1: We will continue to go through the budget
column2: line by line
column3: page by page
column4: to eliminate programs that we can't afford and don't work. We've already identified $20 billion in savings for next year. To help working families
column5: we'll extend our middle class tax cuts. But at a time of record deficits
column6: we will not continue tax cuts for oil companies
column7: for investment fund managers
column8: and for those making over $250
column9: 000 a year. We just can't afford it.

column1: Now
column2: even after paying for what we spent on my watch
column3: we'll still face the massive deficit we had when I took office. More importantly
column4: the cost of Medicare
column5: Medicaid
column6: and Social Security will continue to skyrocket. That's why I've called for a bipartisan fiscal commission
column7: modeled on a proposal by Republican Judd Gregg and Democrat Kent Conrad. This can't be one of those Washington gimmicks that lets us pretend we solve a problem. The commission will have to provide a specific set of solutions by a certain deadline.

column1: Now
column2: yesterday the Senate blocked a bill that would have created this commission
column3: so I'll issue an Executive order that will allow us to go forward
column4: because I refuse to pass this problem on to another generation of Americans. And when the vote comes tomorrow
column5: the Senate should restore the pay-as-you-go law that was a big reason for why we had record surpluses in the 1990s.

column1: Now
column2: I know that some in my own party will argue that we can't address the deficit or freeze Government spending when so many are still hurting. And I agree
column3: which is why this freeze won't take effect until next year
column4: when the economy is stronger. That's how budgeting works.  But understand
column5: if we don't take meaningful steps to rein in our debt
column6: it could damage our markets
column7: increase the cost of borrowing
column8: and jeopardize our recovery
column9: all of which would have an even worse effect on our job growth and family incomes.

column1: From some on the right
column2: I expect we'll hear a different argument
column3: that if we just make fewer investments in our people
column4: extend tax cuts
column5: including those for the wealthier Americans
column6: eliminate more regulations
column7: maintain the status quo on health care
column8: our deficits will go away. The problem is
column9: that's what we did for 8 years. That's what helped us into this crisis. It's what helped lead to these deficits. We can't do it again.

column1: Rather than fight the same tired battles that have dominated Washington for decades
column2: it's time to try something new. Let's invest in our people without leaving them a mountain of debt. Let's meet our responsibility to the citizens who sent us here. Let's try common sense----a novel concept.

column1: Now
column2: to do that
column3: we have to recognize that we face more than a deficit of dollars right now. We face a deficit of trust
column4: deep and corrosive doubts about how Washington works that have been growing for years. To close that credibility gap
column5: we have to take action on both ends of Pennsylvania Avenue to end the outsized influence of lobbyists
column6: to do our work openly
column7: to give our people the Government they deserve.

column1: Now
column2: that's what I came to Washington to do. That's why
column3: for the first time in history
column4: my administration posts on--our White House visitors online. That's why we've excluded lobbyists from policymaking jobs or seats on Federal boards and commissions. But we can't stop there. It's time to require lobbyists to disclose each contact they make on behalf of a client
column5: with my administration or with Congress. It's time to put strict limits on the contributions that lobbyists give to candidates for Federal office.

column1: With all due deference to separation of powers
column2: last week
column3: the Supreme Court reversed a century of law that I believe will open the floodgates for special interests
column4: including foreign corporations
column5: to spend without limit in our elections. I don't think American elections should be bankrolled by America's most powerful interests
column6: or worse
column7: by foreign entities. They should be decided by the American people. And I'd urge Democrats and Republicans to pass a bill that helps correct some of these problems.

column1: I'm also calling on Congress to continue down the path of earmark reform
column2: Democrats and Republicans--Democrats and Republicans. Look
column3: you've trimmed some of this spending
column4: you've embraced some meaningful change
column5: but restoring the public trust demands more. For example
column6: some Members of Congress post some earmark requests online. Tonight I'm calling on Congress to publish all earmark requests on a single web site before there's a vote so that the American people can see how their money is being spent.

column1: Of course
column2: none of these reforms will even happen if we don't also reform how we work with one another. Now
column3: I'm not naive. I never thought that the mere fact of my election would usher in peace and harmony and----some postpartisan era. I knew that both parties have fed divisions that are deeply entrenched. And on some issues
column4: there are simply philosophical differences that will always cause us to part ways. These disagreements
column5: about the role of government in our lives
column6: about our national priorities and our national security
column7: they've been taking place for over 200 years. They're the very essence of our democracy.

column1: But what frustrates the American people is a Washington where every day is election day. We can't wage a perpetual campaign where the only goal is to see who can get the most embarrassing headlines about the other side
column2: a belief that if you lose
column3: I win. Neither party should delay or obstruct every single bill just because they can. The confirmation of--I'm speaking to both parties now--the confirmation of well-qualified public servants shouldn't be held hostage to the pet projects or grudges of a few individual Senators.

column1: Washington may think that saying anything about the other side
column2: no matter how false
column3: no matter how malicious
column4: is just part of the game. But it's precisely such politics that has stopped either party from helping the American people. Worse yet
column5: it's sowing further division among our citizens
column6: further distrust in our Government. So no
column7: I will not give up on trying to change the tone of our politics. I know it's an election year. And after last week
column8: it's clear that campaign fever has come even earlier than usual. But we still need to govern.

column1: To Democrats
column2: I would remind you that we still have the largest majority in decades and the people expect us to solve problems
column3: not run for the hills. And if the Republican leadership is going to insist that 60 votes in the Senate are required to do any business at all in this town--a supermajority--then the responsibility to govern is now yours as well. Just saying no to everything may be good short-term politics
column4: but it's not leadership. We were sent here to serve our citizens
column5: not our ambitions. So let's show the American people that we can do it together.

column1: This week
column2: I'll be addressing a meeting of the House Republicans. I'd like to begin monthly meetings with both Democratic and Republican leadership. I know you can't wait.

column1: Now
column2: throughout our history
column3: no issue has united this country more than our security. Sadly
column4: some of the unity we felt after 9/11 has dissipated. And we can argue all we want about who's to blame for this
column5: but I'm not interested in relitigating the past. I know that all of us love this country. All of us are committed to its defense. So let's put aside the schoolyard taunts about who's tough. Let's reject the false choice between protecting our people and upholding our values. Let's leave behind the fear and division and do what it takes to defend our Nation and forge a more hopeful future for America and for the world.

column1: That's the work we began last year. Since the day I took office
column2: we've renewed our focus on the terrorists who threaten our Nation. We've made substantial investments in our homeland security and disrupted plots that threatened to take American lives. We are filling unacceptable gaps revealed by the failed Christmas attack
column3: with better airline security and swifter action on our intelligence. We've prohibited torture and strengthened partnerships from the Pacific to South Asia to the Arabian Peninsula. And in the last year
column4: hundreds of Al Qaida's fighters and affiliates
column5: including many senior leaders
column6: have been captured or killed
column7: far more than in 2008.

column1: And in Afghanistan
column2: we're increasing our troops and training Afghan security forces so they can begin to take the lead in July of 2011 and our troops can begin to come home. We will reward good governance
column3: work to reduce corruption
column4: and support the rights of all Afghans
column5: men and women alike. We're joined by allies and partners who have increased their own commitments and who will come together tomorrow in London to reaffirm our common purpose. There will be difficult days ahead
column6: but I am absolutely confident we will succeed.

column1: As we take the fight to Al Qaida
column2: we are responsibly leaving Iraq to its people. As a candidate
column3: I promised that I would end this war
column4: and that is what I am doing as President. We will have all of our combat troops out of Iraq by the end of this August. We will support the Iraqi Government as they hold elections
column5: and we will continue to partner with the Iraqi people to promote regional peace and prosperity. But make no mistake: This war is ending
column6: and all of our troops are coming home.

column1: Tonight all of our men and women in uniform
column2: in Iraq
column3: in Afghanistan
column4: and around the world
column5: they have to know that we--that they have our respect
column6: our gratitude
column7: our full support. And just as they must have the resources they need in war
column8: we all have a responsibility to support them when they come home. That's why we made the largest increase in investments for veterans in decades last year. That's why we're building a 21st-century VA. And that's why Michelle has joined with Jill Biden to forge a national commitment to support military families.

column1: Now
column2: even as we prosecute two wars
column3: we're also confronting perhaps the greatest danger to the American people
column4: the threat of nuclear weapons. I've embraced the vision of John F. Kennedy and Ronald Reagan through a strategy that reverses the spread of these weapons and seeks a world without them. To reduce our stockpiles and launchers
column5: while ensuring our deterrent
column6: the United States and Russia are completing negotiations on the farthest reaching arms control treaty in nearly two decades. And at April's Nuclear Security Summit
column7: we will bring 44 nations together here in Washington
column8: DC
column9: behind a clear goal: securing all vulnerable nuclear materials around the world in 4 years so that they never fall into the hands of terrorists.

column1: Now
column2: these diplomatic efforts have also strengthened our hand in dealing with those nations that insist on violating international agreements in pursuit of nuclear weapons. That's why North Korea now faces increased isolation and stronger sanctions
column3: sanctions that are being vigorously enforced. That's why the international community is more united and the Islamic Republic of Iran is more isolated. And as Iran's leaders continue to ignore their obligations
column4: there should be no doubt: They too will face growing consequences. That is a promise.

column1: That's the leadership we are providing: engagement that advances the common security and prosperity of all people. We're working through the G-20 to sustain a lasting global recovery. We're working with Muslim communities around the world to promote science and education and innovation. We have gone from a bystander to a leader in the fight against climate change. We're helping developing countries to feed themselves and continuing the fight against HIV/AIDS. And we are launching a new initiative that will give us the capacity to respond faster and more effectively to bioterrorism or an infectious disease
column2: a plan that will counter threats at home and strengthen public health abroad.

column1: As we have for over 60 years
column2: America takes these actions because our destiny is connected to those beyond our shores. But we also do it because it is right. That's why
column3: as we meet here tonight
column4: over 10
column5: 000 Americans are working with many nations to help the people of Haiti recover and rebuild. That's why we stand with the girl who yearns to go to school in Afghanistan
column6: why we support the human rights of the women marching through the streets of Iran
column7: why we advocate for the young man denied a job by corruption in Guinea. For America must always stand on the side of freedom and human dignity--always.

column1: Abroad
column2: America's greatest source of strength has always been our ideals. The same is true at home. We find unity in our incredible diversity
column3: drawing on the promise enshrined in our Constitution: The notion that we're all created equal; that no matter who you are or what you look like
column4: if you abide by the law
column5: you should be protected by it; if you adhere to our common values
column6: you should be treated no different than anyone else.

column1: We must continually renew this promise. My administration has a Division that is once again prosecuting violations and employment discrimination. We finally strengthened our laws to protect against crimes driven by hate. This year
column2: I will work with Congress and our military to finally repeal the law that denies gay Americans the right to serve the country they love because of who they are. It's the right thing to do.

column1: We're going to crack down on violations of equal pay laws so that women get equal pay for an equal day's work. And we should continue the work of fixing our broken immigration system
column2: to secure our borders and enforce our laws and ensure that everyone who plays by the rules can contribute to our economy and enrich our Nation.

column1: In the end
column2: it's our ideals
column3: our values that built America
column4: values that allowed us to forge a nation made up of immigrants from every corner of the globe
column5: values that drive our citizens still. Every day
column6: Americans meet their responsibilities to their families and their employers. Time and again
column7: they lend a hand to their neighbors and give back to their country. They take pride in their labor and are generous in spirit. These aren't Republican values or Democratic values that they're living by
column8: business values or labor values
column9: they're American values.

column1: Unfortunately
column2: too many of our citizens have lost faith that our biggest institutions--our corporations
column3: our media
column4: and
column5: yes
column6: our Government--still reflect these same values. Each of these institutions are full of honorable men and women doing important work that helps our country prosper. But each time a CEO rewards himself for failure or a banker puts the rest of us at risk for his own selfish gain
column7: people's doubts grow. Each time lobbyists game the system or politicians tear each other down instead of lifting this country up
column8: we lose faith. The more that TV pundits reduce serious debates to silly arguments
column9: big issues into sound bites
column10: our citizens turn away. No wonder there's so much cynicism out there. No wonder there's so much disappointment.

column1: I campaigned on the promise of change. Change we can believe in
column2: the slogan went. And right now I know there are many Americans who aren't sure if they still believe we can change or that I can deliver it.

column1: But remember this: I never suggested that change would be easy or that I could do it alone. Democracy in a nation of 300 million people can be noisy and messy and complicated. And when you try to do big things and make big changes
column2: it stirs passions and controversy. That's just how it is.

column1: Those of us in public office can respond to this reality by playing it safe and avoid telling hard truths and pointing fingers. We can do what's necessary to keep our poll numbers high and get through the next election
column2: instead of doing what's best for the next generation.

column1: But I also know this: If people had made that decision 50 years ago or 100 years ago or 200 years ago
column2: we wouldn't be here tonight. The only reason we are here is because generations of Americans were unafraid to do what was hard
column3: to do what was needed even when success was uncertain
column4: to do what it took to keep the dream of this Nation alive for their children and their grandchildren.

column1: Now
column2: our administration has had some political setbacks this year
column3: and some of them were deserved. But I wake up every day knowing that they are nothing compared to the setbacks that families all across this country have faced this year. And what keeps me going
column4: what keeps me fighting
column5: is that despite all these setbacks
column6: that spirit of determination and optimism
column7: that fundamental decency that has always been at the core of the American people
column8: that lives on.

column1: It lives on in the struggling small-business owner who wrote to me of his company
column2: "None of us
column3: he said, . . . are willing to consider
column4: even slightly
column5: that we might fail." It lives on in the woman who said that even though she and her neighbors have felt the pain of recession
column6: "We are strong. We are resilient. We are American." It lives on in the 8-year-old boy in Louisiana who just sent me his allowance and asked if I would give it to the people of Haiti. And it lives on in all the Americans who've dropped everything to go someplace they've never been and pull people they've never known from the rubble
column7: prompting chants of "U.S.A.! U.S.A.! U.S.A.!" when another life was saved.

column1: The spirit that has sustained this Nation for more than two centuries lives on in you
column2: its people. We have finished a difficult year. We have come through a difficult decade. But a new year has come. A new decade stretches before us. We don't quit. I don't quit. Let's seize this moment to start anew
column3: to carry the dream forward
column4: and to strengthen our Union once more.

column1: Thank you. God bless you
column2: and God bless the United States of America.@

column1: Barack Obama|Address Before a Joint Session of the Congress on the State of the Union|2011-01-25|@Mr. Speaker
column2: Mr. Vice President
column3: Members of Congress
column4: distinguished guests
column5: and fellow Americans: Tonight I want to begin by congratulating the men and women of the 112th Congress
column6: as well as your new Speaker
column7: John Boehner. And as we mark this occasion
column8: we're also mindful of the empty chair in this Chamber
