column9: and we pray for the health of our colleague and our friend Gabby Giffords.

column1: It's no secret that those of us here tonight have had our differences over the last 2 years. The debates have been contentious; we have fought fiercely for our beliefs. And that's a good thing. That's what a robust democracy demands. That's what helps set us apart as a nation.
But there's a reason the tragedy in Tucson gave us pause. Amid all the noise and passion and rancor of our public debate
column2: Tucson reminded us that no matter who we are or where we come from
column3: each of us is a part of something greater
column4: something more consequential than party or political preference.

column1: We are part of the American family. We believe that in a country where every race and faith and point of view can be found
column2: we are still bound together as one people
column3: that we share common hopes and a common creed
column4: that the dreams of a little girl in Tucson are not so different than those of our own children
column5: that they all deserve the chance to be fulfilled. That too is what sets us apart as a nation.

column1: Now
column2: by itself
column3: this simple recognition won't usher in a new era of cooperation. What comes of this moment is up to us. What comes of this moment will be determined not by whether we can sit together tonight
column4: but whether we can work together tomorrow.

column1: I believe we can
column2: and I believe we must. That's what the people who sent us here expect of us. With their votes
column3: they've determined that governing will now be a shared responsibility between parties. New laws will only pass with support from Democrats and Republicans. We will move forward together or not at all
column4: for the challenges we face are bigger than party and bigger than politics.

column1: At stake right now is not who wins the next election. After all
column2: we just had an election. At stake is whether new jobs and industries take root in this country or somewhere else. It's whether the hard work and industry of our people is rewarded. It's whether we sustain the leadership that has made America not just a place on a map
column3: but the light to the world.

column1: We are poised for progress. Two years after the worst recession most of us have ever known
column2: the stock market has come roaring back
column3: corporate profits are up
column4: the economy is growing again.

column1: But we have never measured progress by these yardsticks alone. We measure progress by the success of our people
column2: by the jobs they can find and the quality of life those jobs offer
column3: by the prospects of a small-business owner who dreams of turning a good idea into a thriving enterprise
column4: by the opportunities for a better life that we pass on to our children.

column1: That's the project the American people want us to work on--together.
Now
column2: we did that in December. Thanks to the tax cuts we passed
column3: Americans' paychecks are a little bigger today. Every business can write off the full cost of new investments that they make this year. And these steps
column4: taken by Democrats and Republicans
column5: will grow the economy and add to the more than 1 million private sector jobs created last year.

column1: But we have to do more. These steps we've taken over the last 2 years may have broken the back of this recession
column2: but to win the future
column3: we'll need to take on challenges that have been decades in the making.

column1: Many people watching tonight can probably remember a time when finding a good job meant showing up at a nearby factory or a business downtown. You didn't always need a degree
column2: and your competition was pretty much limited to your neighbors. If you worked hard
column3: chances are you'd have a job for life
column4: with a decent paycheck and good benefits and the occasional promotion. Maybe you'd even have the pride of seeing your kids work at the same company.

column1: That world has changed. And for many
column2: the change has been painful. I've seen it in the shuttered windows of once booming factories and the vacant storefronts on once busy Main Streets. I've heard it in the frustrations of Americans who've seen their paychecks dwindle or their jobs disappear
column3: proud men and women who feel like the rules have been changed in the middle of the game.

column1: They're right. The rules have changed. In a single generation
column2: revolutions in technology have transformed the way we live
column3: work
column4: and do business. Steel mills that once needed 1
column5: 000 workers can now do the same work with 100. Today
column6: just about any company can set up shop
column7: hire workers
column8: and sell their products wherever there's an Internet connection.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: nations like China and India realized that with some changes of their own
column3: they could compete in this new world. And so they started educating their children earlier and longer
column4: with greater emphasis on math and science. They're investing in research and new technologies. Just recently
column5: China became the home to the world's largest private solar research facility and the world's fastest computer.

column1: So yes
column2: the world is changed. The competition for jobs is real. But this shouldn't discourage us. It should challenge us. Remember
column3: for all the hits we've taken these last few years
column4: for all the naysayers predicting our decline
column5: America still has the largest
column6: most prosperous economy in the world. No workers are more productive than ours. No country has more successful companies or grants more patents to inventors and entrepreneurs. We're the home to the world's best colleges and universities
column7: where more students come to study than any place on Earth.

column1: What's more
column2: we are the first nation to be founded for the sake of an idea: the idea that each of us deserves the chance to shape our own destiny. That's why centuries of pioneers and immigrants have risked everything to come here. It's why our students don't just memorize equations
column3: but answer questions like: "What do you think of that idea? What would you change about the world? What do you want to be when you grow up?"

column1: The future is ours to win. But to get there
column2: we can't just stand still. As Robert Kennedy told us: "The future is not a gift. It is an achievement." Sustaining the American Dream has never been about standing pat. It has required each generation to sacrifice and struggle and meet the demands of a new age.

column1: And now it's our turn. We know what it takes to compete for the jobs and industries of our time. We need to outinnovate
column2: outeducate
column3: and outbuild the rest of the world. We have to make America the best place on Earth to do business. We need to take responsibility for our deficit and reform our Government. That's how our people will prosper. That's how we'll win the future. And tonight I'd like to talk about how we get there.

column1: The first step in winning the future is encouraging American innovation. None of us can predict with certainty what the next big industry will be or where the new jobs will come from. Thirty years ago
column2: we couldn't know that something called the Internet would lead to an economic revolution. What we can do--what America does better than anyone else--is spark the creativity and imagination of our people. We're the nation that put cars in driveways and computers in offices; the nation of Edison and the Wright brothers
column3: of Google and Facebook. In America
column4: innovation doesn't just change our lives. It is how we make our living.

column1: Our free enterprise system is what drives innovation. But because it's not always profitable for companies to invest in basic research
column2: throughout our history
column3: our Government has provided cutting-edge scientists and inventors with the support that they need. That's what planted the seeds for the Internet. That's what helped make possible things like computer chips and GPS. Just think of all the good jobs--from manufacturing to retail--that have come from these breakthroughs.

column1: Half a century ago
column2: when the Soviets beat us into space with the launch of a satellite called Sputnik
column3: we had no idea how we would beat them to the Moon. The science wasn't even there yet. NASA didn't exist. But after investing in better research and education
column4: we didn't just surpass the Soviets
column5: we unleashed a wave of innovation that created new industries and millions of new jobs.

column1: This is our generation's Sputnik moment. Two years ago
column2: I said that we needed to reach a level of research and development we haven't seen since the height of the space race. And in a few weeks
column3: I will be sending a budget to Congress that helps us meet that goal. We'll invest in biomedical research
column4: information technology
column5: and especially clean energy technology
column6: an investment that will strengthen our security
column7: protect our planet
column8: and create countless new jobs for our people.

column1: Already
column2: we're seeing the promise of renewable energy. Robert and Gary Allen are brothers who run a small Michigan roofing company. After September 11
column3: they volunteered their best roofers to help repair the Pentagon. But half of their factory went unused
column4: and the recession hit them hard. Today
column5: with the help of a Government loan
column6: that empty space is being used to manufacture solar shingles that are being sold all across the country. In Robert's words
column7: "We reinvented ourselves."

column1: That's what Americans have done for over 200 years: reinvented ourselves. And to spur on more success stories like the Allen Brothers
column2: we've begun to reinvent our energy policy. We're not just handing out money. We're issuing a challenge. We're telling America's scientists and engineers that if they assemble teams of the best minds in their fields and focus on the hardest problems in clean energy
column3: we'll fund the Apollo projects of our time.

column1: At the California Institute of Technology
column2: they're developing a way to turn sunlight and water into fuel for our cars. At Oak Ridge National Laboratory
column3: they're using supercomputers to get a lot more power out of our nuclear facilities. With more research and incentives
column4: we can break our dependence on oil with biofuels and become the first country to have a million electric vehicles on the road by 2015.

column1: We need to get behind this innovation. And to help pay for it
column2: I'm asking Congress to eliminate the billions in taxpayer dollars we currently give to oil companies. I don't know if you've noticed
column3: but they're doing just fine on their own.  So instead of subsidizing yesterday's energy
column4: let's invest in tomorrow's.

column1: Now
column2: clean energy breakthroughs will only translate into clean energy jobs if businesses know there will be a market for what they're selling. So tonight I challenge you to join me in setting a new goal: By 2035
column3: 80 percent of America's electricity will come from clean energy sources.

column1: Some folks want wind and solar. Others want nuclear
column2: clean coal
column3: and natural gas. To meet this goal
column4: we will need them all
column5: and I urge Democrats and Republicans to work together to make it happen.

column1: Maintaining our leadership in research and technology is crucial to America's success. But if we want to win the future
column2: if we want innovation to produce jobs in America and not overseas
column3: then we also have to win the race to educate our kids.

column1: Think about it. Over the next 10 years
column2: nearly half of all new jobs will require education that goes beyond a high school education. And yet as many as a quarter of our students aren't even finishing high school. The quality of our math and science education lags behind many other nations. America has fallen to ninth in the proportion of young people with a college degree. And so the question is whether all of us
column3: as citizens and as parents
column4: are willing to do what's necessary to give every child a chance to succeed.

column1: That responsibility begins not in our classrooms
column2: but in our homes and communities. It's family that first instills the love of learning in a child. Only parents can make sure the TV is turned off and homework gets done. We need to teach our kids that it's not just the winner of the Super Bowl who deserves to be celebrated
column3: but the winner of the science fair. We need to teach them that success is not a function of fame or PR
column4: but of hard work and discipline.

column1: Our schools share this responsibility. When a child walks into a classroom
column2: it should be a place of high expectations and high performance. But too many schools don't meet this test. That's why instead of just pouring money into a system that's not working
column3: we launched a competition called Race to the Top. To all 50 States
column4: we said
column5: "If you show us the most innovative plans to improve teacher quality and student achievement
column6: we'll show you the money."

column1: Race to the Top is the most meaningful reform of our public schools in a generation. For less than 1 percent of what we spend on education each year
column2: it has led over 40 States to raise their standards for teaching and learning. And these standards were developed
column3: by the way
column4: not by Washington
column5: but by Republican and Democratic Governors throughout the country. And Race to the Top should be the approach we follow this year as we replace No Child Left Behind with a law that's more flexible and focused on what's best for our kids.

column1: You see
column2: we know what's possible from our children when reform isn't just a top-down mandate
column3: but the work of local teachers and principals
column4: school boards and communities. Take a school like Bruce Randolph in Denver. Three years ago
column5: it was rated one of the worst schools in Colorado
column6: located on turf between two rival gangs. But last May
column7: 97 percent of the seniors received their diploma. Most will be the first in their families to go to college. And after the first year of the school's transformation
column8: the principal who made it possible wiped away tears when a student said
column9: "Thank you
column10: Ms. Waters
column11: for showing that we are smart and we can make it." That's what good schools can do
column12: and we want good schools all across the country.

column1: Let's also remember that after parents
column2: the biggest impact on a child's success comes from the man or woman at the front of the classroom. In South Korea
column3: teachers are known as nation builders. Here in America
column4: it's time we treated the people who educate our children with the same level of respect. We want to reward good teachers and stop making excuses for bad ones. And over the next 10 years
column5: with so many baby boomers retiring from our classrooms
column6: we want to prepare 100
column7: 000 new teachers in the fields of science and technology and engineering and math.

column1: In fact
column2: to every young person listening tonight who's contemplating their career choice: If you want to make a difference in the life of our Nation
column3: if you want to make a difference in the life of a child
column4: become a teacher. Your country needs you.

column1: Of course
column2: the education race doesn't end with a high school diploma. To compete
column3: higher education must be within the reach of every American. That's why we've ended the unwarranted taxpayer subsidies that went to banks and used the savings to make college affordable for millions of students. And this year
column4: I ask Congress to go further and make permanent our tuition tax credit
column5: worth $10
column6: 000 for 4 years of college. It's the right thing to do.

column1: Because people need to be able to train for new jobs and careers in today's fast-changing economy
column2: we're also revitalizing America's community colleges. Last month
column3: I saw the promise of these schools at Forsyth Tech in North Carolina. Many of the students there used to work in the surrounding factories that have since left town. One mother of two
column4: a woman named Kathy Proctor
column5: had worked in the furniture industry since she was 18 years old. And she told me she's earning her degree in biotechnology now
column6: at 55 years old
column7: not just because the furniture jobs are gone
column8: but because she wants to inspire her children to pursue their dreams too. As Kathy said
column9: "I hope it tells them to never give up."

column1: If we take these steps
column2: if we raise expectations for every child and give them the best possible chance at an education
column3: from the day they are born until the last job they take
column4: we will reach the goal that I set 2 years ago: By the end of the decade
column5: America will once again have the highest proportion of college graduates in the world.

column1: One last point about education: Today
column2: there are hundreds of thousands of students excelling in our schools who are not American citizens. Some are the children of undocumented workers
column3: who had nothing to do with the actions of their parents. They grew up as Americans and pledge allegiance to our flag
column4: and yet they live every day with the threat of deportation. Others come here from abroad to study in our colleges and universities. But as soon as they obtain advanced degrees
column5: we send them back home to compete against us. It makes no sense.

column1: Now
column2: I strongly believe that we should take on
column3: once and for all
column4: the issue of illegal immigration. And I am prepared to work with Republicans and Democrats to protect our borders
column5: enforce our laws
column6: and address the millions of undocumented workers who are now living in the shadows. I know that debate will be difficult. I know it will take time. But tonight
column7: let's agree to make that effort. And let's stop expelling talented
column8: responsible young people who could be staffing our research labs or starting a new business
column9: who could be further enriching this Nation.

column1: The third step in winning the future is rebuilding America. To attract new businesses to our shores
column2: we need the fastest
column3: most reliable ways to move people
column4: goods
column5: and information
column6: from high-speed rail to high-speed Internet.

column1: Our infrastructure used to be the best
column2: but our lead has slipped. South Korean homes now have greater Internet access than we do. Countries in Europe and Russia invest more in their roads and railways than we do. China is building faster trains and newer airports. Meanwhile
column3: when our own engineers graded our Nation's infrastructure
column4: they gave us a D.

column1: We have to do better. America is the nation that built the transcontinental railroad
column2: brought electricity to rural communities
column3: constructed the Interstate Highway System. The jobs created by these projects didn't just come from laying down track or pavement. They came from businesses that opened near a town's new train station or the new off-ramp.

column1: So over the last 2 years
column2: we've begun rebuilding for the 21st century
column3: a project that has meant thousands of good jobs for the hard-hit construction industry. And tonight I'm proposing that we redouble those efforts.

column1: We'll put more Americans to work repairing crumbling roads and bridges. We'll make sure this is fully paid for
column2: attract private investment
column3: and pick projects based [on]* what's best for the economy
column4: not politicians.

column1: Within 25 years
column2: our goal is to give 80 percent of Americans access to high-speed rail. This could allow you to go places in half the time it takes to travel by car. For some trips
column3: it will be faster than flying
column4: without the pat-down.  As we speak
column5: routes in California and the Midwest are already underway.

column1: Within the next 5 years
column2: we'll make it possible for businesses to deploy the next generation of high-speed wireless coverage to 98 percent of all Americans. This isn't just about--this isn't about faster Internet or fewer dropped calls. It's about connecting every part of America to the digital age. It's about a rural community in Iowa or Alabama where farmers and small-business owners will be able to sell their products all over the world. It's about a firefighter who can download the design of a burning building onto a handheld device
column3: a student who can take classes with a digital textbook
column4: or a patient who can have face-to-face video chats with her doctor.

column1: All these investments--in innovation
column2: education
column3: and infrastructure--will make America a better place to do business and create jobs. But to help our companies compete
column4: we also have to knock down barriers that stand in the way of their success.

column1: For example
column2: over the years
column3: a parade of lobbyists has rigged the Tax Code to benefit particular companies and industries. Those with accountants or lawyers to work the system can end up paying no taxes at all. But all the rest are hit with one of the highest corporate tax rates in the world. It makes no sense
column4: and it has to change.

column1: So tonight I'm asking Democrats and Republicans to simplify the system
column2: get rid of the loopholes
column3: level the playing field
column4: and use the savings to lower the corporate tax rate for the first time in 25 years without adding to our deficit. It can be done.

column1: To help businesses sell more products abroad
column2: we set a goal of doubling our exports by 2014. Because the more we export
column3: the more jobs we create here at home. Already
column4: our exports are up. Recently
column5: we signed agreements with India and China that will support more than 250
column6: 000 jobs here in the United States. And last month
column7: we finalized a trade agreement with South Korea that will support at least 70
column8: 000 American jobs. This agreement has unprecedented support from business and labor
column9: Democrats and Republicans
column10: and I ask this Congress to pass it as soon as possible.

column1: Now
column2: before I took office
column3: I made it clear that we would enforce our trade agreements and that I would only sign deals that keep faith with American workers and promote American jobs. That's what we did with Korea
column4: and that's what I intend to do as we pursue agreements with Panama and Colombia and continue our Asia-Pacific and global trade talks.

column1: To reduce barriers to growth and investment
column2: I've ordered a review of Government regulations. When we find rules that put an unnecessary burden on businesses
column3: we will fix them. But I will not hesitate to create or enforce commonsense safeguards to protect the American people. That's what we've done in this country for more than a century. It's why our food is safe to eat
column4: our water is safe to drink
column5: and our air is safe to breathe. It's why we have speed limits and child labor laws. It's why last year
column6: we put in place consumer protections against hidden fees and penalties by credit card companies and new rules to prevent another financial crisis. And it's why we passed reform that finally prevents the health insurance industry from exploiting patients.

column1: Now
column2: I have heard rumors that a few of you still have concerns about our new health care law.  So let me be the first to say that anything can be improved. If you have ideas about how to improve this law by making care better or more affordable
column3: I am eager to work with you. We can start right now by correcting a flaw in the legislation that has placed an unnecessary bookkeeping burden on small businesses.

column1: What I'm not willing to do--what I'm not willing to do--is go back to the days when insurance companies could deny someone coverage because of a preexisting condition.
I'm not willing to tell James Howard
column2: a brain cancer patient from Texas
column3: that his treatment might not be covered. I'm not willing to tell Jim Houser
column4: a small-businessman from Oregon
column5: that he has to go back to paying $5
column6: 000 more to cover his employees. As we speak
column7: this law is making prescription drugs cheaper for seniors and giving uninsured students a chance to stay on their patients'--parents' coverage.

column1: So I say to this Chamber tonight: Instead of refighting the battles of the last 2 years
column2: let's fix what needs fixing
column3: and let's move forward.

column1: Now
column2: the final critical step in winning the future is to make sure we aren't buried under a mountain of debt.

column1: We are living with a legacy of deficit spending that began almost a decade ago. And in the wake of the financial crisis
column2: some of that was necessary to keep credit flowing
column3: save jobs
column4: and put money in people's pockets.

column1: But now that the worst of the recession is over
column2: we have to confront the fact that our Government spends more than it takes in. That is not sustainable. Every day
column3: families sacrifice to live within their means. They deserve a Government that does the same.

column1: So tonight I am proposing that starting this year
column2: we freeze annual domestic spending for the next 5 years. Now
column3: this would reduce the deficit by more than $400 billion over the next decade and will bring discretionary spending to the lowest share of our economy since Dwight Eisenhower was President.

column1: This freeze will require painful cuts. Already
column2: we've frozen the salaries of hard-working Federal employees for the next 2 years. I've proposed cuts to things I care deeply about
column3: like community action programs. The Secretary of Defense has also agreed to cut tens of billions of dollars in spending that he and his generals believe our military can do without.

column1: Now
column2: I recognize that some in this Chamber have already proposed deeper cuts
column3: and I'm willing to eliminate whatever we can honestly afford to do without. But let's make sure that we're not doing it on the backs of our most vulnerable citizens. And let's make sure that what we're cutting is really excess weight. Cutting the deficit by gutting our investments in innovation and education is like lightening an overloaded airplane by removing its engine. It may make you feel like you're flying high at first
column4: but it won't take long before you feel the impact.

column1: Now
column2: most of the cuts and savings I've proposed only address annual domestic spending
column3: which represents a little more than 12 percent of our budget. To make further progress
column4: we have to stop pretending that cutting this kind of spending alone will be enough. It won't.

column1: The bipartisan fiscal commission I created last year made this crystal clear. I don't agree with all their proposals
column2: but they made important progress. And their conclusion is that the only way to tackle our deficit is to cut excessive spending wherever we find it
column3: in domestic spending
column4: defense spending
column5: health care spending
column6: and spending through tax breaks and loopholes.

column1: This means further reducing health care costs
column2: including programs like Medicare and Medicaid
column3: which are the single biggest contributor to our long-term deficit. The health insurance law we passed last year will slow these rising costs
column4: which is part of the reason that nonpartisan economists have said that repealing the health care law would add a quarter of a trillion dollars to our deficit. Still
column5: I'm willing to look at other ideas to bring down costs
column6: including one that Republicans suggested last year: medical malpractice reform to rein in frivolous lawsuits.

column1: To put us on solid ground
column2: we should also find a bipartisan solution to strengthen Social Security for future generations. We must do it without putting at risk current retirees
column3: the most vulnerable
column4: or people with disabilities
column5: without slashing benefits for future generations
column6: and without subjecting Americans' guaranteed retirement income to the whims of the stock market.

column1: And if we truly care about our deficit
column2: we simply can't afford a permanent extension of the tax cuts for the wealthiest 2 percent of Americans. Before we take money away from our schools or scholarships away from our students
column3: we should ask millionaires to give up their tax break. It's not a matter of punishing their success
column4: it's about promoting America's success.

column1: In fact
column2: the best thing we could do on taxes for all Americans is to simplify the individual Tax Code. This will be a tough job
column3: but members of both parties have expressed an interest in doing this
column4: and I am prepared to join them.

column1: So now is the time to act. Now is the time for both sides and both Houses of Congress
column2: Democrats and Republicans
column3: to forge a principled compromise that gets the job done. If we make the hard choices now to rein in our deficits
column4: we can make the investments we need to win the future.

column1: Let me take this one step further. We shouldn't just give our people a Government that's more affordable
column2: we should give them a Government that's more competent and more efficient. We can't win the future with a Government of the past.

column1: We live and do business in the Information Age
column2: but the last major reorganization of the Government happened in the age of black-and-white TV. There are 12 different agencies that deal with exports. There are at least five different agencies that deal with housing policy. Then there's my favorite example: The Interior Department is in charge of salmon while they're in fresh water
column3: but the Commerce Department handles them when they're in saltwater.  I hear it gets even more complicated once they're smoked.

column1: Now
column2: we've made great strides over the last 2 years in using technology and getting rid of waste. Veterans can now download their electronic medical records with a click of the mouse. We're selling acres of Federal office space that hasn't been used in years
column3: and we'll cut through redtape to get rid of more. But we need to think bigger. In the coming months
column4: my administration will develop a proposal to merge
column5: consolidate
column6: and reorganize the Federal Government in a way that best serves the goal of a more competitive America. I will submit that proposal to Congress for a vote
column7: and we will push to get it passed.

column1: In the coming year
column2: we'll also work to rebuild people's faith in the institution of Government. Because you deserve to know exactly how and where your tax dollars are being spent
column3: you'll be able to go to a web site and get that information for the very first time in history. Because you deserve to know when your elected officials are meeting with lobbyists
column4: I ask Congress to do what the White House has already done: put that information online. And because the American people deserve to know that special interests aren't larding up legislation with pet projects
column5: both parties in Congress should know this: If a bill comes to my desk with earmarks inside
column6: I will veto it. I will veto it.

column1: The 21st-century Government that's open and competent
column2: a government that lives within its means
column3: an economy that's driven by new skills and new ideas--our success in this new and changing world will require reform
column4: responsibility
column5: and innovation. It will also require us to approach that world with a new level of engagement in our foreign affairs.

column1: Just as jobs and businesses can now race across borders
column2: so can new threats and new challenges. No single wall separates East and West. No one rival superpower is aligned against us.

column1: And so we must defeat determined enemies
column2: wherever they are
column3: and build coalitions that cut across lines of region and race and religion. And America's moral example must always shine for all who yearn for freedom and justice and dignity. And because we've begun this work
column4: tonight we can say that American leadership has been renewed and America's standing has been restored.

column1: Look to Iraq
column2: where nearly 100
column3: 000 of our brave men and women have left with their heads held high. American combat patrols have ended
column4: violence is down
column5: and a new Government has been formed. This year
column6: our civilians will forge a lasting partnership with the Iraqi people
column7: while we finish the job of bringing our troops out of Iraq. America's commitment has been kept. The Iraq war is coming to an end.

column1: Of course
column2: as we speak
column3: Al Qaida and their affiliates continue to plan attacks against us. Thanks to our intelligence and law enforcement professionals
column4: we're disrupting plots and securing our cities and skies. And as extremists try to inspire acts of violence within our borders
column5: we are responding with the strength of our communities
column6: with respect for the rule of law
column7: and with the conviction that American Muslims are a part of our American family.

column1: We've also taken the fight to Al Qaida and their allies abroad. In Afghanistan
column2: our troops have taken Taliban strongholds and trained Afghan security forces. Our purpose is clear: By preventing the Taliban from reestablishing a stranglehold over the Afghan people
column3: we will deny Al Qaida the safe haven that served as a launching pad for 9/11.

column1: Thanks to our heroic troops and civilians
column2: fewer Afghans are under the control of the insurgency. There will be tough fighting ahead
column3: and the Afghan Government will need to deliver better governance. But we are strengthening the capacity of the Afghan people and building an enduring partnership with them. This year
column4: we will work with nearly 50 countries to begin a transition to an Afghan lead
column5: and this July
column6: we will begin to bring our troops home.

column1: In Pakistan
column2: Al Qaida's leadership is under more pressure than at any point since 2001. Their leaders and operatives are being removed from the battlefield. Their safe havens are shrinking. And we've sent a message from the Afghan border to the Arabian Peninsula to all parts of the globe: We will not relent
column3: we will not waver
column4: and we will defeat you.

column1: American leadership can also be seen in the effort to secure the worst weapons of war. Because Republicans and Democrats approved the new START Treaty
column2: far fewer nuclear weapons and launchers will be deployed. Because we rallied the world
column3: nuclear materials are being locked down on every continent so they never fall into the hands of terrorists.

column1: Because of a diplomatic effort to insist that Iran meet its obligations
column2: the Iranian Government now faces tougher sanctions
column3: tighter sanctions than ever before. And on the Korean Peninsula
column4: we stand with our ally South Korea and insist that North Korea keeps its commitment to abandon nuclear weapons.

column1: This is just a part of how we're shaping a world that favors peace and prosperity. With our European allies
column2: we revitalized NATO and increased our cooperation on everything from counterterrorism to missile defense. We've reset our relationship with Russia
column3: strengthened Asian alliances
column4: built new partnerships with nations like India.

column1: This March
column2: I will travel to Brazil
column3: Chile
column4: and El Salvador to forge new alliances across the Americas. Around the globe
column5: we're standing with those who take responsibility
column6: helping farmers grow more food
column7: supporting doctors who care for the sick
column8: and combating the corruption that can rot a society and rob people of opportunity.

column1: Recent events have shown us that what sets us apart must not just be our power; it must also be the purpose behind it. In south Sudan--with our assistance--the people were finally able to vote for independence after years of war. Thousands lined up before dawn. People danced in the streets. One man who lost four of his brothers at war summed up the scene around him. "This was a battlefield for most of my life
column2: he said. Now we want to be free."

column1: And we saw that same desire to be free in Tunisia
column2: where the will of the people proved more powerful than the writ of a dictator. And tonight let us be clear: The United States of America stands with the people of Tunisia and supports the democratic aspirations of all people.

column1: We must never forget that the things we've struggled for and fought for live in the hearts of people everywhere. And we must always remember that the Americans who have borne the greatest burden in this struggle are the men and women who serve our country.
Tonight let us speak with one voice in reaffirming that our Nation is united in support of our troops and their families. Let us serve them as well as they've served us
column2: by giving them the equipment they need
column3: by providing them with the care and benefits that they have earned
column4: and by enlisting our veterans in the great task of building our own Nation.

column1: Our troops come from every corner of this country. They're Black
column2: White
column3: Latino
column4: Asian
column5: Native American. They are Christian and Hindu
column6: Jewish and Muslim. And yes
column7: we know that some of them are gay. Starting this year
column8: no American will be forbidden from serving the country they love because of who they love. And with that change
column9: I call on all our college campuses to open their doors to our military recruiters and ROTC. It is time to leave behind the divisive battles of the past. It is time to move forward as one Nation.

column1: We should have no illusions about the work ahead of us. Reforming our schools
column2: changing the way we use energy
column3: reducing our deficit
column4: none of this will be easy. All of it will take time. And it will be harder because we will argue about everything: the costs
column5: the details
column6: the letter of every law.

column1: Of course
column2: some countries don't have this problem. If the central government wants a railroad
column3: they build a railroad
column4: no matter how many homes get bulldozed. If they don't want a bad story in the newspaper
column5: it doesn't get written.

column1: And yet
column2: as contentious and frustrating and messy as our democracy can sometimes be
column3: I know there isn't a person here who would trade places with any other nation on Earth.

column1: We may have differences in policy
column2: but we all believe in the rights enshrined in our Constitution. We may have different opinions
column3: but we believe in the same promise that says this is a place where you can make it if you try. We may have different backgrounds
column4: but we believe in the same dream that says this is a country where anything is possible
column5: no matter who you are
column6: no matter where you come from.

column1: That dream is why I can stand here before you tonight. That dream is why a working class kid from Scranton can sit behind me.  That dream is why someone who began by sweeping the floors of his father's Cincinnati bar can preside as Speaker of the House in the greatest nation on Earth.

That dream--that American Dream--is what drove the Allen Brothers to reinvent their roofing company for a new era. It's what drove those students at Forsyth Tech to learn a new skill and work towards the future. And that dream is the story of a small-business owner named Brandon Fisher.
Brandon started a company in Berlin
column2: Pennsylvania
column3: that specializes in a new kind of drilling technology. And one day last summer
column4: he saw the news that halfway across the world
column5: 33 men were trapped in a Chilean mine
column6: and no one knew how to save them.

column1: But Brandon thought his company could help. And so he designed a rescue that would come to be known as Plan B. His employees worked around the clock to manufacture the necessary drilling equipment
column2: and Brandon left for Chile.

column1: Along with others
column2: he began drilling a 2
column3: 000-foot hole into the ground
column4: working 3 or 4 hour--3 or 4 days at a time without any sleep. Thirty-seven days later
column5: Plan B succeeded and the miners were rescued. But because he didn't want all of the attention
column6: Brandon wasn't there when the miners emerged. He'd already gone back home
column7: back to work on his next project.

column1: And later
column2: one of his employees said of the rescue
column3: "We proved that Center Rock is a little company
column4: but we do big things."

column1: We do big things.
From the earliest days of our founding
column2: America has been the story of ordinary people who dare to dream. That's how we win the future.

column1: We're a nation that says
column2: "I might not have a lot of money
column3: but I have this great idea for a new company." "I might not come from a family of college graduates
column4: but I will be the first to get my degree." "I might not know those people in trouble
column5: but I think I can help them
column6: and I need to try." "I'm not sure how we'll reach that better place beyond the horizon
column7: but I know we'll get there. I know we will."

column1: We do big things.
The idea of America endures. Our destiny remains our choice. And tonight
column2: more than two centuries later
column3: it's because of our people that our future is hopeful
column4: our journey goes forward
column5: and the state of our Union is strong.

column1: Thank you. God bless you
column2: and may God bless the United States of America.@

column1: Barack Obama|Address Before a Joint Session of the Congress on the State of the Union|2012-01-24|@Mr. Speaker
column2: Mr. Vice President
column3: Members of Congress
column4: distinguished guests
column5: and fellow Americans: Last month
column6: I went to Andrews Air Force Base and welcomed home some of our last troops to serve in Iraq. Together
column7: we offered a final
column8: proud salute to the colors under which more than a million of our fellow citizens fought and several thousand gave their lives.

column1: We gather tonight knowing that this generation of heroes has made the United States safer and more respected around the world. For the first time in 9 years
column2: there are no Americans fighting in Iraq. For the first time in two decades
column3: Usama bin Laden is not a threat to this country. Most of Al Qaida's top lieutenants have been defeated. The Taliban's momentum has been broken
column4: and some troops in Afghanistan have begun to come home.

column1: These achievements are a testament to the courage
column2: selflessness
column3: and teamwork of America's Armed Forces. At a time when too many of our institutions have let us down
column4: they exceed all expectations. They're not consumed with personal ambition. They don't obsess over their differences. They focus on the mission at hand. They work together.

column1: Imagine what we could accomplish if we followed their example. Think about the America within our reach: a country that leads the world in educating its people; an America that attracts a new generation of high-tech manufacturing and high-paying jobs; a future where we're in control of our own energy and our security and prosperity aren't so tied to unstable parts of the world; an economy built to last
column2: where hard work pays off and responsibility is rewarded.

column1: We can do this. I know we can
column2: because we've done it before. At the end of World War II
column3: when another generation of heroes returned home from combat
column4: they built the strongest economy and middle class the world has ever known. My grandfather
column5: a veteran of Patton's army
column6: got the chance to go to college on the GI bill. My grandmother
column7: who worked on a bomber assembly line
column8: was part of a workforce that turned out the best products on Earth.

column1: The two of them shared the optimism of a nation that had triumphed over a depression and fascism. They understood they were part of something larger
column2: that they were contributing to a story of success that every American had a chance to share
column3: the basic American promise that if you worked hard
column4: you could do well enough to raise a family
column5: own a home
column6: send your kids to college
column7: and put a little away for retirement.

column1: The defining issue of our time is how to keep that promise alive. No challenge is more urgent. No debate is more important. We can either settle for a country where a shrinking number of people do really well while a growing number of Americans barely get by
column2: or we can restore an economy where everyone gets a fair shot and everyone does their fair share and everyone plays by the same set of rules. What's at stake aren't Democratic values or Republican values
column3: but American values. And we have to reclaim them.

column1: Let's remember how we got here. Long before the recession
column2: jobs and manufacturing began leaving our shores. Technology made businesses more efficient
column3: but also made some jobs obsolete. Folks at the top saw their incomes rise like never before
column4: but most hard-working Americans struggled with costs that were growing
column5: paychecks that weren't
column6: and personal debt that kept piling up.

column2: the house of cards collapsed. We learned that mortgages had been sold to people who couldn't afford or understand them. Banks had made huge bets and bonuses with other people's money. Regulators had looked the other way or didn't have the authority to stop the bad behavior.

column1: It was wrong
column2: it was irresponsible
column3: and it plunged our economy into a crisis that put millions out of work
column4: saddled us with more debt
column5: and left innocent
column6: hard-working Americans holding the bag. In the 6 months before I took office
column7: we lost nearly 4 million jobs. And we lost another 4 million before our policies were in full effect.

column1: Those are the facts. But so are these: In the last 22 months
column2: businesses have created more than 3 million jobs. Last year
column3: they created the most jobs since 2005. American manufacturers are hiring again
column4: creating jobs for the first time since the late 1990s. Together
column5: we've agreed to cut the deficit by more than $2 trillion. And we've put in place new rules to hold Wall Street accountable so a crisis like this never happens again.

column1: The state of our Union is getting stronger. And we've come too far to turn back now. As long as I'm President
column2: I will work with anyone in this Chamber to build on this momentum. But I intend to fight obstruction with action
column3: and I will oppose any effort to return to the very same policies that brought on this economic crisis in the first place.

column1: No
column2: we will not go back to an economy weakened by outsourcing
column3: bad debt
column4: and phony financial profits. Tonight I want to speak about how we move forward and lay out a blueprint for an economy that's built to last
column5: an economy built on American manufacturing
column6: American energy
column7: skills for American workers
column8: and a renewal of American values.

column1: Now
column2: this blueprint begins with American manufacturing.

column1: On the day I took office
column2: our auto industry was on the verge of collapse. Some even said we should let it die. With a million jobs at stake
column3: I refused to let that happen. In exchange for help
column4: we demanded responsibility. We got workers and automakers to settle their differences. We got the industry to retool and restructure. Today
column5: General Motors is back on top as the world's number-one automaker. Chrysler has grown faster in the U.S. than any major car company. Ford is investing billions in U.S. plants and factories. And together
column6: the entire industry added nearly 160
column7: 000 jobs.

column1: We bet on American workers. We bet on American ingenuity. And tonight
column2: the American auto industry is back.

column1: What's happening in Detroit can happen in other industries. It can happen in Cleveland and Pittsburgh and Raleigh. We can't bring every job back that's left our shore. But right now it's getting more expensive to do business in places like China. Meanwhile
column2: America is more productive. A few weeks ago
column3: the CEO of Master Lock told me that it now makes business sense for him to bring jobs back home. Today
column4: for the first time in 15 years
column5: Master Lock's unionized plant in Milwaukee is running at full capacity.

column1: So we have a huge opportunity at this moment to bring manufacturing back. But we have to seize it. Tonight my message to business leaders is simple: Ask yourselves what you can do to bring jobs back to your country
column2: and your country will do everything we can to help you succeed.

column1: We should start with our Tax Code. Right now companies get tax breaks for moving jobs and profits overseas. Meanwhile
column2: companies that choose to stay in America get hit with one of the highest tax rates in the world. It makes no sense
column3: and everyone knows it. So let's change it.

column1: First
column2: if you're a business that wants to outsource jobs
column3: you shouldn't get a tax deduction for doing it. That money should be used to cover moving expenses for companies like Master Lock that decide to bring jobs home.

column1: Second
column2: no American company should be able to avoid paying its fair share of taxes by moving jobs and profits overseas. From now on
column3: every multinational company should have to pay a basic minimum tax. And every penny should go towards lowering taxes for companies that choose to stay here and hire here in America.

column1: Third
column2: if you're an American manufacturer
column3: you should get a bigger tax cut. If you're a high-tech manufacturer
column4: we should double the tax deduction you get for making your products here. And if you want to relocate in a community that was hit hard when a factory left town
column5: you should get help financing a new plant
column6: equipment
column7: or training for new workers.

column1: So my message is simple: It is time to stop rewarding businesses that ship jobs overseas and start rewarding companies that create jobs right here in America. Send me these tax reforms
column2: and I will sign them right away.

column1: We're also making it easier for American businesses to sell products all over the world. Two years ago
column2: I set a goal of doubling U.S. exports over 5 years. With the bipartisan trade agreements we signed into law
column3: we're on track to meet that goal ahead of schedule. And soon there will be millions of new customers for American goods in Panama
column4: Colombia
column5: and South Korea. Soon there will be new cars on the streets of Seoul imported from Detroit and Toledo and Chicago.

column1: I will go anywhere in the world to open new markets for American products. And I will not stand by when our competitors don't play by the rules. We've brought trade cases against China at nearly twice the rate as the last administration
column2: and it's made a difference. Over a thousand Americans are working today because we stopped a surge in Chinese tires. But we need to do more. It's not right when another country lets our movies
column3: music
column4: and software be pirated. It's not fair when foreign manufacturers have a leg up on ours only because they're heavily subsidized.

column1: Tonight I'm announcing the creation of a trade enforcement unit that will be charged with investigating unfair trading practices in countries like China. There will be more inspections to prevent counterfeit or unsafe goods from crossing our borders. And this Congress should make sure that no foreign company has an advantage over American manufacturing when it comes to accessing financing or new markets like Russia. Our workers are the most productive on Earth
column2: and if the playing field is level
column3: I promise you
column4: America will always win.

column1: I also hear from many business leaders who want to hire in the United States
column2: but can't find workers with the right skills. Growing industries in science and technology have twice as many openings as we have workers who can do the job. Think about that: openings at a time when millions of Americans are looking for work. It's inexcusable
column3: and we know how to fix it.

column1: Jackie Bray is a single mom from North Carolina who was laid off from her job as a mechanic. Then
column2: Siemens opened a gas turbine factory in Charlotte and formed a partnership with Central Piedmont Community College. The company helped the college design courses in laser and robotics training. It paid Jackie's tuition
column3: then hired her to help operate their plant.

column1: I want every American looking for work to have the same opportunity as Jackie did. Join me in a national commitment to train 2 million Americans with skills that will lead directly to a job. My administration has already lined up more companies that want to help. Model partnerships between businesses like Siemens and community colleges in places like Charlotte and Orlando and Louisville are up and running. Now you need to give more community colleges the resources they need to become community career centers
column2: places that teach people skills that businesses are looking for right now
column3: from data management to high-tech manufacturing.

column1: And I want to cut through the maze of confusing training programs so that from now on
column2: people like Jackie have one program
column3: one website
column4: and one place to go for all the information and help that they need. It is time to turn our unemployment system into a reemployment system that puts people to work.

column1: These reforms will help people get jobs that are open today. But to prepare for the jobs of tomorrow
column2: our commitment to skills and education has to start earlier.

column1: For less than 1 percent of what our Nation spends on education each year
column2: we've convinced nearly every State in the country to raise their standards for teaching and learning
column3: the first time that's happened in a generation. But challenges remain
column4: and we know how to solve them.

column1: At a time when other countries are doubling down on education
column2: tight budgets have forced States to lay off thousands of teachers. We know a good teacher can increase the lifetime income of a classroom by over $250
column3: 000. A great teacher can offer an escape from poverty to the child who dreams beyond his circumstance. Every person in this Chamber can point to a teacher who changed the trajectory of their lives. Most teachers work tirelessly
column4: with modest pay
column5: sometimes digging into their own pocket for school supplies
column6: just to make a difference.

column1: Teachers matter. So
column2: instead of bashing them or defending the status quo
column3: let's offer schools a deal. Give them the resources to keep good teachers on the job and reward the best ones. And in return
column4: grant schools flexibility to teach with creativity and passion
column5: to stop teaching to the test
column6: and to replace teachers who just aren't helping kids learn. That's a bargain worth making.

column1: We also know that when students don't walk away from their education
column2: more of them walk the stage to get their diploma. When students are not allowed to drop out
column3: they do better. So tonight I am proposing that every State--every State--requires that all students stay in high school until they graduate or turn 18.

column1: When kids do graduate
column2: the most daunting challenge can be the cost of college. At a time when Americans owe more in tuition debt than credit card debt
column3: this Congress needs to stop the interest rates on student loans from doubling in July.

column1: Extend the tuition tax credit we started that saves millions of middle class families thousands of dollars
column2: and give more young people the chance to earn their way through college by doubling the number of work-study jobs in the next 5 years.

column1: Of course
column2: it's not enough for us to increase student aid. We can't just keep subsidizing skyrocketing tuition; we'll run out of money. States also need to do their part by making higher education a higher priority in their budgets. And colleges and universities have to do their part by working to keep costs down.

column1: Recently
column2: I spoke with a group of college presidents who have done just that. Some schools redesign courses to help students finish more quickly. Some use better technology. The point is
column3: it's possible. So let me put colleges and universities on notice: If you can't stop tuition from going up
column4: the funding you get from taxpayers will go down. Higher education can't be a luxury. It is an economic imperative that every family in America should be able to afford.

column1: Let's also remember that hundreds of thousands of talented
column2: hard-working students in this country face another challenge: the fact that they aren't yet American citizens. Many were brought here as small children
column3: are American through and through
column4: yet they live every day with the threat of deportation. Others came more recently
column5: to study business and science and engineering
column6: but as soon as they get their degree
column7: we send them home to invent new products and create new jobs somewhere else. That doesn't make sense.

column1: I believe as strongly as ever that we should take on illegal immigration. That's why my administration has put more boots on the border than ever before. That's why there are fewer illegal crossings than when I took office. The opponents of action are out of excuses. We should be working on comprehensive immigration reform right now.
But if election-year politics keeps Congress from acting on a comprehensive plan
column2: let's at least agree to stop expelling responsible young people who want to staff our labs
column3: start new businesses
column4: defend this country. Send me a law that gives them the chance to earn their citizenship. I will sign it right away.

column1: You see
column2: an economy built to last is one where we encourage the talent and ingenuity of every person in this country. That means women should earn equal pay for equal work. It means we should support everyone who's willing to work and every risk taker and entrepreneur who aspires to become the next Steve Jobs.

column1: After all
column2: innovation is what America has always been about. Most new jobs are created in startups and small businesses. So let's pass an agenda that helps them succeed. Tear down regulations that prevent aspiring entrepreneurs from getting the financing to grow. Expand tax relief to small businesses that are raising wages and creating good jobs. Both parties agree on these ideas. So put them in a bill and get it on my desk this year.

column1: Innovation also demands basic research. Today
column2: the discoveries taking place in our federally financed labs and universities could lead to new treatments that kill cancer cells but leave healthy ones untouched
column3: new lightweight vests for cops and soldiers that can stop any bullet. Don't gut these investments in our budget. Don't let other countries win the race for the future. Support the same kind of research and innovation that led to the computer chip and the Internet
column4: to new American jobs and new American industries.

column1: And nowhere is the promise of innovation greater than in American-made energy. Over the last 3 years
column2: we've opened millions of new acres for oil and gas exploration
column3: and tonight I'm directing my administration to open more than 75 percent of our potential offshore oil and gas resources. Right now--right now--American oil production is the highest that it's been in 8 years. That's right
column4: 8 years. Not only that
column5: last year
column6: we relied less on foreign oil than in any of the past 16 years.

column1: But with only 2 percent of the world's oil reserves
column2: oil isn't enough. This country needs an all-out
column3: all-of-the-above strategy that develops every available source of American energy
column4: a strategy that's cleaner
column5: cheaper
column6: and full of new jobs.

column1: We have a supply of natural gas that can last America nearly 100 years. And my administration will take every possible action to safely develop this energy. Experts believe this will support more than 600
column2: 000 jobs by the end of the decade. And I'm requiring all companies that drill for gas on public lands to disclose the chemicals they use. Because America will develop this resource without putting the health and safety of our citizens at risk.

column1: The development of natural gas will create jobs and power trucks and factories that are cleaner and cheaper
column2: proving that we don't have to choose between our environment and our economy. And by the way
column3: it was public research dollars
column4: over the course of 30 years
column5: that helped develop the technologies to extract all this natural gas out of shale rock
column6: reminding us that Government support is critical in helping businesses get new energy ideas off the ground.

column1: Now
column2: what's true for natural gas is just as true for clean energy. In 3 years
column3: our partnership with the private sector has already positioned America to be the world's leading manufacturer of high-tech batteries. Because of Federal investments
column4: renewable energy use has nearly doubled
column5: and thousands of Americans have jobs because of it.

column1: When Bryan Ritterby was laid off from his job making furniture
column2: he said he worried that at 55 no one would give him a second chance. But he found work at Energetx
column3: a wind turbine manufacturer in Michigan. Before the recession
column4: the factory only made luxury yachts. Today
column5: it's hiring workers like Bryan
column6: who said
column7: "I'm proud to be working in the industry of the future."

column1: Our experience with shale gas
column2: our experience with natural gas
column3: shows us that the payoffs on these public investments don't always come right away. Some technologies don't pan out
column4: some companies fail. But I will not walk away from the promise of clean energy. I will not walk away from workers like Bryan. I will not cede the wind or solar or battery industry to China or Germany because we refuse to make the same commitment here.

column1: We've subsidized oil companies for a century. That's long enough. It's time to end the taxpayer giveaways to an industry that rarely has been more profitable and double down on a clean energy industry that never has been more promising. Pass clean energy tax credits. Create these jobs.

We can also spur energy innovation with new incentives. The differences in this Chamber may be too deep right now to pass a comprehensive plan to fight climate change. But there's no reason why Congress shouldn't at least set a clean energy standard that creates a market for innovation. So far
column2: you haven't acted. Well
column3: tonight I will. I'm directing my administration to allow the development of clean energy on enough public land to power 3 million homes. And I'm proud to announce that the Department of Defense
column4: working with us
column5: the world's largest consumer of energy
column6: will make one of the largest commitments to clean energy in history
column7: with the Navy purchasing enough capacity to power a quarter of a million homes a year.

column1: Of course
column2: the easiest way to save money is to waste less energy. So here's a proposal: Help manufacturers eliminate energy waste in their factories and give businesses incentives to upgrade their buildings. Their energy bills will be a hundred billion dollars lower over the next decade
column3: and America will have less pollution
column4: more manufacturing
column5: more jobs for construction workers who need them. Send me a bill that creates these jobs.

column1: Building this new energy future should be just one part of a broader agenda to repair America's infrastructure. So much of America needs to be rebuilt. We've got crumbling roads and bridges
column2: a power grid that wastes too much energy
column3: an incomplete high-speed broadband network that prevents a small-business owner in rural America from selling her products all over the world.

column1: During the Great Depression
column2: America built the Hoover Dam and the Golden Gate Bridge. After World War II
column3: we connected our States with a system of highways. Democratic and Republican administrations invested in great projects that benefited everybody
column4: from the workers who built them to the businesses that still use them today.

column1: In the next few weeks
column2: I will sign an Executive order clearing away the redtape that slows down too many construction projects. But you need to fund these projects. Take the money we're no longer spending at war
column3: use half of it to pay down our debt
column4: and use the rest to do some nation-building right here at home.

column1: There's never been a better time to build
column2: especially since the construction industry was one of the hardest hit when the housing bubble burst. Of course
column3: construction workers weren't the only ones who were hurt. So were millions of innocent Americans who've seen their home values decline. And while Government can't fix the problem on its own
column4: responsible homeowners shouldn't have to sit and wait for the housing market to hit bottom to get some relief.

column1: And that's why I'm sending this Congress a plan that gives every responsible homeowner the chance to save about $3
column2: 000 a year on their mortgage by refinancing at historically low rates. No more redtape. No more runaround from the banks. A small fee on the largest financial institutions will ensure that it won't add to the deficit and will give those banks that were rescued by taxpayers a chance to repay a deficit of trust.

column1: Let's never forget: Millions of Americans who work hard and play by the rules every day deserve a Government and a financial system that do the same. It's time to apply the same rules from top to bottom. No bailouts
column2: no handouts
column3: and no copouts. An America built to last insists on responsibility from everybody.

column1: We've all paid the price for lenders who sold mortgages to people who couldn't afford them and buyers who knew they couldn't afford them. That's why we need smart regulations to prevent irresponsible behavior. Rules to prevent financial fraud or toxic dumping or faulty medical devices
column2: these don't destroy the free market. They make the free market work better.

column1: There's no question that some regulations are outdated
column2: unnecessary
column3: or too costly. In fact
column4: I've approved fewer regulations in the first 3 years of my Presidency than my Republican predecessor did in his. I've ordered every Federal agency to eliminate rules that don't make sense. We've already announced over 500 reforms
column5: and just a fraction of them will save business and citizens more than $10 billion over the next 5 years. We got rid of one rule from 40 years ago that could have forced some dairy farmers to spend $10
column6: 000 a year proving that they could contain a spill
column7: because milk was somehow classified as an oil. With a rule like that
column8: I guess it was worth crying over spilled milk.

column1: Now
column2: I'm confident a farmer can contain a milk spill without a Federal agency looking over his shoulder. Absolutely. But I will not back down from making sure an oil company can contain the kind of oil spill we saw in the Gulf 2 years ago. I will not back down from protecting our kids from mercury poisoning or making sure that our food is safe and our water is clean. I will not go back to the days when health insurance companies had unchecked power to cancel your policy
column3: deny your coverage
column4: or charge women differently than men.

column1: And I will not go back to the days when Wall Street was allowed to play by its own set of rules. The new rules we passed restore what should be any financial system's core purpose: getting funding to entrepreneurs with the best ideas and getting loans to responsible families who want to buy a home or start a business or send their kids to college.
So
column2: if you are a big bank or financial institution
column3: you're no longer allowed to make risky bets with your customers' deposits. You're required to write out a "living will" that details exactly how you'll pay the bills if you fail
column4: because the rest of us are not bailing you out ever again. And if you're a mortgage lender or a payday lender or a credit card company
column5: the days of signing people up for products they can't afford with confusing forms and deceptive practices
column6: those days are over. Today
column7: American consumers finally have a watchdog in Richard Cordray
column8: with one job: to look out for them.

column1: We'll also establish a financial crimes unit of highly trained investigators to crack down on large-scale fraud and protect people's investments. Some financial firms violate major antifraud laws because there's no real penalty for being a repeat offender. That's bad for consumers
column2: and it's bad for the vast majority of bankers and financial service professionals who do the right thing. So pass legislation that makes the penalties for fraud count.

column1: And tonight I'm asking my Attorney General to create a special unit of Federal prosecutors and leading State attorney general to expand our investigations into the abusive lending and packaging of risky mortgages that led to the housing crisis. This new unit will hold accountable those who broke the law
column2: speed assistance to homeowners
column3: and help turn the page on an era of recklessness that hurt so many Americans.

column1: Now
column2: a return to the American values of fair play and shared responsibility will help protect our people and our economy. But it should also guide us as we look to pay down our debt and invest in our future.

column1: Right now our most immediate priority is stopping a tax hike on 160 million working Americans while the recovery is still fragile. People cannot afford losing $40 out of each paycheck this year. There are plenty of ways to get this done. So let's agree right here
column2: right now. No side issues. No drama. Pass the payroll tax cut without delay. Let's get it done.

column1: When it comes to the deficit
column2: we've already agreed to more than $2 trillion in cuts and savings. But we need to do more
column3: and that means making choices. Right now we're poised to spend nearly $1 trillion more on what was supposed to be a temporary tax break for the wealthiest 2 percent of Americans. Right now
column4: because of loopholes and shelters in the Tax Code
column5: a quarter of all millionaires pay lower tax rates than millions of middle class households. Right now Warren Buffett pays a lower tax rate than his secretary.

column1: Do we want to keep these tax cuts for the wealthiest Americans? Or do we want to keep our investments in everything else
column2: like education and medical research
column3: a strong military and care for our veterans? Because if we're serious about paying down our debt
column4: we can't do both.

column1: The American people know what the right choice is. So do I. As I told the Speaker this summer
column2: I'm prepared to make more reforms that rein in the long-term costs of Medicare and Medicaid and strengthen Social Security
column3: so long as those programs remain a guarantee of security for seniors. But in return
column4: we need to change our Tax Code so that people like me
column5: and an awful lot of Members of Congress
column6: pay our fair share of taxes.

column1: Tax reform should follow the Buffett rule. If you make more than a million dollars a year
column2: you should not pay less than 30 percent in taxes. And my Republican friend Tom Coburn is right: Washington should stop subsidizing millionaires. In fact
column3: if you're earning a million dollars a year
column4: you shouldn't get special tax subsidies or deductions. On the other hand
column5: if you make under $250
column6: 000 a year
column7: like 98 percent of American families
column8: your taxes shouldn't go up. You're the ones struggling with rising costs and stagnant wages. You're the ones who need relief.

column1: Now
column2: you can call this class warfare all you want. But asking a billionaire to pay at least as much as his secretary in taxes? Most Americans would call that common sense.

column1: We don't begrudge financial success in this country. We admire it. When Americans talk about folks like me paying my fair share of taxes
column2: it's not because they envy the rich. It's because they understand that when I get a tax break I don't need and the country can't afford
column3: it either adds to the deficit or somebody else has to make up the difference
column4: like a senior on a fixed income or a student trying to get through school or a family trying to make ends meet. That's not right. Americans know that's not right. They know that this generation's success is only possible because past generations felt a responsibility to each other and to the future of their country
column5: and they know our way of life will only endure if we feel that same sense of shared responsibility. That's how we'll reduce our deficit. That's an America built to last.

column1: Now
column2: I recognize that people watching tonight have differing views about taxes and debt
column3: energy and health care. But no matter what party they belong to
column4: I bet most Americans are thinking the same thing right about now: Nothing will get done in Washington this year or next year or maybe even the year after that
column5: because Washington is broken.

column1: Can you blame them for feeling a little cynical?

The greatest blow to our confidence in our economy last year didn't come from events beyond our control. It came from a debate in Washington over whether the United States would pay its bills or not. Who benefited from that fiasco?
I've talked tonight about the deficit of trust between Main Street and Wall Street. But the divide between this city and the rest of the country is at least as bad
column2: and it seems to get worse every year.

column1: Now
column2: some of this has to do with the corrosive influence of money in politics. So together
column3: let's take some steps to fix that. Send me a bill that bans insider trading by Members of Congress. I will sign it tomorrow. Let's limit any elected official from owning stocks in industries they impact. Let's make sure people who bundle campaign contributions for Congress can't lobby Congress and vice versa
column4: an idea that has bipartisan support
column5: at least outside of Washington.

column1: Some of what's broken has to do with the way Congress does its business these days. A simple majority is no longer enough to get anything--even routine business--passed through the Senate. Neither party has been blameless in these tactics. Now both parties should put an end to it. For starters
column2: I ask the Senate to pass a simple rule that all judicial and public service nominations receive a simple up-or-down vote within 90 days.

column1: The executive branch also needs to change. Too often
column2: it's inefficient
column3: outdated
column4: and remote. That's why I've asked this Congress to grant me the authority to consolidate the Federal bureaucracy so that our Government is leaner
column5: quicker
column6: and more responsive to the needs of the American people.

column1: Finally
column2: none of this can happen unless we also lower the temperature in this town. We need to end the notion that the two parties must be locked in a perpetual campaign of mutual destruction
column3: that politics is about clinging to rigid ideologies instead of building consensus around commonsense ideas.

column1: I'm a Democrat
column2: but I believe what Republican Abraham Lincoln believed: that Government should do for people only what they cannot do better by themselves and no more. That's why my education reform offers more competition and more control for schools and States. That's why we're getting rid of regulations that don't work. That's why our health care law relies on a reformed private market
column3: not a Government program.

column1: On the other hand
column2: even my Republican friends who complain the most about Government spending have supported federally financed roads and clean energy projects and Federal offices for the folks back home.

column1: The point is
column2: we should all want a smarter
column3: more effective Government. And while we may not be able to bridge our biggest philosophical differences this year
column4: we can make real progress. With or without this Congress
column5: I will keep taking actions that help the economy grow. But I can do a whole lot more with your help. Because when we act together
column6: there's nothing the United States of America can't achieve.

column1: That's the lesson we've learned from our actions abroad over the last few years. Ending the Iraq war has allowed us to strike decisive blows against our enemies. From Pakistan to Yemen
column2: the Al Qaida operatives who remain are scrambling
column3: knowing that they can't escape the reach of the United States of America.

column1: From this position of strength
column2: we've begun to wind down the war in Afghanistan. Ten thousand of our troops have come home. Twenty-three thousand more will leave by the end of this summer. This transition to Afghan lead will continue
column3: and we will build an enduring partnership with Afghanistan so that it is never again a source of attacks against America.

column1: As the tide of war recedes
column2: a wave of change has washed across the Middle East and North Africa
