column3: from Tunis to Cairo
column4: from Sana'a to Tripoli. A year ago
column5: Qadhafi was one of the world's longest serving dictators
column6: a murderer with American blood on his hands. Today
column7: he is gone. And in Syria
column8: I have no doubt that the Asad regime will soon discover that the forces of change cannot be reversed and that human dignity cannot be denied.

column1: How this incredible transformation will end remains uncertain. But we have a huge stake in the outcome. And while it's ultimately up to the people of the region to decide their fate
column2: we will advocate for those values that have served our own country so well. We will stand against violence and intimidation. We will stand for the rights and dignity of all human beings: men and women; Christians
column3: Muslims
column4: and Jews. We will support policies that lead to strong and stable democracies and open markets
column5: because tyranny is no match for liberty.

column1: And we will safeguard America's own security against those who threaten our citizens
column2: our friends
column3: and our interests. Look at Iran. Through the power of our diplomacy
column4: a world that was once divided about how to deal with Iran's nuclear program now stands as one. The regime is more isolated than ever before. Its leaders are faced with crippling sanctions
column5: and as long as they shirk their responsibilities
column6: this pressure will not relent.

column1: Let there be no doubt: America is determined to prevent Iran from getting a nuclear weapon
column2: and I will take no options off the table to achieve that goal. But a peaceful resolution of this issue is still possible
column3: and far better. And if Iran changes course and meets its obligations
column4: it can rejoin the community of nations.

column1: The renewal of American leadership can be felt across the globe. Our oldest alliances in Europe and Asia are stronger than ever. Our ties to the Americas are deeper. Our ironclad commitment--and I mean ironclad--to Israel's security has meant the closest military cooperation between our two countries in history.
We've made it clear that America is a Pacific power
column2: and a new beginning in Burma has lit a new hope. From the coalitions we've built to secure nuclear materials to the missions we've led against hunger and disease
column3: from the blows we've dealt to our enemies to the enduring power of our moral example
column4: America is back.

column1: Anyone who tells you otherwise
column2: anyone who tells you that America is in decline or that our influence has waned
column3: doesn't know what they're talking about. That's not the message we get from leaders around the world who are eager to work with us. That's not how people feel from Tokyo to Berlin
column4: from Cape Town to Rio
column5: where opinions of America are higher than they've been in years. Yes
column6: the world is changing. No
column7: we can't control every event. But America remains the one indispensable nation in world affairs
column8: and as long as I'm President
column9: I intend to keep it that way.

column1: That's why
column2: working with our military leaders
column3: I've proposed a new defense strategy that ensures we maintain the finest military in the world
column4: while saving nearly half a trillion dollars in our budget. To stay one step ahead of our adversaries
column5: I've already sent this Congress legislation that will secure our country from the growing dangers of cyber threats.

column1: Above all
column2: our freedom endures because of the men and women in uniform who defend it. As they come home
column3: we must serve them as well as they've served us. That includes giving them the care and the benefits they have earned
column4: which is why we've increased annual VA spending every year I've been President. And it means enlisting our veterans in the work of rebuilding our Nation.

column1: With the bipartisan support of this Congress
column2: we're providing new tax credits to companies that hire vets. Michelle and Jill Biden have worked with American businesses to secure a pledge of 135
column3: 000 jobs for veterans and their families. And tonight I'm proposing a veterans jobs corps that will help our communities hire veterans as cops and firefighters
column4: so that America is as strong as those who defend her.

column1: Which brings me back to where I began. Those of us who've been sent here to serve can learn a thing or two from the service of our troops. When you put on that uniform
column2: it doesn't matter if you're Black or White
column3: Asian
column4: Latino
column5: Native American; conservative
column6: liberal; rich
column7: poor; gay
column8: straight. When you're marching into battle
column9: you look out for the person next to you or the mission fails. When you're in the thick of the fight
column10: you rise or fall as one unit
column11: serving one Nation
column12: leaving no one behind.

column1: You know
column2: one of my proudest possessions is the flag that the SEAL team took with them on the mission to get bin Laden. On it are each of their names. Some may be Democrats
column3: some may be Republicans
column4: but that doesn't matter. Just like it didn't matter that day in the Situation Room
column5: when I sat next to Bob Gates
column6: a man who was George Bush's Defense Secretary
column7: and Hillary Clinton
column8: a woman who ran against me for President.

column1: All that mattered that day was the mission. No one thought about politics. No one thought about themselves. One of the young men involved in the raid later told me that he didn't deserve credit for the mission. It only succeeded
column2: he said
column3: because every single member of that unit did their job: the pilot who landed the helicopter that spun out of control
column4: the translator who kept others from entering the compound
column5: the troops who separated the women and children from the fight
column6: the SEALs who charged up the stairs. More than that
column7: the mission only succeeded because every member of that unit trusted each other. Because you can't charge up those stairs into darkness and danger unless you know that there's somebody behind you
column8: watching your back.

column1: So it is with America. Each time I look at that flag
column2: I'm reminded that our destiny is stitched together like those 50 stars and those 13 stripes. No one built this country on their own. This Nation is great because we built it together. This Nation is great because we worked as a team. This Nation is great because we get each other's backs. And if we hold fast to that truth
column3: in this moment of trial
column4: there is no challenge too great
column5: no mission too hard. As long as we are joined in common purpose
column6: as long as we maintain our common resolve
column7: our journey moves forward
column8: and our future is hopeful
column9: and the state of our Union will always be strong.

column1: Thank you
column2: God bless you
column3: and God bless the United States of America.@

column1: Barack Obama|Address Before a Joint Session of the Congress on the State of the Union|2013-02-12|@Please
column2: everybody
column3: have a seat. Mr. Speaker
column4: Mr. Vice President
column5: Members of Congress
column6: fellow Americans: Fifty-one years ago
column7: John F. Kennedy declared to this Chamber that "the Constitution makes us not rivals for power
column8: but partners for progress." "It is my task
column9: he said, to report the state of the Union; to improve it is the task of us all."

column1: Tonight
column2: thanks to the grit and determination of the American people
column3: there is much progress to report. After a decade of grinding war
column4: our brave men and women in uniform are coming home. After years of grueling recession
column5: our businesses have created over 6 million new jobs. We buy more American cars than we have in 5 years and less foreign oil than we have in 20. Our housing market is healing
column6: our stock market is rebounding
column7: and consumers
column8: patients
column9: and homeowners enjoy stronger protections than ever before.

column1: So together
column2: we have cleared away the rubble of crisis
column3: and we can say with renewed confidence that the state of our Union is stronger.

column1: But we gather here knowing that there are millions of Americans whose hard work and dedication have not yet been rewarded. Our economy is adding jobs
column2: but too many people still can't find full-time employment. Corporate profits have skyrocketed to alltime highs
column3: but for more than a decade
column4: wages and incomes have barely budged.

column1: It is our generation's task
column2: then
column3: to reignite the true engine of America's economic growth: a rising
column4: thriving middle class.

column1: It is our unfinished task to restore the basic bargain that built this country: the idea that if you work hard and meet your responsibilities
column2: you can get ahead
column3: no matter where you come from
column4: no matter what you look like or who you love.

column1: It is our unfinished task to make sure that this Government works on behalf of the many
column2: and not just the few; that it encourages free enterprise
column3: rewards individual initiative
column4: and opens the doors of opportunity to every child across this great Nation.

column1: The American people don't expect government to solve every problem. They don't expect those of us in this Chamber to agree on every issue. But they do expect us to put the Nation's interests before party. They do expect us to forge reasonable compromise where we can. For they know that America moves forward only when we do so together and that the responsibility of improving this Union remains the task of us all.
Now
column2: our work must begin by making some basic decisions about our budget
column3: decisions that will have a huge impact on the strength of our recovery.

column1: Over the last few years
column2: both parties have worked together to reduce the deficit by more than $2.5 trillion
column3: mostly through spending cuts
column4: but also by raising tax rates on the wealthiest 1 percent of Americans. As a result
column5: we are more than halfway towards the goal of $4 trillion in deficit reduction that economists say we need to stabilize our finances.

column1: Now we need to finish the job. And the question is
column2: how?
Congress passed a law saying that if both parties couldn't agree on a plan to reach our deficit goal
column3: about a trillion dollars' worth of budget cuts would automatically go into effect this year. These sudden
column4: harsh
column5: arbitrary cuts would jeopardize our military readiness. They'd devastate priorities like education and energy and medical research. They would certainly slow our recovery and cost us hundreds of thousands of jobs. And that's why Democrats
column6: Republicans
column7: business leaders
column8: and economists have already said that these cutsknown here in Washington as the sequesterare a really bad idea.

column1: Now
column2: some in Congress have proposed preventing only the defense cuts by making even bigger cuts to things like education and job training
column3: Medicare
column4: and Social Security benefits. That idea is even worse.

column1: Yes
column2: the biggest driver of our long-term debt is the rising cost of health care for an aging population. And those of us who care deeply about programs like Medicare must embrace the need for modest reforms; otherwise
column3: our retirement programs will crowd out the investments we need for our children and jeopardize the promise of a secure retirement for future generations.

column1: But we can't ask senior citizens and working families to shoulder the entire burden of deficit reduction while asking nothing more from the wealthiest and the most powerful. We won't grow the middle class simply by shifting the cost of health care or college onto families that are already struggling or by forcing communities to lay off more teachers and more cops and more firefighters. Most AmericansDemocrats
column2: Republicans
column3: and Independentsunderstand that we can't just cut our way to prosperity. They know that broad-based economic growth requires a balanced approach to deficit reduction
column4: with spending cuts and revenue and with everybody doing their fair share. And that's the approach I offer tonight.

column1: On Medicare
column2: I'm prepared to enact reforms that will achieve the same amount of health care savings by the beginning of the next decade as the reforms proposed by the bipartisan Simpson-Bowles Commission.

column1: Already
column2: the Affordable Care Act is helping to slow the growth of health care costs. And the reforms I'm proposing go even further. We'll reduce taxpayer subsidies to prescription drug companies and ask more from the wealthiest seniors. We'll bring down costs by changing the way our Government pays for Medicare
column3: because our medical bills shouldn't be based on the number of tests ordered or days spent in the hospital; they should be based on the quality of care that our seniors receive. And I am open to additional reforms from both parties
column4: so long as they don't violate the guarantee of a secure retirement. Our Government shouldn't make promises we cannot keep
column5: but we must keep the promises we've already made.

column1: To hit the rest of our deficit reduction target
column2: we should do what leaders in both parties have already suggested and save hundreds of billions of dollars by getting rid of tax loopholes and deductions for the well-off and the well-connected. After all
column3: why would we choose to make deeper cuts to education and Medicare just to protect special interest tax breaks? How is that fair? Why is it that deficit reduction is a big emergency justifying making cuts in Social Security benefits
column4: but not closing some loopholes? How does that promote growth?

column1: Now is our best chance for bipartisan
column2: comprehensive tax reform that encourages job creation and helps bring down the deficit. We can get this done. The American people deserve a Tax Code that helps small businesses spend less time filling out complicated forms and more time expanding and hiring; a Tax Code that ensures billionaires with high-powered accountants can't work the system and pay a lower rate than their hard-working secretaries; a Tax Code that lowers incentives to move jobs overseas and lowers tax rates for businesses and manufacturers that are creating jobs right here in the United States of America. That's what tax reform can deliver. That's what we can do together.

column1: I realize that tax reform and entitlement reform will not be easy. The politics will be hard for both sides. None of us will get a hundred percent of what we want. But the alternative will cost us jobs
column2: hurt our economy
column3: visit hardship on millions of hard-working Americans. So let's set party interests aside and work to pass a budget that replaces reckless cuts with smart savings and wise investments in our future. And let's do it without the brinksmanship that stresses consumers and scares off investors. The greatest nation on Earth cannot keep conducting its business by drifting from one manufactured crisis to the next. We can't do it.

column1: Let's agree right here
column2: right now to keep the people's Government open and pay our bills on time and always uphold the full faith and credit of the United States of America. The American people have worked too hard
column3: for too long
column4: rebuilding from one crisis to see their elected officials cause another.

column1: Now
column2: most of us agree that a plan to reduce the deficit must be part of our agenda. But let's be clear: Deficit reduction alone is not an economic plan. A growing economy that creates good
column3: middle class jobs
column4: that must be the north star that guides our efforts. Every day
column5: we should ask ourselves three questions as a nation: How do we attract more jobs to our shores? How do we equip our people with the skills they need to get those jobs? And how do we make sure that hard work leads to a decent living?

column1: Now
column2: a year and a half ago
column3: I put forward an American Jobs Act that independent economists said would create more than 1 million new jobs. And I thank the last Congress for passing some of that agenda. I urge this Congress to pass the rest. But tonight I'll lay out additional proposals that are fully paid for and fully consistent with the budget framework both parties agreed to just 18 months ago. Let me repeat: Nothing I'm proposing tonight should increase our deficit by a single dime. It is not a bigger Government we need
column4: but a smarter Government that sets priorities and invests in broad-based growth. That's what we should be looking for.

column1: Our first priority is making America a magnet for new jobs and manufacturing. After shedding jobs for more than 10 years
column2: our manufacturers have added about 500
column3: 000 jobs over the past 3. Caterpillar is bringing jobs back from Japan. Ford is bringing jobs back from Mexico. And this year
column4: Apple will start making Macs in America again.

column1: There are things we can do right now to accelerate this trend. Last year
column2: we created our first manufacturing innovation institute in Youngstown
column3: Ohio. A once-shuttered warehouse is now a state-of-the-art lab where new workers are mastering the 3-D printing that has the potential to revolutionize the way we make almost everything. There's no reason this can't happen in other towns.

column1: So tonight I'm announcing the launch of three more of these manufacturing hubs
column2: where businesses will partner with the Department of Defense and Energy to turn regions left behind by globalization into global centers of high-tech jobs. And I ask this Congress to help create a network of 15 of these hubs and guarantee that the next revolution in manufacturing is made right here in America. We can get that done.

column1: Now
column2: if we want to make the best products
column3: we also have to invest in the best ideas. Every dollar we invested to map the human genome returned $140 to our economyevery dollar. Today
column4: our scientists are mapping the human brain to unlock the answers to Alzheimer's. They're developing drugs to regenerate damaged organs
column5: devising new materials to make batteries 10 times more powerful. Now is not the time to gut these job-creating investments in science and innovation
column6: now is the time to reach a level of research and development not seen since the height of the space race. We need to make those investments.

column1: Today
column2: no area holds more promise than our investments in American energy. After years of talking about it
column3: we're finally poised to control our own energy future. We produce more oil at home than we have in 15 years. We have doubled the distance our cars will go on a gallon of gas and the amount of renewable energy we generate from sources like wind and solar
column4: with tens of thousands of good American jobs to show for it. We produce more natural gas than ever before
column5: and nearly everyone's energy bill is lower because of it. And over the last 4 years
column6: our emissions of the dangerous carbon pollution that threatens our planet have actually fallen.

column1: But for the sake of our children and our future
column2: we must do more to combat climate change. Now
column3: it's true that no single event makes a trend. But the fact is
column4: the 12 hottest years on record have all come in the last 15. Heat waves
column5: droughts
column6: wildfires
column7: floodsall are now more frequent and more intense. We can choose to believe that Superstorm Sandy and the most severe drought in decades and the worst wildfires some States have ever seen were all just a freak coincidence. Or we can choose to believe in the overwhelming judgment of science and act before it's too late.

column1: Now
column2: the good news is we can make meaningful progress on this issue while driving strong economic growth. I urge this Congress to get together
column3: pursue a bipartisan
column4: market-based solution to climate change
column5: like the one John McCain and Joe Lieberman worked on together a few years ago. But if Congress won't act soon to protect future generations
column6: I will. I will direct my Cabinet to come up with executive actions we can take
column7: now and in the future
column8: to reduce pollution
column9: prepare our communities for the consequences of climate change
column10: and speed the transition to more sustainable sources of energy.

column1: And 4 years ago
column2: other countries dominated the clean energy market and the jobs that came with it. And we've begun to change that. Last year
column3: wind energy added nearly half of all new power capacity in America. So let's generate even more. Solar energy gets cheaper by the year; let's drive down costs even further. As long as countries like China keep going all in on clean energy
column4: so must we.

column1: Now
column2: in the meantime
column3: the natural gas boom has led to cleaner power and greater energy independence. We need to encourage that. And that's why my administration will keep cutting redtape and speeding up new oil and gas permits. That's got to be part of an all-of-the-above plan. But I also want to work with this Congress to encourage the research and technology that helps natural gas burn even cleaner and protects our air and our water.

column1: In fact
column2: much of our new-found energy is drawn from lands and waters that we
column3: the public
column4: own together. So tonight I propose we use some of our oil and gas revenues to fund an energy security trust that will drive new research and technology to shift our cars and trucks off oil for good. If a nonpartisan coalition of CEOs and retired generals and admirals can get behind this idea
column5: then so can we. Let's take their advice and free our families and businesses from the painful spikes in gas prices we've put up with for far too long.

column1: I'm also issuing a new goal for America: Let's cut in half the energy wasted by our homes and businesses over the next 20 years. We'll work with the States to do it. Those States with the best ideas to create jobs and lower energy bills by constructing more efficient buildings will receive Federal support to help make that happen.
America's energy sector is just one part of an aging infrastructure badly in need of repair. Ask any CEO where they'd rather locate and hire
column2: a country with deteriorating roads and bridges or one with high-speed rail and Internet
column3: high-tech schools
column4: self-healing power grids. The CEO of Siemens Americaa company that brought hundreds of new jobs to North Carolinasaid that if we upgrade our infrastructure
column5: they'll bring even more jobs. And that's the attitude of a lot of companies all around the world. And I know you want these job-creating projects in your district. I've seen all those ribbon-cuttings.

column1: So tonight I propose a Fix-It-First program to put people to work as soon as possible on our most urgent repairs
column2: like the nearly 70
column3: 000 structurally deficient bridges across the country. And to make sure taxpayers don't shoulder the whole burden
column4: I'm also proposing a partnership to rebuild America that attracts private capital to upgrade what our businesses need most: modern ports to move our goods
column5: modern pipelines to withstand a storm
column6: modern schools worthy of our children. Let's prove there's no better place to do business than here in the United States of America
column7: and let's start right away. We can get this done.

column1: And part of our rebuilding effort must also involve our housing sector. The good news is
column2: our housing market is finally healing from the collapse of 2007. Home prices are rising at the fastest pace in 6 years. Home purchases are up nearly 50 percent
column3: and construction is expanding again.

column1: But even with mortgage rates near a 50-year low
column2: too many families with solid credit who want to buy a home are being rejected. Too many families who never missed a payment and want to refinance are being told no. That's holding our entire economy back. We need to fix it.

column1: Right now there's a bill in this Congress that would give every responsible homeowner in America the chance to save $3
column2: 000 a year by refinancing at today's rates. Democrats and Republicans have supported it before
column3: so what are we waiting for? Take a vote and send me that bill. Why arewhy would we be against that? Why would that be a partisan issue
column4: helping folks refinance? Right now overlapping regulations keep responsible young families from buying their first home. What's holding us back? Let's streamline the process and help our economy grow.

column1: These initiatives in manufacturing
column2: energy
column3: infrastructure
column4: housing
column5: all these things will help entrepreneurs and small-business owners expand and create new jobs. But none of it will matter unless we also equip our citizens with the skills and training to fill those jobs.

column1: And that has to start at the earliest possible age. Study after study shows that the sooner a child begins learning
column2: the better he or she does down the road. But today
column3: fewer than 3 in 10 4-year-olds are enrolled in a high-quality preschool program. Most middle class parents can't afford a few hundred bucks a week for a private preschool. And for poor kids who need help the most
column4: this lack of access to preschool education can shadow them for the rest of their lives. So tonight I propose working with States to make high-quality preschool available to every single child in America. That's something we should be able to do.

column1: Every dollar we invest in high-quality early childhood education can save more than 7 dollars later on: by boosting graduation rates
column2: reducing teen pregnancy
column3: even reducing violent crime. In States that make it a priority to educate our youngest children
column4: like Georgia or Oklahoma
column5: studies show students grow up more likely to read and do math at grade level
column6: graduate high school
column7: hold a job
column8: form more stable families of their own. We know this works. So let's do what works and make sure none of our children start the race of life already behind. Let's give our kids that chance.

column1: Let's also make sure that a high school diploma puts our kids on a path to a good job. Right now countries like Germany focus on graduating their high school students with the equivalent of a technical degree from one of our community colleges. So those German kids
column2: they're ready for a job when they graduate high school. They've been trained for the jobs that are there. Now at schools like P-TECH in Brooklyn
column3: a collaboration between New York Public Schools and City University of New York and IBM
column4: students will graduate with a high school diploma and an associate's degree in computers or engineering. We need to give every American student opportunities like this.

column1: And 4 years ago
column2: we started Race to the Top
column3: a competition that convinced almost every State to develop smarter curricula and higher standards
column4: all for about 1 percent of what we spend on education each year. Tonight I'm announcing a new challenge to redesign America's high schools so they better equip graduates for the demands of a high-tech economy. And we'll reward schools that develop new partnerships with colleges and employers and create classes that focus on science
column5: technology
column6: engineering
column7: and math: the skills today's employers are looking for to fill the jobs that are there right now and will be there in the future.

column1: Now
column2: even with better high schools
column3: most young people will need some higher education. It's a simple fact: The more education you've got
column4: the more likely you are to have a good job and work your way into the middle class. But today
column5: skyrocketing costs price too many young people out of a higher education or saddle them with unsustainable debt.

column1: Through tax credits
column2: grants
column3: and better loans
column4: we've made college more affordable for millions of students and families over the last few years. But taxpayers can't keep on subsidizing higher and higher and higher costs for higher education. Colleges must do their part to keep costs down
column5: and it's our job to make sure that they do.

column1: So tonight I ask Congress to change the Higher Education Act so that affordability and value are included in determining which colleges receive certain types of Federal aid. And tomorrow my administration will release a new college scorecard that parents and students can use to compare schools based on a simple criterion: where you can get the most bang for your educational buck.
Now
column2: to grow our middle class
column3: our citizens have to have access to the education and training that today's jobs require. But we also have to make sure that America remains a place where everyone who's willing to workeverybody who's willing to work hardhas the chance to get ahead.

column1: Our economy is stronger when we harness the talents and ingenuity of striving
column2: hopeful immigrants. And right now leaders from the business
column3: labor
column4: law enforcement
column5: faith communities
column6: they all agree that the time has come to pass comprehensive immigration reform. Now is the time to do it. Now is the time to get it done.  Now is the time to get it done.

column1: Real reform means stronger border security
column2: and we can build on the progress my administration has already made: putting more boots on the southern border than at any time in our history and reducing illegal crossings to their lowest levels in 40 years.

column1: Real reform means establishing a responsible pathway to earned citizenship
column2: a path that includes passing a background check
column3: paying taxes and a meaningful penalty
column4: learning English
column5: and going to the back of the line behind the folks trying to come here legally.

column1: And real reform means fixing the legal immigration system to cut waiting periods and attract the highly skilled entrepreneurs and engineers that will help create jobs and grow our economy.
In other words
column2: we know what needs to be done. And as we speak
column3: bipartisan groups in both Chambers are working diligently to draft a bill
column4: and I applaud their efforts. So let's get this done. Send me a comprehensive immigration reform bill in the next few months
column5: and I will sign it right away. And America will be better for it. Let's get it done.  Let's get it done.

column1: But we can't stop there. We know our economy is stronger when our wives
column2: our mothers
column3: our daughters can live their lives free from discrimination in the workplace and free from the fear of domestic violence. Today the Senate passed the "Violence Against Women's Act" that Joe Biden originally wrote almost 20 years ago. And I now urge the House to do the same. Good job
column4: Joe. And I ask this Congress to declare that women should earn a living equal to their efforts
column5: and finally pass the "Paycheck Fairness Act" this year.

column1: We know our economy is stronger when we reward an honest day's work with honest wages. But today
column2: a full-time worker making the minimum wage earns $14
column3: 500 a year. Even with the tax relief we put in place
column4: a family with two kids that earns the minimum wage still lives below the poverty line. That's wrong. That's why
column5: since the last time this Congress raised the minimum wage
column6: 19 States have chosen to bump theirs even higher.

column1: Tonight let's declare that in the wealthiest nation on Earth
column2: no one who works full-time should have to live in poverty and raise the Federal minimum wage to $9 an hour. We should be able to get that done.

column1: This single step would raise the incomes of millions of working families. It could mean the difference between groceries or the food bank
column2: rent or eviction
column3: scraping by or finally getting ahead. For businesses across the country
column4: it would mean customers with more money in their pockets. And a whole lot of folks out there would probably need less help from government. In fact
column5: working folks shouldn't have to wait year after year for the minimum wage to go up while CEO pay has never been higher. So here's an idea that Governor Romney and I actually agreed on last year: Let's tie the minimum wage to the cost of living so that it finally becomes a wage you can live on.

column1: Tonight let's also recognize that there are communities in this country where no matter how hard you work
column2: it is virtually impossible to get ahead: factory towns decimated from years of plants packing up; inescapable pockets of poverty
column3: urban and rural
column4: where young adults are still fighting for their first job. America is not a place where the chance of birth or circumstance should decide our destiny. And that's why we need to build new ladders of opportunity into the middle class for all who are willing to climb them.

column1: Let's offer incentives to companies that hire Americans who've got what it takes to fill that job opening
column2: but have been out of work so long that no one will give them a chance anymore. Let's put people back to work rebuilding vacant homes in rundown neighborhoods. And this year
column3: my administration will begin to partner with 20 of the hardest hit towns in America to get these communities back on their feet. Now
column4: we'll work with local leaders to target resources at public safety and education and housing.

column1: We'll give new tax credits to businesses that hire and invest. And we'll work to strengthen families by removing the financial deterrents to marriage for low-income couples and do more to encourage fatherhood
column2: because what makes you a man isn't the ability to conceive a child
column3: it's having the courage to raise one. And we want to encourage that. We want to help that.

column1: Stronger families. Stronger communities. A stronger America. It is this kind of prosperitybroad
column2: shared
column3: built on a thriving middle classthat has always been the source of our progress at home. It's also the foundation of our power and influence throughout the world.

column1: Tonight we stand united in saluting the troops and civilians who sacrifice every day to protect us. Because of them
column2: we can say with confidence that America will complete its mission in Afghanistan and achieve our objective of defeating the core of Al Qaida.

column1: Already
column2: we have brought home 33
column3: 000 of our brave service men and women. This spring
column4: our forces will move into a support role
column5: while Afghan security forces take the lead. Tonight I can announce that over the next year
column6: another 34
column7: 000 American troops will come home from Afghanistan. This drawdown will continue
column8: and by the end of next year
column9: our war in Afghanistan will be over.

column1: Beyond 2014
column2: America's commitment to a unified and sovereign Afghanistan will endure
column3: but the nature of our commitment will change. We're negotiating an agreement with the Afghan Government that focuses on two missions: training and equipping Afghan forces so that the country does not again slip into chaos and counterterrorism efforts that allow us to pursue the remnants of Al Qaida and their affiliates.

column1: Today
column2: the organization that attacked us on 9/11 is a shadow of its former self. It's true
column3: different Al Qaida affiliates and extremist groups have emerged
column4: from the Arabian Peninsula to Africa. The threat these groups pose is evolving. But to meet this threat
column5: we don't need to send tens of thousands of our sons and daughters abroad or occupy other nations. Instead
column6: we'll need to help countries like Yemen and Libya and Somalia provide for their own security and help allies who take the fight to terrorists
column7: as we have in Mali. And where necessary
column8: through a range of capabilities
column9: we will continue to take direct action against those terrorists who pose the gravest threat to Americans.

column1: Now
column2: as we do
column3: we must enlist our values in the fight. That's why my administration has worked tirelessly to forge a durable legal and policy framework to guide our counterterrorism efforts. Throughout
column4: we have kept Congress fully informed of our efforts. I recognize that in our democracy
column5: no one should just take my word for it that we're doing things the right way. So
column6: in the months ahead
column7: I will continue to engage Congress to ensure not only that our targeting
column8: detention
column9: and prosecution of terrorists remains consistent with our laws and system of checks and balances
column10: but that our efforts are even more transparent to the American people and to the world.

column1: Of course
column2: our challenges don't end with Al Qaida. America will continue to lead the effort to prevent the spread of the world's most dangerous weapons. The regime in North Korea must know they will only achieve security and prosperity by meeting their international obligations. Provocations of the sort we saw last night will only further isolate them
column3: as we stand by our allies
column4: strengthen our own missile defense
column5: and lead the world in taking firm action in response to these threats.

column1: Likewise
column2: the leaders of Iran must recognize that now is the time for a diplomatic solution
column3: because a coalition stands united in demanding that they meet their obligations
column4: and we will do what is necessary to prevent them from getting a nuclear weapon.

column1: At the same time
column2: we'll engage Russia to seek further reductions in our nuclear arsenals and continue leading the global effort to secure nuclear materials that could fall into the wrong hands
column3: because our ability to influence others depends on our willingness to lead and meet our obligations.

column1: America must also face the rapidly growing threat from cyber attacks. Now
column2: we know hackers steal people's identities and infiltrate private e-mails. We know foreign countries and companies swipe our corporate secrets. Now our enemies are also seeking the ability to sabotage our power grid
column3: our financial institutions
column4: our air traffic control systems. We cannot look back years from now and wonder why we did nothing in the face of real threats to our security and our economy.

column1: And that's why
column2: earlier today
column3: I signed a new Executive order that will strengthen our cyber defenses by increasing information sharing and developing standards to protect our national security
column4: our jobs
column5: and our privacy.

column1: But now Congress must act as well
column2: by passing legislation to give our Government a greater capacity to secure our networks and deter attacks. This is something we should be able to get done on a bipartisan basis.

column1: Now
column2: even as we protect our people
column3: we should remember that today's world presents not just dangers
column4: not just threats
column5: it presents opportunities. To boost American exports
column6: support American jobs and level the playing field in the growing markets of Asia
column7: we intend to complete negotiations on a Trans-Pacific Partnership. And tonight I'm announcing that we will launch talks on a comprehensive transatlantic trade and investment partnership with the European Union
column8: because trade that is fair and free across the Atlantic supports millions of good-paying American jobs.

column1: We also know that progress in the most impoverished parts of our world enriches us all
column2: not only because it creates new markets
column3: more stable order in certain regions of the world
column4: but also because it's the right thing to do. In many places
column5: people live on little more than a dollar a day. So the United States will join with our allies to eradicate such extreme poverty in the next two decades by connecting more people to the global economy
column6: by empowering women
column7: by giving our young and brightest minds new opportunities to serve and helping communities to feed and power and educate themselves
column8: by saving the world's children from preventable deaths
column9: and by realizing the promise of an AIDS-free generation
column10: which is within our reach.

column1: You see
column2: America must remain a beacon to all who seek freedom during this period of historic change. I saw the power of hope last year in Rangoon
column3: in Burma
column4: when Aung San Suu Kyi welcomed an American President into the home where she had been imprisoned for years; when thousands of Burmese lined the streets
column5: waving American flags
column6: including a man who said: "There is justice and law in the United States. I want our country to be like that."

column1: In defense of freedom
column2: we'll remain the anchor of strong alliances from the Americas to Africa
column3: from Europe to Asia. In the Middle East
column4: we will stand with citizens as they demand their universal rights and support stable transitions to democracy.

column1: We know the process will be messy
column2: and we cannot presume to dictate the course of change in countries like Egypt
column3: but we can and will insist on respect for the fundamental rights of all people. We'll keep the pressure on a Syrian regime that has murdered its own people and support opposition leaders that respect the rights of every Syrian. And we will stand steadfast with Israel in pursuit of security and a lasting peace.

column1: These are the messages I'll deliver when I travel to the Middle East next month. And all this work depends on the courage and sacrifice of those who serve in dangerous places at great personal risk: our diplomats
column2: our intelligence officers
column3: and the men and women of the United States Armed Forces. As long as I'm Commander in Chief
column4: we will do whatever we must to protect those who serve their country abroad
column5: and we will maintain the best military the world has ever known.

column1: We'll invest in new capabilities
column2: even as we reduce waste and wartime spending. We will ensure equal treatment for all servicemembers and equal benefits for their families
column3: gay and straight. We will draw upon the courage and skills of our sisters and daughters and moms
column4: because women have proven under fire that they are ready for combat.

column1: We will keep faith with our veterans
column2: investing in world-class careincluding mental health carefor our wounded warriors
column3: supporting our military families
column4: giving our veterans the benefits and education and job opportunities that they have earned. And I want to thank my wife Michelle and Dr. Jill Biden for their continued dedication to serving our military families as well as they have served us. Thank you
column5: honey. Thank you
column6: Jill.

column1: Defending our freedom
column2: though
column3: is not just the job of our military alone. We must all do our part to make sure our God-given rights are protected here at home. That includes one of the most fundamental rights of a democracy: the right to vote. Now
column4: when any American
column5: no matter where they live or what their party
column6: are denied that right because they can't afford to wait for 5 or 6 or 7 hours just to cast their ballot
column7: we are betraying our ideals.

column1: So tonight I'm announcing a nonpartisan commission to improve the voting experience in America. And it definitely needs improvement. I'm asking two long-time experts in the fieldwho
column2: by the way
column3: recently served as the top attorneys for my campaign and for Governor Romney's campaignto lead it. We can fix this
column4: and we will. The American people demand it
column5: and so does our democracy.

column1: Of course
column2: what I've said tonight matters little if we don't come together to protect our most precious resource: our children. It has been 2 months since Newtown. I know this is not the first time this country has debated how to reduce gun violence. But this time is different. Overwhelming majorities of AmericansAmericans who believe in the Second Amendmenthave come together around commonsense reform
column3: like background checks that will make it harder for criminals to get their hands on a gun. Senators of both parties are working together on tough new laws to prevent anyone from buying guns for resale to criminals. Police chiefs are asking our help to get weapons of war and massive ammunition magazines off our streets
column4: because these police chiefs
column5: they're tired of seeing their guys and gals being outgunned.

column1: Each of these proposals deserves a vote in Congress. Now
column2: if you want to vote no
column3: that's your choice. But these proposals deserve a vote. Because in the 2 months since Newtown
column4: more than a thousand birthdays
column5: graduations
column6: anniversaries have been stolen from our lives by a bullet from a gunmore than a thousand.

column1: One of those we lost was a young girl named Hadiya Pendleton. She was 15 years old. She loved Fig Newtons and lip gloss. She was a majorette. She was so good to her friends
column2: they all thought they were her best friend. Just 3 weeks ago
column3: she was here
column4: in Washington
column5: with her classmates
column6: performing for her country at my Inauguration. And a week later
column7: she was shot and killed in a Chicago park after school
column8: just a mile away from my house.

column1: Hadiya's parents
column2: Nate and Cleo
column3: are in this Chamber tonight
column4: along with more than two dozen Americans whose lives have been torn apart by gun violence. They deserve a vote. They deserve a vote.  They deserve a vote. Gabby Giffords deserves a vote. The families of Newtown deserve a vote. The families of Aurora deserve a vote. The families of Oak Creek and Tucson and Blacksburg
column5: and the countless other communities ripped open by gun violence
column6: they deserve a simple vote. They deserve a simple vote.

column1: Our actions will not prevent every senseless act of violence in this country. In fact
column2: no laws
column3: no initiatives
column4: no administrative acts will perfectly solve all the challenges I've outlined tonight. But we were never sent here to be perfect. We were sent here to make what difference we can
column5: to secure this Nation
column6: expand opportunity
column7: uphold our ideals through the hard
column8: often frustrating
column9: but absolutely necessary work of self-government.

column1: We were sent here to look out for our fellow Americans the same way they look out for one another
column2: every single day
column3: usually without fanfare
column4: all across this country. We should follow their example.

column1: We should follow the example of a New York City nurse named Menchu Sanchez. When Hurricane Sandy plunged her hospital into darkness
column2: she wasn't thinking about how her own home was faring. Her mind was on the 20 precious newborns in her care and the rescue plan she devised that kept them all safe.

column1: We should follow the example of a North Miami woman named Desiline Victor. When Desiline arrived at her polling place
column2: she was told the wait to vote might be 6 hours. And as time ticked by
column3: her concern was not with her tired body or aching feet
column4: but whether folks like her would get to have their say. And hour after hour
column5: a throng of people stayed in line to support her
column6: because Desiline is 102 years old. And they erupted in cheers when she finally put on a sticker that read
column7: "I voted."  There's Desiline.

column1: We should follow the example of a police officer named Brian Murphy. When a gunman opened fire on a Sikh temple in Wisconsin and Brian was the first to arriveand he did not consider his own safety. He fought back until help arrived and ordered his fellow officers to protect the safety of the Americans worshiping inside
column2: even as he lay bleeding from 12 bullet wounds. And when asked how he did that
column3: Brian said
column4: "That's just the way we're made."

column1: That's just the way we're made. We may do different jobs and wear different uniforms and hold different views than the person beside us. But as Americans
column2: we all share the same proud title: We are citizens. It's a word that doesn't just describe our nationality or legal status. It describes the way we're made. It describes what we believe. It captures the enduring idea that this country only works when we accept certain obligations to one another and to future generations; that our rights are wrapped up in the rights of others; and that well into our third century as a nation
column3: it remains the task of us all
column4: as citizens of these United States
column5: to be the authors of the next great chapter of our American story.

column1: Thank you. God bless you
column2: and God bless these United States of America.@

column1: Barack Obama|Address Before a Joint Session of the Congress on the State of the Union|2014-01-28|@Mr. Speaker
column2: Mr. Vice President
column3: Members of Congress
column4: my fellow Americans: Today in America
column5: a teacher spent extra time with a student who needed it and did her part to lift America's graduation rate to its highest levels in more than three decades. An entrepreneur flipped on the lights in her tech startup and did her part to add to the more than 8 million new jobs our businesses have created over the past 4 years. An autoworker fine-tuned some of the best
column6: most fuel-efficient cars in the world and did his part to help America wean itself off foreign oil.

column1: A farmer prepared for the spring after the strongest 5-year stretch of farm exports in our history. A rural doctor gave a young child the first prescription to treat asthma that his mother could afford. A man took the bus home from the graveyard shift
column2: bone-tired
column3: but dreaming big dreams for his son. And in tight-knit communities all across America
column4: fathers and mothers will tuck in their kids
column5: put an arm around their spouse
column6: remember fallen comrades
column7: and give thanks for being home from a war that after 12 long years is finally coming to an end.

column1: Tonight this Chamber speaks with one voice to the people we represent: It is you
column2: our citizens
column3: who make the state of our Union strong.

column1: And here are the results of your efforts: the lowest unemployment rate in over 5 years; a rebounding housing market; a manufacturing sector that's adding jobs for the first time since the 1990s; more oil produced at home than we buy from the rest of the world
column2: the first time that's happened in nearly 20 years; our deficits cut by more than half. And for the first time in over a decade
column3: business leaders around the world have declared that China is no longer the world's number-one place to invest
column4: America is.

column1: That's why I believe this can be a breakthrough year for America. After 5 years of grit and determined effort
column2: the United States is better positioned for the 21st century than any other nation on Earth.

column1: The question for everyone in this Chamber
column2: running through every decision we make this year
column3: is whether we are going to help or hinder this progress. For several years now
column4: this town has been consumed by a rancorous argument over the proper size of the Federal Government. It's an important debate
column5: one that dates back to our very founding. But when that debate prevents us from carrying out even the most basic functions of our democracywhen our differences shut down Government or threaten the full faith and credit of the United Statesthen we are not doing right by the American people.

column1: Now
column2: as President
column3: I'm committed to making Washington work better and rebuilding the trust of the people who sent us here. And I believe most of you are too. Last month
column4: thanks to the work of Democrats and Republicans
column5: Congress finally produced a budget that undoes some of last year's severe cuts to priorities like education. Nobody got everything they wanted
column6: and we can still do more to invest in this country's future while bringing down our deficit in a balanced way
column7: but the budget compromise should leave us freer to focus on creating new jobs
column8: not creating new crises.

column1: And in the coming months
column2: let's see where else we can make progress together. Let's make this a year of action. That's what most Americans want: for all of us in this Chamber to focus on their lives
column3: their hopes
column4: their aspirations. And what I believe unites the people of this Nationregardless of race or region or party
column5: young or old
column6: rich or pooris the simple
column7: profound belief in opportunity for all: the notion that if you work hard and take responsibility
column8: you can get ahead in America.

column1: Now
column2: let's face it
column3: that belief has suffered some serious blows. Over more than three decades
column4: even before the great recession hit
column5: massive shifts in technology and global competition had eliminated a lot of good
column6: middle class jobs and weakened the economic foundations that families depend on.

column1: Today
column2: after 4 years of economic growth
column3: corporate profits and stock prices have rarely been higher
column4: and those at the top have never done better. But average wages have barely budged. Inequality has deepened. Upward mobility has stalled. The cold
column5: hard fact is that even in the midst of recovery
column6: too many Americans are working more than ever just to get by
column7: let alone to get ahead. And too many still aren't working at all.

column1: So our job is to reverse these trends. It won't happen right away
column2: and we won't agree on everything. But what I offer tonight is a set of concrete
column3: practical proposals to speed up growth
column4: strengthen the middle class
column5: and build new ladders of opportunity into the middle class. Some require congressional action
column6: and I am eager to work with all of you. But America does not stand still
column7: and neither will I. So wherever and whenever I can take steps without legislation to expand opportunity for more American families
column8: that's what I'm going to do.

column1: As usual
column2: our First Lady sets a good example.  Well ... Michelle's "Let's Move!" partnership with schools
column3: businesses
column4: local leaders has helped bring down childhood obesity rates for the first time in 30 years. And that's an achievement that will improve lives and reduce health care costs for decades to come. The Joining Forces alliance that Michelle and Jill Biden launched has already encouraged employers to hire or train nearly 400
column5: 000 veterans and military spouses.

column1: Taking a page from that playbook
column2: the White House just organized a College Opportunity Summit
column3: where already
column4: 150 universities
column5: businesses
column6: nonprofits have made concrete commitments to reduce inequality in access to higher education and to help every hard-working kid go to college and succeed when they get to campus. And across the country
column7: we're partnering with mayors
column8: Governors
column9: and State legislatures on issues from homelessness to marriage equality.

column1: The point is
column2: there are millions of Americans outside of Washington who are tired of stale political arguments and are moving this country forward. They believeand I believethat here in America
column3: our success should depend not on accident of birth
column4: but the strength of our work ethic and the scope of our dreams. That's what drew our forebears here. That's how the daughter of a factory worker is CEO of America's largest automaker; how the son of a barkeep is Speaker of the House; how the son of a single mom can be President of the greatest nation on Earth.

column1: Opportunity is who we are. And the defining project of our generation must be to restore that promise. We know where to start: The best measure of opportunity is access to a good job. With the economy picking up speed
column2: companies say they intend to hire more people this year. And over half of big manufacturers say they're thinking of insourcing jobs from abroad.

column1: So let's make that decision easier for more companies. Both Democrats and Republicans have argued that our Tax Code is riddled with wasteful
column2: complicated loopholes that punish businesses investing here and reward companies that keep profits abroad. Let's flip that equation. Let's work together to close those loopholes
column3: end those incentives to ship jobs overseas
column4: and lower tax rates for businesses that create jobs right here at home.

column1: Moreover
column2: we can take the money we save from this transition to tax reform to create jobs rebuilding our roads
column3: upgrading our ports
column4: unclogging our commutes
column5: because in today's global economy
column6: first-class jobs gravitate to first-class infrastructure. We'll need Congress to protect more than 3 million jobs by finishing transportation and waterways bills this summer. That can happen. But I'll act on my own to slash bureaucracy and streamline the permitting process for key projects so we can get more construction workers on the job as fast as possible.

column1: We also have the chance
column2: right now
column3: to beat other countries in the race for the next wave of high-tech manufacturing jobs. My administration has launched two hubs for high-tech manufacturing in Raleigh
column4: North Carolina
column5: and Youngstown
column6: Ohio
column7: where we've connected businesses to research universities that can help America lead the world in advanced technologies. Tonight I'm announcing
column8: we'll launch six more this year. Bipartisan bills in both Houses could double the number of these hubs and the jobs they create. So get those bills to my desk. Put more Americans back to work.

column1: Let's do more to help the entrepreneurs and small-business owners who create most new jobs in America. Over the past 5 years
column2: my administration has made more loans to small-business owners than any other. And when 98 percent of our exporters are small businesses
column3: new trade partnerships with Europe and Asiathe Asia-Pacific will help them create more jobs. We need to work together on tools like bipartisan trade promotion authority to protect our workers
column4: protect our environment
column5: and open new markets to new goods stamped "Made in the U.S.A."

column1: Listen
column2: China and Europe aren't standing on the sidelines
column3: and neither should we. We know that the nation that goes all-in on innovation today will own the global economy tomorrow. This is an edge America cannot surrender. Federally funded research helped lead to the ideas and inventions behind Google and smartphones. And that's why Congress should undo the damage done by last year's cuts to basic research so we can unleash the next great American discovery. There are entire industries to be built based on vaccines that stay ahead of drug-resistant bacteria or paper-thin material that's stronger than steel. And let's pass a patent reform bill that allows our businesses to stay focused on innovation
column4: not costly and needless litigation.

column1: Now
column2: one of the biggest factors in bringing more jobs back is our commitment to American energy. The all-of-the-above energy strategy I announced a few years ago is working
column3: and today
column4: America is closer to energy independence than we have been in decades.

column1: One of the reasons why is natural gas. If extracted safely
column2: it's the bridge fuel that can power our economy with less of the carbon pollution that causes climate change. Businesses plan to invest almost $100 billion in new factories that use natural gas. I'll cut redtape to help States get those factories built and put folks to work
column3: and this Congress can help by putting people to work building fueling stations that shift more cars and trucks from foreign oil to American natural gas.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: my administration will keep working with the industry to sustain production and jobs growth while strengthening protection of our air
column3: our water
column4: our communities. And while we're at it
column5: I'll use my authority to protect more of our pristine Federal lands for future generations.

column1: Well
column2: it's not just oil and natural gas production that's booming
column3: we're becoming a global leader in solar too. Every 4 minutes
column4: another American home or business goes solar
column5: every panel pounded into place by a worker whose job cannot be outsourced. Let's continue that progress with a smarter tax policy that stops giving $4 billion a year to fossil fuel industries that don't need it so we can invest more in fuels of the future that do.

column1: And even as we've increased energy production
column2: we've partnered with businesses
column3: builders
column4: and local communities to reduce the energy we consume. When we rescued our automakers
column5: for example
column6: we worked with them to set higher fuel efficiency standards for our cars. In the coming months
column7: I'll build on that success by setting new standards for our trucks so we can keep driving down oil imports and what we pay at the pump.

column1: And taken together
column2: our energy policy is creating jobs and leading to a cleaner
column3: safer planet. Over the past 8 years
column4: the United States has reduced our total carbon pollution more than any other nation on Earth. But we have to act with more urgency
column5: because a changing climate is already harming Western communities struggling with drought and coastal cities dealing with floods. That's why I directed my administration to work with States
column6: utilities
column7: and others to set new standards on the amount of carbon pollution our power plants are allowed to dump into the air.

column1: The shift to a cleaner energy economy won't happen overnight
column2: and it will require some tough choices along the way. But the debate is settled. Climate change is a fact. And when our children's children look us in the eye and ask if we did all we could to leave them a safer
column3: more stable world
column4: with new sources of energy
column5: I want us to be able to say
column6: yes
column7: we did.

column1: Finally
column2: if we're serious about economic growth
column3: it is time to heed the call of business leaders
column4: labor leaders
column5: faith leaders
column6: law enforcement and fix our broken immigration system. Republicans and Democrats in the Senate have acted
column7: and I know that members of both parties in the House want to do the same. Independent economists say immigration reform will grow our economy and shrink our deficits by almost $1 trillion in the next two decades. And for good reason: When people come here to fulfill their dreamsto study
column8: invent
column9: contribute to our culturethey make our country a more attractive place for businesses to locate and create jobs for everybody. So let's get immigration reform done this year.  Let's get it done. It's time.

column1: The ideas I've outlined so far can speed up growth and create more jobs. But in this rapidly changing economy
column2: we have to make sure that every American has the skills to fill those jobs. The good news is
column3: we know how to do it.

column1: Two years ago
column2: as the auto industry came roaring back
column3: Andra Rush opened up a manufacturing firm in Detroit. She knew that Ford needed parts for the best selling truck in America
column4: and she knew how to make those parts. She just needed the workforce. So she dialed up what we call an American Job Center
column5: places where folks can walk in to get the help or training they need to find a new job or a better job. She was flooded with new workers. And today
column6: Detroit Manufacturing Systems has more than 700 employees. And what Andra and her employees experienced is how it should be for every employer and every job seeker.

column1: So tonight I've asked Vice President Biden to lead an across-the-board reform of America's training programs to make sure they have one mission: train Americans with the skills employers need and match them to good jobs that need to be filled right now. That means more on-the-job training and more apprenticeships that set a young worker on an upward trajectory for life. It means connecting companies to community colleges that can help design training to fill their specific needs. And if Congress wants to help
column2: you can concentrate funding on proven programs that connect more ready-to-work Americans with ready-to-be-filled jobs.

column1: I'm also convinced we can help Americans return to the workforce faster by reforming unemployment insurance so that it's more effective in today's economy. But first
column2: this Congress needs to restore the unemployment insurance you just let expire for 1.6 million people.

column1: Let me tell you why. Misty DeMars is a mother of two young boys. She'd been steadily employed since she was a teenager
column2: put herself through college. She'd never collected unemployment benefits
column3: but she'd been paying taxes. In May
column4: she and her husband used their life savings to buy their first home. A week later
column5: budget cuts claimed the job she loved. Last month
column6: when their unemployment insurance was cut off
column7: she sat down and wrote me a letter
column8: the kind I get every day. "We are the face of the unemployment crisis
column9: she wrote. I'm not dependent on the government. Our country depends on people like us who build careers
column10: contribute to society
column11: care about our neighbors. I'm confident that in time
column12: I will find a job
column13: I will pay my taxes
column14: and we will raise our children in their own home in the community we love. Please give us this chance."

column1: Congress
column2: give these hard-working
column3: responsible Americans that chance. Give them that chance.  Give them the chance. They need our help right now. But more important
column4: this country needs them in the game. That's why I've been asking CEOs to give more long-term unemployed workers a fair shot at new jobs
column5: a new chance to support their families. And in fact
column6: this week
column7: many will come to the White House to make that commitment real. Tonight I ask every business leader in America to join us and to do the same
column8: because we are stronger when America fields a full team.

column1: Of course
column2: it's not enough to train today's workforce. We also have to prepare tomorrow's workforce
column3: by guaranteeing every child access to a world-class education. Estiven Rodriguez couldn't speak a word of English when he moved to New York City at age 9. But last month
column4: thanks to the support of great teachers and an innovative tutoring program
column5: he led a march of his classmates through a crowd of cheering parents and neighbors from their high school to the post office
column6: where they mailed off their college applications. And this son of a factory worker just found out
column7: he's going to college this fall.

column1: Five years ago
column2: we set out to change the odds for all our kids. We worked with lenders to reform student loans
column3: and today
column4: more young people are earning college degrees than ever before. Race to the Top
column5: with the help of Governors from both parties
column6: has helped States raise expectations and performance. Teachers and principals in schools from Tennessee to Washington
column7: DC
column8: are making big strides in preparing students with the skills for the new economy: problem solving
column9: critical thinking
column10: science
column11: technology
column12: engineering
column13: math.

column1: Now
column2: some of this change is hard. It requires everything from more challenging curriculums and more demanding parents to better support for teachers and new ways to measure how well our kids think
column3: not how well they can fill in a bubble on a test. But it is worth it
column4: and it is working. The problem is
column5: we're still not reaching enough kids
column6: and we're not reaching them in time. And that has to change.

column1: Research shows that one of the best investments we can make in a child's life is high-quality early education. Last year
column2: I asked this Congress to help States make high-quality pre-K available to every 4-year-old. And as a parent as well as a President
column3: I repeat that request tonight. But in the meantime
column4: 30 States have raised pre-K funding on their own. They know we can't wait. So just as we worked with States to reform our schools
column5: this year
column6: we'll invest in new partnerships with States and communities across the country in a Race to the Top for our youngest children. And as Congress decides what it's going to do
column7: I'm going to pull together a coalition of elected officials
column8: business leaders
column9: and philanthropists willing to help more kids access the high-quality pre-K that they need. It is right for America. We need to get this done.

column1: Last year
column2: I also pledged to connect 99 percent of our students to high-speed broadband over the next 4 years. Tonight I can announce that with the support of the FCC and companies like Apple
column3: Microsoft
column4: Sprint
column5: and Verizon
column6: we've got a down payment to start connecting more than 15
column7: 000 schools and 20 million students over the next 2 years
column8: without adding a dime to the deficit.

column1: We're working to redesign high schools and partner them with colleges and employers that offer the real-world education and hands-on training that can lead directly to a job and career. We're shaking up our system of higher education to give parents more information and colleges more incentive to offer better value so that no middle class kid is priced out of a college education.
We're offering millions the opportunity to cap their monthly student loan payments to 10 percent of their income
column2: and I want to work with Congress to see how we can help even more Americans who feel trapped by student loan debt. And I'm reaching out to some of America's leading foundations and corporations on a new initiative to help more young men of color facing especially tough odds to stay on track and reach their full potential.

column1: The bottom line is
column2: Michelle and I want every child to have the same chance this country gave us. But we know our opportunity agenda won't be complete
column3: and too many young people entering the workforce today will see the American Dream as an empty promise
column4: unless we also do more to make sure our economy honors the dignity of work and hard work pays off for every single American.

column1: Today
column2: women make up about half our workforce
column3: but they still make 77 cents for every dollar a man earns. That is wrong
column4: and in 2014
column5: it's an embarrassment. Women deserve equal pay for equal work. She deserves to have a baby without sacrificing her job. A mother deserves a day off to care for a sick child or a sick parent without running into hardship. And you know what
column6: a father does too. It is time to do away with workplace policies that belong in a "Mad Men" episode.  This year
column7: let's all come togetherCongress
column8: the White House
column9: businesses from Wall Street to Main Streetto give every woman the opportunity she deserves. Because I believe when women succeed
column10: America succeeds.

column1: Now

column1: In the year since I asked this Congress to raise the minimum wage

column2: Governor
column3: State legislator in America
column4: I say: You don't have to wait for Congress to act; Americans will support you if you take this on.

column1: And as a chief executive
column2: I intend to lead by example. Profitable corporations like Costco see higher wages as the smart way to boost productivity and reduce turnover. We should too. In the coming weeks
column3: I will issue an Executive order requiring Federal contractors to pay their federally funded employees a fair wage of at least 10 dollars and 10 cents an hour. Because if you cook our troops' meals or wash their dishes
column4: you should not have to live in poverty.

column1: Of course
column2: to reach millions more
column3: Congress does need to get on board. Today
column4: the Federal minimum wage is worth about 20 percent less than it was when Ronald Reagan first stood here. And Tom Harkin and George Miller have a bill to fix that by lifting the minimum wage to 10 dollars and 10 cents. It's easy to remember: 10-10. This will help families. It will give businesses customers with more money to spend. It does not involve any new bureaucratic program. So join the rest of the country. Say yes. Give America a raise. Give them a raise.

column1: There are other steps we can take to help families make ends meet
column2: and few are more effective at reducing inequality and helping families pull themselves up through hard work than the earned-income tax credit. Right now it helps about half of all parents at some point. Think about that: It helps about half of all parents in America at some point in their lives. But I agree with Republicans like Senator Rubio that it doesn't do enough for single workers who don't have kids. So let's work together to strengthen the credit
column3: reward work
column4: help more Americans get ahead.

column1: Let's do more to help Americans save for retirement. Today
column2: most workers don't have a pension. A Social Security check often isn't enough on its own. And while the stock market has doubled over the last 5 years
column3: that doesn't help folks who don't have 401(k)s. That's why
column4: tomorrow
column5: I will direct the Treasury to create a new way for working Americans to start their own retirement savings: MyIMyRA.

column1: It's a new savings bond that encourages folks to build a nest egg. MyRA guarantees a decent return with no risk of losing what you put in. And if this Congress wants to help

column3: but does little or nothing for middle class Americans. Offer every American access to an automatic IRA on the job so they can save at work just like everybody in this Chamber can.

column1: And since the most important investment many families make is their home
column2: send me legislation that protects taxpayers from footing the bill for a housing crisis ever again and keeps the dream of homeownership alive for future generations.

column1: One last point on financial security: For decades

column5: a physician's assistant and single mom from Arizona

column9: she had emergency surgery. Just one week earlier
column10: Amanda said

column4: more than 3 million Americans under age 26 have gained coverage under their parent's plan. More than 9 million Americans have signed up for private health insurance or Medicaid coverage. Nine million.

column2: no Americannone
column3: zerocan ever again be dropped or denied coverage for a preexisting condition like asthma or back pain or cancer. No woman can ever be charged more just because she's a woman. And we did all this while adding years to Medicare's finances
column4: keeping Medicare premiums flat
column5: and lowering prescription costs for millions of seniors.

column1: Now

column6: tell America what you'd do differently. Let's see if the numbers add up. But let's not have another 40-something votes to repeal a law that's already helping millions of Americans like Amanda. The first 40 were plenty.

column7: farmers out on the tractor
column8: grocery clerks. They're people who go to work every morning praying they don't get sick. No one deserves to live that way."

column4: and plus

column6: not the size of our bank accounts

column2: students
column3: pastors
column4: police officers all over this country who say

column7: to help stop more tragedies from visiting innocent Americans in our movie theaters
column8: in our shopping malls

column8: all our troops are out of Iraq. More than 60
