column12: and America's longest war will finally be over.

column1: After 2014
column2: we will support a unified Afghanistan as it takes responsibility for its own future. If the Afghan Government signs a security agreement that we have negotiated
column3: a small force of Americans could remain in Afghanistan with NATO allies to carry out two narrow missions: training and assisting Afghan forces and counterterrorism operations to pursue any remnants of Al Qaida. For while our relationship with Afghanistan will change
column4: one thing will not: our resolve that terrorists do not launch attacks against our country.

column1: The fact is
column2: that danger remains. While we've put Al Qaida's core leadership on a path to defeat
column3: the threat has evolved as Al Qaida affiliates and other extremists take root in different parts of the world. In Yemen
column4: Somalia
column5: Iraq
column6: Mali
column7: we have to keep working with partners to disrupt and disable those networks. In Syria
column8: we'll support the opposition that rejects the agenda of terrorist networks. Here at home
column9: we'll keep strengthening our defenses and combat new threats like cyber attacks. And as we reform our defense budget
column10: we will have to keep faith with our men and women in uniform and invest in the capabilities they need to succeed in future missions.

column1: We have to remain vigilant. But I strongly believe our leadership and our security cannot depend on our outstanding military alone. As Commander in Chief
column2: I have used force when needed to protect the American people
column3: and I will never hesitate to do so as long as I hold this office. But I will not send our troops into harm's way unless it is truly necessary
column4: nor will I allow our sons and daughters to be mired in open-ended conflicts. We must fight the battles that need to be fought
column5: not those that terrorists prefer from us: large-scale deployments that drain our strength and may ultimately feed extremism.

column1: So even as we actively and aggressively pursue terrorist networks through more targeted efforts and by building the capacity of our foreign partners
column2: America must move off a permanent war footing. That's why I've imposed prudent limits on the use of drones. For we will not be safer if people abroad believe we strike within their countries without regard for the consequence.

column1: That's why
column2: working with this Congress
column3: I will reform our surveillance programs
column4: because the vital work of our intelligence community depends on public confidence
column5: here and abroad
column6: that privacy of ordinary people is not being violated.

column1: And with the Afghan war ending
column2: this needs to be the year Congress lifts the remaining restrictions on detainee transfers and we close the prison at Guantanamo Bay. Because we counter terrorism not just through intelligence and military actions
column3: but by remaining true to our constitutional ideals and setting an example for the rest of the world.

column1: You see
column2: in a world of complex threats
column3: our security
column4: our leadership
column5: depends on all elements of our power
column6: including strong and principled diplomacy. American diplomacy has rallied more than 50 countries to prevent nuclear materials from falling into the wrong hands and allowed us to reduce our own reliance on cold war stockpiles. American diplomacy
column7: backed by the threat of force
column8: is why Syria's chemical weapons are being eliminated.

column1: And we will continue to work with the international community to usher in the future the Syrian people deserve
column2: a future free of dictatorship
column3: terror
column4: and fear. As we speak
column5: American diplomacy is supporting Israelis and Palestinians as they engage in the difficult but necessary talks to end the conflict there
column6: to achieve dignity and an independent state for Palestinians and lasting peace and security for the State of Israel
column7: a Jewish state that knows America will always be at their side.

column1: And it is American diplomacy
column2: backed by pressure
column3: that has halted the progress of Iran's nuclear program and rolled back parts of that program for the very first time in a decade. As we gather here tonight
column4: Iran has begun to eliminate its stockpile of higher levels of enriched uranium. It's not installing advanced centrifuges. Unprecedented inspections help the world verify every day that Iran is not building a bomb. And with our allies and partners
column5: we're engaged in negotiations to see if we can peacefully achieve a goal we all share: preventing Iran from obtaining a nuclear weapon.

column1: These negotiations will be difficult. They may not succeed. We are clear eyed about Iran's support for terrorist organizations like Hizballah
column2: which threatens our allies. And we're clear about the mistrust between our nations
column3: mistrust that cannot be wished away. But these negotiations don't rely on trust. Any long-term deal we agree to must be based on verifiable action that convinces us and the international community that Iran is not building a nuclear bomb. If John F. Kennedy and Ronald Reagan could negotiate with the Soviet Union
column4: then surely a strong and confident America can negotiate with less powerful adversaries today.

column1: The sanctions that we put in place helped make this opportunity possible. But let me be clear: If this Congress sends me a new sanctions bill now that threatens to derail these talks
column2: I will veto it. For the sake of our national security
column3: we must give diplomacy a chance to succeed. If Iran's leaders do not seize this opportunity
column4: then I will be the first to call for more sanctions and stand ready to exercise all options to make sure Iran does not build a nuclear weapon. But if Iran's leaders do seize the chanceand we'll know soon enoughthen Iran could take an important step to rejoin the community of nations
column5: and we will have resolved one of the leading security challenges of our time without the risks of war.

column1: Now
column2: finally
column3: let's remember that our leadership is defined not just by our defense against threats
column4: but by the enormous opportunities to do good and promote understanding around the globe: to forge greater cooperation
column5: to expand new markets
column6: to free people from fear and want. And no one is better positioned to take advantage of those opportunities than America.

column1: Our alliance with Europe remains the strongest the world has ever known. From Tunisia to Burma
column2: we're supporting those who are willing to do the hard work of building democracy. In Ukraine
column3: we stand for the principle that all people have the right to express themselves freely and peacefully and to have a say in their country's future. Across Africa
column4: we're bringing together businesses and governments to double access to electricity and help end extreme poverty. In the Americas
column5: we're building new ties of commerce
column6: but we're also expanding cultural and educational exchanges among young people. And we will continue to focus on the Asia-Pacific
column7: where we support our allies
column8: shape a future of greater security and prosperity
column9: and extend a hand to those devastated by disaster
column10: as we did in the Philippines
column11: when our Marines and civilians rushed to aid those battered by a typhoon
column12: and who were greeted with words like
column13: "We will never forget your kindness" and "God bless America."

column1: We do these things because they help promote our long-term security
column2: and we do them because we believe in the inherent dignity and equality of every human being
column3: regardless of race or religion
column4: creed or sexual orientation. And next week
column5: the world will see one expression of that commitment
column6: when Team U.S.A. marches the red
column7: white
column8: and blue into the Olympic Stadium and brings home the gold.

column1: My fellow Americans
column2: no other country in the world does what we do. On every issue
column3: the world turns to us
column4: not simply because of the size of our economy or our military might
column5: but because of the ideals we stand for and the burdens we bear to advance them. No one knows this better than those who serve in uniform.

column1: As this time of war draws to a close
column2: a new generation of heroes returns to civilian life. We'll keep slashing that backlog so our veterans receive the benefits they've earned and our wounded warriors receive the health careincluding the mental health carethat they need. We'll keep working to help all our veterans translate their skills and leadership into jobs here at home. And we will all continue to join forces to honor and support our remarkable military families.

column1: Let me tell you about one of those families I've come to know. I first met Cory Remsburg
column2: a proud Army Ranger
column3: at Omaha Beach on the 65th anniversary of D-day. Along with some of his fellow Rangers
column4: he walked me through the program and the ceremony. He was a strong
column5: impressive young man
column6: had an easy manner
column7: he was sharp as a tack. And we joked around and took pictures
column8: and I told him to stay in touch.

column1: A few months later
column2: on his 10th deployment
column3: Cory was nearly killed by a massive roadside bomb in Afghanistan. His comrades found him in a canal
column4: face down
column5: underwater
column6: shrapnel in his brain. For months
column7: he lay in a coma. And the next time I met him
column8: in the hospital
column9: he couldn't speak
column10: could barely move. Over the years
column11: he's endured dozens of surgeries and procedures
column12: hours of grueling rehab every day.

column1: Even now
column2: Cory is still blind in one eye
column3: still struggles on his left side. But slowly
column4: steadily
column5: with the support of caregivers like his dad Craig and the community around him
column6: Cory has grown stronger. And day by day
column7: he's learned to speak again and stand again and walk again. And he's working toward the day when he can serve his country again. "My recovery has not been easy
column8: he says. Nothing in life that's worth anything is easy." Cory is here tonight. And like the Army he loves
column9: like the America he serves
column10: Sergeant First Class Cory Remsburg never gives up
column11: and he does not quit. Cory.

column1: My fellow Americans
column2: men and women like Cory remind us that America has never come easy. Our freedom
column3: our democracy
column4: has never been easy. Sometimes
column5: we stumble
column6: we make mistakes; we get frustrated or discouraged. But for more than 200 years
column7: we have put those things aside and placed our collective shoulder to the wheel of progress: to create and build and expand the possibilities of individual achievement
column8: to free other nations from tyranny and fear
column9: to promote justice and fairness and equality under the law so that the words set to paper by our Founders are made real for every citizen. The America we want for our kidsa rising America where honest work is plentiful and communities are strong
column10: where prosperity is widely shared and opportunity for all lets us go as far as our dreams and toil will take usnone of it is easy. But if we work togetherif we summon what is best in us
column11: the way Cory summoned what is best in himwith our feet planted firmly in today
column12: but our eyes cast toward tomorrow
column13: I know it is within our reach. Believe it.

column1: Barack Obama|Address Before a Joint Session of the Congress on the State of the Union|2015-01-20|@Mr. Speaker
column2: Mr. Vice President
column3: Members of Congress
column4: my fellow Americans: We are 15 years into this new century. Fifteen years that dawned with terror touching our shores
column5: that unfolded with a new generation fighting two long and costly wars
column6: that saw a vicious recession spread across our Nation and the world. It has been and still is a hard time for many.

column1: But tonight we turn the page. Tonight
column2: after a breakthrough year for America
column3: our economy is growing and creating jobs at the fastest pace since 1999. Our unemployment rate is now lower than it was before the financial crisis. More of our kids are graduating than ever before. More of our people are insured than ever before. And we are as free from the grip of foreign oil as we've been in almost 30 years.

column1: Tonight
column2: for the first time since 9/11
column3: our combat mission in Afghanistan is over. Six years ago
column4: nearly 180
column5: 000 American troops served in Iraq and Afghanistan. Today
column6: fewer than 15
column7: 000 remain. And we salute the courage and sacrifice of every man and woman in this 9/11 generation who has served to keep us safe. We are humbled and grateful for your service.

column1: America
column2: for all that we have endured
column3: for all the grit and hard work required to come back
column4: for all the tasks that lie ahead
column5: know this: The shadow of crisis has passed
column6: and the State of the Union is strong.

column1: At this momentwith a growing economy
column2: shrinking deficits
column3: bustling industry
column4: booming energy productionwe have risen from recession freer to write our own future than any other nation on Earth. It's now up to us to choose who we want to be over the next 15 years and for decades to come.

column1: Will we accept an economy where only a few of us do spectacularly well? Or will we commit ourselves to an economy that generates rising incomes and chances for everyone who makes the effort?
Will we approach the world fearful and reactive
column2: dragged into costly conflicts that strain our military and set back our standing? Or will we lead wisely
column3: using all elements of our power to defeat new threats and protect our planet?

column1: Will we allow ourselves to be sorted into factions and turned against one another? Or will we recapture the sense of common purpose that has always propelled America forward?
In 2 weeks
column2: I will send this Congress a budget filled with ideas that are practical
column3: not partisan. And in the months ahead
column4: I'll crisscross the country making a case for those ideas. So tonight I want to focus less on a checklist of proposals and focus more on the values at stake in the choices before us.

column1: It begins with our economy. Seven years ago
column2: Rebekah and Ben Erler of Minneapolis were newlyweds.  She waited tables. He worked construction. Their first child Jack was on the way. They were young and in love in America. And it doesn't get much better than that. "If only we had known
column3: Rebekah wrote to me last spring, what was about to happen to the housing and construction market." As the crisis worsened
column4: Ben's business dried up
column5: so he took what jobs he could find
column6: even if they kept him on the road for long stretches of time. Rebekah took out student loans and enrolled in community college and retrained for a new career. They sacrificed for each other. And slowly
column7: it paid off. They bought their first home. They had a second son Henry. Rebekah got a better job and then a raise. Ben is back in construction and home for dinner every night.

column1: It is amazing, Rebekah wrote
column2: "what you can bounce back from when you have to. . . . We are a strong
column3: tight-knit family who has made it through some very
column4: very hard times." We are a strong
column5: tight-knit family who has made it through some very
column6: very hard times.

column1: America
column2: Rebekah and Ben's story is our story. They represent the millions who have worked hard and scrimped and sacrificed and retooled. You are the reason that I ran for this office. You are the people I was thinking of 6 years ago today
column3: in the darkest months of the crisis
column4: when I stood on the steps of this Capitol and promised we would rebuild our economy on a new foundation. And it has been your resilience
column5: your effort that has made it possible for our country to emerge stronger.

column1: We believed we could reverse the tide of outsourcing and draw new jobs to our shores. And over the past 5 years
column2: our businesses have created more than 11 million new jobs.

column1: We believed we could reduce our dependence on foreign oil and protect our planet. And today
column2: America is number one in oil and gas. America is number one in wind power. Every 3 weeks
column3: we bring online as much solar power as we did in all of 2008. And thanks to lower gas prices and higher fuel standards
column4: the typical family this year should save about $750 at the pump.

column1: We believed we could prepare our kids for a more competitive world. And today
column2: our younger students have earned the highest math and reading scores on record. Our high school graduation rate has hit an alltime high. More Americans finish college than ever before.

column1: We believed that sensible regulations could prevent another crisis
column2: shield families from ruin
column3: and encourage fair competition. Today
column4: we have new tools to stop taxpayer-funded bailouts and a new consumer watchdog to protect us from predatory lending and abusive credit card practices. And in the past year alone
column5: about 10 million uninsured Americans finally gained the security of health coverage.

column1: At every step
column2: we were told our goals were misguided or too ambitious
column3: that we would crush jobs and explode deficits. Instead
column4: we've seen the fastest economic growth in over a decade
column5: our deficits cut by two-thirds
column6: a stock market that has doubled
column7: and health care inflation at its lowest rate in 50 years. This is good news
column8: people.

column1: So the verdict is clear. Middle class economics works. Expanding opportunity works. And these policies will continue to work as long as politics don't get in the way. We can't slow down businesses or put our economy at risk with Government shutdowns or fiscal showdowns. We can't put the security of families at risk by taking away their health insurance or unraveling the new rules on Wall Street or refighting past battles on immigration when we've got to fix a broken system. And if a bill comes to my desk that tries to do any of these things
column2: I will veto it. It will have earned my veto.

column1: Today
column2: thanks to a growing economy
column3: the recovery is touching more and more lives. Wages are finally starting to rise again. We know that more small-business owners plan to raise their employees' pay than at any time since 2007. But here's the thing: Those of us here tonight
column4: we need to set our sights higher than just making sure Government doesn't screw things up ... that Government doesn't halt the progress we're making. We need to do more than just do no harm. Tonight
column5: together
column6: let's do more to restore the link between hard work and growing opportunity for every American.

column1: Because families like Rebekah's still need our help. She and Ben are working as hard as ever
column2: but they've had to forego vacations and a new car so that they can pay off student loans and save for retirement. Friday night pizza
column3: that's a big splurge. Basic childcare for Jack and Henry costs more than their mortgage and almost as much as a year at the University of Minnesota. Like millions of hard-working Americans
column4: Rebekah isn't asking for a handout
column5: but she is asking that we look for more ways to help families get ahead.

column1: And in fact
column2: at every moment of economic change throughout our history
column3: this country has taken bold action to adapt to new circumstances and to make sure everyone gets a fair shot. We set up worker protections
column4: Social Security
column5: Medicare
column6: Medicaid to protect ourselves from the harshest adversity. We gave our citizens schools and colleges
column7: infrastructure and the Internet
column8: tools they needed to go as far as their efforts and their dreams will take them.

column1: That's what middle class economics is: the idea that this country does best when everyone gets their fair shot
column2: everyone does their fair share
column3: everyone plays by the same set of rules. We don't just want everyone to share in America's success
column4: we want everyone to contribute to our success.

column1: So what does middle class economics require in our time? First
column2: middle class economics means helping working families feel more secure in a world of constant change. That means helping folks afford childcare
column3: college
column4: health care
column5: a home
column6: retirement. And my budget will address each of these issues
column7: lowering the taxes of working families and putting thousands of dollars back into their pockets each year.

column1: Here's one example. During World War II
column2: when men like my grandfather went off to war
column3: having women like my grandmother in the workforce was a national security priority
column4: so this country provided universal childcare. In today's economy
column5: when having both parents in the workforce is an economic necessity for many families
column6: we need affordable
column7: high-quality childcare more than ever.

column1: It's not a nice-to-have
column2: it's a must-have. So it's time we stop treating childcare as a side issue
column3: or as a women's issue
column4: and treat it like the national economic priority that it is for all of us. And that's why my plan will make quality childcare more available and more affordable for every middle class and low-income family with young children in America
column5: by creating more slots and a new tax cut of up to $3
column6: 000 per child
column7: per year.

column1: Here's another example. Today
column2: we are the only advanced country on Earth that doesn't guarantee paid sick leave or paid maternity leave to our workers. Forty-three million workers have no paid sick leave43 million. Think about that. And that forces too many parents to make the gut-wrenching choice between a paycheck and a sick kid at home. So I'll be taking new action to help States adopt paid leave laws of their own. And since paid sick leave won where it was on the ballot last November
column3: let's put it to a vote right here in Washington. Send me a bill that gives every worker in America the opportunity to earn 7 days of paid sick leave. It's the right thing to do.  It's the right thing to do.

column1: Of course
column2: nothing helps families make ends meet like higher wages. That's why this Congress still needs to pass a law that makes sure a woman is paid the same as a man for doing the same work. I mean
column3: it's 2015.  It's time. We still need to make sure employees get the overtime they've earned. And to everyone in this Congress who still refuses to raise the minimum wage
column4: I say this: If you truly believe you could work full time and support a family on less than $15
column5: 000 a year
column6: try it. If not
column7: vote to give millions of the hardest working people in America a raise.

column1: Now
column2: these ideas won't make everybody rich
column3: won't relieve every hardship. That's not the job of government. To give working families a fair shot
column4: we still need more employers to see beyond next quarter's earnings and recognize that investing in their workforce is in their company's long-term interest. We still need laws that strengthen rather than weaken unions
column5: and give American workers a voice.

column1: But you know
column2: things like childcare and sick leave and equal pay
column3: things like lower mortgage premiums and a higher minimum wagethese ideas will make a meaningful difference in the lives of millions of families. That's a fact. And that's what all of us
column4: Republicans and Democrats alike
column5: were sent here to do.

column1: Now
column2: second
column3: to make sure folks keep earning higher wages down the road
column4: we have to do more to help Americans upgrade their skills. America thrived in the 20th century because we made high school free
column5: sent a generation of GIs to college
column6: trained the best workforce in the world. We were ahead of the curve. But other countries caught on. And in a 21st-century economy that rewards knowledge like never before
column7: we need to up our game. We need to do more.

column1: By the end of this decade
column2: two in three job openings will require some higher educationtwo in three. And yet we still live in a country where too many bright
column3: striving Americans are priced out of the education they need. It's not fair to them
column4: and it's sure not smart for our future. And that's why I'm sending this Congress a bold new plan to lower the cost of community college to zero.

column1: Keep in mind
column2: 40 percent of our college students choose community college. Some are young and starting out. Some are older and looking for a better job. Some are veterans and single parents trying to transition back into the job market. Whoever you are
column3: this plan is your chance to graduate ready for the new economy without a load of debt. Understand
column4: you've got to earn it. You've got to keep your grades up and graduate on time.

column1: Tennessee
column2: a State with Republican leadership
column3: and Chicago
column4: a city with Democratic leadership
column5: are showing that free community college is possible. I want to spread that idea all across America so that 2 years of college becomes as free and universal in America as high school is today. Let's stay ahead of the curve. And I want to work with this Congress to make sure those already burdened with student loans can reduce their monthly payments so that student debt doesn't derail anyone's dreams.

column1: Thanks to Vice President Biden's great work to update our job training system
column2: we're connecting community colleges with local employers to train workers to fill high-paying jobs like coding and nursing and robotics. Tonight I'm also asking more businesses to follow the lead of companies like CVS and UPS and offer more educational benefits and paid apprenticeships
column3: opportunities that give workers the chance to earn higher paying jobs even if they don't have a higher education.

column1: And as a new generation of veterans comes home
column2: we owe them every opportunity to live the American Dream they helped defend. Already
column3: we've made strides towards ensuring that every veteran has access to the highest quality care. We're slashing the backlog that had too many veterans waiting years to get the benefits they need. And we're making it easier for vets to translate their training and experience into civilian jobs. And Joining Forces
column4: the national campaign launched by Michelle and Jill Biden ... thank you
column5: Michelle; thank you
column6: Jillhas helped nearly 700
column7: 000 veterans and military spouses get a new job. So to every CEO in America
column8: let me repeat: If you want somebody who's going to get the job done and done right

column1: Finally
column2: as we better train our workers
column3: we need the new economy to keep churning out high-wage jobs for our workers to fill. Since 2010
column4: America has put more people back to work than Europe
column5: Japan
column6: and all advanced economies combined.

column1: Our manufacturers have added almost 800
column2: 000 new jobs. Some of our bedrock sectors
column3: like our auto industry
column4: are booming. But there are also millions of Americans who work in jobs that didn't even exist 10 or 20 years ago
column5: jobs at companies like Google and eBay and Tesla.

column1: So no one knows for certain which industries will generate the jobs of the future. But we do know we want them here in America. We know that. And that's why the third part of middle class economics is all about building the most competitive economy anywhere
column2: the place where businesses want to locate and hire.

column1: Twenty-first century businesses need 21st-century infrastructure: modern ports and stronger bridges
column2: faster trains and the fastest Internet. Democrats and Republicans used to agree on this. So let's set our sights higher than a single oil pipeline. Let's pass a bipartisan infrastructure plan that could create more than 30 times as many jobs per year and make this country stronger for decades to come. Let's do it. Let's get it done. Let's get it done.

column1: Twenty-first century businesses
column2: including small businesses
column3: need to sell more American products overseas. Today
column4: our businesses export more than ever
column5: and exporters tend to pay their workers higher wages. But as we speak
column6: China wants to write the rules for the world's fastest growing region. That would put our workers and our businesses at a disadvantage. Why would we let that happen? We should write those rules. We should level the playing field. And that's why I'm asking both parties to give me trade promotion authority to protect American workers
column7: with strong new trade deals from Asia to Europe that aren't just free
column8: but are also fair. It's the right thing to do.

column1: Look
column2: I'm the first one to admit that past trade deals haven't always lived up to the hype

We can't close ourselves off from those opportunities. More than half of manufacturing executives have said they're actively looking to bring jobs back from China. So let's give them one more reason to get it done.

column1: Twenty-first century businesses will rely on American science and technology
column2: research and development. I want the country that eliminated polio and mapped the human genome to lead a new era of medicine
column3: one that delivers the right treatment at the right time.

column1: In some patients with cystic fibrosis
column2: this approach has reversed a disease once thought unstoppable. So tonight I'm launching a new precision medicine initiative to bring us closer to curing diseases like cancer and diabetes and to give all of us access to the personalized information we need to keep ourselves and our families healthier. We can do this.

column1: I intend to protect a free and open Internet
column2: extend its reach to every classroom and every community and help folks build the fastest networks so that the next generation of digital innovators and entrepreneurs have the platform to keep reshaping our world. I want Americans to win the race for the kinds of discoveries that unleash new jobs: converting sunlight into liquid fuel; creating revolutionary prosthetics so that a veteran who gave his arms for his country can play catch with his kids again; pushing out into the solar system not just to visit
column3: but to stay. Last month
column4: we launched a new spacecraft as part of a reenergized space program that will send American astronauts to Mars. And in 2 months
column5: to prepare us for those missions
column6: Scott Kelly will begin a year-long stay in space. So good luck

column1: Now
column2: the truth is
column3: when it comes to issues like infrastructure and basic research
column4: I know there's bipartisan support in this Chamber. Members of both parties have told me so. Where we too often run onto the rocks is how to pay for these investments. As Americans
column5: we don't mind paying our fair share of taxes as long as everybody else does too. But for far too long
column6: lobbyists have rigged the Tax Code with loopholes that let some corporations pay nothing while others pay full freight. They've riddled it with giveaways that the super-rich don't need
column7: while denying a break to middle class families who do.

column1: This year
column2: we have an opportunity to change that. Let's close loopholes so we stop rewarding companies that keep profits abroad and reward those that invest here in America. Let's use those savings to rebuild our infrastructure and to make it more attractive for companies to bring jobs home. Let's simplify the system and let a small-business owner file based on her actual bank statement
column3: instead of the number of accountants she can afford. And let's close the loopholes that lead to inequality by allowing the top 1 percent to avoid paying taxes on their accumulated wealth. We can use that money to help more families pay for childcare and send their kids to college. We need a Tax Code that truly helps working Americans trying to get a leg up in the new economy
column4: and we can achieve that together.  We can achieve it together.

column1: Helping hard-working families make ends meet
column2: giving them the tools they need for good-paying jobs in this new economy
column3: maintaining the conditions of growth and competitivenessthis is where America needs to go. I believe it's where the American people want to go. It will make our economy stronger a year from now
column4: 15 years from now
column5: and deep into the century ahead.

column1: Of course
column2: if there's one thing this new century has taught us
column3: it's that we cannot separate our work here at home from challenges beyond our shores. My first duty as Commander in Chief is to defend the United States of America. In doing so
column4: the question is not whether America leads in the world
column5: but how. When we make rash decisions
column6: reacting to the headlines instead of using our heads
column7: when the first response to a challenge is to send in our military
column8: then we risk getting drawn into unnecessary conflicts and neglect the broader strategy we need for a safer
column9: more prosperous world. That's what our enemies want us to do.

column1: I believe in a smarter kind of American leadership. We lead best when we combine military power with strong diplomacy
column2: when we leverage our power with coalition building
column3: when we don't let our fears blind us to the opportunities that this new century presents. That's exactly what we're doing right now. And around the globe
column4: it is making a difference.

column1: First
column2: we stand united with people around the world who have been targeted by terrorists
column3: from a school in Pakistan to the streets of Paris. We will continue to hunt down terrorists and dismantle their networks
column4: and we reserve the right to act unilaterally
column5: as we have done relentlessly since I took office
column6: to take out terrorists who pose a direct threat to us and our allies. At the same time
column7: we've learned some costly lessons over the last 13 years. Instead of Americans patrolling the valleys of Afghanistan
column8: we've trained their security forces
column9: who have now taken the lead
column10: and we've honored our troops' sacrifice by supporting that country's first democratic transition. Instead of sending large ground forces overseas
column11: we're partnering with nations from South Asia to North Africa to deny safe haven to terrorists who threaten America.

column1: In Iraq and Syria
column2: American leadershipincluding our military poweris stopping ISIL's advance. Instead of getting dragged into another ground war in the Middle East
column3: we are leading a broad coalition
column4: including Arab nations
column5: to degrade and ultimately destroy this terrorist group. We're also supporting a moderate opposition in Syria that can help us in this effort and assisting people everywhere who stand up to the bankrupt ideology of violent extremism.

column1: Now
column2: this effort will take time. It will require focus. But we will succeed. And tonight I call on this Congress to show the world that we are united in this mission by passing a resolution to authorize the use of force against ISIL. We need that authority.

column1: Second
column2: we're demonstrating the power of American strength and diplomacy. We're upholding the principle that bigger nations can't bully the small
column3: by opposing Russian aggression and supporting Ukraine's democracy and reassuring our NATO allies.

column1: Last year
column2: as we were doing the hard work of imposing sanctions along with our allies
column3: as we were reinforcing our presence with frontline states
column4: Mr. Putin's aggression
column5: it was suggested
column6: was a masterful display of strategy and strength. That's what I heard from some folks.  Well
column7: today
column8: it is America that stands strong and united with our allies
column9: while Russia is isolated with its economy in tatters. That's how America leads: not with bluster
column10: but with persistent
column11: steady resolve.

column1: In Cuba
column2: we are ending a policy that was long past its expiration date. When what you're doing doesn't work for 50 years
column3: it's time to try something new.  And our shift in Cuba policy has the potential to end a legacy of mistrust in our hemisphere. It removes a phony excuse for restrictions in Cuba. It stands up for democratic values and extends the hand of friendship to the Cuban people. And this year
column4: Congress should begin the work of ending the embargo.

column1: As His Holiness Pope Francis has said
column2: diplomacy is the work of "small steps." And these small steps have added up to new hope for the future in Cuba. And after years in prison
column3: we are overjoyed that Alan Gross is back where he belongs. Welcome home
column4: Alan. We're glad you're here.

column1: Our diplomacy is at work with respect to Iran
column2: where
column3: for the first time in a decade
column4: we've halted the progress of its nuclear program and reduced its stockpile of nuclear material. Between now and this spring
column5: we have a chance to negotiate a comprehensive agreement that prevents a nuclear-armed Iran
column6: secures America and our allies
column7: including Israel
column8: while avoiding yet another Middle East conflict. There are no guarantees that negotiations will succeed
column9: and I keep all options on the table to prevent a nuclear Iran.

column1: But new sanctions passed by this Congress
column2: at this moment in time
column3: will all but guarantee that diplomacy fails: alienating America from its allies
column4: making it harder to maintain sanctions
column5: and ensuring that Iran starts up its nuclear program again. It doesn't make sense. And that's why I will veto any new sanctions bill that threatens to undo this progress. The American people expect us only to go to war as a last resort
column6: and I intend to stay true to that wisdom. Third
column7: we're looking beyond the issues that have consumed us in the past to shape the coming century. No foreign nation
column8: no hacker
column9: should be able to shut down our networks
column10: steal our trade secrets
column11: or invade the privacy of American families
column12: especially our kids. So we're making sure our Government integrates intelligence to combat cyber threats
column13: just as we have done to combat terrorism.

column1: And tonight I urge this Congress to finally pass the legislation we need to better meet the evolving threat of cyber attacks
column2: combat identity theft
column3: and protect our children's information. That should be a bipartisan effort. If we don't act
column4: we'll leave our Nation and our economy vulnerable. If we do
column5: we can continue to protect the technologies that have unleashed untold opportunities for people around the globe.

column1: In West Africa
column2: our troops
column3: our scientists
column4: our doctors
column5: our nurses
column6: our health care workers are rolling back Ebola
column7: saving countless lives and stopping the spread of disease. I could not be prouder of them
column8: and I thank this Congress for your bipartisan support of their efforts. But the job is not yet done
column9: and the world needs to use this lesson to build a more effective global effort to prevent the spread of future pandemics
column10: invest in smart development
column11: and eradicate extreme poverty.

column1: In the Asia-Pacific
column2: we are modernizing alliances while making sure that other nations play by the rules: in how they trade
column3: how they resolve maritime disputes
column4: how they participate in meeting common international challenges like nonproliferation and disaster relief. And no challengeno challengeposes a greater threat to future generations than climate change.

column1: Two thousand fourteen was the planet's warmest year on record. Now
column2: 1 year doesn't make a trend
column3: but this does: 14 of the 15 warmest years on record have all fallen in the first 15 years of this century.

column1: Now
column2: I've heard some folks try to dodge the evidence by saying they're not scientists
column3: that we don't have enough information to act. Well
column4: I'm not a scientist
column5: either. But you know what
column6: I know a lot of really good scientists ... at NASA and at NOAA and at our major universities. And the best scientists in the world are all telling us that our activities are changing the climate
column7: and if we don't act forcefully
column8: we'll continue to see rising oceans
column9: longer
column10: hotter heat waves
column11: dangerous droughts and floods
column12: and massive disruptions that can trigger greater migration and conflict and hunger around the globe. The Pentagon says that climate change poses immediate risks to our national security. We should act like it.

column1: And that's why
column2: over the past 6 years
column3: we've done more than ever to combat climate change
column4: from the way we produce energy to the way we use it. That's why we've set aside more public lands and waters than any administration in history. And that's why I will not let this Congress endanger the health of our children by turning back the clock on our efforts. I am determined to make sure that American leadership drives international action.

column1: In Beijing
column2: we made a historic announcement: The United States will double the pace at which we cut carbon pollution. And China committed
column3: for the first time
column4: to limiting their emissions. And because the world's two largest economies came together
column5: other nations are now stepping up and offering hope that this year the world will finally reach an agreement to protect the one planet we've got.

column1: And there's one last pillar of our leadership
column2: and that's the example of our values. As Americans
column3: we respect human dignity
column4: even when we're threatened
column5: which is why I have prohibited torture and worked to make sure our use of new technology like drones is properly constrained. It's why we speak out against the deplorable anti-Semitism that has resurfaced in certain parts of the world. It's why we continue to reject offensive stereotypes of Muslims
column6: the vast majority of whom share our commitment to peace. That's why we defend free speech and advocate for political prisoners and condemn the persecution of women or religious minorities or people who are lesbian
column7: gay
column8: bisexual
column9: or transgender. We do these things not only because they are the right thing to do
column10: but because ultimately
column11: they will make us safer.

column1: As Americans
column2: we have a profound commitment to justice. So it makes no sense to spend $3 million per prisoner to keep open a prison that the world condemns and terrorists use to recruit. Since I've been President
column3: we've worked responsibly to cut the population of Gitmo in half. Now it is time to finish the job. And I will not relent in my determination to shut it down. It is not who we are. It's time to close Gitmo.

column1: As Americans
column2: we cherish our civil liberties
column3: and we need to uphold that commitment if we want maximum cooperation from other countries and industry in our fight against terrorist networks. So while some have moved on from the debates over our surveillance programs
column4: I have not. As promised
column5: our intelligence agencies have worked hard
column6: with the recommendations of privacy advocates
column7: to increase transparency and build more safeguards against potential abuse. And next month
column8: we'll issue a report on how we're keeping our promise to keep our country safe while strengthening privacy.

column1: Looking to the future instead of the past
column2: making sure we match our power with diplomacy and use force wisely
column3: building coalitions to meet new challenges and opportunities
column4: leading always with the example of our valuesthat's what makes us exceptional. That's what keeps us strong. That's why we have to keep striving to hold ourselves to the highest of standards: our own.

column1: You know
column2: just over a decade ago
column3: I gave a speech in Boston where I said there wasn't a liberal America or a conservative America
column4: a Black America or a White America
column5: but a United States of America. I said this because I had seen it in my own life
column6: in a nation that gave someone like me a chance; because I grew up in Hawaii
column7: a melting pot of races and customs; because I made Illinois my home
column8: a State of small towns
column9: rich farmland
column10: one of the world's great cities
column11: a microcosm of the country where Democrats and Republicans and Independents
column12: good people of every ethnicity and every faith
column13: share certain bedrock values.

column1: Over the past 6 years
column2: the pundits have pointed out more than once that my Presidency hasn't delivered on this vision. How ironic
column3: they say
column4: that our politics seems more divided than ever. It's held up as proof not just of my own flawsof which there are manybut also as proof that the vision itself is misguided
column5: naive
column6: that there are too many people in this town who actually benefit from partisanship and gridlock for us to ever do anything about it.

column1: I know how tempting such cynicism may be. But I still think the cynics are wrong. I still believe that we are one people. I still believe that together
column2: we can do great things
column3: even when the odds are long.

column1: I believe this because over and over in my 6 years in office
column2: I have seen America at its best. I've seen the hopeful faces of young graduates from New York to California and our newest officers at West Point
column3: Annapolis
column4: Colorado Springs
column5: New London. I've mourned with grieving families in Tucson and Newtown
column6: in Boston
column7: in West
column8: Texas
column9: and West Virginia. I've watched Americans beat back adversity from the Gulf Coast to the Great Plains
column10: from Midwest assembly lines to the Mid-Atlantic seaboard. I've seen something like gay marriage go from a wedge issue used to drive us apart to a story of freedom across our country
column11: a civil right now legal in States that 7 in 10 Americans call home. So I know the good and optimistic and big-hearted generosity of the American people who every day live the idea that we are our brother's keeper and our sister's keeper. And I know they expect those of us who serve here to set a better example.

column1: So the question for those of us here tonight is how we
column2: all of us
column3: can better reflect America's hopes. I've served in Congress with many of you. I know many of you well. There are a lot of good people here on both sides of the aisle. And many of you have told me that this isn't what you signed up for: arguing past each other on cable shows
column4: the constant fundraising
column5: always looking over your shoulder at how the base will react to every decision.

column1: Imagine if we broke out of these tired old patterns. Imagine if we did something different. Understand
column2: a better politics isn't one where Democrats abandon their agenda or Republicans simply embrace mine. A better politics is one where we appeal to each other's basic decency instead of our basest fears. A better politics is one where we debate without demonizing each other
column3: where we talk issues and values and principles and facts rather than "gotcha" moments or trivial gaffes or fake controversies that have nothing to do with people's daily lives.

column1: A politicsa better politics is one where we spend less time drowning in dark money for ads that pull us into the gutter and spend more time lifting young people up with a sense of purpose and possibility
column2: asking them to join in the great mission of building America.

column1: If we're going to have arguments
column2: let's have arguments
column3: but let's make them debates worthy of this body and worthy of this country. We still may not agree on a woman's right to choose
column4: but surely we can agree it's a good thing that teen pregnancies and abortions are nearing alltime lows and that every woman should have access to the health care that she needs.

column1: Yes
column2: passions still fly on immigration
column3: but surely we can all see something of ourselves in the striving young student and agree that no one benefits when a hard-working mom is snatched from her child and that it's possible to shape a law that upholds our tradition as a nation of laws and a nation of immigrants. I've talked to Republicans and Democrats about that. That's something that we can share.

column1: We may go at it in campaign season
column2: but surely we can agree that the right to vote is sacred
column3: that it's being denied to too many
column4: and that on this 50th anniversary of the great march from Selma to Montgomery and the passage of the Voting Rights Act
column5: we can come together
column6: Democrats and Republicans
column7: to make voting easier for every single American.

column1: We may have different takes on the events of Ferguson and New York. But surely we can understand a father who fears his son can't walk home without being harassed. And surely we can understand the wife who won't rest until the police officer she married walks through the front door at the end of his shift. And surely we can agree that it's a good thing that for the first time in 40 years
column2: the crime rate and the incarceration rate have come down together
column3: and use that as a starting point for Democrats and Republicans
column4: community leaders and law enforcement
column5: to reform America's criminal justice system so that it protects and serves all of us.

column1: That's a better politics. That's how we start rebuilding trust. That's how we move this country forward. That's what the American people want. And that's what they deserve.
I have no more campaigns to run.
My only agenda

I know because I won both of them. My only agenda for the next 2 years is the same as the one I've had since the day I swore an oath on the steps of this Capitol: to do what I believe is best for America. If you share the broad vision I outlined tonight
column2: I ask you to join me in the work at hand. If you disagree with parts of it
column3: I hope you'll at least work with me where you do agree. And I commit to every Republican here tonight that I will not only seek out your ideas
column4: I will seek to work with you to make this country stronger.

column1: Because I want this Chamber
column2: I want this city to reflect the truth: that for all our blind spots and shortcomings
column3: we are a people with the strength and generosity of spirit to bridge divides
column4: to unite in common effort
column5: to help our neighbors
column6: whether down the street or on the other side of the world.

column1: I want our actions to tell every child in every neighborhood
column2: your life matters
column3: and we are committed to improving your life chances
column4: as committed as we are to working on behalf of our own kids. I want future generations to know that we are a people who see our differences as a great gift
column5: that we're a people who value the dignity and worth of every citizen: man and woman
column6: young and old
column7: Black and White
column8: Latino
column9: Asian
column10: immigrant
column11: Native American
column12: gay
column13: straight
column14: Americans with mental illness or physical disability. Everybody matters. I want them to grow up in a country that shows the world what we still know to be true: that we are still more than a collection of red States and blue States
column15: that we are the United States of America.

column1: I want them to grow up in a country where a young mom can sit down and write a letter to her President with a story that sums up these past 6 years: "It's amazing what you can bounce back from when you have to. ... We are a strong
column2: tight-knit family who's made it through some very
column3: very hard times."

column1: My fellow Americans
column2: we too are a strong
column3: tight-knit family. We too have made it through some hard times. Fifteen years into this new century
column4: we have picked ourselves up
column5: dusted ourselves off
column6: and begun again the work of remaking America. We have laid a new foundation. A brighter future is ours to write. Let's begin this new chapter together
column7: and let's start the work right now.

column1: Thank you. God bless you. God bless this country we love. Thank you.@
Barack Obama|Address Before a Joint Session of the Congress on the State of the Union|2016-01-12|@Thank you. Mr. Speaker
column2: Mr. Vice President
column3: Members of Congress
column4: my fellow Americans: Tonight marks the eighth year that I've come here to report on the State of the Union. And for this final one
column5: I'm going to try to make it a little shorter. I know some of you are antsy to get back to Iowa.  I've been there. I'll be shaking hands afterwards if you want some tips.

column1: Now
column2: I understand that because it's an election season
column3: expectations for what we will achieve this year are low. But
column4: Mr. Speaker
column5: I appreciate the constructive approach that you and other leaders took at the end of last year to pass a budget and make tax cuts permanent for working families. So I hope we can work together this year on some bipartisan priorities like criminal justice reform and helping people who are battling prescription drug abuse and heroin abuse. So
column6: who knows
column7: we might surprise the cynics again.

column1: But tonight I want to go easy on the traditional list of proposals for the year ahead. Don't worry
column2: I've got plenty ... from helping students learn to write computer code to personalizing medical treatments for patients. And I will keep pushing for progress on the work that I believe still needs to be done: fixing a broken immigration system
column3: protecting our kids from gun violence
column4: equal pay for equal work
column5: paid leave
column6: raising the minimum wage. All these things still matter to hard-working families. They're still the right thing to do. And I won't let up until they get done.

column1: But for my final address to this Chamber
column2: I don't want to just talk about next year. I want to focus on the next 5 years
column3: the next 10 years
column4: and beyond. I want to focus on our future.

column1: We live in a time of extraordinary change
column2: change that's reshaping the way we live
column3: the way we work
column4: our planet
column5: our place in the world. It's change that promises amazing medical breakthroughs
column6: but also economic disruptions that strain working families. It promises this education for girls in the most remote villages
column7: but also connects terrorists plotting an ocean away. It's change that can broaden opportunity or widen inequality. And whether we like it or not
column8: the pace of this change will only accelerate.

column1: America has been through big changes before: wars and depression
column2: the influx of new immigrants
column3: workers fighting for a fair deal
column4: movements to expand civil rights. Each time
column5: there have been those who told us to fear the future; who claimed we could slam the brakes on change; who promised to restore past glory if we just got some group or idea that was threatening America under control. And each time
column6: we overcame those fears. We did not
column7: in the words of Lincoln
column8: adhere to the "dogmas of the quiet past." Instead
column9: we thought anew and acted anew. We made change work for us
column10: always extending America's promise outward
column11: to the next frontier
column12: to more people. And because we did
column13: because we saw opportunity with awhere others saw peril
column14: we emerged stronger and better than before.

column1: What was true then can be true now. Our unique strengths as a nationour optimism and work ethic
column2: our spirit of discovery
column3: our diversity
column4: our commitment to rule of lawthese things give us everything we need to ensure prosperity and security for generations to come.

column1: In fact
column2: it's in that spirit that we have made progress these past 7 years. That's how we recovered from the worst economic crisis in generations. That's how we reformed our health care system and reinvented our energy sector. That's how we delivered more care and benefits to our troops coming home and our veterans. That's how we secured the freedom in every State to marry the person we love.

column1: But such progress is not inevitable. It's the result of choices we make together. And we face such choices right now. Will we respond to the changes of our time with fear
column2: turning inward as a nation
column3: turning against each other as a people? Or will we face the future with confidence in who we are
column4: in what we stand for
column5: in the incredible things that we can do together?

column1: So let's talk about the future and four big questions that I believe we as a country have to answer
column2: regardless of who the next President is or who controls the next Congress. First
column3: how do we give everyone a fair shot at opportunity and security in this new economy? Second
column4: how do we make technology work for us and not against us
column5: especially when it comes to solving urgent challenges like climate change? Third
column6: how do we keep America safe and lead the world without becoming its policeman? And finally
column7: how can we make our politics reflect what's best in us and not what's worst?

column1: Let me start with the economy and a basic fact: The United States of America right now has the strongest
column2: most durable economy in the world. We're in the middle of the longest streak of private sector job creation in history. More than 14 million new jobs
column3: the strongest 2 years of job growth since the 1990s
column4: an unemployment rate cut in half. Our auto industry just had its best year ever. That's just part of a manufacturing surge that's created nearly 900
column5: 000 new jobs in the past 6 years. And we've done all this while cutting our deficits by almost three-quarters.

column1: Anyone claiming that America's economy is in decline is peddling fiction. Now
column2: what is trueand the reason that a lot of Americans feel anxiousis that the economy has been changing in profound ways
column3: changes that started long before the great recession hit
column4: changes that have not let up.

column1: Today
column2: technology doesn't just replace jobs on the assembly line
column3: but any job where work can be automated. Companies in a global economy can locate anywhere
column4: and they face tougher competition. As a result
column5: workers have less leverage for a raise. Companies have less loyalty to their communities. And more and more wealth and income is concentrated at the very top.

column1: All these trends have squeezed workers
column2: even when they have jobs
column3: even when the economy is growing. It's made it harder for a hard-working family to pull itself out of poverty
column4: harder for young people to start their careers
column5: tougher for workers to retire when they want to. And although none of these trends are unique to America
column6: they do offend our uniquely American belief that everybody who works hard should get a fair shot.

column1: For the past 7 years
column2: our goal has been a growing economy that also works better for everybody. We've made progress
column3: but we need to make more. And despite all the political arguments that we've had these past few years
column4: there are actually some areas where Americans broadly agree.

column1: We agree that real opportunity requires every American to get the education and training they need to land a good-paying job. The bipartisan reform of No Child Left Behind was an important start
column2: and together
column3: we've increased early childhood education
column4: lifted high school graduation rates to new highs
column5: boosted graduates in fields like engineering. In the coming years
column6: we should build on that progress
column7: by providing pre-K for all and offering every student the hands-on computer science and math classes that make them job-ready on day one. We should recruit and support more great teachers for our kids.

column1: And we have to make college affordable for every American. No hard-working student should be stuck in the red. We've already reduced student loan payments byto 10 percent of a borrower's income. And that's good. But now we've actually got to cut the cost of college. Providing 2 years of community college at no cost for every responsible student is one of the best ways to do that
column2: and I'm going to keep fighting to get that started this year. It's the right thing to do.

column1: But a great education isn't all we need in this new economy. We also need benefits and protections that provide a basic measure of security. It's not too much of a stretch to say that some of the only people in America who are going to work the same job
column2: in the same place
column3: with a health and retirement package for 30 years are sitting in this Chamber.  For everyone else
column4: especially folks in their forties and fifties
column5: saving for retirement or bouncing back from job loss has gotten a lot tougher. Americans understand that at some point in their careers
column6: in this new economy
column7: they may have to retool
column8: they may have to retrain. But they shouldn't lose what they've already worked so hard to build in the process.

column1: That's why Social Security and Medicare are more important than ever. We shouldn't weaken them
column2: we should strengthen them. And for Americans short of retirement
column3: basic benefits should be just as mobile as everything else is today. That
column4: by the way
column5: is what the Affordable Care Act is all about. It's about filling the gaps in employer-based care so that when you lose a job or you go back to school or you strike out and launch that new business
column6: you'll still have coverage. Nearly 18 million people have gained coverage so far. And in the process
column7: health care inflation has slowed. And our businesses have created jobs every single month since it became law.

column1: Now
column2: I'm guessing we won't agree on health care anytime soon
column3: but ... a little applause back there.  Just a guess. But there should be other ways parties can work together to improve economic security. Say a hard-working American loses his job. We shouldn't just make sure that he can get unemployment insurance
column4: we should make sure that program encourages him to retrain for a business that's ready to hire him. If that new job doesn't pay as much
column5: there should be a system of wage insurance in place so that he can still pay his bills. And even if he's going from job to job
column6: he should still be able to save for retirement and take his savings with him. That's the way we make the new economy work better for everybody.

column1: I also know Speaker Ryan has talked about his interest in tackling poverty. America is about giving everybody willing to work a chance
column2: a hand up. And I'd welcome a serious discussion about strategies we can all support
column3: like expanding tax cuts for low-income workers who don't have children.

column1: But there are some areas wherewe just have to be honestit has been difficult to find agreement over the last 7 years. And a lot of them fall under the category of what role the Government should play in making sure the system's not rigged in favor of the wealthiest and biggest corporations. And it's an honest disagreement
column2: and the American people have a choice to make.

column1: I believe a thriving private sector is the lifeblood of our economy. I think there are outdated regulations that need to be changed. There is redtape that needs to be cut.  There you go! Yes! See? But after years now of record corporate profits
column2: working families won't get more opportunity or bigger paychecks just by letting big banks or big oil or hedge funds make their own rules at everybody else's expense. Middle class families are not going to feel more secure because we allowed attacks on collective bargaining to go unanswered. Food stamp recipients did not cause the financial crisis; recklessness on Wall Street did. Immigrants aren't the principal reason wages haven't gone up; those decisions are made in the boardrooms that all too often put quarterly earnings over long-term returns. It's sure not the average family watching tonight that avoids paying taxes through offshore accounts.

column1: The point is
column2: I believe that in this new economy
column3: workers and startups and small businesses need more of a voice
column4: not less. The rules should work for them. And I'm not alone in this. This year
column5: I plan to lift up the many businesses who have figured out that doing right by their workers or their customers or their communities ends up being good for their shareholders. And I want to spread those best practices across America. That's part of a brighter future.

column1: In fact
column2: it turns
column3: out many of our best corporate citizens are also our most creative. And this brings me to the second big question we as a country have to answer: How do we reignite that spirit of innovation to meet our biggest challenges?

column1: Sixty years ago
column2: when the Russians beat us into space
column3: we didn't deny Sputnik was up there.  We didn't argue about the science or shrink our research and development budget. We built a space program almost overnight. And 12 years later
column4: we were walking on the Moon.

column1: Now
column2: that spirit of discovery is in our DNA. America is Thomas Edison and the Wright Brothers and George Washington Carver. America is Grace Hopper and Katherine Johnson and Sally Ride. America is every immigrant and entrepreneur from Boston to Austin to Silicon Valley
column3: racing to shape a better future. That's who we are.

column1: And over the past 7 years
column2: we've nurtured that spirit. We've protected an open Internet and taken bold new steps to get more students and low-income Americans online. We've launched next-generation manufacturing hubs and online tools that give an entrepreneur everything he or she needs to start a business in a single day. But we can do so much more.

column1: Last year
column2: Vice President Biden said that with a new moonshot
column3: America can cure cancer. Last month
column4: he worked with this Congress to give scientists at the National Institutes of Health the strongest resources that they've had in over a decade. Wellso tonight I'm announcing a new national effort to get it done. And because he's gone to the mat for all of us on so many issues over the past 40 years
column5: I'm putting Joe in charge of mission control. For the loved ones we've all lost
column6: for the families that we can still save
column7: let's make America the country that cures cancer once and for all. What do you say
column8: Joe? Let's make it happen.

column1: Now
column2: medical research is critical. We need the same level of commitment when it comes to developing clean energy sources. Look
column3: if anybody still wants to dispute the science around climate change
column4: have at it.  You will be pretty lonely
column5: because you'll be debating our military
column6: most of America's business leaders
column7: the majority of the American people
column8: almost the entire scientific community
column9: and 200 nations around the world who agree it's a problem and intend to solve it. But even if the planet wasn't at stake
column10: even if 2014 wasn't the warmest year on recorduntil 2015 turned out to be even hotterwhy would we want to pass up the chance for American businesses to produce and sell the energy of the future? Listen
column11: 7 years ago
column12: we made the single biggest investment in clean energy in our history. Here are the results. In fields from Iowa to Texas
column13: wind power is now cheaper than dirtier
column14: conventional power. On rooftops from Arizona to New York
column15: solar is saving Americans tens of millions of dollars a year on their energy bills and employs more Americans than coal in jobs that pay better than average. We're taking steps to give homeowners the freedom to generate and store their own energy
column18: that environmentalists and Tea Partiers have teamed up to support. And meanwhile
column19: we've cut our imports of foreign oil by nearly 60 percent and cut carbon pollution more than any other country on Earth. Gas under 2 bucks a gallon ain't bad either.

column1: Now we've got to accelerate the transition away from old
column2: dirtier energy sources. Rather than subsidize the past
column3: we should invest in the future
column4: especially in communities that rely on fossil fuels. We do them no favor when we don't show them where the trends are going. And that's why I'm going to push to change the way we manage our oil and coal resources so that they better reflect the costs they impose on taxpayers and our planet. And that way
column5: we put money back into those communities and put tens of thousands of Americans to work building a 21st-century transportation system.

column1: Now
column2: none of this is going to happen overnight. And yes
column3: there are plenty of entrenched interests who want to protect the status quo. But the jobs we'll create
column4: the money we'll save
column5: the planet we'll preservethat is the kind of future our kids and our grandkids deserve. And it's within our grasp.

column1: Now
column2: climate change is just one of many issues where our security is linked to the rest of the world. And that's why the third big question that we have to answer together is how to keep America safe and strong without either isolating ourselves or trying to nation-build everywhere there's a problem.

column1: Now
column2: I told you earlier all the talk of America's economic decline is political hot air. Well
column3: so is all the rhetoric you hear about our enemies getting stronger and America getting weaker. Let me tell you something: The United States of America is the most powerful nation on Earth. Period.  Period. It's not even close.  It's not even close. It's not even close. We spend more on our military than the next eight nations combined. Our troops are the finest fighting force in the history of the world.  All right. No nation attacks us directly
column4: or our allies
column5: because they know that's the path to ruin. Surveys show our standing around the world is higher than when I was elected to this office
column6: and when it comes to every important international issue
column7: people of the world do not look to Beijing or Moscow to lead. They call us. So I think it's useful to level set here
column8: because when we don't
column9: we don't make good decisions.

column1: Now
column2: as someone who begins every day with an intelligence briefing
column3: I know this is a dangerous time. But that's not primarily because of some looming superpower out there
column4: and it's certainly not because of diminished American strength. In today's world
column5: we're threatened less by evil empires and more by failing states.

column1: The Middle East is going through a transformation that will play out for a generation
column2: rooted in conflicts that date back millennia. Economic headwinds are blowing in from a Chinese economy that is in significant transition. Even as their economy severely contracts
column3: Russia is pouring resources in to prop up Ukraine and Syria
column4: client states that they saw slipping away from their orbit. And the international system we built after World War II is now struggling to keep pace with this new reality. It's up to us
column5: the United States of America
column6: to help remake that system. And to do that well
column7: it means that we've got to set priorities. Priority number one is protecting the American people and going after terrorist networks. Both Al Qaida and now ISIL pose a direct threat to our people
column8: because in today's world
column9: even a handful of terrorists who place no value on human life
column10: including their own
column11: can do a lot of damage. They use the Internet to poison the minds of individuals inside our country. Their actions undermine and destabilize our allies. We have to take them out.

column1: But as we focus on destroying ISIL
column2: over-the-top claims that this is world war III just play into their hands. Masses of fighters on the back of pickup trucks
column3: twisted souls plotting in apartments or garages
column4: they pose an enormous danger to civilians; they have to be stopped. But they do not threaten our national existence. That is the story ISIL wants to tell. That's the kind of propaganda they use to recruit. We don't need to build them up to show that we're serious
column5: and we sure don't need to push away vital allies in this fight by echoing the lie that ISIL is somehow representative of one of the world's largest religions. We just need to call them what they are: killers and fanatics who have to be rooted out
column6: hunted down
column7: and destroyed.

column1: And that's exactly what we're doing. For more than a year
column2: America has led a coalition of more than 60 countries to cut off ISIL's financing
column3: disrupt their plots
column4: stop the flow of terrorist fighters
column5: and stamp out their vicious ideology. With nearly 10
column6: 000 airstrikes
column7: we're taking out their leadership
column8: their oil
column9: their training camps
column10: their weapons. We're training
column11: arming
column12: and supporting forces who are steadily reclaiming territory in Iraq and Syria.

column1: If this Congress is serious about winning this war and wants to send a message to our troops and the world
column2: authorize the use of military force against ISIL. Take a vote.  Take a vote. But the American people should know that with or without congressional action
column3: ISIL will learn the same lessons as terrorists before them. If you doubt America's commitmentor mineto see that justice is done
column4: just ask Usama bin Laden. Ask the leader of Al Qaida in Yemen
column5: who was taken out last year
column6: or the perpetrator of the Benghazi attacks
column7: who sits in a prison cell. When you come after Americans
column8: we go after you. And it may take time
column9: but we have long memories
column10: and our reach has no limits.

column1: Our foreign policy has to be focused on the threat from ISIL and Al Qaida
column2: but it can't stop there. For even without ISIL
column3: even without Al Qaida
column4: instability will continue for decades in many parts of the world: in the Middle East
column5: in Afghanistan and parts of Pakistan
column6: in parts of Central America
column7: in Africa and Asia. Some of these places may become safe havens for new terrorist networks. Others will just fall victim to ethnic conflict or famine
column8: feeding the next wave of refugees. The world will look to us to help solve these problems
column9: and our answer needs to be more than tough talk or calls to carpet-bomb civilians. That may work as a TV sound bite
column10: but it doesn't pass muster on the world stage.

column1: We also can't try to take over and rebuild every country that falls into crisis
column2: even if it's done with the best of intentions. That's not leadership; that's a recipe for quagmire
column3: spilling American blood and treasure that ultimately will weaken us. It's the lesson of Vietnam; it's the lesson of Iraq. And we should have learned it by now.

column1: Now
column2: fortunately there is a smarter approach: a patient and disciplined strategy that uses every element of our national power. It says America will always act
column3: alone if necessary
column4: to protect our people and our allies
column5: but on issues of global concern
column6: we will mobilize the world to work with us and make sure other countries pull their own weight. That's our approach to conflicts like Syria
column7: where we're partnering with local forces and leading international efforts to help that broken society pursue a lasting peace. That's why we built a global coalition
column8: with sanctions and principled diplomacy
column9: to prevent a nuclear-armed Iran. And as we speak
column10: Iran has rolled back its nuclear program
column11: shipped out its uranium stockpile
column12: and the world has avoided another war.

column1: That's how we stopped the spread of Ebola in West Africa. Our military
column2: our doctors
column3: our development workersthey were heroic; they set up the platform that then allowed other countries to join in behind us and stamp out that epidemic. Hundreds of thousands
column4: maybe a couple million
column5: lives were saved.

column1: That's how we forged a Trans-Pacific Partnership to open markets and protect workers and the environment and advance American leadership in Asia. It cuts 18
column2: 000 taxes on products made in America
column3: which will then support more good jobs here in America. With TPP
column4: China does not set the rules in that region
column5: we do. You want to show our strength in this new century? Approve this agreement. Give us the tools to enforce it. It's the right thing to do.

column1: Let me give you another example. Fifty years of isolating Cuba had failed to promote democracy. It set us back in Latin America. That's why we restored diplomatic relations
column2: opened the door to travel and commerce
column3: positioned ourselves to improve the lives of the Cuban people. So if you want to consolidate our leadership and credibility in the hemisphere
column4: recognize that the cold war is over. Lift the embargo.

column1: The point is
column2: American leadership in the 21st century is not a choice between ignoring the rest of the worldexcept when we kill terroristsor occupying and rebuilding whatever society is unraveling.
