Leadership means a wise application of military power and rallying the world behind causes that are right. It means seeing our foreign assistance as a part of our national security
column3: not something separate
column4: not charity.

column1: When we lead nearly 200 nations to the most ambitious agreement in history to fight climate change
column2: yes
column3: that helps vulnerable countries
column4: but it also protects our kids. When we help Ukraine defend its democracy or Colombia resolve a decades-long war
column5: that strengthens the international order we depend on. When we help African countries feed their people and care for the sick
column6: it's the right thing to do
column7: and it prevents the next pandemic from reaching our shores. Right now we're on track to end the scourge of HIV/AIDS. That's within our grasp. And we have the chance to accomplish the same thing with malaria
column8: something I'll be pushing this Congress to fund this year.

column1: That's American strength. That's American leadership. And that kind of leadership depends on the power of our example. That's why I will keep working to shut down the prison at Guantanamo. It is expensive
column2: it is unnecessary
column3: and it only serves as a recruitment brochure for our enemies. There's a better way.

column1: And that's why we need to reject any politicsany politicsthat targets people because of race or religion. Let me just say this. This is not a matter of political correctness
column2: this is a matter of understanding just what it is that makes us strong. The world respects us not just for our arsenal
column3: it respects us for our diversity and our openness and the way we respect every faith.

column1: His Holiness Pope Francis told this body from the very spot that I'm standing on tonight that "to imitate the hatred and violence of tyrants and murderers is the best way to take their place." When politicians insult Muslims
column2: whether abroad or our fellow citizens
column3: when a mosque is vandalized or a kid is called names
column4: that doesn't make us safer. That's not telling it whattelling it like it is. It's just wrong. It diminishes us in the eyes of the world. It makes it harder to achieve our goals. It betrays who we are as a country. "We the People." Our Constitution begins with those three simple words
column5: words we've come to recognize mean all the people
column6: not just some; words that insist we rise and fall together
column7: that that's how we might perfect our Union. And that brings me to the fourth and maybe most important thing that I want to say tonight.

column1: The future we wantall of us wantopportunity and security for our families
column2: a rising standard of living
column3: a sustainable
column4: peaceful planet for our kidsall that is within our reach. But it will only happen if we work together. It will only happen if we can have rational
column5: constructive debates. It will only happen if we fix our politics.

column1: A better politics doesn't mean we have to agree on everything. This is a big country: different regions
column2: different attitudes
column3: different interests. That's one of our strengths too. Our Founders distributed power between States and branches of government and expected us to argue
column4: just as they did
column5: fiercely
column6: over the size and shape of government
column7: over commerce and foreign relations
column8: over the meaning of liberty and the imperatives of security.

column1: But democracy does require basic bonds of trust between its citizens. It doesn't work if we think the people who disagree with us are all motivated by malice. It doesn't work if we think that our political opponents are unpatriotic or trying to weaken America. Democracy grinds to a halt without a willingness to compromise or when even basic facts are contested or when we listen only to those who agree with us. Our public life withers when only the most extreme voices get all the attention. And most of all
column2: democracy breaks down when the average person feels their voice doesn't matter
column3: that the system is rigged in favor of the rich or the powerful or some special interest.

column1: Too many Americans feel that way right now. It's one of the few regrets of my Presidency: that the rancor and suspicion between the parties has gotten worse instead of better. I have no doubt
column2: a President with the gifts of Lincoln or Roosevelt might have better bridged the divide
column3: and I guarantee
column4: I'll keep trying to be better so long as I hold this office.

column1: But
column2: my fellow Americans
column3: this cannot be my taskor any President'salone. There are a whole lot of folks in this Chamber
column4: good people
column5: who would like to see more cooperation
column6: would like to see a more elevated debate in Washington
column7: but feel trapped by the imperatives of getting elected
column8: by the noise coming out of your base. I know; you've told me. It's the worst kept secret in Washington. And a lot of you aren't enjoying being trapped in that kind of rancor.

column1: But that means if we want a better politicsand I'm addressing the American people nowif we want a better politics
column2: it's not enough just to change a Congressman or change a Senator or even change a President. We have to change the system to reflect our better selves.

column1: I think we've got to end the practice of drawing our congressional districts so that politicians can pick their voters and not the other way around. Let a bipartisan group do it.

I believe we've got to reduce the influence of money in our politics so that a handful of families or hidden interests can't bankroll our elections. And if our existing approach to campaign finance reform can't pass muster in the courts
column2: we need to work together to find a real solution. Because it's a problem. And most of you don't like raising money.  I know. I've done it.

column1: We've got to make it easier to vote
column2: not harder. We need to modernize it for the way we live now. This is America: We want to make it easier for people to participate. And over the course of this year
column3: I intend to travel the country to push for reforms that do just that. But I can't do these things on my own. Changes in our political processin not just who gets elected
column4: but how they get electedthat will only happen when the American people demand it. It depends on you. That's what's meant by a government of
column5: by
column6: and for the people.

column1: What I'm suggesting is hard. It's a lot easier to be cynical; to accept that change is not possible and politics is hopeless and the problem is
column2: all the folks who are elected don't care; and to believe that our voices and our actions don't matter. But if we give up now
column3: then we forsake a better future. Those with money and power will gain greater control over the decisions that could send a young soldier to war or allow another economic disaster or roll back the equal rights and voting rights that generations of Americans have fought
column4: even died
column5: to secure. And then
column6: as frustration grows
column7: there will be voices urging us to fall back into our respective tribes
column8: to scapegoat fellow citizens who don't look like us or pray like us or vote like we do or share the same background.

column1: We can't afford to go down that path. It won't deliver the economy we want. It will not produce the security we want. But most of all
column2: it contradicts everything that makes us the envy of the world.

column1: So
column2: my fellow Americans
column3: whatever you may believe
column4: whether you prefer one party or no party
column5: whether you supported my agenda or fought as hard as you could against it
column6: our collective futures depends on your willingness to uphold your duties as a citizen. To vote. To speak out. To stand up for others
column7: especially the weak
column8: especially the vulnerable
column9: knowing that each of us is only here because somebody
column10: somewhere
column11: stood up for us. We need every American to stay active in our public lifeand not just during election timeso that our public life reflects the goodness and the decency that I see in the American people every single day.

column1: It is not easy. Our brand of democracy is hard. But I can promise that a little over a year from now
column2: when I no longer hold this office
column3: I will be right there with you as a citizen
column4: inspired by those voices of fairness and vision
column5: of grit and good humor and kindness
column6: that have helped America travel so far. Voices that help us see ourselves not
column7: first and foremost
column8: as Black or White or Asian or Latino
column9: not as gay or straight
column10: immigrant or native born
column11: not Democrat or Republican
column12: but as Americans first
column13: bound by a common creed. Voices Dr. King believed would have the final word: voices of "unarmed truth and unconditional love."

column1: And they're out there
column2: those voices. They don't get a lot of attention; they don't seek a lot of fanfare; but they're busy doing the work this country needs doing. I see them everywhere I travel in this incredible country of ours. I see you
column3: the American people. And in your daily acts of citizenship
column4: I see our future unfolding.

column1: I see it in the worker on the assembly line who clocked extra shifts to keep his company open and the boss who pays him higher wages instead of laying him off. I see it in the dreamer who stays up late at night to finish her science project and the teacher who comes in early
column2: maybe with some extra supplies that she bought because she knows that that young girl might someday cure a disease.

column1: I see it in the American who served his time
column2: made bad mistakes as a child
column3: but now is dreaming of starting over. And I see it in the business owner who gives him that second chance. The protester determined to prove that justice matters and the young cop walking the beat
column4: treating everybody with respect
column5: doing the brave
column6: quiet work of keeping us safe.

column1: I see it in the soldier who gives almost everything to save his brothers
column2: the nurse who tends to him till he can run a marathon
column3: the community that lines up to cheer him on. It's the son who finds the courage to come out as who he is and the father whose love for that son overrides everything he's been taught.

column1: I see it in the elderly woman who will wait in line to cast her vote as long as she has to
column2: the new citizen who casts his vote for the first time
column3: the volunteers at the polls who believe every vote should count. Because each of them
column4: in different ways
column5: know how much that precious right is worth.

column1: That's the America I know. That's the country we love: clear eyed
column2: big hearted
column3: undaunted by challenge. Optimistic that unarmed truth and unconditional love will have the final word. That's what makes me so hopeful about our future. I believe in change because I believe in you
column4: the American people. And that's why I stand here as confident as I have ever been that the state of our Union is strong.

column1: Thank you. God bless you. God bless the United States of America. Thank you.@
Donald J. Trump|Address Before a Joint Session of the Congress|2017-02-28|@Thank you very much. Mr. Speaker
column2: Mr. Vice President
column3: Members of Congress
column4: the First Lady of the United States
column5: and citizens of America: Tonight
column6: as we mark the conclusion of our celebration of Black History Month
column7: we are reminded of our Nation's path towards civil rights and the work that still remains to be done. Recent threats targeting Jewish community centers and vandalism of Jewish cemeteries
column8: as well as last week's shooting in Kansas City
column9: remind us that while we may be a nation divided on policies
column10: we are a country that stands united in condemning hate and evil in all of its very ugly forms.

column1: Each American generation passes the torch of truth
column2: liberty
column3: and justice in an unbroken chain
column4: all the way down to the present. That torch is now in our hands
column5: and we will use it to light up the world. I am here tonight to deliver a message of unity and strength
column6: and it is a message deeply delivered from my heart. A new chapter of American greatness is now beginning. A new national pride is sweeping across our Nation. And a new surge of optimism is placing impossible dreams firmly within our grasp.

column1: What we are witnessing today is the renewal of the American spirit. Our allies will find that America is once again ready to lead. All the nations of the worldfriend or foewill find that America is strong
column2: America is proud
column3: and America is free.

column1: In 9 years
column2: the United States will celebrate the 250th anniversary of our founding: 250 years since the day we declared our independence. It will be one of the great milestones in the history of the world. But what will America look like as we reach our 250th year? What kind of country will we leave for our children?

column1: I will not allow the mistakes of recent decades past to define the course of our future. For too long
column2: we've watched our middle class shrink as we've exported our jobs and wealth to foreign countries. We've financed and built one global project after another
column3: but ignored the fates of our children in the inner cities of Chicago
column4: Baltimore
column5: Detroit
column6: and so many other places throughout our land.

column1: We've defended the borders of other nations
column2: while leaving our own borders wide open for anyone to cross and for drugs to pour in at a now unprecedented rate. And we've spent trillions and trillions of dollars overseas
column3: while our infrastructure at home has so badly crumbled.

column1: Then
column3: the Earth shifted beneath our feet. The rebellion started as a quiet protest
column4: spoken by families of all colors and creeds
column5: families who just wanted a fair shot for their children and a fair hearing for their concerns.

column1: But then the quiet voices became a loud chorus
column2: as thousands of citizens now spoke out together
column3: from cities small and large
column4: all across our country. Finally
column5: the chorus became an earthquake
column6: and the people turned out by the tens of millions
column7: and they were all united by one very simple
column8: but crucial demand: that America must put its own citizens first. Because only then can we truly make America great again.

column1: Dying industries will come roaring back to life. Heroic veterans will get the care they so desperately need. Our military will be given the resources its brave warriors so richly deserve. Crumbling infrastructure will be replaced with new roads
column2: bridges
column3: tunnels
column4: airports
column5: and railways gleaming across our very
column6: very beautiful land. Our terrible drug epidemic will slow down and
column7: ultimately
column8: stop. And our neglected inner cities will see a rebirth of hope
column9: safety
column10: and opportunity. Above all else
column11: we will keep our promises to the American people.  Thank you.

column1: It's been a little over a month since my Inauguration
column2: and I want to take this moment to update the Nation on the progress I've made in keeping those promises.

column1: Since my election
column2: Ford
column3: Fiat Chrysler
column4: General Motors
column5: Sprint
column6: Softbank
column7: Lockheed
column8: Intel
column9: Walmart
column10: and many others have announced that they will invest billions and billions of dollars in the United States and will create tens of thousands of new American jobs.

column1: The stock market has gained almost $3 trillion in value since the election on November 8a record. We've saved taxpayers hundreds of millions of dollars by bringing down the price of fantasticand it is a fantasticnew F-35 jet fighter
column2: and we'll be saving billions more on contracts all across our Government. We have placed a hiring freeze on nonmilitary and nonessential Federal workers.

column1: We have begun to drain the swamp of government corruption by imposing a 5-year ban on lobbying by executive branch officials and a lifetime ban ... thank you. Thank you. And a lifetime ban on becoming lobbyists for a foreign government.
We have undertaken a historic effort to massively reduce job-crushing regulations
column2: creating a deregulation Task Force inside of every Government agency. And we're imposing a new rule which mandates that for every one new regulation
column3: two old regulations must be eliminated. We're going to stop the regulations that threaten the future and livelihood of our great coal miners.

column1: We have cleared the way for the construction of the Keystone and Dakota Access pipelines
column2: thereby creating tens of thousands of jobs. And I've issued a new directive that new American pipelines be made with American steel.

column1: We have withdrawn the United States from the job-killing Trans-Pacific Partnership. And with the help of Prime Minister Justin Trudeau
column2: we have formed a council with our neighbors in Canada to help ensure that women entrepreneurs have access to the networks
column3: markets
column4: and capital they need to start a business and live out their financial dreams.

column1: To protect our citizens
column2: I have directed the Department of Justice to form a Task Force on Reducing Violent Crime. I have further ordered the Departments of Homeland Security and Justice
column3: along with the Department of State and the Director of National Intelligence
column4: to coordinate an aggressive strategy to dismantle the criminal cartels that have spread all across our Nation. We will stop the drugs from pouring into our country and poisoning our youth
column5: and we will expand treatment for those who have become so badly addicted.

column1: At the same time
column2: my administration has answered the pleas of the American people for immigration enforcement and border security. By finally enforcing our immigration laws
column3: we will raise wages
column4: help the unemployed
column5: save billions and billions of dollars
column6: and make our communities safer for everyone. We want all Americans to succeed
column7: but that can't happen in an environment of lawless chaos. We must restore integrity and the rule of law at our borders.

column1: For that reason
column2: we will soon begin the construction of a great
column3: great wall along our southern border. As we speak tonight
column4: we are removing gang members
column5: drug dealers
column6: and criminals that threaten our communities and prey on our very innocent citizens. Bad ones are going out as I speak
column7: and as I've promised throughout the campaign.

column1: To any in Congress who do not believe we should enforce our laws
column2: I would ask you this one question: What would you say to the American family that loses their jobs
column3: their income
column4: or their loved one because America refused to uphold its laws and defend its borders?

column1: Our obligation is to serve
column2: protect
column3: and defend the citizens of the United States. We are also taking strong measures to protect our Nation from radical Islamic terrorism. According to data provided by the Department of Justice
column4: the vast majority of individuals convicted of terrorism and terrorism-related offenses since 9/11 came here from outside of our country. We have seen the attacks at home
column5: from Boston to San Bernardino to the Pentagon
column6: and
column7: yes
column8: even the World Trade Center.

column1: We have seen the attacks in France
column2: in Belgium
column3: in Germany
column4: and all over the world. It is not compassionate
column5: but reckless to allow uncontrolled entry from places where proper vetting cannot occur. Those given the high honor of admission to the United States should support this country and love its people and its values. We cannot allow a beachhead of terrorism to form inside America. We cannot allow our Nation to become a sanctuary for extremists.

column1: That is why my administration has been working on improved vetting procedures
column2: and we will shortly take new steps to keep our Nation safe and to keep those out who will do us harm.

column1: As promised
column2: I directed the Department of Defense to develop a plan to demolish and destroy ISIS
column3: a network of lawless savages that have slaughtered Muslims and Christians
column4: and men and women and children of all faiths and all beliefs. We will work with our allies
column5: including our friends and allies in the Muslim world
column6: to extinguish this vile enemy from our planet.

column1: I have also imposed new sanctions on entities and individuals who support Iran's ballistic missile program and reaffirmed our unbreakable alliance with the State of Israel.
Finally
column2: I have kept my promise to appoint a Justice to the United States Supreme Court
column3: from my list of 20 judges
column4: who will defend our Constitution.

column1: I am greatly honored to have Maureen Scalia with us in the gallery tonight. Thank you
column2: Maureen. Her late
column3: great husband
column4: Antonin Scalia
column5: will forever be a symbol of American justice. To fill his seat
column6: we have chosen Judge Neil Gorsuch
column7: a man of incredible skill and deep devotion to the law. He was confirmed unanimously by the Court of Appeals
column8: and I am asking the Senate to swiftly approve his nomination.

column1: Tonight
column2: as I outline the next steps we must take as a country
column3: we must honestly acknowledge the circumstances we inherited. Ninety-four million Americans are out of the labor force. Over 43 million people are now living in poverty
column4: and over 43 million Americans are on food stamps. More than 1 in 5 people in their prime working years are not working. We have the worst financial recovery in 65 years. In the last 8 years
column5: the past administration has put on more new debt than nearly all of the other Presidents combined.

column1: We've lost more than one-fourth of our manufacturing jobs since NAFTA was approved
column2: and we've lost 60
column3: 000 factories since China joined the World Trade Organization in 2001. Our trade deficit in goods with the world last year was nearly $800 billion dollars. And overseas we have inherited a series of tragic foreign policy disasters. Solving these and so many other pressing problems will require us to work past the differences of party. It will require us to tap into the American spirit that has overcome every challenge throughout our long and storied history. But to accomplish our goals at home and abroad
column4: we must restart the engine of the American economy
column5: making it easier for companies to do business in the United States
column6: and much
column7: much harder for companies to leave our country.

column1: Right now American companies are taxed at one of the highest rates anywhere in the world. My economic team is developing historic tax reform that will reduce the tax rate on our companies so they can compete and thrive anywhere and with anyone. It will be a big
column2: big cut.

column1: At the same time
column2: we will provide massive tax relief for the middle class. We must create a level playing field for American companies and our workershave to do it. Currently
column3: when we ship products out of America
column4: many other countries make us pay very high tariffs and taxes. But when foreign companies ship their products into America
column5: we charge them nothing
column6: or almost nothing.

column1: I just met with officials and workers from a great American company
column2: Harley-Davidson. In fact
column3: they proudly displayed five of their magnificent motorcycles
column4: made in the U.S.A.
column5: on the front lawn of the White House.  And they wanted me to ride one
column6: and I said
column7: "No
column8: thank you."

column1: At our meeting
column2: I asked them
column3: how are you doing
column4: how is business? They said that it's good. I asked them further
column5: how are you doing with other countries
column6: mainly international sales? They told mewithout even complaining
column7: because they have been so mistreated for so long that they've become used to itthat it's very hard to do business with other countries because they tax our goods at such a high rate. They said that in the case of another country
column8: they taxed their motorcycles at 100 percent. They weren't even asking for a change. But I am.

column1: I believe strongly in free trade
column2: but it also has to be fair trade. It's been a long time since we had fair trade. The first Republican President
column3: Abraham Lincoln
column4: warned that the "abandonment of the protective policy by the American Government will produce want and ruin among our people." Lincoln was right
column5: and it's time we heeded his advice and his words. I am not going to let America and its great companies and workers be taken advantage of us any longer. They have taken advantage of our country. No longer.

column1: I am going to bring back millions of jobs. Protecting our workers also means reforming our system of legal immigration. The current
column2: outdated system depresses wages for our poorest workers and puts great pressure on taxpayers. Nations around the world like Canada
column3: Australia
column4: and many others
column5: have a merit-based immigration system. It's a basic principle that those seeking to enter a country ought to be able to support themselves financially. Yet
column6: in America
column7: we do not enforce this rule
column8: straining the very public resources that our poorest citizens rely upon. According to the National Academy of Sciences
column9: our current immigration system costs American taxpayers many billions of dollars a year.

column1: Switching away from this current system of lower skilled immigration
column2: and instead adopting a merit-based system
column3: we will have so many more benefits. It will save countless dollars
column4: raise workers' wages
column5: and help struggling familiesincluding immigrant familiesenter the middle class. And they will do it quickly
column6: and they will be very
column7: very happy
column8: indeed.

column1: I believe that real and positive immigration reform is possible
column2: as long as we focus on the following goals: to improve jobs and wages for Americans
column3: to strengthen our Nation's security
column4: and to restore respect for our laws. If we are guided by the wellbeing of American citizens
column5: then I believe Republicans and Democrats can work together to achieve an outcome that has eluded our country for decades.

column1: Another Republican President
column2: Dwight D. Eisenhower
column3: initiated the last truly great national infrastructure programthe building of the Interstate Highway System. The time has come for a new program of national rebuilding. America has spent approximately $6 trillion in the Middle East; all the while
column4: our infrastructure at home is crumbling. With this $6 trillion
column5: we could have rebuilt our country twice
column6: and maybe even three times if we had people who had the ability to negotiate.

column1: To launch our national rebuilding
column2: I will be asking Congress to approve legislation that produces a $1 trillion investment in infrastructure of the United Statesfinanced through both public and private capitalcreating millions of new jobs. This effort will be guided by two core principles: buy American and hire American.

column1: Tonight I am also calling on this Congress to repeal and replace Obamacare with reforms that expand choice
column2: increase access
column3: lower costs
column4: and at the same time
column5: provide better health care.

column1: Mandating every American to buy Government-approved health insurance was never the right solution for our country. The way to make health insurance available to everyone is to lower the cost of health insurance
column2: and that is what we are going do.

column1: Obamacare premiums nationwide have increased by double and triple digits. As an example
column2: Arizona went up 116 percent last year alone. Governor Matt Bevin of Kentucky just said Obamacare is failing in his Statethe State of Kentuckyand it's unsustainable and collapsing.

column1: One-third of the counties have only one insurer
column2: and they are losing them fast. They are losing them so fast. They are leaving
column3: and many Americans have no choice at all. There's no choice left. Remember when you were told that you could keep your doctor and keep your plan? We now know that all of those promises have been totally broken. Obamacare is collapsing
column4: and we must act decisively to protect all Americans.

column1: Action is not a choice
column2: it is a necessity. So I am calling on all Democrats and Republicans in Congress to work with us to save Americans from this imploding Obamacare disaster.

column1: Here are the principles that should guide the Congress as we move to create a better health care system for all Americans:
First
column2: we should ensure that Americans with preexisting conditions have access to coverage
column3: and that we have a stable transition for Americans currently enrolled in the health care exchanges.

column1: Secondly
column2: we should help Americans purchase their own coverage through the use of tax credits and expanded health savings accounts
column3: but it must be the plan they want
column4: not the plan forced on them by our Government.

column1: Thirdly
column2: we should give our State Governors the resources and flexibility they need with Medicaid to make sure no one is left out.

column1: Fourth
column2: we should implement legal reforms that protect patients and doctors from unnecessary costs that drive up the price of insurance and work to bring down the artificially high price of drugs and bring them down immediately. And finally
column3: the time has come to give Americans the freedom to purchase health insurance across State lines
column4: which will create a truly competitive national marketplace that will bring costs way down and provide far better care. So important.

column1: Everything that is broken in our country can be fixed. Every problem can be solved. And every hurting family can find healing and hope.
Our citizens deserve this and so much more
column2: so why not join forces and finally get the job done
column3: and get it done right? On this and so many other things
column4: Democrats and Republicans should get together and unite for the good of our country and for the good of the American people.

column1: My administration wants to work with members of both parties to make childcare accessible and affordable; to help ensure new parents that they have paid family leave; to invest in women's health; and to promote clean air and clean water; and to rebuild our military and our infrastructure.
True love for our people requires us to find common ground
column2: to advance the common good
column3: and to cooperate on behalf of every American child who deserves a much brighter future.

column1: An incredible young woman is with us this evening
column2: who should serve as an inspiration to us all. Today is Rare Disease Day
column3: and joining us in the gallery is a rare disease survivor
column4: Megan Crowley.

column1: Megan was diagnosed with Pompe disease
column2: a rare and serious illness
column3: when she was 15 months old. She was not expected to live past 5. On receiving this news
column4: Megan's dad John fought with everything he had to save the life of his precious child. He founded a company to look for a cure and helped develop the drug that saved Megan's life. Today she is 20 years old and a sophomore at Notre Dame.

column1: Megan's story is about the unbounded power of a father's love for a daughter. But our slow and burdensome approval process at the Food and Drug Administration keeps too many advances
column2: like the one that saved Megan's life
column3: from reaching those in need. If we slash the restraints
column4: not just at the FDA
column5: but across our Government
column6: then we will be blessed with far more miracles just like Megan. In fact
column7: our children will grow up in a nation of miracles.

column1: But to achieve this future
column2: we must enrich the mind and the souls of every American child. Education is the civil rights issue of our time. I am calling upon members of both parties to pass an education bill that funds school choice for disadvantaged youth
column3: including millions of African American and Latino children. These families should be free to choose the public
column4: private
column5: charter
column6: magnet
column7: religious
column8: or home school that is right for them.

column1: Joining us tonight in the gallery is a remarkable woman
column2: Denisha Merriweather. As a young girl
column3: Denisha struggled in school and failed third grade twice. But then
column4: she was able to enroll in a private center for learninggreat learning centerwith the help of a tax credit and a scholarship program.

column1: Today
column2: she is the first in her family to graduate
column3: not just from high school
column4: but from college. Later this year she will get her master's degree in social work. We want all children to be able to break the cycle of poverty just like Denisha.

column1: But to break the cycle of poverty
column2: we must also break the cycle of violence. The murder rate in 2015 experienced its largest single-year increase in nearly half a century. In Chicago
column3: more than 4
column4: 000 people were shot last year alone
column5: and the murder rate so far this year has been even higher. This is not acceptable in our society.

column1: Every American child should be able to grow up in a safe community
column2: to attend a great school
column3: and to have access to a high-paying job. But to create this future
column4: we must work with
column5: not againstnot againstthe men and women of law enforcement. We must build bridges of cooperation and trust
column6: not drive the wedge of disunity
column7: and really
column8: it's what it isdivision. It's pure
column9: unadulterated division. We have to unify.

column1: Police and sheriffs are members of our community. They're friends and neighbors
column2: they're mothers and fathers
column3: sons and daughters
column4: and they leave behind loved ones every day who worry about whether or not they'll come home safe and sound. We must support the incredible men and women of law enforcement.

column1: And we must support the victims of crime. I have ordered the Department of Homeland Security to create an office to serve American victims. The office is called VOICE: Victims of Immigration Crime Engagement. We are providing a voice to those who have been ignored by our media and silenced by special interests. Joining us in the audience tonight are four very brave Americans whose Government failed them. Their names are Jamiel Shaw
column2: Susan Oliver
column3: Jenna Oliver
column4: and Jessica Davis.

column1: Jamiel's 17-year-old son was viciously murdered by an illegal immigrant gang member who had just been released from prison. Jamiel Shaw
column2: Jr. was an incredible young man
column3: with unlimited potential
column4: who was getting ready to go to college where he would have excelled as a great college quarterback. But he never got the chance. His father
column5: who is in the audience tonight
column6: has become a very good friend of mine. Jamiel
column7: thank you. Thank you.

column1: Also with us are Susan Oliver and Jessica Davis. Their husbands
column2: Deputy Sheriff Danny Oliver and Detective Michael Davis
column3: were slain in the line of duty in California. They were pillars of their community. These brave men were viciously gunned down by an illegal immigrant with a criminal record and two prior deportations. Should have never been in our country.

column1: Sitting with Susan is her daughter
column2: Jenna. Jenna
column3: I want you to know that your father was a hero
column4: and that tonight you have the love of an entire country supporting you and praying for you.

column1: To Jamiel
column2: Jenna
column3: Susan
column4: and Jessica: I want you to know that we will never stop fighting for justice. Your loved ones will never
column5: ever be forgotten. We will always honor their memory.

column1: Finally
column2: to keep America safe
column3: we must provide the men and women of the United States military with the tools they need to prevent war. If they must
column4: they have to fight and they only have to win.

column1: I am sending Congress a budget that rebuilds the military
column2: eliminates the defense sequester
column3: and calls for one of the largest increases in national defense spending in American history. My budget will also increase funding for our veterans. Our veterans have delivered for this Nation
column4: and now we must deliver for them.

column1: The challenges we face as a nation are great
column2: but our people are even greater. And none are greater or are braver than those who fight for America in uniform.

column1: We are blessed to be joined tonight by Carryn Owens
column2: the widow of U.S. Navy Special Operator
column3: Senior Chief William "Ryan" Owens. Ryan died as he lived: a warrior and a hero
column4: battling against terrorism and securing our Nation. I just spoke to our great General Mattis
column5: just now
column6: who reconfirmed thatand I quote"Ryan was a part of a highly successful raid that generated large amounts of vital intelligence that will lead to many more victories in the future against our enemy." Ryan's legacy is etched into eternity. Thank you.  And Ryan is looking down
column7: right nowyou know thatand he is very happy because I think he just broke a record.

column1: For as the Bible teaches us
column2: there is no greater act of love than to lay down one's life for one's friends. Ryan laid down his life for his friends
column3: for his country
column4: and for our freedom. And we will never forget Ryan.

column1: To those allies who wonder what kind of a friend America will be
column2: look no further than the heroes who wear our uniform. Our foreign policy calls for a direct
column3: robust
column4: and meaningful engagement with the world. It is American leadership based on vital security interests that we share with our allies all across the globe.

column1: We strongly support NATO
column2: an alliance forged through the bonds of two world wars that dethroned fascism
column3: and a cold war
column4: and defeated communism.

column1: But our partners must meet their financial obligations. And now
column2: based on our very strong and frank discussions
column3: they are beginning to do just that. In fact
column4: I can tell you
column5: the money is pouring in. Very nice. We expect our partnerswhether in NATO
column6: the Middle East
column7: or in the Pacificto take a direct and meaningful role in both strategic and military operations
column8: and pay their fair share of the cost. Have to do that.

column1: We will respect historic institutions
column2: but we will respect the foreign rights of all nations
column3: and they have to respect our rights as a nation also. Free nations are the best vehicle for expressing the will of the people
column4: and America respects the right of all nations to chart their own path. My job is not to represent the world. My job is to represent the United States of America.

column1: But we know that America is better off when there is less conflict
column2: not more. We must learn from the mistakes of the past. We have seen the war and the destruction that have ravaged and raged throughout the worldall across the world. The only long-term solution for these humanitarian disasters
column3: in many cases
column4: is to create the conditions where displaced persons can safely return home and begin the long
column5: long process of rebuilding.

column1: America is willing to find new friends and to forge new partnerships where shared interests align. We want harmony and stability
column2: not war and conflict. We want peace
column3: wherever peace can be found.

column1: America is friends today with former enemies. Some of our closest allies
column2: decades ago
column3: fought on the opposite side of these terrible
column4: terrible wars. This history should give us all faith in the possibilities for a better world. Hopefully
column5: the 250th year for America will see a world that is more peaceful
column6: more just
column7: and more free.

column1: On our 100th anniversary
column3: citizens from across our Nation came to Philadelphia to celebrate America's centennial. At that celebration
column4: the country's builders and artists and inventors showed off their wonderful creations. Alexander Graham Bell displayed his telephone for the first time. Remington unveiled the first typewriter. An early attempt was made at electric light. Thomas Edison showed an automatic telegraph and an electric pen. Imagine the wonders our country could know in America's 250th year. Think of the marvels we can achieve if we simply set free the dreams of our people. Cures to the illnesses that have always plagued us are not too much to hope. American footprints on distant worlds are not too big a dream. Millions lifted from welfare to work is not too much to expect. And streets where mothers are safe from fear
column5: schools where children learn in peace
column6: and jobs where Americans prosper and grow are not too much to ask.

column1: When we have all of this
column2: we will have made America greater than ever beforefor all Americans. This is our vision. This is our mission. But we can only get there together. We are one people with one destiny. We all bleed the same blood. We all salute the same great American flag. And we all are made by the same God.

column1: When we fulfill this vision
column2: when we celebrate our 250 years of glorious freedom
column3: we will look back on tonight as when this new chapter of American greatness began. The time for small thinking is over. The time for trivial fights is behind us. We just need the courage to share the dreams that fill our hearts
column4: the bravery to express the hopes that stir our souls
column5: and the confidence to turn those hopes and those dreams into action.

column1: From now on
column2: America will be empowered by our aspirations
column3: not burdened by our fears; inspired by the future
column4: not bound by failures of the past; and guided by our vision
column5: not blinded by our doubts.

column1: I am asking all citizens to embrace this renewal of the American spirit. I am asking all Members of Congress to join me in dreaming big and bold
column2: and daring things for our country. I am asking everyone watching tonight to seize this moment. Believe in yourselves
column3: believe in your future
column4: and believe
column5: once more
column6: in America.

column1: Thank you
column2: God bless you
column3: and God bless the United States.@

column1: Donald J. Trump|Address Before a Joint Session of the Congress on the State of the Union|2018-01-30|@Mr. Speaker
column2: Mr. Vice President
column3: Members of Congress
column4: the First Lady of the United States
column5: and my fellow Americans: Less than 1 year has passed since I first stood at this podium
column6: in this majestic Chamber
column7: to speak on behalf of the American people and to address their concerns
column8: their hopes
column9: and their dreams. That night
column10: our new administration had already taken very swift action. A new tide of optimism was already sweeping across our land. Each day since
column11: we have gone forward with a clear vision and a righteous mission: to make America great again for all Americans.

column1: Over the last year
column2: we have made incredible progress and achieved extraordinary success. We have faced challenges we expected and others we could never have imagined. We have shared in the heights of victory and the pains of hardship. We have endured floods and fires and storms. But through it all
column3: we have seen the beauty of America's soul and the steel in America's spine.

column1: Each test has forged new American heroes to remind us who we are and show us what we can be. We saw the volunteers of the Cajun Navy racing to the rescue with their fishing boats to save people in the aftermath of a totally devastating hurricane. We saw strangers shielding strangers from a hail of gunfire on the Las Vegas strip.
We heard tales of Americans like Coast Guard Petty Officer Ashlee Leppert
column2: who is here tonight in the gallery with Melania. Ashlee was aboard one of the first helicopters on the scene in Houston during the Hurricane Harvey. Through 18 hours of wind and rain
column3: Ashlee braved live power lines and deep water to help save more than 40 lives. Ashlee
column4: we all thank you. Thank you very much.

column1: We heard about Americans like firefighter David Dahlberg. He's here with us also. David faced down walls of flame to rescue almost 60 children trapped at a California summer camp threatened by those devastating wildfires. To everyone still recovering in Texas
column2: Florida
column3: Louisiana
column4: Puerto Rico
column5: and the Virgin Islandseverywherewe are with you
column6: we love you
column7: and we always will pull through together
column8: always. Thank you to David and the brave people of California. Thank you very much
column9: David. Great job.

column1: Some trials over the past year touched this Chamber very personally. With us tonight is one of the toughest people ever to serve in this House
column2: a guy who took a bullet
column3: almost died
column4: and was back to work 3 months later: the legend from Louisiana ... Congressman Steve Scalise. I think they like you
column5: Steve.  We are incredibly grateful for the heroic efforts of the Capitol Police officers
column6: the Alexandria Police
column7: and the doctors
column8: nurses
column9: and paramedics who saved his life and the lives of many others; some in this room. In the aftermath ... yes. Yes.

column1: In the aftermath of that terrible shooting
column2: we came together
column3: not as Republicans or Democrats
column4: but as representatives of the people. But it is not enough to come together only in times of tragedy. Tonight I call upon all of us to set aside our differences
column5: to seek out common ground
column6: and to summon the unity we need to deliver for the people. This is really the key. These are the people we were elected to serve.  Thank you. Over the last year
column7: the world has seen what we always knew: that no people on Earth are so fearless or daring or determined as Americans. If there is a mountain
column8: we climb it. If there is a frontier
column9: we cross it. If there's a challenge
column10: we tame it. If there's an opportunity
column11: we seize it. So let's begin tonight by recognizing that the state of our Union is strong because our people are strong. And together
column12: we are building a safe
column13: strong
column14: and proud America.

column1: Since the election
column2: we have created 2.4 million new jobs
column3: including 200
column4: 000 new jobs in manufacturing alone. Tremendous numbers. After years and years of wage stagnation
column5: we are finally seeing rising wages. Unemployment claims have hit a 45-year low. And something I'm very proud of: African American unemployment stands at the lowest rate ever recorded. And Hispanic American unemployment has also reached the lowest levels in history.

column1: Small-business confidence is at an alltime high. The stock market has smashed one record after another
column2: gaining $8 trillion and more in value in just this short period of time. The great news for Americans: 401(k)
column3: retirement
column4: pension
column5: and college savings accounts have gone through the roof.

column1: And just as I promised the American people from this podium 11 months ago
column2: we enacted the biggest tax cuts and reforms in American history. Our massive tax cuts provide tremendous relief for the middle class and small business. To lower tax rates for hard-working Americans
column3: we nearly doubled the standard deduction for everyone. Now
column4: the first $24
column5: 000 earned by a married couple is completely tax free. We also doubled the child tax credit. A typical family of four making $75
column6: 000 will see their tax bill reduced by $2
column8: slashing their tax bill in half. In April
column9: this will be the last time you will ever file under the old and very broken system
column10: and millions of Americans will have more take-home pay starting next montha lot more.

column1: We eliminated an especially cruel tax that fell mostly on Americans making less than $50
column2: 000 a year
column3: forcing them to pay tremendous penalties simply because they couldn't afford Government-ordered health plans. We repealed the core of the disastrous Obamacare. The individual mandate is now gone
column4: thank heavens.  Great job.

column1: We slashed the business tax rate from 35 percent all the way down to 21 percent
column2: so American companies can compete and win against anyone else anywhere in the world. These changes alone are estimated to increase average family income by more than $4
column4: a lot of money. Small businesses have also received a massive tax cut and can now deduct 20 percent of their business income.

column1: Here tonight are Steve Staub and Sandy Keplinger of Staub Manufacturing
column2: a small
column3: beautiful business in Ohio. They've just finished the best year in their 20-year history. Because of tax reform
column4: they are handing out raises
column5: hiring an additional 14 people
column6: and expanding into the building next door. It's a good feeling.

column1: One of Staub's employees
column2: Corey Adams

column4: lost his job during the 2008 recession
column5: and was later hired by Staub

column8: please stand. And he's a great welder.  I was told that by the man that owns that company that's doing so well. So congratulations
column9: Corey.

column1: Since we passed tax cuts
column2: roughly 3 million workers have already gotten tax cut bonuses
column3: many of them thousands and thousands of dollars per worker. And it's getting more every month
column4: every week. Apple has just announced it plans to invest a total of $350 billion in America and hire another 20
column5: 000 workers. And just a little while ago
column6: ExxonMobil announced a $50 billion investment in the United Statesjust a little while ago.

column1: This
column2: in fact
column3: is our new American moment. There has never been a better time to start living the American Dream. So to every citizen watching at home tonight
column4: no matter where you've been or where you've come from
column5: this is your time. If you work hard
column6: if you believe in yourself
column7: if you believe in America
column8: then you can dream anything
column9: you can be anything
column10: and together
column11: we can achieve absolutely anything.

column1: Tonight I want to talk about what kind of future we are going to have and what kind of a nation we are going to be. All of us
column2: together
column3: as one team
column4: one people
column5: and one American family can do anything. We all share the same home
column6: the same heart
column7: the same destiny
column8: and the same great American flag. Together
column9: we are rediscovering the American way. In America
column10: we know that faith and family
column11: not government and bureaucracy
column12: are the center of American life. The motto is
column13: "In God We Trust." And we celebrate our police
column14: our military
column15: and our amazing veterans as heroes who deserve our total and unwavering support.

column2: a 12-year-old boy from Redding
column3: California
column4: who noticed that veterans' graves were not marked with flags on Veterans Day. He decided all by himself to change that and started a movement that has now placed 40
column5: 000 flags at the graves of our great heroes. Preston
