column7: like Preston
column8: teach all of us about our civic duty as Americans. And I met Preston a little while ago
column9: and he is something very special
column10: that I can tell you. Great future. Thank you very much for all you've done
column11: Preston. Thank you very much.

column1: Preston's reverence for those who have served our Nation reminds us of why we salute our flag
column2: why we put our hands on our hearts for the Pledge of Allegiance
column3: and why we proudly stand for the national anthem. Americans love their country
column4: and they deserve a Government that shows them the same love and loyalty in return. For the last year
column5: we have sought to restore the bonds of trust between our citizens and their Government. Working with the Senate
column6: we are appointing judges who will interpret the Constitution as written
column7: including a great new Supreme Court Justice and more circuit court judges than any new administration in the history of our country. We are totally defending our Second Amendment and have taken historic actions to protect religious liberty.

column1: And we are serving our brave veterans
column2: including giving our veterans choice in their health care decisions. Last year
column3: Congress also passed
column4: and I signed
column5: the landmark VA Accountability Act. Since its passage
column6: my administration has already removed more than 1
column7: 500 VA employees who failed to give our veterans the care they deserve. And we are hiring talented people who love our vets as much as we do. And I will not stop until our veterans are properly taken care of
column8: which has been my promise to them from the very beginning of this great journey.

column1: All Americans deserve accountability and respect
column2: and that's what we are giving to our wonderful heroes
column3: our veterans. Thank you. So tonight I call on Congress to empower every Cabinet Secretary with the authority to reward good workers and to remove Federal employees who undermine the public trust or fail the American people.

column1: In our drive to make Washington accountable
column2: we have eliminated more regulations in our first year than any administration in the history of our country. We have ended the war on American energy
column3: and we have ended the war on beautiful
column4: clean coal. We are now
column5: very proudly
column6: an exporter of energy to the world. In Detroit
column7: I halted Government mandates that crippled America's great
column8: beautiful autoworkers so that we can get Motor City revving its engines again. And that's what's happening. Many car companies are now building and expanding plants in the United States
column9: something we haven't seen for decades. Chrysler is moving a major plant from Mexico to Michigan. Toyota and Mazda are opening up a plant in Alabama
column10: a big one. And we haven't seen this in a long time. It's all coming back.

column1: Very soon
column2: auto plants and other plants will be opening up all over our country. This is all news Americans are totally unaccustomed to hearing. For many years
column3: companies and jobs were only leaving us. But now they are roaring back. They're coming back. They want to be where the action is. They want to be in the United States of America. That's where they want to be.

column1: Exciting progress is happening every single day. To speed access to breakthrough cures and affordable generic drugs
column2: last year
column3: the FDA approved more new and generic drugs and medical devices than ever before in our country's history. We also believe that patients with terminal conditions and terminal illness should have access to experimental treatment immediately that could potentially save their lives. People who are terminally ill should not have to go from country to country to seek a cure. I want to give them a chance right here at home. It's time for Congress to give these wonderful
column4: incredible Americans the right to try.  Right?

column1: One of my greatest priorities is to reduce the price of prescription drugs. In many other countries
column2: these drugs cost far less than what we pay in the United States. And it's very
column3: very unfair. That is why I have directed my administration to make fixing the injustice of high drug prices one of my top priorities for the year. And prices will come down substantially. Watch.

column1: America has also finally turned the page on decades of unfair trade deals that sacrificed our prosperity and shipped away our companies
column2: our jobs
column3: and our wealth. Our Nation has lost its wealth
column4: but we're getting it back so fast. The era of economic surrender is totally over. From now on
column5: we expect trading relationships to be fair and
column6: very importantly
column7: reciprocal.

column1: We will work to fix bad trade deals and negotiate new ones. And they'll be good ones
column2: but they'll be fair. And we will protect American workers and American intellectual property through strong enforcement of our trade rules.

column1: As we rebuild our industries
column2: it is also time to rebuild our crumbling infrastructure. America is a nation of builders. We built the Empire State Building in just 1 year. Isn't it a disgrace that it can now take 10 years just to get a minor permit approved for the building of a simple road? I am asking both parties to come together to give us safe
column3: fast
column4: reliable
column5: and modern infrastructure that our economy needs and our people deserve.

column1: Tonight I'm calling on Congress to produce a bill that generates at least $1.5 trillion for the new infrastructure investment that our country so desperately needs. Every Federal dollar should be leveraged by partnering with State and local governments and
column2: where appropriate
column3: tapping into private sector investment to permanently fix the infrastructure deficit. And we can do it.

column1: Any bill must also streamline the permitting and approval process
column2: getting it down to no more than 2 years and perhaps even 1. Together
column3: we can reclaim our great building heritage. We will build gleaming new roads
column4: bridges
column5: highways
column6: railways
column7: and waterways all across our land. And we will do it with American heart and American hands and American grit. We want every American to know the dignity of a hard day's work. We want every child to be safe in their home at night. And we want every citizen to be proud of this land that we all love so much. We can lift our citizens from welfare to work
column8: from dependence to independence
column9: and from poverty to prosperity.

column1: As tax cuts create new jobs
column2: let's invest in workforce development
column3: and let's invest in job training
column4: which we need so badly. Let's open great vocational schools so our future workers can learn a craft and realize their full potential. And let's support working families by supporting paid family leave.

column1: As America regains its strength
column2: opportunity must be extended to all citizens. That is why this year
column3: we will embark on reforming our prisons to help former inmates
column4: who have served their time
column5: get a second chance at life.

column1: Struggling communities
column2: especially immigrant communities
column3: will also be helped by immigration policies that focus on the best interests of American workers and American families. For decades
column4: open borders have allowed drugs and gangs to pour into our most vulnerable communities. They've allowed millions of low-wage workers to compete for jobs and wages against the poorest Americans. Most tragically
column5: they have caused the loss of many innocent lives.

column1: Here tonight are two fathers and two mothers: Evelyn Rodriguez
column2: Freddy Cuevas
column3: Elizabeth Alvarado
column4: and Robert Mickens. Their two teenage daughtersKayla Cuevas and Nisa Mickenswere close friends on Long Island. But in September 2016
column5: on the eve of Nisa's 16th birthdaysuch a happy time it should have beenneither of them came home. These two precious girls were brutally murdered while walking together in their hometown.

column1: Six members of the savage MS-13 gang have been charged with Kayla and Nisa's murders. Many of these gang members took advantage of glaring loopholes in our laws to enter the country as illegal
column2: unaccompanied alien minors
column3: and wound up in Kayla and Nisa's high school. Evelyn
column4: Elizabeth
column5: Freddy
column6: and Robert: Tonight everyone in this chamber is praying for you. Everyone in America is grieving for you. Please stand. Thank you very much. I want you to know that 320 million hearts are right now breaking for you. We love you. Thank you.

column1: While we cannot imagine the depths of that kind of sorrow
column2: we can make sure that other families never have to endure this kind of pain. Tonight I am calling on Congress to finally close the deadly loopholes that have allowed MS-13 and other criminal gangs to break into our country. We have proposed new legislation that will fix our immigration laws and support our ICE and Border Patrol agentsthese are great people; these are great
column3: great peoplethat work so hard in the midst of such danger so that this can never happen again.

column1: The United States is a compassionate nation. We are proud that we do more than any other country anywhere in the world to help the needy
column2: the struggling
column3: and the underprivileged all over the world. But as President of the United States
column4: my highest loyalty
column5: my greatest compassion
column6: my constant concern is for America's children
column7: America's struggling workers
column8: and America's forgotten communities. I want our youth to grow up to achieve great things. I want our poor to have their chance to rise.

column1: So tonight I am extending an open hand to work with members of both parties
column2: Democrats and Republicans
column3: to protect our citizens of every background
column4: color
column5: religion
column6: and creed. My duty
column7: and the sacred duty of every elected official in this Chamber
column8: is to defend Americans
column9: to protect their safety
column10: their families
column11: their communities
column12: and their right to the American Dream. Because Americans are dreamers too. Here tonight is one leader in the effort to defend our country
column13: Homeland Security Investigations Special Agent Celestino Martinez. He goes by "D.J." and "C.J." He said
column14: "Call me either one."  So we'll call you "C.J."  Served 15 years in the Air Force before becoming an ICE agent and spending the last 15 years fighting gang violence and getting dangerous criminals off of our streets. Tough job.

column1: At one point
column2: MS-13 leaders ordered C.J.'s murder. And they wanted it to happen quickly. But he did not cave to threats or to fear. Last May
column3: he commanded an operation to track down gang members on Long Island. His team has arrested nearly 400
column4: including more than 220 MS-13 gang members. And I have to tell you
column5: what the Border Patrol and ICE have done
column6: we have sent thousands and thousands and thousands of MS-13 horrible people out of this country or into our prisons. So I just want to congratulate you
column7: C.J. You're a brave guy. Thank you very much.

column1: And I asked C.J.
column2: "What's the secret?" He said
column3: "We're just tougher than they are." And I like that answer.  Now
column4: let's get Congress to send youand all of the people in this great Chamber have to do it; we have no choice. C.J.
column5: we're going to send you reinforcements
column6: and we're going to send them to you quickly. It's what you need.

column1: Over the next few weeks
column2: the House and Senate will be voting on an immigration reform package. In recent months
column3: my administration has met extensively with both Democrats and Republicans to craft a bipartisan approach to immigration reform. Based on these discussions
column4: we presented Congress with a detailed proposal that should be supported by both parties as a fair compromise
column5: one where nobody gets everything they want
column6: but where our country gets the critical reforms it needs and must have.

column1: Here are the four pillars of our plan: The first pillar of our framework generously offers a path to citizenship for 1.8 million illegal immigrants who were brought here by their parents at a young age. That covers almost three times more people than the previous administration covered. Under our plan
column2: those who meet education and work requirements and show good moral character will be able to become full citizens of the United States over a 12-year period.

column1: The second pillar fully secures the border. That means building a great wall on the southern border
column2: and it means hiring more heroes
column3: like C.J.
column4: to keep our communities safe. Crucially
column5: our plan closes the terrible loopholes exploited by criminals and terrorists to enter our country
column6: and it finally ends the horrible and dangerous practice of catch-and-release.

column1: The third pillar ends the visa lottery
column2: a program that randomly hands out green cards without any regard for skill
column3: merit
column4: or the safety of American people. It's time to begin moving toward a merit-based immigration system
column5: one that admits people who are skilled
column6: who want to work
column7: who will contribute to our society
column8: and who will love and respect our country.

column1: The fourth and final pillar protects the nuclear family by ending chain migration. Under the current broken system
column2: a single immigrant can bring in virtually unlimited numbers of distant relatives. Under our plan
column3: we focus on the immediate family by limiting sponsorships to spouses and minor children. This vital reform is necessary
column4: not just for our economy
column5: but for our security and for the future of America.

column1: In recent weeks
column2: two terrorist attacks in New York were made possible by the visa lottery and chain migration. In the age of terrorism
column3: these programs present risks we can just no longer afford. It's time to reform these outdated immigration rules and finally bring our immigration system into the 21st century. These four pillars represent a down-the-middle compromise and one that will create a safe
column4: modern
column5: and lawful immigration system. For over 30 years
column6: Washington has tried and failed to solve this problem. This Congress can be the one that finally makes it happen. Most importantly
column7: these four pillars will produce legislation that fulfills my ironclad pledge to sign a bill that puts America first. So let's come together
column8: set politics aside
column9: and finally get the job done.

column1: These reforms will also support our response to the terrible crisis of opioid and drug addiction. Never before has it been like it is now. It is terrible. We have to do something about it. In 2016
column2: we lost 64
column3: 000 Americans to drug overdoses: 174 deaths per day
column4: 7 per hour. We must get much tougher on drug dealers and pushers if we are going to succeed in stopping this scourge.

column1: My administration is committed to fighting the drug epidemic and helping get treatment for those in need
column2: for those who have been so terribly hurt. The struggle will be long
column3: and it will be difficult
column4: but as Americans always do
column5: in the end
column6: we will succeed. We will prevail.

column1: As we have seen tonight
column2: the most difficult challenges bring out the best in America. We see a vivid expression of this truth in the story of the Holets family of New Mexico. Ryan Holets is 27 years old
column3: an officer with the Albuquerque Police Department. He's here tonight with his wife Rebecca. Thank you
column4: Ryan.

column1: Last year
column2: Ryan was on duty when he saw a pregnant
column3: homeless woman preparing to inject heroin. When Ryan told her she was going to harm her unborn child
column4: she began to weep. She told him she didn't know where to turn
column5: but badly wanted a safe home for her baby.

column1: In that moment
column2: Ryan said he felt God speak to him: "You will do it
column3: because you can." He heard those words. He took out a picture of his wife and their four kids. Then
column4: he went home to tell his wife Rebecca. In an instant
column5: she agreed to adopt. The Holets named their new daughter Hope. Ryan and Rebecca
column6: you embody the goodness of our Nation. Thank you. Thank you
column7: Ryan and Rebecca.

column1: As we rebuild America's strength and confidence at home
column2: we are also restoring our strength and standing abroad. Around the world
column3: we face rogue regimes
column4: terrorist groups
column5: and rivals like China and Russia that challenge our interests
column6: our economy
column7: and our values. In confronting these horrible dangers
column8: we know that weakness is the surest path to conflict and unmatched power is the surest means to our true and great defense.

column1: For this reason
column2: I am asking Congress to end the dangerous defense sequester and fully fund our great military. As part of our defense
column3: we must modernize and rebuild our nuclear arsenal
column4: hopefully
column5: never having to use it
column6: but making it so strong and so powerful that it will deter any acts of aggression by any other nation or anyone else. Perhaps someday in the future
column7: there will be a magical moment when the countries of the world will get together to eliminate their nuclear weapons. Unfortunately
column8: we are not there yet
column9: sadly.

column1: Last year
column2: I also pledged that we would work with our allies to extinguish ISIS from the face of the Earth. One year later
column3: I am proud to report that the coalition to defeat ISIS has liberated very close to 100 percent of the territory just recently held by these killers in Iraq and in Syria and in other locations as well. But there is much more work to be done. We will continue our fight until ISIS is defeated.

column1: Army Staff Sergeant Justin Peck is here tonight. Near Raqqa
column2: last November
column3: Justin and his comrade
column4: Chief Petty Officer Kenton Stacy
column5: were on a mission to clear buildings that ISIS had rigged with explosive so that civilians could return to that city
column6: hopefully
column7: soon and
column8: hopefully
column9: safely.

column1: Clearing the second floor of a vital hospital
column2: Kenton Stacy was severely wounded by an explosion. Immediately
column3: Justin bounded into the booby-trapped and unbelievably dangerous and unsafe building
column4: and found Kenton
column5: but in very
column6: very bad shape. He applied pressure to the wound and inserted a tube to reopen an airway. He then performed CPR for 20 straight minutes during the ground transport and maintained artificial respiration through 2 hours and through emergency surgery.

column1: Kenton Stacy would have died if it were not for Justin's selfless love for his fellow warrior. Tonight Kenton is recovering in Texas
column2: Raqqa is liberated
column3: and Justin is wearing his new Bronze Star
column4: with a "V" for valor. Staff Sergeant Peck
column5: all of America salutes you.

column1: Terrorists who do things like place bombs in civilian hospitals are evil. When possible
column2: we have no choice but to annihilate them. When necessary
column3: we must be able to detain and question them. But we must be clear: Terrorists are not merely criminals
column4: they are unlawful enemy combatants. And when captured overseas
column5: they should be treated like the terrorists they are.

column1: In the past
column2: we have foolishly released hundreds and hundreds of dangerous terrorists
column3: only to meet them again on the battlefield
column4: including the ISIS leader
column5: al-Baghdadi
column6: who we captured
column7: who we had
column8: who we released. So today I'm keeping another promise. I just signed
column9: prior to walking in
column10: an order directing Secretary Mattiswho is doing a great job
column11: thank youto reexamine our military detention policy and to keep open the detention facilities in Guantanamo Bay. I am asking Congress to ensure that
column12: in the fight against ISIS and Al Qaida
column13: we continue to have all necessary power to detain terrorists
column14: wherever we chase them down
column15: wherever we find them. And in many cases
column17: it will now be Guantanamo Bay.

column1: At the same time
column2: as of a few months ago
column3: our warriors in Afghanistan have new rules of engagement. Along with their heroic Afghan partners
column4: our military is no longer undermined by artificial timelines
column5: and we no longer tell our enemies our plans.

column1: Last month
column2: I also took an action endorsed unanimously by the U.S. Senate just months before. I recognized Jerusalem as the capital of Israel. Shortly afterwards
column3: dozens of countries voted in the United Nations General Assembly against America's sovereign right to make this decision. In 2016
column4: American taxpayers generously sent those same countries more than $20 billion in aid. That is why tonight I am asking Congress to pass legislation to help ensure American foreign-assistance dollars always serve American interests and only go to friends of America
column5: not enemies of America.

column1: As we strengthen friendships all around the world
column2: we are also restoring clarity about our adversaries. When the people of Iran rose up against the crimes of their corrupt dictatorship
column3: I did not stay silent. America stands with the people of Iran in their courageous struggle for freedom. I am asking Congress to address the fundamental flaws in the terrible Iran nuclear deal. My administration has also imposed tough sanctions on the communist and socialist dictatorships in Cuba and Venezuela.

column1: But no regime has oppressed its own citizens more totally or brutally than the cruel dictatorship in North Korea. North Korea's reckless pursuit of nuclear missiles could very soon threaten our homeland. We are waging a campaign of maximum pressure to prevent that from ever happening. Past experience has taught us that complacency and concessions only invite aggression and provocation. I will not repeat the mistakes of past administrations that got us into this very dangerous position. We need only look at the depraved character of the North Korean regime to understand the nature of the nuclear threat it could pose to America and to our allies.
Otto Warmbier was a hard-working student at the University of Virginia
column2: and a great student he was. On his way to study abroad in Asia
column3: Otto joined a tour to North Korea. At its conclusion
column4: this wonderful young man was arrested and charged with crimes against the state. After a shameful trial
column5: the dictatorship sentenced Otto to 15 years of hard labor
column6: before returning him to America last June
column7: horribly injured and on the verge of death. He passed away just days after his return.

column1: Otto's wonderful parents
column2: Fred and Cindy Warmbier
column3: are here with us tonight
column4: along with Otto's brother and sister
column5: Austin and Greta. Please. Incredible people. You are powerful witnesses to a menace that threatens our world
column6: and your strength truly inspires us all. Thank you very much. Thank you. Tonight we pledge to honor Otto's memory with total American resolve. Thank you.

column1: Finally ... thank you. We are joined by one more witness to the ominous nature of this regime. His name is Mr. Ji Sung-ho. In 1996
column2: Sung-ho was a starving boy in North Korea. One day
column3: he tried to steal coal from a railroad car to barter for a few scraps of food
column4: which were very hard to get. In the process
column5: he passed out on the train tracks
column6: exhausted from hunger. He woke up as a train ran over his limbs. He then endured multiple amputations without anything to dull the pain or the hurt. His brother and sister gave what little food they had to help him recover and ate dirt themselves
column7: permanently stunting their own growth.

column1: Later
column2: he was tortured by North Korean authorities after returning from a brief visit to China. His tormentors wanted to know if he'd met any Christians. He had
column3: and he resolved
column4: after that
column5: to be free. Sung-ho traveled thousands of miles on crutches all across China and Southeast Asia to freedom. Most of his family followed. His father was caught trying to escape and was tortured to death.

column1: Today
column2: he lives in Seoul
column3: where he rescues other defectors and broadcasts into North Korea what the regime fears most: the truth. Today
column4: he has a new leg. But
column5: Sung-ho
column6: I understand you still keep those old crutches as a reminder of how far you've come. Your great sacrifice is an inspiration to us all. Please. Thank you. Sung-ho's story is a testament to the yearning of every human soul to live in freedom.

column1: It was that same yearning for freedom that nearly 250 years ago gave birth to a special place called America. It was a small cluster of colonies caught between a great ocean and a vast wilderness. It was home to an incredible people with a revolutionary idea: that they could rule themselves; that they could chart their own destiny; and that
column2: together
column3: they could light up the entire world.

column1: That is what our country has always been about. That is what Americans have always stood for
column2: always strived for
column3: and always done. Atop the dome of this Capitol stands the statue of Freedom. She stands tall and dignified among the monuments to our ancestors who fought and lived and died to protect her: monuments to Washington and Jefferson and Lincoln and King. Memorials to the heroes of Yorktown and Saratoga; to young Americans who shed their blood on the shores of Normandy and the fields beyond; and others
column4: who went down in the waters of the Pacific and the skies all over Asia. And Freedom stands tall over one more monument: this one. This Capitolthis living monumentthis is the monument to the American people.We're a people whose heroes live not only in the past
column5: but all around us
column6: defending hope
column7: pride
column8: and defending the American way.

column1: They work in every trade. They sacrifice to raise a family. They care for our children at home. They defend our flag abroad. And they are strong moms and brave kids. They are firefighters and police officers and border agents
column2: medics and marines. But above all else
column3: they are Americans. And this Capitol
column4: this city
column5: this Nation
column6: belongs entirely to them. Our task is to respect them
column7: to listen to them
column8: to serve them
column9: to protect them
column10: and to always be worthy of them.

column1: Americans fill the world with art and music. They push the bounds of science and discovery. And they forever remind us of what we should never
column2: ever forget: The people dreamed this country
column3: the people built this country

Look, in closing, as we gather here tonight, the images of a violent mob assaulting this Capitol, desecrating our democracy, remain vivid in all our minds. Lives were put at risk  many of your lives. Lives were lost. Extraordinary courage was summoned. The insurrection was an existential crisis, a test of whether our democracy could survive. And it did.
But the struggle is far from over. The question of whether our democracy will long endure is both ancient and urgent, as old as our Republic, still vital today. Can our democracy deliver on its promise that all of us, created equal in the image of God, have a chance to lead lives of dignity, respect, and possibility?
